1	Magnetic Field Effect of Near-field Radiative Heat Transfer for SiC Nanowires/Plates	We demonstrate the near-field radiative transfer between two aligned SiC nanowires and plates under different magnetic field intensity, in which the Lorentz-Drude equations of dielectric constant tensor are proposed to describe the dielectric constant as magnetic field applied on the SiC structure. Using Local effective medium theory (EMT) and fluctuation-dissipation theorem, we evaluate the near-field radiation between SiC nanowires/plates with different filling ratio and gap distance under extent magnetic field. Compared to the near-field heat flux between two SiC plates, the one between SiC nanowires can be enhanced with magnetic field intensity, high filling ratio and small gap distance. The results of this work can further improve the study of near-field radiative transfer and beneficial to explore more approaches to enact the near field radiative transfer of nanostructure.
2	<strong>Plasmonic nanoparticle lithography: Fast resist-free laser technique for large-scale sub-50 nm hole array fabrication</strong>	Cheap large-scale fabrication of ordered nanostructures is important for multiple applications in photonics and biomedicine including optical filters, solar cells, protection marks, and membranes. Existing methods are either expensive or have strict limitations on the feature size and fabrication complexity. Here we present a new laser-based technique, plasmonic nanoparticle lithography, which is capable of rapid fabrication of large-scale arrays of sub-50 nm holes on various substrates. It is based on near-field enhancement and melting induced under ordered arrays of plasmonic nanoparticles, which are brought in contact or in close proximity with a desired material and acting as optical near-field lenses. The nanoparticles are arranged in ordered patterns on a flexible substrate and can be attached and removed from the patterned sample surface. They are not affected by the patterning process and can be reused multiple times as permanent near-field masks. This new resist-free nanolithography technique provides a simple and cheap solution for large-scale nanofabrication.
3	<strong>Spin coating of silver nanoparticle ink for semi-transparent and colored solar cells</strong>	This letter reports on the fabrication of colored and semi-transparent silver nanoparticle layers, and their optical properties for use in semi-transparent solar cell applications. A spin coating method, using silver nanoparticle inks (nanoinks), is used to deposit silver nanoparticle layers onto substrates. The transmittance, reflectance, and color of the silver nanoparticle layers, spin-coated with nanoinks, are significantly dependent on the spin speed and the nanoink concentration. However, similar optical effects do not occur with typical silver colloids. With semi-transparent silver nanoparticle layers, transmittances of over 20 % at visible light wavelength are obtained by increasing the spin speed. Different nanoink concentrations cause variations in the size and distribution of the nanoparticles, which significantly changes the optical properties of the silver nanoparticle layer. These results are associated with the excitation of the dipole or quadruple plasmon modes of the nanoparticles. The characteristic properties of the silver nanoparticles lead to a color variation of the substrates on which the nanoparticles are spin-coated. Furthermore, both color variation and efficiency improvement via light trapping are achieved with the application of silver nanoparticles to semi-transparent Si thin film solar cells. This concept, based on a metal plasmonic layer, fundamentally differs from the application of the color adjusting oxide films, which only induce color variation by the control of optical interference with different film thicknesses. The beneficial effect of spin-coated silver nanoparticle layers can be applied to other semi-transparent photovoltaic devices, due to the simplicity and the cost-effectiveness of the spin coating method.
4	Substrate-molecule decoupling induced by self-assembly &ndash; Implications for graphene nanoribbon fabrication	Interactions between conjugated organic molecules and metal surfaces are often very strong, resulting in extensive hybridization between the molecule and surface and the loss of well-defined frontier orbitals on the molecule. In this Letter, we use density functional theory calculations to show that, for the case of graphene nanoribbon precursor molecules adsorbed to copper surfaces <em>via</em> van der Waals forces, the surface-molecule interaction is weakened upon molecular self-assembly. This phenomenon, which we abbreviate as SAID (Self-Assembly Induced Decoupling), results in a partial recovery of frontier orbital density on the molecules. The SAID phenomenon opens a new topic in the field of organic-metal interface physics, and may have broader implications for thin film devices and catalysis.
5	Essential role of enhanced surface electron-phonon interaction on electrical transport of suspended polycrystalline gold nanofilms	The electrical resistivity of suspended polycrystalline gold nanofilms with different length has been measured in a temperature range of 2 K to 340 K, which dramatically increases compared with bulk gold and slightly increases with length. The classical size effect theories considering surface and grain boundary scatterings cannot explain the increased film resistivity, especially the temperature dependence of resistivity, in the whole temperature range. Considering the fact that the reduction of the coordination number of atoms at the surface and the interface leads to a decrease of the phonon spectrum frequency and consequently affects the surface phonon spectrum, the electron-phonon interaction as a relatively independent surface effect is taken into account. The theoretical predictions and the experimental measured film resistivity match very well in the whole temperature range and the extracted surface Debye temperature decreases significantly compared to the bulk value, which illustrates the essential role of enhanced surface electron-phonon interaction on electrical transport of the present gold nanofilms.
6	<strong>Fabrication of controllably variable sub-100 nm gaps in silver nanowires by photothermal-induced stress</strong>	A technique to fabricate nanogaps with controllably variable gap width in silver (Ag) nanowires (NWs) by photothermal-induced stress utilizing a focused continuous wave laser (532 nm) is presented. For the case of an Ag NW on gold thin film, a gap width starting from ~ 20 nm is achieved with a critical minimum power (CMP) of about 160 mW. Whereas in case of an Ag NW placed on top of a ZnO NW, the attained gap width is as small as a few nm (&lt; 10 nm) with a CMP of only ~ 100 mW. In both cases, the CMP is much lower as compared to the required CMP (~ 280 mW) for an Ag NW placed on a bare silica substrate. The photothermal-induced stress along with melting/sublimation of silver aids in breaking the Ag NW. In particular, the former one plays a key role in attaining extremely narrow gap. This technique to fabricate sub-100 nm nanogaps in metal NWs can be extensively implemented in fabrication and maintenance of nanomechanical, nanoplasmonic and nanoelectronic devices.
7	<strong>Resistive Switching study in HfO<sub>2</sub> based OxRAM by Conductive Atomic Force Microscopy in Vacuum</strong>	This study aims to characterize the oxide based Resistive Random Access Memory (OxRAM) memory cell at nanoscale. Resistive memory stacks were characterized by conductive atomic force microscopy (C-AFM) under vacuum. The AFM tips served as top electrode. The effect of different tip material, polarity, bottom electrode and compliance current on resistive switching are described and compared with results obtained for devices at micrometric scale. The experimental results are then interpreted by a filament based model. An interpretation in term of conductive filament geometry is finally given.
8	<strong>Effect of CNT coating on the overall thermal conductivity of unidirectional polymer hybrid nanocomposites</strong>	The role of carbon nanotube (CNT) coating on the carbon fiber (CF) surfaces in the effective thermal conductivities of the unidirectional polymer hybrid nanocomposites is investigated by a newly presented multi-stage micromechanical method. The constructional feature of the hybrid nanocomposite is that randomly oriented CNTs grown on the CF surfaces. For simulating, a new version of the semi-empirical Halpin-Tsai (H-T) model is appropriately coupled with an analytical unit cell micromechanical model developed in the present research. The model captures the influences of the CNTs random dispersion, waviness, length, diameter, volume fraction and the CNT/polymer interfacial thermal resistance and also the CF cross-section shape parameters. The predicted results for the thermal conductivities of fibrous composites and polymer nanocomposites containing CNTs are verified with the available experimental data and a very good agreement is found. The results show that the longitudinal thermal conductivity of CF-reinforced hybrid nanocomposites is not affected by the CNTs coating. However, the nanocomposites transverse thermal conductivities are significantly enhanced over those of the conventional fibrous composites without the CNTs coating. An improvement in the nanocomposites transverse thermal conducting behavior can be observed with (i) increasing the CNTs volume fraction and length (ii) using straight CNTs and (iii) forming a perfect bonding interface.
9	<strong>Lattice thermal conductivity of graphitic carbon nanoparticles derived from pyrolytic glucose</strong>	The lattice thermal conductivity is reported for graphitic carbon nanoparticles (GCPs) carbonized from glucose by the solid-state pyrolysis route. Both the out-of-plane and the in-plane coherence length are calculated to increase with the carbonization temperature ranging from 700 &deg;C to 1200 &deg;C. Temperature and excitation power dependent Raman scattering measurements are performed to understand the thermal conductivity of GCPs related to the G-peaks. Unexpectedly, the thermal conductivities of the polymeric nanocomposites based on GCPs are also strongly dependent on the graphitization levels of GCPs, and a clear signature of thermal percolation threshold can be found.
10	Note: On the dielectric constant of nanoconfined water	Investigations of dielectric properties of water in nanoconfinement arehighly relevant for various applications. Here, using a simple capacitor model,we show that the low dielectric constant of nanoconfined water found inmolecular dynamics simulations can be largely explained by the so-calleddielectric dead-layer effect known for ferroelectric nanocapacitors.
11	Reversal time of jump-noise driven magnetization dynamics in nanomagnets via Monte Carlo simulations	The jump-noise is a nonhomogeneous Poisson process which models thermal e&#xFB00;ects in magnetization dynamics, with special applications in low temperature escape rate phenomena. In this work, we develop improved numerical methods for Monte Carlo simulation of jump-noise dynamics, and validate the method by comparing the stationary distribution obtained numerically against the analytic Boltzmann distribution. In accordance with the Ne&eacute;l-Brown theory, jump-noise dynamics display an exponential relaxation toward equilibrium with a characteristic reversal time, which we extract for nanomagnets with uniaxial and cubic anisotropy. We also identify an analytic upper bound on the strength of jump-noise: this bound establishes the regime of small noise in which an equivalent Gilbert damping coe&#xFB03;cient can be de&#xFB01;ned within the classical framework of magnetization dynamics.
12	<strong>Hierarchical Ag nanostructures on Sn-doped indium oxide nano-branches: Super hydrophobic surface for surface-enhanced Raman scattering</strong>	Herein, we fabricated a super-hydrophobic SERS substrate using Sn-doped indium oxide (Indium-tin-oxide: ITO) nano-branches as a template. ITO nano-branches with tens of nanometer diameter are first fabricated through the vapor-liquid-solid (VLS) growth to provide roughness of the substrate. 10nm thickness of Ag thin film was deposited and then treated with the post-annealing process to create numerous air-pockets in the Ag film, forming a hierarchical Ag nanostructures. The resulting substrate obtained Cassie&rsquo;s wetting property with a water contact angle of 151<sup>&ordm;</sup>. Compared to the normal hydrophobic Ag nanoparticle substrate, increase of about 4.25-fold higher SERS signal was obtained for 7&mu;L of rhodamine 6G aqueous solutions.
13	The role of defects in the simple cubic phase of the C82 nano-crystal by using Ewald method	In conjunction with the local- field method and Ewald method, the complex non-Hermitian dielectric tensor is theoretically calculated by using Su-Schrieffer-Heeger (SSH) model for the simple cubic (sc) phase of the C82 crystal with it defects. Via removing the hexagonal and the pentagon next to each other, the dielectric tensor changed and defects affect the optical properties of the C82 crystal. The removal of atoms or the C82 defected crystal reduces the intensity of the optical spectrum.
14	Molecular Dynamics Simulation for the impact of the Electric Field on the water condensation on the wall	A detailed analysis of the effects of the electric field (EF) intensity and the surface wettability on the condensation of the water on the wall is performed by Molecular dynamics simulations. The existence of the EF leads to the reorientation of the dipole moment of water molecules. The water molecules tend to the direction of the EF with its strength increasing. As leads to the morphology of the droplet condensed on the surface transforming from ellipsoid to nanocolumnar. The density of the clusters formed on the wall is affected by the EF. In addition, the deposition of water molecules on the surface will be suppressed with the EF to bate the energy exchange between the molecules and the wall. This leads to cutting down the rate of condensation. The strength of the wettability of the surface enhances the resistance of the wall for the reorientation of the dipole moment of water molecules. Moreover, the EF strength required for making the cluster deform will rise, and the rate of deposition of water molecules on the surface is suppressed as the EF elevates.
15	Analysis of Zn Substitution on Structure, Optical Absorption, Magnetization and High Temperature Specific Heat Anomaly of the Nano-Crystalline LaFeO<sub>3</sub>	Nano-crystalline LaFe<sub>1-x</sub>Zn<sub>x</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (0 &le; x &le; 0.3) samples synthesized through sol-gel auto combustion technique have been studied. X-ray diffraction patterns reveal that the nanoparticles have orthorhombic crystal structure and exist in single phase with Zn doping.&nbsp; Bond lengths and bond angles change with concentration, leading to the modification of parent structure; the change in structure is reflected in the thermal measurements too. Optical properties have been studied using infra red spectroscopy in the wave number range of 400cm<sup>-1</sup>-4000 cm<sup>-1 </sup>and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy in the wavelength range of 200nm-800nm. FTIR spectra show two strong active vibrational bands present at 564 cm<sup>-1</sup> and 410 cm<sup>-1</sup>, that are related to the functional groups present in the material. Optical bandgap has been determined and is found to decrease with the increase in concentration of Zn. The optical band gap lies in the range of 2.5eV-2.2eV. Raman study rules out the symmetry breaking or any other structural phase transition in the system. The Raman spectra reveal the strain present in the samples on increasing the concentration of Zn doping.&nbsp; The variation of specific heat at wide temperature range 30<sup>o</sup>C-900<sup>o</sup>C is reported. Specific heat has been found to be sensitive to magnetic ordering. The Neel temperature has been decreased with increasing Zn concentration from 411<sup>o</sup>C to 377<sup>o</sup>C, which is concomitant with the Rietveld analysis. Decreased density of material in&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; LaFe<sub>1-x</sub>Zn<sub>x</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples leads to the increased specific heat. Hysteresis loops indicate that Zn doping increases the magnetic moment and decreases the coercivity.
16	<strong>Brillouin light scattering investigation of interfacial Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction in ultrathin Co/Pt nanostripe arrays </strong>	Interface Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction (iDMI) is known to induce spin-waves non-reciprocity in ultrathin films. Indeed, Brillouin light scattering has been used to investigate how the lateral size reduction can affect the iDMI constant in Pt (6 nm)/Co (3 nm) based-nanostripe arrays. For this, 100 and 300 nm-width nanostripes have been fabricated using e-beam lithography and ion etching, and their behaviour has then been compared to a reference continuous film. The experimental data showed that the measured iDMI induced non-reciprocity is slightly different for the 100 nm-width nanostripes with respect to the other samples. This suggests that the width of the nanostripes can influence the strength of the apparent iDMI if this dimension is comparable to the spin waves attenuation length propagating within the nanostripes. Indeed, in contrast to the other samples, the linear frequency difference (non-reciprocity) behaviour versus wavenumber for the 100 nm-width nanostripes has been analysed and discussed through two approaches: either different iDMI constant or iDMI constant similar to one of the continuous film with a non-zero intercept for zero wavenumber.
17	Nanoscale stickiness of the hydrogen bond	The exclusion of water molecules surrounding a hydrogen bond modulates the dielectric response, thereby strengthening the underlying electrostatics. Thus, a nanoscale stickiness to nonpolar materials is apparent and has a mechanical equivalent accessible to molecular force probes. This "wrapping drag" is known to drive fundamental biological processes but its physical underpinnings have been lacking. As shown, quantification of the dielectric modulation requires a nanoscale dielectric theory and a thermodynamic ansatz yielding the reversible work required to unwrap a hydrogen bond. Theoretical computation and experimental validation of this parameter result from reconciliation of discrete molecular behavior with continuum electrostatics laws.
18	Static strain tuning of quantum dots embedded in a photonic wire	We use strain to statically tune the semiconductor band gap of individual InAs quantum dots (QDs) embedded in a GaAs photonic wire featuring very efficient single photon collection efficiency. Thanks to the geometry of the structure, we are able to shift the QD excitonic transition by more than 20 meV by using nano-manipulators to apply the stress. Moreover, owing to the strong transverse strain gradient generated in the structure, we can relatively tune two QDs located in the wire waveguide and bring them in resonance, opening the way to the observation of collective effects such as superradiance.
19	Measurement of anisotropic thermal conductivity of a dense forest ofsnanowires using the 3w method	The 3w method is a dynamic measurement technique developed for determining the thermal conductivity of thin films or semi-infinite bulk materials. A simplified model is often applied to deduce the thermal conductivity from the slope of the real part of the ac temperature amplitude as a function of the logarithm of frequency, which in-turn brings a limitation on the kind of samples under observation. In this work, we have measured the thermal conductivity of a forest of nanowires embedded in nanoporous alumina membranes using the 3w method. An analytical solution of 2D heat conduction is then used to model the multilayerssystem, considering the anisotropic thermal properties of the different layers, substrate thermal conductivity and their thicknesses. Data treatment is performed by fitting the experimental results with the 2D model on two different sets of nanowires (silicon and BiSbTe) embedded in the matrix of nanoporous alumina template, having thermal conductivities that differ by at least one order of magnitude. These experimental results show that this method extends the applicability of the 3! technique to more complex systems having anisotropicsthermally properties.
20	Interaction energy of a pair of identical coplanar uniformly charged nanodisks	We consider a nanosystem consisting of two coplanar uniformly charged nanodisks that are coupled via Coulomb forces. Such a model represents a typical situation encountered in two-dimensional semiconductor quantum dot systems of electrons.sWe provide an exact integral expression for the interaction energy between the two coplanar nanodisks as a function of their separation distance.sIt is found that the difference between a standard Coulomb potential and the current one has features reminiscent of a Lennard-Jones interaction potential.sThe results derived can be useful to understand formation of clusters and/or aggregates in systems of coplanar charged nanodisks that contain electrons.
21	Two-stage DNA compaction induced by silver ions suggests a cooperative binding mechanism	The interaction between silver ions and DNA plays an important role in therapeutic use of silver ions and in related technologies such as DNA sensors. However, the underlying mechanism has not been fully understood. In this study, the dynamics of Ag<sup>+</sup>-DNA interaction at a single-molecule level was studied using magnetic tweezers. AgNO<sub>3 </sub>solutions with concentrations ranging from 1 &#x00B5;M to 20 &#x00B5;M led to a 1.4-1.8 &#x00B5;m decrease in length of a single &#x03BB;-DNA molecule, indicating that Ag<sup>+</sup> has a strong binding with DNA, causing the DNA conformational change. The compaction process comprises one linear declining stage and another sigmoid-shaped stage, which can be attributed to the interaction mechanism. Considering cooperative effect, the sigmoid trend was well-explained using a phenomenological model. In contrast, addition of silver nanoparticle solution induced no detectable transition of DNA. The dependence of the interaction on ionic strength and DNA concentration were examined via morphology characterization and particle size distribution measurements. The size of the Ag<sup>+</sup> -DNA complex decreased with increase in Ag ionic strength ranging from 1 &#x00B5;M to 1 mM. Morphology characterization confirmed that silver ions induced DNA to adopt a compacted globular conformation. At a fixed [AgNO3]:[DNA base pairs] ratio, increasing DNA concentration led to increased sizes of the complexes. Intermolecular interaction is believed to affect the Ag<sup>+</sup>-DNA complex formation to a large extent.
22	Inhibition of High Shear Arterial Thrombosis by Charged Nanoparticles	Platelet accumulation under high shear rates at the site of atherosclerotic plaque rupture leads to myocardial infarction and stroke. Current antiplatelet therapies remain ineffective within a large percentage of the population, while presenting significant risks for bleeding. We explore a novel way to inhibit arterial thrombus formation by biophysical means without the use of platelet inactivating drugs. Our computational multi-scale dynamics model has identified that charged particles of a specific size can entangle vWF polymers and reduce the amount of elongation at high shear rates. We tested these predictions using negatively charged nanoparticles (CNP) to inhibit arterial thrombus formation. CNP of a particular size and charge inhibited thrombus formation, with a 10-fold peak inhibition over control conditions of thrombotic occlusion. Particles of differing material composition, size, and charge had little effect as predicted by computational studies. This study demonstrates a new antithrombotic agent with potentially greater safety and efficacy than current pharmaceutical therapies.
23	Unexpected large nanoparticle size of single dimer hotspot systems for broadband SERS enhancement	We have numerically demonstrated the feasibility and possibility to achieve broadband surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) enhancement in the visible and near-infrared wavelength range using single nanoparticle (NP) dimer hotspot systems. Instead of the conventionally reported sub-100 nm, we find that the optimal NP size is as large as 200 nm in diameter for both Ag and Au. The key lies in the continuous arising of the bonding dipole plasmon (BDP) mode and higher-order resonances at shorter wavelengths. Further, it is revealed that the near- and far-field optical responses of these hotspot systems correlate well with each other, despite of the intrinsic enormous near- to far-field redshift for individual large NPs. The physical principles demonstrated here benefit significantly the fundamental understanding and engineering optimization of broadband SERS substrates.
24	Response to Comment on "Water-processed carbon nanotube/graphene hybrids with enhanced field emission properties"	In this response, we explain the points mentioned by R. Rani and R. Bhatia in their Comment for our previous paper [AIP Advances 5, 097130 (2015); Ref. 1], that the high value of &#x03B2; obtained in Ref. 1 is misleading because it does not corroborate with the obtained Jmax, and the obtained value of Jmax is "low" in the mentioned study as compared to the reported values [J. Appl. Phys. 111, 044307 (2012) & Appl. Phys. Lett. 102, 033102 (2013); Ref. 2 & 3]. For the high value of &#x03B2;, the obtained current Jmax is corroborated but such high value is mainly due to the multistage effect when CNTs are deposited on the rough surface of reduced graphene. For the "low" Jmax, although this is true when compared with Ref. 2 and 3, but we believe that our value is a generally common value when compared with other reports [Diam. Relat. Mater. 47, 1 (2014); J. Alloys Compd. 610, 659 (2014); J. Nanomater. 2013, 5239 (2013); Ref. 4-6] using the similar method as described in Ref. 1. Therefore, the conclusions from the experimental results on field emission performance of CNT/graphene composite materials in Ref. 1 are reliable.
25	<strong>Guided mode resonance of nanoantenna to achieve enhanced Raman signal from blu-ray DVD</strong><strong>Guided mode resonance of nanoantenna to achieve enhanced Raman signal from blu-ray DVD</strong>	We report here the working of a simple yet highly reproducible surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) substrate by efficiently guiding localized plasmon resonance mode from metal nanoantenna by trapping it in the channels of a blu-ray digital versatile disc (BR-DVD). The patterned structure of a blank BR-DVD which is made of polycarbonate material has a periodicity of 320nm with channel width of 100nm. Due to high refractive index (1.58) of the material, the locally generated resonance electromagnetic field in metal nanoparticles is efficiently guided by the channel of the disc. This would cause an overall enhancement of Raman signal intensity for any SERS based sensing studies. Using the proposed substrate, SERS based studies have been performed for two commonly used chemicals.
26	Enhanced chemotherapeutic efficacy of the low-dose doxorubicin in breast cancer via nanoparticle delivery system cross-linked hyaluronic acid	Despite the development of treatment options in breast cancer, many patients died of recurrence and metastasis. Owing to enhanced permeability and retention effect in solid tumor tissue, nanoparticles delivery systems have been emerged as novel strategy in cancer chemotherapy. As extracellular matrix glycosamino-glycan hyaluronan (HA) could bind its surface receptor adhesion molecule CD44 which strongly expressed on breast cancer. We have previously reported a DOX-loaded HA-Lys-LA X-NPs (X-NP-DOX) nanoparticles delivery system for breast cancer treatment. In the present study, we further investigated the antitumor effect of X-NP-DOX nanoparticles delivery system using low-dose DOX in both in vitro and in vivo systems. We demonstrated that low-dose X-NP-DOX possessed the ability for inhibiting MCF-7 breast cancer cell growth, invasion and migration, and inducing apoptosis in vitro. In in vivo experiments, injection of low-dose X-NP-DOX into tumor-bearing mouse resulted in significant reduction of tumor size. TUNEL staining further revealed that low-dose X-NP-DOX induced higher percentage of apoptotic cells compared with free DOX or Saline. Furthermore, our study demonstrated that low-dose X-NP-DOX inhibited Notch1 and Ras/MAPK pathways, decreased cancer stem cells (CSCs) population, reduced tumorigenesis compared to free DOX in both in vitro or in vivo settings. Owing to its enhanced efficacy and higher targetability compared to free DOX, low-dose DOX delivered by nanoparticle system may be a promising novel strategy for breast cancer treatment.
27	AC impedance spectroscopy response of the effect of the modifier carbon chain length on the dielectric properties of Ag@TiO<sub>2</sub>/poly(vinylidene fluoride) nanocomposites	In this letter, poly (vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF)-based nanocomposites filled with surface-functionalized Ag@TiO<sub>2</sub> core-shell nanoparticles were fabricated. High dielectric permittivity was realized by introducing Ag@TiO<sub>2</sub> core-shell nanoparticles into the PVDF. Using two phosphonic acids surfactants with different carbon&nbsp;chain&nbsp;lengths, octyl and octadecyl phosphonic acid, we modified the filler surface to improve the dispersion of the core-shell filler in the PVDF. Experimental results showed that the dielectric constant of the composite containing fillers modified by octyl phosphonic acid (148 at 1 KHz) was almost three times higher than that modified by octadecyl phosphonic acid (58 at 1 KHz) at the same filler loading. By introducing a circuit model based on AC impedance spectroscopy (AC-IS), we analyzed the mechanism of interfacial polarization between the modified core-shell filler and polymer matrix.
28	Study on A New Self-sensing Magneto-rheological Elastomer Bearing	The complexity of a semi-active vibration isolation system makes it could be difficult to play the role effectively on the impact load. A new self-sensing bearing based on the modified anisotropic magneto-rheological elastomer (MRE) which fabricated by dispersed multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) and carbonyl iron particles (CIPs) into polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) matrix under a magnetic field was proposed. Firstly, the working conditions of bearing were analyzed and decoupled, an optimal structure size of bearing was selected and used for the build-up the experiment test system. Then, the self-sensing characteristic of the MRE bearing under the multi-field-coupling of load and magnetic fields was investigated by this test system. The results showed that the resistance of the modified MRE which has been applied a preload by the bearing also can be changed about 28%~56% under the extrusion force, mechanical force and external magnetic field. Finally, the mechanical properties of the magneto-rheological elastomer bearing (MRB) was also tested, and the stiffness and damping can increase 1~2.7 and 1~2.37 times under the external controlled current, respectively. This study confirms that the modified MRE of the MRB are potentially capable of being used as actuator and sensor simultaneously.
29	Magnetic polymer nanocomposites based on polyvinylidenefluoride (PVDF) and magnetite (Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>) nanoparticles &nbsp;for the absorption of high frequency electromagnetic waves	<em>In the presented work nanocomposites based on polyvinylidenefluoride (PVDF) and </em><em>magnetic </em><em>Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4&nbsp; </sub></em><em>nanoparticles </em><em>were prepared</em><em>. The structure and content of nanocomposite materials were studied by using SEM, TEM, AFM and X-Ray phase analysis. Magnetic properties of </em><em>PVDF+Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4&nbsp; </sub></em><em>nanocomposites have been studied&nbsp; upon increasing nanoparticle content in polymer matrix up to 20%,&nbsp; revealing a superparamagnetic behaviour as </em><em>Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4 </sub></em><em>nanoparticles in polymer matrix act out like single-domain particles. It has also been observed that, </em><em>PVDF+Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub></em><em> based nanocomposites can absorb the electromagnetic waves in the high frequency range 0,1-30 GHz. </em><em>It has been shown that </em><em>the absorption of electromagnetic waves by PVDF+</em><em>Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub></em><em> nanocomposites can be explained by the different molecular structures and also by the scattering of the electromagnetic waves at the boundary of nanoparticle-polymer matrix. It has been established that due to the different Maxwell relaxation times of the nanocomposite components, the energy refraction at the interface of two components is increased.</em>
30	A comparative study on phase locking of spin transfer nano-oscillators using commonsmicrowave sources	Phase-locking or synchronization is a typical nonlinear phenomenon which can be achieved insvery many ways. One of the most prominent ways of achieving it is by injection locking, that isslocking the oscillations to an external applied oscillating source of frequency nearly equal to thesoscillator frequency. For a spin transfer nano oscillator (STNO), one can apply an external sourcesby means of two ways: they are (i) through an alternating spin current and (ii) through an externalsmicrowave magnetic field. We have compared both the above methods of phase-locking by studyingsthe synchronization of STNOs and made a critical comparison to show the effectiveness of usingsmicrowave magnetic field as an external driving source.
31	<strong>Shape-memory photonic metamaterial</strong>	Non-volatile temperature-induced structural phase transitions such as those found in &nbsp;chalcogenide glasses and chalcogenide-based nanostructures are known to lead to strong changes in their optical properties and are widely used in rewritable optical disk technology. Here, for the first time, we demonstrate that thermally-activated optical memory can be achieved with a fully metallic plasmonic metamaterial made from shape memory alloy. A Nickel Titanium film of nanoscale thickness structured on the subwavelength scale exhibits bistability of its optical properties upon temperature cycling between 30 &deg;C and 210 &deg;C. The structure which consists of an array of NiTi nanowires covered with a nanoscale thickness gold layer to enhance its plasmonic properties, shows two non-volatile states with an optical reflectivity difference of 12% associated with the nanoscale displacements of alternating nanowires in the structure. We argue that robust, all-metal shape memory photonic metamaterials can find applications in bistable optical devices.
32	<strong>Development of </strong><strong>solid-solid bonding with the super</strong> <strong>thickness of </strong><strong>porous </strong><strong>Ag in die-attached modules structure</strong>	Bonding technology with a super thickness (500&micro;m) of die-attached bonding layer was developed by using solid porous Ag in the die-attached module structure. In this technology, solid porous Ag structures was fabricated by sintering Ag-paste, the interface between two solid porous Ag were bonded together with the hillocks growth as well as Ag nanoparticles formation. The interface connection ratio achieved almost 90 % and the bonding strength over 30 MPa in the die-attached module structure. Most important, bonding strength did not change with the thickness of die-attached bonding layers various from 100 &micro;m to 500 &micro;m. Finite element simulation analyses confirmed that an increase of the bonding layer thickness will lead to a significant decrease of the occurred stress in the die-attached module structure. It provided a new bonding technology based on the solid porous Ag structure especially a method to fabricate the thicker die-attached bonding layer in the die-attached module structure for its high temperature applications.
33	Investigation of the expansion dynamics of silicon plasmas generated by double nanosecond laser pulses	A systematic investigation of the expansion dynamics of plasma plumes generated by two Q-switched Nd:YAG lasers at 1064 nm wavelength operating on a silicon target was undertaken for the inter-pulse delay times of 0, 100, 200, and 400 ns using a technique involving fast-gated intensified charge-coupled device imaging. Our results indicate that the plasmas exhibit free expansion in a vacuum environment at an inter-pulse delay time of 0 ns. With increasing inter-pulse delay time, the plasma front becomes sharpened and an interaction boundary is formed. Moreover, using to the radiation intensity distribution along the plasma axis of symmetry, the formation and evolution mechanism of the plasmas generated by the double pulses was analyzed at different inter-pulse delay times. Finally, the experimental results of the expansion of the plasma core and front were compared with a radiation hydrodynamics model and a drag model, and were found to be generally in good agreement.
34	Quantitative Comparison of Closed-Loop and Dual Harmonic Kelvin Probe Force Microscopy Techniques	Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) is a widely used technique to map surface potentials at the nanometer scale. In traditional KPFM, a feedback loop regulates the DC bias applied between a sharp conductive probe and sample to nullify the electrostatic force (closed-loop operation). In comparison, open-loop techniques such as dual harmonic KPFM (DH-KPFM) are simpler to implement, less sensitive to artefacts and offer the unique ability to probe voltage sensitive materials and operate in liquid environments. Here, we directly compare the two techniques in terms of their bandwidth and sensitivity to instrumentation artefacts. Furthermore, we introduce a new correction for traditional KPFM termed 'setpoint correction', which allows us to obtain agreement between open and closed-loop techniques within 1%. Quantitative validation of DH-KPFM may lead to a wider adoption of open-loop KPFM techniques by the scanning probe community.
35	Analytical Study On Effects Of Mn Substitution In Cobalt Ferrite	Ferrites are usually ferromagnetic materials consisting of iron oxide phases combined with one or more metallic oxides. They are being now used in diversified fields owing to possibility of synthesizing them in the form of nanoparticles. Cobalt ferrites are best known candidate for use in various sensor applications. Recently Mn2+ doped Cobalt ferrites have received renewed attention for understanding of their tenable behavior and tuning of fundamental magnetic properties to optimize them in advanced applications as revealed from various literature reviews. Three compositions of Mn doped Cobalt ferrites have undertaken for analytical study to understand effects of Mn substitutions on their fundamental magnetic properties. Impact of Mn content on lattice constant, hoping and bond lengths, magnetic moment, Curie temperature and porosity has been discussed in this analytical study to predict the controlling of magnetization, magnetomechanical property and superparamagnetism (SPM) by adjusting dopant content. The lattice constant found to decrease and effective magnetic moment &mu; to increase with the Mn content, substituted for Co, which may be significant to the tunability of the Curie temperature, TC and have influence on SPM. On the other hand, the compositions where Mn substituted for Fe may increase the porosity due to their increased bond lengths with Mn content and thus may optimize them for applications in gas sensors. However, the analysis and findings are completely based on theoretical aspect in this paper and needs verification experimentally to confirm and supplement the prediction.
36	<strong>Enhanced thermoelectric performance through grain boundary engineering in quaternary chalcogenide Cu<sub>2</sub>ZnSnSe<sub>4</sub></strong>	Quaternary chalcognide Cu<sub>2</sub>ZnSnSe<sub>4</sub> (CZTSe) is a promising wide band-gap p-type thermoelectric material. The structure and thermoelectric properties of lead substituted Cu<sub>2</sub>ZnSn<sub>1-x</sub>Pb<sub>x</sub>Se<sub>4</sub> are investigated. Lead primarily exists in the framework of PbSe as demonstrated by x-ray diffraction and calculation of x-ray absorption near-edge structure spectroscopy. The second phase distributes at the boundaries of CZTSe with thickness in several hundreds of nanometer. With appropriate grain boundary engineering, the enhancement of power factor and a decrease of thermal conductivity can be achieved simultaneously. As a result, a maximum figure of merit zT of 0.45 is obtained for the sample with x=0.02 at 723K.
37	Strong Correlation between the Magnetocaloric Properties of Nanotubes of La0.325Pr0.3Ca0.375MnO3 and their Diameters.	Under 0.01 T applied magnetic field variation, the calculation of magnetocaloric properties for 200 and 800 nm nanotubes of La0.325Pr0.3Ca0.375MnO3 (LPCMO) perovskite such as magnetic entropy change, full-width at half-maximum, relative cooling power, and magnetic specific heat change. MCE of 800 nm nanotubes of LPCMO is more than MCE of 800 nm ones. LPCMO nanotubes have hopeful application for MR in an extended high-temperature range due to high values of &#x03B4;TFWHM. Therefore, nanotubes of LPCMO are very significant for MR applications, especially nitrogen liquefier.
38	<strong>Low intrinsic c-axis thermal conductivity in PVD grown epitaxial Sb<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> films<sup></sup></strong>	Accurate determination and comprehensive understanding of the intrinsic c-axis thermal conductivity of thermoelectric layered Sb<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> is of high importance for the development of strategies to optimize the figure of merit in thin film devices via heterostructures and defect engineering. We present here high precision measurements of &nbsp;of epitaxial Sb<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> thin films on Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> substrates grown by physical vapor deposition (PVD) in the temperature range of 100 K to 300 K. The Kapitza resistances of the involved interfaces have been determined and subtracted from the film data, allowing access to the intrinsic thermal conductivity of single crystalline Sb<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub>. At room temperature, we obtain = 1.6 W/mK, being much smaller than the in-plane thermal conductivity of &nbsp;= 5 W/mK and even lower than the thermal conductivity of nanocrystalline films of k<sub>nc</sub> &asymp; 2.0-2.6 W/mK published by Park et al.[i]. High crystallinity and very low defect concentration of the films were confirmed by x-ray diffraction (XRD) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). Our data reveal that the phonon mean free path &nbsp;is not limited by defect scattering and is of intrinsic nature, i.e. due to phonon-phonon scattering similar to other soft van der Waals type bonded layered systems.s<p>[i] N.-W. Park, et al., <em>Nanoscale Res. Lett.</em> <strong>9</strong>, 96 (2014).
39	<strong>Characterization of Floating-gate Memory Device with Thiolate-Protected Gold and Gold-Palladium Nanoclusters</strong>	The floating-gate memory characteristics of thiolate-protected gold (Au:SR) and palladium doped Au (AuPd:SR) nanoclusters, Au<sub>25</sub>(SR)<sub>18</sub>, Au<sub>24</sub>Pd(SR)<sub>18</sub>, and Au<sub>38</sub>(SR)<sub>24</sub> (R = C<sub>12</sub>H<sub>25</sub>), were investigated by capacitance-voltage (<em>C&ndash;V</em>) measurements in vacuum. Monolayer films of Au:SR nanoclusters were formed as floating-gate memory layers on p-type Si substrates by the Langmuir-Schaefer method with surface pressure - area (&pi;-<em>A</em>) isotherm measurements. A fluoropolymer (CYTOP, ~15 nm thick) was spin-coated on top to form a hydrophobic insulating layer. Using an Au pad (~40 nm thick) as the gate electrode, <em>C&ndash;V</em> measurements exhibit clockwise hysteresis curves originating from the Au:SR and AuPd:SR nanoclusters against the reference measured in each sample, and the hysteresis widths were dependent on the composition and sizes of the Au:SR nanoclusters. The positive and negative voltage shifts in the hysteresis can be explained in terms of electronic structures in Au:SR and AuPd:SR-based devices.
40	A novel bonding method for fabrication of PMMA nanofluidic chip with extremely low deformation of the nano-trenches	All PMMA-based nanofluidic chips are becoming increasingly important for biological and medical applications. To fabricate PMMA nanofluidic chips, the open nano-trenches should be sealed by thermal bonding method. However, the present thermal bonding method suffers from high deformation of nano-trenches due to PMMA softening near glass transition temperature. In this work, a novel bonding technique, based on acetone and ethanol (v:v, 8:2) treatment, is developed to adjust the Young's modulus of PMMA in its surface layer. By optimizing nanoimprinting and bonding process, PMMA nanofluidic chip was fabricated without undesired nano-trench deformation. The integrity of the enclosed PMMA nanofluidic system was verified by a fluorescence filling experiment.
41	A universal mechanism for enhancing the thermoelectricity of nanoribbons by branching	Inspired by the novel mechanism of reducing thermal conductivity by local phonon resonance instead of by inducing structural defects, we investigate the effect of side branching on the thermoelectric properties of $\rm{MoS_{2}}$ nanoribbons, and prove that side branching is a highly efficient mechanism for enhancing the thermoelectricity of different kinds of nanoribbons. For both armchair and zigzag $\rm{MoS_{2}}$ nanoribbons, the side branches result in not only significant reduction of thermal conductance but also notable increase of the Seebeck coefficient. Consequently, the thermoelectric figure of merit (ZT) of the armchair $\rm{MoS_{2}}$ nanoribbon is boosted from 0.72 to as high as 1.93, and the originally non-thermoelectric metallic zigzag $\rm{MoS_{2}}$ nanoribbon is turned into a thermoelectric material due to the appearance of the band gap induced by the side branches. These results mean that the mechanism of branching is not only very efficient, but also takes effect regardless of the original properties of the nanoribbons, and thus will hold great promise for its application in the thermoelectric field.
42	<strong>Strain engineering on electronic structure and carrier mobility in</strong><strong><strong>&nbsp;</strong></strong><strong><strong>monolayer GeP</strong></strong><strong><sub><strong>3</strong></sub></strong>	Using density functional theory coupled with Boltzmann transport equation with relaxation time approximation, we have studied the strain effect on the electronic structure and carrier mobility of two-dimensional (2D) monolayer GeP<sub>3</sub>.&nbsp;We find that the energies of valence&nbsp;band maximum and conduction&nbsp;band minimum are nearly linearly shifted with biaxial strain, and the band structure experience a remarkable transition from semiconductor to metal with appropriate compression (-5% strain). Under biaxial strain, the mobilities of electron and hole in monolayer GeP<sub>3</sub>&nbsp;reduce and increase by more than one&nbsp;order of magnitude,&nbsp;respectively.&nbsp;It is suggested&nbsp;that it is possible to perform successive transitions from <em>n</em>-type semiconductor (-4% strain)&nbsp;to good performance <em>p</em>-semiconductor (+6% strain)&nbsp;by applying strain in monolayer GeP<sub>3</sub>, which is potentially useful for flexible electronics&nbsp;and nanosized mechanical sensors.
43	<strong>Optical Extinction Efficiencies for Metallic Single Wall Carbon Nanotubes in the Infrared Spectral Region</strong>	The extinction efficiency (mass normalized extinction cross section) of a sample of metallic single wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) has been measured in the infrared spectral region. The tubes were obtained from Nano-Integris Inc. and measured while suspended in propanol. Calculation of the extinction efficiency based on a computational code for fibers of finite length shows good agreement with the experimental results. The computation involved convolution over the SWCNTs&rsquo; length and diameter distributions. The results emphasize the potential of SWCNTs as efficient obscurants of electromagnetic radiation in the infrared spectral region.
44	Phenomenological modelling of light transmission through nanowires arrays	A phenomenological model has been developed and is discussed. The model is able to describe the experimentally measured light transmission of nanowires arrays. A slab of nanospheres and rough layers with thickness waviness were combined to simplify the nanowires structure description. This phenomenological description was proven to be feasible by fitting experimental data. As a conclusion, light transmitted through randomly distributed nanowires can be explained by the combination of volume and surface scatterings using respectively Mie theory and rough Fresnel coefficients at the interfaces.
45	Novel facets of multifunctional Ag@Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>&nbsp;core-shell nanoparticles for multimodal imaging applications	Multifunctional biocompatible nanoparticles, with magnetic core and optically active shell, acting as multifunctional nanoparticles with core size 6 nm encapsulated by varying silver shell thickness were synthesized through novel single phase microemulsion method. Incorporation of silver shell on to the magnetite core enhances the intensity of highest luminescence peak observed for magnetite up to very significant luminescence enhancement factor. A blue photoluminescence (PL) peak observed in the visible region of spectrum, brighten further with the increase in the thickness of silver shell. The magnetic properties of these core- shell nanomaterials shows superparamagnetic behavior at room temperature, which is a mandatory criteria for MRI contrast enhancement agents. The hyperthermic response of synthesized magnetite nanoparticles elevates its temperature to 43&deg; C in a sharp span of time, which is above the desired temperature for therapeutic application of these multifunctional nanomaterials. &nbsp;These excellent optical and magnetic properties, in the material having size range suitable for cellular uptake, make it a potential candidate for both diagnostic and therapeutic use in biomedical applications.
46	Mg3F7: a superatom with potential for new nanomaterials design	The superhalogen features of polynuclear structures are theoretically investigated here for Mg3F7 clusters. At the CCSD(T) and OVGF level, the Mg3F7 cluster has been confirmed to be superhalogen due to its high electron affinity (7.9 eV). The corresponding daughter anionic species (Mg3F7&#x2212;) displays a highly symmetric (C3v) umbrella-like structure and magic cluster stability. The enlarged stability of the Mg3F7&#x2212; nonstoichiometric system is the result of its electronic shell saturation and superhalogen nature of its neutral parent. The extra electron of the Mg3F7&#x2212; anion aggregates on the terminal fluorine ligands with non-negligible distribution occurring on the bridging F units too. These two properties lower both the kinetic and potential energies of the extra electron respectively and thus lead to large electron binding energy. When interacting with the fullerene nanoparticle (C60), the radical neutral Mg3F7 superhalogen captures an electron and forms stable and strongly bound "binary salt" consisted of Mg3F7&#x2212; anion and C60&#x2022;+ radical cation. In other words, the C60Mg3F7 compound resembles a diatomic molecule with an ionic bond (such as sodium chloride). Thus Mg3F7 can be used as an effective oxidizing agent to construct new ionized nanomaterials.
47	Buongiorno's model for fluid flow of 3D Oldroyd-B magneto nanofluid with nonlinear thermal radiation-A series solution	This study examines the flow of 3D Oldroyd-B magneto nanofluid under the influence of nonlinear thermal radiation and convective heat and mass boundary conditions. Temperature dependent thermal conductivity with Joule heating and viscous dissipation are also added to novelty of the problem. Buongiorno's model featuring Brownian diffusion and thermophoresis is adopted here. Renowned Homotopy Analysis method (HAM) is adopted to obtain the convergent series solutions. Effects of varied arising parameters on involved distributions are reflected through graphical illustrations. From this study, it is perceived that strong magnetic field hinders the fluid motion and lead to rise in temperature that eventually lowers heat transfer rate from the surface. Further, decrease in heat transfer rate is also observed for enhanced values of thermal radiation parameter. Validation of presented results is done by comparing them with an already published paper and excellent consensus is achieved; thus trustworthy results are being presented.
48	<strong>Charge Transfer Dynamical Processes at Graphene-Transition Metal Oxides/Electrolyte Interface for Energy Storage: Insights from In-Situ Raman Spectroelectrochemistry</strong>	Electrochemical assembled hybrids consisting of two-dimensional supercapacitive functionalized graphene (graphene oxide; GO reduced graphene oxide; rGO multilayer graphene; MLG, electrochemically reduced GO; ErGO) and three-dimensional graphene scaffold (rGO<sub>HT</sub>; hydrothermally prepared) decorated with pseudocapacitive cobalt nanoparticles (CoNP), nanostructured cobalt oxide (CoO and Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>) and manganese oxide (MnO<sub>2</sub>) polymorphs, were prepared to facilitate chemically bridged interfaces with tunable properties. Since Raman spectroscopy can capture various spectral features, variations in chemical structural bonding, in-situ Raman spectroelectrochemistry is employed (1) to probe dynamical interfacial processes, (2) to monitor and quantify the spectral changes with successive redox reactions, and (3) to quantify the associated parameters including electron transfer properties. Raman spectroscopy can capture variations in structural bonding of &lsquo;hybrid&rsquo; electrodes in aqueous electrolytes with applied bias. The transverse optical (TO) and longitudinal optical (LO) phonons above 500 cm<sup>&minus;</sup><sup>1</sup> belonging to Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>, CoO and MnO<sub>2</sub> and carbon-carbon bonding (D, G, and 2D) bands occurring at 1340 cm<sup>-1</sup>, 1590 cm<sup>&minus;1</sup> and 2670 cm<sup>-1</sup>, respectively, are analyzed. Consistent quasi-reversible variation in Raman intensity and band position reveal structural modification, combination of charge transfer due to localized orbital re-hybridization and mechanical strain resulting in finely tuned electronic properties. Moreover, the heterogeneous basal and edge plane sites of graphene hybrids reinforce efficient interfacial electron transfer and available electronic density of states for enhanced performance. We estimated the extent and nature of charge transfer (n- or p-) complemented with Density Functional Theory calculations affected by hydration and demonstrating the synergistic coupling between graphene, cobalt (and manganese) oxide polymorphs for energy storage.
49	Freestanding Triboelectric-Structure based Three-Dimensional Spherical Nanogenerator	In this paper, we report a three-dimensional spherical triboelectric nanogenerator based on freestanding triboelectric-structure (FS-TENG) for converting full space mechanical energy into electric energy, which consists of freestanding polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) balls, a transparent spherical shell and aluminum conductive layers attached to the inner surface of the spherical shell. On the basis of the coupling of triboelectric and electrostatic effects, the potential difference between the conjugated aluminum electrodes is generated, can efficiently harvest the full space mechanical energy in all directions. The as-fabricated FS-TENG can deliver a maximal output voltage up to 120 V, and an instantaneous current of 0.4 &#x03BC;A, and a corresponding output power of 48 &#x03BC;W, which can be used to directly drive tens of blue light-emitting diodes. This study proves the possibility to harvest mechanical energy by FS-TENG from all directions for applications such as self-powered vibration sensors.
50	Plane shock loading on mono- and nano-crystalline silicon carbide	The understanding of the nanoscale mechanisms of shock damage and failure in SiC is essential for its application in effective and damage tolerant coatings. We use molecular-dynamics simulations to investigate the shock properties of 3C-SiC along low-index crystallographic directions and in nanocrystalline samples with 5 nm and 10 nm grain size. The predicted Hugoniot in the particle velocities range 0.1 km/s - 6.0 km/s agree well with experimental data. The shock response transitions from elastic to plastic, predominantly deformation twinning, to structural transformation to the rock-salt phase. Predicted strengths from 12.3 to 30.9 GPa, at the Hugoniot elastic limit, are in excellent agreement with experimental data.
51	Inter-layer and Intra-layer Heat Transfer in Bilayer/Monolayer Graphene van der Waals Heterostructure: Is There a Kapitza Resistance Analogous?	Van der Waals heterostructures have exhibited interesting physicalproperties. In this paper, heat transfer in hybrid coplanar bilayer/monolayer(BL-ML) graphene, as a model layered van der Waals heterostructure, was studiedusing non-equilibrium molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. Temperature profileand inter- and intra-layer heat fluxes of the BL-ML graphene indicated that,there is no fully developed thermal equilibrium between layers and the drop inaverage temperature profile at the step-like BL-ML interface is notattributable to the effect of Kapitza resistance. By increasing the length ofthe system up to 1 $\mu$m in the studied MD simulations, the thermallynon-equilibrium region was reduced to a small area near the step-likeinterface. All MD results were compared to a continuum model and a good matchwas observed between the two approaches. Our results provide a usefulunderstanding of heat transfer in nano- and micro-scale layered 2D materialsand van der Waals heterostructures.
52	<strong>MHD natural convection and thermal radiation of micropolar nanofluid within a porous enclosure including elliptic heater utilizing KKL model</strong>	This work studies the natural convection heat transfer and thermal radiation of micropolar nanofluid within a porous cavity under the effects of uniform magnetic field and internal elliptic heater taking into account the single-phase nanofluid approach, local thermal equilibrium model and Darcy law for the transport processes inside a porous medium. The Galerkin finite element method with the structured non-uniform grid is used to solve the formulated non-linear equations. The governing parameters are Darcy&ndash;Rayleigh number <em>Ra</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;10&ndash;1000, porosity <em>&epsilon;</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.1&ndash;0.9, Darcy number <em>Da</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;10<sup>&ndash;5</sup>&ndash;10<sup>&ndash;1</sup>, radiation parameter <em>R<sub>d</sub></em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0&ndash;2, volume fraction of the nanoparticles <em>&phi;</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0&ndash;0.04, vortex viscosity parameter &Delta;&nbsp;=&nbsp;0&ndash;2, Hartmann number <em>Ha</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0&ndash;50. It has been revealed the heat transfer enhancement with thermal radiation parameter, Darcy&ndash;Rayleigh number, porosity and nanoparticles volume fraction.
53	<strong>Deep traps in nanodielectrics and their impact on charge transport</strong>	Nanodielectrics have attracted significant attention due to their potential applications as the improved dielectrics in high voltage direct current (HVDC) power transmission. One of the improved properties widely reported is the suppression of space charge in nanodielectrics when subject to higher DC electric fields. The proposed mechanism for the suppression in space charge is the introduction of deep traps due to the interaction between nanoparticles and polymer matrix. However, the supporting experimental results that lead to the deep trap formation are not rigorously examined. In this letter, a simple and more direct approach has been adopted based on the isothermal surface potential decay (ISPD) measurements to prove the presence of deep traps introduced by nanoparticles. The observed phenomenon also allows one to explain the mechanism of charge suppression in nanodielectrics.
54	Dynamics of electron-phonon coupling in bicontinuous nanoporous gold	The nano-size effect on electron-phonon interaction in free-electron noble metals has been a subject of intense discussion because of their important applications in physics, chemistry and biomedicine. However, the interference from supports of dispersive nanoparticulate metals has led to controversial observations. We utilize free-standing, bicontinuous nanoporous gold (NPG) films to investigate electron-phonon interaction dynamics using ultrafast MeV electron diffraction. Compared to solid gold films, NPG shows faster electron-phonon interaction and thus noticeably higher electron-phonon coupling constant. The results demonstrate that surface states of electrons and phonons play an important role in electron-phonon coupling of nanostructured materials.
55	Effect of Rise Time and Pulse Width on the Characteristic of Nanosecond Surface Dielectric Barrier Discharge Actuator	Nanosecond pulsed surface dielectric barrier discharge (ns-SDBD) actuator is a novel technology for active flow control due to its high control capability and low power consumption. In this paper, effects of pulse parameters on the ns-SDBD actuator with a two-electrode SDBD geometry structure are investigated. In particular, the electrical and optical characterizations of the ns-SDBD are investigated by changing the rise time and pulse width of the applied voltages. Experimental results show that short rise time leads to high current amplitude and diffuse-like plasma layer, while pulse width has slightly effect on the current amplitude and discharge uniformity. The deposited energy can reach up to the maximum at the rise time of 50 ns, whose value is 9.26 mJ, and then it slumps down, and finally decreases to a small value when the rise time increases from 150 ns to 500 ns. Whereas the longer pulse width deposit more energy on the surface of dielectric layer. Furthermore, the schlieren image shows the heat released by the ns-SDBD results in the generation of a circular arc wave and a plane wave. The intensity of the circular arc wave increases when the rise time decreases and the propagation distance of induced pressure wave in the vertical direction is approximately to linear growth. There is almost no change in the intensity of induced pressure waves under varying pulse width within the nanosecond range. However, two waves are produced while the pulse width is long enough. Vortex which finally develops into a jet is observed in a relatively long-time period after discharge. The vortex in schlieren picture is sharp and dark with long pulse due to the decrease of deposited energy and tangential acceleration ability.
56	<strong>Three-dimensional super-resolution correlation-differential confocal microscopy with nanometer axial focusing capability</strong>	We present a correlation-differential confocal microscopy (CDCM), a novel method that can simultaneously improve the three-dimensional spatial resolution and axial focusing capability of confocal microscopy (CM). CDCM divides the CM imaging light path into two paths, where the detectors are before and after the focus with an equal axial offset in opposite directions. Then, the light intensity signals received from the two paths are processed by the correlation product and differential subtraction to improve the CM spatial resolution and axial focusing capability, respectively. Theoretical analyses and preliminary experiments indicate that, for the excitation wavelength of &lambda; = 405 nm, numerical aperture of NA = 0.95, and the normalized axial offset of <em>u<sub>M</sub></em> = 5.21, the CDCM resolution is improved by 26.7% and 35.3% in the lateral and axial directions, respectively, compared with that of the CM. Also, the axial focusing resolution important for the imaging of sample surface profiles is improved to 1 nm.
57	<strong>Flow and heat transfer over a permeable bi-axial stretching/shrinking sheet in a nanofluid</strong>	This paper studies the bi-axial boundary layer flow of a nanofluid past a stretching/shrinking sheet. A suitable similarity transformation simplifies the system of partial differential equations into a system of ordinary differential equations. The obtained system of the governing ordinary differential equations is then solved numerically by using the bvp4c function from MATLAB. The generated numerical results are presented graphically and discussed in the relevance of the governing parameters. Dual solutions are found as the sheet is shrunk in the horizontal direction. Stability analysis shows that the first solution is physically realizable whereas the second solution is not practicable.
58	<strong>Hafnium Oxide Nanoparticles Fabricated by Femtosecond Laser Ablation in Water</strong>	We report the fabrication of colloidal hafnia (HfO<sub>2</sub>) nanoparticles (NPs) and nanoribbons in deionized water by femtosecond laser ablation. It is observed that the particle size and the density of nanoribbons increase with an increase in laser energy which was varied from 200 to 500 &micro;J in steps of 100 &micro;J. &nbsp;A pellet of sintered HfO<sub>2</sub> powder at 500<sup>0</sup> C was used for ablation process. The estimated average NPs size varied from 13.5 to 18.0 nm with varying input laser energy. The average nanoribbon size varied from 10 nm to 20 nm for all the laser energies. At lower input energies the generated NPs were observed to be in monoclinic phase (pure HfO<sub>2</sub>) while at higher input energies both monoclinic and hexagonal phases (pure HfO<sub>2</sub> and Hf<sub>6</sub>O) were observed. The structural variation is further confirmed by Selective Area Electron Diffraction, Raman and Grazing Incident X-Ray Diffraction measurements.
59	Photovoltaic performance of p-Si/Cd<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Zn<em><sub>x</sub></em>O heterojunctions	Heterojunctions of p-Si/Cd<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Zn<em><sub>x</sub></em>O were synthesized by depositing Cd<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Zn<em><sub>x</sub></em>O films with a thickness of 100-500 nm on c-Si substrates by electrochemical deposition. The morphological properties of the films were studied by scanning microscopy. The electric and photoelectrical properties of p-Si/Cd<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Zn<em><sub>x</sub></em>O heterojunctions and optical properties of Cd<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Zn<em><sub>x</sub></em>O films were investigated depending on the electrochemical deposition potential and films composition. It is found out that heterojunctions of p-Si/Cd<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Zn<em><sub>x</sub></em>O with nano-structured surface, which deposited at cathode potential of -1.2 V, shows good rectification (k&raquo;1640). Under AM1.5 conditions (W = 100 mW/cm<sup>2</sup>) the maximal values of open-circuit voltage, short-circuit current, fill factor and efficiency of our best nano-structured cell, were <em>U</em><sub>oc </sub>= 442&nbsp;mV, <em>J</em><sub>sc </sub>= 19.9&nbsp;mA/cm<sup>2</sup>, <em>ff</em> = 0.59 and h = 5.1 %, respectively.
60	<strong>KH<sub>2</sub>PO<sub>4</sub></strong><strong>&nbsp;single crystals activated with the Ti<sup>4+</sup> ions in the form of&nbsp;</strong><strong>TiO<sub>2-x</sub>&times;<em>n</em>H<sub>2</sub>O nanoparticles: structural peculiarities, point defects, and dielectric properties</strong>	Potassium dihydrogen phosphate KH<sub>2</sub>PO<sub>4</sub> (KDP) single crystals activated with the Ti<sup>4+</sup> ions in the form of&nbsp;TiO<sub>2-x</sub>&times;<em>n</em>H<sub>2</sub>O nanoparticles in h-phase, synthesized by sulfate method using TiOSO<sub>4</sub>&times;<em>&#x0445;</em>H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>&times;<em>y</em>H<sub>2</sub>O, have been first grown by the temperature lowering method and cut from the pyramidal (<em>P</em>) and prismatic (<em>Pr</em>) growth sectors. First-performed neutron powder diffraction investigation of <em>P</em> and <em>Pr</em> samples<sub> </sub>of KDP:Ti<sup>4+</sup> crystal allowed to reveal<sub> </sub>vacancies in the K and H sites for both samples, their number being larger in the <em>Pr</em> structure compared to the <em>P</em> one. Taking into account a deficiency of the K and H sites, full occupation of the O site, presence of Ti<sup>4+</sup> ions in the structure, and the electroneutrality condition, a partial substitution of (PO<sub>4</sub>)<sup>3-</sup> anion by (SO<sub>4</sub>)<sup>2-</sup> one, larger for the <em>Pr</em> sample, was observed. The real compositions of <em>P</em> and <em>Pr</em> samples, correlated with the cation-anion internuclear distances, were refined. The dielectric permittivity of the <em>Pr</em> sample was significantly lower than that of the <em>P</em> one; it decreases with the decreasing &#x041A;&ndash;&#x041E;, &#x0420;&ndash;&#x041E;, and &#x041E;&middot;&middot;&middot;&#x041D; distances and increasing deficiency of the K and H sites.
61	<span style="color: #000000;">Local </span><span style="color: #000000;">nanoscale</span><span style="color: #000000;"> strain mapping of a metallic glass during in </span><span style="color: #000000;">situ </span><span style="color: #000000;">testing</span>	<span style="color: #000000;">The local elastic strains during tensile deformation in a </span><span style="color: #000000;">CuZrAlAg</span><span style="color: #000000;"> metallic glass are obtained by fitting an elliptic shape function to the characteristic amorphous ring in electron diffraction patterns. Scanning </span><span style="color: #000000;">nanobeam</span><span style="color: #000000;"> electron diffraction enables strain mapping with a resolution of a few </span><span style="color: #000000;">nanometers</span><span style="color: #000000;">. Here, a fast direct electron detector is used to acquire the diffraction patterns at a sufficient speed to map the local transient strain during continuous tensile loading </span><span style="color: #800000;"></span><em><span style="color: #000000;">in </span><span style="color: #000000;">situ</span></em><span style="color: #000000;"> in the transmission electron microscope. The elastic strain in tensile direction was found to increase during loading. After catastrophic fracture, a residual elastic strain that relaxes over time was observed.</span>
62	Vapor-deposited octadecanethiol masking layer on copper to enable Area Selective HfNx ALD on dielectrics studied by in-situ spectroscopic ellipsometry	Area-selective atomic layer deposition (AS-ALD) has attracted a great deal of attention in recent years for self-aligned accurate pattern placement with sub-nanometer thickness control. We demonstrate a methodology to achieve AS-ALD by using undecanethiol and octadecanethiol masking layers deposited selectively in vapor phase on copper vs. low-&#x03BA;. Our approach has been demonstrated in combination with an in-situ HfNx ALD. In-situ spectroscopic ellipsometer was performed to investigate the blocking ability of the thiols on the copper surface against ALD nucleation. A considerable growth inhibition up to 480 cycles for HfNx deposited at 170&#x00BA;C has been observed on the copper surface, while the same functionalization did not inhibit the nucleation on the dielectric surfaces.
63	Reversal time of jump-noise driven magnetization dynamics in nanomagnets via Monte Carlo simulations	The jump-noise is a nonhomogeneous Poisson process which models thermal e&#xFB00;ects in magnetization dynamics, with special applications in low temperature escape rate phenomena. In this work, we develop improved numerical methods for Monte Carlo simulation of jump-noise dynamics, and validate the method by comparing the stationary distribution obtained numerically against the analytic Boltzmann distribution. In accordance with the Ne&eacute;l-Brown theory, jump-noise dynamics display an exponential relaxation toward equilibrium with a characteristic reversal time, which we extract for nanomagnets with uniaxial and cubic anisotropy. We also identify an analytic upper bound on the strength of jump-noise: this bound establishes the regime of small noise in which an equivalent Gilbert damping coe&#xFB03;cient can be de&#xFB01;ned within the classical framework of magnetization dynamics.
64	Energy transfer between molecules in the presence of a graphene-coated plasmonic nanoshell	In this study&lrm;, &lrm;we investigate the transfer of energy from a donor molecule to an acceptor molecule close a spherical multilayer nanoparticle consisting of a core surrounded by two shells. We obtain general expression for the interaction energy in a hybrid plasmonic nanoshell-molecular system by considering the role of dipolar, quadrupolar&lrm;, &lrm;octupolar&lrm;, &lrm;hexadecapolar&lrm;, &lrm;triakontadipolar plasmonic modes. &lrm;Owing to high tunability of multishell nanoparticles, the resonance energy transfer can be enhanced and strongly tuned by adjusting and controlling the size of core and the thickness of shells. Also, the impact of graphene-coated multilayer spherical nanoparticles on the energy transfer from donor to acceptor molecules is studied, because by covering nanoparticles in graphene it becomes possible to achieve tunable nanophotonic and graphene nanoplasmonics devices. It is found that this kind of nanostructures can provide high intermolecular sensitivity of the resonant energy, which is important for some applications such as biosensing and molecular dynamics.&lrm;
65	Controlled Synthesis of 2D Transition Metal Dichalcogenide Heterostructures and Alloys	The advent of two-dimensional (2D) materials and van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures has been a boon for the nanoscience community, enabling the fabrication of nanostructures with atomic-scale precision, resulting in high performance opto-electronic devices. Yet, while vdW heterostructures have been widely studied, their fabrication remains rudimentary, relying upon physical stacking and <em>ad hoc </em>collections of recipes, rather than a rational framework. Here, we report our work on the synthesis of a collection of vdW heterostructures and monolayer alloys of the 2D transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) and the creation of a unifying, diagrammatic approach to heterostructure growth, which we call Time-Temperature-Architecture (TTA) diagrams. We demonstrate the temperature tunable synthesis of in-plane, vertical, and hybrid heterostructures, as well as monolayer alloys within the MoS<sub>2</sub>-WS<sub>2</sub> and MoSe<sub>2</sub>-WSe<sub>2</sub> systems. We use the TTA framework to add previously unexplored entries to this collection: the first ever single-step growth of MoSe<sub>2</sub>-WSe<sub>2</sub> vertical heterostructures and Mo<em><sub>1-x</sub></em>W<em><sub>x</sub></em>Se<sub>2</sub> alloys, and a new hybrid architecture that combines the morphologies of both vertical and in-plane heterostructures. The TTA diagrams are a simple framework for vdW heterostructure and alloy growth, representing a novel nano-modular synthesis platform, which we believe may be a crucial enabler of capitalization of TMD heterostructures&rsquo; emergent properties.
66	Space charge mitigation effect on dielectric breakdown in polyimide nanocomposites through trap density enhancement	From a novel empirical power law between the DC breakdown field and the DC conductivity, an analysis of the trapping characteristics in polyimide/boron nitride (PI/BN) nanocomposites is presented based on space-charge-limited current (SCLC) measurements. The impact of the total trap density <em>H<sub>t</sub></em> enhancement (up to 1.1&times;10<sup>17</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup>) induced by the BN nanoparticles on the space charge mitigation, the DC conductivity reduction and the DC breakdown field increase is clearly reported. This work proves that an efficient control of the trapping parameters allows huge enhancement of the insulating properties of PI films.
67	<strong>Enhanced photoelectrochemical water splitting of BiVO<sub>4</sub> photonic crystal photoanode by decorating with MoS<sub>2</sub> nanosheets</strong>	Bismuth vanadate (BiVO<sub>4</sub>) has been considered as one of the promising Photoelectrochemical (PEC) photoanode materials. However, the performances remain poorly rated due to inefficient carries separation, short carrier diffusion length and sluggish water oxidation kinetic. Herein, a photoanode consisted of MoS<sub>2</sub> nanosheets coating on the three-dimensional ordered BiVO<sub>4</sub> inverse opal is fabricated by a facile combination of nanosphere lithography and hydrothermal methods. By taking the advantage of the photonic crystal and two-dimensional material, the optimized MoS<sub>2</sub>/BiVO<sub>4</sub> inverse opal photoanode exhibits a 560% improvement of the photocurrent density and threefold enhancement of the incident photon-to-current efficiency than that of the pristine BiVO<sub>4 </sub>film photoanode. Systematic studies reveal that the excellent PEC activity should be attributed from enhanced light harvesting and charge separation efficiency.
68	Environmentally friendly nanofabrication of ultra-low reflectivity black silicon photovoltaics by high density inductively coupled plasmas	Photovoltaics (PV) as a renewable source of energy has received renewed interest in the immediate provision of sustainable energy to meet market demand in recent years. A key challenge in clean energy research is to ensure that the technology not only provides a sustainable energy source during device operation, butis also environmentally sustainable during the manufacturing phase of the device lifecycle. Plasma sources have been conventionally employed in numerous PV processes due to highly controllable process parameters that enable precise control of material properties at the nanoscale. However, these processes usually employ toxic feedstocks as a means to obtain favourable PV characteristics, such as nanotexturing. In this work, an Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) system was employed for fabrication of highly efficient nanotextured PV cells. A 2-step process was developed to use a high density N<sub>2</sub> discharge for high density plasma immersion ion implantation (HD-PIII) in group V doping of c-Si samples for high quality junction formation. Subsequently, an Ar + H<sub>2</sub> discharge was utilized for the simultaneous nanotexturing of the surface as well as passivation of surface defects through intense hydrogenation from the plasma generated radical flux. The resulting black silicon (b-Si) PV cells fabricated through this process typically has ultra-low reflectance of &lt; 1.8 %, V<sub>oc</sub> of ~ 540 mV, and J<sub>sc</sub> of ~ 24 mA&times;cm<sup>-2</sup>.
