In-situ plasma diagnostics were also performed to enable a truly deterministic method for obtaining optimal material properties based on plasma parameters instead of process parameters, which may vary for different reactor geometries.
69	<strong>Probing of interface optical phonon modes in AlGaN multi-quantum wells using tip enhanced Raman spectroscopy</strong>	Group III nitride based 2D multi-quantum well (MQW) nanostructures find remarkable applications in the visible to ultraviolet light sources. The interface (IF) optical phonon modes in a superlattice of [Al<em><sub>0.35</sub></em>Ga<em><sub>0.65</sub></em>N (~1.75 nm)/Al<em><sub>0.55</sub></em>Ga<em><sub>0.45</sub></em>N (~2 nm)]<sub>20 </sub>MQWs using tip enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS) is reported. The far-field (without TERS probe) and near-field, with TERS probe decorated by Au spherical nanoparticle of ~ 200 nm&nbsp;diameter, measurements were carried out at ambient conditions using the scanning probe microscope coupled with the laser Raman spectrometer showing enhancement in the Raman intensities in the later.&nbsp; The IF phonon mode belonging to <em>E</em><sub>1</sub> symmetry [IF(<em>E</em><sub>1</sub>)]&nbsp; beating normal to the <em>c</em>-axis of MQWs appeared to be more prominent in the case of TERS measurement compared to that of other optical phonon modes. The confined electric field of the electro-magnetic excitation using vertically polarized laser source parallel to the plane of the film using TERS probe is made responsible for the plasmonic enhancement of IF(<em>E</em><sub>1</sub>) phonon mode.
70	<strong>Electronic and Mechanical properties of doped W-Re nanostructues &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &ndash; A DFT study</strong>	The electronic and mechanical properties of Tungsten (W), Re doped W (W-Re), La doped W-Re and Cu doped W-Re nanostructures were explored using density functional theory (DFT). The electronic properties were studied in terms of density of states spectrum. For exploring mechanical properties, elastic constants, Young&rsquo;s modulus, Bulk modulus and Shear modulus are observed. Furthermore, the ductility and hardness of the nanostructures are also studied at the atomistic level. The results reveal that W<sub>0.81</sub>Re<sub>0.14</sub>Cu<sub>0.05 </sub>nanostructures show the best combination when compared to factors like ductility and Young&rsquo;s modulus.
71	MD simulation and nanoindentation study of thermally annealed glassy Ni-Zr alloy thin films	Thin films of Ni-Zr glassy alloy (Ni78Zr22) were deposited at room temperature by D.C. magnetron co-sputtering from individual high purity Ni and Zr targets. The alloy films were vacuum annealed in steps of 200 {degree sign}C up to 800 {degree sign}C; where devitrification was observed to occur through grazing incidence X-ray diffraction (GIXRD) measurements. Thin films of metallic glass are known to exhibit useful mechanical properties, which can vary significantly with the structure of the film; influenced through thermal annealing. Tuning of these mechanical properties are of particular interest to engender suitability of glassy films for various technological applications. Mechanical properties of Ni-Zr glassy alloy thin films were measured after each thermal anneal, through nanoindentation technique. The hardness values thus obtained were observed to steadily increase with annealing temperature, as the alloy films underwent an amorphous to crystalline transformation. The resistance of the soft as-deposited and hard annealed films to plastic deformation were obvious from a comparison of GIXRD patterns before and after nanoindentation. The results of a rising trend of hardness with temperature could be adequately supported through Molecular Dynamic (MD) simulations of the nanoindentation process applied to a thermally annealed Ni78Zr22 film. The resultant  variation in elastic moduli of this alloy film with annealing could also be gauged. Moreover through MD simulations, properties of high hardness and low brittleness of the crystalline annealed film could be established. This is a desirable combination for many practical uses which require the film material to withstand deformation and be sufficiently wear resistant. Studies on structure-property relationships in thin film metallic glasses are important to recognize how best to tune their properties to suit specific applications.
72	<strong>Magneto Jeffrey nanofluid bioconvection over a rotating vertical cone due to gyrotactic</strong><strong> microorganism</strong>	The particular inquiry is made to envision the behavioral characteristics of gyrotactic microorganism effects on the MHD flow of Jeffrey nanofluid. Together the nanoparticles and motile microorganism are inducted into the modeled non-linear differential equations. The optimal solutions for the governing equations are tackled by Optimal Homotopy Analysis Method. The physical characteristics of the relatable parameters are explored and deliberated in the terms of graphs and numerical charts. Also, the precision of the present findings is certified by equating them with the previously published work.
73	XRD analysis of sol-gel prepared nanoparticles of &#x03B1;-alumina using aqueous and non-aqueous sols: A mathematical approach	Nanoparticles of &#x03B1;-alumina were prepared by aqueous and non-aqueous sols using aluminium isopropoxide as a precursor dissolved in distilled water and propanol respectively at calcination temperatures of 1100&#x1D52;C and 1200&#x1D52;C. The synthesized &#x03B1;-alumina nanoparticles were characterized by XRD and TEM. XRD and TEM revealed that the nanoparticles were highly crystalline. TEM image shows uniform and spherical structure having an average crystallite size of 30nm. The crystallite size and microstrain was evaluated using X-ray diffraction line profiles (XRDLP) by applying Williamson-Hall method for both isotropic and anisotropic behaviour of the crystallite. The other physical parameters such as Young's modulus, stress and energy density were calculated using uniform deformation model (UDM), uniform deformation stress model (UDSM) and uniform deformation energy density model (UDEDM). The Williamson-Hall analysis results were discussed with the obtained results of Scherrer's analysis and TEM images.
74	Doubly stratified MHD squeezing flow of convectively heated Maxwell nano-fluid	This article is made to discuss the effect of magneto-hydrodynamic (MHD) on squeezing flow of the nanoparticles between two confined boundaries. Constitutive expressions are utilized for convectively heated Maxwell nano-fluid using Buongiorno's model in the mathematical development of considered flow problem. Here system of transport equations incorporates the combined effects of thermophoresis diffusion, Brownian diffusion and double stratification. Coupled non-linear ordinary differential equations are transformed by employing suitable similar transformations. The formulated non-linear system is evaluated successfully via convergent approach. The graphical analysis is carried out for different active physical flow parameters. Nusselt and Sherwood numbers are also treated graphically. The results portray that the velocity profile is increasing function of material parameter in the region 0{less than or equal to}&#x03B7;<0.5 while it shows reverse behavior in the domain0.5<&#x03B7;{less than or equal to}1.0. Further there is no variation in the flow velocity at &#x03B7;=0. Moreover, for larger values of Biot number, convective effects dominant on plate surface and help the temperature and nanoparticle concentration to increase rapidly near the surface.
75	<strong>Magnetic nanoparticle in a rotating magnetic field</strong>	The article describes the conditions needed to meet the parameters of magnetite nanoparticles, the liquid medium and the magnetic field required in the phenomenon of magnetic hyperthermia with a rotating magnetic field. The minimum amplitude of the magnetic field intensity was theoretically determined and the thermal power released by the rotating spheres in the viscous medium was estimated. The estimates were based on the assumption that the magnetic relaxation times meet the condition:<em>t</em><sub>N</sub>&gt;&gt;<em>t</em><sub>B</sub>. The general construction of apparatus generating a rotating magnetic field is described. Experimental research was carried out with the use of an oil-based magnetic liquid with magnetite particles with a magnetic core diameter <em>d</em><sub>m</sub> = 11.8 nm. The specific absorption rate (<em>SAR</em>) value was determined in the experiment and the amplitude of the magnetic field intensity required in the medical &nbsp;therapy for a given magnetic fluid and for the frequency <em>f</em> = 41.9 kHz should be determined.
76	Advanced photonic filters based on cascaded Sagnac loop reflector resonators in silicon-on-insulator nanowires	We demonstrate advanced integrated photonic filters in silicon-on-insulator (SOI) nanowires implemented by cascaded Sagnac loop reflector (CSLR) resonators. We investigate mode splitting in these standing-wave (SW) resonators and demonstrate its use for engineering the spectral profile of on-chip photonic filters. By changing the reflectivity of the Sagnac loop reflectors (SLRs) and the phase shifts along the connecting waveguides, we tailor mode splitting in the CSLR resonators to achieve a wide range of filter shapes for diverse applications including enhanced light trapping, flat-top filtering, Q factor enhancement, and signal reshaping. We present the theoretical designs and compare the CSLR resonators with three, four, and eight SLRs fabricated in SOI. We achieve versatile filter shapes in the measured transmission spectra via diverse mode splitting that agree well with theory. This work confirms the effectiveness of using CSLR resonators as integrated multi-functional SW filters for flexible spectral engineering.
77	<strong>Half-metallicity in Tetrapyrroles Modified Graphene Nanoribbons</strong>	We predict existence of the half-metallicity in porphin modified graphene nanoribbons based on first-principle density functional theory calculations. The porphin modified graphene nanoribbons are constituted by coupling porphin molecules to the graphene nanoribbons in one side based on the recent experiment (Y. He et al., Nat. Chem., 2017, 9, 33&ndash;38). We found that the porphin modified zigzag graphene nanoribbons exhibit half-metallicity, and their band gaps are fixed at about 0.3eV for the spin-up channel regardless the variation of graphene width and porphin modified densities. For the armchair graphene nanoribbons, porphin modification will influence their band gaps and break up the original rules of 3n+1. These findings open a new avenue to the graphene based electronic and spintronic devices.
78	SPR-Enhanced Fluorescence and Protein-Improved Blood Compatibility of Quadruple Core/Shell Nanostructure of Ag@SiO2@Eu3+(tta)3Phen@Protein	This study presents a quadruple core/shell nanostructures of Ag@SiO2@Eu3+(tta)3Phen@protein with both excellent fluorescent property and blood compatibility. In this quadruple nanostructure, surface-plasma resonance (SPR) was utilized to enhance the fluorescence of europium (Eu3+) complexes. In this situation, the fluorescence of Eu3+(tta)3Phen in the triple Ag@SiO2@Eu3+(tta)3Phen nanostructure is greatly enhanced. In order to increase the biocompatibility in blood, lysozyme was used to modify the surface of above triple nano-structure to get the quadruple nanostructure of Ag@SiO2@Eu3+(tta)3Phen@lysozyme. Then, through the clinical anti-coagulation tests of this quadruple nanostructure in human blood, the blood compatibility of Ag@SiO2@Eu3+(tta)3Phen@lysozyme is largely improved comparing with the triple nanostructure of Ag@SiO2@Eu3+(tta)3Phen, and the values of PT-S, APTT-S, TT-S, and AT-III of quadruple nanostructure blood sample with the modification of protein have the high correlation coefficients, 0.993 to 0.994, which means that the quadruple nanostructure of Ag@SiO2@Eu3+(tta)3Phen@lysozyme is close to the anti-coagulation property of physiological saline state (0.9% NaCl aqueous solution). Thus, this work provides two key properties of the quadruple nanostructure of Ag@SiO2@Eu3+(tta)3Phen@lysozyme: the excellent fluorescence and the excellent blood compatibility. This nanomaterial can be applied to bio-imaging and bio-sensing in blood.
79	Fractal superconducting nanowire single-photon detectors with reduced polarization sensitivity	We demonstrate the superconducting nanowire single-photon detectors (SNSPDs) based on a fractal design of the nanowires to reduce the polarization sensitivity of detection efficiency. We patterned niobium-titanium-nitride thin films into Peano curves with a line width of 100 nm and integrated the nanowires with optical micro-cavities to enhance their optical absorption. At the base temperature of 2.6 K, the fractal SNSPD exhibited a polarization-maximum device efficiency of 67% and a polarization-minimum device efficiency of 61%, at the wavelength of 1550 nm. Therefore, the polarization sensitivity, defined as their ratio, was 1.1, lower than the polarization sensitivity of the SNSPDs in the meander design. The reduced polarization sensitivity of the detector could be maintained for higher-order spatial modes in multi-mode optical fibers and could tolerate misalignment between the optical mode and the detector. This fractal design is applicable to both amorphous and polycrystalline materials that are commonly used for making SNSPDs.
80	<strong>Plasmonic nanobump-assembled platform for absorption enhancement of upconversion materials</strong>	We numerically investigate a plasmonic nanobump and upconversion (UC) layer incorporated metal&ndash;insulator&ndash;metal (MIM) platform as a light absorber. The hemispherical nanobump array situated over a substrate can serve as an optical nanoantenna in a broadband wavelength range. By precisely engineering the design and optical parameters of the insulating spacer layer sandwiched by the top nanobumps and back reflecting metal film, we can manipulate the light absorption inside the upconversion layer. The optical near-field distribution of the nanobump-assembled plasmonic platform is studied using the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method to probe the origin of enhanced absorption within the thin UC layer. A suggested mathematical model considering plasmonic and quenching effects of the MIM configuration to analyze the near-field maximum as a function of an insulator thickness is in good agreement with the FDTD result.&nbsp; The 30-fold enhanced light absorption within the UC layer is observed for the MIM plasmonic platform compared to the reference sample. Well-established optical field confinement at the nanoscale gap and excitation of surface plasmons (SPs) near the nanobumps can be attributed to increased light absorption inside the plasmonic MIM platform. The plasmonic nanobump array platform can be an alternative strategy to apply a highly efficient light absorber to an UC device.
81	<strong>Optical properties of wurtzite silicon nanowires: A promising material for optoelectronic applications</strong>	Wurtzite silicon has exhibited a wealth of interesting properties but known to have PL at room temperature. Several researchers have reported the limitations of diamond cubic silicon in the area of optoelectronic devices due to its indirect band gap. Therefore, different phases of silicon are investigated worldwide for the substitute of diamond silicon to overcome its limitation. Recently, wurtzite silicon nanowires (w-SiNWs) have suggested as a potential material for optoelectronic applications. Therefore, optical properties of the w-SiNWs are investigated here. The w-SiNWs are synthesized using top down fabrication method. Presence of the w-SiNWs is confirmed by first-order and second-order Raman spectra. Furthermore, observed second-order Raman active optical modes and acoustic modes of w-SiNWs are analyzed using phonon dispersion curve of wurtzite silicon. Absorption coefficient of SiNWs is remarkably enhanced due to phase transformation from diamond structure to wurtzite structure. Moreover, greenish-yellow photoluminescence (PL) is observed here from w-SiNWs.
82	<strong>Investigation of corrugated channel performance with different wave shapes: Nanofluid as working media</strong>	A two-dimensional computational fluid dynamics (2-D CFD) study on turbulent forced convection of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-water nanofluid flow inside the heated corrugated channel is carried out. The mixture model, which has been verified to be the appropriate model to simulate nanofluids behavior, is employed to model nanofluids, and the governing equations are solved by means of finite volume method (FVM). The effects of wave shape (triangular, trapezoidal, and sinusoidal), phase shift (0, <em>&pi;</em>/2, and <em>&pi;</em>), nanoparticle volume fraction (0 to 4%), and Reynolds number (6,000 to 22,000) on the thermal-hydraulic performance of the corrugated channel are investigated. The results indicate, while the trapezoidal corrugated channel has the highest values of Nusselt number, the sinusoidal corrugated channel offers the optimum performance. Based on the considered performance evaluation criterion (PEC), the lower phase shifts present a better thermal-hydraulic performance (higher PEC). Also, the rate of heat transfer and PEC values enhance with the increase in Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticle volume fraction. Finally, correlations are proposed to predict Nusselt number and friction factor of the water and nanofluids flows in the corrugated channel.
83	<strong>Low temperature synthesis of complex solid solution (1-x)Bi<sub>0.5</sub>Na<sub>0.5</sub>TiO<sub>3</sub>&ndash;xBaTiO<sub>3 </sub>system: BT induced structural and dielectric anomalies in NBT</strong>	(1-x)Bi<sub>0.5</sub>Na<sub>0.5</sub>TiO<sub>3</sub>&ndash;xBaTiO<sub>3</sub> (NBT-BT) complex solid solutions with different composition of BT (x = 0 &ndash; 0.08, Dx = 0.02) were synthesized by low temperature hydrothermal-combustion route. BT-induced structural distortion in NBT are analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectroscopy (RS) studies. XRD result confirms the presence of morphotrophic phase boundary (MPB) by co-existence of (202) rhombohedral peak and (002)/(200) tetragonal peaks at x = 0.06. However, arisen of new vibration modes at A-site and splitting of bands at B sites at the MPB region are revealed by RS study. Microstructural features of as-developed NBT-BT system exhibit rod-like and cuboid-shape mixed morphology; however BT is found inhibiting grain growth of NBT. The broadening of the dielectric peak with deviation from Curie&ndash;Weiss law proves the dielectric dispersion near the MPB region of NBT&ndash;BT. BT in NBT causes enhancement in remnant polarization (P<sub>r</sub>), suppression in coercive field (E<sub>c</sub>) with giant strain (0.27%) at MPB region. Study exhibits potential of nanostructure NBT-BT system to be used as actuators.
84	<strong>A novel fabrication method of two-photon luminescent organic nano-architectures using electron-beam irradiation</strong>	Optical recording on organic thin films with a high spatial resolution is promising for high-density optical memories, optical computing, and security purposes. The spatial resolution of the optical recording is limited by the diffraction of light. Electrons can be focused to a nanometer-sized spot, providing the potential for achieving better resolution. In conventional electron-beam lithography, however, optical tuning of the fabricated structures is limited mostly to metals and semiconductors rather than organic materials. In this article, we report a novel fabrication method of luminescent organic architectures using a focused electron beam. We optimized the fabrication conditions of the electron beam to generate chemical species showing visible photoluminescence via two-photon near-infrared excitations. We utilized this fabrication method to draw nanoscale optical architectures on a polystyrene thin film.
85	Saturable absorption by carbon nanotubes on silica microtoroids<strong> </strong>	Saturable absorption is a key technology for shaping the waveform of light such as in passive mode-locking. The combination of high-<em>Q</em> optical microcavities with a saturable absorber allows stable lasing and soliton formation. This work describes saturable absorption by carbon nanotubes (CNTs) on silica microtoroids. CNTs, which are saturable absorbers capable of a fast response time and broadband absorption, were grown on silica microtoroids by chemical vapor deposition (CVD). Raman spectroscopy revealed that the CNTs are in good quality (G/D ratio ~7) and about 1.0 nm in diameter, thus confirming that a sample for use in the telecommunication band can be prepared by CVD. A counter-propagating pump-probe experiment enabled us to investigate the characteristics of CNTs as saturable absorbers while suppressing thermo-optic bistability in a microcavity system. The results revealed a saturable absorption coefficient of 0.042&nbsp;cm<sup>-1</sup>, a saturable intensity of 25.9&nbsp;MW/cm<sup>2</sup>, and a modulation depth of 28%. This is the first step toward the demonstration of the robust mode-locking in a silica microtoroid consisting of CNTs.
86	<strong>Pulsed photo-ionization spectroscopy of traps in as-grown and neutron irradiated ammonothermally synthesized GaN</strong>	GaN-based structures are promising materials in applications for production of radiation&nbsp;&nbsp; detectors and high-voltage high-frequency devices. In this work, the wafer pieces of the GaN grown by ammonothermal technology have been studied to reveal the dominant defects introduced by growth procedures and reactor neutron irradiations in a wide range 10<sup>12</sup> - 5&times;10<sup>16</sup> cm<sup>-2</sup> of fluences.&nbsp; Several defects in the as-grown and in the irradiated material have been revealed by using the pulsed photo-ionization spectroscopy (PPIS) technique. The PPIS measurements have been performed by combining femtosecond (40 fs) and nanosecond (4 ns) laser pulses emitted by optical parametric oscillators to clarify the role of electron-phonon coupling.
87	<strong>Nickel-doped ferrite nanoparticles substituted in fiber optic clad Structure: A modified magnetic fluid to enhance magnetic sensory </strong>	A simple structure of wide-range magnetic field sensor is proposed and experimentally established using a tapered polymer optical fiber (POF) coated with Nickel &ndash;doped magnetic fluid (MF) containing ferrite nanoparticles formulated as &nbsp; for x=0, 0.1, 0.3, and 0.5 suspended in ester. The proposed sensor functions based on intensity modulation of the evanescent field technique, i.e. the sensory manner is as a result of exposing the evanescent field from the clad region of the optical fiber to the surrounding environment. The middle segment of &nbsp;&nbsp;the POF was tapered with the waist diameter of 0.5 mm and tapering length of 10 mm and then surrounded with MF. The coated MF around this segment provides the sensitivity for the proposed sensor as it modifies the effective refractive index of the cladding corresponding to the applied magnetic field and consequently offers a keen method for magnetic sensing. In order to evaluate the best MF content influence on the sensing performance, four different samples of &nbsp; for x=0, 0.1, 0.3, and 0.5.&nbsp; were tested and the optimized ratio for the dopant is proposed. All the pure and doped ferrite samples were characterized by X-Ray Diffraction pattern (XRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Vibrating Sample Magnetometer (VSM) and Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM). Characteristic Results confirm that by doping Nickel cation in ferrite nanoparticle, the saturation magnetization increases from 65 emu/gr to 75 emu/gr, which enhances the sensory capability of the MF.
88	Laser-Induced Formation of Bismuth Nanoparticles	In the current letter, the synthesis of metallic Bi nanoparticles with coexisting crystallographic structures (rhombohedral, monoclinic, and cubic), obtained by direct femtosecond laser irradiation of NaBiO<sub>3</sub> is demonstrated for the first time. The procedure is performed under non-special ambient conditions, providing a pathway ahead to prototype and scale-up the manufacture of Bi-based nanomaterials. By exploring the use of high laser power values, it is revealed that the promoted laser-mediated reactions lead to the synthesis of coexisting phases in metal nanoparticles, which may be a widely occurring phenomenon in other materials under femtosecond laser irradiation.
89	Micromagnetic evaluation of the dissipated heat in cylindrical magnetic nanowires	Magnetic nanowires (NW) are promising candidates for heat generation under AC-field application due to their large shape anisotropy. They may be used for catalysis, hyperthermia or water purification treatments. In the present work we theoretically evaluate the heat dissipated by a single magnetic nanowire, originated from the domain wall dynamics under the action of an AC-field. We compare the Permalloy NWs (which demagnetize via the transverse wall propagation) with the Co fcc NWs whose reversal mode is via a vortex domain wall. The average hysteresis loop areas &ndash;which are proportional to the Specific Absorption Rate (SAR)&ndash; as a function of the field frequency have a pronounced maximum in the range 200MHz-1GHz. This maximum frequency is smaller in Permalloy than in Co and depends on the nanowire length. A simple model related to the nucleation and propagation time and domain wall velocity (higher for the vortex than for the transverse domain wall) is proposed to explain the non-monotonic SAR dependence on the frequency.
90	Magnetic flux-closure domains in high aspect ratio electroless-deposited CoNiB nanotubes	Magnetic azimuthal (flux-closure) domains in nanotubes could be interesting for data storage, sensors or spin waveguides with non-reciprocity of propagation induced by curvature. However, as expected from theory and recently confirmed experimentally, azimuthal domains could be found only in small aspect ratio tubes (large diameters or short lengths). Using magnetic X-ray microscopies, we show that electroless-plated CoNiB tubes can sustain series of azimuthal domains also for high aspect ratios thanks to an additional material-related magnetic anisotropy.  The anisotropy and thus the magnetic state can be tuned by annealing or adjusting the chemical composition to yield either azimuthal, or axial magnetization.
91	Mechanical properties and deformation behaviors of surface modified silicon: A molecular dynamic study	A fundamental knowledge of mechanical properties and deformation behaviors of surface modify silicon is necessary to explore for understanding remove mechanism during Chemical mechanical polishing (CMP) process. In this work, nanoindentation of monocrystalline silicon covered with an amorphous SiO2 film with different thickness is carried out by molecular dynamic (MD) simulation. It is found that the calculated indentation modulus increases with the growing indentation depth for both pure and composite samples, while the modulus decreases with increasing film thickness at the same indentation depth. The derived hardness during indentation process, which is more sensitive to amorphous SiO2 film thickness, is complex due to deformation behaviors of SiO2 film. Its deformation behaviors consist of four periods during indentation process, containing densification, densification-rupture transition, rupture and unloading stages, which is verified by CN number of silicon atoms within SiO2 film and number of Si-O bond as a function of indentation depth. It is concluded that the SiO2 film servers as a media to dissipate the stress and transmit the stress from indenter to underlying silicon substrate and MD results show that the difference of phase distribution between pure and composite silicon at the same penetration depth is drove by the Von Mises stress.
92	Full-wave Theory Combined with Analytical Closed-form Expressions Applied to Whispering-Gallery-Mode Lasing of Fully Anisotropic Nanoparticles beyond Visible	A full-wave theory for the prediction of the complex whispering-gallery-mode (WGM) resonances beyond visible, of fully anisotropic nano/microresonators, is presented. The theory is based on the volume integral equation (VIE) method, supported by appropriate perturbation theory which enables analytical closed-form expressions valid for extremely large indices of the involved spherical wavefunctions. These closed-form expressions allow for the instant computation of the eigenbasis required for the solution of the VIE. The theory is applied to the calculation of WGM spectra of uniaxial semiconductor crystals beyond visible. Combined with a state-of-the-art open-source algorithm for complex roots computation, this theory constitutes a rigorous tool for the interpretation of experimental data obtained from photonic applications, including WGM lasing of fully anisotropic nanoresonators.
93	Morphological characterization of GaAs and AlAs islands grown on InGaAs by droplet epitaxy	In this work, we investigated the droplet epitaxy (DE) of Ga droplets and Al droplets son In0.53Ga0.47As lattice-matched to InP substrates via molecular beam epitaxy as a means to extract adatom diffusion information.  We previously demonstrated that In droplets on In0.53Ga0.47As form a central droplet surrounded by a thinner halo with radius directly related to the adatom diffusion length.  However, for Ga or Al droplets on In0.53Ga0.47As which are explored in this work, the morphology was significantly different.  We observed anisotropic mounds, etched tracks and pits, and quantum dot-like features.  To develop an understanding of the formation of these nanostructures, we explored various substrate temperatures, growth rates, and As-crystallization conditions.  While unexpected, this morphology could have implications toward interesting nanostructure formation, enabling drastically different morphologies than previously observed.  We extracted the Ga droplet density as a function of both growth rate and substrate temperature to estimate diffusion trends.  These results indicate that these Ga droplets still follow conventional nucleation trends for substrate temperatures below 500 {degree sign}C.  Furthermore, by comparing these results with our previous work with In droplets on In0.53Ga0.47As, we find that Ga adatoms diffuse slower than In adatoms on the In0.53Ga0.47As surface.
94	Development of effective stochastic potential method using random matrix theory for efficient conformational sampling of semiconductor nanoparticles at non-zero temperatures	The relationship between structure and property is central to chemistry, and enables the understanding of chemical phenomena and processes. Need for an efficient conformational sampling of chemical systems arises from the presence of solvents and the existence of non-zero temperatures. However, conformational sampling of structures to compute molecular quantum mechanical properties is computationally expensive because a large number of electronic structure calculations are required. In this work, the development and implementation of the effective stochastic potential (ESP) method is presented to perform efficient conformational sampling of molecules. The overarching goal of this work is to alleviate the computational bottleneck associated with performing a large number of electronic structure calculations required for conformational sampling.  sWe introduce the concept of a deformation potential and demonstrate its existence by the proof-by-construction approach. sA statistical description of the fluctuations in the deformation potential due to non-zero temperature was obtained using infinite-order moment expansion of the distribution.  The formal mathematical definition of the ESP was derived using functional minimization approach to smatch the infinite-order moment expansion for the deformation potential.  Practical implementation of the ESP was obtained using the random-matrix theory method. The developed method was applied to two proof-of-concept calculations of the distribution of HOMO-LUMO gap in water molecule and solvated CdSe clusters at 300K. The need for large sample size to obtain statistically meaningful results was demonstrated by performing 10<sup>5</sup> ESP calculations. The results from these prototype calculations demonstrated the efficacy of the ESP method for performing efficient conformational sampling. We envision that the fundamental nature of this work will not only extend our knowledge of chemical systems at non-zero temperatures but will also generate new insights for innovative technological applications.
95	Effect of the plasma channel velocity on the diode parameters during breakdown in a highly inhomogeneous electric field	Here, continuing our research in the breakdown of a gas diode with a highly inhomogeneous electric field, we present an analytical model which relates the diode current and voltage to the plasma channel velocity from cathode to anode in an axisymmetric statement. It is shown that the voltages cross- and lengthwise the diode can differ greatly and that the difference increases as the channel moves faster. This effect should be taken into account when analyzing subnanosecond pulsed breakdowns in a highly inhomogeneous electric, otherwise a large discrepancy is possible between measured and actual diode voltage. The analytical model is based on charge conservation laws and Lorentz transforms for electric field strengths and coordinates and is verified using the KARAT particle-in-cell (PIC) and xoopic particle-in-cell/Monte Carlo (PIC/MC) codes. The simulation results agree well with the analytical model developed.
96	Room temperature operable ammonia gas sensor based on nanostructured SnO2 synthesized by polyol technique	SnO2 nanoparticles were synthesized by low temperature polyol route and calcined at 700{degree sign}C. XRD studies confirmed the tetragonal phase and nanocrystalline nature of SnO2 particles. Gas sensors were fabricated by spin coating of SnO2 nanoparticles on gold interdigitated electrodes. The gas sensors showed high sensitivity, excellent selectivity and repeatability at room temperature for NH3. The high sensitivity and reversibility at room temperature of the nanostructured SnO2 sensor could be attributed to the intrinsically small particle size and high surface-to-volume ratio.
97	Energy spectrum and wave functions for a 1D quantum dot with strong spin-orbit coupling	For a semiconductor nanowire quantum dot with the confining potential modeled by both the infinite and the finite square wells, we exactly obtain the energy spectrum and the corresponding wave functions in the strong spin-orbit coupling regime. The energy levels in the quantum dot can be specified with respect to the $Z_{2}$ symmetry. There exists at least two bound states in the finite square, one has the $\sigma^{x}\mathcal{P}=-1$ symmetry and the other has the $\sigma^{x}\mathcal{P}=1$ symmetry. A strong enhancement of the spin-orbit effect is demonstrated by tuning the well height of the confining potential. Also, there exists a critical well height $V^{c}_{0}$, at which the spin-orbit effect is enhanced to maximal.
98	<strong>Analysis Heat Transfer of Hydromagnetic Water-Graphene Oxide Nanofluid Flow in the Channel with Asymmetric Forced Convection on Walls</strong>	<span style="font-size: 9.0pt;">In this paper, heat transfer of hydromagnetic water-graphene oxide nanofluid flow in the channel with asymmetric forced convection on walls is analyzed. The basic partial differential equations include momentum and energy for this problem are reduced to the ordinary differential equations which are solved numerically by using finite element method (FEM) in the FlexPDE software package. For validity, the results is compared with 4th order Runge-Kutta numerical solution. Effects of different physical parameters such as the nanoparticle volume fraction, the Magnet parameter, the Biot number and the Eckert number on the dimensionless velocity profiles, the dimensionless temperature profiles and the dimensionless gradient temperature profiles have been discussed.</span> <span style="font-size: 9.0pt;">It was concluded that with increase in the nanoparticle volume fraction and Magnet parameter the dimensionless velocity profiles of flow reduce. With rising the amount of Biot numbers, the dimensionless temperature decreases and dimensionless gradient temperature profiles increases. By increasing in nanoparticle fraction volume, the dimensionless temperature profiles of flow is increased and enhances the heat transfer coefficient. By increasing in nanoparticle fraction volume, the convection on walls increases within the channel. Also, with increasing in Eckert number, the dimensionless temperature profile increases and the convection inside the channel on upper wall decreases and on lower wall increases.</span>
99	Synthesis and Characterization of Novel TiO2/Cdse Core-Shell Nanoparticles by Surface Functionalization Route	In this work we report the synthesis of the Titanium dioxide/ Cadmium Selinide (TiO2/CdSe) core-shell (CS) nanoparticles. TiO2 nanoparticles are surface-functionalized using citric acid. These modified nanoparticles are then treated with aqueous solution of Cadmium chloride, CdCl2 and Sodium selenosulphate, Na2SeSO3 to obtain TiO2/CdSe core-shell nanoparticles. The effect of citric acid amount on the resulting structure was studied using X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). The optical properties and the shell growth were studied using by UV-Vis absorption spectra and photoluminescence (PL) spectra.
100	<strong>The Uniformity Analysis of NbN Nanowires Based on Element Mapping</strong>	Superconducting nanowire with super large ratio of length to width is the core component of superconducting nanowire single photon detector (SNSPD).The uniformity of these nanowires directly affects key parameters of SNSPD, like the detection efficiency, dark counts and time jitter. It is also a significant factor contributing to the uniformity and the product yield of final devices. In this letter, we have made Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) mapping and statistical analysis of NbN nanowires with different widths. Based on this, we established a method to evaluate the homogeneity of superconducting nanowires from the perspective of elemental distribution. With the help of AES element imaging, we drew the distribution images of N, Nb, Si and O on the nanowires. Based on graphic analysis, the uniformities of element distribution in both transverse and vertical dimensions were discussed, which can provide an intuitive criterion for optimizing the processing technique of SNSPD to improve the consistency and product yield.
101	<strong>Magnetic polymer nanocomposites based on polyvinylidenefluoride (PVDF) and magnetite (Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>) nanoparticles for the absorption of high frequency electromagnetic waves</strong>	<em>In the presented work nanocomposites based on PVDF and </em><em>magnetic </em><em>Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4&nbsp; </sub></em><em>nanoparticles</em><em>were prepared</em><em>. The structure and content of nanocomposite materials were studied by using SEM, TEM, AFM and X-Ray phase analysis. Magnetic properties of </em><em>PVDF+Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4&nbsp; </sub></em><em>nanocomposites have been studied&nbsp; upon increasing nanoparticle content in polymer matrix up to 20%,&nbsp; revealing a superparamagnetic behaviour as </em><em>Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4 </sub></em><em>nanoparticles in polymer matrix act out like single-domain particles. It has also been observed that, </em><em>PVDF+Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub></em><em> based nanocomposites can absorb the electromagnetic waves in the high frequency range 0,1-30 GHz. </em><em>It has been shown that </em><em>the absorption of electromagnetic waves by PVDF+</em><em>Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub></em><em> nanocomposites can be explained by the different molecular structures and also by the scattering of the electromagnetic waves at the boundary of nanoparticle-polymer matrix. </em>
102	Ultra-flexible transparent electrodes by embedding silver nanowires into polyimide thin films to achieve smooth surface, pronounced thermal stability, and strong adhesion	Silver nanowires (AgNWs) percolated films are considered as promising candidates for alternative transparent electrodes (TEs). However, due to their high surface roughness, poor adhesion and thermal stability, their use in TE application is still heavily limited. Herein, we report an ultra-flexible TE by imbedding AgNWs into polyimide (PI) to achieve smooth surface, pronounced thermal stability, and high adhesion. Besides the excellent electrical conductivity of about 7-13&#x03A9;/&#x25A1; in sheet resistance, the obtained AgNWs/PI films also have excellent transparency and mechanical resilience. The AgNWs/PI films show extraordinary stability in terms of electrical conductivity after arbitrary twisting and thermal heating test, respectively.
103	Multi-directional emission and detection of spin waves propagating in yttrium iron garnet with wavelengths down to about 100 nm	We performed broadband spin-wave spectroscopy on 200 nm thick yttrium iron garnet containing arrays of partially embedded magnetic nanodisks. Using integrated coplanar waveguides (CPWs) we studied the excitation and transmission of spin waves depending on the presence of nanomagnet arrays of different lateral extensions. By means of the grating coupler effect we excited spin waves propagating in multiple lateral directions with wavelengths down to 111 nm. They exhibited group velocities of up to 1 km/s. Detection of such short-wavelength spin waves was possible only in symmetrically designed emitter/detector configurations, not with a bare CPW. The effective propagation distance amounted to several 10 &mu;m. We report spin waves propagating between grating couplers under oblique angles. This was not shown before and substantiates the versatility of the grating coupler effect when implementing nanomagnonic circuits.
104	<strong>Effect of the surface wettability changes on nanostructured polymer film for heat exchanger applications</strong>	Polymer heat exchangers have drawn attention due to their special characteristics such as flexibility, low weight, corrosion and bio-fouling resistance, as well as their ease of manufacturing. However, since their thermal conductivity is low, polymer heat exchangers require a way to increase their heat transfer rate. We investigated the effect of modifying the surface wettability of polymer films on the heat transfer rate during the condensation process, both theoretically and experimentally. Condensed water formation on the film surface depends on the surface wettability control, thus hydrophilic and hydrophobic surfaces can induce film-wise and drop-wise condensation of water, respectively. Generally, the polymer surface shows a hydrophobic property due to the intrinsic C-C and C-H bonding of polymer frames. Here, we used four different types of polymer films, which have different thermal conductivity and controlled wettability properties, including: polyimide film, polyimide film containing aluminum nanoparticles, and both films with super-hydrophobic treatment. The experimental results shows that nanostructured polymers with hydrophobic treatment have a 25% lower wetted area fraction than that without hydrophobic treatment, independent of the thermal conductivity of the polymer films. To compare the heat transfer rates for different samples, we designed a thermal resistance model considering vapor convection, vapor-water interfaces and curvatures, and conductions of the droplet, nanostructure, and polymer. Through a theoretical approach, we found that the convective thermal resistance dominantly affects the heat transfer rate and treated polymers showed a 200% higher total heat transfer than bare polymer.
105	Structural evolution and electrical properties of carbon ion implanted ultrananocrystalline diamond films	We have investigated the structural evolution and electrical properties of carbon ion implanted ultrananocrystalline diamond (UNCD) films. The results show that both nanocrystalline diamond grains and amorphous carbon grain boundaries (GBs) make contributions to the conductivity in C<sup>+</sup>-implanted UNCD films by impedance spectroscopy measurements. The impedance value of diamond grains is relatively stable, whist that of grain boundaries (R<sub>b</sub>) dramatically increases after C<sup>+</sup> implantation and decreases as annealing temperature (T<em><sub>a</sub></em>)<sub> </sub>increases from 650 to 1000 <sup>o</sup>C. This means that C<sup>+</sup> implantation has more significant impact on the conductivity of GBs. Conductive atomic force microscopy results evidence that the number of conductive sites increases in GB regions at T<em><sub>a </sub></em>above 900 <sup>o</sup>C, which is originated from the formation of nanographitic phase confirmed by high resolution transmission electronic microscopy. Visible Raman shows that resistive trans-polyacetylene oligomers desorb from GBs at T<em><sub>a </sub></em>above 900 <sup>o</sup>C, which also results in the lower R<sub>b</sub> values of samples C12900 and C121000.
106	<strong>Various Magnetic features and Magnetocaloric effect of spinel type Cobalt ferrite nanoparticles tuned by annealing temperature</strong>	Cobalt ferrite (CoFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>) nanoparticles synthesized by chemical co-precipitation method were studied to see the effect of annealing temperatures on the structural parameters and magnetic properties of the sample. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscope (TEM) and SAD pattern demonstrated that single face (fcc) spinel structure of CoFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> has been formed showing particles in completely crystalline state which was further confirmed by the lattice parameter and the unmixed hkl values. The particle size are in the range of about 5-10 nm depending on the annealing temperature from 200&deg;C to 400&deg;C. The grain growth occurred monotonically with the increase of annealing temperature. The magnetic properties demonstrated a strong dependence on particle size. The saturation magnetization M<sub>s</sub>, remanent ratio M<sub>r</sub>/M<sub>s </sub>and coercivity H<sub>c</sub> increased with the increase of particle size. The hysteresis curves for samples of different grain size showed the ferrimagnetic behavior which are completely analogous to the slow relaxation sextet peaks of M&ouml;ssbauer spectroscopy. Other parameters such as chemical shift, quadruple splitting and hyperfine field and site occupancy of Fe<sup>3+</sup> were determined by M&ouml;ssbauer spectroscopy. Ferrimagnetic to superparamagnetic transition temperature known as blocking temperature T<sub>B</sub> was determined from the temperature dependent magnetization curves. With the increase of grain size, Blocking temperature also increases. Maximum entropy changes due to magnetic phase transition was 0.9257 J/kg/<sup>o</sup>C for the samples annealed at 400<sup>o</sup>C in the context of Magnetocaloric effect.
107	Electronic and Magnetic Studies in Heteroepitaxial Self-assembled BaTiO3-Fe2O3 Nanostructures	Self-assembled vertical growth of BaTiO3 nanostructures in the matrix of Fe2O3 is described. Array of well controlled and systematically ordered nanostructures of composite phases were grown on MgO and SrTiO3 single crystal substrate by using pulse laser deposition technique with optimised conditions. The phase purity of composite structures was characterized by using X-ray diffraction and Raman spectroscopy. Surface topographical and morphological measurements are carried out for confirming the nanostructure growth in the composite thin films. Ferroelectric properties are probed by polarization versus electric field (P-E) measurements. The electronic and magnetic properties of the composite is studied by employing X-ray absorption spectroscopy and magnetization study. The presence of strain state in nanostructures play an important role to modify the crystal field effect and magnetic properties of the composite compound. It is shown that the vertical self-assembly of nano rods of BaTiO3 can be grown in the matrix layer of Fe2O3 on MgO substrate by co-ablation.
108	Monolithic integration of BaTiO3 thin film MOSCAPs on Ge wafers	Titanates exhibit electronic properties highly desirable for field effect transistors such as very high permittivity and ferroelectricity. However, the difficulty of chemically etching titanates hinders their commercial use in device manufacturing. Here, we report the selective area in finestra growth of highly crystalline BaTiO3 within photolithographically defined openings of a sacrificial SiO2 layer on a Ge (001) wafer by molecular beam epitaxy. After the BaTiO3 deposition, the sacrificial SiO2 can be etched away, revealing isolated nanoscale gate stacks circumventing the need to etch the titanate thin film. Reflection high-energy electron diffraction in conjunction with scanning electron microscopy is carried out to confirm the crystallinity of the samples. X-ray diffraction is performed to determine the out-of-plane lattice constant and crystal quality of the BTO film. Electrical measurements are performed on electrically isolated Pt/BaTiO3/SrTiO3/Ge capacitor devices.
109	Study of transport property in micro/nano-crystalline silicon films grown using 27.12 MHz assisted PECVD process	Investigation of electrical properties in hydrogenated micro/nano-crystalline (nc-Si:H/&#x03BC;c-Si:H) thin films deposited using 27.12 MHz assisted Plasma Enhanced Chemical vapor Deposition (PECVD) process were presented. In the present study, we use Steady State Photo-carrier Grating (SSPG) technique for the estimation of diffusion length of holes (Lh) in silicon thin films. The Lh found to vary from 0.190 &#x03BC;m to 0.080 &#x03BC;m for 41 % - 22 % crystalline fraction in nc-Si:H/&#x03BC;c-Si:H thin films. In addition to that measurement of temperature dependent dark conductivity and time induced photo-conductivity also conducted for the estimation of activation energy (Ea), coefficient of the variable range hopping process (To) and light induced degradation. From these results, lowest value of Ea (&#xF07E; 0.58 eV), To (&#xF07E; 0.016 &#x00D7; 108 K) with no degradation were observed for the film having 41 % - 32 % crystalline fraction due to the presence of high fraction of crystallites which can create conductive percolation pathway. Moreover, efforts were also also made to understand the light induced volume expansion which has been observed in 38 % &#x03BC;c-Si:H.
110	Sub-nano Crystalline Silicon Thin Films as Active Layer in Solar Cells	The investigation presents the atypical aspects of silicon thin films in terms of growth under variation of applied power using Radio frequency Plasma Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition technique (RF-PECVD). The corresponding material found to maintain the typical properties of amorphous without compensating the structural modification in terms of crystallinity and has been defined as a material having the "sub-nano crystalline phase". To explore the characteristics of the existing sub-nano crystalline form of silicon, characterizations like, UV-Visible spectroscopy, Photoluminescence and Temperature dependent conductivity analysis have been effectively made to map the structural details along with the electrical and optical properties. These results conclude the formation of sub-nano crystalline regime which found to be separated via transition regime at 30 W applied power. The article presents sub-nano crystalline silicon thin films as one of the alternative for hydrogenated amorphous silicon in various applications.
111	Coherent transmission of&nbsp; superconducting carriers through a&nbsp; ~ 2 micron&nbsp; polar semiconductor	Coherent transmission of Cooper pairs through a non-superconducting medium is a key challenge for hybrid electronics with superconductors, normal metals and semiconductors. While superconductor-normal metal-superconductor (SNS) junctions have been known for quite sometime,<br />including a low carrier density region or&nbsp; a 2 dimensional electron gas (2DEG) in the path of superconducting electrons is relatively less explored. Indeed, this is&nbsp; due to the limited choice of materials that would make ohmic contacts to such systems, while simultaneously&nbsp; supporting a superconducting phase. In this paper we show a coherent transmission of supercurrent through a degenerate semiconductor over a length&nbsp;&nbsp; $\approx$ 2~$\mu$m with a critical magnetic field $B_c&nbsp; \approx 8~{\rm T}$ at 1.6~K and $T_c$ $\approx$ 5~K at zero magnetic field. This length scale is much larger than the typical thickness of a Josephson junction.&nbsp; Our system is a fragment of a GaN nanowall network that has been shown to support a&nbsp; high mobility 2DEG ($\mu_n &gt; 10^4 \rm{cm^{2}V^{-1}s^{-1}}$). The current and voltage probes were&nbsp; superconducting Tungsten-Gallium composite electrodes and the measurements could be done in&nbsp; four-probe geometry.&nbsp; We demostrate ballistic type carrier transport with a near ideal transparency of 1 and a critical current ($I_c$) large enough such that the Josephson coupling parameter ${\hbar}{I_c}/e{k_B}T_c &gt;&gt; 1$
112	<strong>An analytical method for calculation of interlaminar normal/shear stresses in micro and nano laminated composite beams</strong>	In this manuscript, a mono dimensional displacement model for micro and nano laminated composite Timoshenko beam is presented. In order to calculate interlaminar stresses correctly, the layer-wise displacement model is refined. In the presented model, the behavior of displacements at the interface of adjacent layers is modeled by transverse and tangential springs of high stiffnesses. The reaction of different springs in different directions indicates an approximation of transverse and tangential interactions between adjacent layers of the laminated beam. Using the presented model and also modified couple stress theory, the in-plane stresses of the laminated composite Timoshenko beam subjected to different boundary conditions including simply - simply supported, clamped - clamped and clamped - free are studied. In addition, the effects of material length scale parameter and elastic foundation on the stresses are investigated. The advantage of this method is accurate calculation of interlaminar stresses without using the equilibrium equations.
113	Reduced thermal conductivity of nanoscale three-dimensional Si phononic crystal with ellipsoidal pores<sup></sup>	In this work, a nanoscale three-dimensional Si phononic crystals (3D Si PnCs) with ellipsoidal pores is proposed and its thermal conductivity is studied through equilibrium molecular dynamics (EMD) simulations. The results show that 3D Si PnCs with ellipsoidal pores could have much lower thermal conductivity than 3D Si PnCs with spherical pores. When&nbsp;<em>&phi;</em>=60% and&nbsp;<em>&rho;</em>=0.7, the calculated thermal conductivity of 3D Si PnCs with ellipsoidal pores at&nbsp;<em>x</em>&nbsp;direction is merely 0.15 W&middot;m<sup>-1</sup>&middot;K<sup>-1</sup>, which is about 47.65% of the corresponding 3D Si PnCs with spherical pores and is merely 0.10% of bulk Si. For 3D Si PnCs with spherical pores, the low thermal conductivity primarily resulted from increased phonon mode localization. Meanwhile, further reduced thermal conductivity of 3D Si PnCs with ellipsoidal pores mainly caused by phonon backscattering with pore boundaries perpendicular to&nbsp;<em>x</em>&nbsp;direction. Comparing with 3D Si PnCs with spherical pores, the proposed nanoscale 3D Si PnCs with ellipsoidal pores could have extremely low thermal conductivity at&nbsp;<em>x</em>direction even when its porosity is small. This work suggests that 3D Si PnCs with ellipsoidal pores is a promising thermoelectric material for large-scale utilization.
114	Study of Transparent Electrodes Based on Thin Films of Metallic Nanostructures.	Abstract- Transparent electrodes are a necessary component in many modern devices such as touch screens, LEDs and solar cells, all of which are growing in demand. This role has been served by doped metal oxides like indium tin oxide. Now a days, advances in nanostructures have opened the door for other transparent conductive materials, each with unique properties. In this paper metal nanostructures are discussed in which nanowires and grids have relatively large film apertures, and so may need to be combined with another more continuous transparent electrode. The emerging metallic nanomaterials discussed in this paper will continue to allow these same minds to flex their creative capacities to design a revolutionary new breed of transparent and flexible electronics.
115	Mn-doped SnS<sub>2</sub> nanostructure as a potential efficiency CO catalyst:a first-principles study	Abstracts<p>The SnS<sub>2</sub> is a new class of 2D materials with unique properties, which are still largely unexplored in the CO catalyst field. The modulation of electronic structures and chemical activities of the Mn atom substituted for S atom in SnS<sub>2</sub> monolayer sheet is studied based on density functional theory. The electrons of doped Mn are introduced to the dangling bond of monovacancy SnS<sub>2</sub> system, which can enhance the stability of Mn-Sn bond. The Mn-SnS<sub>2</sub> monolayer sheet prefers good catalytic activity for the CO oxidation via the more favorable Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism with a two-step route to the Eley-Rideal or the latest report of termolecular Eley-Rideal mechanisms. In summary, we show first-principles evidence toward the realization of SnS<sub>2 </sub>based catalyst for CO catalytic oxidation which can be facilitating the applications of SnS<sub>2</sub> in the fields of catalysis and air pollution prevention.
116	<strong>An Optimised Way for Extraction of Optical Band Gap Energy from Tauc Plot using Zinc based Nanomaterials </strong>	The application of Zn-based semiconductor nanostructures is developing at an astounding pace due to its size and shape dependent optoelectronic properties. A method to calculate the optical band gap energy (&Delta;E) from Tauc plot using UV-Vis spectra is usually a practice. However, finding the accurate value of &Delta;E by extrapolating the linear segment of the graph may include eye-estimation error. Use of Wang&rsquo;s equation with XRD data to determine &Delta;E may serve as a reference through which accuracy in its estimation may be achieved. This letter compares the values of &Delta;E using Wang&rsquo;s equation with one achieved from the Tauc plot. Discrepancy of the &Delta;E values as-obtained using two above methods may be removed considering the intersection of two tangents in Tauc plot for Zn based nanomaterials<strong>.</strong>
117	Synthesis and characterization of CuInSSe nanoparticals via simple and low cost technique	In this study, we report on the preparation and study of the structural, surface morphology and optical properties of copper indium sulphoselenide (CuInSSe) nanoparticles. CuInSSe nanocrystals are prepared by a wet chemical route using low cost solution precursors for low cost solar cells. The nanoparticals are characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM)/EDAX (Energy Dispersive Analysis of X-ray), TEM (transmission electron microscope) and optical study and the results indicate that the particles crystallize in the chalcopyrite structure, single phase, showing smooth morphology in form of clusters and the optical band gap value is 1.23 eV.  The average crystallite size is calculated from X-ray spectral peaks with Scherrer's formula and it is in the range 30 to 40 nm.
118	Imaging graphene nanoribbons using bimodal dynamic scanning force microscopy	We have performed topographic measurements on graphene nanoribbons after on-surface synthesis using scanning force microscopy. We have excited the cantilever both at its first and second flexural eigenfrequency. While we used the first harmonic for topographic measurements we used the second eigenmode for high-resolution imaging in the frequency channel. The amplitude of the second eigenmode oscillation was only 50~pm to make it sensitive to the measurement of short-ranged forces. The sample was cooled down to liquid nitrogen temperatures while the tip remained at room temperature. We observe the serrated edge of the nanoribbon caused by the armchair configuration of the nanoribbon. In addition we see stripe-like contrast that marks the onset of intramolecular contrast. The edges of the graphene nanoribbons appear much brighter than their center and are sensitive to the atomic-scale configuration of the edge.
119	<strong>Impact of velocity slip and convective boundary condition on MHD heat and mass transfer analysis of nanofluids over an inclined porous plate filled with single and multi - wall carbon nanotubes</strong>	Numerical study of MHD boundary layer flow, heat and mass transfer analysis of water based nanofluids containing single and multi &ndash; walled CNTs over a vertical cone under the influence of convective boundary condition, chemical reaction and suction/injection is presented in this analysis. The suitable similarity transformations reduced the governing non-linear partial differential equations into the system of coupled ordinary differential equations and are solved by using Finite element method. The sway of various pertinent parameters on velocity, temperature and concentration profiles is examined and the results are shown graphically. Furthermore, the values of local skin-friction coefficient, Nusselt and Sherwood number is also studied for various values of non &ndash; dimensional parameters and the results are shown in tabular form.
120	Computational analysis of heat, mass transfer and entropy generation in Casson nanofluid with thermal radiation and viscous dissipation	This article studies the heat, mass transfer and entropy analysis of Casson nanofluid under the influence of thermal radiation and viscous dissipation over a stretching sheet. This problem is modeled with slip and thermal boundary conditions. Entropy produced, is also discussed. The governing nonlinear PDEs are converted to a set of ODEs using appropriate similarity transformations. Hence resulting system of ODEs are solved by an efficient numerical technique, called the finite difference scheme that is the Keller box method. It is seen that the greater entropy is generated by increasing the values of the thermophrosis parameter, Brownian motion parameter, Biot number and Prandtl number. While it is reduced by increasing the values of Casson fluid parameter, slip parameter and Lewis number. Nusselt number (heat transfer index) and Sherwood number (mass transfer index) have been computed. It is observed that by increasing the values of thermal radiation parameter and Eckert number, the Nusselt number increases. The Sherwood number shows an increasing behaviour for thermal radiation parameter but is a decreasing function of Eckert number.
121	Opto-structural properties of microcrystalline silicon films deposited using 60 MHz assisted VHF-PECVD process	The silicon thin film has been deposited using VHF (60 MHz) plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) process. The structural transition along with their variable grain distribution within amorphous silicon matrix has been discussed with the help of optical and structural measurements. Raman characterization along with photoluminescence (PL) and micro-ellipsometry spectroscopy have been investigated to recognize transitions in these silicon films including the microstructure mainly related with crystallite fraction and optical constants. From Raman results, the structural transition from amorphous to microcrystalline growth occurs as indicated by narrow band observed at 515 cm-1 observed at 10 W powers. With increasing power the crystallinity increases and the films are highly crystalline in nature. The contribution of nano-sized crystallites increases the crystalline volume fraction from 32 to 84%. The peak observed nearly at 2 eV in photoluminescence emission spectra (PL) confirms the presence of nanocrystallites in the deposited films. The shift in refractive index (n) and extinction coefficient (k) were also observed at different power variation. The investigation of results obtained from spectroscopic ellipsometry explains the microstructure of deposited film with changes in crystallite sizes and their volume fractions.
122	<strong>Quasi-Frenkel-exciton near-UV luminescence with large Stokes shift in trigonal wide-bandgap Cs<sub>4</sub>PbCl<sub>6</sub> nanocrystals</strong>	Inorganic lead halide perovskite nanocrystals (NCs) have attracted great interest due to their superior luminescent and optoelectronic properties. Compared with ordinary cubic CsPbCl<sub>3</sub> with visible-region luminescence, trigonal Cs<sub>4</sub>PbCl<sub>6</sub> has much wider bandgap and distinct optical properties. Unlike the case of cubic perovskite NCs, little has been known about the luminescence properties of trigonal perovskite NCs. In this study, the well-crystallized Cs<sub>4</sub>PbCl<sub>6</sub> NCs with sizes of 2.2&ndash;11.8 nm are synthesized, which exhibit stable near-UV luminescence with remarkable quantum confinement effect at room temperature. In comparison with negligible Stokes shift in the CsPbCl<sub>3</sub> NCs, the Cs<sub>4</sub>PbCl<sub>6</sub> NCs exhibit very large Stokes shift (0.91 eV). The experiments in combination with first-principles calculations reveal that the near-UV luminescence stems from the quasi-Frenkel excitons trapped in the isolated PbCl<sub>6</sub><sup>4&ndash;</sup> octahedrons of the Cs<sub>4</sub>PbCl<sub>6</sub> NCs; this is different from the CsPbCl<sub>3</sub> NCs whose luminescence originates from the free Wannier excitons. These wide-bandgap Cs<sub>4</sub>PbCl<sub>6</sub> NCs with near-UV luminescence have strong application potential in short-wavelength optoelectronic nanodevices.
123	Local Ferroelectric & Piezoelectric studies on PVDF - Bi25FeO40 composite thin films using Piezo force microscopy	The local ferroelectric & piezoelectric properties of PVDF-Bi25FeO40 composite thin films are investigated using piezo force microscopy (PFM) technique. The composite thin films are prepared by spincoater with PVDF & Bi25FeO40 nano powder solution mixture. The surface microstructure, confined domain structure & its corresponding d33 coefficient is explored with PFM under poling and no-poling.
124	Enhanced Discharging Energy Density in rGO/PVDF Nanocomposites: the Role of Heterointerface	Recent reports of conductive-filler/polymer composites with large dielectric permittivity K have made them potential candidates for flexible capacitors. Hence, an interesting yet unrevealed question is how these high K composites behave under strong operational electric field strengths. In this letter, we use in-situ-reduced-graphite-oxide (rGO)/Poly(vinylidene fluoride) nanocomposites as an example to study the energy storage behaviour of these high K materials. We show that the dielectric behaviour is contrasting between weak and strong field, and high K materials inevitably become lossier with increasing field strength. Simultaneously, we found the in-situ reduction temperature can affect the energy storage performance, and much enhanced energy storage performances are achieved in nanocomposites reduced at moderate temperatures. For instance, a nanocomposite reduced at 160&deg;C with an rGO volume fraction of 1.5 vol.% possesses a discharging energy density of 0.67J/cm<sup>3</sup> at 50MV/m, corresponding to 2.9 times increase over the pure PVDF. A model is proposed to explain this behaviour involving a reduced electrical contrast of the rGO/PVDF heterointerface that minimizes the recombination of localized charge carriers. The findings of this research have elucidated both the potential and limitation of high K nanocomposites, and has shed light on the optimisation of the design and fabrication of high discharging energy density flexible capacitors for microelectronic devices.
125	Synthesis of CdS nanoparticle by sol-gel method as low temperature NO2 sensor	Nitrogen dioxide (NO2) is important to be detected because it is poisonous and dangerous, still at very low concentration. However, most of the NO2 gas sensors based on CdS, not as much of sensitivity at operate high temperatures. Thin film based NO2 gas sensor of Cadmium sulphide (CdS) nanostructures were prepared by the chemical route and deposited over the Pt Inter Digital Electrodes (IDEs) substrates. CdS thin film prepares by spin coating technique with different speed (1000, 2000 and 3000 rpm) and film was annealed at 500 &#xF0B0;C. The CdS thin film was characterized by different techniques, such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and Ultraviolet-Visible spectroscopy (UV-Vis), which offered the information about the chemical structure of CdS, whereas electron microscopy images provided information regarding the morphology of the thin film material. CdS thin film observed maximum response (1.73&#x00D7;102) at 70 {degree sign}C operating temperature towards 20 ppm NO2 gas.
126	Synthesis and characterization of CdTe thin films deposited by electrochemical route	Electrodeposition is a low-cost and environment friendly method for the synthesis of semiconductor thin films and nanostructures. In this work, we synthesized cadmium telluride (CdTe) thin films on indium tin oxide coated glass substrate using an electrodeposition technique from an acidic sulphate aqueous electrolyte at the deposition temperature of 70{degree sign}C. The films were potentiostatically deposited at a constant potential of -0.70V with respect to saturated silver/silver chloride (Ag/AgCl) electrode as reference electrode. These films were characterized by using X-ray diffraction (XRD), Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), UV-Visibe (UV-Vis) spectroscopy, photoluminescence (PL) and probestation attached with Keithley source meter to investigate  structural, morphological, optical and electrical properties respectively. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern revealed that the films have cubic structure and are polycrystalline in nature. The average crystallite size and texture coefficient of the film were also calculated. Surface morphology of thin films was analysed using Scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The deposited films were homogeneous, uniform. The band gap of CdTe thin films was found to be 1.45 eV from the UV-Vis spectroscopy measurement. From photoluminescence spectrum, emission peak of prepared film was observed at 820 nm. The Electrical studies of films were done with keithley 2400 series source meter and current-voltage behavior was demonstrated. These semiconducting thin films may have broad applications in future optoelectronic based devices.
127	Future of Battery Energy Storage Systems	Growing needs of energy all over the world along with the integration of renewables and introduction of hourly tariff require energy storage in bulk. Li-Ion batteries are most efficient energy storage with energy cost of 400 $/kWh. High cost of Li-Ion batteries is significant barrier to deploy them at large scale. Salt water and redox flow batteries have moderate cost currently used at grid level due to moderate cost have an energy cost of only around 200 $/kWh. A lot of research is needed to reduce the cost to make these batteries viable for grid scale energy storage. This paper highlights key developments achieved in the battery energy storage technology during last 15 years. Along with the cost reduction size and weight reduction are also very important in mobile applications of energy storage like Plugin Hybrid Electrical Vehicles (PHEV). The use of many nano-materials has resulted in increase of energy density of existing battery technologies specially Li-Ion batteries. However, to commercialize the manufacturing of nanomaterial based batteries, a lot of new processes and techniques need to be introduced in the current battery industry.
128	<strong>Radiation stability of CBD grown nanocrystalline CdS films against ion beam irradiation for solar cell applications</strong>	<span style="font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;">Here we investigate the effect of swift heavy ion irradiation (SHII) on various properties of chemical bath deposited nanocrystalline CdS (nCdS) thin film. For this purpose, nCdS films are exposed to the varying ion fluences (1&times;10<sup>11</sup>-1&times;10<sup>14</sup> ion/cm<sup>2</sup>) of 80 Mev O<sup>+6</sup> ions. Glancing angle x-ray diffraction (GAXRD) and micro-Raman studies confirm the almost negligible structural transformation in CdS after ion irradiation even at highest fluence i.e. 1&times;10<sup>14</sup> ion/cm<sup>2</sup>. GAXRD, micro-Raman spectroscopy, field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and UV-Visible spectroscopy studies suggest that the structure, shape and size of particles as well as band gap of the nCdS films remain unaltered upon irradiation. The quality of the films and their radiation hardness is investigated by optical as well as electrical properties using photoluminescence spectroscopy and Hall measurements respectively. The films are found to be radiation resistant for 80 MeV O<sup>+6</sup> ion irradiation as compared to other heavy radiations. The stability of various properties of nCdS films under the impact of SHII may be due to lesser or comparable value of electronic energy loss (S<sub>e</sub>) to the threshold value of S<sub>e</sub>. Radiation hardness of nCdS thin films is a good sign for fabrication of high performance, radiation stable and long lasting solar cell for extraterrestrial applications.</span>
129	Synthesis and characterization of biodegradable cellulose nanowhiskers thin-film structures for flexible electronic devices and packaging application	Environmentally friendly cellulose nanowhiskers are cellulose crystallite rods having 3 - 70 nm dia, 25 nm to >1000 nm in length. Due to some of their properties like high specific surface area to weight ratio, mechanical,low density (1.6g/cm3), surface functionalization potential allowing it to achieve desired properties, and show great promise to biodegradable solutions in market such as packaging, healthcare, textiles, filtration, rheology modifiers, 3D printing & flexible electronics,etc. This work reports the chemical synthesis of cellulose nanowhiskers (CNWh) films from non edible part of cauliflower and were characterized by TGA, DSC, FTIR and electrical conductivity parameters. The 30, 40 and 50 wt% concentration dried cauliflower waste powder (CWP) hydrolysis by H2SO4 and water to split the &#x03B2;-l, 4-glucosidic bonds chain lengths while preserving the basic structure to possesses excellent strength, stability. Uniform flexible thin films of CNWhs were successfully prepared on glass plate at ambient temperature by solvent casting and dried at 50-60{degree sign}C for 120 min in hot air oven. The FTIR showed the glycosidic bonds breakage, peaks disappearance at 1200-1300 cm&#x2212;1 ascribed to lignin removal. CNWh films of 30% and 40% showed the lowest thermal expansion and highest thermal stability. DSC studies revealed that the H2SO4 treated samples are more stable than untreated sample, due to their high glass transition temperature. TGA analysis revealed the better thermal stability upto 190{degree sign}C, initial degradation at 260{degree sign}C and complete degradation at 460{degree sign}C. Conductivity study by four probe method showed the lowest resistivity of 0.755 Ohm.cm in 40% CNWh. The films studied properties showing the excellent device fabrication , packaging,etc applications.
130	Mg doped ZnO nanostructures for efficient Organic Light Emitting Diode	ZnO and Mg-doped ZnO nanostructures have been synthesized by a hydrothermal method for its potential application in Organic Light Emitting Diodes (OLED). Studies have been undertaken for structural as well as optical properties of ZnO after Mg doping with various concentrations. Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy-dispersive X-ray analysis indicated the rod-like structure for ZnO and with doping it's converted into the tetrapod structure. X-ray diffraction reveals the pure hexagonal phase of the wurtzite structure of ZnO and also finds other peaks related to Mg. UV-Visible suggested the exciton characteristic at room temperature and band gap variation while Photoluminescence spectra reveal two different regions (ultraviolet and blue). Synthesized materials have been blended with Poly [9, 9-dioctylfluorenyl-2, 7-diyl] (PFO) and prototype OLED has been fabricated using these materials as an emissive layer. Electroluminescence spectra show prominent blue emission at 433nm, 460 nm and 490 at 10V. Current-Voltage (I-V) curve reveal that the stability of OLED device at 20% of doping as compared with pristine PFO device.
131	Laser Molecular Beam Epitaxial Growth and Characterization of AlGaN Nanowall Network Structure on Sapphire (0001)	Self-assembled AlGaN nanowall networks have been epitaxially grown on sapphire (0001) by laser molecular beam epitaxy (LMBE) technique. The effect of growth temperature on the formation of AlGaN nanowall network structure has been studied in the range 600-700 &#xF0B0;C. It is found that growth of AlGaN under a strong N-rich growth condition at high growth temperature of 700 &#xF0B0;C is conducive for the formation of self-assembled nanowall network. The AlGaN nanowall network is highly oriented along c-direction as observed by in-situ reflection high energy electron diffraction and high-resolution x-ray diffraction measurements. The nanowall width and pore size are measured to be 20-50 and 30-70 nm, respectively, by using field emission scanning electron microscopy. From room temperature photoluminescence measurement, a strong UV emission at about 3.52 eV due to band-to-band transition is obtained for AlGaN nanowall structure with a high UV-to-yellow luminescence intensity ratio indicating good optical quality. The grown AlGaN nanowall network can find applications in field emitters, photo-detectors, and other nitride based optoelectronic devices.
132	Depth-Profiling X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) Analysis of Colloidal ZnO-CdSe Nanocomposites	X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy owing to its short inelastic mean free path of core-level electrons is the most consistent technique for the in-depth analysis of nanoparticles and with the layer-to-layer-depth profiling technique, helpful information regarding state and distribution of constituting elements along the depth of the sample. In this present work, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) has been used to study the core level of ZnO nanoparticles synthesized by wet chemical route at different calcination time.
