Composition ratio for Zn:O and various oxidation states are determined to find the best possible ZnO nanocrystals. 1hr calcined ZnO nanoparticles are chosen for synthesizing ZnO-CdSe nanocomposites as these particles were of large size ~ 20 nm, nearly monodispersed and of high purity. These nanocrystals are integrated with CdSe qdots of varied size (5nm and 8nm) via MPA (mercaptopropionic acid) as a linker to develop hybrid nanocomposites for application in Quantum Dot sensitized solar cells QDSSC's. Here, XPS technique has been used as a probe to pictorially model the compositional, structural and morphological aspects of ZnO-CdSe nanocomposites. On the basis of XPS and other complimentary techniques, it was found that high quality of nanocomposite can be synthesized with smaller sized quantum dots, as compared to larger sized quantum dots because of unbounded phosphorus (P) and selenium (Se). Also, it confirms the role of linker that strengthens the binding  of CdSe quantum dots on the surface of ZnO thus making it hard to separate the anchored, interstitial CdSe completely which paves the way for the development of stoichiometric, structurally & morphologically-stable ZnO-CdSe nanocomposites.
133	Influence of solute concentration on the properties of  sol-gel spin coated  Zinc oxide thin films	Zinc Oxide (ZnO) is a versatile material with unique properties, finds variety of application in microelectronics and photonics associated technologies. ZnO thin films have been developed by Sol-gel spin coating method. ZnO thin films have been deposited on to mineral glass substrate under optimized coating conditions, using the sol solution containing different solute concentration viz., 0.27, 0.36, 0.46 and 0.56 mole %. The crystallographic parameters have been evaluated from the XRD data and its variation with solute concentration is investigated. Optical constants and band gap energy of the ZnO thin films have been determined from the transmittance measurement in the UV-Visible region. Higher optical transmittance of 88.3 % have been observed for the ZnO thin film coated with the sol solution containing 3.6 mole % of solute. Atomic force microscopy image of the ZnO films illustrates with uniformly spaced nano structured grains and cylindrical rods. Photoluminescence studies of the ZnO film coated with sol solution containing 0.36 mole % demonstrate three emission peaks at 420 nm, 480 nm and 520 nm respectively for the excitation wavelength 350 nm.  The influences of solute concentration of the ZnO sol solution on the structural, optical and surface properties of the spin coated ZnO thin films have been analyzed and elaborately discussed. This study aimed to develop device quality ZnO thin films for photovoltaic applications.
134	Superconducting properties of NbN film, bridge & meanders	The transport properties of superconducting NbN nanostructures in the form of thin film, bridge of width (w) = 50 &#x00B5;m and three meanders of w = 500, 250 and 100 nm have been investigated by resistance (R) measurements in temperature (T) range = 2 -300 K and magnetic field (B) range = 0 - 7 Tesla. The nano-structuring was carried out using Focused Ion Beam (FIB) milling. Reduction of sample width results in significant changes in the normal and superconducting state properties. For instance, the observed metallic behavior in the thin film sample is lost and the normal state resistance increases drastically from 2.4 &#x03A9; to 418 k&#x03A9; for the 100 nm meander. In the superconducting state the value of critical temperature Tc (upper critical field Bc2 at T = 0 K) reduces gradually with width reduction, it changes from 13.15 K (42.8 Tesla) in the case of thin film sample to 5.7 K (12.7 Tesla) for the 100 nm meander sample. The superconducting transitions are found to get broader for the bridge sample and the meanders additionally show low-temperature resistive tails. In case of all the samples with reduced width, the transition onsets are found to be rounded at surprisingly high values of T ~ 25 K >> Tc. These results are discussed in terms of the possible intrinsic effects due to reduced dimensions and extrinsic effects due to the FIB milling process.
135	Plasma Induced Nanostructures on the Surface of Tungsten Anode in Atmospheric Pressure Glow	Nanostructures such as "fuzz", holes, and flakes were observed on anode electrodes made of stainless steel and tungsten that were exposed to an atmospheric pressure, helium Direct current (DC) glow discharge.  The structures exhibited morphology similar to the tungsten fuzz growth observed in experiments that simulate wall conditions in fusion reactors, suggesting similar physics may be present in both scenarios.  The anode surface temperature ranged between 1000 and 1300 K with an ion fluence rate of order of 1024 s-1m-2.  In this work, scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were used to characterize the evolution of nanostructure formation as a function of time.  Observed nanostructures were found to vary with the morphology of the discharge plasma attachment. The composition of the structures was found to be predominantly the native metal. This work gives some insight into the formation of nanostructures at atmospheric pressure which has not only applications for material processing but also provides potentially another avenue to study fuzz formation processes relevant to fusion.
136	Studies of the mechanism and characteristics of the anodic aluminum oxide thin film-enabled fluorescence enhancement	The mechanism of the anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) thin film for the fluorescence enhancement is reported for the first time. It has been found that the main contributing factor to the fluorescence enhancement is the plasmonic Al nanoparticles (NPs) embedded in the film, while the nanopore size and porosity have limited contribution. The characteristics of the enhancement have also been studied. It has been found that the enhancement is highly related to the gap between the fluorophore and the surface of the AAO thin film. Different excitation wavelength also results in somewhat different fluorescence enhancement. Using a simple model with Al NPs uniformly distributed in the thin film, the calculated the enhancement factor and characteristics of the fluorescence enhancement show the similar trend to the experimental results.
137	Effects of electron-electron interaction on the collinear indirect exchange coupling in graphene nanoflake	Using the Hubbard model in the framework of the tight-bonding formulation, We study the effects of the&nbsp;electron-electron (e-e) interaction on the indirect magnetic exchange coupling between the magnetic impurities&nbsp;embedded in triangular graphene nanoflakes.The results show that the magnitude of the coupling enhances&nbsp;in the presence of the e-e interaction and Rashba spin-orbit interaction(RSOI). Also, the RKKY coupling&nbsp;magnitude depends on the impurity positions in nanoflake and the size of the system.
138	<strong>Determining the polarity of AlGaN nanostructure by piezoresponse force microscopy</strong>	The electronic property of the materials can be tuned with the application of mechanical strain to materials having both semiconducting and piezoelectric character leading to a new research area of piezotronics. Group III nitride falls in this category along with its excellent optoelectronic behaviour. The present report demonstrates the piezoresponse force microscopic imaging of the Al<sub>0.97</sub>Ga<sub>0.03</sub>N nanostructures oriented in different crystallographic directions. Al<sub>0.97</sub>Ga<sub>0.03</sub>N nanostructures are grown by the plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy technique. The phase formation is investigated by the Raman spectroscopic analysis. Spatial distribution of piezoresponse for Al<sub>0.97</sub>Ga<sub>0.03</sub>N nanostructures was mapped and the polarities of the different crystalline planes of <em>m</em> and <em>c</em> are determined. The corresponding piezoresponse is explained on the basis of spontaneous and induced polarization in a unit cell of the hexagonal crystal, which is further confirmed using piezoresponse spectroscopy. An unusually high value of d<sub>33 </sub>~ 9.0 pm/V for nanosize Al<sub>0.97</sub>Ga<sub>0.03</sub>N is attributed to the availability of free boundary for volume expansion or contraction at the nanoscale.
139	Oxidation facilitated antimicrobial ability of laser micro-textured titanium alloy against gram-positive staphylococcus aureus for biomedical applications	Micro-textures were engineered on titanium samples by rapid, highly repeatable and cost effective nanosecond laser texturing process. The controlled and repeatable micro-texture was effective in reduction of adhesion and proliferation of Staphylococcus aureus. However, the adhesion and proliferation of human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells was found unaffected. We observed time-delayed saturation of oxidation on laser micro-textured Ti6Al4V as compared to pristine material yielding super-hydrophobic surface (contact angle of ~158.2&#x02DA;). An in-house setup was designed to expose a 3 dimensionally laser micro-textured Ti6Al4V sample to S. aureus-spiked-nutrient-broth for 24 hours in a closed loop continuous flow system. We observed 50 % reduction of S. aureus adhesion and proliferation over laser micro-textured surface than pristine samples. In-vitro tests confirmed that blood coagulation remain largely unaffected, while protein adsorption was decreased by four folds on the micro-textured surfaces; a desirable property for surgical tools. Nanosecond laser micro-textured surfaces were effective in reducing S. aureus adhesion and its proliferation due to phase evolution, oxidative transformation of Ti6Al4V as well as due to reduction of surface potential. In addition, laser based micro-texturing is a non-toxic, environment friendly green process that also provides cost effective alternative over conventional surface modification techniques such as mechanical micromachining and chemical treatments.
140	Effect of MWCNT-Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>/Water Hybrid Nanofluid on the Thermal Performance of Ribbed Channel with Apart Sections of Heating and Cooling	Two-dimensional (2D) numerical simulation is performed to &nbsp;simulate the laminar force convection of nanofluid in a ribbed channel with apart heating (cooling) sources using lattice Boltzmann method (LBM). The multi-wall carbon nanotubes-iron oxide nanoparticles/water hybrid nanofluid (MWCNT-Fe3O4/water hybrid nanofluid) used in this simulation. &nbsp;The velocity field, temperature distribution and heat transfer rate are analyzed numerically with the streamlines and isotherm patterns by a house-code. Also, the effect of Reynolds number (Re=25, 50, 75 and 100), nanoparticle solid volume fraction (&#x03D5;=0, 0.001, 0.003) and ratio of the height of blocks (A=0.2, 0.3, 0.4) considered in this paper. The computational method is validated with the results reported in the literature and a good agreement is founded. The obtained results showed a maximum value 16.49% increase in average heat transfer coefficient for all the considered cases compared to the base fluid. Moreover, the local Nusselt number showed that the use of blocks on the channel's walls could increase the amount of heat transfer. Finally, averaged Nusselt number shows a linear dependence by increasing the ratio of the height of blocks for constant solid volume fraction. The results of this study are &nbsp;applicable in industrial equipment heating and cooling applications.
141	<strong>Non-volatile memory and negative photoconductivity in a metal-insulator-semiconductor diode with embedded Co nanoparticles</strong>	We describe a new metal-insulator-semiconductor (MIS) device in which Cobalt based nano particles (NPs) in a core-shell structure (Co &ndash; core and Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> - shell) are embedded between a thermally grown SiO<sub>2</sub> layer and a HfO<sub>2</sub> film deposited by atomic layer deposition. Two additional structures were prepared for comparison. One had no NPs and the other included the Fe NPs, prepared using the same procedure as used for the Co film. All devices exhibited the classic behavior of a voltage variable MIS capacitor with or without a large hysteresis as in non-volatile memory systems. However, only the device with Co core-shell structure exhibits a negative photoconductivity (NPC) effect as well as non-volatile memory (NVM) capabilities in both the capacitance-voltage (<em>C-V)</em> and current-voltage (<em>I-V) </em>characteristics. The dependence of <em>C-V</em> and current voltage <em>I-V</em> characteristics on illumination intensity and wavelength (from ultraviolet to near infrared) as well as on temperature were characterized. Illumination enhances the NPC effect as well as the flat-band voltage shift determined from C-V characteristics and hence the memory width. Illumination in the wavelength range of 735-780 nm caused a current decrease, at a given voltage, by up to a factor of two. The NPC effect stimulates an annihilation of the stored charges and therefore erases the system instantly at small applied bias. The main cause of NPC effect under illumination is the photo excitation of supplementary trap channels in the Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> shell, which lowers the free carrier density and hence the conductivity of the MIS structure.
142	<strong> Width and strain effect on quantum transport in MoS2 armchair nanoribbons </strong>	Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is layered transition metal dichalcogenide (TMDC), which in its monolayer form has the direct bandgap of 1.8 eV. This large bandgap makes MoS2 a good candidate for using in transistors. The density-functional study of strain and width effects on the electronic band structure and transport properties of the MoS2-bare and MoS2-passivated armchair nanorib- bons are presented. We focused on the quantum conductance and band structures of the MoS2-bare and MoS2-passivated armchair nanoribbons applying Wannier function and Non-Equilibrium Green Function in different width, and for width 7 and 8 under strain in -15% to +15%. Our results indicate that MoS2-passivated armchair nanoribbons are good candidates for using in transistors, composites and for fabrication of flexible electronic devices.
143	Probing Patchy Saturation of Fluids in Nanoporous Media by Ultrasound	Nanoporous materials provide high surface area per unit mass and are capable of fluids adsorption. While the measurements of overall amount of fluid adsorbed by a nanopororus sample are straightforward, probing the fluid spacial distribution is non-trivial. We consider published data on adsorption and desorption of fluids in nanoporous glasses reported along with the measurements of ultrasonic waves propagation. We analyse these using Biot's theory of dynamic poroelasticity, approximating the patches as spherical shells. Our calculations show that on adsorption the patch diameter is on the order of 10-20 pore diameters, while on desorption the patch size is comparable to the sample size. Our analysis suggests that one can employ ultrasound to probe the uniformity of fluid spatial distribution in nanoporous materials.
144	<strong>Ignition and self-propagating reactions in Al/Pt multilayers of varied stoichiometry</strong>	The propensity of Al/Pt multilayers to undergo high temperature, self-propagating reactions has been evaluated across broad ranges of stoichiometry and bilayer thickness. Freestanding, ~1.6 mm-thick Al/Pt multilayers having nanometer-scale layer thicknesses ignite and exhibit rapid exothermic reactions when the molar ratio of reactants is in the range of 1Al:4Pt to 4Al:1Pt. &nbsp;Reactive Al/Pt structures have heats of reaction (<em>&#x2206;H<sub>rxn</sub></em>) between -30 and -95 kJ/mol.at. with equimolar forms showing the largest calorific output. Ignition occurs at temperatures below the melting point of both reactants (and eutectics) demonstrating that initiation occurs via solid-state mixing.&nbsp; Equimolar multilayers exhibit the lowest ignition temperatures when comparing structures having a specific bilayer thickness.&nbsp; Equimolar Al/Pt multilayers also undergo the most rapid self-sustained reactions with wavefront speeds as large as 73 m/s. &nbsp;Al- and Pt-rich multilayers react at reduced rates (as low as 1 m/s), consistent with reduced |<em>&#x2206;H<sub>rxn</sub></em>| and lower adiabatic temperatures. &nbsp;Nearly all of the reactive multilayers undergo stable, propagating reactions characterized by a smooth wavefront morphology.&nbsp; Only multilayers made with a 1Al:4Pt molar ratio and large bilayer thickness of 800 nm exhibit a 2-D instability.&nbsp; An analytical model that accounts for key thermodynamic properties, preliminary mixing along interfaces, and thermal/mass transport is used to predict the wavefront speed dependencies on bilayer thickness.&nbsp; Good fits to experimental data provide estimates for thermal diffusivity of premixed interfacial volumes and activation energy associated with mass transport.&nbsp; We suggest that Pt dissolution in to molten Al is a rate-limiting step underlying propagating reactions in many forms of Al/Pt.
145	Nanometer Growth of Marine Bio-films of Different Metallic Alloys in Seawater by Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy	The main purpose of this study was to monitor the growth of the marine bio-film, of micro/macro-organisms, on the surface of different metallic alloys in seawater by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The alloys used in this study were; UNS 1020 carbon steel, stainless steel 304, stainless steel 316L, Sanicro 28, Cu-Ni 70-30, Hastelloy G-30, and titanium. The EIS was used to measure the A.C. Impedance (Z) and the double layer capacitance (Cdl) of the formed bio-film in seawater on a frequent basis. The total exposure time of the tests was ranged between 90 days to 180 days. The visual inspection of the tested samples showed a bio-film formation on the surface of these samples.  The microbiologically influenced (induced) corrosion(MIC) was observed only on the carbon steel.   Monitoring the growth of the bio-film formation was accomplished by the EIS during the 90-180 days exposure of the tested samples.   A gradual monitoring of the growth of the bio-film formation was achieved by mathematically correlating the obtained the A.C. Impedance (Z) and the double layer capacitance (Cdl) of the bio-film to the thickness of the bio-film formation.   The advantage of EIS is a non-invasive technique with a sensing (spatial) resolution in a nanometer scale in a comparison to other techniques of monitoring the growth of bio-films on metallic alloys in aqueous solutions.
146	Transmitted optical spatial differentiator based on subwavelength high-contrast gratings	A transmitted optical spatial differentiator based on subwavelength high-contrast gratings (HCG) is proposed experimentally. The spatial differentiation property of the subwavelength HCG is analyzed by calculating its spatial spectral transfer function based on the periodic waveguide theory. By employing the FDTD solutions, the performance of the subwavelength HCG spatial differentiator was investigated numerically. The subwavelength HCG differentiator with thickness at nanoscale was fabricated on the quartz substrate by the electron beam lithography and the Bosch deep silicon etching. Observed under an optical microscope with a CCD camera, the spatial differentiation of the incident field profile was obtained by the subwavelength HCG differentiator in transmission without Fourier lens. By projecting the images of slits with different widths and letter `X' on the subwavelength HCG differentiator, edge detections of both kinds of images were obtained in transmission. With the nanoscale HCG structure and simple optical implementation, the proposed optical spatial differentiator provide the prospects for application in optical computing systems and parallel data processing.
147	<strong>2D</strong><strong><strong>&nbsp;electron crystals on p</strong></strong><strong><strong>lasm</strong></strong><strong><strong>a </strong></strong><strong><strong>surface induced&nbsp;</strong></strong><strong><strong>by</strong></strong><strong><strong>&nbsp;nanosecond </strong></strong><strong><strong>pulsed</strong></strong><strong><strong>&nbsp;</strong></strong><strong><strong>laser</strong></strong><strong><strong>&nbsp;on silicon</strong></strong>	During pulsed laser interaction on silicon surface, the transient electron lattices occur on plasma resonance induced from faster photons on surface. Here, it is interesting&nbsp;that the electron crystals&nbsp;can be built on plasma surface induced by intensive faster photons&nbsp;on silicon, which is similar with&nbsp;Wigner crystal&nbsp;in intensive electric field or intensive magnetic field. In the two-dimensional&nbsp;(2D)&nbsp;Bravais lattices, the electron crystals of three-fold, four-fold and six-fold symmetry lattices can be observed on plasma surface by using the reflecting&nbsp;Talbot effect images. On these surface period lattices, the decay spectrum&nbsp;of faster emission on the&nbsp;2D transient&nbsp;electron crystal was measured, which is related to&nbsp;the faster decay peak with lifetime of 100ns. These new phenomena have a good application in preparing the PN junction&nbsp;of photo-electronic devices, where the surface electron gas on plasma surface can inject into the top layer to build N type region, and the positive ions under plasma can inject into the bottom layer for forming P type region on silicon&nbsp;in vacuum.
148	A new application area of C<sub>60</sub>: overall improvement of insulating oil&rsquo;s electrical performance	A new nano-C<sub>60</sub> based insulating oil was found which is considered could overcome the barriers to the application of nano-modified insulating oil. We found nano-C<sub>60</sub> based insulating oil has an excellent stability and its electrical performance increased by 17.9%, 9.3% and 8.3%, respectively, for AC and positive/negative lightning impulse voltage. We believe C<sub>60</sub> molecules have a strong capacity to absorb electrons and they can capture photons in the streamer, which may weaken the photo ionization in streamer and thereby improve the electrical performance of insulating oil.
149	<strong>Tunable Magnetic Properties and Valley Splitting in Layered Ferrovalley 2H-VSe<sub>2</sub>: Strain and Layer Thickness Effects</strong>	Geometry structure, band structure, magnetic moment and magnetocrystalline anisotropy energy of layered 2H-VSe<sub>2</sub> are investigated by first-principles calculations. It is found that the VSe<sub>2 </sub>are intrinsic ferromagnetic with an in-plane magnetocrystalline anisotropy no matter how the change of the strain and layer thickness is. Additionally, the valley splitting in monolayer VSe<sub>2</sub> can be modulated by strain due to the modulated intrinsic exchange interaction of V 3<em>d </em>electrons. Interestingly, the valley splitting decreases and the V magnetic moment monotonously increases as a strain increases, showing that the valley splitting is related to the magnetic moment. Furthermore, the slight effect of interlayer coupling on V magnetic moment appears. The tunable magnetism and valley splitting may provide novel applications in multifunctional nanoelectronics.
150	<strong>Large negative thermal expansion in highly strained multiferroic films</strong>	In contrast to bulk BiFeO<sub>3</sub> (BFO), highly strained BFO films (nearly tetragonal phase, T-like phase) possess many more characteristics favorable for device applications, such as colossal ferroelectric and piezoelectric properties, nanoscale shape memory effect, persistent photoconductivity and an electromechanical response. Here, we identify novel negative thermal expansion (NTE) behavior in highly strained BFO films. Through La doping, the N&eacute;el temperature can be further adjusted over a broad range of temperatures. The lattice parameters show anomalies at the spin order-to-disorder transition point that are driven by spin-lattice coupling. For the Bi<sub>0.9</sub>La<sub>0.1</sub>FeO<sub>3</sub> film, NTE is observed from room temperature to 673 K or even higher, with a giant negative coefficient of linear thermal expansion of <strong>&alpha;</strong> = -12.8&times;10<sup>-6</sup> /K occurring over 370 K. Furthermore, we find that the NTE effect is greatly enhanced by phase coexistence in T-like BFO films. A giant negative coefficient of linear thermal expansion of <strong>&alpha;</strong> = -22.3&times;10<sup>-6</sup> /K is observed at T = 400-673 K for a 50 nm mixed-phase T-like BFO film. Our findings have broad application prospects for functional materials to display not only good physical properties but also controllable thermal expansion.
151	<strong>The origin of photoluminescence in &beta;-Ga&shy;<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub></strong>	&beta;-Ga&shy;<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, a candidate material for power electronics and UV optoelectronics, shows strong room temperature photoluminescence (PL). In addition to the three well known bands of as-grown samples in the UV, blue and green, also red PL was observed upon nitrogen-doping. This raises the possibility of applying &beta;-Ga&shy;<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanostructures as white phosphors. Using an optimized, Koopmans-compliant hybrid functional, we show that most intrinsic point defects, as well as substitutional nitrogen act as deep acceptors, and each of the observed PL bands can be explained by electron recombination with a hole trapped in one of them. We suggest this mechanism to be general in wide band gap semiconductors which can only be doped <em>n</em>-type. Calculations on the nitrogen acceptor reproduce the observed red luminescence accurately. Earlier we have shown that not only the energy, but the polarization properties of the UV band can be explained by self-trapped hole states. Here we find that the blue band has its origin mainly in singly negative Ga&ndash;O divacancies, and the green band is caused dominantly by interstitial O atoms (with minor contribution of Ga vacancies to both). These assignments can explain the experimentally observed dependence of the PL bands on free electron concentration and stoichiometry. The information provided here paves the way for the conscious tuning of light emission from &beta;-Ga&shy;<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>.
152	Simultaneous growth of diamond and SiC/graphene nanolaminate: Formation of a triple hybrid material	A diamond, 3C-SiC and graphene composite material is synthesized via microwave chemical vapor deposition on a cemented tungsten carbide substrate. The deposited composite material consists of a microcrystalline diamond phase and a second phase, a SiC/graphene nanolaminate structure. The formation of this triple hybrid structure was confirmed by X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. The growth mechanism is discussed.
153	Nanoscale patterning of electronic devices at the amorphous&nbsp;LaAlO<sub>3</sub>-SrTiO<sub>3</sub> oxide interface using an electron sensitive polymer mask	A new approach is presented for designing complex oxide mesoscopic electronic devices based on the conducting interfaces of room temperature grown LaAlO<sub>3</sub>/SrTiO<sub>3</sub> heterostructures. The technique is based entirely on methods known from conventional semiconductor processing technology and we demonstrate lateral resolution of ~100 nm. We study the low temperature transport properties of nanoscale wires and demonstrate the feasibility of the technique for defining in-plane gates allowing local control of the electrostatic environment in mesoscopic devices.
154	<strong>Momentum-quantization induced band splitting in semiconductor nanostructures: Observation of emission lines in InP nanotubes</strong>	The effect of spatial confinement-induced momentum quantization on the band structure of semiconductor nanotubes is investigated by developing a theoretical model with subsequent experimental verification on MOCVD-grown InP nanotubes. The incorporation of momentum quantization in sp<sup>3</sup>s*-model with spin-orbit coupling indicates the splitting of &Gamma;-point into two different symmetric points, &Gamma;' and &Gamma;", which emit two spectral lines as confirmed by cathodoluminescence spectra. The observation provides novel insight into the band structure based transport behavior of semiconductor quantum devices.
155	<strong>Femtosecond Two-photon Absorption Spectroscopy of Copper Indium Disulfide Quantum Dots: A Structure-Optical Properties Relationship</strong>	We have interpreted the two-photon absorption spectrum of water-soluble Cu<sub>0.18</sub>In<sub>0.42</sub>S<sub>2</sub> QDs with an average diameter of approximately 2.6 nm. For that, we employed the wavelength-tunable femtosecond Z-scan technique and the parabolic effective-mass approximation model, in which the excitonic transition energies were phenomenologically corrected due to the stoichiometry of the nanocrystal. This model considers a conduction band and three valence sub-bands allowing excitonic transitions via centrosymmetric (<em>&Delta;l = &plusmn;1</em>, where <em>l </em>is the angular momentum of the absorbing state) and noncentrosymmetric (<em>&Delta;l = 0</em>) channels. In such case, this became relevant because the CuInS<sub>2</sub> QDs with chalcopyrite crystal structure is a noncentrosymmetric semiconductor. Thus, our experimental results pointed out two 2PA allowed bands located at 715 nm (2hv =3.47 eV) and 625 nm (2hv =3.97 eV) with cross sections of (6.3 &plusmn; 1.0) x 10<sup>2</sup> GM and (4.5 &plusmn; 0.7) x 10<sup>2</sup> GM, respectively. According to the theoretical model, these 2PA bands can be ascribed to the 1P<sub>1/2</sub>(h<sub>3</sub>) &rarr; 1S<sub>3/2</sub>(e) (lower energy band) and 1P<sub>1/2</sub>(h<sub>heavy</sub>) &rarr; 1S<sub>3/2</sub>(e) <strong>(90%)</strong>/<strong>(10 %)</strong>1P<sub>1/2</sub>(h<sub>split-off</sub>) &rarr; 1P<sub>3/2</sub>(e) (higher energy band) excitonic transitions. A good agreement (magnitude and spectral position) between the experimental and theoretical data were obtained. However, our experimental data suggest that the higher-energy 2PA band may have other contributions due to the mixing between the heavy- and the light-hole bands, which the effective mass model does not take into consideration.
156	Bilayered graphene nanoribbons with closed edge holes: atomic structures and electronic properties	Here we presented results which may be considered as a first step to initiate the fundamental interest to the perforated bilayered nanoribbon structures with close edges based on graphene. Theoretical investigations of a novel bilayered graphene nanoribbon (BGNR) structures with periodically arranged hole using <em>ab initio</em> calculations is presented. BGNRs with various type of stacking (AA, AB and 30&deg;) were considered. If was found that such structures could display different electronic properties (from semiconducting to metallic) depending on the geometry configuration of the holes.
157	Computational analysis of Joule-heating and viscous dissipation effects on magnetohydrodynamic flow and heat transfer of Cu-water Jeffrey nanofluid over a stretching sheet	The purpose of the present study is to examine  the impact of copper nanoparticles on the steady 2D magnetohydrodynamic boundary layer  flow and heat transfer  of Jeffrey fluid over a stretching sheet with viscous dissipation. Copper nanoparticles  are suspended with water, kerosene and ethylene glycol  as the base fluids. The governing non-linear partial differential equations (PDEs) are reduced to the non-linear ordinary differential equations (ODEs) by using  appropriate dimensionless variables and then solved numerically by using Keller-box technique. The impacts ofsnanoparticle volume fraction,  magnetic parameter, Deborah number,  Prandtl number and Eckert number  on the velocity and temperature profiles, local Nusselt number and skin friction %drag coefficient%s are investigated with the assistance of graphs and tables. Results indicate that the  velocity, skin friction and local Nusselt number for the  copper-water nanofluid are comparatively less than those of the base fluid, however the temperature is enhanced through the addition of nanoparticles.  It is found that both the skin friction and the Nusselt number increase by increasing the  Deborah number whereas they decrease by increasing the magnetic parameter. It is noticed that the copper-water Jeffrey nanofluids has higher skin friction and heat transfer rate as compared to copper-ethylene glycol and copper-kerosene Jeffrey nanofluids.
158	<strong>Perpendicular Anisotropy in the Heusler Compound Co<sub>2</sub>TiSi</strong>	Perpendicular magnetic anisotropy, a property of utmost importance in magnetic nano&shy;techno&shy;&shy;logies, is relatively easy to create in ultrathin films due to surface and interface contributions. In films of Co<sub>2</sub>TiSi on MgO, which are of interest for high-density magnetoresistive random-access memories (MRAMs), perpen&shy;dicular anisotropy has been achieved for film thicknesses of a few atomic layers, but thermal stability in nanoelectronic devices requires perpendicular anisotropy in thicker films. Here we report robust perpendicular anisotropy of 0.5 MJ/m<sup>3</sup> in 100 nm epitaxial films of Co<sub>2</sub>TiSi on MgO(001). This result is surprising for several reasons. First, surface and inter&shy;face aniso&shy;tropies are too small to explain perpendicular anisotropy in such films. Second, Co<sub>2</sub>TiSi has a substantial magnetization and crystallizes in a cubic Heusler struc&shy;ture, so that conventional wisdom predicts a preferential magnetization direction in the film plane rather than perpendicular. Third, the films have lattice constants a = b &raquo; c and the cor&shy;responding strain is unable to account for the perpendicular anisotropy. We explain the per&shy;pendicular anisotropy as a symmetry-breaking chemical-ordering effect promoted by the substrate.
159	Tuning nanostructures and optical properties of undoped and N-doped ZnO by supercritical fluid treatment	It has been reported that supercritical fluid can improve the performance of ZnO based devices, while the mechanism of this improvement is still unclear. In this paper we study the transformation of surface morphologies and emission properties of ZnO films before and after supercritical fluid treatment, connecting the two structures together, which can tune the performance of ZnO films or ZnO films based device, such as catalytic, opto-electronic performance. Both undoped and N-doped ZnO nanostructures obtained by supercritical fluid (SCF) treated films are investigated by the surface morphology techniques (scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and atomic force morphology (AFM)), as well as room temperature photoluminescence (RT-PL). It is found that, the W-SCCO2 technology can be used to effectively obtain the nanostructures in ZnO films with self-catalyzed process due to the Zn rich condition in ZnO films, and can promote the inhibition of defect luminescence by inducing -OH into the films. Two models are proposed to interpret the supercritical processes. This work demonstrates that the water-mixed supercritical CO2 (W-SCCO2) technology could be used as a novel effective tool for nano design and for improving the properties of functional metal oxides.
160	Pattern formation on ion-irradiated Si surface at energies where sputtering is negligible	The effect of low energy irradiation, where the sputtering is&nbsp; imperceptible, has not been deeply studied in the pattern formation. In this work, we want to address this question by analyzing the nanoscale topography formation on Si surface, which is irradiated at room temperature by Ar<sup>+</sup> ions near the displacement threshold energy, for incidence angles ranging from 0 to 85<sup>o</sup>. The transition from smooth to ripple patterned surface, i.e. the stability/instability bifurcation angle is observed at 55<sup>o</sup>, whereas the ripples with their wave-vector is parallel to the ion beam projection in the angular window of 60-70<sup>o</sup>, and with 90<sup>o</sup>&nbsp;rotation with respect to the ion beam projection at the grazing angles of incidence. A similar irradiation setup has been simulated by means of molecular dynamics, which made it possible, firstly, to quantify the effect of the irradiation in terms of erosion and redistribution using sequential irradiation and, secondly, to evaluate the ripple wavelength using the crater function formalism. The ripple formation results can be solely attributed to the mass redistribution based mechanism, as erosion due to ion sputtering near or above the threshold energy is practically negligible.
161	Efficient correction of wavefront inhomogeneities in X-ray holographic nanotomography by random sample displacement	In X-ray tomography, ring-shaped artifacts present in the reconstructed slices are an inherent problem degrading the global image quality and hindering the extraction of quantitative information. To overcome this issue, we propose a strategy for suppression of ring artifacts originating from the coherent mixing of the incident wave and the object. We discuss the limits of validity of the empty beam correction in the framework of a simple formalism. We then deduce a correction method based on two-dimensional random sample displacement, with minimal cost in terms of spatial resolution, acquisition and processing time. The method is demonstrated on bone tissue and on a hydrogen electrode of a ceramic-metallic solid oxide cell. Compared to the standard empty beam correction we obtain high quality nanotomography images revealing detailed object features. The resulting absence of artifacts allows straightforward segmentation and posterior quantification of the data.
162	Orthogonally polarized self-mixing grating interferometer for two-dimensional displacement measurement	In this paper, we present an orthogonally polarized self-mixing grating interferometer (SMGI) for simultaneous measurement of in-plane and out-of-plane displacements. The measurement ranges in both directions are limited only by the length of grating. The orthogonally polarized lights emitted from a birefringent He-Ne laser are separated and enter the grating at {plus minus}1st-order Littrow diffraction angles, respectively. The diffraction beams return to the laser cavity then self-mixing interference effect occurs. To differentiate the orthogonally polarized lights and obtain high resolution, phase modulation technique is introduced to extract phases from the orthogonally polarized SMGI signals. Based on mode competition effects, balanced detection is applied to avoid the laser internal noise in the signal. Measurement results show that the proposed system can reach a nanoscale resolution and submicron accuracy in both two directions. The work provides a good way to achieve high precision two-dimensional displacement measurement with a robust system configuration.
163	Study of buckling behavior at the nanoscale through capillary adhesion force	This paper presents mechanical actuation experiments performed on ultrathin suspended nanoscale silicon devices presenting Euler buckling. The devices are fabricated by a combination of focused ion beam (FIB) implantation and selective wet etching. By loading the center of curved nanobeams with an atomic force microscope (AFM) tip the beams can be switched from an up-buckled position to the opposite down-buckled configuration. It is possible to describe the entire snap-through process thanks to the presence of strong capillary forces that act as physical constraint between the tip and the device. The experiments conducted recall the same behavior of macro and microscale devices with similar geometry. Curved nanobeams present a bistable behavior, i.e. they are stable in both configurations, up or down-buckled. In addition to that, by the method presented, it is possible to observe the dynamic of a mechanical switch at the nanoscale.
164	Spectroscopy of gold atoms and gold oligomers in helium nanodroplets	The 6p <sup>2</sup>P<sub>1/2</sub> &#x2190; 6s <sup>2</sup>S<sub>1/2</sub> and 6p <sup>2</sup>P<sub>3/2</sub> &#x2190; 6s <sup>2</sup>S<sub>1/2</sub> transitions (D lines) of gold atoms embedded in superfluid helium nanodroplets have been investigated using resonant two-photon ionization spectroscopy. Both transitions are strongly blue-shifted and broadened due to the repulsive interaction between the Au valence electron and the surrounding helium. The in-droplet D lines are superimposed by the spectral signature of Au atoms relaxed into the metastable <sup>2</sup>D states. These features are narrower than the in-droplet D lines and exhibit sharp rising edges that coincide with bare atom transitions. It is concluded that they originate from metastable <sup>2</sup>D state AuHe<sub>n</sub> exciplexes that have been ejected from the helium droplets during a relaxation process. Interestingly, the mechanism that leads to the formation of these complexes is suppressed for very large helium droplets consisting of about 2 x 10<sup>6</sup> He atoms, corresponding to a droplet diameter on the order of 50 nm. The assignment of the observed spectral features is supported by <i>ab-initio</i> calculations employing a multiconfigurational self consistent field (MCSCF) method and a multi-reference configuration interaction (MRCI) calculation.sFor large helium droplets doped with Au oligomers, excitation spectra for mass channels corresponding to Au<sub>n</sub> with n = 2, 3, 4, 5, 7 and 9 are presented. The mass spectrum reveals even-odd oscillations in the number of Au atoms that constitute the oligomer, which is characteristic for coinage metal clusters. Resonances are observed close by the in-droplet D1 and D2 transitions, which, surprisingly, exhibit a very similar shape independent of the cluster size.
165	FREE ENERGY OF WATER HETEROGENEOUS NUCLEATION IN THE FIELD OF NANOSCOPIC DEFECTS ON BASAL FACE OF  &#x03B2;-AgI CRYSTAL	The free energy, the formation work and the entropy dependences for water condensate formed from the vapor over the defect-free and containing surface defects basal face of &#x03B2;-AgI crystal at initial stage of adsorption at temperatures of 260 K and 400 K are calculated using the bicanonical statistical ensemble method, with Ewald summation for long-range electrostatic and polarization interactions with the substrate. The effect of surface defects in form of rectangular "towers" as a part of regular structure on the adsorption capacity of the surface is investigated. In contrast to the small-scale structures, relatively larger coarse-grained nanostructure on crystal surface demonstrates unconditional advantages in adsorption properties with respect to defect-free surface. The adsorption on the surface with multiple defects begins at vapor pressures 5-6 orders of magnitude lower than on the defect-free surface. The increased adsorption capacity of nanostructured surface is resistant to temperature variations. The adsorbate on the surface of the crystal is thermodynamically stable, both on defect-free and nanostructured surfaces, with the exception of short initial stage of the monomolecular film on the defect-free surface.
166	<strong>Effects of Laser Wavelength on Aluminum Plasma in Transverse Magnetic Fields</strong>	The influence of laser wavelength on nanosecond laser-produced Al plasma in transverse magnetic field is studied. A Q-switch Nd:YAG pulsed laser is used to ablate an aluminum sample at 50 mJ at 1064 nm, 532 nm, and 266 nm wavelengths. A permanent magnetic trap is used with nearly uniform magnetic field of 0.8 T to confine plasma expansion, reduce both fast and slow components of plasma velocity, and increase signal intensity. Fast photography is performed using an Intensified Charged Coupled Device (ICCD) camera to study the plume hydrodynamics as it evolves through the magnetic field. Optical Emission Spectroscopy (OES) is used to determine the effect of laser wavelength on key ionic and neutral emission lines, including enhancement and reduction of certain emission lines in the presence of a magnetic field. Fast photography results confirm that laser wavelength has a significant effect on plume hydrodynamics, especially as it evolves through the magnetic field which confines both fast and slow components of the plasma as early as ~45 ns after laser impact for all laser wavelengths used, as well as reducing the velocity of the plasma by about 4 to 5 times. It is shown that 266 nm laser wavelength under magnetic field enhanced both ionic and neutral lines by up to 11 times while 532 nm laser plasma only showed enhancements in ionic lines with reduction in neutral. Laser wavelength of 1064 nm showed a slight enhancement of ionic lines with a significant reduction in neutral lines under the same conditions.
167	Buffer Insensitive Optoelectronic Quality of InP-on-Si with Templated Liquid Phase Growth	As Moore's Law comes to an end, the search for additional integrated circuit functionality has shifted from scaling lateral dimensions down to combining multiple materials onto a single substrate. However, the quality of crystalline semiconductors is highly sensitive to the substrate upon which it is grown, preventing multiple materials from being directly grown on single substrates. To circumvent this challenge, many complex growth strategies have been developed, such as strain relaxation buffer-layers, nanostructure growth, and template selective epitaxy.  However, even with these advanced growth technique, the growth of manufacturable crystalline materials is still limited to crystalline surfaces. Here, we show that using templated liquid phase (TLP) growth, single crystalline indium phosphide on Si can be using a variety of buffers, both crystalline and amorphous. However, by performing detailed optoelectronic characterization, we find that the quality of the grown material not only closely matches commercial single crystalline InP wafers but is also highly insensitive to the buffer layer used. This unique feature of TLP growth could enable the next generation of crystalline material integration.
168	Glasses of three alkyl phosphates show a range of kinetic stabilities when prepared by physical vapor deposition	In situ AC-nanocalorimetry was used to characterize vapor-deposited glasses of three phosphates with increasing lengths of alkyl side chains: trimethyl phosphate, triethyl phosphate, and tributyl phosphate. The as-deposited glasses were assessed in terms of their reversing heat capacity, onset temperature, and isothermal transformation time. Glasses with a range of kinetic stabilities were prepared, including kinetically stable glasses, as indicated by high onset temperatures and long transformation times. Trimethyl phosphate forms highly stable glasses, similar to many other organic molecules, while triethyl phosphate and tributyl phosphate do not. Triethyl phosphate and tributyl phosphate present the first examples of non-hydrogen bonding systems that are unable to form stable glasses via vapor deposition at 0.2 nm/s. Based on experiments utilizing different deposition rates, we conclude that triethyl phosphate and tributyl phosphate lack the surface mobility required for stable glass formation. This may be related to their high enthalpies of vaporization and the internal structure of the liquid state.
169	Heating rate dependent ignition of Al/Pt nanolaminates through pulsed laser irradiation	Direct laser irradiation of sputter deposited Al/Pt nanolaminate multilayers results in rapid local heating and exothermic mixing of reactant layers. Milli- and microsecond pulsed laser irradiation under certain test conditions leads to single-point ignition of rapid, self-propagating, formation reactions. Multilayers having bilayer thicknesses of 328 nm, 164 nm, and 65 nm are characterized by their ignition onset times and temperatures. &nbsp;Smaller bilayer thickness multilayers require less laser intensity for ignition compared with larger bilayer designs (when utilizing a particular pulse duration). The relationship between laser intensity and ignition onset time is used to calibrate an activation energy for ignition within a finite element reactive heat transport model. The local heating rate is varied from 10<sup>4</sup> K/s to 10<sup>6</sup> K/s by selecting a laser intensity. &nbsp;Kissinger analysis was performed on the heating rate-dependent ignition temperatures measured with high speed pyrometry to experimentally determine an activation energy in the foils of (6.2 &plusmn; 1.6 x 10<sup>4</sup> J/mole atoms). This value is then compared to an activation energy produced from model fits to ignition onset time of 7.2 x 10<sup>4</sup> J/mole atoms.
170	Improved electrical conductivity of poly(ethylene oxide) nanofibers using multi-walled carbon nanotubes	Highly conductive nanofibers with 1570 S/m were obtained from electrospinning of a polymer solution containing multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs). Homogeneous dispersion of high concentrations of MWCNTs was achieved by attaching poly(styrenesulfonic acid <em>graft</em> aniline) (PSS-<em>g</em>-ANI), an amphiphilic surfactant, to the MWCNT surface. The hydrophilic sulfonic acid group facilitated the dissolution of PSS-<em>g</em>-ANI-grafted MWCNTs in a polyethyelene oxide solution up to 6.7 wt% MWCNT. To our knowledge, this is the highest level of MWCNT doping attained in a solution designed for electrospinning. With the incorporation of PSS-<em>g</em>-ANI, the concentration of MWCNTs embedded in the electrospun nanofibers increased. More importantly, the alignment of MWCNTs along the nanofiber axis increased significantly, as confirmed by observed birefringence under crossed polarizers. The combination of higher doping levels and better alignment afforded highly conductive nanofibers suitable for electronic nanodevices.
171	Gelatin coated magnetic nanowires as highly detectable optical labels	This work proposes the elaboration of magnetic nickel nanowires (NiNWs) coated with gelatin as highly optical detection labels. Incorporation of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) into the gelatin matrix helps amplify detection limits. Our approach takes advantage of the use of NiNWs that act as preferential light dispersant and the use of an inexpensive gelatin coating; this coating helps impregnate AgNPs by simultaneously increasing the composite plasmonic contrast and as an antimicrobial protector. Synthesized nanocomposiste exhibits superior detection performance in the pico g/mL range when compared with light scattering techniques; the best detection limit of our optical label is <em>ca.</em> 140 pg/mL (0.14 ppb). Obtained detectability compares with sophisticated expensive state-of-art detection levels suggesting that our nanocomposite may be used in many fields of study including medicine, microbiology and chemistry of materials.
172	<strong>Effects of Surface Tension and Viscosity on Gold and Silver Sputtered onto Liquid Substrates </strong>	In this paper we study DC magnetron sputtering of gold and silver onto liquid substrates of varying viscosities and surface tensions. We were able to separate the effects of viscosity from surface tension by depositing the metals onto silicone oils with a range of viscosities. The effects of surface tension were studied by depositing the metals onto squalene, poly(ethylene glycol), and glycerol. It was found that dispersed nanoparticles formed on liquids with low surface tension and low viscosity whereas dense films formed on liquids with low surface tension and high viscosity. Nanoparticles formed on both the liquid surface and within the bulk liquid for high surface tension liquids. &nbsp;Our results can be used to tailor the metal and liquid interaction to fabricate particles and films for various applications in optics, electronics, and catalysis.
173	<strong>Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Acoustic Absorption by a Carbon Nanotube</strong>	Acoustic absorption by a carbon nanotube (CNT) was studied using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations in a molecular domain containing a monatomic gas driven by a time-varying periodic force to simulate acoustic wave propagation. Attenuation of the sound wave and the characteristics of the sound field due to interactions with the CNT were studied by evaluating the behavior of various acoustic parameters and comparing the behavior with that of the domain without the CNT present. A standing-wave model was developed for the CNT-containing system to predict sound attenuation by the CNT and the results were verified against estimates of attenuation using the thermodynamic concept of exergy. This study demonstrates acoustic absorption effects of a CNT in a thermostatted MD simulation, quantifies the acoustic losses induced by the CNT and illustrates their effects on the CNT. Overall, a platform was developed for MD simulations that can model acoustic damping induced by nanostructured materials such as CNTs, which can be used to further understanding of nanoscale acoustic loss mechanisms associated with molecular interactions between acoustic waves and nanomaterials.
174	Negative Differential Resistance, Rectification, Tunable Peak-Current Position and Switching Effects in an Alanine-based Molecular Device	The transport properties of a molecular bio-electronic device based on the Alanine amino-acid is investigated. The considered device consisting of an Alanine molecule as the central potential-dot coupled to two ZGNR (zigzag graphene nanoribbon) conducting electrodes. The current-voltage characteristics of this dual tunneling molecular junction are studied at two different optimized compositions of the central molecule. The proposed amino-acid based structure utilize the tunneling coupling similar to that of semiconducting single electron transistors (SETs) to avoid complications due to the atomic interfaces. The current-voltage characteristics show polarity-dependent behavior making the device feasible of being applied as a molecular rectifier. Negative differential resistance (NDR) along with tunable peak-current position has been also observed in the current-voltage characteristics. The device is also capable of being applied as a switch controllable by the central molecule orientation.
175	<strong>Quasi-free-standing silicene in 2D van der Waals heterostructures</strong>	<strong>Silicene is a promising 2D Dirac material because of its novel electronic properties and potential integration with current silicon-based nano-/micro-electronics technology. However, unlike most other 2D materials, which are relatively inert, silicene has an active surface and interacts strongly with solid substrates. On the other hand, silicene has been found to interact weakly in graphene/silicene/graphene (Gr/Si/Gr) heterostructures. Here we use first-principles calculations to search among several such heterostructures with different 2D materials as cladding layers to find the best choice that preserves the properties of free-standing silicene, especially the Dirac points, which are not preserved at the Fermi energy in Gr/Si/Gr heterostructures. We find that quasi-free-standing silicene can be achieved in BN/silicene/BN heterostructure, with the Dirac cones left intact at the Fermi energy. We further discuss potential van der Waals heterostructures (vdWHs) of two silicene layers that are separated by multiple BN layers and cladded by monolayer BN. Interlayer coupling between the two silicene layers is present when there is either one or two BN layers separating the silicene layers, but the coupling becomes negligible at three BN layers. We further investigated potential BN/silicene superlattices. By changing the number of BN layers between silicene layers, a conversion between Dirac lines and Dirac points can be achieved in such superlattices.</strong>
176	<strong>Skyrmionium &ndash; high velocity without the skyrmion Hall effect</strong>	The lateral motion of a magnetic skyrmion, arising because of the skyrmion Hall effect, imposes a number of restrictions on the use of this spin state in the racetrack memory. A skyrmionium is a more promising spin texture for memory applications, since it has zero total topological charge and propagates strictly along a nanotrack. Here, the stability of the skyrmionium, as well as the dependence of its size on the magnetic parameters, such as the Dzyaloshinsky-Moriya interaction and perpendicular magnetic anisotropy, are studied by means of micromagnetic simulations. We propose an advanced method for the skyrmionium&rsquo;s nucleation due to a local enhancement in the spin Hall effect. The stability of the skyrmionium being in motion under the action of the spin polarized current is analyzed.
177	<span style="color: #000000;">Investigation of trapping levels in p-type </span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">Zn<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub></span><span style="color: #008000;"></span><span style="color: #000000;"> nanowires using transport and optical properties</span>	<span style="color: #000000;">Here we report the synthesis and</span> <span style="color: #000000;">structural characterization of high-quality </span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">Zn<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub></span><span style="color: #008000;"></span><span style="color: #000000;"> nanowires via</span> <span style="color: #000000;">chemical vapour deposition. Structural and morphological characterizations revealed a reliable growth process of long, uniform and single crystalline nanowires. From temperature dependent transport measurements we have observed the contribution of different acceptor levels (15, 50, 70, 90 and 197 meV) in </span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">Zn<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub></span><span style="color: #008000;"></span><span style="color: #000000;"> to the conduction mechanisms. These levels were associated to zinc vacancies and phosphorous interstitials atoms which assign a p-type character to this semiconductor. From time resolved </span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">photoluminescence</span><span style="color: #000000;"> experiments a 91 </span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">ps</span><span style="color: #000000;"> lifetime decay was found. Such fast lifetime decay is in agreement with the exciton transition along the bulk emission from high crystalline quality nanowires. </span>
178	<strong>Localized Deformation in Ni-Mn-Ga Single Crystals</strong>	The magnetomechanical behavior of ferromagnetic shape memory alloys such as Ni-Mn-Ga, and hence the relationship between structure and nanoscale magnetomechanical properties, is of interest for their potential applications in actuators. Furthermore, due to its crystal structure, the behavior of Ni-Mn-Ga is anisotropic. Accordingly, nanoindentation and magnetic force microscopy were used to probe the nanoscale mechanical and magnetic properties of electropolished single crystalline 10M martensitic Ni-Mn-Ga as a function of the crystallographic <em>c</em>-axis (easy magnetization) direction relative to the indentation surface (i.e., <em>c</em>-axis in-plane versus out-of-plane). Load-displacement curves from 5-10 mN indentations on in-plane regions exhibited pop-in during loading, whereas this phenomenon was absent in out-of-plane regions. Additionally, the reduced elastic modulus measured for the <em>c</em>-axis out-of-plane orientation was ~50% greater than for in-plane. Although heating above the transition temperature to the austenitic phase followed by cooling to the room temperature martensitic phase led to partial recovery of the indentation deformation, the magnitude and direction of recovery depended on the original relative orientation of the crystallographic <em>c</em>-axis: positive recovery for the in-plane orientation versus negative recovery (i.e., increased indent depth) for out-of-plane. Moreover, the <em>c</em>-axis orientation for out-of-plane regions switched to in-plane upon thermal cycling, whereas the number of twins in the in-plane regions increased. We hypothesize that dislocation plasticity contributes to the permanent deformation, while pseudoelastic twinning causes pop-in during loading and large recovery during unloading in the <em>c</em>-axis in-plane case. Minimization of indent strain energy accounts for the observed changes in twin orientation and number following thermal cycling.
179	<strong>Probability of Conductive Bond Formation in a Percolating Network of Nanowires with Fusible Tips</strong>	Meeting the heat dissipation demands of microelectronic devices requires development of polymeric composites with high thermal conductivity. This property is drastically improved by percolation networks of metallic filler particles that have their particle-to-particle contact resistances reduced through thermal or electromagnetic fusing. However, composites with fused metallic fillers are electrically conductive, which prevents their application within the chip-board and the inter-chip gaps. Here we propose that electrically insulating composites for these purposes can be achieved by the application of fusible metallic coatings to the tips of nanowires with thermally conductive, but electrically insulating cores. We derive analytical models that relate the ratio of the coated and total nanowire lengths to the fraction of fused, and thus conductive, bonds within percolating networks of these structures. We consider two types of materials for these fusible coatings. First, we consider silver-like coatings, which only form conductive bonds when contacting the silver-like coating of another nanowire. Second, we consider liquid metal-like coatings, which form conductive bonds regardless of whether they contact a coated or uncoated segment of another nanowire. These models were validated using Monte Carlo simulations, which also revealed that electrical short-circuiting is highly unlikely until most of wire is coated. Furthermore, we demonstrate that switching the tip coating from silver- to liquid metal-like materials can double the fraction of conductive bonds. Consequently, this work provides motivation to develop scalable methods for fabrication of the hybrid liquid-coated nanowires, whose dispersion in polymer matrix is predicted to yield highly thermally conductive, but electrically insulating composites.
180	Chemical potential and free energy of nanoconfined water in Newton black films	In this work we investigate possible approximations to the free energy and chemical potential of water within a Newton black film as a natural nanoconfinement. As a first step we explore the different approximations in a sample of 500 water molecules (bulk water), finding that the overlapping distribution method is the more accurate. For the Newton black film we also calculate the free energy profile of the water molecules along the bilayer normal. We obtain that depending on the position of the water molecule inside the bilayer, the excess chemical potential is lower than that of bulk water, suggesting that a water molecule is more stable inside the Newton black film than in bulk. A charged semiflexible amphiphilic model and the TIP5P model of water are used in our simulations.
181	Physical Vapor Deposition of Ag Nanoparticles through Shadowing Assembly	The morphology evolution of Ag NPs deposited by glancing angle deposition (GLAD) in a wide range of nominal deposition thickness d at room temperature has been investigated systematically. Non-spherical Ag NPs are formed with d < 500 nm, while vertical Ag nanorod-like nanostructures are produced when d > 500 nm. Based on three-dimensional Monte Carlo simulations, such a morphological change can be attributed to the high mobility and reemission of Ag atoms as well as the shadowing effect during the GLAD growth.
182	<strong>Single-shot femtosecond laser ablation of gold surface in air and isopropyl alcohol environments: nanotopographic and optical emission studies </strong>	Dynamics of ablative plumes from a gold surface in ambient air and liquid iso-propyl alcohol were studied by time-resolved optical emission spectroscopy in single-shot IR femtosecond-laser ablation regimes, typical for non-filamentary and non-fragmentation laser production of nanoparticles sols. Despite one order of magnitude shorter (few nanoseconds) lifetimes and almost two orders of magnitude lower intensities of the ablative plume emission in the alcohol ambient at the same peak laser fluence, nanofoam-like spallative crater topographies appeared rather similar for the dry and wet conditions. These facts envision the underlying surface spallation as one of basic ablation mechanisms relevant for both dry and wet advanced femtosecond laser surface nano/micro-machining and texturing, as well as for femtosecond laser ablative production of nanoparticle sols by MHz femtosecond-laser pulse trains via their direct nanojetting in air and fluid environments.
183	Accurate Energies of Highest-Occupied Molecular Orbitals and Lowest-Unoccupied Molecular Orbitals of Metal Clusters Using Efficient Density Functional Computations	The paper presents a computational method for the estimation of highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMOs) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of metallic nano-clusters using efficient density functional computations with the high accuracy of the GW method. Electronic structures of magnesium nano-clusters Mgn(n=1-22,25,30,35,40) are computed using the density functional theory (DFT) and the quasiparticle GW method. It is found that the energy difference between the DFT and GW results, defined as the scissors operator or correction, is only dependent on the cluster size, and independent of the electronic shell filling effect. The scissors operators of HOMOs and LUMOs of metallic clusters can thus be fitted by using simple power functions of the cluster size n. Therefore, the HOMOs and LUMOs of metallic clusters can be efficiently calculated using DFT with a modification of scissors operators. The scissors operators are also demonstrated to be applicable to occupied and unoccupied states near the Fermi level.
184	<strong>The Germanium &ldquo;Halo&rdquo;: Visualizing invisible Ge interstitials</strong>	We report the ability to image distributions of Ge interstitials within amorphous SiO<sub>2</sub> matrices using conventional transmission electron microscopy and energy dispersive <em>x</em>-ray fluorescence mapping. While previous, established methods have only been able to infer the presence of interstitials within materials, our direct &ldquo;visualization&rdquo; approach allows the ability to study and better understand the dynamics of several interesting phenomena that occur within the Ge-Si-O system during processing at temperatures greater than 700<sup>o</sup>C. These phenomena include Ostwald Ripening, migration of Ge nanocrystallites through amorphous SiO<sub>2</sub> and Si<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> matrices, Ge incorporation in Si-rich materials such as Si<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> and Si, and finally, morphological changes in the Ge nanocrystallites themselves.
185	Dynamics of a magnetic skyrmionium driven by spin waves	The magnetic skyrmionium is a skyrmion-like structure but carries a zero net skyrmion number, which can be used as a building block for non-volatile information processing devices. Here, we study the dynamics of a magnetic skyrmionium driven by propagating spin waves in both thin films and nanotracks. It is found that the skyrmionium can be effectively driven into motion by spin waves showing tiny skyrmion Hall effect, of which the mobility is much better than that of the skyrmion at the same condition. We also show that the skyrmionium mobility depends on the nanotrack width and damping coefficient, and can be controlled by an external out-of-plane magnetic field. Besides, we demonstrate the skyrmionium motion driven by spin waves is inertial. Our results indicate that the skyrmionium is a promising building block for building spin-wave spintronic devices.
186	<strong>Diode Junction Temperature in Ultraviolet AlGaN Quantum-Disks-in-Nanowires</strong>	The diode junction temperature (T<sub>j</sub>) of light emitting devices is a key parameter affecting the efficiency, output power and reliability. Herein, we present experimental measurements of the T<sub>j</sub> on ultraviolet (UV) AlGaN nanowires (NWs) light emitting diodes (LEDs), grown on a thin metal-film and silicon substrate using the diode forward voltage and electroluminescence (EL) peak-shift methods. The forward-voltage vs temperature curves show temperature coefficient <em>dV<sub>F</sub>/dT</em> values of -6.3 mV/&deg;C and -5.2 mV/&deg;C, respectively. Significantly smaller T<sub>j</sub> of 61.45 &deg;C is measured for the sample on metal substrate, as compared to that of the sample on silicon (105.76 &deg;C), at 50 mA, which results from the better electrical-to-optical energy conversion and the absence of the thermally insulating SiN<sub>x </sub>at the NWs/silicon interface. Lower T<sub>j</sub> of 24 &deg;C was achieved using the peak-shift method for the sample on metal substrate. In contrast to the reported higher T<sub>j</sub> values for AlGaN planar LEDs exhibiting low lateral and vertical heat dissipation, we obtained a relatively lower T<sub>j</sub> at similar values of injection current. Lower temperatures are also achieved using IR camera, confirming that the T<sub>j</sub> reaches higher values than the overall device temperature. Furthermore, the heat source density is simulated and compared to experimental data. This work provides insight in addressing the high junction temperature limitations in light-emitters and it aims to realize UV AlGaN NWs for high power and reliable devices.
187	A review on the laser-assisted flow deposition method: growth of ZnO nanostructures	NA
188	Magnetic field influenced augmented thermal transport in superparamagnetic cobalt and nickel ferrite aqueous nanocolloids	Nanoscale ferrites have become increasingly popular in novel nanoscale engineering and&nbsp;technology involving magnetism. The present article reports a novel aqueous magnetic&nbsp;nanofluid of high colloidal phase stability and high thermal conductivity enhancement in the&nbsp;presence of external magnetic fields. Nanoscale, superparamagnetic and high magnetic&nbsp;moment cobalt (CoFe2O4) and nickel ferrite (NiFe2O4) particles have been used to synthesize&nbsp;stable water based MNFs. Largely amplified thermal conductivity of the colloids under the&nbsp;influence of magnetic field has been observed. Augmentation in thermal conductivity ~175%<br />(in comparison to zero field case) has been observed for CoFe2O4 MNF at 0.4 T for 7 vol. %<br />concentration whereas for the NiFe2O4 it has been observed to be ~ 110 %. Near field<br />magneto-static interactions and Neel-Brownian relaxivity of the magnetic nanoparticles has<br />been discussed to play important roles in the particle fibrillation and augmented heat<br />conduction process. Decrease of thermal conduction caliber beyond certain field strength has<br />been observed and this phenomenon has been elucidated by appealing to the thermodynamics<br />considerations of chain clustering. A mathematical model has been put forward to deduce the<br />enhancement in thermal conductivity of the magnetic fluids under influence of field and good<br />agreement has been obtained with respect to experimental observations. The present nanoferrite based smart magnetic colloids with enhanced and field tunable thermal transport<br />characteristics hold strong potential as futuristic micro-device thermal management smart<br />systems.
189	<strong>Ba<em><sub>x</sub></em>Sr<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>TiO<sub>3</sub> nanocrystalline thin films deposition grounded in RF magnetron co-sputtering </strong>	A solid solution of barium-strontium titanate Ba<em><sub>x</sub></em>Sr<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>TiO<sub>3</sub> (BSTO) were deposited in thin films by RF reactive co-sputtering for <em>x</em> values within 0 &le; <em>x</em> &le; 1. &nbsp;Films composition was controlled through RF power applied to BaTiO<sub>3</sub> (BTO) and SrTiO<sub>3</sub> (STO) targets. The average crystal size for the whole composition is around 20 nm, obtained from XRD data analysis

191	Femtosecond Laser Metal-smithing of Sub-wavelength Structures	We thoroughly study the modification of indium semi-spherical nanostructures with radii of around 175 nm<br />into linear microstructures more than 2 &mu;&#x0016;m long in the direction of laser polarization. The experimental results<br />and a rudimentary analysis confirm that melting occurs from intense laser pulses. In short, we demonstrate<br />that melting of the indium droplet followed by trapping in high spatial frequency laser induced periodic<br />surface structures on silicon substrate cause nanostucture modification.
