192	Cavitation bubble nucleation induced by shock-bubble interaction in a gelatin gel	An optical visualization technique is developed to study cavitation bubble nucleation that results from interaction between a laser-induced shock and a preexisting gas bubble in a 10 wt% gelatin gel; images of the nucleated cavitation bubbles are captured and the cavitation inception pressure is determined based on Euler flow simulation. A spherical gas cavity is generated by focusing an infrared laser pulse into a gas-supersaturated gel and the size of the laser-generated bubble in mechanical equilibrium is tuned via mass transfer of the dissolved gas into the bubble. A spherical shock is then generated, through rapid expansion of plasma induced by the laser focusing, in the vicinity of the gas bubble. The shock-bubble interaction is recorded by a CCD camera with flash illumination of a nanosecond green laser pulse. The observation captures cavitation inception in the gel under tension that results from acoustic impedance mismatching at the bubble interface interacting with the shock. We measure the probability of cavitation inception from a series of the repeated experiments, with varying the bubble radius and the standoff distance. The threshold pressure is defined at the cavitation inception probability equal to one half and is calculated, through comparisons to Euler flow simulation, at &minus;24.4 MPa. This threshold value is similar to that from shock-bubble interaction experiments using water, meaning that the gel viscoelasticity has a minor impact on bubble nucleation dynamics.
193	Influence of ambient gas on the optical properties of CdS quantum dots prepared by plasma-liquid interactions	In this study CdS quantum dots were fabricated by injecting non-equilibrium plasma jet into the aqueous solution including Na2S2O3, CdSO4 and Thioglycolic acid (TGA) in the presence of an ambient gas such as nitrogen and oxygen gases. In order to investigate the structure, morphology, size and chemical nature of the prepared CdS nanocrystals in presence of ambient gas, X-ray diffraction (XRD), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), tunneling electron microscopy (TEM) and dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) were used. The optical properties of CdS nanoparticles were characterized using UV-Vis and photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopies. It was found that the presence of ambient gases especially oxygen, reduces the size and concentration of the synthesized nanoparticles, while the crystalline structure of these nanoparticles is not altered. It was also found that with the increase of flow rate of ambient gas the PL emission intensity of quantum dots was reduced, and the PL position as well as absorption edge shifts to blue wavelengths.
194	<strong>Excitonic recombinations in thin porous GaN epilayers deposited on Si(111)</strong>	<em>We investigate the similarity between the behavior of the photoluminescence of porous gallium nitride and the one of an assembly of quantum wires as it was previously discovered for the case of porous silicon (</em><em>M. Voos,&nbsp;Ph. Uzan,&nbsp;C. Delalande,&nbsp;G. Bastard, and&nbsp;A.&nbsp;Halimaoui, Applied Physics Letters&nbsp;<strong>61</strong>, 1213 (1992), </em><em>doi:&nbsp;10.1063/1.107598</em><em>). The photoluminescence properties of porous GaN can be interpreted within the concept of an in-homogeneously size-distributed collection of nanorods. The recombination rate is considered as a competing mixture of radiative and nonradiative recombination rates with contribution of </em><em>slow non-radiative surface recombination. The photoluminescence intensity increases from 2D films configuration to a porous one, in line with inhibition of in-plane carrier diffusion towards non-radiative recombination centers produced by the porosification of the material. </em>
195	<strong>Rare </strong><strong><strong>e</strong></strong><strong><strong>arth </strong></strong><strong><strong>d</strong></strong><strong><strong>oping </strong></strong><strong><strong>e</strong></strong><strong><strong>ngineering in </strong></strong><strong><strong>nanostructured ZnO</strong></strong><strong><strong>: </strong></strong><strong><strong>a</strong></strong><strong><strong>&nbsp;</strong></strong><strong><strong>n</strong></strong><strong><strong>ew </strong></strong><strong><strong>t</strong></strong><strong><strong>ype of </strong></strong><strong><strong>e</strong></strong><strong><strong>co-</strong></strong><strong><strong>f</strong></strong><strong><strong>riendly </strong></strong><strong><strong>p</strong></strong><strong><strong>hotocatalyst with </strong></strong><strong><strong>e</strong></strong><strong><strong>nhanced </strong></strong><strong><strong>p</strong></strong><strong><strong>hotocatalytic </strong></strong><strong><strong>c</strong></strong><strong><strong>haracteristics</strong></strong>	Aiming<strong>&nbsp;</strong>at development of practical and eco-friendly photocatalyst driven for maximizing best combination&nbsp;of photocataytic performance for dye waste water treatment, in present work, we demonstrate a new type of&nbsp;rose-like ZnO photocatalysts available in mass production&nbsp;doped with 0-2 mol% rare earth element, i.e., Lanthanum (La). A facile synthesis of nanostructured La-ZnO by chemical solution deposition method with low cost and tailored photocatalytic performance is reported. Corresponding structures, morphologies, chemical and photocatalytic characteristics are complementarily investigated by XRD, Raman, SEM, TEM, XPS, PL&nbsp;and UV-Vis spectroscopy studies in detail. La ions&nbsp;with trivalent state&nbsp;are successfully doped into the ZnO lattice,&nbsp;interestingly, each&nbsp;petal&nbsp;of rose-like nanostructured La-ZnO&nbsp;are&nbsp;composed of numerous&nbsp;nanoparticles in&nbsp;diameter&nbsp;of&nbsp;15-25 nm&nbsp;attached on surface in order. Importantly, the degradation efficiency of Rhodamin B&nbsp;over La-ZnO photocatalysts increases up to 1.5 mol% doping then decreased&nbsp;with&nbsp;higher dopant contents. La doping engineering results in&nbsp;a slight red shift in the absorption spectra band and consequently boost up&nbsp;the light absorption efficiency of photocatalysts.&nbsp;Among&nbsp;our developed photocatalysts, 1.5 mol% La-doped ZnO exhibits the highest&nbsp;photocatalytic activity&nbsp;for the degradation of Rhodamin B, poise as the best combination of photocatalytic performance and production cost, promising as a new platform&nbsp;of industrial level available photocatalysts for dye waste water treatment.
196	Direction-Dependent Stretchability of AgNW Electrodes on Microprism-Mediated Elastomeric Substrates	Silver nanowires (AgNWs) have become an efficient electrode candidate for stretchable electronics. We report the effects of directional stretching in microprism-mediated AgNW stretchable electrodes on polyurethane (PU) substrates. The wavy substrate is fabricated using a customized microprism on polyethylene terephthalate. AgNWs on stretchable PU substrates show stable normalized resistance up to 35% strain under parallel uniaxial stretching. This performance is much better than AgNWs on bare PU substrate or on wavy PU under perpendicular stretching, which can only sustain 10%-15% strain before significant increase in normalized resistance. Finite element simulations were conducted to reveal the strain distribution and variation in the AgNW electrodes on both bare and wavy PU substrates when stretched along parallel and perpendicular directions. Comparing to AgNW electrodes on bare PU and on wavy PU under perpendicular stretching, the wavy PU surface relief features can effectively alleviate the strain in the AgNW network when stretched along parallel direction, leading to better performance.
197	Tolman lengths and rigidity constants of multicomponent fluids: Fundamental theory and numerical examples	The curvature dependence of the surface tension can be described by the Tolman length (first order correction)sand the rigidity constants (second order corrections) through the Helfrich expansion. We present and explainsthe general theory for this dependence for multicomponent fluids and calculate the Tolman length and rigiditysconstants for a hexane-heptane mixture by use of density gradient theory. We show that the Tolman lengthsof multicomponent fluids is independent of the choice of dividing surface and present simple formulae thatscapture the change in the rigidity constants for different choices of dividing surface. For multicomponentsfluids, the Tolman length, rigidity constants and the accuracy of the Helfrich expansion depend on the choicesof path in composition and pressure space along which droplets and bubbles are considered. For the hexane-sheptane mixture, we find that the most accurate choice of path is the direction of constant liquid-phasescomposition. For this path, the Tolman length and rigidity constants are nearly linear in the mole-fractionsof the liquid-phase and the Helfrich expansion represents the surface tension of hexane-heptane droplets andsbubbles within 0.1% down to radii of 3 nanometers. The presented framework is applicable to a wide range ofsfluid mixtures and can be used to accurately represent the surface tension of nanoscopic bubbles and droplets.
198	Dielectric sphere-coupled THz super-resolution imaging	A straightforward THz imaging method, analogous to microsphere optical nanoscope, is proposed and developed with spatial resolution beyond the diffraction limit. By attaching a 3 mm Teflon sphere directly onto a free-standing silicon grating, a subwavelength spatial resolution better than l/3 is demonstrated. Furthermore, the dielectric sphere-coupled THz microscope not only enables far-field, large-area measurement but also characterizes high-throughput and broad-bandwidth imaging properties. In addition, a numerical study of the THz pulse propagation through a dielectric sphere agrees well with the experimental results, showing frequency-dependent magnification and focal length.
199	Low-Frequency Noise in Supported and Suspended MoS<sub>2</sub> Transistors	Sensitivity of sensors, the phase noise of oscillators and intrinsic device performance at the nanoscale are primarily limited by fluctuations in resistance at low frequencies, also called flicker noise. These intrinsic fluctuations in resistance become more prominent in two-dimensional materials due to their ultra-thin nature. Here, we report the low-frequency noise (LFN) behavior of supported and suspended MoS<sub>2</sub> field effect transistors. Carrier-number fluctuation mechanism was found to be responsible for LFN in both configurations. The extracted frequency index (&gamma; in 1/f<sup>&gamma;</sup>) indicates the different trap time-constants and mechanisms responsible for LFN in MoS<sub>2</sub> transistors. A&nbsp;&gamma; value of 2 in suspended transistors indicates a tight trap time-constant distribution likely due to recombination-generation through trap states arising only from intrinsic defects and/or extrinsic adsorbates. A wide time-constant distribution (&gamma; ~1 to 1.4) in supported transistors indicates the presence of various kinds of traps such as adsorbates, intrinsic defects as well as interface and oxide traps. Further, variation in S<sub>0</sub> (characterizes the magnitude of noise) with gate voltage in both supported and suspended device configurations was validated analytically using the carrier-number fluctuation model.
200	Control and Manipulation of Geometric Nonlinearity in Ultrathin Nanoelectromechanical Systems	Nonlinearities in nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS) play a vital role in dynamics of the device. Clear understanding of nonlinearities and ability to control and manipulate them to enhance the performance are crucial for applications with these devices. Here we utilize an electrostatic mechanism to control the geometric nonlinearity of an atomically thin NEMS. The exquisite control enables us to demonstrate hardening, softening and mixed nonlinear responses in the device. The electrostatic control over the nonlinearity is utilized to effectively nullify Duffing nonlinearity in a specific regime. The observed mixed nonlinear response is the result of cross coupling between strong quadratic and quartic nonlinearities, an aspect explained by method of multiple scale analysis.
201	Microcavity enhanced single photon emission from two-dimensional WSe2	Atomically flat semiconducting materials such as monolayer WSe2 hold great promise for novel optoelectronic devices. Recently, quantum light emission has been observed from bound excitons in exfoliated WSe2. As part of developing optoelectronic devices, the control of the radiative properties of such emitters is an important step. Here we report the coupling of a bound exciton in WSe2 to open microcavities. We use a range of radii of curvature in the plano-concave cavity geometry with mode volumes in the &lambda;^3 regime, giving Purcell factors of up to 8 while increasing the photon flux five-fold. Additionally we determine the quantum efficiency of the single photon emitter to be &eta; = 0.46 &plusmn; 0.03. Our findings pave the way to versatile monolayer based, ultra-bright single photon sources for a wide range of applications in nanophotonics and quantum information technologies.
202	Deterministic control of radiative processes by shaping the mode field	Quantum dots (QDs) interacting with confined light fields in photonic crystal cavities represent a scalable light source for the generation of single photons and laser radiation in the solid-state platform. The complete control of light-matter interaction in these sources is needed to fully exploit their potential, but it has been challenging due to the small length scales involved. In this work, we experimentally demonstrate the control of the radiative interaction between InAs QDs and one mode of three coupled nanocavities. By non-locally moulding the mode field experienced by the QDs inside one of the cavities, we are able to deterministically tune, and even suppress, the spontaneous emission into the mode. The presented method will enable the real-time switching of Rabi oscillations, the shaping of the temporal waveform of single photons and the implementation of novel nanolaser modulation schemes.
203	A Three-Dimensional Model for Lubricant Depletion Dynamics under Sliding Condition on Bit Patterned Media of Disk Drives	In this paper we model the depletion dynamics of molecularly thin layer of lubricants on bit patterned media disk of disk drives under a sliding air bearing head. The dominant physics and consequently the lubricant depletion dynamics on a patterned disk are shown to be significantly different from the well studied cases on a smooth disk. Our results indicate that the surface tension effect, which is negligible on a flat disk, apparently suppresses depletion by enforcing a bottleneck effect around the disk pattern peak regions to thwart the migration of lubricants. When the disjoining pressure is relatively small, it enhances the depletion. But when the disjoining pressure becomes dominant, the disjoining pressure resists depletion. Disk pattern orientation plays a critical role in the depletion process. The effect of disk pattern orientation on depletion originates from its complex interaction with other intermingled factors of external air shearing stress distribution and lubricant particle trajectory. Patterning disk surface with nanostructures of high density, high aspect ratio, and particular orientation is demonstrated to be one efficient way to alleviate the formation of lubricant depletion tracks.
204	<strong>The nanoscale partial-gate InAs nanowire field-effect transistors for suppressing the excess OFF-state current</strong>	<span style="margin: 0px; line-height: 150%; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; font-size: 12pt;"><span style="margin: 0px; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; font-size: 12pt;">The excess OFF-state current caused by band to band tunneling (BTBT) is a serious issue for short channel nanowire (NW) field-effect transistors (FETs), especially for semiconductors with narrow bandgap such as InAs. Here, to suppress the OFF-state current, we for the first time fabricate and study InAs NW FETs with nanoscale partial-gate (PG). While compared with full-gate (FG) FET fabricated on the same NW, PGFET shows better OFF-state characteristics. Through studying the devices with different measurement conditions and fabrication processes, we find the excess OFF-state leakage current is mainly induced by the BTBT caused by the high-field at the drain-end of the channel, which can be obviously suppressed by the ungated region of PGFET. The roles of both electrons and holes current are discussed and bipolar gain effect is found to also exist in InAs NW FETs. Through statistic study, we find BTBT effect can be more serious in the devices with better gate-control.</span></span>
205	A novel branched CdO/ZnO core/shell heterogeneous structure and its enhanced photoelectrocatalytic performance	We report a novel branched core/shell CdO/ZnO hetero-nanostructure with hexagonal symmetry. The nanomaterials were fabricated via an improved one-step chemical vapor deposition method, consist of a CdO wire as the core and ZnO as the shell. With cadmium act as catalyst, ZnO nanowires grow as perpendicular branches from the CdO/ZnO one-dimensional core/shell structure. The nanostructures were characterized with XRD and TEM. A homogeneous epitaxial growth mechanism has been postulated for the formation of the nanostructure. The materials show a broad and strong absorption ranging from visible to ultraviolet and a better photoelectrocatalytic properties in comparison to pure ZnO or CdO.
206	A Time-Resolved Millimeter Wave Conductivity Apparatus (TRmmWC) for Charge Dynamical Properties of Semiconductors	We demonstrate a contactless, time-resolved, millimeter wave conductivity apparatus capable of measuring photoconductivity of a diverse range of materials. This cavity-less system determines the time-dependent magnitude of a sample's charge carrier density-mobility product by monitoring the response of a continuous, millimeter-wave probe beam following excitation of the sample by an ultrafast laser pulse.  The probe beam is tunable from 110 GHz to 170 GHz and the sample response data can be obtained over the sub-nanosecond to millisecond time interval.  This system fills the frequency gap between microwave and terahertz techniques, and has been tested on silicon wafers, perovskite thin films and CdSxSe1-x nanowire samples. We demonstrate a minimum detectable photoconductance change of ~1 &#xF06D;S and an estimated time resolution for conductance decay of ~ 100 picoseconds.  The calibration constant of the system, needed for quantitative calculation of photoconductivity from experimental data, has been determined using silicon wafers.  This system has several advantages over currently used techniques, such as facile tunability of probe frequency and substantially wider time range for study of decay kinetics, while maintaining an open sample environment that enables characterization of a wide range of sample sizes under controlled environmental conditions.
207	Wide field of view, real time bioimaging apparatus for noninvasive analysis of nanocarrier pharmacokinetics in living model animals	Understanding nanocarrier pharmacokinetics is crucial for the emerging nanopharmacy, which highly demands noninvasive and real-time visualization of the in vivo dynamics of nanocarriers. To this end, we have developed a 2-photon excitation and time-resolved (TPE-TR) bioimaging apparatus for the analysis of the spatial distribution and temporal evolution of nanocarriers in living model animals. The specific polymeric nanocarrier, Eu@pmma-maa doped with Eu-complexes luminescing in long persistence at ~615 nm upon near-infrared 2-photon excitation, allows the complete rejection of tissue autofluorescence by selective luminescence detection. This together with an unique beam shaping scheme for homogeneous line excitation, a delicate timing strategy for single-shot and line-by-line imaging, as well as an equal optical path design for in-plane scanning, endow the TPE-TR apparatus with the following prominent features: An imaging depth of ~10 mm, a field of view (FOV) of 32&#x00D7;32 mm2 along with a horizontal resolution of ~60 &#x03BC;m, a sub-10 second frame time and negligible laser heating effect. In addition, a combination of the in-pane line scan with the 3D scan of a model animal offers the convenience for examining an interested FOV with a millimeter vertical resolution. Application of TPE-TR bioimaging to living mouse reveals rich information on the dynamics of nanocarriers including the spatial distribution, the temporal evolution, and the kinetics of domains of interest. The noninvasive TPE-TR bioimaging instrumentation with a wide FOV and a large imaging depth will find applications in the pharmaceutical development of nanocarriers and relevant research fields.<sup>
208	Less severe processing improves carbon nanotube photovoltaic performance	Thin film semiconducting single walled carbon nanotube (s-SWCNT) photovoltaics suffer losses due to trapping and quenching of excitons by defects induced when dispersing s-SWCNTs into solution. We study these aspects by preparing photovoltaic devices from (6,5) carbon nanotubes isolated by different processes: extended ultrasonication, brief ultrasonication, and shear force mixing. Peak quantum efficiency increases from 28 to 38 to 49% as the processing harshness decreases and is attributed to both increasing s-SWCNT length and reducing sidewall defects. Fill-factor and open-circuit voltage also improve with shear force mixing, highlighting the importance of obtaining long, defect-free s-SWCNTs for efficient photoconversion devices.
209	<strong>Electronic phase engineering induced thermoelectric enhancement in manganites</strong>	The nano-structuring engineering and the introduce of magnetic scattering are effective ways to enhance the thermoelectric performance. In this work, we use the magnetic treatments on the La<sub>0.4</sub>Pr<sub>0.225</sub>Ca<sub>0.375</sub>MnO<sub>3 </sub>system to demonstrate that the electronic phase engineering can enhance the thermoelectric performance by simultaneously reducing the thermal conductivity and raising the power factor in the strongly correlated electron system. The study indicates that the magnetic treatment reduces the charge-ordered insulator (COI) and thereafter impedes the growth of ferromagnetic metal (FMM) phase from the COI phase in the subsequent cooling. As a consequence, it miniaturizes the FMM domains, change the magnetic scattering of carriers and reduces the electron-like carriers transformed from the hole-like carriers, which raises the Seebeck coefficient and reduces the thermal conductivity and therefore raises the thermoelectric efficiency.
210	Precision control of nano-positioning stage : an iterative learning-based model predictive control approach	Due to nonlinearities such as hysteresis and creep effect, it is difficult to achieve precise control of nano-positioning stages, e.g., piezo actuators, for high-speed/bandwidth trajectory tracking. In this paper, we propose an iterative learning-based model predictive control (IL-MPC) approach to achieve this goal by addressing the control issues raised by the nonlinear dynamics. IL-MPC strategically combines both model predictive control (MPC) and iterative learning control (ILC) tools: the MPC is applied to a piezo actuator to ensure the tracking error is limited through all iterations and the ILC is applied to the system consists of the MPC and the piezo actuator to guarantee high precision trajectory tracking with the existence of MPC modeling uncertainty and system nonlinearity. Moreover, the MPC also ensures the fast convergence of the ILC. Superior than conventional iterative learning-based control techniques, the proposed IL-MPC can be implemented for tracking both repetitive trajectories and those with variations of nano-positioning stages with high accuracy. Thesupper bound of the tracking error with respect to the variation of the desired trajectory is derived to demonstrate the convergence and accuracy of IL-MPC. For experimental validation and demonstration, IL-MPC was implemented to control a nano-piezo actuator to tracksboth repetitive high-speed/broadband trajectories and trajectories with varying amplitude, phase and frequency, respectively.
211	A new low-cost method of fabricating micro-nano electro- hydrodynamic jet needle	Electro-hydrodynamic (EHD) jet is widely used for direct writing of micro and nano structures. However, the application of EHD jet is limited by its high-cost production process. To overcome the drawbacks mentioned above, a new fabrication method of polymer EHD jet needle is proposed in this paper. A silicon nano mold is firstly produced by inclined deposition technique, and a micro-nano PDMS mold is developed by casting double-layer PDMS on the silicon nano mold with a photomask film between the two PDMS layers. Using the micro-nano PDMS mold, an EHD jet needle can be fabricated in SU-8 photoresist layers by thermal nanoimprinting and ultraviolet lithography. The final SU-8 needle consists of hybrid micro-nano channels, in which the nano channels are 380 nm in width and 72 nm in depth. This low-cost fabrication method of micro-nano needle may have a great contribution to direct write-on-demand nano-patterning technology.
212	Exploring the interactions of oxygen with defective ZnO nanoparticles	The interactions of environmental oxygen with vacuum-annealed defective ZnO have been studied by electrical methods, vacuum Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and in situ adsorption experiments. It was found that the vacuum-annealed defective ZnO exhibits varied electrical response at different temperature, which, by vacuum IR investigation, was ascribed to the subtle balance between formation of oxygen vacancies and their interactions with environmental oxygen. Further studies showed that two microscopic steps including surface adsorption and bulk diffusion were dominating the interactions between defective ZnO and environmental oxygen, and the corresponding apparent activation energy were estimated by in situ adsorption experiments to be 0.093 eV and 0.67 eV.
213	Raman spectroscopy of defective graphite surfaces supporting platinum nanoparticles	Ion-beam-induced defects in carbon supports for Pt nanoparticles have been found to promote Pt&minus;C bonding and enhance catalytic activity during the oxygen reduction reaction. This work used Raman spectroscopy to examine highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) following the irradiation with 380 keV argon ions (Ar<sup>+</sup>) and the deposition of platinum (Pt) nanoparticles using radio frequency (rf) magnetron sputtering. The peak broadening of the resulting spectra indicated that the surface structure of the HOPG was damaged during the Pt deposition process. Therefore, we suggest that Raman spectroscopy should be performed after the Pt deposition to assess the surface structures of carbon supports for Pt nanoparticle catalysts.
214	<strong>High-temperature conduction behavior of carbon nanotube fiber from 25 &ordm;C to 1100 &ordm;C</strong>	The high-temperature conduction behaviors of pure CNT fiber and CNT/SiC and CNT/C composite-fibers from 25 &ordm;C to 1100 &ordm;C in N<sub>2</sub> atmosphere are reported for the first time. The results show a significant increase in the electrical conductivities of CNT fibers in the temperature regime, as the semi-conductive SiC and conductive C matrix were introduced. As the temperature increased, the conductivities of all fibers increase with temperature up to a critical temperature, <em>T<sub>c</sub></em>, was reached, beyond which, a dramatic decrease in the conductivities was observed. The conduction behavior of all fibers can be well explained by the three-dimensional variable range hopping mechanism at the temperature below <em>T<sub>c</sub></em>, and followed a heterogeneous mechanism above <em>T<sub>c</sub></em>. Interestingly, <em>T<sub>c</sub></em> was reduced after the introduction of SiC and C matrix, and this is explained by the competing effect of the internal nanotube resistance and the contact resistance between nanotubes that decreases with the introduction of SiC and C matrix. We propose that the study of high-temperature conduction behaviors of the CNT fibers aid to improve their conductivities and applications at high-temperatures, and the presented conduction mechanisms could be used for other kinds of CNT-structured fibers.
215	The research of quenching effect in Gradient-Band-Gap CdSSe nanowire	Quenching effect of photoconductive semiconductor material has an important application value in detecting semiconductor defect and infrared light. In this paper, we improve Vapor-Liquid-Solid (VLS) method to grow nanowires. Our experiment vessel is a heat resisting quartz tube. With the conditions of gold catalysis, appropriate temperature, and other practical handle, we grow Gradient-Band-Gap CdSSe nanowires successfully. We choose a 310 um nanowire to research its quenching effect. Refer to waveguiding excitation, we study quenching effects of different component parts of the nanowire respectively. Below 10<sup>-8</sup>w power injection, we find that if we increase light intensities of different band gap nanowires, the quenching degree will increase at the same time. However, the peak of quenched rate for 90% CdS proportion nanowire arrivals earlier than 90% CdSe proportion. Even in 10<sup>-6</sup> w light, the peak of quenched rate for CdSe still does not appear. The reason is that with the increase of CdS, more recombination centers turn into the trap energy level centers, so more electrons can jump to the conduction band. This result can help us to make the high-resolution infrared detector under the limited material, and provide convenience for detecting the defect level of semiconductor materials effectively.
216	Citric acid induced W<sub>18</sub>O<sub>49 </sub>electrochromic films with enhanced optical modulation	Electrochromic materials exhibit promising applications in energy-saving fields for its ability to control heat from outdoors. Nanostructured W<sub>18</sub>O<sub>49 </sub>has drawn attention for its one-dimensional structure to transfer charge efficiently as a remarkable electrochromic material. W<sub>18</sub>O<sub>49 </sub>bi-layer films were fabricated through a facile one-step solvothermal process with citric acid as a chelate agent. The results indicated that citric acid could induce the increased deposition on the substance and nanostructured film with denser layer at the bottom and tussock-like upper layer. The bi-layer film exhibited an enhanced optical modulation of 68.7%, a coloration efficiency of 82.1 cm<sup>2</sup>/C, and fast bleaching and coloration switching time (1.4 s and 2.3 s), with expectation to be applied in electrochromic field.
217	Analysis of mixed convection flow in an inclined lid-driven enclosure with Buongiorno's nanofluid model	The mixed convection flow of a nanofluid in an inclined cavity with its sidewalls being sinusoidally heated and linearly distributed of nanoparticle volume fraction is considered. The Buongiorno's model which is the most plausible with reasonable explanation on the slip mechanisms between nanoparticles and fluid medium is applied to formulate the problem. The buoyancy item is simplified by the Boussinesq approximation in an easier and convenient way to illustrate the density variation of nanoparticles with fewer coefficients being involved.&nbsp;The accurate solutions are obtained by the newly developed wavelet-homotopy technique, which are in full agreement with previous studies.&nbsp;Parametrical studies are given on the regimes of the complex flow field, heat and nanoparticle volume fraction. Discussion of applicability of the nanofluid model is presented. Effects of different parameters such as the Grashof number, the slipping parameters, the nanoparticles related parameters, the inclination, the boundary coefficients including amplitude ratios of temperature and concentration, along with the phase deviation are investigated on the fluid field focusing on the fluid flow along with heat and mass transfer characteristics.
218	<strong>Highly Enhanced Room-Temperature Photoluminescence in V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> Nanospheres</strong>	The room-temperature photoluminescence (PL) in V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> nanostructures with one- and zero-like dimensional structures were investigated. A large increase of the V<sup>4+</sup> oxidation state in nanowires and nanospheres was observed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> nanowires and nanospheres revealed highly enhanced PL intensity compared with the nanoparticles and nanorods. In particular, V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> nanospheres and nanowires showed intense ultraviolet (UV) PL near 396 nm (3.13 eV), and the UV PL intensity was more intense in the nanospheres. The intense UV PL in V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> nanospheres was attributed to enhanced transition probability in terms of the large increase of the V<sup>4+</sup> (3<em>d</em><sup>1</sup>) oxidation state. The PL properties in V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> nanostructures showed strong dependencies on the oxidation state and morphology.
219	Mn-doped SnS2 nanostructure as a potential efficiency CO catalyst:sa first-principles study	The SnS2 is a new class of 2D materials with unique properties, which are still largely unexplored in the CO catalyst field. The modulation of electronic structures and chemical activities of the Mn atom substituted for S atom in SnS2 monolayer sheet is studied based on density functional theory. The electrons of doped Mn are introduced to the dangling bond of monovacancy SnS2 system, which can enhance the stability of Mn-Sn bond. The Mn-SnS2 monolayer sheet prefers good catalytic activity for the CO oxidation via the more favorable Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism with a two-step route to the Eley-Rideal or the latest report of termolecular Eley-Rideal mechanisms. In summary, we show first-principles evidence toward the realization of SnS2 based catalyst for CO catalytic oxidation which can be facilitating the applications of SnS2 in the fields of catalysis and air pollution prevention.
220	<strong>Phase Change Induced Quantization in NIR Emitting Ag<sub>2</sub>S Nanocrystals: An Understanding via Structural and Optical Response</strong>	Quantum dots sensitized solar cells with low cost and simultaneously achieving high power conversion efficiency have been of great interest. The origination of quantum confinement in a system dramatically improves its physical properties. Here we report the phase change induced quantization in NIR emitting Ag<sub>2</sub>S quantum dots (QDs) by analysing their structural and optical response. Ag<sub>2</sub>S QDs have been synthesized by bottom-up technique. Structural and morphology of nanocrystals have been investigated by XRD, TEM and Raman spectroscopy. The size-dependent excited state optical properties of Ag<sub>2</sub>S QDs have been systematically investigated by UV-VIS-NIR spectroscopy and photoluminescence (PL). Experimentally, we determine the quantum confinement in the Ag<sub>2</sub>S QDs due to change in phase and change in the size of the particles. The synthesized QDs via this mode may be suitable for capturing solar energy, especially in NIR region.
221	<strong>Reliable information encryption and digital display applications based on multistate smart windows</strong>	A multistate smart window based on the reversible electrodepositing metal device (REMD) with excellent electrochromic performance is reported. A thiol modified ITO glass acts as positive electrode and an ITO nanoparticles coated ITO glass serves as negative electrode. The REMD can exhibit 4 different color states. Its mirror state presents a higher reflectance than the commercial Ag-based mirror and the transmittance of its transparent state can reach as high as 82.9 %. Moreover, the REMD can work steadily without any decline in light-modulation performance after 1000 cycles. Notably, a reliable information encryption device and novel digital display is proposed and designed. The REMD will provide broader potential applications in electrochromic smart windows.
222	<strong>Atomic Study of Structural Evolution of Nano- and Single-crystalline Au Nanowires Under Torsion</strong>	The effect of temperature on the structural evolution of nanocrystalline (NC) and single-crystalline (SC) Au nanowires (NWs) under torsional deformation is studied using molecular dynamics simulations based on the many-body embedded-atom potential. The effect is investigated using common neighbor analysis and discussed in terms of shear strain distribution and atomic flow field. The simulation results show that deformation for NC NWs is mainly driven by the nucleation and propagation of dislocations and the gliding of grain boundaries (GBs) and that for SC NWs is mainly driven by dislocations and the formation of disordered structures. Dislocations for NC and SC NWs easily nucleate at GBs and free surfaces, respectively. For NC NWs, torsional buckling occurs easily at GBs with large gliding. SC NWs have a more uniform and larger elastic deformation under torsion compared to that for NC NWs due to the former&rsquo;s lack of grains. SC NWs have a long period of elastic deformation transforming into plastic deformation. Increasing temperature facilitates stress transmission throughout NWs.
223	Laser-to-droplet alignment sensitivity in laser-produced plasma sources of extreme ultraviolet light	We present and experimentally validate a model describing the sensitivity of the tilt angle, expansion and propulsion velocity of a tin micro-droplet irradiated by a 1 &mu;m Nd:YAG laser pulse to its relative alignment. This sensitivity is particularly relevant in industrial plasma sources of extreme ultraviolet light for nanolitho- graphic applications. Our model has but a single parameter: the dimensionless ratio of the laser spot size to the effective size of the droplet, which is related to the position of the plasma critical density surface. Our model enables the development of straightforward scaling arguments in turn enabling precise control the alignment sensitivity.
224	High-performance gadolinium doped indium oxide nanofibers&nbsp;field-effect transistors and their application in logic gate	One-dimensional metal oxide&nbsp;nanofibers (NFs) have been regarded as promising building&nbsp;blocks for large&nbsp;area and low&nbsp;cost electronic devices. As one of the representative metal oxide semiconducting materials, In<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>&nbsp;based materials attracted much interest due to their excellent electrical and optical properties.&nbsp;However, most of the field-effect transistors (FETs)&nbsp;based on In<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>&nbsp;NFs&nbsp;usually operate in the depletion mode, which lead to large power consumption and complicated integrated circuit (IC) design.&nbsp;In this report, gadolinium&nbsp;(Gd) doped In<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>&nbsp;(InGdO) NFs were fabricated by electrospinning and applied as the channels&nbsp;in FETs. By adjusting the doping concentration and the NFs density, the device performance was precisely manipulated. It was found that the FETs&nbsp;based on the InGdO NFs with Gd doping concentration of 3% and NFs density of 2.9 &micro;m<sup>-1</sup>&nbsp;exhibited the best device performance, including a field-effect mobility (&micro;<sub>FE</sub>) of 2.83 cm<sup>2</sup>/Vs, an on/off current ratio (I<sub>on</sub>/I<sub>off</sub>)&nbsp;of ~ 4&times;10<sup>8</sup>, a threshold voltage (V<sub>TH</sub>)&nbsp;of 5.8 V, and a subthreshold swing (SS)&nbsp;of 2.4 V/decade. By employing the high-<em>k </em>ZrO<sub>x</sub>&nbsp;thin films as the gate dielectrics in FETs, the m<sub>FE</sub>, V<sub>TH</sub>&nbsp;and SS can be further improved to be 17.4 cm<sup>2</sup>/Vs, 0.7 V and 160&nbsp;mV/decade, respectively. To demonstrate the potential application of the InGdO&nbsp;NFs/ZrO<sub>x</sub>&nbsp;FETs,&nbsp;the inverter based on the FETs was constructed and a gain of ~ 11 was achieved.
225	<strong>Conductivity of disordered nanowire networks: the dependence on length ratio of conducting paths to whole nanowires</strong>	Conducting behavior of disordered nanowire networks is found to be determined by the length ratio of conducting paths to whole nanowires in the networks, which is concluded from combined studies of simulation and experiment. An algorithm is designated for the simulation where evolution dynamics of conducting paths and network conductance could be monitored at the same time. It is found that, with increment of nanowire length (at given area fraction), conducting paths grow more slowly than the percolated clusters, but they play a key role in the conductivity. Normalized network conductivity of the disordered nanowire network is found to function linearly with the length-ratio of conducting paths to the whole nanowires. And this relationship has been verified by experiments where network were built up from random aligned silver nanowires. In addition, the newly proposed relationship could be used to anticipate theoretical conductivity of given disordered nanowire network, as well as the average junction resistance between nanowires. The relationship happens to be very similar to the Effective Medium Theory proposed by Kirkpatrick (1973), but the deterministic parameter shall be changed from filling probability to the length ratio. The difference lies on that length ratio only concerns on conducting paths, rather than either dead ends or branches. At last, the length ratio functioned relationship could be treated as a&nbsp;basic tool to describe the conducting behavior of disordered nanowire networks.
226	<strong>High Strength Fiber Reinforced Composites with Surface Fibrilized Aramid Fibers</strong>	Debonding of the fiber-matrix interface is a common issue in composites, especially for aramid fiber reinforced composites due to their smooth and inert surface . Here, a novel surface treatment is developed for aramid fibers in order to enhance interfacial properties in composites while preserving the fiber&rsquo;s tensile strength. The fibrilization approach follows recent work on aramid nanofibers and uses a solution of potassium hydroxide and dimethyl sulfoxide at room temperature.&nbsp; This process is perfomred to exfoliate the surface fibrils such that a psudo-wiskerized fiber is prepared which provides mechanical interlocking with the matrix.&nbsp; The surface bound fibrils also contain increased polar functional groups which additionally provides improved wetting due to enhanced compatibility of the fiber with the matrix as well as offering reactive sites to allow covalent bonding with reactive themrosets such as epoxy. It is shown that the surface fibrilated fibers possess an 128% improved interfacial shear strength with an epoxy matrix, as well as an 62% increased short beam strength, compared to untreated fiber reinforced composites. The tensile strength of the treated fibers is demonstrated to be preserved, ensuring a significant improvement in common failure modes without a degradation of in-plane properties. The results indicate the potential of this treatment as a simple, fast, and cost-effective method to improve not only the interface in aramid fiber reinforced polymer matrix composites but also the bulk laminated composite.
227	Systematic Investigation of Plasmonic Amplification in Al, Rh, Ag, and Au Nanoparticle Dimers and Design Rules for UV-Visible Plasmonics	It is now well established that, due to excitation of localized surface plasmon resonances in plasmonic nanosystems, the electric field from an external irradiation source is greatly amplified in their vicinity. Surface plasmon mediated electric field amplification near plasmonic nanosystems is of vital importance for; light absorption enhancement in solar cells, molecular detection using surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy, proximity measurement of biological macromolecules such as proteins, lipids and nucleic acids using plasmon enhanced FRET, cancer therapy using photo-thermal effects, just to name only a few applications. In comparison to an isolated spherical shaped nanoparticle, their aggregate provide greater field enhancement, wider spectral tuning, and multiple resonant features. In view of the superior plasmonic characteristics of dimer configuration, a systematic investigation of plasmonic amplification due to, Al, Rh, Ag and Au nanoparticles in dimer configuration has been done, and their suitability and scope for UV-Visible applications is assessed. The dependence of plasmonic amplification and spectral tuning on crucial dimer parameters e.g., particle size, embedding medium, and particle-particle separation is expressed in terms of fitting expressions, which can be used for designing dimer based systems for UV-Visible spectral window. Moreover, dimer designs optimized for certain specific wavelengths using fitting expressions developed here are presented.
228	Optical observation of Brownian rotation of magnetic nanoparticles in water under a damped oscillating magnetic field.	It is important to understand the rotation mechanism of magnetic nanoparticle especially its Brownian rotation in liquid under an alternating magnetic field for the success of the biomedical application such as magnetic hyperthermia treatment and magnetic particle imaging. Although many effort has paid to observe the Brownian rotation by using ac magnetization measurement, it is hard to separate the contributions of the Brownian rotation and the N&eacute;el rotation on the magnetization signal. In this study, we measured optical transmittance of magnetic nanoparticle dispersion under a damped oscillating magnetic field with Faraday configuration. Since the time variation of the transmittance reflects the orientation of the easy axis along the magnetic field, the rotation dynamics can be observed with light. The observed rotation behavior, which exhibits the butterfly-shaped hysteresis, is in good agreement with the theoretical prediction by Mamiya. Furthermore, we were able to evaluate the order parameter of the easy axis thanks to the high initial amplitude of the damped oscillating magnetic field.
229	Enhancing the sensitivity of single electron spin sensor by multi-frequency control	The negatively charged nitrogen vacancy (NV) center in diamond is increasingly attracting as a solid state quantum sensor for high sensitivity and nanoscale application. However, the coupling with host non-zero nuclear spin of NV center decreases the signal contrast and the sensing sensitivity. Here, we apply multi-frequency synchronous manipulation on the NV center to recover the signal contrast and enhance the sensitivity. A sensitivity enhancement factor of 2.7 is achieved at low magnetic field, compared to the single microwave driven sensing process. The sensing sensitivity at varies magnetic field approaches that is obtained with full signal contrast. Such a multi-frequency controlled sensitivity enhancement also works on the sensing of temperature, strain and electric field and the application of other spin-spin coupling systems.
230	<strong>Unusually large magnetoresistance of FeCo nanocrystals encapsulated by the graphene layers in the FeCo-graphene nanocomposites</strong>	Graphene-coated FeCo nanocrystals of core-shell structure have been synthesized through an improved process of thermal decomposition of a Prussian blue analogue. The magnetic, transport and magneto-transport properties have been studied for the FeCo-graphene nanocomposites from different preparation conditions. Large magnetoresistance (MR) of -9.6% at room temperature is observed on the samples synthesized at 1000<sup>o</sup>C and with post-annealing. Furthermore all of the FeCo-graphene samples exhibit unusual enhancement of MR effect with the rise of temperature. The authors suggest that high MR is attributed to improved quality of the FeCo-graphene interface and efficient carrier hopping in graphene matrix for these hierarchical-structure nanocomposites.
231	<strong>Fabrication and characterization of ZnS/ZnO core shell </strong><strong>nanostructures on silver wires</strong>	In this research, ZnS nanoparticles were synthesized on ZnO/silver wires to form ZnS/ZnO core shell structures on silver wires. 232	Structural anomalies in exfoliated WS<sub>2</sub>: High pressure investigations on monolayer and nanocrystalline tungsten disulfide	A detailed high pressure X-ray diffraction and Raman Spectroscopy studies are carried out on monolayer WS<sub>2</sub> and nanocrystalline WS<sub>2</sub>. The monolayer sample is obtained by liquid exfoliation. Photoluminiscence and Raman measurements show it to consist of monolayer. High pressure X-ray diffraction measurements in conjunction with Raman studies show the emergence of a triclinic modification along with the hexagonal phase of WS<sub>2</sub> above about 5.8 GPa. However analysis of our ambient and high pressure studies on monolayer WS<sub>2</sub> along with those of the nanocrystalline sample indicate to the presence of the triclinic phase in patches embedded in the parent hexagonal phase raising a question mark over the structural purity of the exfoliated monolayered materials beyond a certain stress conditions. Raman mode values and their FWHM of the monolayer sample show anomalous changes at about 27 GPa, the pressure where the sample completely gets converted to the triclinic structure indicating importance of strain in the structural as well as electronic properties of two dimensional materials.
233	<strong>Evidence of self biased converse magnetoelectric response in P(VDF-TrFe)/ SmFeO<sub>3</sub> nanocomposite films </strong>	In this study, we investigate magnetoelectric (ME) properties in nanocomposite films (P(VDF-TrFE))/SmFeO<sub>3</sub> consist of ferroelectric copolymer, poly(vinylindene &#xFB02;uoride-tri&#xFB02;uoroethylene) (P(VDF-TrFE)) and magnetic SmFeO<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles. Comparative magnetization vs magnetic field hysteresis loops for un-poled and electric field poled (P(VDF-TrFE))/SmFeO<sub>3</sub> nanocomposite films demonstrate strong electric filed control of magnetization. The nanocomposite films exhibit large exchange biasing (EB) effects in magnetic measurements near spin switching temperature (~100 K) of SmFeO<sub>3</sub> and the EB effects were significantly modified under electric field (E) poled conditions (at E=200 kV/cm), indicating ME coupling. Remarkably, we observe electric field poling induced self biased converse ME effect in the (P(VDF-TrFE))/SmFeO<sub>3</sub> nanocomposite films. The maximum magnetoelectric output voltage (&alpha;) obtained is 55 mVcm<sup>-1</sup>Oe<sup>-1</sup> at H<sub>bias</sub>= 1 kOe and 25 mVcm<sup>-1</sup>Oe<sup>-1 </sup>at H<sub>bias</sub>= 0, after electric field poling. The discovery of self biasing phenomenon with converse ME effects at room temperature in flexible (P(VDF-TrFE))/SmFeO<sub>3 </sub>nanocomposite films is highly desirable for device applications such as electrically controlled thin memory devices and ME sensors etc.
234	The effect of ethanol on the structure and physical properties of carbon nanocoils	As an exotic quasi-1D nanomaterials, carbon nanocoils (CNCs) have special helical morphology and polycrystalline-amorphous structure. In this paper, the effect of ethanol on the structure and physical properties of CNCs is investigated. CNCs are soaked by ethanol for different time. The internal structural characterization shows that ethanol permeates into CNCs through defects and vacancies. The permeation of ethanol increases the inner stress inside CNCs and leads to the rearrangement of <em>sp<sup>2</sup></em><sup> </sup>grains to alleviate the stress. As a result, the coherence of graphite grains is improved. Meanwhile, the permeation of ethanol molecules separates <em>sp<sup>2</sup></em> grains and graphite layers in a grain. After long time soak, the chemical structure of CNCs shows slow change. The contents of C-O- and C=O bonds are all increased, resulting in the atomic ratio of C to O decreasing from 48 to 29 for 346 days soak. The increase of C-O- and C=O bonds promotes the transformation of <em>sp<sup>2</sup></em> sites to other saturation sites. As results of both physical and chemical changes of structure, the concentration of conduction electrons is decreased, the electron hopping barrier and phonon scattering are increased, leading to the significantly decrease of electrical conductivity and thermal diffusivity.
235	<strong>Effect of </strong><strong>Ag nanoparticle </strong><strong>s</strong><strong>elf-generation on the low-temperature pressureless Ag </strong><strong>sintering process</strong>	In this study, a&nbsp;self-generation phenomenon of Ag nanoparticles (AgNPs) with a size less than 10 nm was observed in the Ag sintering process under an air atmosphere, which corresponds to a stronger sintered Ag tension and shear strength than that sintered in nitrogen. It is confirmed that oxygen plays an important role in the generation of AgNPs. It is also revealed from transmission electron microscopy observations that many AgNPs accumulate around the grains and grain boundaries of the Ag sintered in air, which promotes connection and necking among Ag particles. The generation mechanism of AgNPs was analyzed, and the results indicate that AgNPs may form because of the oxidation and reduction processes of Ag grains and the compression stress release at the grain boundaries. This work will be helpful to understand the bonding mechanism of using Ag sintering technology under low-temperature pressureless conditions.
236	<strong>Magnetoresistive Sensors for Biomedicine</strong>	Currently there is a plethora of sensors (e.g. electrochemical, optical, piezoelectric etc.) used in life sciences for either analyte detection or diagnostic purposes but in the last decade magnetic biosensors have received extended interest as a promising candidate for the development of next-generation, highly sensitive biomedical platforms. This approach is based on magnetic labeling, replacing the otherwise classic fluorescence labeling, combined with magnetic sensors that detect the stray field of the superparamagnetic markers (e.g. magnetic micro-nanoparticles or magnetic nanostructures). Apart from the increased sensitivity, magnetic biosensors exhibit the unique ability of controlling and modulating the superparamagnetic markers by an externally applied magnetic force as well as the capability of compact integration of their electronics on a single chip. The magnetic field sensing mechanism most widely investigated for applications in life sciences is based on the magnetoresistance (MR) effect that was first discovered in 1856 by Lord Kelvin. However, it is the giant magnetoresistance effect (GMR), discovered by Gr&uuml;nberg and Fert in 1988, that actually exhibits the greatest potential as a biosensing principle. This perspective, will shortly explain the magnetic labeling method and will provide a brief overview of the different MR sensor technologies (giant magnetoresistive - GMR, spin valves and tunnel magnetoresistive -TMR) mostly used in biosensing applications as well as a compact assessment of the state of the art. Newly implemented innovations and their broad-ranging implications will be discussed, challenges that need to be addressed will be identified and new hypotheses will be proposed.
237	Observation of 2-D deposition patterns from doped superfluid helium droplets	Superfluid helium droplets have now emerged as a unique tool for the fabrication of nanomaterials. Unlike conventional synthetic methods, by this approach nanomaterials are formed in very cold superfluid helium by the addition of atoms one by one, which subsequently aggregate into nanostructures. Experiments have confirmed that quantized vortices are present in large helium droplets, which can serve as the intrinsic templates for the fabrication of 1-D nanomaterials. A recent X-ray diffraction experiment revealed arrays of quantized vortices in nanoscale helium droplets. However, all of the deposition experiments using large helium droplets so far show isolated nanowires, which are consistent the presence of only one vortex line in each helium droplet. This apparent contradiction provokes important questions about how vortices behave when confined to the nanoscale. Here we investigated the formation of Ag and Au nanoparticles in large helium droplets and examined deposition patterns at different expansion zones of the droplet beam, in order to learn how the rotational states of superfluid helium droplets vary with the selected droplets. After being deposited on a thin solid surface, the resulting nanoparticles were then imaged by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The major findings include: 1) 2-D scattered patterns were observed using droplets at the central zone of the droplet beam for the first time, which are consistent with the presence of an array of quantized vortices in the droplet; and 2) at an off-centre position a single nanowire is formed, indicating that helium droplets each contains a single vortex line when droplets are formed at the edge of the droplet beam. This work provides new insights to quantized vortices in nanoscale superfluid helium and offers extra dimension for the formation of novel nanostructures using superfluid helium droplets as nano-reactors.
238	Bending stability of CuxCrO2 - a transparent p-type conducting oxide for large area flexible electronics	The best performing p-type transparent conducting oxides are crystalline materials, deposited at high temperatures, incompatible with the drive to low cost flexible electronics. We investigated a nanocrystalline, copper deficient CuxCrO2 , deposited at low temperatures upon flexible polyimide. The as-deposited film without post annealing has a conductivity of 6 Scm&#x2212;1 . We demonstrate that this p-type transparent oxide retains its excellent electrical conductivity under tensile strain, withstanding over a thousand bending cycles. In contrast, compressive strain is shown to lead to an immediate reduction in conductivity which we attribute to a de-lamination of the thin film from the substrate.
239	Peristaltic nano fluid flow of a six constant Jeffreys fluid model in a non-uniform vertical tube	This study deals with the peristaltic nano fluid flow of an incompressible six constant Jeffrey's fluid through a non-uniform vertical tube. The fluid flow is due to the sinusoidal wave traveling with constant speed c of propagation along the walls of the tube. The partial differential equations governing the flow are rst modeled in the cylindrical coordinate system and then simplied by using the assumption of low Reynolds number and long wave length. The resulting equations are solved analytically by utilizing the homotopy perturbation technique (HPM). The obtained expressions for the velocity, temperature, and nanoparticles concentration proles are sketched through graphs and the impact of various emerging parameters are investigated for changed peristaltic waves. Streamlines have been also plotted at the end of the paper.
240	Tuning of band gap in two-dimensional photonic crystals composed of nanolayer graphene coated anisotropic tellurium rods	Using the Dirichlet-to-Neumann map method, the photonic band structure of two-dimensional photonic crystals with square and triangular lattices made of circular graphene-coated anisotropic tellurium rods embedded in air background, are calculated. We have selected transverse magnetic mode of electromagnetic waves and the resulting band structures showed the existence of two band gaps in the frequency spectrum, called Bragg photonic band gap and graphene-induced photonic band gap. It is shown that these photonic band gaps are widely tunable and their bandwidth can be adjusted by changing the chemical potential of graphene nanolayers using an applied gate voltage.
241	Interaction between &#x03B2;-cyclodextrin and cholesterol domain. sA molecular dynamics simulation study	Using the molecular dynamics simulation method we studied the system composed of &#x03B2;-cyclodextrin (&#x03B2;CD) molecules and cholesterol clusters, both standalone and in a water environment. We have found that &#x03B2;CD molecules do not penetrate the interior of cholesterol cluster, rather stick or "glue" to these cholesterol molecules that make up the surface of the cluster. Moreover, our simulations have shown that the ability of &#x03B2;CD to pull cholesterol molecule out of the cluster surface is rather marginal. Consequently, some chemical modifications of &#x03B2;-cyclodextrin molecule should be considered while searching for the oligosaccharide based tools (nanomedicine) able to effectively influence cholesterol deposit in the inner part of blood arteries.
242	Design of a patterned nanostructure array using a nanosecond pulsed laser	We investigated the influence of phase shift between scattered lights using gold lines (GLs) spacings. At a spacing of 5,787 nm, ten nanodot (ND) arrays were formed at intervals of 533 nm by nanosecond pulsed laser. The results show that the formation of the patterned nanostructure array (PNSA) was affected by the resonance of scattered light. We conclude that ND arrays were formed with a spacing of &#x039B; = n&#x03BB;.sAnd we have designed PNSA comprising two ND arrays on a Si substrate. The PNSA with dimensions of 1,600 nm &#x00D7; 1,600 nm was prepared using 30-nm-wide GLs.
243	Three-dimensional single-molecule localization with nanometer accuracy using Metal-Induced Energy Transfer (MIET) Imaging	Our paper presents the first theoretical and experimental study of using single-molecule Metal-Induced Energy Transfer (smMIET) for localizing single fluorescent molecules in three dimensions. Metal-Induced Energy Transfer uses the fact that the emission properties of fluorescent molecules are strongly modulated by the presence of a metal, with a strong dependence of this modulation on the dye-metal distance. We have used this method in the past for localizing fluorescent emitters with nanometer accuracy along the optical axis of a microscope. The combination of smMIET with existing single-molecule localization based super-resolution methods that provide nanometer lateral localization accuracy offers the prospect of achieving isotropic nanometer localization accuracy in all three spatial dimensions. We give a thorough theoretical explanation and analysis of smMIET, describe its experimental requirements, also in its combination with lateral single-molecule localization techniques, and we present first proof-of-principle experiments using dye molecules immobilized on top of a silica spacer, and of dye molecules embedded in thin polymer films.
244	Effect of surface hydroxyl groups on heat capacity of mesoporous silica	This paper quantifies the effect of surface hydroxyl groups on the effective specific and volumetric heat capacities of mesoporous silica. To achieve a wide range of structural diversity mesoporous silica samples were synthesized by various methods, including (i) polymer-templated nanoparticle-based powders, (ii) polymer-templated sol-gel powders, and (iii) ambigel silica samples dried by solvent exchange at room temperature. Their effective specific heat capacity, the specific surface area, and the porosity were measured using differential scanning calorimetry and low-temperature nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements, respectively. The experimentally measured specific heat capacity was larger than the conventional weight-fraction-weighted specific heat of the air and silica constituents. The difference was attributed to the presence of OH groups at the large internal surface area. A thermodynamic model was developed based on surface energy considerations to account for the effect of surface OH groups on the specific and volumetric heat capacity. The model predictions fell within the experimental uncertainty.
245	Self-referencing 3D optical imaging microscopy	Quantitative 3D imaging of cells provides important morphological information about them, leading to their characterization, comparison and identification. Interference principle when applied to microscopy provides high contrast quantitative phase images of otherwise transparent objects along with their thickness information. Two-beam off-axis geometry of interference microscopes, in which the light beam interacting with the object interferes with a separate reference beam, are preferred since it leads to single shot quantitative phase imaging methodologies. But these techniques lead to bulky setups, with lower temporal stability not suitable for measurement of nanometer level cell thickness fluctuations. Self-referencing interference microscopes manipulates a portion of the light beam interacting with the cells to act as the reference, leading to compact, temporally stable geometries ideal for measurement of cell dynamics. Here we give an overview of our efforts in the development of such microscopes and their use in 3D cell imaging.
246	<strong>Determination of the tunneling decay length for nanocomposites Au-PMMA</strong>	In this work nanocomposites formed by gold ion implantation in PMMA (polymethylmethacrylate), using low energy, are analyzed by transmission electron microscopy, concerning to the nanoparticles size and distribution. Different implantation doses (<em>x</em>) were used and parameters as number of gold nanoparticles per area <em>r</em>, diameter distribution <em>D</em>(<em>x</em>) and the distances between the surfaces of the metallic nanoparticles <em>&delta;</em>(<em>x</em>), among others parameters, were obtained. It was possible to observe that, as the dose increases, the particles diameter increases, the most probable nearest neighbors distance <em>d</em> decreases and the number of particles per area <em>r</em> also decreases. With the results, it was also possible to calculate the tunneling decay length <em>&xi;</em> and the electron affinity<em> &epsilon;</em> of the PMMA modified by the gold ion implantation.
247	A First-Principles Analysis of Ballistic Conductance, Grain Boundary Scattering andVertical Resistance in Aluminum Interconnects	We present an ab initio evaluation of electron scattering mechanisms in Al interconnects from a back-end-of-line (BEOL) perspective. We consider the ballistic conductance as a function of nanowire size, as well as the impact of surface oxidation on<br />electron transport. We also consider several representative twin grain boundaries and calculate the specific resistivity and reflection coefficients for each case. Lastly, we<br />calculate the vertical resistance across the Al/Ta(N)/Al and Cu/Ta(N)/Cu interfaces, which are representative of typical vertical interconnect structures with diffusion barriers. Despite a high ballistic conductance, the calculated specific resistivities at grain boundaries are 70-100% higher in Al than in Cu, and the vertical resistance across Ta(N) diffusion barriers are 60-100% larger for Al than for Cu. These results suggest that in addition to the well-known electromigration limitations in Al interconnects,<br />electron scattering represents a major problem in achieving low interconnect line resistance at fine dimensions.
248	Chemical potential and free energy of nanoconfined water in Newton black films	In this work we investigate possible approximations to the free energy and chemical potential of water within a Newton black film as a natural nanoconfinement. As a first step we explore the different approximations in a sample of 500 water molecules (bulk water), finding that the overlapping distribution method is the more accurate. For the Newton black film we also calculate the free energy profile of the water molecules along the bilayer normal. We obtain that depending on the position of the water molecule inside the bilayer, the excess chemical potential is lower than that of bulk water, suggesting that a water molecule might be  more stable inside the Newton black film than in bulk. A charged semiflexible amphiphilic model and the TIP5P model of water are used in our simulations.
249	<strong>Thermal processing shifts the resonant wavelength of gold nanoplates</strong>	Gold nanoplates (GNPs) are attractive as wavelength-specific light absorbing coatings for converting incident infrared light to thermal energy. In this work, we show that even relatively low temperature processing (100-400 &ordm;C) can permanently shift the resonant wavelength peak from the infrared to visible wavelengths; our samples shift from 860 to 650 nm after an hour at 350 &ordm;C. The mechanism is melting-induced shape change, which causes rounding of sharp corners and reflow of the plate-like shapes toward spheres with smaller diameters and shorter resonant wavelengths, as well as merging with neighboring particles. Since 150-200 &ordm;C temperatures are commonly attained during the curing step of photoresists in microfabrication, and easily exceeded during curing of polyimide coatings for encapsulation (350 &ordm;C), these wavelength shifts are important to understand when incorporating GNPs into microelectromechanical (MEMS) devices. In addition, 200 &ordm;C temperatures are also reached in applications where localized heating is performed on thermally isolated structures such as micro hotplates. Thus, properly understanding the melting behavior of GNPs enables researchers to address these issues by strategically planning the fabrication process, such as starting with long wavelength particles to accommodate the shift, using low temperature processing methods, and ensuring that the nanoplates are well-dispersed so nanoplate clusters do not sinter together during processing.
250	Electron Scattering at Interfaces in Nano-scale Vertical Interconnects: A Combined Experimental and Ab Initio Study	We present a combined theoretical and experimental study on the electron transport characteristics across several representative interface structures found in back-end-of-line (BEOL) interconnect stacks for advanced semiconductor manufacturing: Cu/Ta(N)/Co/Cu and Cu/Ta(N)/Ru/Cu. In particular, we evaluate the impact of replacing a thin TaN barrier with Ta while considering both Co and Ru as wetting layers. Both theory and experiment indicate a pronounced reduction in vertical resistance when replacing TaN with Ta, regardless of whether a Co or Ru wetting layer is used. This indicates that a significant portion of the total<br />vertical resistance is determined by electron scattering at the Cu/Ta(N) interface. The electronic structure of these nano-sized interconnects is analyzed in terms of the atom-resolved projected density of states and k-resolved transmission spectra at the Fermi level. This work further develops a fundamental understanding of electron transport and material characteristics in nano-sized interconnects.
251	<strong>Electrochemically induced superconductivity in organic-inorganic hybrid halide perovskite (CH<sub>3</sub>NH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Pb(SCN)<sub>2</sub>I<sub>2</sub></strong>	Halide perovskites exhibit rich physical properties and have been the foci in search for promising materials for solar cells and Li-ion batteries. We report here that superconductivity with a critical temperature of ~7.2 Kelvin can be induced in halide perovskite (CH<sub>3</sub>NH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Pb(SCN)<sub>2</sub>I<sub>2 </sub>electrochemically. Transmission electron microscopy and magnetic hysteresis loop measurements were conducted to understand this observation. We attribute the observed superconductivity to the Li-reduced formation of lead nanoclusters.
252	About 4.688nm&#x00D7;0.626nm Transistor Built up of Ten Doping Atoms in a (8, 0) Single-Wall Carbon Nanotube	The development of silicon based integrated circuits is close to the physical scale limit. Carbon nanotube transistors achieve a characteristic size of 40 nanometers. How to further miniaturization of electronic components on carbon substrates is the key to its further development. We have constructed a double junction structure, in (8, 0) single-wall carbon nanotube (SWCNT) doped with nitrogen, boron and phosphorus atoms, and investigate the electronic transport properties. The current through the doped regions is controlled by gate voltage. When we apply bias (more than 0.8V in the positive direction or 1.2V in the negative direction) onto the structure, and raise the gate voltage from 0V to 1.0V, the current increases in an order of magnitude of 102&#x03BC;A, and the transmission peaks in bias window get wider and higher. If the bias is changed from -1.2V to 0.8V, the structure remains cut-off. The peaks are created by the overlapping of the incomplete bands of the nitrogen-doping region, the boron-doped region and the phosphorus-doping region. Such N, B, and P doped regions (about 46.88 &#x00C5; &#x00D7; 6.26 &#x00C5;) forms atomic scale transistor in the carbon nanotube. The transistor can be used to construct atomic scale functional circuits. We get atomic scale transistor that can operate under normal current and voltage conditions (current: 25-150&#x03BC;A, gate voltage: 0-1V, bias voltage: 1.5-2V).
253	In Vitro Models of Transport across the Blood-Brain Barrier	The blood-brain barrier (BBB) is the tightest endothelial barrier in humans. Characterized by the presence of tight endothelial junctions and adherens junctions, the primary function of the BBB is to maintain brain homeostasis through the control of solute transit across the barrier. The specific features of this barrier make for unique modes of transport of solutes, nanoparticles and cells across the BBB. Understanding the different routes of traffic adopted by each of these is therefore critical in the development of targeted therapies. In an attempt to move towards controlled experimental assays, multiple groups are now opting for the use of microfluidic systems. A comprehensive understanding of bio-transport processes across the BBB in microfluidic devices is therefore necessary to develop targeted and efficient therapies for a host of diseases ranging from neurological disorders to the spread of metastases in the brain.
254	Fundamentals and applications of optomechanically induced transparency	Cavity optomechanical systems have been shown to exhibit an analogon to atomic electromagnetically induced transparency that a transmission window for the propagation of the probe field is induced by a strong control field when the resonance condition is met. Sharp transmission features controlled by the control laser beam enable many applications ranging from force sensors to quantum computation and communication. In recent years, there has been significant progress in both theoretical and experimental studies of this phenomenon, driven by the development of nanophotonics as well as the improvement of nano-fabrication techniques. Optomechanically induced transparency has been found to manifest in numerous different physical mechanisms, e.g., nonlinear optomechanically induced transparency, double optomechanically induced transparency, PT symmetric optomechanically induced transparency, and optomechanically induced transparency in various hybrid optomechanical systems, etc. These results offer a pathway towards an integrated quantum optomechanical memory, show the utility of these chip-scale optomechanical systems for optical buffering, amplification, and filtering of microwave-over-optical signals, and may be applicable to modern optical networks and future quantum networks. Here we systematically review the latest research progress on the fundamentals and applications of optomechanically induced transparency. Perspectives and opportunities on future developments are also provided by focusing on several promising topics.
255	Transport of Nitrate and Nitrite Ions through Graphene Nanopores	Nitrate (NO3-) and nitrite (NO2-) ions are naturally occurring inorganic ions that are part of the nitrogen cycle. High doses of these ions in drinking  water impose a potential risk to public health. In this work, molecular dynamics simulations are carried out to study the removal of nitrate and nitrite ions from water by using graphene nanosheets (GNS) with hydrogen-functionalized narrow pores in presence of external electric fields. The passage of ions through the pores is investigated through calculations of ion flux and the results are analyzed through calculations of various other properties such as the density of ions and water, ion-water radial distribution functions, two-dimensional density distribution functions and the potentials of mean force of the ions. The simulation results show that the nitrite ions can pass more in numbers than the nitrate ions in a given time through H-functionalized GNS with different pore geometry. The results show that the nitrite ions are selectively removed faster than the nitrate ions despite the former having higher hydration energy in the bulk. This can be explained in terms of the competition between the Z-density of the ions and the free energy barrier calculated from the potential of mean force. Also, an externally applied electric field is found to be important for the selective permeation of nitrite over the nitrate ions. The current study shows that the graphene nanosheets with carefully created pores can be effective in the selective passage of ions from aqueous solutions.
256	Electrical Conductivity in Metals Containing Populous Nanoparticles	Nanoparticle reinforced metals have great potentials to tune metal properties for widespread applications. Significant research has been recently conducted to understand their functional properties, such as electrical property. However, inconsistent arguments and theories exist on how nanoparticles interact with metal matrices to affect their electrical performance, partly due to the difficulty in producing metal samples containing populous dispersed nanoparticles. In this letter, copper and copper alloy samples (Cu, Cu-40Zn, and Cu-60Ag) containing tungsten carbide (WC) nanoparticles of more than 20 vol.% were successfully fabricated. Then, their electrical conductivity was measured. Given the scale of nanoparticles (~50-150 nm) and electronic parameters in metals, a new theoretical model compatible with the Nordheim&rsquo;s rule was established to explain an exponentially decaying electrical conductivity.
257	<strong>Giant enhancement in Goos-Hanchen shift at the singular phase of a nanophotonic cavity</strong>	In this letter, we experimentally demonstrate thirty-fold enhancement in Goos-Hanchen shift at the Brewster angle of a nanophotonic cavity that operates at the wavelength of 632.8 nm. In particular, the point-of-darkness and the singular phase are achieved using a four-layered metal-dielectric-dielectric-metal asymmetric Fabry-Perot cavity. A highly absorbing ultra-thin layer of germanium in the stack gives rise to the singular phase and the enhanced Goos-Hanchen shift at the point-of-darkness.
