The obtained giant Goos-Hanchen shift in the lithography-free nanophotonic cavity could enable many intriguing applications including cost-effective label-free biosensors.
258	<strong>Surface Plasmon Length: Determinant of Localized Surface Plasmon Resonance Wavelength in V-shape Ag Nanorods</strong>	Geometry size was widely regarded as an essential determinant of the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) wavelength in many nanoparticles. In this study, we clarified this concept by demonstrating that resonance wavelength of V-shape Ag nanorods was determined by surface plasmon length, the surface distance between adjacent poles, instead of geometry size. Results showed that for V-shape Ag nanorods, the linearly proportional relationship between resonance wavelength and geometry size no longer held when size greatly decreased. Nonetheless, resonance wavelength was found linearly dependent on surface plasmon length in all situations. This work suggested that attempts of LSPR manipulation should not be restricted to adjustment of geometry size, but any means that could change the surface plasmon length.
259	Colloidal interactions govern the rheology (shear and extensional) and filament-forming capability of cellulose nanofibrils with biopolymer supports	The shear and extensional rheology in dynamic and steady flows were compared for dispersions of semi-rigid fibrils (cellulose nanofibrils, CNF) and two biopolymers (guar gum, GG, and cellulose acetate, CA). Even at low concentrations, the relatively stiffer CNF formed hydrogels with high storage modulus and brittleness. Shear and extensional thinning (flow behavior index 0.2-0.3) were displayed in a wide range of strain rates with a consistency index that depended not only on the CNF solids content but also on the flow type (a decade higher under extensional flow compared to that under shear). Aqueous solutions of GG, the polymer with largest chain flexibility, also displayed shear and extensional thinning, though only at relatively high rates (> 1 s<sup>-1</sup>). Moreover, under small amplitude oscillatory shear, GG had a more viscous response than CNF. Even more Newtonian and viscous behavior was detected in organic solutions of CA, which were suitable dopes for wet-spinning into continuous filaments. Neat CNF hydrogels were difficult to spin continuously unless used in a coaxial configuration, together with GG or CA as a supporting polymer shell. We discuss the role of biopolymer rheological behavior and their interesting synergies which facilitate CNF-based filaments via coaxial spinning.
260	Superlong uniform Light Tunnel Created by Focusing Radially Polarized Vortex Beam	A method of generating a super-long nanoscale light tunnel with longitudinal intensity variation less than three percent of the maximum is presented. A radially polarized vortex beam with topological charge of two can be focused into a relatively short light tunnel when the ring-like annular amplitude filter is used to block the outer annular part of the light beam or when an objective with relatively low numerical aperture is used. A fan-shaped division of the central part of light beam cross section with phase modulation scheme is adopted to generate four relatively short light tunnels simultaneously with exactly the same intensity distribution and optimized axial shift. Based on these foundations, a super-long nanoscale light tunnel with uniform intensity is demonstrated both in simulation and experiment.
261	Quantum Sieving for the Separation of Helium Isotopes	We investigate the passage of a Helium atom through a nano-sized pore in a single atom thick membranes.  The interaction between the atom and the membrane is modeled by an analytical potential, which is obtained by fitting the parameters of the potential to accurate quantum chemical calculations.  Potentials were constructed to mimic the pores in graphenylene and  C<sub>2</sub>N holey sheet. For making the problem tractable, the potential is assumed to have cylindrical symmetry.  This enables us to perform wave packet calculations for the passage, assuming perpendicular incidence of the atom on the membrane.  Further, we also performed full transition state theoretical calculations for the rate of the process.  In these calculations, corrections for tunneling were done by transfer matrix calculations for a one dimensional surface, for motion in the Z-direction, but corrected for zero-point energy for motion in the direction parallel to the surface.  Our calculations show that a full 3D wave packet calculation is essential to capture the full quantum dynamics of the process.  Further, the calculations also suggest that for a pore of sufficiently low activation energy, it should be possible to achieve separation of the isotopes of <i>He</i> by repeated sieving through the membrane, even at room temperature.
262	Growth of S-doped MoO2 Nanosheets with a Controlled Band Gap by CVD	In this work, an investigation of MoO2 nanosheets grown on a SiO2/Si substrate using MoO3 and S powders as the raw materials by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) was carried out. The HRTEM, XPS and Raman results revealed that the S-doped MoO2 nanosheets were synthesized at a large scale, and the proportion of S and MoO3 precursors influenced the morphology of the nanosheets. Photoluminescence spectra exhibited fluorescent emissions from the MoO2 nanosheets at room temperature from defects and electron transitions between the valence and conduction bands. UV-visible absorption spectra show that the band gap of the MoO2 nanosheet can be controlled by the S doping concentration.
263	<strong>The Effect of Graphene on </strong><strong>Surface Plasmon Resonance of Metal Nanoparticles</strong>	Two transparent graphene-metal nanoparticles (NPs) hybrid schemes namely Au NPs covered by graphene layers and Au NPs encapsulated by graphene layers are presented and the effect of graphene on the localized surface plasmon resonance of metal NPs is systematically investigated. For both schemes, the direct contact of graphene with Au NPs would strongly tune the resonant frequency due to the electron transfer from Au NPs to graphene. Such electron transfer is demonstrated by comparing the absorption spectra of Au NPs with different free electron densities between calculation results via FDTD simulation and experimental results, comparing Raman and electric properties of graphene between pure graphene and Au-NPs/graphene hybrid nanostructure, correlating the electron doping concentration in graphene with the electron density change in Au NPs, as well as ruling out the possible mechanism of the change of effective refractive index of Au NPs. Such an effective tuning of the resonant frequency may shed light on the future applications of 2D based materials in plasmonic devices.
264	<strong>Experimental investigation of the effects of nanoparticles on nucleate pool boiling phenomenon under subcooled conditions</strong>	Effect of nanoparticles on single bubble-based nucleate pool boiling phenomenon under subcooled conditions has been studied. Water (as the base fluid) and two different concentrations of water-silica nanofluids (0.005 and 0.01% V/V) have been employed as the working fluids. The boiling experiments have been conducted in a specially-designed chamber wherein an ITO-coated heater substrate has been used to induce single bubble nucleation. Measurements have been performed non-intrusively using rainbow schlieren deflectometry. Thus, the thermal gradients have directly been mapped as two-dimensional distribution of hue values recorded in the form of schlieren images. The measurements clearly revealed the plausible influence of nanoparticles on the strength of temperature gradients prevailing in the boiling chamber. As compared to the base fluid, the experiments with dilute nanofluids showed that the suspended nanoparticles tend to diffuse the temperature gradients, both in the vicinity of the heated substrate as well as in the superheated layer enveloping the bubble. An overall reduction in the bubble volume and contact angle was seen with increasing concentrations of nanofluids. The bubble was found to assume more spherical shape at higher concentrations of dilute nanofluids in comparison to its shape with water-based experiments. Clear oscillations of the bubble in the subcooled pool of liquids were observed, the frequency of which was found to be significantly reduced as the nanoparticles concentration was increased from 0 to 0.01% (V/V). A force balance analysis has been performed to elucidate the plausible mechanisms explaining the observed trends of the oscillation frequencies of the vapor bubble.
265	Electro/mechanical mutable properties of black phosphorene by electric field and strain engineering	Phosphorene a two dimensional (2D) arrangement of black phosphorus atoms has greatly manifested extraordinary properties. In this work we investigated the electronic and mechanical properties of a single-layer black phosphorus using tight binding approximation and Green's function approach. Moreover, by using density functional theory (DFT), we show that the applied strain in the x,y axes and electric field can be used to tune the electronic properties of black phosphorene. We also provide a comparison of phonon vibrational modes of planar and puckered phosphorene to compare their structure stability. It was found that by structural deformation such as modifying the angle between two nearest neighboring P-P bond from two sublayers, consequently having a planar and a most puckered structure, no change can be seen for the effective masses along the y (zigzag) direction, but totally affected along the x (armchair) direction leading to heavier electrons and holes. Furthermore, 2D phosphorene exhibits different stiffness for applied strain in the x,y direction. Such rich variety of electronic, mechanical and structural transformations provide particular 2D phosphorene as a unique material for fundamental physics studies and applicable in nanoelectronic and nanophotonic devices.
266	Nanoindentation tests of heavy-ion-irradiated Au foams &ndash; molecular dynamics simulation	Irradiation by light ions may change the mechanical properties of nanofoams. Using molecular-<br />dynamics simulation, we study the effect of irradiating a Au foam (porosity 50 %, ligament diameter<br />3 nm) with heavy ions: here 10 keV Au ions up to a dose of 10 <sup>18</sup> m <sup>&minus;2</sup> . We demonstrate that in<br />consequence, ligament morphology changes in the irradiated region, caused by local melting. The<br />changes in mechanical properties are monitored by simulated nanoindentation tests. We find that<br />the foam hardness is only around 1/3 of the hardness of a bulk Au crystal. Irradiation increases the<br />hardness of the foam by around 10 % in the central irradiated area. The plastic zone extends to<br />only 1.5 a<sub> c</sub> , where a <sub>c</sub> denotes the contact radius; this value is unchanged under irradiation, while<br />dislocation activity after irradiation is more strongly localized under the indenter surface, indicating<br />that the irradiation-induced melting has stabilized the ligaments.
267	Numerical analysis of Ag-CuO/water rotating Hybrid nanofluid with heat generation/absorption	The present work is committed to examine the impacts of magnetohydrodynamics (MHD), heat generation/absorption and volume fraction of nanoparticles on the flow of hybrid nanofluid past a stretching surface. The comparison of heat transfer properties of rotating, conventional nanofluid with that of developing Hybrid nanofluid is also studied. To examine the Lorentz force impacts on three dimensional stretching surface, another model of "thermophysical properties" is used. The whole system including nanofluid and stretching surface is in rigid body rotation about an axis normal to the plane of stretching surface with constant angular velocity. The system of governing nonlinear partial differential equations have been simplified by using suitable similarity transformations and then solved via an efficient numerical technique BVP-4C. The velocity and local skin friction are obtained in both directions. The rate of heat transfer is determined on the surface. The effects of pertinent physical parameters which are magnetic parameter, rotation parameter, stretching parameter, heat generation or absorption parameter and Prandtl number have been discussed through graphical and tabular form. From the present study, it is noticed that the rate of heat transfer of Hybrid nanofluid is higher than that of ordinary nanofluid. In "Hybrid nanofluid", the required rate of heat transfer can be accomplished by picking distinctive and suitable nanoparticle extents.
268	<strong>Influence of cobalt doping on residual stress in ZnO nanorods</strong>	Cobalt-doped (0%, 5%, 10%, 15%, and 20%) zinc oxide (ZnO) nanorods were deposited on silicon wafers by a chemical bath deposition technique. Variations in energy band gap and stress due to cobalt doping were analyzed by X-ray diffraction techniques, optical measurements and modeled by density functional theory calculations. In addition, the direct residual stress in ZnO nanorods was investigated by measuring the difference in curvature across the doped ZnO thin films deposited on a silicon substrate using the Bow Optic wafer stress measurement system. The stress in doped ZnO films was found to be of compressive in nature. &nbsp;The residual stress in doped ZnO thin films was found in the range of 0.0427 to 1.0174 GPa. The residual stress was also found to scale with the cobalt doping concentration in ZnO thin film. In addition, the crystalline structure of various cobalt doped ZnO nanorods films was confirmed by X-ray diffraction analysis to be of the wurtzite structure. The bandgap of cobalt-doped ZnO was red-shifted from 3.30 eV to 3.21 eV as the cobalt concentration in ZnO nanostructures varied from 0% to 20%. A linear relationship between stress and bandgap shifting in cobalt-doped ZnO nanorods was obtained based on x-ray diffraction and direct stress measurements.
269	Heterodyne dual-polarization epi-detected CARS microscopy for chemical and topographic imaging of interfaces	Coherent Raman Scattering (CRS) has emerged in the last decade as aspowerful multiphoton microscopy technique offeringschemically-specific label-free imaging in real time with highsthree-dimensional spatial resolution. Many technical realizations ofsCRS microscopy have been proposed to remove, suppress, or accountsfor the non-resonant background in the nonlinear susceptibilityswhich complicates spectral analysis and reduces image contrast.sHere, we demonstrate coherent anti-Stokes Raman scatteringsmicroscopy using a dual-polarization balanced heterodyne detectionsin epi-geometry (eH-CARS), providing background-freeschemically-specific image contrast for nanoparticles and interfaces,sshot-noise limited detection, and phase sensitivity. We show thessensitivity and selectivity of eH-CARS in comparison with forwardsCARS and stimulated Raman scattering (SRS) on polystyrene beads insagarose gel. As an important biologically-relevant application, wesdemonstrate eH-CARS imaging of individual lipid bilayers with highscontrast and topographic sensitivity.
270	Spin-relaxation anisotropy in a nanowire quantum dot with strong spin-orbit coupling	We study the impacts of the magnetic field direction on the &nbsp;spin dynamics in a one-dimensional quantum dot with strong spin-orbit coupling. The energy spectrum and the corresponding eigenfunctions in the quantum dot are obtained exactly. We find that no matter how large the spin-orbit coupling is, the electric-dipole spin transition rate as a function of the magnetic field direction always has a &pi; periodicity. However, the phonon-induced spin relaxation rate as a function of the magnetic field direction has a &pi; periodicity only in the weak spin-orbit coupling regime and a 2&pi;&nbsp;periodicity in the strong spin-orbit coupling regime.
271	<strong>Highly conductive two-dimensional electron gas at amorphous aluminium oxide heterostructures</strong>	We have created a two-dimensional electron gas at the Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/SrTiO<sub>3</sub>/LaAlO<sub>3</sub> heterostructures using pulsed laser deposition at growth temperatures in the range of 400-600 &deg;C. The Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/SrTiO<sub>3</sub>/LaAlO<sub>3</sub> heterostructures exhibit a decreased sheet resistance with enhanced growth temperatures of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> films. The amorphous growth of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> films is demonstrated by cross-sectional transmission electron microscopy. Compared with these heterostructures with Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> films deposited on pristine SrTiO<sub>3</sub> and TiO<sub>2</sub> terminated-SrTiO<sub>3</sub>, the Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/STO/LAO heterostructures are more conductive. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy indicates the formation of oxygen vacancies at the STO side of the interface, which result from the redox reactions by reducing the STO films surface. Furthermore, the occurrence of oxygen vacancies on the STO side is verified by a blue-light emission. The fabrication of highly conductive interfaces of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/STO/LAO heterostructures probably enables the integration of an oxide nanoelectronic device and Si-based electronic circuits and opens new avenues for oxide nanoelectronics and mesoscopic physics.
272	Transient Joule Heating/Cooling based PrMnO<sub>3&nbsp;</sub>Oscillator Neuron for Oscillatory Neural Networks	Brain-like, time and energy efficient computational schemes are attracting widespread attention from all constitutional disciplines like devices, circuits and algorithms. Detailed studies into the neural time dynamics have revealed massively parallel computing architectures utilizing the complex spatio-temporal interaction between neurons. In particular, Oscillatory Neural Networks (ONN), based on the thalamo-cortical neural system, claim to use the phase relations of active oscillating units to solve NP-hard problems like pattern recognition, and vertex colouring &ndash; a key challenge for von-Neumann computing. Hardware realization of ONNs using analog CMOS based oscillators is area and power inefficient. The performance gets affected even more as the size of the network increases in line with real life applications. Thus, a nanoscale oscillator with low operating voltage is attractive to enable large ONNs. Recently, transient joule heating induced high nonlinearity in the current-voltage characteristics was shown in area scalable PrMnO<sub>3</sub> (PMO) based RRAM. In this work, transient joule heating based highly non-linear I-V and hysteresis loop, we propose an oscillator neuron using PMO device put in series with a resistor and a capacitor to produce self-sustained oscillations. The transient measurements suggest that the oscillation frequencies of ~ 1MHz can be achieved, beyond which the oscillations are limited by devices heating timescale. Finally, a behavioral model of the oscillator is developed in Verilog-A to explore the design space over which the device operates. Based on such experimentally calibrated circuit models, large network of oscillators can be designed and performance can be evaluated in solving intricate real-life applications.
273	<strong>Experiments on the effects of nanoparticles on subcooled nucleate pool boiling</strong>	Effect of nanoparticles on single bubble-based nucleate pool boiling phenomenon under subcooled conditions has been studied. Water (as the base fluid) and two different concentrations of water-silica nanofluids (0.005 and 0.01% V/V) have been employed as the working fluids. The boiling experiments have been conducted in a specially-designed chamber wherein an ITO-coated heater substrate has been used to induce single bubble nucleation. Measurements have been performed non-intrusively using rainbow schlieren deflectometry. Thus, the thermal gradients have directly been mapped as two-dimensional distribution of hue values recorded in the form of schlieren images. The measurements clearly revealed the plausible influence of nanoparticles on the strength of temperature gradients prevailing in the boiling chamber. As compared to the base fluid, the experiments with dilute nanofluids showed that the suspended nanoparticles tend to diffuse the temperature gradients, both in the vicinity of the heated substrate as well as in the superheated layer enveloping the bubble. An overall reduction in the bubble volume and contact angle was seen with increasing concentrations of nanofluids. The bubble was found to assume more spherical shape at higher concentrations of dilute nanofluids in comparison to its shape with water-based experiments. Clear oscillations of the bubble in the subcooled pool of liquids were observed, the frequency of which was found to be significantly reduced as the nanoparticles concentration was increased from 0 to 0.01% (V/V). A force balance analysis has been performed to elucidate the plausible mechanisms explaining the observed trends of the oscillation frequencies of the vapor bubble.
274	<strong>Rapid fabrication of conductive silver line via plasma-enhanced inkjet printing</strong>	Atmospheric-pressure nonequilibrium plasma was applied to improve inkjet printing in terms of the line width, sintering temperature, and speed. Plasma irradiated silver-nanoparticle-dispersed inks during flight and after landing on a substrate to promote solidification and sintering. A silver line with electrical resistivity of 2.9&times;10<sup>-5</sup>&nbsp;&Omega;&nbsp;cm was fabricated on a polyimide for plasma exposure time of 1 s. During plasma irradiation, the substrate temperature was only reached to 120 &deg;C, avoiding any visible damage. Compared with heat treatment at 120 &deg;C, the silver line with plasma treatment shows lower electrical resistivity, a narrower line width, and a higher sintering speed.
275	Laser-controlled field effect in graphene/hexagonal boron nitride heterostructures	The possibility of modification of the local properties of hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) by laser irradiation is investigated. Investigations conducted using both Raman spectroscopy and electrostatic force microscopy were performed. Laser light induced modifications are found to cause no structural changes. However, they have impact on Raman spectra and local charge state of the material. They are also shown to be stable in time and during electrical grounding of the sample. The mechanism of photoionization of deep defects present in h-BN is proposed to explain the observed phenomenon. The discussed effect opens up new method of nanostructurization of h-BN based planar heterostructures.
276	<strong>Experimental and Theoretical Study of Ultraviolet-Induced Structural/Optical Instability In Nano Silicon-Based Photo Sensing</strong>	Nano silicon is emerging as an active element for UV applications due to quantum confinement-induced widening of the Si bandgap, amenability to integration on Si and less sensitivity to temperature. NanoSi-based UV applications include deep space exploration; high temperature propulsion; solar photovoltaics; and particle detection in high energy accelerators. However, the viability of the technology is limited by a complex nanoSi optical quenching instability. Here, we examined the time dynamics of UV-induced luminescence of sub 3-nm nanoSi. The results show that luminescence initially quenches, but it develops a stability at ~ 50% level with a time characteristic of minutes. Upon isolation, partial luminescence recovery/reversibility occurs with time characteristics of hours. To discern the origin of the instability, we perform first principle atomistic calculations of the molecular / electronic structure in 1-nm Si particles as a function of Si structural bond expansion, using time dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT), with structural relaxation applied in both ground and excited states. For certain bond expansion/relaxation, the results show that the low-lying triplet state dips below the singlet ground state, providing a plausible long-lasting optical trap that may account for luminescence quenching as well as bond cleavage and irreversibility. Time dynamics of device-operation that accommodates the quenching/recovery time dynamics is suggested as a means to alleviate the instability and allow control of recovery, which promises to make it an effective alternative to UV-enhanced Si or metal-based wide-bandgap sensing technology.
277	About the assignment of the EPR lines to Ce3+ in ceria powders	The electron paramagnetic resonance of Ce3+ ions in ceria is a rather controversial issue. In this report we analyze the EPR line with g ~ 1.97 in the absorption spectra of ceria powders, which has been assigned in many studies to Ce3+ ions. Such an assignment is not in agreement with the experimental data nor with the theory of spin-lattice relaxation of rare earth ions in solids. Our statement is supported by our experimental results based on EPR spectroscopy of nanocrystalline ceria, synthesized in various ways, as well as by magnetization measurements of as-prepared and vacuum-annealed ceria nanoparticles. The possible model of the paramagnetic center, which is assigned to the EPR line with g ~ 1.97 in ceria, is an electron trapped near the surface Ce3+/Ce4+ redox pair.
278	Microfluidic Standing Air Bubbles (&#x03BC;SABs)	Bubbles are commonly observed in microfluidic systems, yet they are often categorized as unfavorable elements if not under control. Although previous scientific endeavors have proven that the restrained micro-scale gas-liquid interfaces could be useful for various purposes, there is still plenty of room for further development of functional bubble-based microfluidics. Here, this report introduces a highly stable, controllable and scalable micro-bubble formation and manipulation method, named as Microfluidic Standing Air Bubbles (&#x03BC;SABs). The &#x03BC;SAB arrays are easily originated in specially-designed crevice structures on microfluidic channel walls in a repeatable and scalable manner. The size and geometry of &#x03BC;SABs are tuned by varying air mass transfer through a selectively permeable barrier where the bubbles attaching to. Both numerical calculations and experiments are implemented to explain the multiphysical coupling principles behind the phenomena, and to prove the controllable &#x03BC;SAB variation. A good linearity between &#x03BC;SABs volumetric variation rate and control pressure is validated under normal handling conditions (control pressure: -70kPa to 90kPa, average flow velocity: 0 to 7.4mm/s). Furthermore, the controllability, stability and potential practical applications are experimentally demonstrated. The &#x03BC;SABs own stable, controllable, scalable and flexible liquid-gas interfaces, making them an innovative technology and a promising candidate for accurate micro-manipulation, precise micro-/nano- flow regulation, high-throughput liquid-gas chemical synthesis, innovative biochemical and biophysical assays.
279	Extending the dynamic range of microchannel plate detectors using charge-integration-based counting	Abstract. Microchannel plate (MCP) detectors provide a mechanism to produce a measureable current pulse (~0.1mA over several nanoseconds) when stimulated by a single incident particle or photon. Reductions of the device's amplification factor (i.e., gain) due to high incident particle flux can lead to significant degradation of detection system performance. Here we develop a parameterized model for the variation of MCP gain with incident flux. This model provides a framework with which to quantify the limits of high-flux MCP operation. We then compare the predictions of this model to laboratory measurements of an MCP's response to a pulsed charged particle beam. Finally, we demonstrate that through integration of the MCP output current in pulsed operation, effective count rates up to ~ 1 GHz can be achieved, more than an order of magnitude increase over conventional counting techniques used for spaceflight applications.
280	<strong>Signatures of two dimensional transport in superconducting nanocrystalline boron-doped diamond films</strong>	The possibility of a two dimensional (2D) phase is investigated in superconducting boron-doped nanocrystalline diamond films.&nbsp; The fluctuation spectroscopy schemes such as the Azlamazov-Larkin (AL) and Lerner-Varlamov-Vinokur (LVV) are used to determine the dimensionality crossovers occurring near the superconducting phase transition.&nbsp; It is found that a distinct 2D phase in the fluctuation regime occurs.&nbsp; One of the consequences of the 2D transport is the manifestation of the Berezinskii-Kosterlitz-Thouless (BKT) transition which is verified through both current voltage power law scaling as well as the Halperin-Nelson fitting to the temperature dependent resistance.&nbsp; The suppression of the BKT transition with applied field is found to be correlated with the decrease of Josephson coupling between grains.&nbsp; The identification of a 2D phase accompanied by the BKT transition implies the presence of a topological order, highlighting the potential for diamond based quantum information technology.
281	Characterization of BaTiO<sub>3</sub> nanocubes assembled into highly-ordered monolayers using micro- and nano-Raman spectroscopy	We investigated the influence of heat treatment on the crystallographic structure and ferroelectric phase transition behavior of barium titanate (BaTiO<sub>3</sub>, BT) nanocubes assembled into highly-ordered monolayers, using tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS), temperature-dependent micro-Raman spectroscopy, and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM). TER spectra from individual BT nanocubes with the size of about 20 nm were successfully obtained with a side-illumination optical setup, and revealed that heat treatment enhances their tetragonality. The result of temperature-dependent micro-Raman spectroscopy showed that the ferroelectric phase transition behavior of the monolayers becomes similar to that of bulk BT through heat treatment in spite of their thickness. STEM observation for the cross-section of the heated BT nanocube monolayer showed that amorphous layers exist at the interface between BT nanocubes in face-to-face contact. These results indicate that the tetragonal crystal structure of BT nanocubes is stabilized by heat treatment and the formation of the interfacial amorphous layer during heat treatment may be a key to this phenomenon.
282	<strong>Effect of Lorentz forces on nanofluid flow and heat transfer during solidification process in a porous energy storage system </strong>	In this paper, influence of Lorentz forces on flow and heat transfer of NEPCM during solidification process is presented numerically using finite element method. Poor thermal conductivity of phase change material is a limitation of thermal storage systems. To overcome this problem, NEPCM can be utilized instead of pure PCM. Water and CuO are utilized as PCM and nanoparticles, respectively. Brownian motion impact is considered to predict nanofluid properties. Results are shown as solid fraction, isotherm and stream line contours. Results prove that solidification rate enhances with rise of Lorentz forces. As Hartmann number augments, total energy increases and solid fraction curve will converge in lower time.
283	<span style="color: #000000;">Onset of lasing in small devices: the identification of the first threshold</span>	We present a simple and &#xFB02;exible technique for identifying the onset of coherent emission in lasers, from the meso- to the nano-scale, which makes use of photon counting and a small amplitude modulation added to the pump. The optimal modulation frequency is obtained from the radiofrequency power spectrum of the unperturbed laser emission. The identi&#xFB01;cation of the lasing onset rests on the appearance of a resonance in the response of the zero-order autocorrelation function (g<sup>(2)</sup> (0)) plotted as a function of the pump rate. The intrinsic simplicity of this technique and its use of photon counting make it an excellent tool for certifying the onset of laser emission in nanoscale sources. <span style="color: #000000;"></span>
284	<strong>Spontaneous nanostructure formation in GaAsBi alloys</strong>	Bismuth containing semiconductor alloys are of increasing interest for their potential applications as infrared devices, though material quality in these materials has often proven problematic.&nbsp; This work shows a series of GaAsBi films grown by molecular beam epitaxy over a range of temperatures, 340C-315C, with all other parameters equal.&nbsp; Atomic force microscopy shows that there is an increase in the surface roughness of the films from 0.8nm to 2.7nm RMS. Transmission electron microscopy and atom probe tomography reveals the onset of spontaneous nanostructure formation in the films including nanopores, lateral composition modulation, and Bi rich GaAsBi clusters.&nbsp; The phenomena are shown to correlate and linked to reaching a growth instability due to the differences in surface diffusivity of Bi and As adatoms.
285	Shock Wave Plasma Induced Emission Generated by Low Energy Nanosecond Nd:YAG Laser in Open Air and Its Application to Quantitative Cr Analysis of Low Alloy Steel	We report the result of an experimental study that shows the remarkable benefits of generating a micro shock wave plasma by low energy (800 &#x00B5;J) nanosecond (ns) Nd:YAG laser irradiation on a solid target in open air and the efficient detection of the induced plasma emission. The very low irradiation power density of 0.8 MW/cm2 gives the important benefits of minimizing surface damage on the sample surface and reducing the ion production responsible for the undesirable emission background as well as the Stark broadening effect, and thus leading to largely improved spectral quality. This is corroborated by the result of spectra measured from a number of metal samples which display the sharp emission lines with low background. Specifically, its application to Cr analysis of a series of low alloy steel samples with different Cr concentrations is shown to yield a linear calibration curve with an extrapolated zero intercept and an estimated detection limit of about 10 ppm.
286	A Novel Pore-Free Strategy via Interfacial Effects in Nanocomposites to Produce Polyethylene with Ultra-Low Dielectric Constants	Materials with an ultra-low dielectric constant (&epsilon;) have been the topic of much interest because they are widely used in integrated circuits and high frequency devices. Pores (&epsilon; = 1) have been generally introduced in materials to reduce their &epsilon; to below 2. In this work, an alternative but highly facile method is introduced to create ultra-low &epsilon; materials based on interfacial effects in nanocomposites. Typical nanocomposites, polyethylene/silica nanoparticle composites, were prepared by mechanical blending and hot-pressing. The composite&rsquo;s &epsilon; was dramatically decreased from 2.50 to 1.90 when incorporating 8 wt.% silica. This &epsilon; value was much lower than the low extreme of predicted &epsilon;. The porosities of the composites are below 1 %, indicating that the ultra-low &epsilon; is not a result of a porous structure. Instead, this ultra-low &epsilon; was found to be correlated with dielectric confinement effect of silica nanoparticles caused by interfacial effect. The interfacial effect was evidenced by the change of &epsilon; with loading ratios of silica and pressures, and a nanoparticle-induced crystallization.
287	SiO<sub>2</sub> etch characteristics and environmental impact of Ar/C<sub>3</sub>F<sub>6</sub>O chemistry	For the nano-scale etching in the semiconductor process, perfluorocarbon (PFC) gases are commonly used. However, PFCs mainly used in semiconductor processing have disadvantages such as high life time and global warming effect when released into the air. Therefore, in this research, SiO<sub>2</sub> etch characteristics and global warming effects of C<sub>3</sub>F<sub>6</sub>O gas chemistry with low global warming potential were compared with those of C<sub>4</sub>F<sub>8</sub> chemistry which is one of the gases mainly used in the semiconductor process. With Ar/C<sub>3</sub>F<sub>6</sub>O, the SiO<sub>2</sub> rates were higher while the etch selectivities of SiO<sub>2</sub> over amorphous carbon layer (ACL) as the hardmask layer were lower compared to those with Ar/C<sub>4</sub>F<sub>8</sub>/O<sub>2</sub> when other etch conditions were maintained same. Ar/C<sub>3</sub>F<sub>6</sub>O also showed more anisotropic SiO<sub>2</sub> etch profiles by suppressing the bowing, narrowing, and necking effects compared to Ar/C<sub>4</sub>F<sub>8</sub>/O<sub>2</sub>. When the global warming effects were evaluated by calculating the million metric ton carbon equivalents (MMTCEs) from the volumetric concentrations of emitted by-product species and process gases, the results showed that, at the optimized conditions, Ar/C<sub>3</sub>F<sub>6</sub>O exhibited a lower environmental impact by showing < 24% MMTCE value compared to that of Ar/C<sub>4</sub>F<sub>8</sub>/O<sub>2</sub>. Therefore, it is believed that Ar/C<sub>3</sub>F<sub>6</sub>O could be considered as a new potential replacement gas mixture for Ar/C<sub>4</sub>F<sub>8</sub>/O<sub>2</sub> because of the lower MMTCE and the acceptable etch characteristics of SiO<sub>2</sub>.
288	Enhanced ferromagnetism in mechanically-exfoliated CVD-carbon films prepared by using adamantane as precursor	In this work, room-temperature ferromagnetism which is not caused by conventional magnetic elements (e.g. Fe, Co, and Ni) is observed in carbon films prepared by using adamantane (C10H16): the smallest member of the so called diamondoid series (nano-diamond structures). These chemical-vapor-deposition (CVD) films exhibit a moderately strong ferromagnetism which can be further enhanced by mechanically exfoliating the top layers of the films off; the saturated magnetization can be as large as 3.95 emu/cm3 at room temperature. Magnetic force microscopy measurement shows a clear contrast in magnetization between original and exfoliated regions, indicating that the magnetic origin likely comes from the broken &rdquo;dangling&rdquo; bonds at the exfoliated surface. This work suggests an inexpensive method for creating carbon films whose magnetization can be activated from mechanical exfoliation.
289	Ferro and Anti-ferromagnetic Coupling in Pr, Dy, and Tb Substituted Nd-Fe-B nanoparticles and Its Effect on Magnetic Properties	Magnetic nanoparticles of Nd13.5RE4.5Fe77.5B7.5 (RE = Pr, Dy, and Tb) were prepared by co-precipitation followed by reduction diffusion. After substitution, Pr was ferromagnetic but Dy and Tb were anti-ferromagnetic to Nd and Fe in the Nd-Fe-B crystal lattice. The magneto-crystalline anisotropy energy was increased from 0.2284 MJ/m3 to 0.3924 and 0.3910 MJ/m3 after the substitution of Nd with Dy and Tb in Nd-Fe-B. The main reason for the improvement of the magnetic properties was the enhancement of the magneto-crystalline anisotropy of the crystal lattice by the pinning of magnetic moments and increase of the thickness of the magnetic domain wall.
290	<strong>Bonding and de-bonding of SiC-SiC via an intermediate Ni nano-film</strong>	In this study, a wafer bonding and de-bonding method for silicon carbide (SiC) that can sustain rapid thermal annealing (RTA) at ~1273 K has been realized for the first time. Two SiC wafers were bonded via an intermediate nickel (Ni) nano-film at room temperature without any pressure, which was characterized as a seamless and robust bonding. After the RTA process, the strength of the bonding interface was dramatically decreased and the de-bonding could happen at the interface during pulling test. Both of the mechanisms of bonding and de-bonding have been investigated through interface analyses. The sufficient atomic diffusion between two deposited Ni nano-films together with the interfacial mixing between amorphous SiC and the Ni nano-film contribute to the strong bonding of SiC-SiC. The interfacial precipitation of layered carbon material parallel to the SiC substrates is assumed to be the reason of the interface weakening and successful de-bonding after annealing. It is believed that the further development of this bonding and de-bonding technology will advance thin SiC device fabrication, where the RTA process at ~1273 K is widely used.
291	Novel concept for collective surface plasmon excitation and amplification through the dissipative instability of direct current in a two-dimensional quantum well	We propose an original concept for on-chip excitation and amplification of surface plasmon polaritons. Our approach, named nanoresotron, utilizes the collective effect of dissipative instability of a direct current flowing in a two-dimensional quantum well coupled to a metal surface. The instability arises through the excitation of self-consistent&nbsp; plasma oscillations and results in the creation of a pair of collective surface electromagnetic modes in addition to conventional plasmon resonances. We derive the dispersion equations for these modes using self-consistent solutions of Maxwell's and 2D hydrodynamics equations. We find that the phase velocities of these new collective modes are close to the drift velocity of 2D electrons. We demonstrate that the slow mode is amplified while the fast mode exhibits absorption. Estimates indicate that very high gain are attainable, which makes the nanoresotron a promising scheme to electrically excite and regenerate surface plasmon polaritons.
292	Effect of MWCNT-Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>/Water Hybrid Nanofluid on the Thermal Performance of Ribbed Channel with Apart Sections of Heating and Cooling	A Two-dimensional (2D) numerical simulation is performed to simulate the laminar forced convection of a nanofluid in a ribbed channel with apart heating (cooling) sources using lattice Boltzmann method (LBM). The multi-wall carbon nanotubes-iron oxide nanoparticles/water hybrid nanofluid (MWCNT-Fe3O4/water hybrid nanofluid) is used in this simulation. &nbsp;The velocity field, temperature distribution and heat transfer rate are numerically analyzed with the streamlines and isotherm patterns by means of a house-code. Also, the effect of Reynolds number (Re=25, 50, 75 and 100), nanoparticle solid volume fraction (&#x03D5;=0, 0.001, 0.003) and ratio of the blocks height (A=0.2, 0.3, 0.4) are measured in this paper. The computational method is validated against the results reported in the literature and a good agreement is reported. The obtained results show a maximum value of 16.49% increase in average heat transfer coefficient for all the considered cases relative to the base fluid. Moreover, the local Nusselt number proves that the use of blocks on the channel walls can increase the amount of heat transfer. Finally, average Nusselt number shows a linear dependence on the increasing ratio of&nbsp; blocks height for constant solid volume fraction. The results of this study are applicable to the industrial equipment heating and cooling applications.
293	Numerical Investigation of Nanofluids Heat Transfer in a Channel Consists of Rectangular Cavities by Lattice Boltzmann Method	In this study, Lattice Boltzmann simulation is performed to investigate laminar forced convection of nanofluids&nbsp;in a horizontal parallel-plate channel with three rectangular cavities. Two cavities are considered as located&nbsp;on the top wall of the channel and one on the bottom wall. The effects of the Reynolds number (100-400), the&nbsp;cavity aspect ratio (AR=0.25, 0.5), the various distances of the cavities from each other (X&prime;<sub>c</sub>) at different solid&nbsp;volume fractions of nanofluids (&#x03D5; = 0-0.05) on the velocity, and the temperature profiles of the nanofluids&nbsp;are studied. In addition, the flow patterns, i.e., the deflection and re-circulation zone inside the cavities, and&nbsp;the local and averaged Nusselt numbers on the channel walls are calculated. The results obtained are used&nbsp;to ascertain the validity of the written numerical code, which points to the excellent agreement across the&nbsp;results. The results show that, as the solid volume fraction of nano fluids is enhanced, the transfer of heat&nbsp;to working fluids increases significantly. Further, the results show that the maximum value of the averaged&nbsp;Nusselt number in the channel is obtained at X&prime;c=0.1204 for AR = 0.5 and X&prime;<sub></sub><sub>c</sub>=0.1024 for AR = 0.25. The&nbsp;interval [0.1224, 0.1304] is the best position for the second cavity. It is concluded that the results of this&nbsp;paper are very useful for designing optimized heat exchangers.
294	<strong>ZnO nanorod array/reduced graphene oxide substrate with enhanced performance in photocatalytic degradation</strong>	A novel ZnO nanorod array/reduced graphene oxide (ZnO array/rGO) composite coating was synthesized via the combination of seed layers-growth and aqueous solution reaction for the formation of ZnO nanorod array and further simple water bath method to compound rGO. The results revealed that perpendicular arrays with hexagonal planes were successfully fabricated. The size and density of the arrays can be adjusted by the concentration of the reactants. The influence of the rGO additive concentration on the photocatalytic degradation of the ZnO array/rGO composites under UV radiation were investigated. It was found that the photocatalytic performance could be obviously improved after coupling rGO for MB decomposition. The enhanced photocatalytic activities could be attributed to the interactions between ZnO nanorod arrays and rGO nanosheets and subsequently effective separation of photo-generated electron-hole pairs via rGO as electron sinks. The ZnO array/rGO composites are expected to the ideal photocatalysts for the future utilization to take facile and green preparation, increasing the photo-electron lifetime, improving particle agglomeration and being prone to recovery into account.
295	<strong>Tutorial: Determination of Thermal Boundary Resistance by Molecular Dynamics Simulations</strong>	Due to the high surface&ndash;to&ndash;volume ratio of nanostructured components in microelectronics and other advanced devices, the thermal resistance at material interfaces can strongly affect the overall thermal behavior in these devices. Therefore, the thermal boundary resistance, <em>R</em>, must be taken into account in the thermal analysis of nanoscale structures and devices. This article is a tutorial on the determination of <em>R</em> and the analysis of interfacial thermal transport via molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. In addition to reviewing the commonly-used equilibrium and non-equilibrium MD models for the determination of <em>R</em>, we also discuss several MD simulation methods which can be used to understand interfacial thermal transport behavior. To illustrate how these MD models work for various interfaces, we will show several examples of MD simulation results on thermal transport across solid-solid, solid-liquid, and solid-gas interfaces. The advantages and drawbacks of a few other MD models such as approach-to-equilibrium MD and first-principle MD are also discussed.
296	Synthesis and enhanced third-order nonlinear optical effect of ZnSe/graphene composites	ZnSe/graphene composites can be produced by the amount of hydrazine hydrate, and their nonlinear optical properties are investigated at 532 nm by a picosecond laser Z-scan technique. The attachment of the ZnSe nanocrystals on graphene nanosheets can be confirmed by transmission electron microscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray and UV-Vis spectroscopy. And the interaction between them enhances the optical nonlinearity of ZnSe/graphene composites than single ZnSe or graphene. The increase of ZnSe size further enhances the optical nonlinearity of ZnSe/graphene.
297	Diffusion behavior of water confined in deformed carbon nanotubes	We use molecular dynamics simulations to study the diffusion of water inside deformed carbon nanotubes, with different degrees of eccentricity at 300K. We found a water structural transition between tubular-like to single-file for the (7,7) nanotubes associated with a change from a high to low mobility regimes. The water which in the undeformed (9,9) nanotubes is frozen, becomes liquid for the distortion above a certain threshold. These water diffusion enhancement (suppresion) is related to a reduction (increase) in the number of hydrogen bonds. This suggests that the shape of the nanotube is a particularly important ingredient when considering the dynamical and structural properties of confined water.
298	THE ISING MODEL OF CONFINED WATER IN CNT	The Ising model, describing mathematically phase transitions between disordered and ordered states in ferromagnets and binary alloys, has been applied to the freezing process of water confined inside the carbon nanotube. To take into account the rearrangement of water molecules inside the carbon nanotube to retain their hydrogen bonds in competition with van der Waals interactions with carbon atoms of the nanotube, an additional term has been introduced into the formula for the ordering parameter in water. Inclusion of this hydrophobic effect which  depends exponentially upon the diameter of the tube within the Ising model yields an expression for the dependence of freezing temperature of water inside the CNT upon its diameter. According to the model, the smaller the diameter of the tube, the higher freezing temperature of water molecules.  These theoretical results are in a good agreement with the experimental data.
299	<strong>Conductivity of disordered nanowire networks: the dependence on length ratio of conducting paths to whole nanowires</strong>	Conducting behavior of disordered nanowire networks is found to be determined by the length ratio of conducting paths to whole nanowires in the networks, which has been concluded from combined studies of simulation and experiment. An algorithm is designated for the simulation, where evolution dynamics of conducting paths and network conductance could be monitored at the same time. It is observed that, with increment of nanowire length (at given area fraction), conducting paths grow more slowly than the percolated clusters, but they play a key role in the conductivity. Normalized network conductivity of the disordered nanowire network is found to function linearly with the length-ratio of conducting paths to the whole nanowires. The relationship has been verified by experiments where networks are built up from random aligned silver nanowires. In addition, the newly proposed relationship could be used to anticipate theoretical conductivity of given disordered nanowire network, as well as the average junction resistance between nanowires. The relationship happens to be very similar to the Effective Medium Theory proposed by Kirkpatrick (1973) in treating 2D bond percolation, but the deterministic parameter shall be changed from filling probability of bonds to length ratio of the conducting paths. The difference lies on that the length ratio concerns only on conducting paths, rather than dead ends or branches. At last, the length ratio functioned relationship could be treated as a basic tool to describe the conducting behavior of disordered nanowire networks.
300	Local strain distribution and microstructure of grinding- induced damage layers in SiC wafer	The high angular resolution electron backscatter diffraction (HR-EBSD) technique was utilized in evaluating the elastic strain distribution of grinding-induced damage layers in SiC wafer. Through HR-EBSD analysis, along with TEM observation, it was revealed that the damage layers formed beneath the wafer surface when the surface was ground by diamond abrasives; and the layers were classified hierarchically based on the distribution of elastic strain and lattice defects. In particular, very large elastic strain formed in a defective region of roughly 0.6 &micro;m in thickness, just beneath the ground wafer surface, where lattice defects such as dislocations, stacking faults, and microcracks were introduced inhomogeneously by abrasive interaction and the related plastic deformation and fracture. Based on this inhomogeneity, the defective region was itself classified into two types: one, a highly defective region with very large, complicated strain and high defect density; and the other, a basal plane dislocation (BPD)-glide region, with small strain and few BPDs or stacking faults. Beneath the defective region, a strain gradient region of roughly 1.8 &micro;m in thickness, which was unambiguously identified by HR-EBSD strain analysis alone, revealed a monotonic gradient in the dominant compressive strain component, with no grinding-induced defects. Overall, HR-EBSD analysis revealed a nanometer-scale, hierarchical elastic strain distribution in the grinding-induced damage layers.
301	A NOMS Switch Operating at Low-light-Level	This paper reports an all-optical switch working at low-light-level based on nano-opto-mechanics system (NOMS) technology. This NOMS switch consists of a silicon micro-ring resonator with a suspended arc and a bus waveguide with a footprint size of 50 &micro;m &times; 50 &micro;m. In this device, a &ldquo;weak&rdquo; light beam controls the ON state and OFF state of a &ldquo;strong&rdquo; light beam through nonlinear enhanced optical gradient force. In our experiment, we have successfully demonstrated the repeated switching of ON &amp; OFF states with the control light (&ldquo;weak&rdquo; light) of intensity 380 times lower than that of the probe light (&ldquo;strong&rdquo; light). This new NOMS switch has potential applications in optical memories, quantum information networks, and on-chip optical signal process where the devices or the systems require high power efficiency, high cost-effective and ultra-compact integration.
302	Re doping induced 2H-1T phase transformation and ferromagnetism in MoS2 nanosheets	In this paper, Re doped MoS2 nanosheets were synthesized by a facile hydrothermal reaction and annealing process. Through structural characterization, it was observed that the doping of Re can lead to the 2H-1T transformation in both Re and Mo coordinating structure, and the 1T ratio increased with the Re doping concentration and maximally reached to 51.7 at.% and 85.1 at.% for Mo and Re, respectively. Besides, hysteresis loops demonstrated the intrinsic room temperature ferromagnetism in Re doped MoS2 nanosheets, and the values of saturated magnetization achieved to 9 memu/g when the doping concentration of Re is 17.12 at.%. The magnetic properties were mainly resulted from the increasing net magnetic moments of Re atoms and 1T-coordinated Mo atoms. Additionally, the 1T incorporated 2H structure and magnetism were thermal stable in these samples. These results explored a new path for MoS2 nanosheets to be applied in spintronic devices in the future.
303	<strong>Optical gain and excitonic processes in micrometer-sized ZnO particles</strong>	We investigate the emission properties of various ZnO microstructures with different size and shape in the temperature region from 3 to 300 K using a nanosecond pulsed laser as an excitation source. Room temperature stimulated emission is observed only from the sphere-like ZnO particles with size of a few micrometers. Temperature dependent measurements reveal that the mechanism of optical gain at temperatures below ~150 K is the exciton-exciton scattering, whereas at temperatures from ~150 K to room temperature the gain results solely from the exciton-electron scattering without any contribution from electron-hole plasma lasing. The observed temperature-induced transition between exciton-exciton and exciton-electron scattering is quite similar to the one reported recently for the micrometer-thick ZnO film [R. Matsuzaki <em>et al. </em>Phys. Rev. B 96, 125306 (2017).]. Thus, a purely excitonic stimulated emission is common in micrometer-sized ZnO crystals with appropriate optical feedback.
304	<strong>Seesaw-like</strong><strong> polarized transmission </strong><strong>behavior of</strong> <strong>s</strong><strong>ilver nanowire arrays </strong><strong>aligned by off-center spin-coating</strong>	Straight silver nanowires are synthesized by accelerated oxidization, and aligned into ordered arrays by off-center spin-coating. A seesaw-like behavior is revealed in the polarized transmission spectra the arrays. As polarization angle (<em>&theta;<sub>P</sub></em>, defined as the angle between axis of nanowires and direction of electric field of light) increases, transmission changes in two opposite directions in the two regions separated by a supporting point lying at 494 nm, besides that, they all evolve repeatedly with period of 180<sup>o</sup>. The behavior is different from those reported before, where transmission moves on the same direction. The behavior is ascribed to the Surface Plasma Polaritons (SPPs) determined extinction. Competition appears between the two modes of SPPs in determining the extinction of nanowires, as the mode along nanowire axis is mainly excited by long wavelengths, the other mode perpendicular to that depends mainly on short wavelengths, which then produces the seesaw-like behavior. Simulation is performed using on finite-difference time domain (FDTD) method, which reproduces the polarized transmission behavior. Moreover, it helps to reveal the effect of nanowire diameter on the supporting point in the seesaw-like transmission behavior.
305	<strong>Spin-orbit interaction in Pt or Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> nanoparticle-decorated graphene realized by nanoneedle method</strong>	<strong>The introduction of spin-orbit interactions (SOIs) and the subsequent appearance of a two-dimensional (2D) topological phase are crucial for voltage-controlled</strong><strong> spintronic devices. In contrast, graphene basically lacks SOIs due to the small mass of the carbon atom, and appropriate experimental reports for SOIs are rare. Here, </strong><strong>we precisely control small-amount (cover ratios &lt; 8 %) and damageless random-decoration of heavy nanoparticles </strong><strong>[platinum (Pt) or bismuth telluride (Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub>)]</strong><strong> to </strong><strong>mono-layer </strong><strong>graphene by developing an original nanoneedle method. </strong><strong>X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy</strong><strong> spectra suggest damageless decoration of the nanoparticles, resulting in emergence of the Bi-C and Te-C coupling orbitals.</strong> <strong>In the samples, we find </strong><strong>the emergence of particle-density dependent non-local resistance (R<sub>NL</sub>) peaks, which are attributed to the (inverse) spin Hall effect (SHE) arising from spin-orbit interaction (SOI) with energies as large as </strong><strong>~</strong><strong>50 meV that is the largest value among previous reports and supported by scanning tunnel microscopy spectra. The present observation opens doors to novel physics for topological phases of graphene, introducible by random heavy-nanoparticle decoration with controlled small-amount, and those applications.</strong>
306	<strong>Topological states mediated transport behavior in pnictogen chalcogenide nanocomposites</strong>	Bismuth telluride and selenide are well known 3-D topological materials with gapless surface states. We utilized the surface states to improve charge carrier transport across the hetero-phase boundary in composite samples. The pure and composite samples showed high temperature charge carrier transport influenced by acoustic phonon scattering. However, the electrical conductivity of composite samples was up to three times higher than the pure samples. The enhancement was attributed to topological states at the interface of two phases. The composite samples showed some improvement in thermoelectric and thermal transport behavior which resulted in better power factor and figure of merit as compared to pure samples.
307	<strong>Poly-crystalline silicon-oxide films as carrier-selective passivating contacts for c-Si solar cells</strong>	The poly-Si carrier-selective passivating contacts (CSPC) parasitically absorb a substantial amount of light, especially in the form of free carrier absorption. To minimize these losses, we developed CSPCs based on oxygen-alloyed poly-Si (poly-SiO<sub>x</sub>) and deployed them in c-Si solar cells. TEM analysis indicates the presence of nanometer-scale silicon crystals within such poly-SiO<sub>x</sub> layers. By varying the O content during material deposition, we can manipulate the crystallinity of poly-SiO<sub>x</sub> material and its absorption coefficient. Also depending on O content, the band gap of poly-SiO<sub>x</sub> material can be widened, making it transparent for longer wavelength light. Thus, we optimized the O alloying, doping, annealing and hydrogenation conditions. As a result, an extremely high passivation quality for both n-type poly-SiO<sub>x</sub> (J<sub>0</sub> = 3.0 fA/cm<sup>2</sup>, iVoc = 740 mV) and p-type poly-SiO<sub>x</sub> (J<sub>0</sub> = 17.0 fA/cm<sup>2</sup>, iVoc = 700 mV) is obtained. A fill factor of 83.5% is measured in front/back-contacted solar cell with both polarities made up of poly-SiO<sub>x</sub>. This indicates that the carrier transport through the junction between poly-SiO<sub>x</sub> and c-Si is sufficiently efficient. To demonstrate the merit of poly-SiOx layers&rsquo; high transparency at long wavelengths, they are deployed at the back side of interdigitated back-contacted (IBC) solar cells. A preliminary cell efficiency of 19.7% is obtained with much room for further improvement. Compared to an IBC solar cell with poly-Si CSPCs, a higher internal quantum efficiency at long wavelengths is observed for the IBC solar cell with poly-SiO<sub>x</sub> CSPCs, thus demonstrating the potential of poly-SiO<sub>x</sub> in enabling higher J<sub>SC</sub>.
308	<strong>Thermo-physical trends in time dependent Williamson model around a wedge </strong>	The addition of nano-sized particles into base fluid yields better heat transfer characteristics than that of base fluid without nano-scale particles. Such improvement in thermal conductivity brings attention of researchers and scientists in this direction. This paper provides nano-sized particles individualities subject to Williamson fluid model. The time dependent stagnation point magnetohydrodynamic fluid flow regime for the Williamson model is carried around a wedge surface. The nano-sized particles are suspended in the Williamson fluid flow regime along with pertinent physical effects, namely melting heat transfer, heat generation/absorption and new mass flux condition. The mathematical; formulation yields the system of partial differential equations through acceptable governing laws. The obtain system is enough hard to solve analytically due to non-linear in nature. Therefore, a self-coded algorithm is executed to report numerical solution. A both tabular and graphical trends are used to present the impact of involved physical parameters on Williamson velocity, temperature and concentration fields. In addition, the physical quantity at the surface of the wedge is also examined.
309	Space-charge and current non-uniformities, and contact resistivity of end-bonded metal contacts to thin heavily doped semiconductor nanowires	We report room temperature simulations of the effects of surrounding field and surface defects on small-bias space-charge and current distributions of <em>end-bonded</em> metal contacts having a wide range of intrinsic barrier heights <em>&Phi;<sub>b0</sub></em> = 0.4 - 0.8 V on <em>thin</em> n-type silicon NanoWires (NWs) of radius <em>R</em> = 5 - 10 nm<sup> </sup>and <em>heavy</em> doping of <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> = 10<sup>18 </sup>- 10<sup>20</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup>, embedded in SiO<sub>2</sub>. We have two findings. (i) Radial distributions of space-charge and current, which are almost uniform for <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> &lt; 10<sup>18</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup>, become highly non-uniform for <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> &gt; 10<sup>18</sup> cm<sup>-3 </sup>violating the key assumption of a plane space-charge edge employed in literature to analytically model NW junctions; the non-uniformity peaks at <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> where bulk depletion width &asymp; 2.14<em>R</em>, for large metal size and small surface charge. (ii) At <em>&Phi;<sub>b0</sub></em> = 0.8 V, both generation-recombination and tunneling govern the NW contact resistivity, <em>&rho;<sub>cN</sub></em>, for <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> up to 3 - 5 x 10<sup>18</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup>, so that <em>&rho;<sub>cN</sub></em> varies slowly or may even increase in this <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> range; however, generation-recombination falls rapidly as <em>&Phi;<sub>b0 </sub></em>is reduced or <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> is raised, so that <em>&rho;<sub>cN</sub></em> of contacts with <em>&Phi;<sub>b0</sub></em> = 0.8 V and <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> &gt; 5 x 10<sup>18</sup> cm<sup>-3 </sup>or <em>&Phi;<sub>b0</sub></em> &le; 0.6 V and any <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> is governed by tunneling alone and falls monotonically with <em>N<sub>d</sub></em>. Our insights and data regarding space-charge, current and <em>&rho;<sub>cN</sub></em> variations are useful in design, characterization and analytical modeling of NW devices. Our calculations include the effects of contact geometry, dielectric confinement, image force barrier lowering and heavy doping.
310	Conformational kinetic analysis of replica exchange MD: T-dependent Markov networks for FF amyloid peptides	Recent developments using Markovian descriptions of conformational states of biomolecular systems have led to powerful analysis frameworks for their complex dynamical behavior. In conjunction with enhanced sampling methods, such as replica exchange molecular dynamics (REMD), these frameworks allow the systematic and accurate extraction of transition probabilities between the corresponding states, in the case of Markov state models, and of statistically-optimized transition rates in the case of the corresponding coarse master equations. However, applying automatically such methods to large molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, with explicit water molecules, remains limited both by the initial ability to identify good candidates for the underlying Markovian states, and by the necessity to do so using good collective variables as reaction coordinates that allow the correct counting of inter-state transitions at various lag times. Here, we show that, in cases when representative molecular conformations can be identified for the corresponding Markovian states, and thus their corresponding collective evolution of atomic positions can be calculated along MD trajectories, one can use them to build a new type of simple collective variable, that can be particularly useful in both the correct state assignment and in the subsequent accurate counting of inter-state transition probabilities. In the case of the ubiquitously used root-mean-square deviation (RMSD) of atomic positions, we introduce the relative RMSD measure (RelRMSD) as a good reaction coordinate candidate. We apply this method to the analysis of REMD trajectories of amyloid-forming diphenylalanine (FF) peptides - a system with important nanotechnology and biomedical applications due to its self-assembling and piezoelectric properties - illustrating the use of RelRMSD in extracting its temperature-dependent intrinsic kinetics, without a priory assumptions on the functional form (e.g., Arrhenius or not) of the underlying conformational transition rates. The RelRMSD analysis enables as well a more objective assessment of the convergence of the REMD simulations. This type of collective variable may be generalized to other observables that could capture accurately conformational differences between the underlying Markov states (e.g., dRMSD, T-RMSD, the fraction of native contacts, etc.).
311	<strong>Engineering few-layer MoTe<sub>2</sub> devices by Co/hBN tunnel contacts</strong>	2H phase Molybdenum ditelluride (MoTe<sub>2</sub>) is a layered two-dimensional (2D) semiconductor that has recently gained extensive attention for its intriguing properties, demonstrating great potential for nanoelectronics and optoelectronics. Optimizing the electric contacts to MoTe<sub>2</sub> is a critical step for realizing high performance devices. Here, we demonstrate the first Co/hBN tunnel contact to few-layer MoTe<sub>2</sub>. In sharp contrast to the p-type conduction of Co contacted MoTe<sub>2</sub>, Co/hBN tunnel contacted MoTe<sub>2</sub> devices show clear n-type transport property. Our first principle calculation reveals that the inserted few-layer hBN strongly interacts with Co and significantly reduces its work-function by ~1.2 eV, while MoTe<sub>2</sub> itself has much weaker influence on the work-function of Co. This allows us to build MoTe<sub>2</sub> diodes using the mixed Co/hBN and Co contacts architecture, which can be switched from p-n type to n-p type by changing the gate-voltage, paves the way for engineering multi-functional devices based on atomically thin 2D semiconductors.
312	<strong>Piezoelectric </strong><strong>performance enhancement</strong><strong> of Pb(Mg<sub>1/3</sub>Nb<sub>2/3</sub>)O<sub>3</sub>-0.25PbTiO<sub>3</sub> crystals by alternating current polarization for ultrasonic transducer</strong>	The [001]-oriented Pb(Mg<sub>1/3</sub>Nb<sub>2/3</sub>)O<sub>3</sub>-0.25PbTiO<sub>3</sub>(PMN-0.25PT) single crystal had been poled by using alternating current polarization (ACP). The piezoelectric, dielectric and electromechanical properties of PMN-0.25PT crystals were investigated as functions of polarization frequency, electric field and cycles. The optimal ACP condition for PMN-0.25PT crystals was obtained under an electric field of 12-18 kV/cm with polarization frequency of 20-40 Hz after 20 cycles. Compared to traditional direct current polarization (DCP), ACP makes the piezoelectric coefficient of PMN-0.25PT crystals increase by 40 %, from 1222 pC/N to 1724 pC/N. Piezoresponse force microscopy (PFM) images of the crystals revealed that the periodic stripe nano-domains (non-180&deg; domains) with high domain wall density is the main contributors for piezoelectric enhancement. The results indicate that the alternating current poled PMN-0.25PT crystals with enhanced piezoelectric property will be promising candidate for sensors and transducers.
313	Directly Probing Light Absorption Enhancement of Single Hierarchical Structures with Engineered Surface Roughness	Hierarchical multiscale nanostructures are ideal architectures to harvest solar energy, in which absorption and propagation of light at the subwavelength scale are fundamental key issues. Exploring the light absorption in single hierarchical structures and determining key structural parameters can greatly help in enhancing multiscale optical phenomena and light management for modern photovoltaics, photoelectric and photoelectrochemical devices. However, due to the geometrical complexity of hierarchical architectures, numerical and experimental studies of light absorption have faced significant challenges. Given the light absorption is governed by the geometries of nanostructures, this study investigates the correlation between light absorption and surface roughness of single hierarchical structures by utilizing VO<sub>2</sub>-based near field powermeters. It is found that light trapping is significantly enhanced in rough microwires when the amplitude of roughness is comparable to the light wavelength while it rapidly reaches saturated values with trench depth larger than the light wavelength or trench spacing less than half of the light wavelength. These results are verified both on the fabricated VO<sub>2</sub> and Si hierarchical structures and thus provide a general rational design for modern hierarchical structures with enhanced behaviours.
314	Stray field signatures of N&eacute;el textured skyrmions in Ir/Fe/Co/Pt multilayer films	Skyrmions are nanoscale spin configurations with topological properties that hold great promise for spintronic devices. Here, we establish their N&eacute;el texture, helicity, and size in Ir/Fe/Co/Pt multilayer films by constructing a multipole expansion to model their stray field signatures and applying it to magnetic force microscopy (MFM) images. Furthermore, the demonstrated sensitivity to inhomogeneity in skyrmion properties, coupled with a unique capability to estimate the pinning force governing dynamics, portends broad applicability in the burgeoning field of topological spin textures.
315	Features of interferometry of small-sized plasma channels obtained during nanosecond breakdown	The applicability of the method of smooth perturbations for processing interferograms of small (5-200&#x00A0;&#x03BC;m) objects with taking into account the diffraction is investigated. The test problems showed the consistency of the method to the range of parameters interesting for us. The requirements for preliminary processing of experimental data are determined, adhering to which it is possible to improve the accuracy of the final results. The analysis of experimental interferograms in assuming of the cylindrical symmetry of the plasma object is carried out: the two-dimensional map of the electron density for the plasma object formed at initial stage of nanosecond breakdown was obtained from the phase map.
316	<strong>Molecular dynamics investigation on enhancement of heat transfer between electrified solid surface and liquid water</strong>	Interfacial nanolayer acting as a bridge linking a bulk solid phase and a bulk liquid phase has a crucial impact on the heat transfer from the solid to the liquid. In this work, we proposed a promising method to enhance the heat transfer between a Cu surface and liquid water by applying surface charges to the surface, which was expected to change the structure of the interfacial nanolayer. We employed molecular dynamics simulations to verify the effectiveness of the method. Our simulations showed that applying surface charges led to an orientational alignment of water molecules, reducing the spacing between the solid surface and the interfacial nanolayer and increasing the number of water molecules located at the interface nanolayer. Meanwhile, the presence of surface charges also improves the mismatch of vibrational density of states between solid atoms and water molecules. As a results, the heat transfer was enhanced as compared with that without surface charges and the enhancement becomes more remarkebly when applying more surface charges to the Cu surface.
317	<strong>Temperature-dependent radiative and non-radiative dynamics of photo-excited carriers </strong><strong>in extremely high-density and small InGaN nanodisks </strong><strong>fabricated by damage-free neutral-beam etching using bio-nano-templates</strong>	Temperature-dependent radiative and non-radiative dynamics of photoexcited carriers were studied in In<sub>0.3</sub>Ga<sub>0.7</sub>N nanodisks (NDs) fabricated from quantum wells (QWs) by damage-free neutral-beam etching using bio-nano-templates. The NDs had a diameter of 5 nm, thicknesses of 2 nm and 3 nm, and a sheet density of 2&times;10<sup>11 </sup>cm<sup>-</sup><sup>2</sup>. The radiative decay time, reflecting the displacement between the electron and hole wavefunctions, is about 0.1 ns; this value is almost constant as a function of temperature in the NDs and not dependent on their thickness. We observed non-exponential decay curves of photoluminescence (PL) in the NDs, particularly at temperatures above 150 K. The thermal activation energies of PL quenching in the NDs are revealed to be 95&ndash;110 meV, corresponding to the barrier heights of the valence bands in the disks. Therefore, hole escape is deemed responsible for the PL quenching, while thermal activation energies of 12&ndash;16 meV due to the trapping of carriers by defects were dominant in the mother QWs. The abovementioned non-exponential PL decay curves can be attributed to variations in the rate of hole escape in the NDs because of fluctuations in the valence-band barrier height, which, in turn, is possibly due to compositional fluctuations in the QWs. We found that non-radiative trapping, characteristic of the original QW, also exists in about 1% of the NDs in a form that is not masked by other newly formable defects. Therefore, we suggest that additional defects are not formed during our ND fabrication process.
318	Waxberry like nanosphere Li<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> as high performance electrode materials for supercapacitors	At present, studies on storage device, especial supercapacitors, mainly focus on the attained high performance electrode materials. The porous materials have the superior electrochemical performance owing to its porous structure which could increase the specific and contact area with the electrode. The spinel Li<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> has the three-dimensional tunnel structure for the better diffusion path, which have the advantage of lithium ion insertion and extraction in the framework. In this work, a waxberry like nanosphere and rasberry like nanosphere Li<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> have been fabricated by the wet chemistry and solid-state methods. The diameter of the single waxberry like sphere is about 1 &mu;m. &nbsp;The electrochemical performance of waxberry like nanosphere Li<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> was studied systemically. The specific capacitance of Li<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> was 535 mF cm<sup>-2</sup>, the energy destiny was 110.7 Wh kg<sup>-1</sup>. Compared with rasberry like nanosphere Li<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub>, the waxberry like nanoporous spinel Li<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12 </sub>shows the better electrochemical performance and the stability, furthermore, these performance parameters have been improved as before reported. All these results indicate that the waxberry like nanoporous spinel Li<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> could provide the potential application in high performance supercapacitor.
319	New insight into printable europium doped yttrium borate luminescent pigment for security ink application	Counterfeiting has turned out to be a major area of concern these days and is becoming a serious problem worldwide. Modern technological advances have made counterfeiting of the sophisticated products easy. Therefore, it is need of an hour to search some new luminescent materials to overcome this problem.&nbsp; Herein, we report a highly luminescent YBO<sub>3</sub>:Eu<sup>3+</sup>nanophosphor was synthesized by Sol-gel technique, which can be easily scaled up in large quantity. This highly luminescent boron based optically active, structurally and chemically stable YBO<sub>3</sub>: Eu<sup>3+</sup>nanophosphor with average particle size in the range from 100 to 120 nm provides strong orange-red emission at 591 nm upon 245 nm excitation wavelength and also excitable in range of 280-480 nm excitation wavelengths.
