The structural/microstructural and photoluminescence behaviour were characterized by scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy/high-resolution transmission electron microscopy and fluorescent spectroscopy, respectively. Further, this nanophosphor was used to design luminescent security ink with a commercially available polyvinyl chloride gold medium for printing of highly uniform security codes as investigated by PL mapping instruments.&nbsp; Thus, this facile method to synthesize a low-cost YBO<sub>3</sub>: Eu<sup>3+ </sup>nanophosphor based security ink offers a non-replicable security code for printing that can be easily printed but is difficult to counterfeit.
320	Effects of Electric Fields on Multiple Exciton Generation: An Ab Initio Study	Unique properties of lead chalcogenides have enabled multiple exciton generation (MEG) in their nanocrystals that can be beneficial in enhancing the efficiency of the third generation solar cells. Although the intrinsic electric field plays an imperative role in a solar cell, its effect on the multiple exciton generation (MEG) has been overlooked, so far. Using EOM-CCSD as a many-body approach, we show that any electric field can affect the absorptivity spectra of the lead chalcogenide nanocrystals (Pb<sub>4</sub>Te<sub>4</sub>, Pb<sub>4</sub>Se<sub>4</sub>, and Pb<sub>4</sub>S<sub>4</sub>). The same electric field, however, has insignificant effects on the MEG quantum probabilities and the thresholds in these nanocrystals. Furthermore, simulations show that Pb<sub>4</sub>Te<sub>4</sub>, among the aforementioned nanocrystals, has the lowest MEG threshold and the strongest absorptivity peak that is located in the multi-excitation window, irrespective of the field strength, making it the most suitable candidate for MEG applications. Simulations also demonstrate that an electric field affects the MEG characteristics in the Pb<sub>4</sub>Te<sub>4</sub> nanocrystal, in general, less than it perturbs MEG characteristics in Pb<sub>4</sub>Se<sub>4</sub> and Pb<sub>4</sub>S<sub>4</sub> nanocrystals. Our results can have a great impact in designing optoelectronic devices whose performance can be significantly influenced by MEG.
321	Practical aspects of line tensions	Two corrections to the intrinsic line tension by the curvature dependence of the liquid-vapor surface tension and by the contact angle dependence of the intrinsic line tension are qualitatively estimated.  First, we derive a generalized formula for the modified Young's equation with an apparent line tension from the thermodynamic free-energy minimization.  Next, the curvature dependence of the liquid-vapor surface tension is considered by using Tolman's formula.  Using the reported values of Tolman's length from the molecular dynamics simulations, the sign and the magnitude of the correction to the apparent line tension is semi-quantitatively estimated.  Then, the van der Waals line tension and its contact angle dependence for nanometer-scale droplet is considered.  The two corrections to the apparent van der Waals line tension are as small as nN, and leads to either a positive or a negative apparent line tension.   The gravitational line tension for millimeter-scale droplets is also considered by taking into account the gravitational potential.  The gravitational line tension is of the order of &#x03BC;N so that the correction from the curvature dependence of surface tension can be neglected.  Again, the contact angle dependence of the intrinsic line tension is so large that the apparent line tension becomes always negative even though the intrinsic line tension is always positive.
322	Flexible one-structure arched triboelectric nanogenerator based on common electrode for high efficiency energy harvesting and self-powered motion sensing	Triboelectric nanogenerators are widely concerned because of low cost, simple manufacturing process and high output performance. Here, we demonstrated a flexible one-structure arched triboelectric nanogenerator (FOAT) based on common electrode to combine the single-electrode mode and contact-separation mode by using silicone rubber, epoxy resin and flexible electrode. The peak-to-peak short circuit current of 18&#x00B5;A and the peak-to-peak open circuit voltage of 570V can be obtained from the FOAT with the size of 5*7 cm2 under the frequency of 3Hz and the pressure force of 300N. The peak-to-peak short circuit current of FOAT is increased by 29% and 80% and the peak-to-peak open circuit voltage is increased by 33% and 54% compared with single-electrode mode and contact-separation mode, respectively. FOAT realizes the combination of two generation modes, which improves the output performance of triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG). FOAT can completely light up 62 light-emitting-diodes (LEDs) and 2.2&#x00B5;F capacitor can be easily charged to 1.2V in 9s. When the FOAT is placed at different parts of the body, the human motion can be harvested and be the sensing signal for motion monitoring sensor. Based on the above characteristics, FOAT exhibits great potential in illumination, power supplies for wearable electronic devices and self-powered motion monitoring sensor by harvesting human motion energy.
323	DFT study of gold doped armchair graphene nanoribbons with vacancies	Systematic investigation of electronic, magnetic of vacancies-defected AGNRs and substitution by gold (Au) atoms are done in the framework of DFT. Remarkably, one vacancy- AGNR with a semiconductor behavior exhibits a high magnetic moment equal to 1.65 &#x03BC;B. Substitution of the missed carbon atom by Au one causes suggestive changes in the electronic spin and reduces magnetic moment to a value of 0.98 &#x03BC;B and still remains semiconductor. Divacancies (2V) and four vacancies (4V) AGNRs are nonmagnetics and semiconductors a with relatively large band gaps (0.40 and 0.62 eV). Substitutions with two and three gold atoms respectively leaves unchanged the behavior of the first structure and transform the last one to metallic like.
324	<strong>Ion Transport at Sub-Nanometer Interlayer Spacing in Thermally Modified Graphene Oxide Membranes</strong>	Graphene oxide (GO), an ionic and molecular sieve, is increasingly used to model ion transport channels in biological systems since its properties can be tuned by controlling the structure and dimensions of nano-capillaries between GO sheets. In the present work, ionic percolation at sub-nanometer interlayer spacing was examined for GO films in liquid phase intercalant, using electroimpedance spectroscopy, and response modelled using equivalent circuits. Interlayer spacing was tuned discretely by annealing GO at different temperatures. It was found that percolation resistance, <em>R<sub>P</sub></em>, decreases exponentially with interwall spacing. For GO annealed at T &ge; 180&deg;C, <em>R<sub>P</sub></em> exhibited an exponential decrease with time, suggesting a dynamic interwall spacing.&nbsp; It was demonstrated that <em>R<sub>P</sub></em> behaves similar to ion flux, reported by others. Further, these were found to have an empirical power law dependence. The present work allowed exploration of ion percolation at interlayer spacing down to 5.1 &Aring;, lower than those achieved experimentally so far.
325	Developing a coarse-grained DNA model with sequence specificity	DNA as one of the most significant biomacromolecules has shown great potentiality in many applications, e.g., used as novel materials in DNA origami technology, DNA molecular computing and genetic disease diagnostics. These applications are based on the competition of the nucleobase interactions of DNA chains which strongly depends on the sequence. In this work, we develop a novel coarse-grained (CG) DNA model in order to deeply understand the complex biophysical reactions of DNA. In our model, a nucleotide is mapped to one CG bead and the corresponding force field is extracted and optimized according to the experimental data in terms of the melting temperatures of DNA and the persistence lengths of DNA chain. Meanwhile, the force field of DNA model is rectified according to the bulk thermodynamic properties of DNA to eliminate the finite size effect in simulation. After parameter optimization, our coarse-grained model is able to reproduce the sequence characteristic of DNA and maximize the simulation efficiency. This model is then applied to investigate a toehold-mediated strand displacement system. The simulation is excellently agreed with the experimental data in term of the displacement rates associated with different toehold lengths, which firmly proves that such model can be potentially applied to study the thermodynamic and kinetic properties in a variety of DNA nanotechnologies.
326	Activation energy impact in von K&#x00E1;rm&#x00E1;n swirling flow due to a rotating disk	A new mathematical model is proposed to investigate the flow patterns with heat and mass characteristics of an electrically conducting Maxwell nanofluid over a rotating stretchable disk in the presence of an externally applied uniform magnetic field. Brownian motion and thermophoresis features are incorporated due to nanoparticles accounting Buongiorno model. The characteristics of non-linear thermal radiations on heat transfer mechanism are studied in view of Rosseland approximation model. The mass transfer analysis is inspected by employing the binary chemical reaction with activation energy. Similarity hypotheses is performed to facilitate the solution of governing momentum, energy and concentration equations. The transformed non-linear equations are attempted numerically by using bvp midrich scheme in Maple software for visualizing the influence of governing parameters graphically and numerically. The major outcomes of present analysis reveal that radiation parameter enhances the temperature of the fluid. Solute concentration is an increasing function of activation energy parameter. Moreover, the reaction rate diminishes the solute concentration.
327	<strong>Physisorption of oxygen in SnO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles for perovskite solar cells</strong>	Although SnO<sub>2 </sub>is widely used in perovskite solar cells (PSCs) as electron transport layer, there is still a need of detailed investigation regarding the impact of adsorption on the performance of PSCs. Here, we report the role of physical and chemical adsorption process on SnO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles thin film for the performance of planar heterojunction MAPbI<sub>3</sub>-based PSCs. Oxygen adsorption plays an important role on oxidation states and defective oxides related to the oxygen vacancies in the SnO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles thin films. The SnO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles thin film show higher oxidation state (Sn-O) and lower defective oxides (O-Sn-C) at an annealing temperature of 100 &deg;C due to physisorption, also higher efficiency (18.04 %) of planar heterojunction solar cell. Higher annealing temperature results in desorption of physically adsorbed oxygen species. Therefore, lowering down the annealing temperature of SnO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles thin films is a good strategy to control the oxidation states and oxygen vacancies related to the surface of thin films.
328	<strong>Superhard Q-carbon nanocomposites</strong>	We present a single-step strategy to fabricate adherent coatings of superhard and lubricating Q-carbon nanocomposites by laser melting and ultrafast quenching of amorphous carbon thin films, at ambient temperature and pressure in air. The Q-carbon nanocomposites consist of densely-packed <em>sp<sup>3</sup></em>-rich Q-carbon, and <em>sp<sup>2</sup></em>-rich <em>&alpha;</em>-carbon amorphous phases. Since this transformation is undercooling dependent, we control the undercooling by changing thermal conductivity <em>via</em> increasing <em>sp<sup>3</sup></em> content in as-deposited amorphous carbon films and stimulate ultrafast regrowth rate. The Q-carbon nanocomposites exhibit a hardness of 67 GPa (Young&rsquo;s modulus ~840 GPa), an increase of 220% over DLC, in contrast to the soft <em>&alpha;</em>-carbon (hardness ~18 GPa). The high hardness of Q-carbon nanocomposites results in 0.16 energy dispersion coefficient, in comparison with 0.74 for <em>&alpha;</em>-carbon. The soft <em>&alpha;</em>-carbon phase provides lubrication, resulting in low friction and wear coefficients of 0.09 and 1x10<sup>-6</sup>, respectively, against the diamond tip. The Q-carbon nanocomposites consisting of hard Q-carbon and soft<em> &alpha;</em>-carbon phases, with nanoscale dispersion, increases toughness of the film. This work provides insights into the characteristics of Q-carbon nanocomposites and advances carbon-based superhard materials for long lasting protective coatings and related applications.
329	Reducing stimulated emission threshold power density of AlGaN/AlN multiple quantum wells by nano-trench-patterned AlN template	272-nm deep-ultraviolet stimulated emission is demonstrated by optical pumping from AlGaN/AlN multiple quantum wells (MQWs) grown on nano-patterned AlN templates by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition upon sapphire substrates. Continuous low threading dislocation density (TDD) MQWs zones in parallel with the stimulated light emission direction above the epitaxy lateral overgrowth (ELOG) coalescent areas are obtained by aligning the nano-trench pattern perpendicular to Fabry-Perot cavity facets thus When light resonates through the continuous low TDD MQWs zones, it has higher optical gain and less non-radiative recombination than the case on the nano-net-patterned AlN template where the low TDD zones are discontinuous. Therefore, the threshold power density of 713 kW/cm<sup>2</sup> from the MQWs on the nano-trench-patterned AlN template is achieved, 11% lower than that on the nano-net-patterned AlN template. This result indicates that nano-trench-patterned templates can benefit the performance of AlGaN-based waveguide laser diodes.
330	The study of dynamical quasiparticle properties &nbsp;of undoped graphene nanoribbon	We have calculated the quasiparticle particle self-energy and spectral<br /> function in a undoped graphene nanoribbon when a symmetry breaking<br /> of the sublattice is occurred. Hubbard model Hamiltonian has been<br /> applied to describe the electron dynamics in the structure. Using<br /> the many body $G_{0}W$ approach and Green's function technique, we<br /> have found the dynamical quasiparticle properties of electrons on<br /> nanoribbon structure.<br /> &nbsp;Also random phase approximation has been exploited to calculate electronic self-energy of the<br /> system.<br /> &nbsp;Specially, the effects of gap parameter and Hubbard parameter on spectral function, inelastic<br /> scattering lifetime and band gap renormalization have been studied.<br /> Also the wave vector dependence of inelastic scattering lifetime for different values of gap parameter<br /> has been investigated.<br /> In order to find the quasiparticle excitation spectrum of the<br /> interacting electronic system, we have studied the frequency dependence of spectral function for<br /> different physical parameters
331	<strong>Nanotribological Properties of Bulk Metallic Glasses</strong>	Bulk metallic glasses (BMGs) exhibit unique mechanical properties; however, a detailed understanding of nanotribological properties of BMGs is still lacking. In this article, alloy composition, surface disorder, normal load, and velocity dependence of friction between a single asperity contact and the BMG surface is explored with two-dimensional Prandtl-Tomlinson (PT) model. Our numerical results reveal distinct regimes for load and velocity dependence of friction at small length scales. The friction is inert to alloy composition and surface roughness for small loads in wearless regime. Surface corrugation increases with the number of alloy elements and dominates the friction for normal loads that may lead wear. Calculations for the effect of sliding velocity on friction between a single-atom contact and different BMGs show that velocity dependence of friction is inert to alloy composition and surface structure for sliding velocities smaller than 1.3 &mu;m/s. Besides, the friction evolves non-monotonically with alloy composition and surface disorder for larger sliding velocities. Our analyses disclose that BMGs unveil two unique frictional properties at small length scales: (I) friction is inert to alloy composition and surface disorder in wearless friction regime, (II) velocity dependence of friction does not depend on composition and disorder for small sliding speeds. These results promote BMGs as ideal materials for applications that require high durability and low friction in quasi-dynamic operating conditions.
332	Point-projection microscopy of nano-localized photoemission currents at sub-40 femtosecond time scales	Femtosecond point-projection microscopy (fs-PPM) is an electron microscopy technique that possesses a combination of high spatio-temporal resolution and sensitivity to local electric fields. This allows it to visualize ultrafast charge carrier dynamics in complex nanomaterials. We benchmark the capability of the fs-PPM technique by imaging the ultrafast dynamics of charge carriers produced by multiphoton ionization of silver nanowires. The space-charge driven motion of photoelectrons is followed on sub-100 nm length scales, while the dynamics are captured on 30--100 fs time scales. The build-up of electron holes in the silver nanowires following photoelectron ejection, \ie positive charging, has also been observed. The fastest observed photoelectron temporal response is 33 fs (FWHM), which represents an upper estimate of the instrument response function and is consistent with an expected electron wavepacket duration of 13 fs based on simulations.
333	Optical nanofiber temperature monitoring via double heterodyne detection	Tapered optical fibers (nanofibers) whose diameters are smaller than the optical wavelength are very fragile and can be easily destroyed if excessively heated by energy dissipated from the transmitted light. We present a technique for monitoring the nanofiber temperature using two-stage heterodyne detection. The phase of the heterodyne output signal is determined by that of the transmitted optical field, which, in turn, depends on the temperature through the refractive index. From the phase data, by numerically solving the heat exchange equations, the temperature distribution along the nanofiber is determined. The technique is applied to the controlled heating of the nanofiber by a laser in order to remove rubidium atoms adsorbed on its surface that substantially degrade its transmission. Almost 90% of the nanofiber's original transmission is recovered.
334	Surface damage of silicon induced by combined millisecond and nanosecond laser with different delays	The laser-silicon interaction process was investigated with a new form of double pulse laser, which was called combined pulse laser (CPL). CPL includes a millisecond (ms) superposed by a nanosecond (ns) pulses. The surface damage morphology was investigated under a single ms laser and CPL irradiation. In comparison, the damage effect induced by CPL was more severe, and it can be divided into three kinds according to different delays. Further research was done on the melting depth and damage radius. It was found that the damage radius on the surface mainly depends on the energy density of incident ms laser, and the melting depth decreases with the increase of delay time. The more severe damage effect of CPL was ascribed to the pre-heating ms laser and the interaction of the follow-up ms laser with the surface damage formed by the ns laser.
335	Spin-relaxation anisotropy in a nanowire quantum dot with strong spin-orbit coupling	We study the impacts of the magnetic field direction on the spin dynamics in a one-dimensional quantum dot with strong spin-orbit coupling. The energy spectrum and the corresponding eigen-sfunctions in the quantum dot are obtained exactly. We find that no matter how large the spin-orbit coupling is, the electric-dipole spin transition rate as a function of the magnetic field direction alwaysshas a &#x03C0; periodicity. However, the phonon-induced spin relaxation rate as a function of the magnetic field direction has a &#x03C0; periodicity only in the weak spin-orbit coupling regime and a 2&#x03C0; periodicitysin the strong spin-orbit coupling regime.
336	Molecular dynamics simulation of resonant frequency of graphene nanoribbons	The resonant frequency of the graphene nanoribbon is studied by the molecular dynamics simulation method, which is modulated the dynamic process of vibration after deformation by silicon probe. A series of simulations for the resonant frequency of graphene nanoribbons have been performed. Then the simulation results of resonant frequency are analyzed, which are varied with the length, width, thickness and temperature of graphene nanoribbons. The resonant frequency of graphene nanoribbons is depended on size. The width, thickness and temperature have less influence on the resonant frequency of graphene nanoribbons, and the scale of the length is the main influence.
337	Test bed for contact-mode triboelectric nanogenerator	The triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) has become one of the strongest candidates for sustainable power sources. The power of a TENG depends on factors such as contact area, contact parallelism, contact force, and contact speed. In order to evaluate the  performance of the TENG precisely and quantitatively, it is necessary to apply consistent experimental conditions and measurement processes. In this paper, we propose a test bed capable of adjusting the contact area and contact parallelism, and measuring the contact force, contact speed, current, and voltage in real time. The test bed consists of a 2-axis planar stage, a 2-axis tilting stage, a 1-axis vertical stage, a 3-degree-of-freedom (DOF) force/torque sensor, a capacitive displacement sensor, and a voice coil actuator. The 3-DOF force/torque sensor can provide feedback on the degree of parallelism and contact area alignment as well as contact force. With the proposed test bed, the effects of parallelism error, contact area, contact force, and contact speed on the performance of contact-mode TENGs are quantitatively analyzed. This test bed is expected to be used for the quantitative analysis of contact-mode TENGs with various new structures and for comparison among different devices.
338	<strong>Integrating semiconducting co-catalyst of ReS<sub>2</sub> nanosheets into p-silicon photocathodes toward enhanced solar water reduction</strong>	A heterojunction photocathode of p-Si/ReS<sub>2</sub> was fabricated through uniform growth of vertically standing ReS<sub>2</sub> nanosheets (NSs) on planar p-Si substrate for solar-driven hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). The grafted ReS<sub>2</sub> NSs not only serve as a high-activity HER catalyst but also render a suitable electronic band&nbsp;coupled with p-Si into a &#x2161;-type heterojunction, which facilitates the photo-induced charge separation and utilization. This device achieves a 23-fold-increased photocurrent density at 0 V<sub>RHE</sub> and a 35-fold-enhanced photoconversion ef&#xFB01;ciency compared to pure p-Si counterpart. The multi effects of ReS<sub>2</sub> incorporation in improving light harvesting, photo-generated charge separation and catalytic activity are demonstrated to be responsible for the enhanced PEC performance, suggesting the multifunction of semiconducting co-catalysts integrated into solar water splitting devices.
339	Novel focusing properties of high-numerical-aperture micro-Fresnel zone plates	Focusing properties of high-numerical-aperture micro-Fresnel zone plates (&mu;FZP) have been explored at the wavelength from deep ultraviolet to visible. Numerical calculations are based on vectorial angular spectrum theory. It is found that the axial spot size evaluated by full-width-at-half-maximum is in direct proportion to the inverse of the total annulus number. Linear focal shift phenomenon can be observed due to the wavelength dispersion over a range of tens of nanometers. With the illumination wavelength increasing, the focus is negatively shifting and the peak intensity is first increasing and then decreasing. Meanwhile, the axial focal spot is shrinking while it is broadening along the transverse focal plane. A new method has been demonstrated to probe either multi-focus or a light needle based on high-NA FZPs. The results have been rigorously validated by the three-dimensional finite-difference time-domain method. This study has changed and expanded the basic understandings of the widely-used FZPs.
340	<strong>Two photon induced amplified spontaneous emission at low threshold from Styryl 7 dye incorporated DNA template</strong>	Studies on biophysical interactions between DNA-surfactant complexes and dye molecules are necessary to fully exploit its potential in optoelectronic devices. In this work iinvestigations on nonlinear optical absorption of Styryl 7 dye (LDS 750) incorporating DNA-CTMA (deoxyribonucleic acid blended with cationic surfactant molecule, cetyltrimethyl-ammonium chloride) and PMMA (Poly methyl methacrylate) using Z-scan technique is reported. The sample exhibits reverse saturable absorption with DNA -CTMA complex but with PMMA the sample behaves as a saturable absorber. Amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) from Styryl 7 dye with DNA- CTMA and PMMA were also studied. We observed ASE at low pump energy for Styryl 7&ndash;DNA-CTMA film, when excited with a pulsed nanosecond Nd: YAG laser (&lambda;=532nm) whereas ASE was not observed from dye incorporated with PMMA even with high pump energy. ASE characteristics were studied as a function of excitation energy density for the evaluation of threshold energy and exponential gain coefficient. The enhanced fluorescence and low threshold for ASE make Styryl 7 dye - DNA template a promising candidate for novel optoelectronic applications.
341	<strong>Determining the confined optical length of high index vertical Si nanoforest arrays for photonic applications</strong>	We report on the structural and the optical properties of Si nanowires fabricated by a facile electroless etching technique by varying the optical length (H) of nanowire. The theoretical calculation for exponential sine (ES) profile at constant &lambda;=600 nm shows a better explanation in terms of gradient index with optical length for a vertical nanowires. All the prior observations signify the possibility of strong light trapping due to an exponential gradient towards the high index into the nanowires and the existence of highly dense subwavelength features. The optical admittance (&#x01B5;) shows a strong impact on optical distance (Z) for Z&lt;H, owing to the EM wave interaction with the nanowires that perceive a different &#x01B5; at the oblique angle of incidence (AOI). In addition, the experimental reflectance data and theoretical model for <em>TE </em>and <em>TM</em> modes predict that a minimum optical length of 5 &micro;m can give a very low reflectance value. This indicates that the Si nanowires is polarization insensitive at oblique incidence over a wide AOI (0&ordm;-80&ordm;). Moreover, Raman spectra showed a very strong light confinement effect in the first order transverse optical band with increasing the etching depths. The morphological dependent resonance (MDR) theory for SiNWs describes a strong localized light field confinement for lower wavelength regime up to 600 nm and its effect on the strong resonant absorption modes was further correlated by using COMSOL simulation. The present results should benefit to harness the maximum absorption confined within the nanowires for various photonic application.
342	<strong>Thermoelectric characterization</strong><strong> of nickel-nanowires and nanoparticles embedded in silica aerogels</strong>	Embedded nickel nanowires (NiNWs) and nickel nanoparticles (NiNPs) in silica aerogels at three different concentrations are characterized and considered as potential thermoelectric materials. The embedded NiNWs samples exhibit a 9 orders of magnitude improvement in thermoelectric figure of merit while the embedded NiNPs samples show a 6 orders of magnitude improvement when the concentration of the NiNWs and NiNPs are increased from 0 to 700 ppm. The electrical properties are assessed using four-point probe techniques and thermal conductivity is measured using scanning thermal microscopy (SThM) and compared with HotDisk measurements. The electrical resistivity is highly sensitive to the concentration of NiNWs and NiNPs in the silica aerogel, while the thermal conductivity remains largely unchanged. The sample resistivity is shown to follow a percolation scaling law of the form &nbsp;with critical weight fraction &nbsp;to form a conductive network of approximately at 0.04-0.6 Wt% and 0.08-0.1 Wt% for embedded NiNWs and NiNPs respectively. The results suggest that optimizing the concentration of NiNWs could yield promising thermoelectric properties. The measurement techniques were also used to investigate the uniformity of the aerogels, which was not degraded by the incorporation of fillers.
343	<strong>The temperature dependence of saturation magnetization for yttrium iron garnet doped with Zn, Ni and Co</strong>	The empirical extended Bloch&acute;s law about the saturation magnetization behavior as a function of temperature was used for study nanoparticles of yttrium iron garnet doped with zinc, nickel and cobalt. The exponent values obtained from the fitting vary from 1.42 to 9.68, and are different from the expected values; 9/2, 2, 3/2, 3 and 5/2. The discrepancy was associated to the existence of defects and moments with frustrated exchange interaction due to the nanoparticles size and thermal treatment. Other adjustment attempt was performed including a linear term taking into account the nanometric size of the particles, showing great discrepancy with the experimental results. The results are attributed to the atomic disorder and some possible magnetic frustrations.
344	Comment on "Excellent field emission properties of VO2(A) nanogap emitters in air"	Recently, Liu \textit{et al.} \cite{Liu2018} reported interesting field emission properties of metal VO$_{2}$(A) nanowires with a small gap distance ($d_{g} \sim 10$ nm) to the collector, in air environment. The authors claimed that the field emission properties of VO$_{2}$(A) nanowires were shown to be enhanced with an increase in ambient temperature due to a decrease in the work function. The latter was extracted from experimental current-voltage characteristics, by using their Eq.(1), derived from elementary Fowler-Nordheim (FN) theory. However, the criticisms presented in this comment show that this conclusion is fully questionable. This is mainly due to the following inconsistencies presented in Ref.\cite{Liu2018}: (i) the use of the elementary FN theory in situations where such theory is not expected to be valid and (ii) an unreasonable approach used for a local gap field enhancement factor estimation, in the limit of small gap distance. The inconsistencies (i) and (ii) make the work function values reported for VO$_{2}$(A) nanowires, as well as its functional dependence with the ambient temperature, misleading.
345	Model of ballistic-diffusive thermal transport in HAMR media	A 1D finite element model of nanoscale heat transfer is developed that considers the grain size and temperature dependence of the thermal conductivity and specific heat of the FePt recording layer during heat assisted recording. Ballistic effects on the thermal conductivity are included assuming diffuse scattering at interfaces and grain boundaries. The magnon contribution to the specific heat during laser heating close to the Curie temperature is determined using the finite size scaling theory. Local variations in temperature are shown to arise as a result of the dispersion in FePt grain size&sigma;. The model predicts an inhomogeneous temperature distribution within a single FePt grain that is significant for smaller in-plane grain size.
346	Effective quality factor tuning mechanisms in micromechanical resonators	Quality factor (Q) is an important property of the micro- and nano-electromechanical (MEM/NEM) resonators that underlie timing references, atomic force microscopes, and all other resonant sensors. There are many ways to tune the effective quality factor of MEM/NEM resonators, including external velocity-proportional feedback, parametric amplification, optomechanical back-action, thermal-piezoresistive pumping, and mechanical modal coupling. We review these mechanisms, and demonstrate their equivalence by representing each effective Q tuning technique by a position-proportional and a velocity-proportional force expression. We clarify the relationship between the mechanical Q, the effective Q, and the thermal noise of a resonator, and experimentally show that parametric amplification and thermal-piezoresistive pumping enhance the effective Q, not the mechanical Q, by studying the thermomechanical fluctuations of a micromechanical resonator subjected to these techniques. This paper also reports the first experimental demonstration of the phase slope tuning of a mechanical resonator subjected to parametric amplification.
347	Bias Temperature Instability Model Using Dynamic Defect Potential for Predicting CMOS Aging	This paper describes a new approach for modeling bias-temperature instability (BTI) in nanoscale transistors. The model uses non-iterative surface potential solvers enhanced with dynamic defect potential equations to enable accurate, physics-based circuit level simulations that incorporate BTI effects. Defect maps constructed from experimental data reported on high-k-metal-gate bulk complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) devices are used to parameterize the defect potential equation. By implementing the enhanced surface potential model in Verilog-A, both DC and AC BTI aging effects in combinational circuits are simulated and the results compared conventional threshold voltage shift methods for BTI modeling.
348	<strong>Microstructural, magnetic </strong><strong>and optical </strong><strong>p</strong><strong>roperties of Pr-doped p</strong>e<strong>rovskite manganite La<sub>0.67</sub>Ca<sub>0.33</sub>MnO<sub>3 </sub>nanoparticles</strong><strong> synthesized</strong><strong> <em>via</em> sol - gel process</strong>	We report microstructural, magnetic and optical properties of Pr-doped perovskite manganite (La<sub>1-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>)<sub>0.67</sub>Ca<sub>0.33</sub>MnO<sub>3 </sub>(LPCMO: x = 0.0 - 0.5) nanoparticles synthesized <em>via </em>sol - gel process. Structural characterizations (X-ray and electron diffraction patterns, (high-resolution) TEM images) provide information regarding the phase formation and the single-crystalline nature of the LPCMO systems. X-ray and electron diffraction patterns reveal that all the LPCMO samples crystallize in perovskite crystallography with an orthorhombic structure (<em>Pnma</em> space group), where the MnO<sub>6</sub> octahedron elongated along the <em>b</em> axis due to the Jahn - Teller effect is confirmed by Raman spectra. Crystallite sizes and grain sizes were calculated from XRD and TEM respectively, and the lattice fringes resolved in the high-resolution TEM images of individual LPCMO nanoparticle confirmed its single-crystalline nature. FTIR spectra identify the characteristic Mn-O bond stretching vibration mode near 600 cm<sup>-1</sup>, which shifts towards high wavenumbers with increasing post-annealing temperature or Pr-doped concentration, resulting in further distortion of the MnO<sub>6</sub> octahedron. XPS revealed dual oxidation states of Mn<sup>3+</sup> and Mn<sup>4+</sup> in the LPCMO nanoparticles. UV-Vis absorption spectra confirm the semiconducting nature of the LPCMO nanoparticles with optical bandgaps of 2.55 eV - 2.71 eV. Magnetic measurements as a function of temperature and magnetic field at field cooling (FC) and zero-field cooling (ZFC) modes, provided a Curie temperature around 230 K, saturation magnetization of about 81 emu/g and coercive field of 390 Oe at 10 K. Such magnetic properties and the semiconducting nature of the LPCMO nanoparticles will make them as suitable candidate for magnetic semiconductor spintronics.
349	Silica nano-particles annealing treatment and its effect on chemical mechanical polishing	SiO2 spherical nano-particles are annealed with different temperature. The structural and morphological evolution of silica nano-particles induced by heat treatment are monitored by scanning electron microscopy(SEM), X-Ray diffraction(XRD), Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrum(FTIR) and differential thermal and thermal gravimetric analysis, which disclose the external and internal structure of silica abrasive. The mechanical hardness of silica is measured by nano-indentation technique, which shows the hardness increases as the annealed temperature raising. Silica nanoparticles after annealing are applied as abrasives in chemical mechanical polishing for silicon wafers, showing that material removal rate is improved with the annealed temperature, whereas the surface roughness remains low level as the annealing temperature below 600{degree sign}C.
350	Impact of Hall Current and Nonlinear Thermal Radiation on Jeffrey Nanofluid Flow In The Rotating Frame with Porous Medium	This research article deal with the nonlinear thermally radiated influences on non-Newtonian nanofluid considering (Jeffrey fluid) in a rotating system. The effect of Hall current on the nanofluid is taken into the account. The flow of nanofluid is steady and the medium is a porous. The upper plate is considered fixed and the lower plate kept stretched. The governing equations of the nanofluid  have been transformed to a set of differential nonlinear and coupled equations, using suitable similarity variables and other assumptions. The optimal approach is used to get the solution of the high ordered modeled problems. The convergence of the method has been shown numerically. The variation of the Skin friction, Nusslet number, Sherwood number and their impacts on the velocity distribution, temperature distribution and concentration distribution have been examined. The influence of the Hall effect, rotation, Brownian motion, porosity and thermophoresis analysis have mainly focused in this investigation. Moreover, for comprehension the physical presentation of the embedded parameters, like Deborah number , viscosity parameter  , rotation parameter , Brownian motion parameter , porosity parameter , magnetic parameter , Prandtl number , thermophoretic parameter , and Schmidt number  have been  plotted and deliberated graphically.
351	<strong>Thermoelectric characterization</strong><strong> of nickel-nanowires and nanoparticles embedded in silica aerogels</strong>	Embedded nickel nanowires (NiNWs) and nickel nanoparticles (NiNPs) in silica aerogels at three different concentrations are characterized and considered as potential thermoelectric materials. The embedded NiNWs samples exhibit a 9 orders of magnitude improvement in thermoelectric figure of merit while the embedded NiNPs samples show a 6 orders of magnitude improvement when the concentration of the NiNWs and NiNPs are increased from 0 to 700 ppm. The electrical properties are assessed using four-point probe techniques and thermal conductivity is measured using scanning thermal microscopy (SThM) and compared with HotDisk measurements. The electrical resistivity is highly sensitive to the concentration of NiNWs and NiNPs in the silica aerogel, while the thermal conductivity remains largely unchanged. The sample resistivity is shown to follow a percolation scaling law of the form &nbsp;with critical weight fraction &nbsp;to form a conductive network of approximately at 0.04-0.6 Wt% and 0.08-0.1 Wt% for embedded NiNWs and NiNPs respectively. The results suggest that optimizing the concentration of NiNWs could yield promising thermoelectric properties. The measurement techniques were also used to investigate the uniformity of the aerogels, which was not degraded by the incorporation of fillers.
352	Highly Stable Silica-coated Manganese Ferrite Nanoparticles as High-efficacy T2 Contrast Agents for Magnetic Resonance Imaging	Highly stable silica-coated manganese ferrite nanoparticles were fabricated for application as magnetic resonance imagining (MRI) contrast agents. The manganese ferrite nanoparticles were synthesized using a hydrothermal technique and coated with silica. The particle size was investigated using transmission electron microscopy and was found to be 40-60 nm. The presence of the silica coating on the particle surface was confirmed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. The crystalline structure was investigated by X-ray diffraction, and the particles were revealed to have an inverse spinel structure. Superparamagnetism was confirmed by the magnetic hysteresis curves obtained using a vibrating sample magnetometer. The efficiency of the MRI contrast agents was investigated by using aqueous solutions of the particles in a 4.7 T MRI scanner. The T1 and T2 relaxivities of the particles were 1.42 and 60.65 s-1 mM-1, respectively, in water. The ratio r2/r1 was 48.91, confirming that the silica-coated manganese ferrite nanoparticles were suitable high-efficacy T2 contrast agents.
353	Experimental evaluation of gold nanoparticles as infrared scatterers for advanced cardiovascular optical imaging	The tremendous impact that cardiovascular diseases have in modern society is motivating the research of novel imaging techniques that would make possible early diagnosis and, therefore, efficient treatments. Cardiovascular optical coherence tomography (CV-OCT) emerges as result of such demand has already being used at the clinical level. Full exploit of CV-OCT requires the development of novel contrast molecular agents characterized by a large scattering efficiency in the infrared (800-1400 nm). Gold nanoparticles (GNPs) seem to be the best candidates but their scattering properties in the infrared are hardly known and in most of the cases, these are extracted from numerical simulations. This knowledge gap is here covered by providing an experimental evaluation of the infrared scattering properties of different GNPs (nanoshells, nanostars and nanorods) by a unique combination of techniques (thermal loading experiments, infrared optical coherence tomography, infrared dark field microscopy and optoacoustic spectroscopy). This work determines experimentally the influence of the geometry on the spectral response of the scattering efficiency of GNPs and evidences the existence of remarkable discrepancies between experimental data and numerical simulations.
354	<strong>Carbon Nanotube Polarization Modulation at Far Infrared Range by Thermo-activated Phonon Absorption</strong>	We demonstrate a far infrared polarizer made with super-aligned carbon nanotube based on thermo-activated phonon absorption. It is found that the transmission modulation depth increases with temperature in the range of 100-600 cm<sup>&minus;1</sup>. The modulation depth can reach 1.5 dB by 0.5 V heating for per 1 mm sample width. The modulation is attributed to the thermo-activated phonon absorption of carbon nanotube. The degree of polarization is increased to 80% at 641 K from 40% at RT. It is shown that the degree of polarization can be improved and modulated by heating. The commercialization prospects will be attractive in the future due to the facile fabrication and tunable property.
355	Fundamentals of the nanowire solar cell. Optimization of the open circuit voltage	Present day nanowire solar cells have reached an efficiency of 17.8%. It is the main purpose of this review to highlight recent progress in nanophotonic engineering to further enhance the open circuit voltage (Voc) of a nanowire solar cell. It will be shown that the light extraction efficiency is a major design criterium for enhancing the external radiative efficiency and thus the Voc. Since the semiconductor substrate is a sink for internally generated photoluminescence, it is equally important to eliminate the loss of emitted light into the substrate. The radiative limit for the Voc, which corresponds to one of the necessary conditions in the Shockley Queisser (S-Q) limit, is reached when the external radiative efficiency at the front side of the cell equals unity. Even at the S-Q limit, the Voc is still substantially decreased by a photon entropy loss due to the conversion of a parallel beam of photons from the sun into a randomized emission pattern, in which each individual photon is emitted into a random direction. The 46.7% ultimate solar cell limit for direct solar irradiation can only be approached, once the cell is capable to focus all emitted photoluminescence back to the sun. We expect that nanophotonic engineering will provide a pathway to approach this limit. Nanophotonic engineering also allows to combine a high Voc with a large short-circuit current (Isc) by using tapered nanowires and forward Mie scattering for efficient absorption of the solar light into the nanowires. A prerequisite for this approach is a nanowire array with a high internal photoluminescence efficiency and thus a long minority carrier lifetime. Recent progress on radiative emission lifetime in nanowire arrays is finally reviewed. We conclude with the economics of nanowire solar cells.
356	Investigations on the plasma enabled growth of vertical graphene sheets on CNT surface	A theoretical model is developed to study the nucleation and growth kinetics of vertical graphene (VG) sheet on the carbon nanotubes (CNT) surfacein a reactive low temperature plasma environment. The model considers the plasma sheath formalization in one-dimension along with the kinetics of all the plasma species, charging of the graphene sheet, and growth of VG sheet on the CNT surface owing todefects generation and various processes on the CNT surface. Using the model, we demonstrated that variations in the plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD)process control parameters, such as the total gas pressure, input power, and substrate bias can be used for significant variation in the plasma composition and characteristics that in turn control the ion bombardment and carbon species generation on the CNT surface, and consequently tune the VG sheet dimensions (i.e., height and thickness) and their number density profiles on the CNT surface. It is found that as the total gas pressure is lowered and the input power and substrate bias are enhanced, the number densities and height of the VG sheet on the CNT surface are increased; however, the thickness of the VG sheet is reduced.Some of our theoretical results are in good agreement with the existing experimental observations.
357	<strong>Nonlinear plasmonic behavior of nanohole arrays in thin gold films for imaging of lipids</strong>	We demonstrate linear and nonlinear plasmonic behavior of periodic nanohole arrays in thin gold (Au) films with varying periodicity. The linear optical transmission spectra of the nanohole arrays show a red-shift of the resonance wavelength and the Wood&rsquo;s anomaly with increasing hole spacing. The optical transmission and electric near-field intensity distribution of the nanohole arrays were simulated using the finite element method (FEM). The nonlinear plasmonic behavior of the nanohole arrays was studied by using picosecond pulsed excitation at near infrared wavelengths. The characteristic nonlinear signals indicating two-photon excited luminescence (TPEL), sum frequency generation (SFG), second harmonic generation (SHG) and four-wave mixing (FWM) were observed. The maximum FWM/TPEL signal intensity ratio for the nanohole arrays with periodicity of 500 nm was achieved. Furthermore, we have demonstrated the ability of surface-enhanced coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (SECARS) to visualize low concentration of lipids deposited on the nanohole array having a periodicity of 500 nm.
358	<strong>A novel constitutive model for the mechanical properties of silica aerogels</strong>	Most studies on the mechanical properties of silica aerogels neglected the influence of structural randomness and the dead-ends of nano-porous materials, whereas both of them have a considerable effect on the mechanical properties of silica aerogels. In this study, we propose a cubic frame model with random orientation as the representative volume element (RVE) of silica aerogel to investigate the dead-ends&rsquo; effect on its mechanical properties. To characterize the structural randomness in the open-cell porous materials, a new constitutive model is established by a statistically average of the mechanical response of the random structure. This constitutive model reveals the inherent isotropy of open-cell porous materials. It also indicates the widely-used Gibson-Ashby model may overestimate the Young&rsquo;s modulus and shear modulus for open-cell porous materials. Then the mass ratio of dead-ends and effective skeleton are derived using available experimental results. It shows that the mass ratio of dead-ends increases with the decreasing density of silica aerogels because of the more space resulted from slimmer effective skeleton, which results in the abnormal exponent of the Young&rsquo;s modulus-density power-law relation. We suggest the mass ratio of the effective skeleton to be an intuitive and practical index to reflect the connectivity in silica aerogels. Besides, the dead-ends can significantly enhance the compressive strength of silica aerogels, especially for low-density silica aerogels. We hope this work can provide a new idea to consider the structural randomness in porous materials and give guidance on the mechanical reinforcement of aerogels.
359	A high-voltage subnanosecond sharpener based on a combination of "open" and capillary discharges	The switching features of a new gas-discharge sharpener consisting of a series connection of open and capillary discharges in one device have been studied. Subnanosecond times of its transition into high conductivity mode have been obtained in helium, neon, and argon in a wide range of conditions at a voltage pulse compression degree of ~ 10<sup>3</sup>. The average power of ~ 10 kW has been achieved in the pulse train mode at a voltage of 20 kV and a pulse repetition rate of 44 kHz. The conditions under which the switching time can be 100 ps have been determined.
360	Synthesis and characterization of nickel doped Barium niobate Ba(Ni<sub>0.5</sub>Nb<sub>0.5</sub>)O<sub>3</sub> (BNN) nanomaterial	Ferroelectric materials are of great interest for researchers worldwide, because of their unique physical properties and wide range of applications. The composite nanomaterial Ba(NiNb)<sub>0.5</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>[BNN] was synthesized by conventional solid state reaction method. The structural characterization was done by x- ray diffraction (XRD). The research was carried out to investigate structural properties of BNN nanomaterial as a function of sintering duration. BNN is sintered at 1000<sup>0</sup>C and different samples are prepared by varying duration of heat treatment. It is found that there is no major difference in structural properties of BNN when heated up to 12 hours, but there is a sudden change in structural properties when material is sintered for 18 hours.&nbsp; Average grain size calculated is 50.49 nm and lattice parameter 4.1281 A<sup>0</sup> with cubic crystal structure.
361	<strong>An <em>in silico</em> Inter-subject Variability Study of Extra-thoracic Morphology Effects on Inhaled Particle Transport and Deposition</strong>	An understanding of human inter-subject variability is crucial for the implementation of personalized pulmonary drug delivery as well as exposure assessment of airborne hazardous materials. However, due to the lack of statistically robust data and subsequent comparisons, the influence of human respiratory morphology on inhaled nano-/micro-particle transport and deposition is still not fully known. Thus, focusing on identifying geometric parameters that significantly influence airflow and inhaled particle transport/deposition, an experimentally validated Computational Fluid-Particle Dynamics (CFPD) model based on the Euler-Lagrange method is developed. To enhance the statistical robustness of the investigation, a virtual population group is created that contains seven distinct and widely used human upper-airway configurations, where the same tracheobronchial trees are extended to Generation 6 (G6). Numerical results and the inter-subject variability analysis indicate that the glottis constriction is the morphological parameter that significantly impacts the inhaled particle dynamics in the respiratory tract. Anatomical features of the upper airways should be maintained to capture the <em>personalized</em> airflow and particle transport dynamics for particles smaller than 500 nm or larger than 2 &micro;m. However, a single upper airway model, representing a basic subpopulation group, can be employed to evaluate the <em>total</em> deposition of particles in the diameter range of 500 nm &lt;d<sub>p</sub>&lt; 2 &micro;m. The present study provides an <em>in silico</em> lung-aerosol dynamics framework with detailed particle-deposition results and new physical insight. It may serve as a guide for implementing optimal targeting of inhaled drug-aerosols as well as for the assessment of hazardous aerosol exposure in distinct populations.
362	Growth of well-oriented InN nanodots by magnetron sputtering with varying sputtering temperature	I nN nanodots were deposited on sapphire substrates by radio-frequency (rf) magnetron sputtering under different sputtering temperature. The structure and morphology results revealed that the as grown InN samples showed a well oriented nanodots morphology with a wurtzite crystallographic structure under c-axis preferred growth orientation. The XPS results indicated that the In atoms existed only as combined InN not In2O3 and the atomic ratio of In/N was approximately 1:1.06. Moreover, the optical absorption measurement exhibited that the energy band-gap of InN nanodots were around 1.68-2.01 eV. And the electrical properties of the InN nanodots were also discussed by Hall effect in detail.
363	Enhancement of optical emission and ion currents in a laser produced silicon plasma by Femtosecond Laser-Induced Periodic Surface Structuring (fs-LIPSS)	<em>Laser-induced</em><em> periodic surface structuring (LIPSS) is a powerful technique for modifying the surface properties of solids. Using ultrashort pulses from a Ti:Sapphire laser (800 nm, 100 fs) we have fabricated nanoscale order LIPSS patterns</em> <em>on a silicon (100) surface. The patterns are found to be strongly dependent on the laser pulse energy, state of polarization, number of shots delivered on the target, and the ambient pressure. The role of laser wavelength is studied by using the second harmonic output (400 nm) also for fabrication. Large area (5x4 mm<sup>2</sup>) surface structuring has been carried out at atmospheric pressure after optimizing the laser parameters at 800 nm. The patterned silicon surface shows a substantial reduction in the reflection of incident light over a wide range of wavelengths, in comparison to plain silicon. Moreover, when used for laser induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) experiments, enhanced optical emission and ion current have been observed from the patterned surface. This indicates that coupling of laser energy to the surface is enhanced in the case of patterned silicon. While spectral lines emitted by doubly ionized silicon have been observed from the patterned surface, the plain surface gives lines from singly ionized silicon only.</em> <em>A discernible enhancement has been measured in both optical (50-90%) and electrical (34%) signals from the plasma generated on the patterned surface. These results confirm that LIPSS is a versatile method for enhancing the coupling of laser energy on to irradiated solid surfaces.</em>
364	Polyacrylates in the Presence of an Extraordinary Monovalent Cation - Solution Behavior and Metal Nanoparticle Formation	Sodium polyacrylate (NaPA) in dilute aqueous solution at an ionic strength of [NaNO3] = 0.01 M establishes a rich phase behaviour in the presence of low amounts of silver cations, which were introduced at a few millimoles or less by replacing the corresponding amount of Na+ cations. Beyond an extremely low level of Ag+ cations, anionic PA chains aggregate. By increasing the concentration of Ag+, the aggregates become denser and keep on growing without limit. Once a certain range of [Ag+] is reached, the instantaneously formed dense aggregates remain stable. Irradiation of the PA aggregate solutions with UV-light induces formation of silver nanoparticles (Ag-Np). Based on a combination of UV-vis spectroscopy, light scattering, transmission electron microscopy and small angle neutron scattering, the mechanism of this NaPA assisted formation of Ag-Np is studied. One focus of the study is lying on the effect of the two different solution states of dense aggregates, corresponding to the unstable, growing AgPA aggregates and to the stable AgPA aggregates and another focus is aiming at a characterisation of the morphology of the generated hybrid particles composed of Ag-Np and hosting PA chains.
365	<strong>Self-Powered GaN Nanostructured Ultraviolet Photodetector with rapid Reversibility</strong>	We report the fabrication of self-powered GaN nanostructures based ultraviolet photodetector on Si (111) substrate. Non-homogeneous nanoislands were perceived on Si surface with an average spatial distribution of 50 nm and thickness of 30 nm. The performance parameters such as photosensitivity, detectivity, photo responsivity, low noise equivalent power of fabricated GaN ultraviolet photodetector under self-powered mode are ~10<sup>2</sup>, ~10<sup>9 </sup>Jones, 1.78 mA/W and 8.8&times;10<sup>-11</sup> WHz<sup>-1</sup>, respectively. The transient photo-response measurement revealed a rapid rise and decay time constants of ~18 ms and ~27 ms, respectively. The GaN photodetector displayed significant enhancement in photocurrent and detectivity with increasing power (1 mW to 13 mW). These self-powered characteristics of the GaN ultraviolet photodetector are attributed to inhomogeneous contact area. The nanostructured self-powered GaN photodetector paves way towards Energy efficient optoelectronic device applications.
366	<strong>Thermoelectric Power Factor Enhancement of Ge<sub>2</sub>Sb<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>5</sub> Thin Films by Pulsed Plasma Engineering</strong>	Precise control over microstructure and composition is desired prerequisite for the performance enhancement of thermoelectric materials. In conventional magnetron plasma sputtering synthesis, composition control is challenging when the sputtering-target is composed by different elements. Here, the potential of pulsed power utilization is demonstrated for compositional control of Ge<sub>2</sub>Sb<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>5</sub> thin films <em>via</em> pulse -reversal time and -frequency engineering in pulsed DC-magnetron sputtering process. Amorphous thin films (of 200 nm thickness), deposited on glass substrate, crystallized in to face centered cubic phase with average nanocrystallite size ~10 nm, when annealed at 400 <sup>o</sup>C for 1 h in vacuum conditions. Power density enhancement to 5.56 W/cm<sup>2</sup> at low pulse reversal time induced maximum process throughput as 450 nm/min. Increase in either of pulse frequency or pulse reversal time decreased the discharge voltage and plasma density. As a consequence, kinetic energy of ions and ionization of plasma species are sequentially controlled in order to improve the stoichiometry of film and eventually; the electronic transport. The optimization of pulse plasma engineering yields maximum thermoelectric power factor value as 1.35 &times; 10<sup>&minus;4</sup> Wm<sup>&minus;1</sup>K<sup>&minus;2</sup> with process throughput more than 300 nm/min. The obtained values are promising for applications in the automobile and microelectronics industry.
367	Two fold characteristics of Swift Heavy Ion irradiation on Co3O4/RGO nanocomposites	This work presents the dual role exhibited by swift heavy ion irradiation (SHI) on Co3O4 / RGO nanocomposites.  SHI becomes successful in delinking the attached functional groups from RGO thus driving towards its purification. Raman spectra   confirm this result, where, an exponential decrease of the intensity ratio of D and G peaks of RGO with fluence occurs. Simultaneously, SHI generates extended defects or latent tracks in Co3O4 nanoparticles, decorated in RGO nanosheets, thus modifying its magnetic and surface electronic properties. Results obtained from magnetization studies using SQUID magnetometer and surface electronic response from scanning Kelvin probe support the fact.
368	Radiofrequency generation by coherently moving fluxons	A lattice of Abrikosov vortices in type II superconductors is characterized by a periodic modulation of the magnetic induction perpendicular to the applied magnetic field. For a coherent vortex motion under the action of a transport current, the magnetic induction at a given point of the sample varies in time with a washboard frequency <em>f</em><sub>WB</sub>&nbsp;= <em>v</em>/<em>d</em>, where <em>v</em> is the vortex velocity and <em>d</em> is the distance between the vortices in the direction of motion. Here, by using a spectrum analyzer connected to a 50 nm-wide Au nanowire meander near the surface of a superconducting Nb film we detect an ac voltage induced by coherently moving fluxons. The voltage is peaked at the washboard frequency, <em>f</em><sub>WB</sub>, and its subharmonics, <em>f</em><sub>TOF</sub> =&nbsp; <em>f</em><sub>WB</sub>/5, determined by the antenna width. By sweeping the dc current value, we reveal that&nbsp;<em>f</em><sub>WB</sub> can be tuned from 100 MHz to 1.5 GHz, thereby demonstrating that patterned normal metal/superconductor nanostructures can be used as dc-tunable generators operating in the radiofrequency range.
369	Experimental demonstration of the optical Helmholtz resonance	Optical nanoantennas are studied to manipulate light and enhance light matter interactions. Here, we experimentally demonstrate the optical Hemholtz resonance in a metallic slit-box structure, which is predicted to behave as an harmonic oscillator and to enhance the electric field intensity by several orders of magnitude.<br />It is fabricated thanks to an electron beam lithography in two steps, between which the box was filled with benzocyclobutene (BCB). Up to 80 % of the light is absorbed at a &#x0015; &lambda;= 2.84 &mu;m wavelength under a beam focused by a Cassegrain objective (NA=0.4), even if the dimensions of this resonator are deeply subwavelength<br />for both the slit (width &#x0015;=&lambda;/55 and height &#x0015;=&lambda;/77) and the box (width &#x0015;=&lambda;/7 and height &#x0015;=&lambda;/37). As expected from the inductance nature of the box, the optical properties of the BCB filling the box have no influence on the resonance behavior.
370	Aerosol jet printed silver nanowire transparent electrode for flexible electronic application	Aerosol jet printing technology enables fine feature deposition of electronic materials onto low-temperature, non-planar substrates without masks. In this work, silver nanowires (AgNWs) are proposed to be printed into transparent flexible electrodes by a Maskless Mesoscale Material Deposition Aerosol Jet&reg; printing system on glass substrate. The influence of the most significant process parameters, including printing cycles, printing speed, and nozzle size on the performance of AgNWs electrode, was systematically studied. The morphologies of printed patterns were characterized with scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and the transmittance was evaluated by ultraviolet-visible (UV-VIS) spectrophotometer. 371	<strong>Photoreduction and Energy Storage performances of Ag<sub>2</sub>O@Ag Deposited on CNT-graphene Nanocomposites </strong>	<strong>&nbsp;</strong>s<p>A simple hydrothermal route assisted by a triblock copolymer was used to synthesize Ag<sub>2</sub>O/Ag nanoparticles on a robotic support consists of functionalized MWCNTs and graphene composite (Ag<sub>2</sub>O/Ag/CNT-graphene). This composite together with the individual analogue Ag/CNT and Ag/graphene were characterized by means of XRD, TEM-SAED, N<sub>2</sub> sorptiometry, Raman, FTIR, UV-Vis, and photoluminescence spectroscopy. These nanomaterials were then tested for the catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) to the technologically beneficial 4-aminophenol (4-AP). The Ag<sub>2</sub>O@Ag@CNT-graphene composite calcined at 400<sup>o</sup>C has shown fascinating reduction performances for 4-NP either in the dark (<em>k</em>= 0.014 s<sup>-1</sup>) or under visible light illumination (<em>k</em>= 0.039 s<sup>-1</sup>) in the presence of 5 mM NaBH<sub>4</sub> compared to Ag/CNT (0.0112 s<sup>-1</sup>) and Ag/graphene (0.010 s<sup>-1</sup>) catalysts. This was chiefly because Ag<sub>2</sub>O@Ag@CNT-graphene comprises the highest pore volume (0.49 cm<sup>3</sup>/g) and involves three types of pores in the margin from 1.8 to 4.0 nm in front of only one modal type of pores for the rest of the catalysts. The promotion of the p-n junction evaluated using Mott-schottky equation on Ag<sub>2</sub>O@Ag@CNT-graphene assisted by charges separation and surface plasmon resonance bands of Ag and Ag<sub>2</sub>O are found to be advantageous for 4-NP reduction. The latter composite delivers a specific capacitance of 355 F g<sup>-1</sup> at 1.0 A g<sup>-1</sup> exceeding those of Ag/CNT (230 F g<sup>-1</sup>) and Ag/graphene (185 F g<sup>-1</sup>). The EIS study establishes the high electronic conductivity of the metallic Ag and Ag<sub>2</sub>O moieties, low internal resistance of CNT-graphene as well as the marked ionic transfer facilitated by porous nature of the composite.
372	Vortex dynamics over an airfoil controlled by nanosecond pulse discharge plasma actuator	This paper presents the vortex dynamics of flow reattachment on a NASA SC (2)-0712 airfoil by a nanosecond pulse dielectric barrier discharge (NS DBD) actuator at a Reynolds number of 1&times;10<sup>5</sup>. The two-dimensional Navier-Stokes equations are solved, and a source term on the right-hand side of the governing fluid energy transport equation is incorporated. The experimental results are well-predicted by computations, where the NS DBD actuator discharge produces a pressure wave with a velocity of 342 m/s and near surface thermal perturbations. Both experimental and computational results indicate that the NS DBD actuator introduces a series of vortexes into the shear layer. In turn, those vortexes promote the mixing of the shear layer, which results in separated flow reattachment. The two-dimensional vorticity evolution equation demonstrates that the vorticity is produced due to the intersection of density and pressure surfaces after plasma discharge. This vorticity advects downstream quickly via local flow velocity. The phase time flow results suggest the mechanism of NS DBD for flow control is the heating effect, which changes the local temperature and density and later induces vortex structures. The vortex structures entrain the outer high-momentum fluid into the shear layer and enhance the turbulent kinetic energy and kinetic energy at the leeward of the wing, thereby strengthening the mixing of the shear layer with the main flow, thereby promoting the separated flow reattachment.
373	<strong>The Physical and Chemical Effects of Increasing Acoustic Power at Small Diameter Ultrasonic Horn Tip</strong>	Ultrasonic horn transducers with small tips apply in most of the laboratories.
