Here, we present a systematic study of the physical and chemical effects at the high &ndash; middle and low power for the 3 mm diameter horn tip. Measurement of the electrical power, calorimetric method, and photography of bubble cloud was done to study the physical effect. KI dosimeter as critical sonochemical reactions. Also synthesized nanoparticles under ultrasonic irradiation consider either the physical and chemical effects are done under variation of acoustic power. For example, the rate of synthesized is chemical effect and adhesive between nanoparticles is the physical effect. The results show that increasing the acoustic power change the physical parameter but cannot change the chemical effect.&nbsp; The comparability of the data measured has been discussed by considering bubble collapse and high-pressure shock wave.
374	The impacts of heat generation/absorption and partial slip on boundary layer flow and heat transfer of a nanofluid comprising of self-impelled motile microorganisms passing a stretching sheet	The present paper has conducted the numerical analysis of a nanofluid consisting of microorganisms on the isothermal linear stretching sheet. The problem has been modeled under the influences of partial slip and heat absorption/generation at the sheet surface. The governing equations are converted to ordinary differential equations through a series of similarity transformations. Using a finite difference method, the resulting equations are discretized, and also they are linearized by applying the linearization technique of Newton. Results of temperature, velocity, concentration of nanoparticles, motile microorganisms' density and also coefficient of reduced skin friction, reduced Nu, reduced Shr, and reduced density numbers of the microorganisms are graphically demonstrated and a detailed description is given. The microorganisms dimensionless density increases as &#x03B4; increase, while decreases with increasing the values of Pe, Lb, Gr and &#x03A9;. Also, boundary layer thickness for motile microorganisms declines by increasing Lb and &#x03A9;. Finally, when the rates of heat generation(&#x03BB;>0) and absorbsion (&#x03BB;<0) increase, the. microorganisms density increases and decreases, respectively.
375	<strong>Dielectric properties of two-dimensional (2D) few-layers WS<sub>2</sub> nanosheets and their tunable electromagnetic absorption properties</strong>	Dielectric property as one of the basic nature of layered transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), there are a lot of atlas need to be filled-up. In this study, few-layers (FL) WS<sub>2</sub> nanosheets were fabricated through liquid phase exfoliation, and the dielectric and electromagnetic absorption (EA) properties were first reported. The results show that a composite consisting of 30 wt% FL-WS<sub>2</sub> exhibited an effective EA bandwidth (&le;&minus;10 dB, which means 90% electromagnetic energy was attenuated) of 4.6 GHz at a thickness of 2.5 mm. Meanwhile, the strongest absorption point (RL<sub>str</sub>) can reach &minus;63.0 dB. The most noteworthy is that FL-WS<sub>2 </sub>based composite can completely absorb the electromagnetic energy from X (8-12 GHz) and Ku (12-18 GHz) band. These results indicate that FL-WS<sub>2</sub> has practical application against electromagnetic pollution in the future.
376	<strong>Tracing the evolution of individual screw dislocations in nanotwin lamella at the atomic scale</strong>	In situ tension test in a transmission electron microscope was carried out on pure Cu, with the emphasis laid on the dislocation activities in/near nanotwin lamellas. Two dynamic processes were revealed at the atomic scale: (i) a lattice screw dislocation forming by the combination of two twinning dislocations in twin boundary and (ii) two 60&deg; full dislocations evolving from an extended screw dislocation inside nanotwin lamella. Our results provide insights into the role of screw dislocation during deformation in nanotwined metals: it can trigger the transition of dislocation slip mode by its formation and dissociation, and also contribute to the nucleation of non-screw dislocations.
377	Spin-orbit torque induced magnetic vortex polarity reversal utilizing spin-Hall effect	We propose an effective magnetic vortex polarity reversal scheme that makes use of spin-orbit torque introduced by spin-Hall effect in heavy-metal/ferromagnet multilayers structure, which can result in subnanosecond polarity reversal without endanger the structural stability. Micromagnetic simulations are performed to investigate the spin-Hall effect driven dynamics evolution of magnetic vortex. The mechanism of magnetic vortex polarity reversal is uncovered by a quantitative analysis of exchange energy density, magnetostatic energy density, and their total energy density. The simulation results indicate that the magnetic vortex polarity is reversed through the nucleation-annihilation process of topological vortex-antivortex pair. This scheme is an attractive option for ultra-fast magnetic vortex polarity reversal, which can be used as the guidelines for the choice of polarity reversal scheme in vortex-based random access memory.
378	Three-dimensional atomic force microscopy for sidewall imaging using torsional resonance mode	This article presents a three-dimensional atomic force microscopy (3D-AFM) technique for surface and sidewall imaging of nanostructures. We used the vertical resonance mode and torsional resonance mode to measure the top and sidewall topography, respectively. In this configuration, in order to reduce the impact of the tip shape, we used a cantilever with flared tip of 700nm in effective length, and the cantilever is oscillated near its vertical or torsional resonant frequencies by two piezo actuators. To verify the 3D-AFM, we measured a step height standard with perpendicular sidewall about 100nm high. This technique clearly showed the surface and the sidewall.
379	The effect of V/III ratio on the morphology and structure of GaAs nanowires by MOCVD	In this paper, GaAs nanowires with different V/III ratios (70, 140, 280 and 560) were vertically grown from bottom to top on GaAs substrates by using metal organic chemical vapor deposition based on gold assisted vapor-liquid-solid mechanism. It is found that the growth rate of nanowires is inversely proportional to their V/III ratio. And the V/III ratio can also change nanowire growth type. For the nanowire with small V/III ratios (<280), the reactants are most from those atoms merged in the catalyst. But, for the nanowire with V/III ratio 560, the contribution mainly comes from the diffusions of atoms pyrolyzed on the surface of the nanowire and the substrate. A shrunken neck under the catalyst is observed in TEM characterizations. These results will provide a theoretical basis for potential practical applications of nanowire-based devices.
380	Excitation of higher radial modes of azimuthal surface waves in the electron cyclotron frequency range by rotating relativistic flow of electrons in cylindrical waveguides partially filled by plasmas	Azimuthal surface waves are electromagnetic eigenwaves of cylindrical plasma-dielectric waveguides which propagate azimuthally nearby the plasma-dielectric interface across an axial external stationary magnetic field. Their eigenfrequency in particular can belong to the electron cyclotron frequency range. Excitation of azimuthal surface waves by rotating relativistic electron flows was studied in detail recently in the case of the zero-th radial mode for which the waves' radial phase change within the layer where the electrons gyrate is small. In this case just the plasma parameters cause the main influence on the waves' dispersion properties. In the case of the first and higher radial modes, the wave eigenfrequency is higher and the wavelength is shorter than in the case of the zero-th radial mode. This gain being of interest for practical applications can be achieved without any change in the device design. The possibility of effective excitation of the higher order radial modes of azimuthal surface waves is demonstrated here. Getting shorter wavelengths of the excited waves in the case of higher radial modes is shown to be accompanied by decreasing growth rates of the waves. The results obtained here are of interest for developing new sources of electromagnetic radiation, in nano-physics and in medical physics.
381	The effect of droplet size on jet speed in Near-Field Electrospinning	The effect of droplet size on the jet speed in Near-Field Electrospinning has been studied. The droplet size was not considered as a major process parameter in Far-Field Electrospinning because of the large Tip-To-Collector Distance. However, in NFES, where the Tip-to-collector distance is greatly reduced, the change of droplet size significantly alters the local electric field and jet travel distance which is coupled to the acceleration of charged ions in polymer jet. It was revealed that the jet speed is more closely related to the jet travel distance than the electric field in NFES, suggesting that the possibility of precise control of jet speed for microscale patterning of nanofibers.
382	Doubly charged coronene clusters - much smaller than previously observed	The smallest doubly charged coronene cluster ions reported so far, Cor_15^2+, were produced by charge exchange between bare coronene clusters and He^2+ (H. A. B. Johansson et al., Phys. Rev. A 2011, 84, 04320). These dications are at least five times larger than the estimated Rayleigh limit, i.e. the size at which the activation barrier for charge separation vanishes. Such a large discrepancy is unheard of for doubly charged atomic or molecular clusters. Here we report the mass spectrometric observation of doubly charged coronene trimers, produced by electron ionization of helium nanodroplets doped with coronene. The observation implies that Cor_3^2+ features a non-zero fission barrier, consistent with density functional theory calculations that reveal a sizeable barrier for the trimer.
383	<strong>Observation of FeGe Skyrmions by Electron Phase Microscopy with Hole-Free Phase Plate</strong>	We report application of hole-free phase plate (HFPP) to imaging of magnetic skyrmion lattices. Using HFPP imaging, we observed a skyrmions in FeGe, and succeeded in obtaining phase contrast images that reflect the sample magnetization distribution. According to Aharonov-Bohm effect, the electron phase is shifted by the magnetic flux due to sample magnetization. The differential processing of the intensity in a HFPP image allows us to successfully reconstruct the magnetization map of the skyrmion lattice. Furthermore, the calculated phase shift due to the magnetization of the thin film was consistent with that measured by electron holography experiment, which demonstrates that HFPP imaging can be utilized analysis of magnetic fields and electrostatic potential distribution at nanoscale.
384	<strong>Influence of Curvature on the Contact Instabilities of Thin Viscoelastic Coatings on the Fiber Surfaces </strong>	Contact instabilities of a thin viscoelastic film on a curved surface have been explored with the help of a general linear stability analysis. The governing equations and boundary conditions for a thin zero-frequency linear viscoelastic solid film are linearized to predict the time and length scales associated with this instability. A long-wave analysis corroborates the accuracy of the eigenvalues obtained from the general analysis. While the adhesive interaction between the film surface and contactor stimulate contact instability by subduing the restoring elastic and surface tension forces, the forces due to radial curvature fuel up the capillary instability. Importantly, unlike the unconditionally unstable viscous films, this instability manifests beyond a critical destabilizing force owing to its elastic stiffness of the viscoelastic film. The destabilizing intermolecular and radial curvature forces are tuned by controlling the film-contactor gap and radius of fiber, which eventually helped in predicting the formation of drops, columns, or mixed morphologies. For example, when the contactor-film gap is higher and the radius of fiber and the film thickness are lower, the dominant force due to radial curvature can break the film into droplets whereas a smaller contactor-film separation distance on a fiber of large radius instigate contact instability to develop columnar structures. Otherwise, formation of a mixed morphology composed of droplets and columns is expected. The study highlights that tuning film-contactor gap, radius of fiber, and ratio of stabilizing forces, a host of surface patterns with length scales ranging from few micrometers to hundreds of nanometers can be obtained.
385	Defects characterisation studies and exploration of europium substitution effects in nanocrystalline bismuth ferrite through positron annihilation and other methods	A detailed study of the origin and role of structural defects on the effects of Eu<sup>3+</sup>-substitution(<em>x</em> = 0.0, 0.05, &hellip;, 0.3) in place of Bi<sup>3+</sup> in BiFeO<sub>3 </sub>nanocrystalline multiferroic perovskite samples is presented. The samples were synthesized through the normal sol-gel route and characterised by X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy. Further, UV-Vis absorption studies enabled the measurements of the band gap, which showed a continuous decrease on increased substitution. The phenomenon indicated the creation of defects-induced energy levels in the band gap closer to the conduction band. Positron annihilation spectroscopy is used in the identification of the structural defects in the crystallites. The studies revealed high concentrations of trivacancy-type defects within the Bi<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Eu<em><sub>x</sub></em>FeO<sub>3</sub>nanocrystallites. The transformation from the distorted rhombohedral structure to an orthorhombic configuration with an accompanying lattice contraction at <em>x</em>&gt; 0.2 influenced the positron lifetimes and the intensities. Substitution also helped in the cancellation of pre-existed vacancies through recombination with the doped ions. The measured positron lifetimes also indicated a fraction of the positrons annihilating from the nanocrystallite surfaces. Coincidence Doppler broadening measurements supported the transformation taking place during the substitution process and further identified the cationic vacancies as the predominant defects. The studies were found justified in the magneto-electric voltage measurements under a.c. magnetic fields of different strengths, all of which peaked at <em>x</em> = 0.2 and then decreased concomitantly with the transformation of the crystallites to the orthorhombic structure.
386	Electrical nanopatterning of TiO<sub>2</sub> single crystal surfaces in situ via local resistance and potential switching.	The resistive switching effect allows for a manipulation of the oxide resistance. Here, we monitor the surface conductivity and surface potential of thermally reduced TiO2 single crystals. We show that the resistance of confined areas can be switched by applying a voltage during scanning. By conducting in situ oxidation experiments, we present that this surface switching is related to a local redox reaction, which can be controlled electrically allowing for surface nanopatterning. We discuss that the features of the nanopattern can be scaled down to a lower boundary at several tens of nanometers determined by the presence of intrinsic variations.
387	A new experimental correlations for heat transfer and flow friction characteristics of the nanofluid flow in transverse with combined protrusion rib square duct	In this paper, forced convective flow of &#x3016;Al&#x3017;_2 O_3-water nanofluid in transverse with combined protrusion rib square duct is experimentally studied. The results of experimental analysis are obtained for Reynolds number (&#x3016;Re&#x3017;_num) ranges of 4000-18000, particle concentration (&#x03C6;) ranges of 0.01-0.04, particle diameter (d_np) ranges of 30nm-45nm,  X-axis pitch (X_axis/d_print) ranges of 1.39-2.59, Y-axis pitch (Y_axis/d_print) ranges of 1.39-2.59 and ratio of print diameter (e_rib/d_print) ranges of 0.83-1.67 respectively. The uppermost value of heat transfer is observed at &#x03C6; of 0.04, d_np of 30nm, X_axis/d_print of 1.79, Y_axis/d_print of 1.79 and e_rib/d_print of 1.0. Nusselt number and flow friction correlations have been developed which can predict the corresponding values of Nusselt number and flow friction with the absolute percentage deviation of 4.82% and 4.53% respectively.
388	Development of Fe3O4/Ag core/shell-based multifunctional immunomagnetic nanoparticles for isolation and detection of CD34+ stem cells	Fe3O4/Ag core/shell nanoparticles functionalized with the free amino (NH2) functional groups (Fe3O4/Ag-NH2) were conjugated with fluorescent ECD-antiCD34 antibody using 1-ethyl-3-(3&#x2032;-dimethyl-aminopropyl) carbodiimide (EDC) catalyst (ECD is a fluorescent organic dye attached to the antibody). The characteristic fluorescence of ECD in the antibody was investigated and used as a good indicator for estimating the percentage of the antibodies that were successfully conjugated with the nanoparticles. Conjugation efficiency was found to increase depending on the VNP:VAB ratio, where VNP and VAB are the volumes of the nanoparticle solution (concentration of 50 ppm) and the as-purchased antibody solution, respectively. The conjugation efficiency rapidly grew up from approximately 18 % to around 70 % when VNP:VAB was increased from 2:1 to 100:1 and gradually reached saturated state at the efficiency of about 95 % as the VNP:VAB equaled 300:1. The bioactivity of the above-mentioned conjugation product (denoted by Fe3O4/Ag-antiCD34) was evaluated in an experiment for collection of stem cells from bone marrow samples.
389	Thermally amorphized nanoporous gold: Morphological and mechanical investigation	In this study, the morphological evolution and mechanical enhancement acquired by applying a thermal treatment on a nanoporous gold are investigated by performing molecular dynamics simulations. The thermal treatment is applied to the structure at the amorphization temperature of the monocrystalline nanoporous gold. To determine the transition temperature to amorphous state, the structure is heated up to 1500 K while monitoring the radial pair distribution functions of the nanoporous structure. Following this, the nanoporous gold is annealed at the amorphization temperature with different heating rates (i.e. 10 and 100K/ps) and durations (i.e. 0, 40 and 100ps). For the purpose of maintaining the amorphous phase in the nanoporous gold, the system is quenched to the room temperature. Then, the mechanical behavior of the thermally treated nanoporous gold is observed by applying tensile and compressive loadings to the structure. The results of the thermally treated nanoporous gold are compared with the non-treated nanoporous gold to determine the mechanical alterations. According to this comparison, the Young&rsquo;s modulus and the ultimate tensile strength of the nanoporous gold are increased by 110% and 80% respectively as a result heat treatment. For compression behavior, owing to heat treatment, the elastic region is improved (i.e. 80 and 10% increased compressive modulus for 10 and 100K/ps, respectively) while the plateau region is shortened which results in early densification.
390	Interesting electromagnetic properties of soft Z-type hexaferrite in the gigahertz range for communication	The paper comprises, high-frequency magnetic nanoparticles of Co<sub>2</sub>Z-type hexaferrites of the series Ba<sub>3-X</sub>Sr<sub>X</sub>Co<sub>2</sub>Fe<sub>24</sub>O<sub>41</sub> (where x = 0, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0) synthesized by sol-gel auto combustion method. Of particular interest in controlling electromagnetic losses with enhanced real part of complex permeability and permittivity over the frequency range 2 GHz to 3.43 GHz for antenna applications. Successfully obtained appreciable magnetic and microwave properties due to Sr<sup>2+</sup> substitution for Ba<sup>2+</sup>, in which magnetic moments of Co<sub>2</sub>Z-type hexaferrite lie in the basal plane at room temperature. The larger size crystallites of 52-60 nm range, has a tendency towards multi-domain structure formation, and to decrease the coercivity (Hc) and the magneto-crystalline anisotropy, which in turn increase the real part of permeability (&mu;'). The Maxwell and Wagner type interfacial polarization following the Koop&rsquo;s phenomenological theory, responsible for the&nbsp;variation of the value of permittivity (&epsilon;') with frequency. Several manifestations of electromagnetic studies are reported and explained on the basis of relevant existing theories and models. The desirable results obtained at 2 GHz for composition Ba1.5Sr1.5Co2Fe24O41, are &mu;' = 5 and &#x0510;' = 4.7 with controlled magnetic and electric loss tangents close to zero i.e. 0.003 and 0.006, respectively. The synthesized composite has almost equal values of real permeability and permittivity, as well as the low magnetic and dielectric loss tangents. Such magneto-dielectric substrate material could be valuable for the design of antennas with reduced physical dimensions and good impedance-matched to free space.
391	<strong>Effects of Fretting Interfaces&rsquo; Characteristics on Friction Behavior: Molecular Dynamics Simulation and Theoretical Analysis</strong>	The friction behavior between fretting interfaces is not only of fundamental interest, but also practically important in materials&rsquo; utilities. However, current discussion about the fretting process never investigates into friction contact intervals. Moreover, the fretting process has not been understood systematically from the perspective of different interfacial configuration, and has failed to consider rapidly developing theories in energy, mechanics, etc. In the present work, by performing Molecular Dynamics Simulations on the Al-Al, diamond-diamond, and diamond-silicon fretting interfaces using the bidirectional forces, referring to the novel theories including the energy barrier theory, bonding principles, wear rate analyses, and nanoscale friction laws, we found that the difference in hardness and the material&rsquo;s configuration greatly influence the force response, which leads to force responses during the friction contact intervals, and give different coefficient of friction to the researched interfaces. Due to the possible prominent force responses during the contact intervals, the continuous friction behavior on fretting interfaces must take into consideration the role played by intervals, in order to form a complete discussion, to more accurately estimate friction coefficient, and to correctly relate MD simulation with experiments.
392	<strong>Solution Processable Cd<sub>1&minus;&#x1D465;</sub>Zn<sub>&#x1D465;</sub>S with Controlled Band gap and its Visible Light Photocatalytic Tetracycline Degradation Activity</strong>	Photocatalytic degradation of broad band antibiotics like Tetracycline (TC) under visible-light irradiation is considered as an efficient and cost effective protocol for eliminating it from the aqueous medium. In this study, highly efficient solution processable Cd<sub>1&minus;&#x1D465;</sub>Zn<sub>&#x1D465;</sub>S photocatalysts were synthesized using simple solvothermal route where zinc acetate and cadmium acetate were used as precursors. Composition-tunable alloyed nanorods with band gap energy tunability ranging from UV (3.7eV) to Vis (2.5ev) are characterized both structurally and optically. The photocatalytic performance is strongly related with the ratio of Cd and Zn present in Cd<sub>1&minus;&#x1D465;</sub>Zn<sub>&#x1D465;</sub>S nanorod. The Cd<sub>0.75</sub>Zn<sub>0.25</sub>S sample exhibits the highest photocatalytic degradation rate constant compared to the other family members. Our study gives new insight towards the designing of ternary photocatalytic materials for efficient removal of antibiotics from aqueous solution.
393	Dynamic formation of nanodiamond precursors from the decomposition of carbon suboxide (C<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) in extreme conditions - a ReaxFF study	We use Molecular Dynamics simulations with the ReaxFF-lg potential to model the high pressure pyrolysis of carbon suboxide (C<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) in mixture with argon as pressure bath. We show that the reactive simulations catch the experimental behavior of the low-pressure detonation of C<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (around 10 bar in shock tube experiments) and allows extrapolations to the high-pressure range of solid-state explosive detonation (up to 60 GPa). While at low pressure carbon-based nanostructures are formed through aggregation of species such as carbon dimers C<sub>2</sub>, it appears that the high pressure deeply modifies the process, with aggregation of growing C<sub>x</sub>O<sub>y</sub> heterostructures, in which the oxygen amount is driven by the pressure and the temperature. Pressures in the order of 60 GPa lead to high oxygen ratios which hinder <i>sp<sup>3</sup></i>-hybridization of carbon. But a pressure lowering leads to substantial carbon enrichment through CO<sub>2</sub>/CO release, which consequently facilitates the formation of <i>sp<sup>3</sup></i> carbon phases, allowing in turn the formation of carbon-based nanoparticles with well-formed diamond cores. These results give new insights on the conditions leading to nanodiamonds during the detonation of carbon-rich high explosives.
394	<strong>The effects of annealing temperature on the permittivity and electromagnetic attenuation performance of reduced graphene oxide</strong>	Reduced graphene oxide (RGO) has been prepared through thermal reduction method with different annealing temperature, to explore the effects on the permittivity, as well as electromagnetic attenuation performance. The real and imaginary part of permittivity increase along with the decrement of oxygen functional group and the increment of the filler loading ratio. A composite only loaded with 1 wt% of RGO can possess an effective electromagnetic absorption (EA) bandwidth of 7.60 GHz, when graphene oxide (GO) was reduced under 300 <sup>&deg;</sup>C for 2 h. With the annealing temperature increased to 700 <sup>&deg;</sup>C, the well reduced RGO loaded 7 wt% in the composite, the electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding efficiency (SE) can get higher than 35 dB from 2 to 18 GHz. This study shows that controlling the oxygen functional groups on RGO surface, can also obtain an ideal electromagnetic protective performance without any other decorated nanomaterials.
395	Low-voltage all-inorganic perovskite quantum dot transistor memory	An all-inorganic cesium lead halide perovskite QDs based Au NPs floating-gate memories with solution processed layer-bylayer (LBL) method is demonstrated. Easy synthesis at room temperature and excellent stability makes all-inorganic CsPbBr3 perovskite quantum dots (QDs) suitable as semiconductor layer in low voltage nonvolatile transistor memory. The bipolarity of QDs have both electrons and holes stored in the Au nanoparticles (NPs) floating gate, resulting in bidirectional shifts of initial threshold voltage according to the applied programing and erasing pulses. Under low operation voltage (&plusmn;5 V), the memory achieved great memory window (~2.4 V), long retention time (&gt; 10<sup>5</sup> s) and stable endurance property after 200 cycles. So, the proposed memory device based on CsPbBr3 perovskite QDs has a great potential in the flash memory market.
396	Optical design of GaN nanowire arrays for photocatalytic applications	GaN nanowire (NW) arrays are interesting candidates for photocatalytic applications due to their high surface-to-volume ratio and their waveguide character. The integration of GaN NW arrays on GaN-based light emitting diodes (LEDs), serving as platform for electrically driven NW-based photocatalytic devices, enables an efficient coupling of the light from the planar LED to the GaN NWs. Here, we present a numerical study of the influence of the NW geometries, i.e. the NW diameter, length and period, and the illumination wavelength on the transmission of GaN NW arrays on transparent substrates. A detailed numerical analysis reveals that the transmission characteristics for large periods are determined by the waveguide character of the single NW, whereas for dense GaN NW arrays inter-wire coupling and diffraction effects originating from the periodic arrangement of the GaN NWs dominate the transmission. The numerically simulated results are confirmed by experimental transmission measurements. We also investigate the influence of a dielectric NW shell and of the surrounding medium on the transmission characteristics of a GaN NW array.
397	<strong>Waterproof and stretchable tirboelectric nanogenerator for biomechanical energy harvesting and self-powered sensing</strong>	We introduce a waterproof and stretchable triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) that can be attached on human body, such as finger and wrist, to harvest mechanical energies from body movement. The whole device is composed of stretchable material so that it can endure and scavenge energy from diverse mechanical deformations. Under the gentle mechanical motion of press, stretch and bend, the device with an effective area of 1 &nbsp;2 cm can generate peak-to-peak output current of 257.5 nA, 50.2 nA and 33.5 nA, respectively. Besides, the TENG is tightly encapsulated which can avoid the influence from external environment like humidity and enable it to harvest energy under water. Particularly, owing to the thin and soft property of encapsulation film, the device can response to weak vibration like wrist pulse and act as a self-powered pulse sensor, showing &nbsp;its application prospects in the field of wearable energy harvesting devices and self-powered sensing system.
398	<strong>A novel model for the mechanical properties of silica aerogels</strong>	Most studies on the mechanical properties of silica aerogels neglected the influence of structural randomness and the dead-ends of nano-porous materials, whereas both of them have a considerable effect on the mechanical properties of silica aerogels. In this study, we propose a cubic frame model with random orientation as the representative volume element (RVE) of silica aerogel to investigate the dead-ends&rsquo; effect on its mechanical properties. To characterize the structural randomness in the open-cell porous materials, a new constitutive model is established by a statistically average of the mechanical response of the random structure. This constitutive model reveals the inherent isotropy of open-cell porous materials. It also indicates the widely-used Gibson-Ashby model may overestimate the Young&rsquo;s modulus and shear modulus for open-cell porous materials. Then the mass ratio of dead-ends and effective skeleton are derived using available experimental results. It shows that the mass ratio of dead-ends increases with the decreasing density of silica aerogels because of the more space resulted from slimmer effective skeleton, which results in the abnormal exponent of the Young&rsquo;s modulus-density power-law relation. We suggest the mass ratio of the effective skeleton to be an intuitive and practical index to reflect the connectivity in silica aerogels. Besides, the dead-ends can significantly enhance the compressive strength of silica aerogels, especially for low-density silica aerogels. We hope this work can provide a new idea to consider the structural randomness in porous materials and give guidance on the mechanical reinforcement of aerogels.
399	Probing flexoelectricity via a split Hopkinson pressure bar experiment	Flexoelectricity is thought of as a universal property of all dielectric materials that couples polarization with the inhomogeneous deformation. However, at the macroscale, this coupling is usually very weak and the direct observation of flexoelectricity always suffers by low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). At the micron or submicron scale, both the flexoelectric effect and some surface effects may get pronounced simultaneously. To separate the flexoelectric effect from those surface effects and accurately measure the bulk flexoelectric coefficients is challenging. In this paper, we propose a novel high SNR method for measuring the bulk flexoelectric coefficient &nbsp;of millimeter-sized samples through split Hopkinson pressure bar (SHPB) experiments. Our experimental results show that for normal impact speed (17m/s) of the striker bar, the induced voltage difference is as high as 70mV which can be easily measured without using signal amplifiers. In most of previous works of measuring flexoelectric coefficients, strain gradients are introduced through the design of samples&rsquo; shape such as thin beams, thin films, truncated cones and pyramids. In a different way, the proposed SHPB based approach introduces time varied strains to the system and then converts time gradients of strains into their spatial gradients through elastic waves. As a promising way of measuring bulk flexoelectric coefficients, this approach produces high SNR flexoelectric signals, reduces the interferences from surface effects, and avoids the difficulties in fabricating nanostructures.
400	<strong>Enhancement of coalescence-induced droplet jumping on superhydrophobic surfaces</strong>	Coalescence-induced droplet self-jumping on superhydrophobic surfaces has received extensive attentions over the past decade because of its potential applications ranging from anti-icing materials to self-sustained condensers, and a higher jumping velocity <em>v</em><sub>j</sub> is always expected and favorable. However, the previous studies have shown that there is a velocity limit with <em>v</em><sub>j</sub>&le;0.23<em>u</em><sub>ic</sub> for microscale droplets and <em>v</em><sub>j</sub>&le;0.127<em>u</em><sub>ic</sub> for nanoscale droplets, where <em>u</em><sub>ic</sub> is referred to as the inertial-capillary velocity. Here we show that the jumping velocity can be significantly increased by patterning a single groove, ridge, or more hydrophobic strip, whose size is comparable with the radius of coalescing droplets, on a superhydrophobic surface. We implement molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the coalescence of two equally sized nanodroplets (8 nm in radius) on such surfaces. We found that a maximum <em>v</em><sub>j</sub>=0.23<em>u</em><sub>ic</sub> is achieved on the surface with a 1.4 nm high and 8 nm wide ridge, which is 1.81 times higher than the nanoscale velocity limit. We also demonstrate that the presence of groove, ridge, and strip alters coalescence dynamics of droplets, leading to a significantly shortened coalescence time which remarkably reduces viscous dissipation during coalescence; thus, we believe that the present approach is effective for microscale droplet jumping.
401	<strong>Flexible pressure sensor based on graphene aerogel functionalized with CdS nanocrystalline thin film</strong>	In this paper, we report on functionalization of graphene aerogel with a CdS thin film deposited by magnetron sputtering and on the development of flexible pressure sensors based on ultra-lightweight CdS-aerogel nanocomposite. Analysis by scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray analysis discloses the uniform deposition of nanocrystalline CdS films with the chemical composition deviating from the ideal stoichiometry by 3.4 %. The piezoresistive response of the aforementioned nanocomposite in the pressure range from 1 to 5 atm is found to be more than one order of magnitude higher than that inherent to suspended graphene membranes, leading to an average sensitivity as high as 3.2x10<sup>-4</sup> kPa<sup>-1</sup>.
402	Evolution and tailoring of DUV plasmonic properties in Al nanoparticle arrays by UV irradiation	UV irradiation was used to tailor the surface plasmon band of the densely distributed Al nanoparticle arrays fabricated by gas phase deposition. We showed that the broad surface plasmon resonance band of the as-prepared sample could be tuned to a sharp and strong resonance band in the DUV optical range, with a large blue shift of the peak wavelength. The evolution of the surface plasmon resonance properties was attributed to the UV irradiation-improved surface oxidation of the nanoparticles, which vanished the nearfield couplings between the closely spaced nanoparticles by increasing their interspacing.
403	Atomistic Minimal Model for Estimating Profile of Electrodeposited Nanopatterns	We develop a computationally efficient and methodologically simple approach to realize molecular dynamics simulations of electrodeposition. Our minimal model takes into account the nontrivial electric field due a sharp electrode tip to perform simulation of the controllable coating of a thin layer on a surface with an atomic precision. On the atomic scale a highly site-selective electrodeposition of ions and charged particles by means of the sharp tip of a scanning probe microscope is possible. A better understanding of the microscopic process, obtained mainly from atomistic simulations, helps us to enhance the quality of this nanopatterning technique and to make it applicable in fabrication of nanowires and nanocontacts. In the limit of screened inter-particle interactions, it is feasible to run very fast simulations of the electrodeposition process within the framework of the proposed model and thus to investigate how the shape of the overlayer depends on the tip-sample geometry and dielectric properties, electrolyte viscosity, etc. Our calculations results reveal that the sharpness of the profile of a nano-scale deposited overlayer is dictated by the normal-to-sample surface component of the electric field underneath the tip.
404	Study on the energy deposition and ignition characteristics of a capillary discharge based pulsed plasma thruster	Ablative pulsed plasma thrusters (APPTs) have aroused renewed interest in the investigation and enhancement of the basic performance for the application of micro/nano satellites recently. However, since the complex working mechanism and limited energy deposition efficiency, research on the characteristics of energy deposition and ignition process is critical to the optimization of the APPT design under a low energy level. In this paper, a capillary discharge based PPT is presented and the influence of the electric and geometry parameters on the characteristics are studied by experiments. Two stages are observed in the entire energy deposition process according to the variation of the deposition rate. The promotion of the energy deposition efficiency can be accomplished with the limitation of the main discharge current oscillations by increasing the main capacitance at a fixed energy and the cavity length or decreasing the main charging voltage and cavity inner diameter, which is in accordance with the variation of the equivalent plasma resistance. Shorter ignition delay time and lower jitter are obtained with a higher ignition energy and main charging voltage or a shorter and narrower cavity, which is positively correlated to the electric field distribution along the propellant surface. The accumulation of ablated products and variation of the surface morphology of propellant and igniter are the significant factors that cause the dispersity of the ignition effect and main discharge characteristics with increasing the operation times. Meanwhile, noticeable mal-distribution of the ablation/deposition phenomena in the axial direction of the propellant surface are verified.
405	Evolution of filaments and associated magnetic fields produced by the Weibel Instability in two counterstreaming laser plasmas	The evolution of filaments due to the Weibel instability was studied experimentally in two counterstreaming plasmas produced by nanosecond laser pulses with total energy more than 1 kJ. The magnetic field around filamentations was diagnosed by the Faraday rotation technique as tens of Tesla with an exponential growth rate of 10^-6, which was in good agreement with the calculated features of the Weibel Instability. The separation distances between filaments were also measured, and its temporal evolution, as compared to analytical models from Medvedev [Astrophys. J. 618, L75-L78 (2005)] and Ruyer [Phys. Plasmas 22 032102 (2015).], was mostly attributed to the coalescence behavior of filaments in post saturation regime.
406	Density-functional study of hydrogen cyanide adsorption on silicene nanoribbons	Adsorption of toxic hydrogen cyanide gas (HCN) on armchair silicene nanoribbons (ASiNRs) is investigated by first principles method using density functional theory (DFT) to compute geometric, electronic and transport properties. Two variants of ASiNRs are considered: pristine ASiNR (P-ASiNR) and defective ASiNR (D-ASiNR), which is created by introducing a vacancy in P-ASiNR by removal of a Si atom. Total energy optimizations are used to find the most stable structures. The calculated results reveal that although HCN is physisorbed in both variants, sensitivity in case of D-ASiNR is sufficiently enhanced owing to more adsorption energy and charge transfer between the ASiNR-gas complex. Also the inspection of current-voltage characteristics demonstrates that the introduction of defect has considerably increased the conductivity of ASiNR. Hence, D-ASiNR may be used as a promising sensor for HCN gas.
407	Dielectric properties and out of plane Magnetic anisotropy of electrodeposited Co<sub>1-X</sub>Mn<sub>X </sub>alloy nanowires	The Co<sub>1-x</sub>Mn<sub>x</sub> alloy nanowires with uniform size and high density have been prepared by AC electrodeposition method into the anodized aluminum oxide AAO templates by using the different AC potential from 9 V to 13 V. A systematic study has been done about the voltage dependent physical and magnetic properties of CoMn nanowires. The Energy Dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) shows that the concentration of Mn and Cobalt increases and decreases respectively with the increase of voltage. It is observed from X-ray Diffraction (XRD) data of all samples that CoMn alloy nanowires have the cubic structure and crystallite size varies from 39.63 nm to 48.96 nm. The Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) pattern shows the presence of other materials such as CoO, MnO, and Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>at different wavenumber range. The dielectric properties decrease with the increase of voltage due to incorporation of Mn ions and deduction of Co ions. The decrease in AC conductivity against the increasing voltage is also due to the increase of grain boundary volume. The M-H loops were measured by using the vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) and show the anisotropic and ferromagnetic behavior. When AC potential increases gradually from 9 V to 13 V in equal intervals, the deposition of magnetic ion decreases than that of nonmagnetic ions, as a consequence coercivity (H<sub>C</sub>) and saturation magnetization (M<sub>S</sub>) decreases. It is also found that magnetization reversal has nucleation mode and squareness decreases with increase of angle.&nbsp; This study is useful to modify properties according to our desire.
408	Cluster beams, nano-ripples and bio applications	NA
409	Thermal Conductivity of Poly (3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) Films Engineered by oxidative Chemical Vapor Deposition (oCVD)	Oxidative chemical vapor deposition (oCVD) is a versatile technique that can simultaneously tailor properties (e.g., electrical, thermal conductivity) and morphology of polymer films at the nanoscale. In this work, we report the thermal conductivity of nanoscale oCVD grown poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT) films for the first time. Measurements as low as 0.16 W/m&middot;K are obtained at room temperature for PEDOT films with thicknesses ranging from 50 - 100 nm. These values are lower than those for solution processed PEDOT films doped with the solubilizing agent PSS (polystyrene sulfonate). The thermal conductivity of oCVD grown PEDOT films shows no clear dependence on electrical conductivity, which ranges from 1 S/cm to 30 S/cm. It is suspected that at these electrical conductivities, the electronic contribution to the thermal conductivity is extremely small and that phonon transport is dominant. Our findings suggest that CVD polymerization is a promising route towards engineering polymer films that combine low thermal conductivity with relatively high electrical conductivity values.
410	Free energy of adhesion of lipid bilayers on silica surfaces	The free energy of adhesion per unit area (hereafter referred to as the adhesion strength) of lipid arrays on surfaces is a key parameter that determines the nature of the interaction between materials and biological systems. Here we report classical molecular simulations of water and DMPC lipid bilayers at model silica surfaces with a range of silanol densities and structures. We employ a novel technique that enables us to estimate the adhesion strength of supported lipid bilayers in the presence of water. We find that silanols on the silica surface form hydrogen bonds with water molecules and that the water immersion enthalpy for all surfaces varies linearly with the surface density of these hydrogen bonds. The adhesion strength of lipid bilayers is a linear function of the surface density of hydrogen bonds formed between silanols and the lipid molecules on crystalline surfaces. Roughly 20% of isolated silanols form such bonds but less than 1% of mutually interacting geminal silanols. On amorphous silica the bilayer displays much stronger adhesion than expected from the crystalline surface data. We discuss the implications of these results for nanoparticle toxicity.
411	Vibration-induced structures in scanning tunneling microscope light emission spectra of Ni(110)-(2 &times; 1) O	We obtained scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) light emission spectra of a Ni(110)-(2 &times; 1) O surface. A mosaic of nanoscale light and dark domains was observed in the STM image. When the tip was fixed over the dark domain, stepwise structures were observed at 100 meV and 150 meV below the quantum cutoff in the STM light emission spectra. These energies were consistent with the reported vibrational energies of oxygen atoms adsorbed on the Ni(110)-(2 &times; 1) O surface, and indicated the expected isotope shifts between <sup>16</sup>O and <sup>18</sup>O. Therefore, these stepwise structures are induced by the vibrations of adsorbed oxygen atoms. The 100-meV mode corresponded to the vibration polarized parallel to the surface. A theory describing the coupling between the STM light emission and vibration polarized parallel to the surface is proposed. We conclude that the oxygen atoms cover the dark domain and bare Ni atoms correspond to the light domain. When the exposure level of oxygen was approximately 1/10 of that for Ni(110)-(2 &times; 1) O, light-imaged nanostructures were observed in the terrace where bare Ni atoms are exposed. The step structure caused by the vibrations of adsorbed oxygen was observed in the STM light emission spectra of the light-imaged nanostructures, showing that these structures are covered by oxygen atoms. In other words, the isolated nanostructures covered by oxygen atoms are imaged not as dark, but as light, unlike in the case of Ni(110)-(2 &times; 1) O observed by STM.
412	Low temperature-processed ZnO nanorods-TiO2 nanoparticles composite as electron transporting layer for perovskite solar cells	Electron transport is one of the most crucial processes that determine charge collection efficiency in perovskite solar cells. Herein, a low temperature-processed ZnO-TiO2 nanocomposite is developed as an electron transporting layer for perovskite solar cells. Highly-crystalline ZnO nanorods were deposited electrochemically which served as the scaffold for spin-coated TiO2 nanoparticles. This ZnO-TiO2 nanocomposite is designed to integrate the fast electron transport along the nanorods and the additional surface area provided by the nanoparticles for enhanced electronic contact between the electron-transporting layer and the perovskite layer. A weak PL quenching behavior was observed for ZnO nanorods after TiO2 nanoparticle coating which signifies a reduction in ZnO surface defects. Steady-state photoluminescence and optical absorption measurements indicated improved charge transfer and higher absorption of light, respectively, when ZnO-TiO2 nanocomposite is contacted with the CH3NH3PbI3 layer. However, the clustering of the nanoparticles caused inefficient charge transfer from TiO2 to ZnO.
413	Non-local electron transport through normal and topological ladder-like atomic systems.	We propose locally protected ladder-like atomic system (nanoconductor) on a substrate that is insensitive to external perturbations. The system corresponds to coupled atomic chains fabricated on different surfaces.&nbsp; Electron transport properties of such conductors are studied theoretically using the model tight-binging Su-Schriffer-Hegger (SSH) Hamiltonian and Green's function formalism. We have found that the conductance of the system is almost insensitive to single impurities and oscillates as a function of the impurity chain length with very large periods and the oscillation amplitude depends on the electron localization in the surface. Non-local character of the electron transport was observed also for topological SSH chains where nontrivial end states survive in the presence of disturbances as well as for different substrates.&nbsp; We have found that the careful inspection of the density of states (DOS) or charge&nbsp; waves can provide the information about the atoms energy levels and hopping amplitudes. Moreover, the ladder-like geometry allows one to distinguish between normal and topological zero-energy states. It is important that topological chains do not reveal Friedel oscillations which are observed in non-topological chains.
414	Critical Thickness for Spin Wave-Assisted Switching of Magnetization in a Perpendicularly Magnetized Nanomagnet	The magnetization switching in a perpendicularly magnetized nano magnet by applying circularly polarized rf field is analyzed as a function of the thickness (<em>d</em>) of the specimen using an effective one-dimensional model. It is found that there exist two kinds of critical thicknesses, <em>d</em><sub>c1</sub> and <em>d</em><sub>c2</sub>(&ge; <em>d</em><sub>c1</sub>). When <em>d</em> &lt; <em>d</em><sub>c1</sub>, the switching mode is an uniform type which is well described by a macro-spin model. On the other hand, when d<sub>c1</sub> &le;&nbsp;<em>d</em> &lt;&nbsp;<em>d</em><sub>c2</sub>, the switching mode is a non-uniform type whereas the rf frequency dependence of the switching field is the same as the one with <em>d</em> &nbsp;&lt; <em>d</em><sub>c1</sub>. In the case of <em>d</em> &ge; <em>d</em><sub>c2</sub>, the critical rf frequency at which the switching field takes a minimum value increases. The results indicate that the switching field is more effectively reduced than the conventional microwave-assisted switching.
415	<strong>Van der Waals Epitaxy of Two-Dimensional Single-Layer h-BN on Graphite by Molecular Beam Epitaxy:</strong><strong> Electronic Properties and Band Structure</strong>	Hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) is a promising material for implementation in nanoelectronics due to a large band gap, low spin-orbit coupling, and a small lattice mismatch to graphene. We report on the controlled growth of&nbsp;h-BN/graphite by means of molecular beam epitaxy (MBE). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) suggests an interface without any reaction or intermixing, while the angle resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) measurements show that the h-BN layers are epitaxially aligned with graphite. A well-defined band structure is revealed by ARPES measurement, reflecting the high quality of the h-BN films. The measured valence band maximum (VBM) located at 2.8 eV below the Fermi level reveals the presence of undoped h-BN films (band gap ~ 6 eV). These results demonstrate that, although only weak van der Waals interactions are present between h-BN and graphite, a long range ordering of h-BN can be obtained even on polycrystalline graphite <em>via</em> van der Waals epitaxy, offering the prospect of large area, single layer h-BN.
416	<strong>Development of compact urea biosensor using printed circuit board technology </strong>	This paper presents fabrication of compact and low cost printed circuit board (PCB) based urea biosensor using a circular sized indium tinoxide (ITO) coated glass as working electrode. For this, ITO coated glass was subjected to etching using 50 % concentrated sulphuric acid and keeping a temperature of 50 &#x02DA;C with a suitable mask to protect the circuit area. &nbsp;A silver layer was developed around the ITO working electrode on the same glass by thermal evaporation technique and then AgCl paste was coated on the Ag layer for the preparation of Ag/AgCl reference electrode. A thin layer of mixture of nanostructured copper oxide (Nano-CuO) and nanostructured zinc oxide (Nano-ZnO) was deposited using electrophoretic deposition method on the said working electrode. Urease (Enzyme) was immobilized on the working electrode surface by physical adsorption technique via glutareldehyde as cross-linker. Electrochemical response of this urea bioelectrode was recorded by Keithley Source Meter (KSM) for different urea concentration from 0.1 to 100 mM. This Nano-CuO/Nano-ZnO urea bioelectrode was found to have sensitivity of 488 uA/mM/cm<sup>2</sup>, shelf life of 180 days under normal laboratory condition and lower limit of detection of 35 uM. This method requires only a small amount of urease~ 2 &micro;l and no extra buffer saline for test. Such small sized nanostructured urea biosensor with high commercial impact can be easily fabricated and mass produced using this methodology.
417	Temperature dependence of photoinduced hydrogen production and simultaneous separation in TiO<sub>2</sub> nanotubes/palladium bilayer membrane	Temperature dependence of photoinduced hydrogen production and simultaneous separation was examined in a bilayer membrane comprised by an anodized TiO<sub>2</sub> nanotube arrays (TNAs) and a palladium layer. This membrane was fabricated by transferring a TNA embedded in a titanium sheet onto an electroless-plated palladium film. Sacrificial water splitting with methanol was photocatalytically performed under ultraviolet (UV) irradiation and only generated hydrogen gas was concurrently separated with the Pd layer. The H<sub>2</sub> production rate (r<sub>H2</sub>) with the membrane at various temperatures was evaluated by using a home-made characterization system. The measured r<sub>H2</sub> showed larger values at higher temperature of the membrane and increased abruptly after several hours of UV irradiation. This inflection behavior appeared earlier at higher temperature of the membrane, which can be related to the permeation and adsorption characteristics of hydrogen in the Pd layer.
418	The influence of alkali metals interaction with Al/P-substituted BN nanosheets on their electronic and nonlinear optical properties: A DFT theoretical study	On the basis of the boron nitride (BN) nanosheet, the alkali-doped Al-M, Al-M&#x2032;, P-M, and P-M&#x2032; (M, M&#x2032; = Li, Na, K) electrides were designed to investigate how the dopants affect the nonlinear optical responses. The Al-M, Al-M&#x2032;, P-M, and P-M&#x2032; are obtained by doping an alkali metal atom into the corresponding Al/P-substituted BN nanosheet. The molecular orbital and density of states analysis revealed that doping the alkali metal atoms can significantly narrow the energy gaps of undoped systems, which is mainly attributed to the new high HOMO energy level containing the excess electron. Further, the loosely bound excess electron from alkali metal atom brings the considerable first hyperpolarizabilities (&#x03B2;0) to these doped systems, especially, the P-K&#x2032;possesses the largest &#x03B2;0 value of 70677 au. In addition, the &#x03B2;0 values of novel nanostructures are influenced by both the substitution effect and the doping position of the alkali metals. The further investigations show that transition energy is the decisive factor for the &#x03B2;0 value of the electride. TD-DFT calculations are performed to investigate the effect of alkali metal doping on absorption spectrum. Bathochromic shift is observed in the UV-vis spectrum of all doped systems. We hope that this study could expand the potential application of the BN-based nanosystems in the high-performance nonlinear optical materials.
419	<strong>S</strong><strong>i-core/SiGe-shell channel nanowire field-effect transistor for sub-10-nm logic technology in the THz regime</strong>	Nanowire <em>p</em>-type field-effect transistor (FET) having a SiGe shell channel on a Si core for sub-10-nm advanced logic technology is optimally designed and characterized using in-depth technology computer-aided design (TCAD) with quantum models. SiGe is adopted as the material for the ultra-thin shell channel owing to its two primary merits of high hole mobility and strong Si compatibility. The SiGe shell can effectively confine the hole by the large valence-band offset (VBO) between the Si core and SiGe channel arranged in the radial direction. To obtain simulation results with higher accuracy and credibility, the carriers&rsquo; electrical characteristic modeling and energy-band parameter engineering are carried out in the channel at different Ge fractions. Based on this approach, the proposed device is optimized in terms of the Ge shell channel thickness, Ge fraction in the SiGe channel, and channel length (<em>L</em><sub>g</sub>), by examining a set of primary DC parameters. In addition, radio-frequency (RF) parameters are investigated at sub-10-nm <em>L</em><sub>g</sub>. The cut-off frequency (<em>f</em><sub>T</sub>) and maximum oscillation frequency (<em>f</em><sub>max</sub>) of the proposed device when <em>L</em><sub>g</sub> is 5 nm are found to be 440.0 GHz and 753.9 GHz, respectively, with an intrinsic delay time (<em>&tau;</em>) of 3.14 ps. The proposed SiGe-shell-channel nanowire <em>p</em>-type FET demonstrates good potential for low-power and high-speed applications in 10-nm-and-beyond complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) technology.
420	Effects of doping on photoelectrical properties of one-dimensional &#x03B1;-Si3N4 nanomaterials: a first-principles study	The structural stability, electronic and optical properties of Al-, Y-, O-doped and Al-O-codoped one-dimensional (1D) &#x03B1;-Si3N4 nanomaterials are investigated by first-principles methods. All dopants prefer to locate at the surface of 1D &#x03B1;-Si3N4 nanomaterials except Al. The doping difficulties decrease in the order of AlSi, YSi, ON and AlSi-ON. The conduction types and band gap values of 1D &#x03B1;-Si3N4 nanomaterials are tunable by doping due to the hybridizations of impurity states with the band edges. The increases of hole and electron effective masses caused by doping are different. The doping greatly affects the optical properties of 1D &#x03B1;-Si3N4 nanomaterials mainly at and below the absorption edges. The optical parameters in the parallel direction to the axis are larger than those in the perpendicular direction. Especially if the nanomaterial was doped with Al, its optical parameters are changed most obviously, followed by those of Y-doped nanomaterial, while the differences of the O-doped and Al-O-codoped nanomaterials are not obvious.
421	<strong>Studies on Jahn-Teller distortion and magnetic transitions in GdMn<sub>1-x</sub>Fe<sub>x</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>(x= 0, 0.1, 0.2) Nanoparticles</strong>	GdMnO<sub>3</sub> perovskite compounds demonstrate para to incommensurate anti-ferromagnetic transition at 42 K (T<sub>N</sub>), an incommensurate to A type antiferromagnetic at 22 K and finally show a weak ferromagnetic behavior at 6 K. In this report, the evolution of structure and the rich sequence of magnetic transitions in GdMnO<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles synthesized through sol-gel technique have been studied after incorporating magnetic ions like Iron. GdMn<sub>1-x</sub>Fe<sub>x</sub>O<sub>3&nbsp;</sub>(x= 0, 0.1 and 0.2) show pure phase, orthorhombic structure with Pbnm space group with size ranging from 35 to 45 nm. Rietveld refinement of X-ray powder diffraction data reveals that while lattice parameters, a and b contract, the lattice parameter, c, shows an expansion with increase in Fe concentration which confirms the O' type orthorhombic structure. We observe a decrease in J-T distortion factor with increase in Fe concentration. Decrease in Jahn-Teller (J-T) distortion further corroborates with the decrease in intensity of asymmetric stretching bond observed at 487 cm<sup>-1</sup> from Raman measurement. The lattice parameter contraction is attributed to the presence of Mn<sup>4+</sup> accompanied with increase in oxygen vacancies confirmed from XPS and EXAFS analysis. The temperature dependent magnetization while show an increase in T<sub>N</sub> from 25 K at x= 0 to 36 K at x= 0.2, the magnetic transitions at 11 and 5 K does not show significant change with Fe doping. Spin dynamics of GdMn<sub>1-x</sub>Fe<sub>x</sub>O<sub>3&nbsp;</sub>(x= 0, 0.1 and 0.2) are discussed using the phenomenological models like Neel-Arrhenius, Vogel-Fulcher and Power law.
422	Reaction of N,N'-dimethylformamide and divalent viologen molecule to generate an organic dopant for molybdenum disulfide	Carrier doping of transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDC) is of fundamental importance for enabling a wide range of atomically-thin optoelectronic devices. 423	A multiscale approach for percolation transition using a nucleation and growth model and its application to cement setting	Percolation is commonly observed phenomenon in nature, where a spanning cluster is formed by linking neighboring sites. Studies to estimate the percolation threshold are generally prone to finite size effects. Here, a dynamic multi-scale model virtually free from finite size effects is presented, considering cement setting as an example of off-lattice uncorrelated bond percolation. A statistical approach is developed, where a nano colloidal kinetic Monte Carlo nucleation and growth algorithm describes the formation of hydration products. The model unveils the crucial role of hydration product nano texture on the degree of hydration at setting and explain why it remains largely unaffected under general usage conditions. Our ex-professo experiments afterwards confirms these predictions
424	<strong>Mg <em>vs.</em> Oxygen vacancy in boosting high temperature ferromagnetism in MgO nanocrystallite: An experimental and DFT based study</strong>	Oxygen vacancies are considered responsible for the room temperature ferromagnetism in transition metal oxide (TMOs) systems. In contrast, ferromagnetism in MgO nanocrystallite is regulated by the presence of Mg vacancies. Herein, this conclusion is realized by us both experimentally as well as through density functional theoretical (DFT) calculation.&nbsp; MgO nanocrystallite is grown in at 500 <sup>0</sup>C, 650 <sup>0</sup>C and 800 <sup>0</sup>C under oxygen-rich condition. It is observed that sample grown at 800 <sup>0</sup>C exhibits the highest saturation magnetisation with a Curie temperature approaching 850 K. <em>Rapid cooling </em>in air and heat treatment under an&nbsp;oxygen-poor condition at 200 <sup>0</sup>C for 5 h results in the reduction in saturation magnetisation. EPR results have confirmed that the air calcined samples have Mg vacancy centre, whereas vacuum calcined samples show signals corresponding to Mg vacancy as well as a signal related to the oxygen vacancy. With the support of DFT study, it is surmised that the high-temperature ferromagnetism for samples grown in oxygen-rich condition is due to the spin polarisation of the oxygen atoms surrounding the Mg vacancy.
425	Beating pattern in radiation-induced oscillatory magnetoresistance in 2DES: coupling of plasmon-like and acoustic phonon modes.	We present a microscopic theory on the observation of a beating pattern in the<br />radiation-induced magnetoresistance oscillations at very low magnetic field. We consider that such a beating pattern<br />develops as a result of the coupling between two oscillatory components:<br />the first is a system of electron Landau states<br />being harmonically driven by radiation. The second is a lattice oscillation, i.e.,<br /> an acoustic phonon mode. We analyze the dependence of the<br />beating pattern on temperature, radiation frequency and power.<br />We conclude that the beating pattern is an evidence of the radiation-driven<br />nature of the irradiated Landau states that makes them behave as a collective plasma oscillation<br />at the radiation frequency. Thus, the frequency of such plasmons could be tuned from<br />microwave to terahertz in the same nanodevice with an apparent technological application.
426	Using saturated H2O-ZnO nanofluid porous medium for cooling electronics contained in a inclined hemispherical enclosure	A nanofluid saturated porous medium is used for cooling plane electronic device contained in the base of a hemispherical cavity. According to the intended application in embarked electronics, the base could be tilted with respect to the horizontal plane by an angle ranging between 0&deg; and 180&deg; (horizontal disc with cupola facing upwards and downwards respectively). The volume fraction of the considered water-based ZnO nanofluid varies between 0 (pure water) and 10%, while the Rayleigh number based on the radius of the cavity ranges between 5.21x10<sup>7</sup> and 7.29x10<sup>10</sup>. The ratio between the thermal conductivity of the solid matrix of the porous medium and that of the base fluid varies between 0 and 70.<sup> </sup>Influence of these four parameters on the average temperature of the active electronic device is presented and commented. The work shows that the saturated porous medium has a significant effect on the thermal state of the electronic device. A correlation is proposed to easily calculate this temperature for any combination of these parameters, which allows thermal sizing for optimal cooling of this assembly used in electronics engineering.
427	<strong>Deformation mode transitions</strong><strong> in MgAl/Mg nanoscale amorphous/crystalline multilayers: A molecular dynamics study</strong>	The deformation behavior of MgAl/Mg nanoscale amorphous/crystalline multilayers (NACMs) with equal layer thicknesses of amorphous and crystalline phases under tension loading is investigated by molecular dynamics simulation method. The results show that the plastic deformation mode of NACMs changes from cross generalized shear bands dominated deformation to finally single SB plastic deformation with the increase of layer thickness, and the plastic deformation of NACMs with medium layer thickness is realized through cooperative interactions between crystalline layer, amorphous layer and amorphous/crystalline interfaces (ACIs), which could be treated as a transition progress. The results indicate that the peak stresses of the NACMs are greater than that of monolithic amorphous regardless of layer thickness, which is likely to result from the increase of the strong crystalline phase and the strengthening effect of the ACIs. The results also reveal that the ductility and strength of NACMs could be improved effectively by choosing the appropriate layer thicknesses. In addition, the deformation behavior of NACMs is also quantificationally disclosed and analyzed in current study.
428	Two-frequency undulator in a short SASE FEL for angstrom wavelengths	We perform theoretical study and modeling of harmonic evolution in X-ray single-pass free-electron laser (FEL) with two-frequency undulator. For this purpose a verified phenomenological FEL model is adopted, which accounts for all losses individually for each harmonic. The model was tested with FEL experiments, covering the radiation wavelengths range 0.15&ndash;300 nm. The phenomenological description, based on few main FEL parameters: electron beam current, energy and its spread, divergence, proves to give good match with measurements in various conditions. It is employed to model harmonic bunching and power evolution in an X-band FEL with two-frequency undulator, where 1-st and 3-rd harmonics are suppressed by 2&pi;/5 phase shift of the electrons respectively to photons between the undulator sections. The advantages of the two-frequency undulator in such phase-shifted X-ray FEL are highlighted. FEL-induced energy-spread evolution becomes 3 times lower, than in a common FEL. The possibility to produce intense X-ray radiation by dominant 5-th harmonic in linear regime is demonstrated. Radiation at sub-nanometric wavelength &lambda;<sub>5</sub>=0.15 nm from electrons with 5.47 GeV energy and ~3.66 kA current reaches ~14 GW power already at 30 m. This constitutes a half of a FEL length, where common planar undulator radiates the same wavelength and power by the fundamental harmonic. The power boost and reduction of the saturation length by half are complemented by 2.5 times lower electron energy. The harmonic power increase can be up to 10<sup>4</sup> times respectively to that in a common planar undulator FEL.
429	Chemical Synthesis and magnetic properties of Co<sub>2</sub>FeGa nanoparticles	We report the successful synthesis of Co$_2$FeGa nanoparticles by chemical method and characterization using x-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), selected area electron diffraction (SAED) and magnetic measurements. The Rietveld refinements of XRD data with space group Fm$\bar {3}$m clearly show the formation of B2 disorder single phase. The particle size (D) decreases with increasing the SiO$_2$ concentration. The Bragg peaks and the parameters extracted from high-resolution TEM and SAED pattern are in well agreement with XRD. The coercivity initially increases from 8.5~nm to 12.5~nm, which follow the D$^{-3/2}$ dependence and then starts decreasing (D$^{-1}$ dependence) with increasing D. The critical size is found in between 12.5 to 16~nm in these nanoparticles. The effective magnetic anisotropic constant behaves similarly as coercivity, which indicates the transition from single domain to multi-domain regime as the domain structure changes significantly with the particle size.
430	Broadband voltage rectifier induced by linear bias dependence in CoFeB/MgO magnetic tunnel junctions	In this paper, the perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (PMA) is tailored by changing the thickness of the free layer with the objective of producing MTJ nano-pillars with smooth linear resistance dependence with both in-plane magnetic field and DC bias. We furthermore demonstrate how this linear bias dependence can be used to create a zero-threshold broadband voltage rectifier, a feature which is important for rectification in wireless charging and energy harvesting applications. By carefully balancing the amount of PMA acting in the free layer the measured RF to DC voltage conversion efficiency can be made as large as 11%.
431	<strong>An <em>in silico</em> Inter-subject Variability Study of Extra-thoracic Morphology Effects on Inhaled Particle Transport and Deposition</strong>	An understanding of human inter-subject variability is crucial for the implementation of personalized pulmonary drug delivery as well as exposure assessment of airborne hazardous materials. However, due to the lack of statistically robust data and subsequent comparisons, the influence of human respiratory morphology on inhaled nano-/micro-particle transport and deposition is still not fully known. Thus, focusing on identifying geometric parameters that significantly influence airflow and inhaled particle transport/deposition, an experimentally validated Computational Fluid-Particle Dynamics (CFPD) model based on the Euler-Lagrange method is developed. &nbsp;To enhance the statistical robustness of the investigation, a virtual population group is created that contains seven distinct and widely used human upper-airway configurations, where the same tracheobronchial trees are extended to Generation 6. Numerical results and the inter-subject variability analysis indicate that the glottis constriction is the morphological parameter that significantly impacts the inhaled particle dynamics in the respiratory tract. For reasons of statistical robustness, anatomical features of the upper airways should be maintained to capture the <em>personalized</em> airflow and particle transport dynamics for particles smaller than 500 nm or larger than 2 &micro;m. However, a single upper airway model, representing a basic subpopulation group, can be employed to evaluate the <em>total</em> deposition of particles in the diameter range of 500 nm&lt;d<sub>p</sub>&lt;2 &micro;m. The present study provides an <em>in silico</em> lung-aerosol dynamics framework with detailed particle-deposition results and new physical insight. It may serve as a guide for implementing optimal targeting of inhaled drug-aerosols and for the assessment of hazardous aerosol exposure in distinct populations.
432	Protein Encapsulation via Polyelectrolyte Complex Coacervation: Protection against Protein Denaturation	Complex coacervation can be used as a route to compartmentalize a variety of solutes such as organic small molecules, inorganic nanoparticles as well as proteins within microscale coacervate droplets. To obtain insight into the accumulation of proteins within complex coacervate phases, the encapsulation of BSA within complex coacervates containing cationic polyelectrolyte poly(allylamine hydrochloride) (PAH) and anionic polyelectrolyte poly (acrylic aid) (PAA) was investigated as a function of mixing sequence, total polyelectrolyte concentration, BSA overall concentration, as well as the mixing molar ratio of PAA/PAH. Mixing BSA having a negative net charge with the polycation PAH before coacervation, increasing the total polyelectrolyte concentration and PAA/PAH molar ratio, or decreasing the BSA overall concentration led to more efficient protein encapsulation. Preservation of secondary structure of BSA during the complex coacervation process was confirmed using circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy. Our study shows that PAA-PAH coacervates can serve as protective system against the denaturation of BSA when exposed to extremes of pH, high temperatures, as well as in solution of urea. Additionally, it was found that by encapsulation of protein within coacervates via complex coacervation, the complexation between protein and heavy metal can be efficiently inhibited. Protection of BSA against severe environmental conditions via encapsulation within polyelectrolyte coacervates provides new insights and methods to issues of maintaining stability and function of proteins.
433	Effect of Calcium Ions on the Interactions between Surfaces End-Grafted With Weak Polyelectrolytes	The effect of multivalent ions on the interactions between two opposing surfaces grafted with weak polyelectrolytes was studied using a molecular theory.  More specifically, we study the interactions between two planar surfaces end-tethered with poly(acrylic acid) polymers in electrolyte solutions containing calcium ions. It is found that by adding divalent calcium ions to an aqueous solution of monovalent ions leads to a dramatic reduction in the size and range of effective interactions between the two polymer layers. This is caused  by the formation of favorable  calcium bridges, i.e., complexes of one calcium ion and two  carboxylic acid monomers, that  reduce effective charge sof the polymer layers and, at sufficient calcium ion concentrations, can cause the polymer  layers to collapse. For calcium ion concentrations above  approximately 1mM the repulsions between the opposing end-grafted surfaces disappears and attractions occur. These attractions are correlated with the occurrence of interlayer divalent calcium bridges  and do not occur for poly(acrylic acid) layers in contact with reservoir solutions containing only monovalent ions.  This result indicates the suitability of divalent calcium ions to control andschange the interaction range and strength, which is a useful  property that is desirable in the design of stimuli-responsive nanomaterials.
434	Long-range Synchronization of Nanomechanical Oscillators with Light	We experimentally demonstrate mutual synchronization of two free-running nanomechanical oscillators separated<br />by an effective distance of 28.5 meters and coupled through light. Due to the finite speed of light, the<br />large separation introduces a significant coupling delay of 139 nanoseconds, approximately four and a half<br />times the mechanical oscillation time period. We reveal multiple stable states of synchronized oscillations,<br />enabled by delayed coupling, with distinct synchronization frequencies in the coupled system. These states are<br />accessed by tuning independently the directional coupling strengths. Our results demonstrate rich dynamics<br />and can potentially simplify oscillator networks for neuromorphic computing.
435	Fast resolution change in neutral helium atom microscopy	In neutral helium atom microscopy, a beam of atoms is scanned across a surface. Though still in its infancy neutral helium microscopy has seen a rapid development over the last few years. The inertness and low energy of the helium atoms (less than 0.1 eV) combined with a very large depth of field and the fact that the helium atoms do not penetrate any solid material at low energies, open the possibility for a non-destructive instrument that can measure topology on the nanoscale even on fragile and insulating surfaces. The resolution is determined by the size of the beam (probe). Fast resolution change is an attractivesproperty of a microscope because it allows different aspects of a sample to be investigated and makes it easier to identify specific features. However up till now it has not been possible to change the resolution of a helium microscope without breaking the vacuum and change parts of the atom source. Here we present a modified source design, which allows fast, step wise resolution change. The basic design idea is to insert a moveable holder with a series of collimating apertures in front of the source, thus changing the effective source size of the beam and thereby the spot size on the surface and thus the microscope resolution. We demonstrate a design with 3 resolution steps. The number of resolution steps can easily be extended.
436	<strong>GaAs/GaNAs core-multishell nanowires with nitrogen concentration over 2%</strong>	We report the growth of GaAs/GaNAs/GaAs core-multishell nanowires having N concentrations over 2%. The structures were grown by plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy using constituent Ga-induced vapor-liquid-solid growth on Si(111) substrates. The GaNAs shell nominally contains 0%, 2%, and 3% of nitrogen. The performed cross-sectional scanning transmission electron microscopy measurements confirm the existence of intended core-multishell structure.
