The performed room temperature micro-photoluminescence measurements reveal a red shift of the detected emission with increasing N content in the nanowires, consistent with the expected changes in the GaNAs bandgap energy due to the bowing effect.
437	<strong>Microstructures and magnetic properties of Tb-Fe-Co magnetic nanowire arrays prepared by electrochemical deposition</strong>	Highly ordered Tb-Fe-Co nanowires have been synthesized from Tb-Fe-Co aqueous solution by direct current electrochemical deposition with anodic alumina templates for the first time. The amorphous Tb-Fe phase and Tb-Co phase in as-deposited Tb-Fe-Co nanowires are transformed into Fe2Tb and Co2Tb crystal phases after annealed at 600&#x2103; for 3 h. Tb-Fe-Co nanowires have strong magnetic shape anisotropy. Comparing with the magnetic properties of Fe-Co nanowires, the coercivity and remanence ratio of annealed Tb-Fe-Co nanowires doped with Tb element increase significantly. The study about the impact of the doped rare earth elements Tb on Fe-Co nanowires may provide a way to improve the magnetic properties, and Tb-Fe-Co nanowires will certainly play an important role in future device research of magnetic recording devices.
438	Highly sensitive wearable strain sensor based on ultra-violet/ozone cracked carbon nanotube/elastomer	To simultaneously achieve high sensitivities (&gt; 100) and large stretchability (&gt; 50%) is still a grand challenge in developing the wearable strain sensors. In this study, a strain sensor with a high sensitivity up to 1020.2 and large stretchability of 100% was developed based on ultra-violet/ozone (UV/O<sub>3</sub>) cracked carbon nanotube/elastomers. The high sensitivity is ascribed to the widening of the cut-through cracks generated by the UV/O<sub>3</sub> surface engineering process. The UV/O<sub>3</sub>-cracked strain sensors show the potential application in electronic skins to detect various human motion signals such as bending of wrist, pulsing, and eye blinking.
439	Magnetic Moment and Magnetic Anisotropy of Co$_3$W Nanoclusters, Freestanding Surface, Co$|$Co$_3$W Bilayer and Superlattice by Density-Functional-Based Calculations	The cheaper permanent magnetic nanostructures with magnetic properties equivalent to noble-metal or rare-earth nanomagnets have been experimentally developed for their potential applications in ultrahigh-storage densities in magnetic memory. However, their intrinsic magnetic properties is not well understood under a microscope level. In this work, we performed the theoretical investigations on Co$_3$W bulk, freestanding surface, nanoclusters, as well as Co$|$Co$_3$W bilayer and superlattice for their magnetic moments, magnetic anisotropy energy (MAEs), and electronic structures. Our constructed Co$_3$W nanoclusters are stable and their stabilities increase with W proportion and particle size (up to 1.2 nm). It was well established that Co and W atoms are antiferromagnetically coupled and their magnetic magnitudes decrease with the increasing W proportion. The experimentally observed breakdown of the Hund's third rule in W atoms can be interpreted as the competitions between the intra-atomic SOC in W atoms and Co-W inter-atomic hybridizations. The highest MAE value, about few ten meV, was obtained in small sizes, whereas it is an order of magnitude reduction in large sizes. For Co$_3$W freestanding surface, Co$|$Co$_3$W bilayer and superlattice, they present the large perpendicular MAEs. Our magnetic moment and MAE have the same order of the magnitude of recently experimental measurements, and their electronic origination is revealed through the second-order perturbation method.
440	<strong>Highly Efficient Hybrid Bulk Heterojunction Organic Solar Cells Integrating PbS Nanoparticles </strong>	A brief study on the binary and ternary blended nanostructured based hybrid organic solar cells was conducted. The active layer of the prepared devices composed of constant ratios of the electron donating organic semiconductor, P3HT-poly(3-hexylthiophene) and the electron accepting fullerene <em>PCBM</em>-[6,6] phenyl-C61-<em>butyric acid methyl ester</em> with various ratios of an inorganic semiconductor PbS dissolved in CB-chlorobenzene and DCB. The effect of various concentrations of nanoparticles on the performance of P3HT/PCBM was examined. The PCE - power conversion efficiency with NPs doping in the polymer active layer was improved significantly under standard irradiance (100mW/cm<sup>2</sup>, AM1.5G). This increase in efficiency was owing to decrease in series resistance-Rs with the conjugation of PbS NPs in a blend of the organics active layer. The morphological and optical properties were investigated with FESEM, AFM and UV-visible spectrophotometer respectively.<sup> </sup>
441	Probing flexoelectricity via a split Hopkinson pressure bar experiment	Flexoelectricity is thought of as a universal property of all dielectric materials that couples polarization with the inhomogeneous deformation. However, at the macroscale, this coupling is usually very weak and the direct observation of flexoelectricity always suffers by low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). At the micron or submicron scale, both the flexoelectric effect and some surface effects may get pronounced simultaneously. To separate the flexoelectric effect from those surface effects and accurately measure the bulk flexoelectric coefficients is challenging. In this paper, we propose a novel high SNR method for measuring the bulk flexoelectric coefficient &nbsp;of millimeter-sized samples through split Hopkinson pressure bar (SHPB) experiments. Our experimental results show that for normal impact speed (17m/s) of the striker bar, the induced voltage difference is as high as 70mV which can be easily measured without using signal amplifiers. In most of previous works of measuring flexoelectric coefficients, strain gradients are introduced through the design of samples&rsquo; shape such as thin beams, thin films, truncated cones and pyramids. In a different way, the proposed SHPB based approach introduces time varied strains to the system and then converts time gradients of strains into their spatial gradients through elastic waves. As a promising way of measuring bulk flexoelectric coefficients, this approach produces high SNR flexoelectric signals, reduces the interferences from surface effects, and avoids the difficulties in fabricating nanostructures.
442	Electronic, Magnetic and Transport properties of silicene Armchair nanoribbons substituted with monomer and dimer of Fe atom	This study employed density functional theory calculations to investigate the structural, electronic and magnetic properties of an armchair silicene nanoribbon (ASiNR) substituted with a monomer and a dimer of Fe atom. As a result, the direct band gap of pristine ASiNR turns into a smaller indirect band gap by substituting an Fe atom in the proper position. The magnetic moment of doped Fe reduces and the structure keeps its nonmagnetic property. The substitution of the Fe-dimer can change the pristine ASiNR from a nonmagnetic semiconductor to a magnetic half-metal, which is favorable for spintronic devices. Two external electric fields were applied to the structure substituted with the Fe-dimer and electronic properties were studied in this situation. It was shown that the Fe-dimer substituted ASiNR is such a versatile material that a band gap can be tuned by using an external transverse electric field. Furthermore, the transport properties of these two structures were studied with non-equilibrium Greens function formalism. It is intriguing that single-spin negative differential resistance was observed in the Fe-dimer doped ASiNR.
443	A multiscale approach for percolation transition using a nucleation and growth model and its application to cement setting	Percolation is commonly observed phenomenon in nature, where a spanning cluster is formed by linking neighboring sites. Studies to estimate the percolation threshold are generally prone to finite size effects. Here, a dynamic multi-scale model virtually free from finite size effects is presented, considering cement setting as an example of off-lattice uncorrelated bond percolation. A statistical approach is developed, where a nano colloidal kinetic Monte Carlo nucleation and growth algorithm describes the formation of hydration products. The model unveils the crucial role of hydration product nano texture on the degree of hydration at setting and explain why it remains largely unaffected under general usage conditions. Our ex-professo experiments afterwards confirms these predictions.
444	<strong>SYNTHESIS AND CHARACTERIZATION OF</strong><strong>LaMn<sub>1-x</sub>Fe<sub>x</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (x = 0, 0.1, 0.2)</strong><strong> BY </strong><strong>COPRECIPITATION</strong><strong> ROUTE</strong>	Perovskite type oxides are fascinating nanomaterials and its physical properties of interest to materials science through perovskites include superconductivity, magnetoresistance, ionic conductivity, and a multitude of dielectric properties, which are of great importance in microelectronics and telecommunication. Recently interest has arisen in perovskite-type oxides as catalysts due to high thermal and hydrothermal stability as well as high mechanical strength among other properties. In the present work, LaMn<sub>1-x</sub>Fe<sub>x</sub>O<sub>3</sub> perovskite was synthesized by the co-precipitation method. The product was characterized with X-ray diffractometer (XRD), Scanning electron microscope (SEM), Energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), UV-visible absorption spectroscopy and conductivity study. The XRD pattern confirmed the formation of perovskite phase. The SEM micrographs indicated that the morphology contain porosity due to inter-particle voids. The presence of functional groups of the pure and doped lanthanum manganite were studied by FTIR. The optical band gap decrease with increasing the content of iron in the sample. The conductivity study confirmed that the conductivity increases with increasing the content of iron.
445	Effect of cholesterol on the binding of the precursor neurotransmitter tryptophan to zwitterionic membranes	The characterization of the microscopical forces between the essential -amino-acid tryptophan, precursor of the neurotransmitter serotonin and of the hormone melatonin, and the basic components of cell membranes and their environments (phospholipids, cholesterol, ionic species and water) is of central importance to elucidate their local structure and dynamics as well as the mechanisms responsible for the access of tryptophan to the interior of the cell. We have performed nanosecond molecular dynamics simulations of tryptophan embedded in model zwitterionic bilayer membranes made by di-palmytoil-phosphatidyl-choline and cholesterol inside aqueous sodium-chloride solution in order to systematically examine tryptophan-lipid, tryptophan-cholesterol and tryptophan-water interactions at the corresponding human body temperature and salt concentration. Microscopic properties such as the area per lipid, lipid thickness, radial distribution functions, hydrogen-bonding lengths, potentials of mean force, atomic spectral densities and self-diusion coe;cients have been evaluated. Our results show that the presence of tryptophan signicantly aects the structure and dynamics of the membrane. Tryptophan spends long periods of time at the water-membrane interface and it plays a central role by bridging a few lipids and cholesterol chains by means of hydrogen-bonds. The computed spectral densities, in excellent agreement with experimental infrared and Raman data, revealed the participation of each atomic site of tryptophan to the complete spectrum of the molecule. Tryptophan self-diusion coe;cients have been found to be in between 10^(-7) and 10^(-6) cm2/s and strongly depending of the concentration of cholesterol in the system.
446	Near-infrared light absorption enhancement in Ge nanostructures prepared by nano-sphere lithography	In the present work, Ge nanostructures were prepared by using polystyrene nano-sphere lithography technique. By changing the diameter of the nano-spheres and controlling the etching time, Ge nanostructures with various morphologies were obtained which exhibited the good anti-reflection and optical absorption enhancement characteristics, especially in the near infrared light spectral range (900-1500nm). The optical properties of Ge nanostructures were also simulated by the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) solutions by building the model based on the observed Ge nanostructures. It was suggested that Ge nanostructures etched by using large-sized nano-spheres, like 2000nm, can significantly suppress the reflection of incident light in a wide spectral range but absorb the near infrared light more efficiently compared with the visible light.
447	Direct Ink Writing of 3D Honeycombed CL-20 Structures with High Performance	3D Honeycombed CL-20 structures have been fabricated for intelligent weapon systems by direct ink writing technology. The CL-20/WPU/EC composite ink with high detonation performance was deposited through a fine nozzle on the substrate by a layer-by-layer sequence to produce the 3D structures. Preparation of the composite ink, as well as the principles of the direct ink writing process was investigated systematically. The deposited explosive composite materials has a honeycombed structure with high porosity. No phase change was observed during the preparation process. Waterborne polyurethane (WPU) and ethyl cellulose (EC) show good compatibility with CL-20 particles. Higher apparent activation energy was obtained in CL-20-based composite ink comparing with that of nano-CL-20 due to the presence of non-energetic but stable WPU. The detonation performance of the composite materials can be precisely controlled by adjusting the content of binders. Detonation tests show that the 3D honeycombed CL-20 structures fabricated by DIW have a very small critical detonation size of less than 108 &#x03BC;m, which presents a bright future for the development of intelligent weapon systems.
448	Negative Differential Resistance Effect Aroused by a Unique Carrier Transport in X-like Graphene Nanoribbon Structure	In this paper, a novel twisted X-like armchair graphene nanoribbon (X-AGNR) structure, which exhibits negative differential resistance (NDR), is proposed. Investigating with the quantum simulation based on self-consistent Extended Huckel method, the X-AGNR device shows significant NDR effect when the twist angle is larger than 40 degrees. Through the detailed analysis of X-AGNR&rsquo;s transport properties, we uncover the NDR effect is caused by the match and mismatch of carrier transport channels on the two edges of the twisted region. The value of current peak and the peak-to-valley current ratio (PVCR) can be modulated by the twist angle and size effect. This novel transport mechanism enriches the modulation methods of low-dimensional structure&rsquo;s NDR phenomenon and inspires a new idea to the development of graphene devices.
449	Femtosecond laser-induced transformations in ultra-low expansion glass:  microstructure and local density variations by vibrational spectroscopy	We report X-ray diffraction, resonance Raman and infrared (IR) results on pristine ultra-low expansion (ULE) glass, a binary titanosilicate glass with 5.67 mol% TiO2.  Besides applications requiring high geometrical stability at room temperature, ULE processing by femtosecond (fs) laser radiation leads to nanogratings writing and photo-darkening for imaging and data storage. The knowledge gained here on pristine ULE is employed to understand the transformation mechanisms in this glass by fs laser irradiation at 515 nm. Optical imaging revealed the formation of micro-cavities, and Raman mapping showed molecular oxygen trapped in such cavities of laser-irradiated ULE glass. While titanium in pristine ULE was found predominantly in tetrahedral Ti4+ sites highly dispersed in the silicate matrix, Raman and IR reflectance spectroscopy on laser-irradiated ULE indicated the formation of Ti3+ sites; Ti3+ octahedral sites are formed in the shells of cavities and aggregate in amorphous Ti2O3-type clusters, while the glass around and below cavities contains Ti3+ tetrahedral sites dispersed in the silicate network. Laser-processed ULE glass was found to exhibit also local restructuring of the silicate matrix. Shifts of the strong IR band at about 1080-1100 cm-1 were translated into changes of the average Si-O-Si bond angle in the laser-transformed areas, and found to reflect local density variations; the average local density increases relative to silica glass by about 8% in the shells of micro-cavities and decreases by about 0.5% in the surrounding material. Chemical processes were proposed to account for photo-darkening and local structural transformation effect in the probed areas of the fs laser-processed ULE glasses.
450	Swelling of Nanodomains in Hydrated Block Copolymer Electrolyte Membranes	In this work, we examine the swelling of nanostructured block copolymer electrolytes immersed in liquid water. A series of sulfonated polystyrene-b-polyethylene-b-polystyrene (S-SES) membranes having the same nominal chemical composition but two different morphologies are prepared by systematic changes in processing. We start with a membrane comprising a mixture of homopolymer polystyrene (hPS) and a polystyrene-b-polyethylene-b-polystyrene (SES) copolymer. Homopolymer hPS is subsequently selectively removed from the membrane and the polystyrene domains are sulfonated to give S-SES membranes. The morphology of the membranes is controlled by controlling &#x03D5;v, the volume fraction of hPS in the blended membrane. The morphology of the membranes was studied by small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), cryogenic scanning transmission electron microscopy (cryo-STEM) and cryogenic electron tomography. The overall domain swelling measured by SAXS decreases slightly at &#x03D5;v =0.29; a cross-over from lamellar to bicontinuous morphology is obtained at the same value of &#x03D5;v. The bicontinuous morphologies absorb more water than the lamellar morphologies.  In contrast, the nanodomain swelling of the bicontinuous membrane is slightly less than that of the lamellar membrane.  Quantitative analysis of the STEM images and electron tomography was used determine the swelling on the hydrophilic and hydrophobic domains due to exposure to water.  The hydrophilic PSS-rich domain spacing increases while the hydrophobic PE domain spacing decreases when the membranes are hydrated.  The extent of increase and decrease is not a strong function of &#x03D5;v.
451	Observation of the Hanle effect in giant magnetoresistance measurements	We report the observation of the Hanle effect in the giant magnetoresistance measurement of metallic lateral nanostructures. By applying magnetic fields perpendicularly to the magnetization of the electrodes, we obtain resistance values lower than that of the parallel magnetization state, due to the extra decoherence provided by the random propagation time of the carriers. An analytical model is developed, enabling us to extract the characteristic transport parameters of CoFe, Al and Cu from the fitting of the experimental results. We compare the obtained parameters to that of standard non-local Hanle measurements in lateral spin-valves, with the interest that this measurement configuration gives much larger signal variation.
452	<strong>EBSD-Investigation and Magnetic Properties of Manganese Ferrite Crystallized in a Sodium-Silicate Glass</strong>	Glasses in the system (100 - x)(0.16Na<sub>2</sub>O/0.10MnO/0.74SiO<sub>2</sub>)/xFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, (x = 5&ndash;25<sub> </sub>in mol %)<sub> </sub>were prepared using the traditional melt-quenching technique. They were subsequently crystallized at temperatures in the range from 520 to 700 &deg;C for times ranging from 10 min to 100 h. The elemental composition and the valence states of selected glasses and glass-ceramics were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and showed the presence of Mn<sup>2+</sup> while Fe occurs as both Fe<sup>2+</sup> and Fe<sup>3+</sup>. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses showed the crystallization of a solid solution of the cubic spinel phases MnFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> and/or Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> but for higher temperatures and longer annealing times, also the crystallization of aegirine, NaFe(SiO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. The average spinel crystallite size was determined to range from 4 to 10 nm by XRD. The microstructure was investigated by scanning and transmission electron microscopy (SEM and TEM) as well as electron-backscatter diffraction (EBSD). The EBSD analyses show that the cubic crystals grow via the polygon as well as the dendritic growth mechanisms. The individual grains show independent orientations and inclusions of residual glass while a crystallographic texture could not be detected. The obtained magnetization curves for the compositions in which nanosized spinel crystals precipitate showed that samples crystallized at 650 and 700 &deg;C are superparamagnetic and exhibit thin S-shaped magnetization curves with zero coercivity.
453	<strong>Influence of ERTA on magnetocaloric properties of Sr doped BaFe<sub>12</sub>O<sub>19 </sub>thin films for cryogenics</strong>	The effect of electron beam rapid thermal annealing (ERTA) on the crystallographic, structural, magnetic and magnetocaloric properties of Sr doped M-type barium hexaferrite thin films (Ba<sub>1-x</sub>Sr<sub>x</sub>Fe<sub>12</sub>O<sub>19</sub>) deposited on silicon (001) substrates were investigated. The effect of electron beam rapid thermal annealing (ERTA) on the crystallographic, structural, magnetic and magnetocaloric properties. Amorphous to crystalline phase transitions occurred when the as-deposited thin films were annealed, however crystallinity reduced as a function of Sr concentration. The as-deposited thin films showed uniform grain size and distribution with reduction in grain size as a function of Sr concentration, whereas annealed thin films showed agglomerated structures that increased in numbers as a function of Sr concentration. As-deposited thin films with x = 0, 0.5 and 1.0 showed anti-ferromagnetic, weak ferromagnetic and super-paramagnetic response, respectively. Magnetic hysteresis loops and magnetic force microscopy images indicated improved c-axis in-plane magnetization with reduced coercivity for Sr doped thin films, and saturation magnetization for thin films subjected to ERTA. The Arrott plots in positive quadrant suggested a typical M-type ferrite behaviour with second-order ferromagnetic phase transitions around the Curie temperature. The entropy changes associated with magnetic phase transitions were determined using magnetization measurements performed in the range of 50-105 K for as-deposited and 65-125 K for ERTA samples under different magnetic fields. The calculated maximum relative cooling power (RCP) of the as-deposited and ERTA thin films are1941 mJ/cc and 3065 mJ/cc for 50 kOe magnetic fields. This makes Ba<sub>1-x</sub>Sr<sub>x</sub>Fe<sub>12</sub>O<sub>19 </sub>with x=1 a promising candidate for micro and nano magnetic refrigeration systems.
454	<strong>Eliminating Common Biases in Modeling Electrical Conductivity of Carbon Nanotubes-Polymer Nanocomposites</strong>	Modelling electrical conductivity of carbon-nanotubes (CNT)-polymer nanocomposites demands high computational power. A common approach to circumvent this challenge is by using a small cubic representative volume element (RVE) to simulate CNT conductive network in a polymer matrix. By assuming these networks follow a periodic pattern, any randomly dispersed CNT that protrudes outside the RVE is cut and relocated to point into the RVE from the opposite boundary surface. Representing dispersed CNT by a random resistor network, simulations revealed that the &ldquo;cut-and-relocate&rdquo; approach led to significantly higher CNT concentration in proximity of RVE&rsquo;s walls and shorter CNT length. These biases resulted in inaccurate representative of the morphology of CNT-polymer nanocomposites. This work revealed that using a double-box RVE model and removing any cut CNT protrudes outside the RVE can eliminate the biases and improve simulation accuracy.
455	<strong>Electric switching of visible and infrared transmission using liquid crystals co-doped with plasmonic gold nanorods and dichroic dyes</strong>	Smart windows and many other applications require synchronous or alternating facile electric switching of transmitted light intensity in visible and near infrared spectral ranges, but most electrochromic devices suffer from slow, nonuniform switching, high power consumption and limited options for designing spectral characteristics. Here we develop a guest-host mesostructured composite with rod-like dye molecules and plasmonic nanorods spontaneously aligned either parallel or orthogonally to the director of the liquid crystal host. This composite material enables fast, low-voltage electric switching of electromagnetic radiation in visible and infrared ranges, which can be customized depending on the needs of applications, like climate-dependent optimal solar gain control in smart windows.
456	Influence of plasma-modified nanosilica from rice husks on mechanical properties of epoxy composites	Agricultural wastes such as rice husks was utilized as nanosilica (nSiO2) source. Plasma modification of nSiO2 powders was conducted using a capacitively coupled 13.56 MHz RF plasma under an admixture of argon and hexamethyldisiloxane (HMDSO) or 1,7-octadiene (OD) monomers. Incorporation of plasma-treated nSiO2 at 1% and 5% loading volumes exhibits a more hydrophobic epoxy composite due to attachment of hydrophobic functional group of the nSiO2 surface. Hardness and elastic moduli also increased as loading volume increased with the HMDSO-treated nSiO2 epoxy composite exhibiting the largest increase.
457	Bernal Stacking-Assisted Shear Exfoliation of Nanoplate Bilayers	Nanoplates such as graphene and MoS<sub>2</sub> are promising materials due to their excellent electronic and mechanical properties. The preparation of such nanoplates is, however, still challenging due to the large free energy barrier that multilayer nanoplates need to overcome during exfoliation. In case of a Bernal-stacked bilayer graphene, the binding energy between two graphene layers is about 17.8 meV per atom such that harsh chemical and/or mechanical treatment is usually necessary. In this paper, we perform extensive molecular dynamics simulations for a generic model of nanoplates, and illustrate that when the shear of a moderate shear rate is applied to the nanoplate bilayer solution, the nanoplate bilayer may exfoliate readily. In our simulations, the free energy barrier that two nanoplate layers need to overcome reaches up to 21.8 k<sub>B</sub>T, where k<sub>B</sub> and T denote the Boltzmann constant and temperature, respectively. This implies that without external stimuli, the nanoplate bilayer would hardly exfoliate. Upon the application of shear, however, the transition between different Bernal stacked conformations occurs, which provides multiple intermediate states for exfoliation and facilitates the shear exfoliation. We also find that if one were to increase the affinity between solvent and nanoplates slightly, the free energy barrier would be decreased significantly.
458	<strong>Probing migration property of cancer cells stimulated by on-chip periodic mechanical confinement</strong>	Cancer cell migration and invasion, which are involved in tumour metastasis, are hard to predict and control. Numerous studies have demonstrated that physical cues influence cancer cell migration and affect tumour metastasis. In this study, we proposed the use of a microchannel chip equipped with a number of vertical constrictions to produce periodic compression forces on cells passing through narrow channels. The chip with repeated vertical confinement was applied on adherent MHCC-97L liver cancer cells and suspended OCI-AML leukaemia cells to determine the migration ability of these cancer cells. Given the stimulation of the periodic mechanical confinement on-chip, the migration ability of cancer cells was promoted. Moreover, the migration speed increased as the stimulation was enhanced. Both AFM nanoindentation and optical stretching tests on cancer cells were performed to measure their mechanical property. After confinement stimulation, the cancer cells possessed higher deformability and lower stiffness than non-stimulating cells. The confinement stimulation altered the cell cytoskeleton, which governs the migration speed. This phenomenon was determined through gene expression analysis. The proposed on-chip cell migration assays will help characterise the migration property of cancer cells and benefit the development of new therapeutic strategies for metastasis.
459	<strong> Sensing analysis based on tunable Fano resonance in terahertz graphene-layered metamaterial</strong><strong>s</strong><strong> </strong>	We theoretically investigate the sensing characteristics based on the tunable Fano resonance in terahertz graphene-layered metamaterials. A Fano phenomenon comes from the destructive interferences in a narrow frequency range and it can lead to a high figure of merit of &sim;9786. A simple model for the sensitivity is presented and the sensitivity can reach to 7885 nm/RIU. Besides, the Fano peak becomes more and more unobvious as symmetry breaking slowly recovering. We use an appropriate theoretical theory to explain the generation of Fano phenomena. Our proposed structure and investigation may pave the way for fundamental research of the nanosensor applications and designs in highly integrated optical circuits.
460	<strong>Enhanced Nonlinear Optical Susceptibilities in Phosphorene Nanoribbons: Ab initio study</strong>	Using Density Functional Theory (DFT) method we compute linear optical absorption spectra and nonlinear optical susceptibilities of hydrogen passivated armchair and zigzag Phosphorous Nanoribbons (aPNR and zPNR) as well as &alpha;-phase phosphorous monolayer. We observe that: (a) Crystallographic direction has a strong effect on the band edge absorption which causes optical anisotropy as well as a red shift of absorption spectra by increasing the nanoribbon width. (b) The absorption values are in the order of 10<sup>5</sup> cm<sup>-1</sup> which are close to the experimentally measured values. (c) There is two orders of magnitude enhancement of the 2<sup>nd</sup> order nonlinear optical susceptibility, &chi;<sup>(2)</sup>, in nanoribbons which emanates from breaking the centro-symmetric structure of a monolayer phosphorene by hydrogen surface terminations. (d) Chief among our results is that the 3<sup>rd</sup> order susceptibility, &chi;<sup>(3)</sup>, for phosphorene monolayer and nanoribbons are about &asymp;10<sup>-13 </sup>esu (&asymp;10<sup>-21</sup> m<sup>2</sup>/V<sup>2</sup>) which are in close agreement with experimentally reported values. This strongly supports reliability of our method in calculating nonlinear optical susceptibilities of phosphorene and in general other nanostructures. Enhanced 2<sup>nd</sup> order optical nonlinearity in phosphorene promises better second harmonic and frequency difference (THz) generation for photonics applications.
461	Effect of silver doping by ion implantation on graphene nanoplatelets properties	The structural, electronic and optical properties of thin films based on physically prepared graphene nanoplatelets (GNP) doped by silver ion implantation have been studied. The silver dopant percentage relatively carbon of 1.18 % has been achieved and metal nanoparticles have been formed. The conductivity of the graphene sheet after ion implantation was found to be lowered by the presence of such graphene lattice defects. It was also shown that the surface of the GNP nanoplatelet is not planar, and there are many areas with different local orientation. It has been concluded that in spite of relatively little amount of the attached silver atoms and silver nanoparticles to the GNP surface, the essential changes of GNP structure occur during the ion implantation process, apparently breaking the structure of &#xF070;-electron system, what is confirmed by electron microscopic, Raman and electrophysical measurements.
462	Competing charge trapping and percolation in core-shell single wall carbon nanotubes/ polyaniline nanostructured composites	Core-shell single wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNT)/ polyaniline (PANI) nanocomposites were chemically synthesized and their structural, morphological, and dielectric properties were investigated as a function of the nanofiller content. FE-SEM and TEM images confirm the core-shell nanostructural features of the composites. Broadband dielectric spectroscopy allows the detection of an interfacial dielectric relaxation mechanism which is quite dependent on the dispersion of nanoparticles into the semi-conducting polyaniline matrix. Furthermore, the relaxation process analyzed through Kohlrausch-William-Watts (KWW) model, is found to take place at lower nanofiller loading but progressively fades away on increasing the amount of SWCNT, yielding relaxation spectra which gradually resemble that of a pure conductor. In addition, it is found that competing processes between electrical percolation and interfacial capacitance effects are inherently dependent on the carbon-filler contents. Such behavior is ascribed to charge trapping and de-trapping phenomenaoccurring at core-shell interfaces. The possibility of tuning the composition of the nanocomposites so as to trigger an interplay between capacitance and dc-electrical conduction is envisioned for use in the next generation organic-based supercapacitor or gate memory devices.
463	Chemical synthesis and magnetic properties of Co2FeGa nanoparticles	We report the successful synthesis of Co$_2$FeGa nanoparticles by chemical method and characterization using x-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), selected area electron diffraction (SAED) and magnetic measurements. The Rietveld refinements of XRD data with space group Fm$\bar {3}$m clearly show the formation of B2 disorder single phase. The particle size (D) decreases with increasing the SiO$_2$ concentration. The Bragg peak positions and the inter-planer spacing extracted from high-resolution TEM and SAED pattern are in well agreement with XRD. The coercivity initially increases from 8.5~nm to 12.5~nm, which follow the D$^{-3/2}$ dependence and then starts decreasing (D$^{-1}$ dependence) with increasing D. The critical size is found in between 12.5 to 16~nm in these nanoparticles. The effective magnetic anisotropic constant behaves similarly as coercivity, which indicates the transition from single domain to multi-domain regime as the domain structure changes significantly with the particle size.
464	Beneficial impact of tunneling in nano-structured intermediate-band  solar cell	Using the non equilibrium Green functions formalism we propose a study of theelectronic excitation and collection in nano-structured intermediate-band solarcell. We demonstrate that a thin tunnel barrier between the nano-objects andthe host material is beneficial for both current and voltage. For the current,the confinement generated by such a thin barrier favors the intersubbandoptical coupling in the nano-objects and then improves theexcitation-collection trade-off. We also show that a broadened density-of-statein the nano-objects increases the radiative recombination and then degrades thevoltage. Using a detailed balance model we propose a broadening factor for thisVoc degradation which decreases when a tunnel barrier enhances the life-time inthe nano-objects.
465	FORMATION OF NANODIMENSIONAL STRUCTURES ON MgO FILM SURFACE UNDER BOMBARDMENT BY LOW-ENERGY IONS	The Mg nano-films of 1-2 nm in thickness have been produced on the surface of MgO/Mg under bombardment by Ar+ ions. A composition of the Mg nano-film surface has been studied, as well as its electronic structure and morphology. A model zone-energy diagram of the Mg/MgO system has been constructed. The thin layers of Mg are potentially suitable for creating the device structures like metal-dielectric-semiconductor, nanodimensional contacts and barrier layers of the surface of semiconductor and dielectric films.
466	A novel micro-photogrammetric Instrument for visualizing in 3D small objects applied to the quantitative study of the dissolution behavior of a pharmaceutical dosage form.	3D imaging has a wide range of applications from mapping landscapes on the scale of kilometers to nano-sized objects such as computer chips. Photogrammetry is a well-established technique for creating 3D models of objects on large length scales but has not previously been applied to optical microscopy. We present the first results using a versatile instrument for micro-photogrammetry. An application of interest is the study pharmaceutical dosage forms that present particular difficulties for other methods of quantitative 3D optical imaging. We describe a novel system for studying samples of this type as applied to investigating dissolution behavior.
467	Vibrational spectroscopy via stimulated Raman induced Kerr lensing	We present a new method for the measurement of the stimulated Raman spectrum based on time-dependent spatial modulation of a laser beam as it passes through a Raman active medium. This effect is similar to the instantaneous Kerr lensing and Kerr deflection, yet involves resonant vibrations which result in a time-dependent refractive index change. We use sub-nanojoule pulses together with a sensitive pump-probe measurement apparatus to excite and detect the fine (10^-5 - 10^-4) temporal and spatial variations in intensity resulting from the Raman induced Kerr effect. We demonstrate the effect by changing the spatial overlap between the pump and probe at the sample, and measuring the time-dependent deformation of the probe beam's cross section. This method is particularly useful for detection of low frequency Raman lines, as we demonstrate by measuring Raman spectrum of neat liquids in a cuvette.
468	<strong>Nanoparticulate CdS 2D Array by Chemical Bath Deposition: </strong><strong>Characterization and Optoelectronic Study</strong>	Nanostructured CdS thin film was successfully deposited on glass substrate by chemical bath deposition (CBD) at 80 <sup>o</sup>C. The effect of deposition time on the morphology, composition, optical and optoelectronic properties of nanostructured CdS thin films has been studied. The CBD-grown CdS thin films showed assemble of interconnected nanoparticles in 2D morphology. Nanostructured CdS thin films exhibited metastable cubic phase having uniform, compact and defect-free structure with enhanced crystallinity. Tauc plot of CBD-grown nanostructured CdS thin film showed an optimum band gap of 2.30 eV and a resonant Raman peak at 302.2 cm<sup>-1</sup>. The transverse optics (TO) mode, multi-phonon scattering and high-order replicas of nanostructured CdS thin films were also observed in the Raman study. Metal-semiconductor-metal (MSM) based CdS Photodetector (PD) was fabricated for optoelectronic device characterization. Fabricated Au/CdS/Au MSM PD showed an excellent photodetectivity of 3.8x10<sup>13</sup> Jones. Photoconductive performance such as photo-sensitivity (206.8 %) and - responsivity (0.38 A/W @ 420 nm) under an illumination condition of 100 mW/cm<sup>2</sup> was obtained for application in visible-light photodetector.
469	<strong>Performance analysis of  graphene plasmonic nanoantenna using silicon based substrates</strong>	Surface plasmons in the graphene exhibit unique properties of low losses, strong confinement, field enhancement, long range propagation and high tunability at sub-wavelength scales. Owing to unique EM properties and support of surface plasmon polariton at Terhertzfrequency, graphene has gained momentum for the realization of graphene plasmonic nanoantenna. Graphene plasmonic nanoantennas using different silicon based substrates such as silicon, silicon dioxide, silicon nitride, and silicon carbide are presented in this work. Antennas are analyzed in terms of the reflection, resonant frequency, radiation pattern, half power beam width, front to back ratio and directivity.The proposed graphene plasmonic nanoantennas will be promising for THz communication, sensing, and biomedical application.
470	<strong>Field emission properties of indium decorated vertically aligned carbon nanotubes: An interplay between type of hybridization, density of states and metal thickness</strong>	Field emission (FE) properties of Indium decorated vertically aligned multi-walled carbon nanotube (MWCNT) films are investigated. The superior FE properties are achieved for 4 nm thick Indium coated MWCNTs as compared to those coated with higher thicknesses of Indium and pristine CNTs. Improvement in the FE properties are mainly attributed to transformation of sp<sup>2</sup> to sp<sup>3</sup>-hybridized carbons and Indium thickness. Other factors important for the better FE properties are enhanced density of states near the Fermi level and slightly improved field enhancement factor at relatively low applied electric fields.
471	Tuning the charge transport and photo-physical behavior in nanocomposite of poly(3-hexylthiophene) and silver sulfide quantum dots	The charge transport properties are studied in hybrid thin films composed of poly(3-hexylthiophene) polymer (P3HT) and silver sulfide (Ag<sub>2</sub>S) quantum dots (QDs) by temperature and photo-dependent current-voltage (J-V) characteristics. A complete reversal in J-V characteristics is observed in ITO/Nanocomposite/Au devices as the QDs&rsquo; concentration in the polymer matrix reaches to 50 weight percentage (wt. %).  A detailed study of charge injection through ITO exhibits a transition in transport mechanism from direct tunneling to thermionic emission with increasing QDs up to 20 wt. % and further governed by space charge limited conduction for 50 and 80 wt. % devices. Charge injection through Au shows the transition from Poole-Frenkel to thermionic emission as the QDs surpasses 10 wt. % in polymer matrix. The effect of injection barrier and charge transfer phenomena on the transport properties are discussed in details by photoluminescence and photocurrent measurements.
472	<strong>Synthesis and characterization of D-glucuronic acid-coated Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and Yb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles as potential </strong><strong>computed tomography</strong><strong> contrast agents</strong>	In this study, Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and Yb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles coated with biocompatible and hydrophilic D-glucuronic acid were prepared through a simple one-step polyol process and their X-ray attenuation properties were investigated. The average particle diameters of these nanoparticles were estimated to be 1.5 and 2.0 nm, respectively, by transmission electron microscopy. Their observed X-ray attenuation power was in the order of Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticle &gt; Yb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticle &gt; Ultravist<sup>&reg;</sup> [a commercial molecular iodine computed tomography (CT) contrast agent] at the same atomic concentration. This order was consistent with that of the magnitudes of their atomic X-ray attenuation coefficients (&mu;), i.e., &mu; (Bi) &gt; &mu; (Yb) &gt; &mu; (I). The X-ray attenuation powers of the nanoparticle samples were much stronger than that of Ultravist<sup>&reg;</sup> at the same number density, indicating that all the nanoparticle samples are potential CT contrast agents.
473	<strong>Topological Insulator-Metal Transition and Molecular Electronics Device based on ZigZag PhaGraphene NanoRibbon</strong>	In this work we investigate the electronic transport properties comparing with the results of the <em>Transition-Voltage Spectroscopy</em> (TVS) and propose the behavior characteristic of topological insulator for a graphene allotrope composed of 5-6-7 carbon aromatic rings called phagraphene. Its properties were compared to graphene in a zigzag nanoribbon configuration, i. e., zigzag Graphene and PhaGraphene NanoRibbon (zzGNR and zzPGNR). The molecular geometry and the electronic properties were calculated by Density Functional Theory (DFT) without spin and the electronic transport was obtained by means Extended H&uuml;ckel Theory/Non-Equilibrium Green&acute;s Function (EHT/NEGF) when we couple the optimized molecular geometry of zzGNR and zzPGNR at the Leads (Left and Right) forming the molecular junction effectively that will be subjected to the action of an external bias voltage (<em>V<sub>e</sub></em>) to generate the molecular electronic device. The results exhibit: <em>(i)</em> metal-insulator transition when the <em>V<sub>e</sub></em> is increased until <em>V<sub>e</sub> =</em>1.4V and nonlinear region (resonance) showing <em>Field Effect Transistor (FET)</em> behaviour for zzGNR junction; <em>(ii)</em> two nonlinear regions (two Negative Differential Resistances, NDRs), showing<em> tunnel diode</em> <em>behaviour with two operation windows </em><em>(V<sub>e</sub> = 0.5V and V<sub>e</sub> = 1.7V) </em>for zzPGNR junction. Besides, zzPGNR junction exhibits topological insulator characteristics due to introducing topological defects such as pentagons and heptagons in the hexagonal lattice of graphene and when <em>V<sub>e</sub></em> = 1.7V occurs a topological insulator-metal transition which can be seen in DOS, Transmittance and <em>Frontier Molecular Orbitals</em> (FMOs) under <em>V<sub>e</sub></em>.
474	<strong>Enhanced interfacial Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction and isolated skyrmions in the inversion-symmetry-broken Ru/Co/W/Ru films</strong>	An enhancement of the spin-orbit effects arising on an interface between a ferromagnet (<em>FM</em>) and a heavy metal (<em>HM</em>) is possible through the strong breaking of the structural inversion symmetry in the layered films. Here, we show that an introduction of an ultrathin W interlayer between Co and Ru in <em>Ru/Co/Ru</em> films enables to preserve perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (PMA) and simultaneously induce a large interfacial Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction (iDMI). The study of the spin-wave propagation in the Damon-Eshbach geometry by Brillouin light scattering (BLS) spectroscopy reveals the drastic increase of the iDMI value with increase in W thickness (<em>t<sub>W</sub></em>). The maximum iDMI of -3.1 erg/cm<sup>2</sup> is observed for <em>t<sub>W</sub></em>=0.24 nm, which is 10 times larger than for the quasi-symmetrical <em>Ru/Co/Ru</em> films. We demonstrate the evidence of the spontaneous field-driven nucleation of isolated skyrmions supported by micromagnetic simulations. Magnetic force microscopy measurements reveals the existence of sub-100-nm skyrmions in zero magnetic field. The ability to simultaneously control the strength of PMA and iDMI in quasi-symmetrical <em>HM/FM/HM</em> trilayer systems through the interface engineered inversion asymmetry at the nanoscale excites new fundamental and practical interest in ultrathin ferromagnets, which are a potential host for stable magnetic skyrmions.
475	<strong><strong>Composites of multiwall carbon nanotubes and conducting polyaniline: bulk samples and films produced  from a solution in chloroform</strong></strong>	Multiwall carbon nanotubes and conducting polyaniline, doped with dodecylbenzenesulfonic acid, are blended by employing the solubility of both materials in chloroform. This method represents an alternative to <em>in-situ</em> polymerization of the conducting matrix in the presence of nanotubes, offering an appreciable versatility with regard to possible applications. In these composites, advantageous properties of carbon nanotubes can be utilized in fully conducting structures that are free of problems related to percolation charge transport, and the strong decrease of the conductivity of doped polyaniline at low temperatures is simultaneously suppressed. Pellets are made by pressing the dried powder of the obtained composite, and films by sedimentary deposition. The nanotube content in the pellets can be as high as 40% by weight, and this wide range leads to a control over the shape and magnitude of the conductivity versus temperature curves. As the nanotube content grows, the temperature dependence of the conductivity becomes less steep, which is similar to the effect of annealing temperature on the conductivity of certain polycrystalline graphene samples. In our case, this change is most likely caused by the increase of the density of highly conducting channels and not by homogeneous electron delocalization effects. A commercial printed circuit board is used as the substrate for film deposition, and the conducting properties of the composites do not degrade upon film deposition.
476	A Hybrid Sub-Gridding ADE-FDTD Method for Modeling Periodic Metallic Nanoparticle Arrays	In this paper, a modified sub-gridding scheme that hybridizes the conventional finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method and the unconditionally stable locally one-dimensional (LOD) FDTD is developed for the analysis of periodic metallic nanoparticle arrays. The dispersion of the metal, caused by the evanescent waves propagating along the metal-dielectric interface, is expressed by the Drude model and solved with a generalized auxiliary differential equation (ADE) technique. In the sub-gridding scheme, ADE-FDTD is applied to global coarse grids while ADE-LOD-FDTD is applied to local fine grids. The time step sizes in the fine-grid region and coarse-grid region can be synchronized, obviating the temporal interpolation of the fields during the time-marching process. Numerical examples about extraordinary optical transmission through the periodic metallic nanoparticle array are provided to show accuracy and efficiency of the proposed method.
477	Novel high temperature vacuum nanoindentation system with active surface referencing and non-contact heating for low thermal drift measurements	High temperature nanoindentation is an emerging field with significant advances in instrumentation, calibration and experimental protocols reported in the past couple of years. Performing stable and accurate measurements at elevated temperatures holds the key for small scale testing of materials at service temperatures. We report a novel high temperature vacuum nanoindentation system, High Temperature Ultra Nanoindentation Tester (UNHT3 HTV), utilizing active surface referencing and non-contact heating capable of performing measurements up to 800&#x1D3C;C. This nanoindenter is based on the proven Ultra Nano Hardness Tester (UNHT) design that uses two indentation axes: one for indentation and another for surface referencing. Differential displacement measurement between the two axes enables stable measurements to be performed over long durations. A vacuum level of 10-7 mbar prevents sample surface oxidation at elevated temperatures. The indenter, reference and sample are heated independently using integrated infrared heaters. The instrumental design details for developing a reliable and accurate high temperature nanoindenter are described. High temperature calibration procedures to minimize thermal drift at elevated temperatures are reported. Indentation data on copper, fused silica, epoxy and a hard coating show that this new generation of instrumented indenter can achieve unparalleled stability over the entire temperature range up to 800{degree sign}C with thermal drift rates of &lt; 3 nm/min at elevated temperatures.
478	<strong>Acoustic Wave Sparsely-Activated Localization Microscopy (AWSALM): Super-Resolution Ultrasound Imaging using Acoustic Activation and Deactivation of </strong><strong>Nanodroplets</strong>	Photo-activated localization microscopy (PALM) has revolutionized the field of fluorescence microscopy by breaking the diffraction limit in spatial resolution. In this study, &lsquo;acoustic wave sparsely-activated localization microscopy (AWSALM)&rsquo;, an acoustic counterpart of PALM, is developed to super-resolve structures which cannot be resolved by conventional B-mode imaging. AWSALM utilizes acoustic waves to sparsely and stochastically activate decafluorobutane nanodroplets by acoustic vaporization, and to simultaneously deactivate the existing vaporized nanodroplets via acoustic destruction. In this method, activation, imaging, and deactivation are all performed using acoustic waves. Experimental results show that sub-wavelength micro-structures not resolvable by standard B-mode ultrasound images can be separated by AWSALM. This technique is flow independent and does not require a low concentration of contrast agents, as is required by current ultrasound super resolution techniques. Acoustic activation and deactivation can be controlled by adjusting the acoustic pressure, which remains well within the FDA approved safety range. In conclusion, this study shows the promise of a flow and contrast agent concentration independent super-resolution ultrasound technique which has potential to be faster and go beyond vascular imaging.
479	Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> Thin Films Functionalized with Ag, Au and TiO<sub>2</sub> Analyzed Using X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy	In the present contribution, bare and composite Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> (Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>-X, with X = Ag, Au, or TiO<sub>2</sub>) thin films were fabricated by a two-step vapor-phase route, consisting in: <em>a)</em> the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) of Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> on Si(100) substrates starting from a Mn(II) fluorinated &beta;-diketonate diamine Mn(II) complex; <em>b)</em> the introduction of silver, gold or titania by means of Radio Frequency (RF)-sputtering. The obtained results evidenced the formation of phase-pure &alpha;-Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> thin films chemically modified with fluorine, which, after RF-sputtering, yielded Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>-X nanocomposite systems with tailored properties. In this work, data obtained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization of the surface chemical composition are presented and discussed for bare and functionalized Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> systems. In addition to wide scan spectra, particular attention is dedicated to the analysis of C1s, O1s, Mn2p, Mn3s, F1s and, eventually Ag3d, Au4d<sub>5/2</sub>, and Ti2p core levels, as well as silver Auger signal. In the case of Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>-Au system, a quantification procedure aimed at circumventing problems arising from the overlap of Mn2p/Au4p<sub>1/2</sub> and Mn3s/Au4f signals is proposed.
480	Effect of nanowire curviness on the percolation resistivity of transparent, conductive metal nanowire networks	We study the effect of nanowire curviness on the percolation resistivity of transparent, conductive metal nanowire networks by Monte Carlo simulations. We generate curvy nanowires as one-dimensional sticks using 3<sup>rd</sup>-order B&eacute;zier curves. The degree of curviness in the network is quantified by the concept of curviness angle and curl ratio. We systematically study the interaction between the effect of curviness and five other nanowire/device parameters on the network resistivity, namely nanowire density, nanowire length, device length, device width, and nanowire alignment. We find that the resistivity exhibits a power law dependence on the curl ratio, which is a signature of percolation transport. In each case, we extract the power-law scaling critical exponents and explain the results using geometrical and physical arguments. The value of the curl ratio critical exponent is not universal, but increases as the other nanowire/device parameters drive the network toward the percolation threshold. We find that, for randomly oriented networks, curviness is undesirable since it increases the resistivity. For well-aligned networks, on the other hand, some curviness is highly desirable, since the resistivity minimum occurs for partially curvy nanowires. We explain these results by considering the two competing effects of curviness on the percolation resistivity. The results presented in this work can be extended to any network, film, or nanocomposite consisting of one-dimensional nanoelements. Our results show that Monte Carlo simulations are an essential predictive tool for both studying percolation transport and optimizing the electronic properties of transparent, conductive nanowire networks for a wide range of applications.
481	All-optical nanoscale thermometry with silicon-vacancy centers in diamond	We demonstrate an all-optical thermometer based on an ensemble of silicon-vacancy centers (SiVs) in diamond by utilizing the sensitivity of the zero-phonon line wavelength to temperature, &Delta;&lambda;/&Delta;T = 0.0124(2) nm K<sup>-1 </sup>(6.8(1) GHz K<sup>-1</sup>). Using SiVs in bulk diamond, we achieve 70mK precision at room temperature with a temperature uncertainty &sigma;<sub>T</sub> = 360 mK/&radic;Hz. Finally, we use SiVs in 200 nm nanodiamonds as local temperature probes with 521 mK/&radic;Hz uncertainty and achieve sub-Kelvin precision. These properties deviate by less than 1% between nanodiamonds, enabling calibration-free thermometry for the sensing and control of complex nanoscale systems.
482	Surface-induced melting and solidification from a nanovoid: A study of sizeeffect using a phase field approach	The size effect and the effects of finite-width  surface on barrierless transformations between solid (S), surface melt (SM), and melt (M) from a spherical nanovoid  are studied using a phase field approach. Melting<br />(SM$\to$M and S$\to$M) from nanovoid occurs at significantly greater temperature than the solid-melt equilibrium temperature $\theta_e$. The relationship  for SM and M temperatures versus the ratio   of the void surface width and width of solid-melt interface, $\bar\Delta$,  is found for the nanovoids of different sizes.  Below a critical ratio $\bar\Delta^*$, the melting  occurs via SM and the melting temperature slightly reduces with an increase in $\bar\Delta$. Both S$\to$SM and SM$\to$M transformations have a jump-like character (excluding the case with the sharp void surface), causing small temperature hysteresis.  However,  the solid  melts without  SM for $\bar\Delta&gt;\bar\Delta^*$, and the melting temperature significantly increases with increasing $\bar\Delta$. The results for a nanovoid are compared with the melting/solidification of  a nanoparticle, for which the melting temperatures, in contrast, are much lower than $\theta_e$. A linear dependence of the melting temperatures with the inverse of the void radius is shown. The present study shows an unexplored way to control the  melting from nanovoids by controlling the void size and the width and energy of the surface.
483	Nansocale Schottky Barrier Visualization Utilizing Computational Modeling and Ballistic Electron Emission Microscopy	The electrostatic barrier at a metal semiconductor interface is visualized with nanoscale spatial and meV energetic resolution.  A combination of Schottky barrier mapping with ballistic electron emission microscopy (BEEM) and computational modeling enables extraction of the barrier heights, the hot electron scattering, and the presence of localized charges at the interface from the histograms of the spectra thresholds.  Several metal semiconductor interfaces are investigated including W/Si(001) using two different deposition techniques, Cr/Si(001), and mixed Au-Ag/Si(001).  The findings demonstrate the ability to detect the effects of partial silicide formation in the W and Cr samples and the presence of two barrier heights in intermixed Au/Ag films upon the electrostatic barrier of a buried interface with nanoscale resolution. This has potential to transform the fundamental understanding of the relationship between electrostatic uniformity and interface structure for technologically important metal semiconductor interfaces.
484	Optimized Trap-state Emission of Magic-sized CdSe Quantum Dots for Efficient White LEDs	Magic clusters have attracted significant interest to explore the dynamics of quantum dot (QD) nucleation and growth. At the same time, CdSe magic-sized QDs reveal broadband emission in the visible, which advantageously offer integration of a single-type of nanomaterial and high color rendering ability for white LEDs. Here, we optimized the quantum yield of magic-sized QDs via controlling the synthesis parameters without any shelling or post-treatment process and integrated them in liquid-state on blue LED to prevent the efficiency drop due to host-material effect. The fabricated white LEDs showed color-rendering index and luminous efficiency up to 89 and 11.7 lm/W.
485	Ultrafast Dynamic Response of Single-Crystal <em>beta</em>-HMX	We report experimental and computational studies of shock wave dynamics in single-crystal beta-HMX on an ultrafast time scale.  Here, a laser-based compression drive (~1 ns in duration; stresses of up to ~40 GPa) is used to propagate shock waves normal to the (110) and (010) lattice planes.  Ultrafast time-domain interferometry measurements reveal distinct, time-dependent relationships between the shock wave velocity and particle velocity for each crystal orientation, which suggest evolving physical processes on a sub-nanosecond time scale.  To help interpret the experimental data, elastic shock wave response was simulated using a finite-strain model of crystal thermoelasticity.  At early propagation times (&lt;500 ps), the model is in agreement with the data, which indicates the mechanical response is dominated by thermoelastic deformation.  The model agreement depends on the inclusion of nonlinear elastic effects in both the spherical and deviatoric stress-strain response.  This is achieved by employing an equation-of-state and a pressure-dependent stiffness tensor, which was computed via atomistic simulation.  At later times (&gt;500 ps), the crystal samples exhibit signatures of either inelastic deformation, structural phase transformation, or chemical reaction, depending on the direction of wave propagation.
486	<strong><em>Phase Retrieval for Near-field X-Ray Imaging beyond Linearisation or Compact Support</em></strong>	X-ray phase contrast imaging and tomography relies on phase retrieval to obtain sharp images of<br />micro- and nanoscale objects, with widespread applications in materials science and biomedical research.<br />For high resolution synchrotron experiments, phase retrieval is largely based on the single step reconstruction<br />using the contrast transfer function approach, as introduced almost twenty years ago \cite{Cloetens_Appl.Phys.Lett._1999}. <br />Notwithstanding its tremendous merits, this scheme makes stringent assumptions on the optical properties of the object, requiring in particular <br />a weakly varying phase. In this work we show how significant the loss in image quality becomes,<br />if these assumption are violated, and how phase retrieval can easily be rescued by a simple scheme of alternating projections. <br />Importantly, the approach demonstrated here uses the same input data and constraint sets as the conventional CTF-based phase retrieval.
487	Interfacial Properties of Polymeric Complex Coacervates from Simulation and Theory	Polymeric complex coacervation occurs when two oppositely-charged polyelectrolytes undergo an associative phase separation in aqueous salt solution, resulting in a polymer-dense coacervate phase and a polymer-dilute supernatant phase. This phase separation process represents a powerful way to tune polymer solutions using electrostatic attraction, and is sensitive to environmental conditions such as salt concentration and valency. One area of particular research interest is using this to create nanoscale polymer assemblies, via (for example) block copolymers with coacervate-forming blocks. Key to understanding coacervate-driven assembly is the formation of interface between the coacervate and supernatant phases, and its corresponding thermodynamics. In this work, we use recent advances in coacervate simulation and theory to probe the nature of the coacervate-supernatant interface. First, we show that self-consistent field theory (SCFT) informed by either Monte-Carlo (MC) simulations or transfer matrix (TM) theories is capable of reproducing interfacial features present in large-scale Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations. The quantitative agreement between all three methods gives us a way to efficiently explore interfacial thermodynamics. We show how salt affects the interface, and we find qualitative agreement with literature measurements of interfacial tension. We also explore the influence of neutral polymers, which we predict to drastically influence the phase behavior of coacervates. These neutral polymers can significantly alter the interfacial tension in coacervates; this has a profound effect on the design and understanding of coacervate-driven self-assembly, where equilibrium structure is tied to interfacial properties.
488	Enhanced photoresponse of Ge/Si nanostructures by combining amorphous silicon deposition and annealing	In order to inhibit high carrier recombination rates in Ge-on-Si nanostructures, Ge nanoislands were covered by thin amorphous silicon layers <em>via</em> a low pressure CVD process. The photovoltage magnitude of capped Ge/Si increased by an order of magnitude compared to that of bare Ge islands, which can be due to the effective passivation of recombination centers at the a-Si/Ge interface. The effect is even more enhanced by nearly 5 to 10 times after subsequent anneal at 400&ordm;C in O<sub>2</sub> ambient. The results are explained in terms of passivation properties of hydrogenated amorphous silicon films. This work will facilitate the optoelectronic applications of Ge/Si heterostructures, such as solar energy harvest and photodetectors.
489	<strong>Thermoluminescence and OSL study of   </strong><strong>BaMg<sub>2</sub>Al<sub>6</sub>Si<sub>9</sub>O<sub>30</sub>: Ce<sup>3+</sup></strong><strong>/ </strong><strong>Dy<sup>3+</sup> </strong><strong>phosphor</strong>	Series of nanosiezed BaMg<sub>2</sub>Al<sub>6</sub>Si<sub>9</sub>O<sub>30</sub> phosphor doped with  Ce<sup>3+</sup>/ Dy<sup>3+</sup>  were synthesized by the combustion technique. The phosphors was irradiated first by   Sr-Y90&beta;-emitting source and after that, it was used for the TL-OSL measurement.  Therefore BaMg<sub>2</sub>Al<sub>6</sub>Si<sub>9</sub>O<sub>30</sub> : Ce<sup>3+</sup>/ Dy<sup>3+   </sup>phosphor  shows an isolated glow curve doped at around 201<sup>0</sup>C. Further it was well resolved into two sub-bands  with the help of curve fitting a calculate the trap depth and TL parameters of the observed curve. Also,   OSL decay curve analysis was carried out for  BaMg<sub>2</sub>Al<sub>6</sub>Si<sub>9</sub>O<sub>30 </sub>:<sub>0.1</sub>Ce<sup>3+</sup>,<sub>y</sub>Dy<sup>3+ </sup>phosphor which was well fitted into third order exponential.  The micro and nanostructure of the phosphors materials were confirmed from the SEM, TEM  investigation. Again the phase purity of the materials is confirmed by XRD  which has the hexagonal structure and the observed diffraction pattern of the phosphor is well indexed and confirmed using  theoretical tools of  XRD  for a practical approach to calculate the lattice parameter. Thus prepared nanosized  thermoluminescent materials is a promising candidate, which may act as dosimeters for the irradiation of foods and seeds.
490	<strong>Strain-modulated dynamical stability and magnetic behavior of free standing Pt and Pd nanowires</strong>	We study the Lagrangian strain induced colossal magnetism and thermoelectric performance of platinum (Pt) and palladium (Pd) nanowires (NWs) using first principles density functional calculations. Pt and Pd NWs are found to be dynamical stability in both strain-free and strained situation. The results show that the cohesive energy and magnetic moment of both NWs increases on increasing tensile Lagrangian strain (2% to 10%) in (001) plane. Furthermore, we analyze the thermodynamic properties using quasi-harmonic approximation (QHA), the heat capacity and internal energy for both the NWs originate at 0 K and the internal energy (E) remain high. NWs with (100) and (010) plane, the magnetism exists at strain free case, while increasing strain, the values of magnetism decreases rapidly. Our results show excellent stability, colossal magnetism, and thermoelectric properties of given NWs; therefore, these NWs can be used as a potential thermoelectric material for device applications.s<p><strong> </strong>
491	A Frank-Kasper Polyhedral Structure of 17-Atom Vanadium Clusters	A distorted Frank-Kasper polyhedral structure (A) as the putative global minimum was identified for the neutral and charged V17 clusters by using the Monte Carlo basin-hopping algorithm based on semi-empirical Gupta potential and density functional theory calculations. The cationic V17+ cluster reproduces well the experimental infrared multiple photon dissociation spectroscopy, and the calculated ionization potentials and electron affinities of the A structure are close to its experimental values. It is also found that the shell-closed V17+ structure can be stabilized by 20 delocalized 3c-2e and 4 delocalized 6c-2e &#x03C3; bonds on the outer shell and 12 delocalized 4c-2e &#x03C3; bonds on the inner shell. Our results represent an effective and reliable way to predict and design the novel building block of largely nanoscale materials, and facilitate the understanding of structural correlations on the energy landscapes.
492	Transient lattice deformations of crystals studied by means of ultrafast time-resolved x-ray and electron diffraction	Ultrafast lattice deformation of tens to hundreds of nanometer thick metallic crystals, after femtosecond laser excitation, was measured directly using 8.04 keV subpicosecond x-ray and 59 keV femtosecond electron pulses. Coherent phonons were generated in both single crystal and polycrystalline films. Lattice compression was observed within the first few picoseconds after laser irradiation in single crystal aluminum, which was attributed to the generation of a blast force and the propagation of elastic waves. The different time scale of lattice heating for tens and hundreds nanometer thick films are clearly distinguished by electron and x-ray pulse diffraction. The electron and lattice heating due to ultrafast deposition of photon energy was numerically simulated using the two-temperature model (TTM) and the results agreed with experimental observations. The ultrafast heating described by TTM was also discussed from an electrical circuit perspective, which may provide new insights on the possible connection between thermal and electrical processes. This study demonstrates that the combination of two complimentary ultrafast time-resolved methods, ultrafast x-ray and electron diffraction will provide a panoramic picture of the transient atomic motions and structure in crystals.
493	<em>k</em>-space optical microscopy of nanoparticle arrays: opportunities and artifacts	We report on  the  interesting possibilities offered by <em>k</em>-space optical microscopy for the study of periodic arrays of nanoparticles.  In this work,  several different illumination configurations using an inverted optical microscope are exploited. A recently reported artifact,  called the "condenser effect",  is demonstrated here in a new way. The consequences of this artifact (which is due to spurious reflections in the objective) on Fourier-space imaging and spectroscopic measurements are analyzed in detail. The fact that <em>k</em>-space optical microscopy may be used to resolve the surface-plasmon-polariton band structure in a periodic nanoparticle array on a metallic layer is demonstrated. Potential applications of <em>k</em>-space imaging for the accurate lateral and axial positioning of the sample in optical microscopy are investigated.
494	Stability of Nano Bubbles	With stable existence in liquids for over several weeks, nano bubbles have an extensive range of applications across many fields of science and engineering. For an effective and functional use of these bubbles, it is important to know the reason for their long term stability. Therefore, a comprehensive laboratory investigation was performed to determine bubble size distributions and zeta potentials of nano bubbles, first using four different gases in tap water and deionized water (test series I) and then using two gases in deionized water with different salt concentrations, pH levels and temperatures (test series II). Experimental results from test series I showed that the average bubble size depended on the gas solubility in water and zeta potential depended on the ability of the gas to generate OH- ions at the water/gas interface.  Experimental results from test series II showed that bubbles with high negative zeta potentials can be generated in solutions of high pH, low temperatures and low salt concentrations. The high pH solutions produced smaller but stable nano bubbles. The bubble diameter slightly increased with increasing salt concentration. However, the bubble size did not show considerable dependence on solution temperature. The long-term tests showed that with time zeta potential of bubbles decreased while the bubble size increased. Hence it is hypothesized that nano bubbles will grow with time and will eventually disappear.
495	Single molecule electrophoresis of star polymers through nanopores: Simulations	We study the translocation of charged star polymers through a solid-state nanopore using coarse-grained Langevin dynamics simulations, in the context of using nanopores as high-throughput devices to characterize polymers based on their architecture. The translocation is driven by an externally applied electric field. Our key observation is that translocation kinetics is highly sensitive to the functionality of the star polymer. The mean translocation time is found to vary non-monotonically with polymer functionality, exhibiting a critical value for which translocation is the fastest.  The origin of this effect lies in the competition between higher  driving force inside the nanopore and inter-arm electrostatic repulsion in entering the pore, as the functionality is increased. Our simulations also show that the value of the critical functionality can be tuned by varying nanopore dimensions. Moreover, for narrow nanopores, star polymers above a threshold functionality do not translocate at all. These observations suggest the use of nanopores as a high-throughput low-cost analytical tool to characterize and separate star polymers.
496	Morphology and optical properties of Eu&sup2;&#x207A;-sensitized CsI(Na) thick film	<SPAN style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Eu co-doping of CsI(Na) thick film was deposited by thermal evaporation on quartz substrate which was coated by a nano-reflective layer. Morphology and structure of these films which were studied, using SEM images and XRD pattern, had no distinguishable differences. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy ICP (OES) was utilized in order to measure Sodium and Europium concentration, along deposition. Moreover, their optical properties were investigated by UV absorption, excitation and emission spectroscopy in the wavelength region 200-800 nm. The results indicated that Eu-sensitizing material enhanced the luminescence intensity of CsI(Na) columnar-structure film, compared to conventional CsI(Na) scintillator. This increasing is attributed to the both Eu high quantum efficiency and energy transfer between the activator and sensitizer which is considered with a view of improving scintillator properties. Ion Beam Induced Luminescence (IBIL) measurements also confirm the luminescence results.</SPAN>
497	Enhanced optical response of crystalline silicon photovoltaics devices by integration of silver nanoparticles and ultrathin TiO2 dielectric&#x00A0;layer	Silver nanoparticles (Ag NPs) and titanium&#x00A0;dioxide (TiO2) dielectric layer, produced by magnetron sputtering and a subsequent annealing treatment, were integrated at the front side of crystalline silicon (c-Si) solar cells. A photovoltaics device was realized based on the c-Si substrate and a Ag NPs/TiO2/n/p/Ag layer stack. The results show that the energy conversion efficiency (ECE) can be improved by 9.9% due to introducing the well-sized Ag NPs and ultrathin TiO2 dielectric layer to the c-Si solar cells. The presence of the dielectric layer makes Ag NPs fully exert the advantage of localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) and light scattering, and the recombination of the photo-generated carriers originating from Ag NPs at the surface or in the vicinity of Ag NPs is avoided effectively. Moreover, COMSOL Multiphysics simulations were performed to investigate the reflection and absorption in the c-Si. The simulation results match well with the experimental data.
498	<strong>Synergistic effects on microstructural evolution and hardening of the Hastelloy N alloy under subsequent He and Xe ion irradiation</strong>	Synergistic effects in the evolution of He bubbles and dislocation loops in Hastelloy N alloy were investigated using transmission electron microscopy and nanoindentation. Results show that the sizes of both He bubbles and dislocation loops induced by the He<sup> </sup>and Xe irradiation were larger than those in the individual irradiation cases. The corresponding hardening degree of irradiated sample was also measured to be higher than the combined hardening value of two individual irradiation cases. The synergistic effects were explained by the pre-existed He bubbles that captured vacancies and thus inhibited their annihilation with interstitial atoms during the subsequent Xe irradiation.
499	Efficiency enhancement of flexible OLEDs by using nano-corrugated substrates and conformal Ag transparent anodes	In flexible OLEDs (FOLEDs), the traditional ITO anode has disadvantages such as refractive-index mismatches among substrate and other functional layers, leads to light loss of nearly 80%, meanwhile, the brittle nature and high cost of ITO anode hinder its future application in flexible devices. We investigated an efficient FOLED using a thin silver (Ag) anode, whereas the whole device was deposited on a nano-corrugated flexible polycarbonate (PC) substrate prepared by thermal nanoimprint lithography. The template for the nanoimprint process was a replicate of a silica nano-pillars array fabricated by inductively coupling plasma (ICP) etching through a mask of SiO2 colloidal spheres. The corrugations were well preserved on each layer of the device, both the micro-cavity effect and surface plasmon polariton (SPP) modes of light loss were effectively suppressed. As a result, the current efficiency of the FOLED using a conformal corrugated Ag anode enhanced by 100% compared with a planar Ag anode device, and enhanced by 13% with conventional ITO device. In addition, owing to the quasi-periodical arrangements of the corrugations, the device achieved broad spectra and Lambertian angular emission.
