The Ag anode significantly improved the bending properties of the OLED as compared to the conventional ITO device, leading to a longer lifetime in practical use. The proposed manufacturing method will be useful for fabricating nano corrugation on plastic substrate of FOLED in a cost-effective and convenient manner.
500	<strong>Annealing effect on hierarchical structure of Ge ion implanted SiO<sub>2</sub><sup> </sup>matrix using multifractal technique</strong>	SiO<sub>2</sub> layers of thickness 200 nm were grown on Si substrates. Ge ions of 150 keV energy having fluences of 2.5&times;10<sup>16</sup> and 7.5&times;10<sup>16</sup> ions/cm<sup>2 </sup>were implanted into SiO<sub>2</sub> matrix. The implanted samples were annealed at 950<sup>o </sup>C for 30 minutes in Ar ambience. Due to the process of ion implantation of SiO<sub>2</sub> leads to amorphization, annealing is removing the disorder present in the system and amorphous phase changed to crystalline phase. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurement was done to characterize the Ge nanostructures synthesized by implantation and annealing. Topographical studies of implanted as well as annealed samples were captured by the atomic force microscopy (AFM). Two dimensional multifractal detrended fluctuation analysis (2D-MFDFA) based on the partition function approach was used to study the surfaces of ion implanted and annealed samples. The partition function is used to calculate generalized Hurst exponent with the segment size. Moreover, it is seen that the generalized Hurst exponents vary nonlinearly with the moment, thereby exhibiting the multifractal nature. The multifractality of surface is pronounced after annealing for the surface implanted with fluence ions/cm<sup>2</sup>.
501	<strong>Influence of the thickness of a nanometric copper interlayer on Au/dielectric thermal boundary conductance</strong>	The influence of a thin (1.5 - 30 nm) copper layer on the thermal boundary conductance (TBC) at the interface between gold and silicon, sapphire and diamond, respectively, was studied by Time Domain Thermoreflectance (TDTR). A monotonic increase of the TBC was observed over the first 10 nm, before reaching a plateau. In some cases, it was also observed that an interlayer reduced the TBC as compared to the reference system. This is rationalized by assuming that the TBC evolution as a function the interlayer thickness is controlled by i) a contribution of the gold layer that has to be taken into account for all phonons having a wavelength larger than the interlayer thickness and ii) a thickness-dependant resistance within the interlayer that appears when electron-phonon coupling is incomplete, i.e. typically over the first 10 nm. A model is proposed in which the gold layer resistance is estimated using a simple Debye approximation, while the resistance that appears within the interlayer is estimated by <em>g(T)</em> times <em>h</em> with <em>g(T)</em> the electron-phonon coupling factor and <em>h</em> the interlayer thickness. This results in a system with three resistances in series, i.e. the metal-metal and metal-dielectric interfacial resistances and the interlayer resistance, and a resistance in parallel, i.e. the gold layer resistance. Reasonably good agreement between this model and experimental data is observed.
502	<strong>Modification of alignment layer of TNLCD by doping ferroelectric ZnO nanoparticle for reducing switching voltage.</strong>	Twisted nematic liquid crystal device (TNLCD) was fabricated using ferroelectric ZnO doped polyimide alignment layer. Ferroelectric nanoparticle can produce local electric field and can trigger the orientation of  liquid crystal molecule and reduces the switching voltage. The  uniformly dispersion of ferroelectric ZnO  nanoparticles in the alignment layer was studied using scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and atomic force microscopy (AFM). The ferroelectric property of  ZnO doped polymide was investigated using dynamic contact electrostratic force microscopy (DC-EFM). An increased local electric field due to the presence of nano ZnO was confirmed with the help of scanning tunnelling microscopy (STM). An augmentation of capacitance was observed with increase in concentration, which substantiate the reduction of switching voltage of TNLCD with the modification of ferroelectric nanoparticle doped alignment layer.
503	<strong>Evaluation of the MWCNTs concentrations in Ag/TiO2 matrix by Raman spectroscopy and Gruneisen parameter</strong>	This research systematically investigated the functionalized Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (<em>f</em>-MWCNTs) by using the nitric and the sulfuric acids. Surface functionalization was confirmed by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. The <em>f</em>-MWCNTs-Ag-TiO<sub>2</sub> nanocomposites have been synthesized by using the chemical simple two-step method. To characterize the structural analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging, ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) spectroscopy, Raman and FTIR spectroscopy were used. The results showed that both Ag and TiO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles were well-dispersed over the f-MWCNTs, so it caused to form a uniform nanocomposite. Raman spectroscopy was utilized for the estimation of the magnitude of strain by observing the shifts of the all bands of f-MWCNTs (especially G and 2G bands). The maximum Raman shift of f-MWCNTs is related to the G-band that peaks up-shifted from 2672 cm<sup>-1</sup> up to 2712 cm<sup>-1</sup> for 5 wt.% f-MWCNTs in TiO<sub>2</sub>-Ag matrix and becomes more broadening on the addition of f-MWCNTs up to 20% wt. The shift frequency of G-band indicates the strong interaction between f-MWCNTs and TiO<sub>2</sub>-Ag nanoparticles. So, it provides the mechanism for stress transfer at the interface between f-MWCNTs and TiO<sub>2</sub>-Ag nanoparticles that is pointed in the large increases in the mechanical and acoustical properties obtained.
504	<strong>Identification of Primary Nanoparticles, Their Aggregates and Agglomerates of Carbon-black in Suspension by Dynamic Ultrasound Scattering Techniques</strong>	Carbon black (CB) suspension exhibits various structures depending on the properties of solvent and dispersant as well as the preparation process of suspension. In most cases, they do not exist as independent nanoparticles but as aggregates or agglomerates. In order to evaluate the size distribution at different level of hierarchal structure, we carried out static/dynamic ultrasound scattering analysis for the CB suspensions in alcohol and/or water with or without Nafion, a perfluorinated polymer. The potential of the dynamic ultrasound scattering technique was demonstrated by discriminating diffusing nanoparticles and micron-sized aggregates/agglomerates without dilution of the sample. Particularly, suppression of large agglomerates by addition of Nafion was clearly observed. Phosphotungstic acid, a family of polyoxometalate, was also employed to obtain smaller unit structures of the CB particles without formation of aggregation after decomposition of CB. The effective catalysis was also confirmed by the dynamic ultrasound scattering technique.
505	<strong>Spatially Resolved Observation of Water Transport across Nanomembranes using Bright-field Nanoscopy</strong>	Gaining a detailed understanding of water transport behavior through ultra-thin membranes including atomically thin graphene layers is increasingly becoming necessary due to their potential applications in water desalination and ion separation. It is important to correlate the nanoscopic architecture of the membrane to the macroscopic properties such as the average water transport rate and the ion selective transport rates. Such correlations are only possible when spatially resolved (in the lateral direction) information of mass transport across the membrane is available. Current techniques do not provide spatially resolved information and only provide macroscopic parameters such as the bulk water transport rate. We describe a technique, referred here as Bright-Field Nanoscopy (BFN), which provides spatially resolved measurement of water transport across nanomembranes. Using this technique, we demonstrate how grain engineering of atomically thin chemical vapor deposited (CVD) graphene membranes can tune the bulk water transport rate across the membranes by orders of magnitude. BFN exploits the strong thickness dependent color response of an optical stack consisting of a thin (~25 nm) germanium film deposited over a gold substrate and only requires a regular bright-field microscope for data acquisition. To show the generality of this technique, we demonstrate the strong influence of the terminal layer on the bulk water transport rates in thin (~ 20 nm) layer-by-layer deposited polyelectrolyte multilayer films by exploiting the spatially resolved nature of the acquired data. We also show that by controlling the ambient conditions the effect of terminal layer can be completely suppressed.
506	Effect of Interfacial Stress in Phase Field  Approach for Martensitic Phase transformation in NiAl Shape Memory Alloy	A Phase-Field (PF) theory of phase transition between martensitic variants and twinning within martensitic<br />variants is presented with focus on effect of interfacial stress on Phase Transformations (PTs). In this theory, each variant-variant PTs and twinnings within each martensitic variant can be described by only one order parameter. Thus, it allows us to get analytical solution of the martensite--martensite interface energy and width. Moreover, this theory allows to introduce interface stresses consistent with the sharp interface limit. The finite element method is utilized to solve the coupled PF and elasticity equations for cubic to tetragonal PTs in NiAl shape memory alloy. The effects of interfacial stress are studied for both austenite-martensite and martensite-martensite interfaces. The stress fields are obtain and the effects of interfacial stress on stress field at interfaces are examined. Additionally, the stress as well as temperature induced growth of a martensitic phases inside austenite and martensitic PTs and twining are simulated. The evolution of microstructure and stress fields are obtained and the effects of interfacial stress on morphological evolution of martensitic nanostructures are examined. It is found that the interfacial stress is an important factor, influencing the stress distribution at interfaces and the phase field solution significantly. This theory can be extended for electric, reconstructive and magnetic PTs.
507	<strong>Kinetically Controlled Dewetting of Thin GaAs Cap from An ErAs/GaAs Nanoparticle Composite Layer </strong>	ErAs metal nanoparticles (NPs) embedded in GaAs have multiple applications in plasmonic, terahertz, and tunneling devices. Growing high quality thin GaAs layer over the ErAs NP layer is vital to these applications. In this work, we study the surface stability of GaAs thin cap (1 to 5nm) on single layer of ErAs NPs grown using molecular beam epitaxy in a GaAs matrix. As grown GaAs at low temperature (450&deg;C) can be smooth, however, GaAs was found to dewet from ErAs NP layer with increasing temperature (&gt;500&deg;C) through the formation of clumps or pinholes depending on the layer thickness. Thermodynamically, this dewetting is driven by the high interfacial energy as a result of different crystal structures, however, as a kinetic factor, surface mobility plays important roles in the process. It has been demonstrated that the dewetting can be prevented by combining a higher As overpressure, a low growth/annealing temperature, lower surface coverage of ErAs NP, and thicker GaAs cap.
508	<strong>Enhanced cycle stability of a NiCo<sub>2</sub>S<sub>4</sub> nanostructured electrode for supercapacitors fabricated by the alternate-dip-coating method</strong>	Nanostructured nickel cobalt sulfide (NiCo<sub>2</sub>S<sub>4</sub>) electrodes are successfully fabricated using a simple alternate-dip-coating method. The process involves dipping a TiO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles-covered substrate in a nickel/cobalt mixed precursor solution and sulfur precursor solution alternately at room temperature. The fabricated bimetallic sulfide electrode exhibits a synergetic improvement compensating for the disadvantages of the two single metal sulfide electrodes, <em>i.e.</em> the poor cycle stability of the nickel sulfide electrode and the low specific capacitance (<em>C</em><sub>sp</sub>) of the cobalt sulfide electrode. The two capacitive properties are optimized by adjusting the ratio of nickel and cobalt concentrations in the metal precursor solution, reaching a <em>C</em><sub>sp</sub> of 500 F/g at a current density of 1 mA/cm<sup>2</sup> and its retention of 99.9 % even after 2000 galvanostatic charge-discharge cycles.
509	<strong>Marangoni flow and microstructure of electrode pattern in sintering process of Copper(I) oxide nanoparticle</strong>	Nanoparticle laser sintering is one of the key technology in additive manufacturing. Many kinds of process try to fabricate complicated part, such as free-form surface or seamless part but process resolution and quality are not satisfied with practical applications. Hence, laser sintering is applied to fabricate electrode pattern selectively for high precision manufacturing field. In spite of various advantages, the laser sintering process generate defects on the pattern and one of the major phenomenon is Marangoni flow. In this study, the laser sintering process was done to fabricate electrode pattern uniformly on substrate by suppressing the Marangoni flow and it was controlled by density of nanoparticle and laser characteristics, such as laser power, laser pulse duration, and laser scan speed. As a result, the Marangoni flow was figured out according to blending condition of the nanoparticle solution and laser irradiation parameter.
510	Optical Properties of Nanoporous Gold Foams	We fabricated and experimentally studied Au nano-foams and Al2O3 scaffolds filled with Au nanoparticles (NPs). We found that while the reflectance spectra of Au nano-foams depended very little on the 8-10 nm Al2O3 ALD coating, the spectra were highly sensitive to annealing, which increased the sizes of voids and ligaments from 50-100 nm to ~300 nm. The effective dielectric permittivities of the Au nano-foams and Al2O3 scaffolds with Au NPs were extremely high, ~50. Additionally, Au nano-foams covered with a dielectric (MgF2) featured bright structural colors, requiring the model, which extends beyond the effective medium approximation.
511	<strong>Induced-Charge Electrokinetics in Rotating Electric Fields: a Linear Asymptotic Analysis</strong>	Concerning the electroconvective analyte manipulation in microfluidics, we describe the basic physics of fluid flow driven by rotating induced-charge electro-osmosis (ROT-ICEO), which occurs on the planar surface of a single floating electrode in an external rotating electric field. First, based on a linear asymptotic analysis, the dynamic flow stagnation line in ROT-ICEO induced on the bipolar electrode from a <em>rotary Debye screening charge</em> revolves synchronously with the applied rotating fields. A net hydrodynamic torque is then generated that acts on any fluid or particle sample to produce either a synchronous or asynchronous co-field rotation depending on the frequency of the ac signal. Next, from the synergy between the hydrodynamic and electrochemical ion relaxations, an analytical solution of the sample rotation rate subject to ROT-ICEO slipping on an ideally polarizable surface is obtained for different frequency ranges and determined by the transient nature of the rotating electro-osmotic flow oscillating at twice the field frequency. To visualize the flow field in ROT-ICEO, experiments were performed with fluorescent tracer nanoparticles; they exhibited concentric rotational behavior at the polarized phase interface. Formed like the arms of a nebula disk, the four twisted tails of nanoparticles can be arbitrarily directed under voltage-phase rectification. These experimental results are in good agreement with our mathematical simulations using the Debye&ndash;H&uuml;ckel approximation on ROT-ICEO.
512	Carbide-derived carbons for dense and tunable 3D graphene networks	The mechanical properties of carbide-derived carbons (CDCs) are computed using molecular dynamics simulations, spanning the experimental density range and synthesis temperatures. The structures consist of nanoporous networks with continuous graphene walls enclosing the pores. Calculation of elastic constants and simulation of tensile strain reveal a direct relationship between microstructure and elasticity, with density and temperature inducing significant changes in the pore topology and medium-range order. CDCs have a high elastic moduli and high ultimate tensile strengths while showing resistance to brittle fracture. This suggests that CDCs are a promising route to achieve dense 3D graphene networks with tunable mechanical properties.
513	<strong>Motion Behavior of </strong><strong>Water Droplets</strong><strong> under Driving of Triboelectric Nanogenerator</strong>	By integrating a triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) and a simple circuit board, the motion of water droplet can be controlled by the output of the TENG, which demonstrates a self-powered microfluidic system toward various practical applications in the fields of microfluidic system and soft robotics. This paper describes a method to construct a physical model for this self-powered system on the basis of electrostatics induction theory. The model can precisely simulate the detailed motion behavior of the droplet under driving of TENG and it can also reveal the influences of surface hydrophobicity to the motion of the droplet, which can help us to better understand the key parameters that decides the performance of the system. The experimental observation of the dynamic performance of the droplet has also been done with a high speed camera system. A comparison between simulation results and real measurements confirms that the proposed model can predict the velocity and position of the water droplet driven by high voltage source as well as TENG. Hence, the proposed model in this work could serve as a guidance for optimizing the self-powered systems in future studies.
514	Thermochemical properties of nanometer CL-20 and PETN fabricated by mechanical milling methodology	2,4,6,8,10,12-hexanitro-2,4,6,8,10,12-hexaazaisowurtzitane (CL-20) and pentaerythritol tetranitrate (PETN), of which mean size were of 73.8nm and 267.7nm respectively, were fabrication upon a high-energy ball-mill. SEM analysis was employed to image the micron morphology of nano explosives, and the particle size distribution was calculated with statistic of individual particle size in SEM images. Analyses, such as XRD, IR, and XPS, were also enlisted to confirm whether the crystal phase, molecule structure, and surface elements were changed after a long time milling process. The results were as expected. Thermal analysis was performed at different heating rates. The parameters, such as activation energy (ES), activation enthalpy (&#x0394;H&#x2260;), activation free energy (&#x0394;G&#x2260;), activation entropy (&#x0394;S&#x2260;), and critical temperature of thermal explosion (Tb) etc, were calculated to depict the decomposition courses of the explosives. Moreover, thermal decomposition mechanism of nano CL-20 and nano PETN were investigated via DSC-IR analysis by which their gas products were also detected. The result indicated that nano CL-20 decomposed to CO2 and N2O and nano PETN decayed to NO2, which implied a remarkable difference on decomposition mechanism of two explosives. In addition, mechanical sensitivity of CL-20 and PETN were tested, and the results revealed that nano explosives were more insensitive than raw ones, and then the possible mechanism about this was discussed. Thermal sensitivity was also investigated with 5s bursting point test, and the 5s bursting point (T5s) and the activation of the deflagration were obtained.
515	<strong>Energy dissipation contributed on the machined depth via dynamic plowing lithography of AFM</strong>	In this study, the atomic force microscopy (AFM) tip-based dynamic plowing lithography (DPL) approach is employed to scratch on the poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) thin-film surface. A theoretical model is established based on the relationship between the tip energy dissipation and material removal volume, and the corresponding experiments are also conducted. Both the theoretical and experimental results show that the drive amplitude is proportional to the square of the machined depth of the nanoscale grooves. The mean deviations between the predicted and experimental depths are less than 10%. It is also indicated that the scratching velocity in the range of 0.01-80 &mu;m/s is proportional to the square of the depth (1/<em>h<sup>2</sup></em>), and the mean deviations between the predicted and experimental depths are also less than 7%. In addition, based on the above conclusions, a uniform ripple with desired dimensions can be achieved successfully by overlapping the machined nanogrooves. The wavelength and amplitude of the ripples are determined by controlling the feature size of nanogrooves.
516	<strong>Enhanced room-temperature magnetoresistance in double-barrier graphene spin valves based on antiresonance effect</strong>	Use of a double-barrier spin valve with an armchair graphene nanoribbon to achieve huge tunnel magnetoresistance by an exceptional antiresonance effect is proposed. Compared with single-barrier spin valves, the tunnel magnetoresistance exceeds 10<sup>5</sup>% at room temperature due to the enhanced antiresonance effect in an antiparallel mode in the double-barrier junctions. It is noteworthy that these results can be attributed to a double-barrier design in which a transport gap in the energy interval restricts transmission. This unique mechanism leads to a strong suppression in the propagation of spin electrons. In particular, this phenomenon reveals that spin-polarized currents strongly depend on the thickness of the antiresonance cavity.
517	Study of the effect of osmotic pressure on the water permeability of Carbon-based Two-dimensional Materials	Two-dimensional materials such as graphene and carbon nanotube have promising applications in the preparation of permeable membranes and the field of environmental protection due to their unique structures and components. This paper conducts a study on graphene and nanotubes in salt solution using molecular dynamics computational method, and ascertains the quantitative relations between the ionic concentration, water flux and reverse osmosis pressure by setting up theoretical porous models of the two materials. This fundamental research provides much guidance in the determination of critical parameters like pressure and water flux in the actual application of membranes.
518	<strong>Secondary shock wave: </strong><strong>implication for laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry</strong>	Shadowgraphs of the dynamic evolution of nanosecond laser-induced ablation plumes outside of BCR-2G and BIR-1G geological standard samples at atmospheric pressure are captured. The model of the secondary shock wave is proposed and experimentally verified. Experimental results indicate that the secondary waves appear at 74 ns for BCR-2G and at 98 ns for BIR-1G samples, which result from the reflection of the backward moving gas on the sample surface. Under the same condition, the ablation threshold of the BCR-2G sample is lower than that of the BIR-1G sample. Furthermore, the ablation rate (crater depth per laser pulse) of BCR-2G sample is higher than that of BIR-1G sample. The secondary shock wave induces larger-diameter particles or clusters which have been regarded as a fractionation source. Debris redeposition plays role in the laser ablation and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry. The suppression of the secondary shock wave effect is possible with using low viscosity ablation gas which can expand the shock wave front leading less collision, aggregation of the ablated particles. As a result, the debris redeposition will be attenuated and the larger particles or clusters induced element fractionation can be expected to be suppressed in practice.
519	<strong>Structural and Magnetic property studies of 0-3 Magnetite-Poly(methyl methacrylate) Nanocomposites</strong>	Ultrafine superparamagnetic Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4 </sub>(magnetite) particulate disperse in polymer matrix PMMA (polymethyl methacrylate) are successfully synthesized through solution casting route. We have studies structure and phase of particulate and nanocomposites with x-ray diffraction (XRD) using by Rietveld analysis. The structure of particulate and nanocomposites can be described as a cubic structure with space group (<em>Fd</em> <em>m</em>). Microstructure and elemental composition are examined with the help of scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) respectively. The characteristic functional groups of the polymer are detected from Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). The nanocomposites have tunable band gap energy properties decrease with increases of particulates magnetite in polymer, which determined by UV-spectroscopy. Magnetic measurements revealed superparamagnetic nature of the Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> nanoparticles that also retained in the nanocomposites at room temperature and ferromagnetic at low temperature 5K. The blocking temperature (T<sub>B</sub>) of Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>&ndash;PMMA nanocomposites was found to increase with superparamagnetic Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4 </sub>nanoparticles content with a consistent decrease in saturation magnetization (M<sub>s</sub>) of nanocomposites. The M<sub>s</sub> value could also be estimated on the basis of TGA data, the M<sub>s</sub> values of different nanoparticle and nanocomposites calculated via TGA correlates well with those determined from VSM.
520	<strong>Matrix effect on order-disorder phase transition of FePt nanoparticles</strong>	A theoretical model is developed to systematically study the effect of the matrix to the order-disorder phase transition of FePt nanoparticles, which shows a significant role of the matrix or substrate to the ordering kinetics of FePt nanoparticles during the annealing process. It is shown that there exists a temperature window where one can obtain ordered FePt phase, while the high temperature limit with the largest nucleation rate is favorable for the formation of ordered FePt phase (L1<sub>0</sub>). The matrix or substrate not only reduces particle agglomeration and sintering, but also increases the high temperature limit as well as nucleation rate. Furthermore, the effect of the matrix to the ordering kinetics of FePt nanoparticles relies on its surface energy, the higher the surface energy of the matrix is, the more pronounced the effect is. The validity of the present model is supported by as well the explanations of the contradiction results as the good agreement between the model predictions and experimental data. Those findings are very interesting and crucial for practical application when synthesizing ordered FePt nanoparticles.
521	Seed Free Fabrication of High Quality MoS<sub>2</sub> Monolayer by Chemical Vapour Deposition	MoS<sub>2</sub> is a graphene analogue with exceptional properties for nano-era of semiconductor electronics. Here we report the large-scale synthesis of monolayer MoS<sub>2</sub> onto SiO<sub>2</sub> substrate by seed promotor free CVD process. Piranha treatment reduces the surface free energy of the substrate, thus paving a way for controlled layered growth. Nucleation theory is explored to understand the growth of MoS<sub>2</sub> with and without Piranha treatment, respectively. Careful tracking of parameters, coverage of MoS<sub>2</sub> monolayer extends over centimetre scale with reproducibility. Our results confirm that piranha treatment provides an ideal platform for large scale monolayer MoS<sub>2</sub> on different substrate for device applications.
522	Effect of phonon confinement on the thermal conductivity of In<sub>0.53</sub>Ga<sub>0.47</sub>As nanofilms	Over the past few decades, significant progress has been made to manipulate thermal transport in solids. Most of the effort has focused on reducing the phonon mean free path through boundary scattering. Herein, we demonstrate that the phonon confinement effect can also be used as a tool for managing thermal transport in solids. We measured the thermal conductivities of 10&ndash;70-nm-thick In<sub>0.53</sub>Ga<sub>0.47</sub>As nanofilms and found that the thermal conductivities decrease as the film thickness decreases. However, the reasons for this reduction differ for films with different thicknesses. The thermal conductivity of the 30- and 70-nm-thick In<sub>0.53</sub>Ga<sub>0.47</sub>As nanofilms decreases because of severe phonon boundary scattering. Our analysis indicates that phonon confinement occurs in the 10- and 20-nm-thick In<sub>0.53</sub>Ga<sub>0.47</sub>As nanofilms, which modifies phonon dispersion leading to changes in the phonon group velocity and the Debye temperature. These experimental and theoretical results could help to elucidate the phonon confinement effect in nanomaterials as well as establish a platform for understanding nanoscale thermal physics.
523	<strong>Phonon transport and scattering using modified BDE model coupled with temperature jump boundary condition in nano SiC MOSFET</strong>	In this work, we investigated the non-Fourier heat transfer in nano SiC devices. In the first step, we investigated the ability of our proposed model to describe the phonon scattering in 10 nm MOSFET devices. On the other hand, we studied the nano-heat conduction process in SiC nanodevices. The ballistic-diffusive equation (BDE) was numerically solved to assess the heat transport in the nano transistors. The proposed model is used to report the thermal conductivity through the nature of scattering mechanism. A size-dependent thermal conductivity model agrees with experimental results for silicon nanofilms. To clarify the nature of the phonon-wall collisions, we have considered the effect of the temperature boundary condition on the scattering interface. It is found that our predictive model is able to describe phonons scattering in MOS structures. Furthermore, the SiC MOSFET is more thermally stable than the Si MOSFET.
524	Acoustic funnel and buncher for nanoparticle injection	Acoustics-based techniques are investigated to focus and bunch nanoparticle beams. This allows to overcome the prominent problem of the longitudinal and transverse mismatch of particle stream and x-ray beam in single-particle/single molecule imaging at x-ray free-electron lasers (XFEL). It will also enable synchronized injection of particle streams at kHz repetition rates. Transverse focusing concentrates the particle flux to the (sub)micrometer x-ray focus. In the longitudinal direction, focused acoustic waves can be used to bunch the particle to the same repetition rate as the x-ray pulses. The acoustic manipulation is based on simple mechanical recoil effects and could be advantageous over light-pressure-based methods, which rely on absorption. The acoustic equipment is easy to implement and can be conveniently inserted into current XFEL endstations. With the proposed method, data collection times could be reduced by a factor of 10<sup>4</sup>. This work does not just provide an efficient method for acoustic manipulation of streams of arbitrary gas phase particles, but also opens up wide avenues for acoustics-based particle optics.
525	RHF and DFT  Study of the Molecular and Electronic  Properties of  (SiO2)n and (GeO2)n Nanoclusters	RHF and DFT computations of the molecular and electronic  properties of (SiO2)n and (GeO2)n nanoclusters with   are studied. Silicon dioxide clusters have higher thermal energies and lower average bond lengths and are thus  more stable than Germanium dioxide clusters.  At n=1,  both nanoclusters are non polar, but gradually become more polar with increase in n. The  average polarizability, molecular hyperpolarizability and total thermal energies of the nanoclusters increases with increase in molecular size. Computed values of the electron affinities for  (SiO2)n clusters agree with experimental results.
526	Walker-like breakdown in planar nanowires induced by a square impurity	The current-driven domain wall motion in a planar nanowire with a square impurity located at its center is studied by micromagnetic simulations. We show the existence of four regimes that depend both on the geometrical parameters of the impurity and the nanowire, as well as on the applied current density. These regimes determine a pinning-depinning pattern characterized by: i) the domain wall remains pinned in its initial position; ii) the domain wall is released from its initial position and reaches the square impurity, remaining pinned in that position; iii) the domain wall reaches the impurity and passes it without major obstacles, reaching the other end of the wire; iv) the domain wall reaches the impurity and suffers a series of complex transformations that annihilate it, giving rise to the nucleation of a new domain wall, which is what reaches the other end of the wire. Thus, we claim the existence of a Walker-like breakdown in planar nanowires induced by a square impurity. Our finding could be of practical use in the engineering of logic devices based on the movement of domain walls.
527	<strong>Synthesizing new glass 40P2O5 &ndash; 50BaO - 2.5Na2O &ndash; 2.5MgO - 5TiO2 for the application in high radiation environmental dosimetry</strong>	This paper aimed to present the thermoluminescence (TL) characteristics of phosphorus pentoxide (P2O5) nanopowders as a glass former, modified with barium oxide (BaO) glass. This mixture with activated with titanium oxide (TiO2), than co-activated with magnesium oxide (MgO) and sodium oxide (NaO). The glass was arranged into five different samples depending on the activator concentration and co-activator with the glass matrix 40 P2O5 - 50 BaO. The sample glass 40P2O5 &ndash; 50BaO - 2.5Na2O &ndash; 2.5MgO - 5TiO2 confirmed and proved the following properties: simple, reasonable, and modest way of synthesis, losing nearly about 18.57% from its TL information in 10 days, obvious glow curve shape, linear response, less fading, and high Zeff. Thus, this new formed kind of glass might play a very crucial role especially in the field of environmental dosimetry.
528	<strong>Enhanced Field Emission of Large Size Single-Layer Graphene Emitter Planted in Buffer Layer Substrates by Screen Printing</strong>	This report demonstrates an effective method to make large lateral size graphene for excellent field emission. The large size graphene oxide (GO) was obtained by exfoliating nanoscale expanded graphite and followed with frozen assisted gradient centrifugation. Most of large size GO sheets had their lateral size about 50 &mu;m and demonstrate high quality graphene structure with high 2D peak in Raman spectra after reduction. Mass producible screen-printing method was introduced to plant the reduced GO sheet (rGS) in buffer layer on silicon substrates. Results indicated the emitters made by high quality large size rGS had better performance field emission properties with lower turn-on field reduced from 4V/&mu;m to 0.4V/&mu;m and higher field emission current increased by more than ten times. This study confirmed that the electronic properties of rGS electrodes strongly depend on the lateral size of their precursor GO sheets. And the industrial printing approach will be essential for practical applications of rGS based electronic devices.
529	Controlling Spin Off State by Gas Molecules Adsorption on Metal-Phthalocyanine Molecular Junctions and Its Possibility of Gas Sensor	We present the electronic structure and transport properties of metal phthalocyanine (MPc) (M= Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) molecular junctions for four different gas molecules (NO, CO, O<sub>2</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub>) adsorbing on the M atom of MPc molecule, employing Green&rsquo;s function (GF) technique in combination with spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT). The adsorption configurations, adsorption energy, spin charge transfer and the corresponding transport properties of MPc (M= Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) molecular junctions with these gas molecules are systematically discussed in this work. Our results indicate that the gas adsorption can significantly modify the magnetic moment of MPc for M=Mn, Fe and Co. However, for M=Ni, Cu and Zn, gas adsorption is difficult to be detected due to weak van der Waals interaction between these gases and central M atom. Remarkably, the spin of MPc molecule can be switched to a magnetic off-state by specific gas absorption, giving rise to a potential application on controllable spintronic devices. In addition, CO, NO, O<sub>2</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> gas molecules can be detected selectively by measuring spin filter efficiency of these MPc molecular junctions. On the basis of our results, MPc (M= Mn, Fe, Co) molecular junctions can be considered as a promising nanosensor device to detect individual gas molecules.
530	Atomistic Calculations of Surface Modification in Graphene Coated Copper Electrodes by Energetic Incident Carbon Atoms	Thin nanoscale coating of metal electrodes by graphene promises to be a useful approach in suppressing secondary electron yield.  Recent calculations showed reductions by as much as 50 percent for graphene over copper electrodes for energies below 125 eV, with the results in agreement with experimental data.  Here the robustness and resistance to possible degradation, in response to incoming atomic projectiles, is gauged based on Molecular Dynamics simulations.  Our results for surface irradiation by carbon atoms (as an example) on a nanoscale graphene coatings indicate a defect threshold of about 35 eV, lower surface damage for thicker layers, negligible sputtering and defects less than 6 Angstroms in dimension for energies up to 300 eV.
531	<strong>Phonon-glass-electron-crystal behavior in nanocrystalline Ni doped CoSb<sub>3</sub> skutterudites</strong>	We report the phonon-glass-electron-crystal behavior in Ni doped CoSb<sub>3</sub> skutterudites with Dy partically filled (Dy<sub>0.1</sub>Co<sub>1-x</sub>Ni<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3</sub> (x=0, 0.1, 0.2)). The samples are processed by one step solid-state synthesis route. The structural analysis of the samples using X-ray diffraction reveals the existence of single phase in all the samples irrespective of Ni concentration. Microstructure study using transmission electron microscopy shows the existence of nanometer size grains and the grain size varies between 40 nm to 100 nm. Power factor of Dy<sub>0.1</sub>Co<sub>0.8</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Sb<sub>3</sub> samples is enhanced to 7.1 mW/mK<sup>2</sup>, which is the highest power factor in doped ternary skutterudites reported so far. The enhancement of the power factor is due to the substantial reduction in electrical resistivity with increase in Ni concentration at higher temperature. Lattice thermal conductivity is drastically reduced to 0.26 W/mK at 773 K in Dy<sub>0.1</sub>Co<sub>0.8</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Sb<sub>3 </sub>sample. As a result, a huge increase in figure of merit (ZT~ 1.8) at 773 K is observed in Dy<sub>0.1</sub>Co<sub>0.8</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Sb<sub>3</sub> sample, the highest among the single elemental filled CoSb<sub>3</sub> skutterudites reported so far at this temperature. Hence, Ni doping acts as phonon-glass-electron-glass phenomena in Dy partially filled CoSb<sub>3</sub> skutterudites. This can be taken as reference to synthesize CoSb<sub>3</sub> skutterudite thermoelectric materials having higher figure of merit.
532	Defects characterisation studies and exploration of europium substitution effects in nanocrystalline bismuth ferrite through positron annihilation and other methods	A detailed study of the origin and role of structural defects on the effects of Eu<sup>3+</sup>-substitution(<em>x</em> = 0.0, 0.05,&hellip;, 0.3) in place of Bi<sup>3+</sup> in Bi<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Eu<em><sub>x</sub></em>FeO<sub>3 </sub>nanocrystalline multiferroic perovskite samples is presented. The samples were synthesized through the normal sol-gel route and characterised by X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy. Further, UV-Vis absorption studies enabled the measurements of the band gap, which showed a continuous decrease on increased substitution. The phenomenon indicated the creation of defects-induced energy levels in the band gap closer to the conduction band. Positron annihilation spectroscopy is used in the identification of the structural defects in the crystallites. The studies revealed high concentrations of trivacancy-type defects within the Bi<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Eu<em><sub>x</sub></em>FeO<sub>3</sub>nanocrystallites. The transformation from the distorted rhombohedral structure to an orthorhombic configuration with an accompanying lattice contraction at <em>x</em>&gt; 0.2 influenced the positron lifetimes and the intensities. Substitution also helped in the cancellation of pre-existed vacancies through recombination with the doped ions. The measured positron lifetimes also indicated a fraction of the positrons annihilating from the nanocrystallite surfaces. Coincidence Doppler broadening measurements supported the transformation taking place during the substitution process and further identified the cationic vacancies as the predominant defects. The studies were found justified in the magneto-electric voltage measurements under a.c. magnetic fields of different strengths, all of which peaked at <em>x</em> = 0.2 and then decreased concomitantly with the transformation of the crystallites to the orthorhombic structure.
533	A micro Dalton resolution mass sensor with levitated nanodisks by the scenario ofmeasuring after cooling at room temperature	We propose a mass sensor using optically trapped and cooled dielectric nano disks with "measuring<br />after cooling" scheme. The center-of-mass motion of a trapped particle in vacuum can experience<br />extremely low dissipation resulting in robust decoupling from the heat bath. Thus the ground state<br />measurement can be accomplished in a short time after the optomechanical cooling is nished. This<br />method can lead to 10^-6 &#x0018; 10^-7 Dalton mass sensitivity which is a thousand times smaller than<br />the mass of one electron.
534	Enhancement of overall thermal conductance in a rectangular microchannel heat sink: evolutionary behavior of nanofluids and micro pin fins	Here we show that the overall thermal conductance in a rectangular microchannel heat sink can be maximized with which combinations of the volumetric ratios of nanofluids and micro pin fins. Fluid flow is driven by the pressure difference in between the inlet and outlet of the channel, and the dimensionless pressure difference defined as Bejan (Be) number. Here we uncover the effect of both micro pin fins and nanofluids separately and simultaneously in order to uncover their effect on the thermal conductance (i.e., thermal resistance). Both nanofluids and micro pin fins decrease the thermal resistances due to high thermal conductivity values of solids and increase the heat transfer surface area of the solid particles interacting with the fluid. However, the pumping power (pressure drop) increases in both cases due to the increase in the resistances to the fluid flow. The results documented what should be the solid nanoparticles volume fraction mixed into the base fluid and the solid volume fraction for the micro pin fins in order to minimize thermal resistances. The effect of the number of micro pin fins and their position along the microchannel on the thermal conductance are also documented. If the thermal conductivity of the nanoparticles is lower than the thermal conductivity of the fins, only fins maximize the thermal conductance for low Be numbers, and nanofluids maximize it for high Be numbers. This behavior analogous to an evolutionary concept where fins should dissolve in time to enhance thermal conductance similar to erosion in river beds.
535	Effects of electron-electron interaction on the collinear indirect exchange coupling in graphene nanoflakes	Using the Hubbard model in the framework of the tight-bonding<br />formulation, We study the effects of the electron-electron (e-e) interaction on the<br />indirect magnetic exchange coupling between the magnetic impurities embedded<br />in triangular graphene nanoflakes.The results show that the magnitude of the<br />coupling enhances in the presence of the e-e interaction and Rashba spin-orbit<br />interaction(RSOI). Also, the RKKY coupling magnitude depends on the impurity<br />positions in nanoflake and the size of the system
536	<strong>Tuning the electronic &amp; magnetic properties of graphene/<em>h</em>-BN hetero nanoribbon:</strong><strong> a</strong><strong></strong><strong> first-principles investigation</strong>	The successful synthesis of phase separated in plane graphene/<em>h</em>-BN hetero structures encourages to design one dimensional graphene/<em>h</em>-BN hetero nanoribbon (G/BNNR). Using first-principles density functional based approach, the electronic and magnetic properties of the hybrid ribbons with monohydrogenated edges have been investigated for different configurations with alternative composition of C-C and B-N units in a ribbon of fixed width. The lresult suggests that the electronic as well as magnetic properties of the ribbons can be regulated by the number of C-C (or B-N) units present in the structure. Both the hetero nanoribbons, either with N or B terminated edges, undergo a semiconductor-to-semimetal-to-metal transition with the increase in C-C units for a fixed ribbon width. The spin density distribution shows that significant localization of the magnetic moments is observed at the edge carbon atoms and arises when the number of C-C units is greater than 2 for most of the structures.
537	Nonlinear waves in a model for silicate layers	Some layered silicates are composed of positive ions, surrounded by layers of ions with opposite sign.  Mica muscovite is a particularly interesting material, because there exist fossil and experimental evidence for  nonlinear excitations transporting localized energy and charge along the cation rows within the potassium layers.  This evidence suggest that there are different kinds of excitations with different energies and properties. Some of the authors proposed recently a model based in physical principles and the silicate structure. The main characteristic of the model is that it has a hard substrate potential and two different repulsion terms, between ions and nuclei.  In a previous work with this model,  it was found the propagation of crowdions, i.e., lattice kinks in a lattice with substrate potential that transport mass and charge. They have a single specific velocity  and energy coherent with the experimental data. In this paper we perform a much more thorough search for nonlinear excitations using the pseudospectral method to obtain exact nanopteron solutions, that is single kinks with tails, crowdions and bi-crowdions. We analyze their velocities, energies and stability or instability and the possible reasons for the latter. We relate the different excitations with their possible origin from recoils from different beta decays and with the fossil tracks.  We  explore the consequences of some variation of the physical parameters because their values are not perfectly known. Through a different method, we also have found breathers, that is, localized nonlinear excitations with an internal vibration. They have small amplitude and energy, which is also coherent with the fossil evidence.
538	Symmetry changes during relaxation process and pulse discharge performance of the BaTiO<sub>3</sub>-Bi(Mg<sub>1/2</sub>Ti<sub>1/2</sub>)O<sub>3</sub> ceramic	Lead free relaxor ferroelectrics have attracted continued interests due to their outstanding and eco-friendly properties. In this paper, dielectric relaxation behavior of the 0.6BaTiO<sub>3</sub>-0.4Bi(Mg<sub>1/2</sub>Ti<sub>1/2</sub>)O<sub>3</sub> ceramic (BT-40BMT), which is a typical lead free relaxor ferroelectric, is theoretically and experimentally investigated. At first, the observed dielectric relaxation was quantitatively characterized by a novel statistical model, indicating that the minority co-related polar nano regions (PNRs) dominate the total polarization. Kinetics of the PNRs was subsequently studied by micro-Raman measurements performed at various temperatures. Here, the relaxation of written domains formed by the piezoresponse force microscopy (PFM) tip-bias induced electric field was also studied, which describes the polarization retention performance of BT-40BMT. Absence of ferroelectric signal contribution in local switching was also confirmed by the contact mode kelvin PFM technique, indicating the lack of local ferroelectricity. Moreover, temperature insensitive energy storage property from 293 K to 443 K was obtained. High voltage pulsed discharge behavior was also investigated by using the pulsed current. A power density of 7.9&times;10<sup>8</sup> W/kg is obtained under a pulsed voltage of 50 kV. Combined with the fast discharge time, the 0.6BaTiO<sub>3</sub>-0.4Bi(Mg<sub>1/2</sub>Ti<sub>1/2</sub>)O<sub>3</sub> ceramic is considered as a candidate material for high voltage pulse power applications.
539	<strong>Vortex dynamics </strong><strong>over an airfoil</strong> <strong>controlled by</strong><strong> nanosecond pulse discharge plasma actuator</strong>	This paper presents the vortex dynamics of flow reattachment on a NASA SC (2)-0712 airfoil by a nanosecond pulse dielectric barrier discharge (NS DBD) actuator at a Reynolds number of 1&times;10<sup>5</sup>. The two-dimensional Navier-Stokes equations are solved, and a source term on the right-hand side of the governing fluid energy transport equation is incorporated. The experimental results are well-predicted by computations, where the NS DBD actuator discharge produces a pressure wave with a velocity of 342 m/s and near surface thermal perturbations. Both experimental and computational results indicate that the NS DBD actuator introduces a series of vortexes into the shear layer. In turn, those vortexes promote the mixing of the shear layer, which results in separated flow reattachment. The two-dimensional vorticity evolution equation demonstrates that the vorticity is produced due to the intersection of density and pressure surfaces after plasma discharge. This vorticity advects downstream quickly via local flow velocity. The phase time flow results suggest the mechanism of NS DBD for flow control is the heating effect, which changes the local temperature and density and later induces vortex structures. The vortex structures entrain the outer high-momentum fluid into the shear layer and enhance the turbulent kinetic energy and kinetic energy at the leeward of the wing, thereby strengthening the mixing of the shear layer with the main flow, thereby promoting the separated flow reattachment.
540	<strong>Scale Effect of 6T-SRAM Cell in Nano-scale Technology</strong>	Degradation of the performance of the integrated circuit is introduced by the so-called scale effect when the feature size is reduced down to nanometer level. The scale effect can deteriorate the read stability and write ability of the static random access memory (SRAM). Therefore, it is important to investigate the scale effect of the SRAM cell at nano-scale technology. In this paper, the scale effect of the conventional 6T SRAM cell is discussed with the technology node varying from 90 nm down to 7 nm. The static noise margins (SNM) at the different technology nodes are extracted by using butterfly curves approach. The scale effect on the stability of the SRAM is analyzed based on the relationship between the simulated SNM values and the corresponding technology nodes. The physical mechanism of the scale effect of the SRAM cell is also discussed. It shows that the short channel effect appears and even dominates when the technology node shrinks down to nanoscales. In this manner, the traditional carrier transfer theory is no longer applicable. Because of the leakage current and transmission scattering operation, degradation of the SNM of the SRAM cell appears. An approach for optimization of the scale effect of the SRAM in nano-scale technology is proposed in the paper.
541	Bending deformation behavior of Zr65Cu17.5Ni10Al7.5 bulk metallic glass with different solidification cooling rate	In order to further clarify the relationship between the free volume and bending plasticity, the bending properties of Zr65Cu17.5Ni10Al7.5 bulk metallic glass (BMG) samples with different thicknesses corresponding to different solidification cooling rates were investigated. The results show that the bending plasticity of Zr65Cu17.5Ni10Al7.5 BMG decreases with the decrease of cooling rate, which is consistent with the evolution of shear bands density revealed by the investigation of microstructure. These phenomena are mainly attributed to the decrease of free volume content with the decrease of cooling rates, although the increase of nanocrystallization fraction. These results further confirm that free volume plays an important role in the deformation process of the BMGs.
542	<strong>Molecular dynamics study of defects and dislocations behaviour during tensile deformation of copper-silver core-shell nanowires with varying core diameter and shell thickness</strong>	Core-shell type nanostructures have drawn much attention among material researchers as they exhibit exceptional properties due to their unique structure. Among different core-shell nanostructures, copper-silver core-shell nanostructures are widely investigated in recent days for exhibiting different unique properties like very high mechanical strength. Molecular dynamics simulations were carried out to investigate the underlying deformation mechanism during tensile testing of copper-silver core-shell nanowire with varying core diameter and shell thickness. The Wigner-Seitz defect analysis was used to calculate the total number of point defects like vacancies and interstitials during the entire deformation process. The type, number and total length of dislocation segments were thoroughly investigated throughout the different stages of deformation. The effect of varying core diameter and shell thickness on the defects and dislocations configuration were also studied. Thus this study helps us to understand the underlying mechanisms or factors that contribute to the ultra-high strength and mechanical properties of Cu-Ag core-shell nanowires with varying core diameter and shell thickness.
543	Optical trapping of ultrasmooth gold nanoparticles in liquid and air	Optical manipulation of gold nanoparticles has emerged as an exciting avenue for studies in nanothermometry, cell poration, optical binding and optomechanics. However, conventional gold nanoparticles usually depart from a spherical shape, making such studies less controlled and leading to potential artifacts in trapping behavior. We synthesize ultrasmooth gold nanoparticles, which offer improved circularity and monodispersity. In this article, we demonstrate the advantages of such nanoparticles through a series of optical trapping experiments in both liquid and air. Compared to their conventional counterparts, ultrasmooth gold nanoparticles exhibit up to a three-fold reduction in standard deviation for trap stiffness measurements both in liquid and air and thus offer more controlled studies of plasmon mediated light-matter interactions.
544	Structural, Optical and Luminescent Properties of Antimony Doped ZnO Nanowires	We synthesized Sb-doped ZnO (ZnO:Sb) nanowires with varying Sb content and carried out a systematic study on their structural, optical and photoluminescent properties. Scanning electron microscopy revealed a hexagonal morphology of the as grown wires, while the x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Ultra Violet -Visible spectroscopy results indicated the incorporation of Sb dopants into the ZnO lattice. XPS and x-ray diffraction analysis revealed that all ZnO:Sb nanowires with different Sb doping possessed typical wurtzite structure and had no other impurity phases. Furthermore, the XPS results showed that Sb ions are in an oxidation state between 3+ and 5+, indicating the existence of the (Sb<sub>Zn</sub>-2V<sub>Zn</sub>) acceptor complex in the ZnO:Sb nanowires. Photoluminescence (PL) measurements confirmed the formation of shallow acceptor levels in the ZnO:Sb nanowires. PL measurements at Low temperature showed strong violet luminescence, which is originated from free-electron to acceptor level (FA) transitions. The FA emission showed a slight blue shift with the increase of the temperature. As a result of Sb incorporation into the ZnO lattice, we observed a red shift in the ZnO:Sb nanowires energy gap with the increase of Sb doping. This red shift is attributed to the formation of acceptor levels inside the ZnO band gap. The identification of this acceptor level in these single-phase Sb doped ZnO nanowires provides strong promise of p-type conductivity of ZnO by Sb doping.
545	<strong>Decouple the Effects of Surface Structure and Intrinsic Wettability on Boiling Heat Transfer<sup></sup></strong>	Surface structure and intrinsic wettability are both important for boiling heat transfer. While superhydrophilic micro, nano and hierarchical surfaces are widely used for boiling enhancement, the surface structure and intrinsic wettability are usually coupled together. This study aims to decouple their effects on boiling heat transfer. Copper meshes are utilized as the microporous structures, and conformal superhydrophilic films are deposited by atomic layer deposition (ALD) of TiO<sub>2</sub>. Although ALD coatings for boiling have been done on flat surfaces, our study separates the effect of surface structure from that of intrinsic wettability on a three-dimensional (3D) microporous surface. By comparing two and four layer meshes, we show that the surface structure has no obvious effects on the critical heat flux (CHF), but can significantly enhance the heat transfer coefficient (HTC). The intrinsic superhydrophilicity dramatically increases the CHF due to the fast rewetting of dryout domains. Our conclusion is that fast rewetting is critical to increase CHF, while large exposed surface areas are vital to enhance HTC.
546	Density-functional study of hydrogen cyanide adsorption on silicene nanoribbons	Adsorption of toxic hydrogen cyanide gas (HCN) on armchair silicene nanoribbons (ASiNRs) is investigated by first principles method using density functional theory (DFT) to compute geometric, electronic and transport properties. Two variants of ASiNRs are considered: pristine ASiNR (P-ASiNR) and defective ASiNR (D-ASiNR), which is created by introducing a vacancy in P-ASiNR by removal of a Si atom. Total energy optimizations are used to find the most stable structures. The calculated results reveal that although HCN is physisorbed in both variants, sensitivity in case of D-ASiNR is sufficiently enhanced owing to more adsorption energy and charge transfer between the ASiNR-gas complex. Also the inspection of current-voltage characteristics demonstrates that the introduction of defect has considerably increased the conductivity of ASiNR. Hence, D-ASiNR may be used as a promising sensor for HCN gas.
547	Bubble dimer dynamics induced by double laser beam ablation in liquid	An approach based on double laser beam ablation in liquid is presented for the preparation of polymetallic nanoparticle colloids. The dynamics of double laser-induced bubble dimer is studied by the combination of an inviscid Rayleigh-Plesset model, ultrafast camera, and time-resolved shadowgraph experiments. It indicates that the bubble-pair will rapidly merge into a dimer and then undergo symmetric evolution as a single bubble, which can promote the agglomeration of different kinds of metal particles in this thermodynamic environment. Moreover, the atomic ratio of polymetallic compound with high crystallinity can be precisely adjusted by double laser energy ratio without any additives.
548	High-frequency soft magnetic properties of Co&ndash;SiO<sub>2</sub> nano-granular films with large out-of-plane magnetic anisotropy	For their use as flexible frameworks in high-frequency electromagnetic devices, soft magnetic thin films must have a high permeability <em>&mu;</em> up to frequencies of the order of tens of GHz and must overcome directional limitations. In this study, we demonstrate full in-plane, high-frequency, soft magnetic performances of Co<sub>x&middot;</sub>(SiO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>1-x</sub> nano-granular films with large out-of-plane anisotropy. For a film with Co concentration <em>x</em> = 0.52, we obtained a high value <em>&mu;</em> = 4 up to the resonance frequency of 13 GHz for every direction in the film plane. The full in-plane permeability and resonance frequency are respectively about double and five times higher than those of conventional in-plane uniaxial magnetically anisotropic or stripe-domain type soft magnetic films. The fine magnetic-maze-domain structure that we observed using magnetic force microscopy was unaffected by the application of an external magnetic field. Both the large out-of-plane anisotropy fields of a few thousand Oe and the negligibly small remnant magnetization contribute to producing a resonance frequency greater than 10 GHz and to enable magnetically isotropic conditions in the film plane, with high reversibility in external magnetic fields. Our film with the large out-of-plane anisotropy promises to be a useful material for applications in fully directional and flexible designs of electromagnetic devices.
549	<strong>Photocurrent enhancement in metal-semiconductor-metal based broadband absorbers with double Schottky barriers</strong>	We experimentally report improved photocurrent performance under the illumination of both UV and visible light in the metal-semiconductor-metal nanostructures with double Schottky barriers, consisting of a monolayer of Au nanoparticles and a planar Au film separated by a thin WO<sub>3</sub> layer. We demonstrate that the near-unit broadband optical absorption causing the increased population of the hot electrons together with the occurrence of electron trapping effect at the bottom Schottky barrier are responsible for the photocurrent enhancement under visible illumination. Under the direct UV band-gap excitation of WO<sub>3</sub>, the electron trapping effect at the bottom barrier plays a crucial role in the anodic photocurrent enhancement. Furthermore, we demonstrate that by replacing the Au film with the metal Pt of higher work function to increase the barrier height of the bottom Schottky barrier, and hence strengthening its ability for electron trapping, the photocurrent can gain a further significant enhancement under both the visible and UV illuminations.
550	<strong>Synthesis and optical properties of Co<sup>2+</sup>-doped ZnO Network prepared by new precursors </strong>	Pure ZnO nanoparticles (NPs) and Co/ZnO alloy NPs were synthesized with different percentages of cobalt impurity (1%, 3%, 5%, and 25%) with new precursors through the coprecipitation method. The structural results of the XRD analysis indicated that the pure and impure samples have a wurtzite hexagonal structure such that with an elevation of Co impurity up to 1%, the size of the nanocrystals declines by up to 30 nm. Furthermore, the FESEM analysis results suggest the homogeneity of the NPs such that with increased cobalt impurity, its level declines. The TEM analysis results revealed that the NPs with 5% impurity have a mean size of 32 nm in spherical form. The FTIR optical analysis results suggest a very sharp absorption peak within the wavelength ranges of 434&ndash;448 cm<sup>&minus;1</sup>, belonging to the Zn-O vibration bond. In addition, the absorption peak developed at the wavelength of 3428 cm<sup>&minus;1</sup> is related to the activation of the OH radicals, whose absorption value grows with the addition of an impurity, thereby, causing enhanced photocatalytic activity. The UV-DRS optical analysis indicated that the absorption wavelength grows with increased impurity, causing the development of redshift and a reduction of the energy band gap. In this regard, for the pure sample, the band gap value was 3.18 eV, while for the sample with 5% impurity, the band gap was obtained as 2.68 eV. The VSM magnetic analysis suggests ferromagnetic development in the impure sample, with a saturation magnetism of 16 memu/g and a coercivity field of 342 G.
551	Effect of MWCNT-Fe3O4/Water Hybrid Nanofluid on the Thermal Performance of Ribbed Channel with Apart Sections of Heating and Cooling	A Two-dimensional (2D) numerical simulation is performed to simulate the laminar forced convection of a nanofluid in a ribbed channel with apart heating (cooling) sources using lattice Boltzmann method (LBM). The multi-wall carbon nanotubes-iron oxide nanoparticles/water hybrid nanofluid (MWCNT-Fe3O4/water hybrid nanofluid) is used in this simulation.  The velocity field, temperature distribution and heat transfer rate are numerically analyzed with the streamlines and isotherm patterns by means of a house-code. Also, the effect of Reynolds number (Re=25, 50, 75 and 100), nanoparticle solid volume fraction (&#x03D5;=0, 0.001, 0.003) and ratio of the blocks height (A=0.2, 0.3, 0.4) are measured in this paper. The computational method is validated against the results reported in the literature and a good agreement is reported. The obtained results show a maximum value of 16.49% increase in average heat transfer coefficient for all the considered cases relative to the base fluid. Moreover, the local Nusselt number proves that the use of blocks on the channel walls can increase the amount of heat transfer. Finally, average Nusselt number shows a linear dependence on the increasing ratio of  blocks height for constant solid volume fraction. The results of this study are applicable to the industrial equipment heating and cooling applications.
552	<strong>Hydrothermally synthesized Zn rich novel ZnO nanostructures for development of high responsivity deep UV photo-detectors</strong>	ZnO is a well-known material for near UV light detection, however its near UV absorption limits its potential for making it a candidate for deep UV range. Although Mg doped ZnO and integration of ZnO with materials like Ga<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> has been used to cover deep UV region. Nevertheless, pristine ZnO nanostructures synthesized by hydrothermal technique, have never been used for deep UV detection. Here, in this letter, we have engineered the absorption spectra of ZnO in the deep UV region by intentionally incorporating only Zn atoms. Tri-Sodium citrate (Na<sub>2</sub>C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>5</sub>O<sub>7</sub>) has been used both as surfactant for fabricating honeycomb nanostructures as well as a reducing agent to incorporate Zn in ZnO nanostructures. The high absorption coefficient of Zn in deep UV region facilitates high photo-responsivity in this region of electromagnetic spectrum. Compared to relatively common ZnO nano-rods, honeycomb nanostructures exhibits ~3 order of magnitude lower dark current and ~2 orders of magnitude higher photo-current. The measured photosensitivity in honeycomb nanostructure is approximately 4.9*10<sup>5</sup>, which is ~5 orders of magnitude higher compared to that of ZnO nano-rods based devices. These observed effects have been attributed to the formation of Schottky junction at Ag/ZnO interface along with thinner nano-plates (~ 20 nm) present in honeycomb structures. The responsivity of the photoconductor is as high as 1.15 x 10<sup>3</sup>A/W, which can be ascribed to the thinner nano-walls and high Zn concentration in honeycomb nanostructures. Such large enhancement in the UV photo-response makes it a promising candidate for deep UV photo-detectors for commercial applications.
553	<strong>Excellent photoresponse of individual WS<sub>2</sub> nanowire-nanoflake hybrid materials</strong>	Van der Waals solids have been recognized as highly photosensitive materials that compete conventional Si and compound semiconductor based devices. While 2-dimensional (2D) nanosheets of single and multiple layers of molybdenum and tungsten chalcogenides have been extensively studied, their corresponding 1-dimensional and other nanostructured derivatives are not explored yet. Here, we report on the electrical and photosensitive properties of WS<sub>2</sub> nanowire-nanoflake hybrid materials we developed lately. We probe individual hybrid nanostructured particles along the structure using focused ion beam deposited Pt contacts. Further, we use conductive atomic force microscopy to analyze electrical behavior across the nanostructure in the transverse direction. The electrical measurements are complemented by in situ laser beam illumination to explore the photoresponse of the nanohybrids in the visible optical spectrum. Photodetector devices with responsivity up to ~0.4 AW<sup>-1</sup> are demonstrated outperforming other transition metal dichalcogenides and graphene.
554	Benchmarking of GGA density functionals for modeling structures of nanoporous, rigid and flexible MOFs	The adequate choice of interaction model is essential to reproduce qualitatively and estimate quantitatively the experimentally observed characteristics of materials or phenomena in computer simulations. Here we present the results of a benchmarking of DFT calculations of rigid and flexible metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). The stability of these systems depends on the dispersion interactions. We compare the performance of two functionals, PBE and PBEsol, with and without the dispersion corrections (D2 and TS), in reproducing the high-accuracy low-temperature X-ray and neutron diffraction data for both groups of MOFs. We focus our analysis on the key structural parameters: the lattice parameters, bond lengths and angles. We show that the dispersion long range correction is essential to stabilize the structures and, in some cases, to converge the system to a geometry that is in line with the experimentally observed structure, especially for breathing MIL-53 structures or zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs). We found that for all structures and all analyzed parameters the D2-corrected PBE functional performs the best, except for bonds involving the metal ions; however, even for these bonds, the difference between the experimentally observed and calculated lengths is small. Therefore, we recommend the use of PBE-D2 functional in further numerical analyses of rigid and flexible nanoporous MOFs.
555	<strong>Bolometric photodetection using plasmon-assisted resistivity change in vanadium dioxide</strong>	Vanadium oxide is a key sensing material for bolometric photodetection, thanks to its strong temperature dependence of resistivity close to room temperature. Here we demonstrate the photodetection of a stoichiometric vanadium dioxide thin film integrated with silver nanorods. The nanorods convert light into heat, consequently suppressing the resistivity of vanadium dioxide via localised surface plasmon resonance. Incorporation of this thermo-plasmonic effect into bolometric photodetection allows for wavelength and polarisation sensitivity. This work opens the path to a broad family of photodetection functionalities for vanadium dioxide-based microbolometers.
556	Cluster beams, nano-ripples and bio applications	Gas cluster ions are aggregates of weakly bonded gas atoms or molecules. Upon impact of gas cluster ions, multiple collisions occur between target atoms and the atoms in the cluster ions. These impact processes are completely different from those of collision-cascade process which are induced by atomic or molecular (monomer) ions. Although the impact process of gas cluster ions is different, ripples, which are similar to that formed by monomer ions, are formed by gas cluster ion impacts at oblique incidence. In this review, ripple formations by gas cluster ions are explained from the point of formation mechanism, characteristics, and applications of bio-sensors.
557	Tuning the structural and magnetic properties of MnZn nano-ferrites synthesized under a high magnetic field	NA
558	<strong>Spectroscopic behaviour of Er<sup>3+</sup>/Eu<sup>3+</sup>/Yb<sup>3+ </sup></strong><strong>codoped NaZnPO<sub>4 </sub>nanophosphors in optical thermometry</strong>	The Eu<sup>3+ </sup>activated Er<sup>3+</sup>/Yb<sup>3+</sup>: NaZnPO<sub>4 </sub>nanphosphors synthesized by co-precipitation technique have been structurally and optically characterized. The effect of Eu<sup>3+ </sup>ions concentration on photoluminescence (PL) intensity and mechanisms involved has been discussed. The red to green intensity ratio, suppression ratio and asymmetry ratio have been calculated with the variation of Eu<sup>3+</sup> concentration. The Eu&ndash;O ligand behaviour and spectral characteristics have been discussed in the light of nephelauxetic ratio and Judd&ndash;Ofelt parameters. Quantum yield of the nanophosphors is found to be ~ 25%. Optical thermometry behaviour of the developed nanophosphors with maximum sensitivity ~ 7.3&times;10<sup>-3 </sup>K<sup>-1</sup> at 503 K is reported.
559	Effects of RF Plasma Modification on the Thermal and Mechanical Properties of Electrospun Chitosan/Poly(vinyl Alcohol) Nanofiber Mats	On the design and fabrication of biomedical devices, the mechanical integrity and the thermal stability of the materials used are of paramount consideration. In this study, the effects of 13.56 MHz radio frequency plasma modification using argon (Ar) and oxygen (O2) plasma discharges on the morphology, thermal properties and tensile properties of the nonwoven electrospun chitosan/poly(vinyl alcohol) nanofibrous membranes were investigated. The SEM results have shown a significant change in the morphology of the nanofiber mats due to the Ar and O2 plasma discharges. The TG-DTG data revealed two major degradation steps for both the pristine samples and the Ar plasma-treated samples due to the molecular backbone degradation and decomposition of polyene and carbonyl residues. However, a third peak was observed for O2 plasma-treated samples which may be due to the oxygen functionalities imparted by the discharge. DSC results have shown the glass transition temperature at 65&#x00BA;C to 68&#x00BA;C and a melting temperature at around 200&#x00BA;C to 220&#x00BA;C. Also, a decrease in the crystallinity of the plasma-treated samples were noted from the DSC thermograms. A significant (p &lt; 0.0.5) decrease in the tensile strength, yield strength, Young's modulus and elongation at break were noted for the plasma-treated samples due to the etching and ablation effects induced by energetic particle interactions. However, the mechanical properties are still comparable with the tensile properties of human tissues such as the skin. These nonwoven mats with tuned properties have potential use in biomedical engineering particularly as tissue scaffolds, wound dressings, sutures and antibacterial gauzes.
560	<strong>Enhanced Electroluminescence Efficiency in Nanocluster Light Emitting Diodes through Apical Ligand Exchange</strong>	Metal halide nanoclusters represent an attractive class of molecular building blocks to design functional materials with superior optical properties that can be utilized in solar energy conversion, light emitting diodes, sensors and photodynamic therapies. Here, we demonstrate red and near-infrared light emitting diodes with a maximum external quantum efficiency &gt; 1% utilizing phosphorescent octahedral molybdenum iodide nanoclusters. This is the highest reported electrically driven quantum efficiency for nanoclusters. Efficiency improvement in these devices is realized by substituting heavier ligands in the apical nanocluster position that leads to the improvement in photoluminescence and exciton formation efficiencies in the nanoclusters. These results highlight how modulation of nanocluster salts with key terminal ligands has a profound effect on photoluminescence as well as electrical injection.
561	Propagation of THz Pulses in Rectangular Subwavelength Dielectric Waveguides	Rectangular subwavelength waveguides are necessary for the development of micro/nano photonic devices and on-chip platforms. Using a time-resolved imaging system, we studied the transient properties and the propagation modes of   THz pulses in rectangular subwavelength dielectric waveguides. The dynamic process of THz pulses was systematically recorded to a movie. In addition, an anomalous group velocity dispersion was demonstrated in rectangular subwavelength waveguides. By using effective index method, we theoretically calculated the modes in rectangular subwavelength waveguides, which agree well with the experiments and simulations. This work provides the opportunity to improve the analysis and design of the integrated platforms and photonic devices.
562	<strong>Novel Amorphous Nanowires from Solution Processed Ge<sub>25</sub>Se<sub>65</sub>Sb<sub>10</sub> Chalcogenide Glass</strong>	One dimensional chalcogenide nanostructures are promising candidates which enables new photonic functionalities. The findings of a novel one step method for synthesis of amorphous nanowires from GeSeSb chalcogenide glass using ethylenediamine or ethanolamine as solvent is reported. Inspite of having same morphology, it is manifested that the nanowire dimensions could be tuned with solute concentration which in turn helps for controllable nanowire characteristics.
563	Geometries and stabilities and electronic propertiessof (CdS)2n (n=5-27) electrode nanoclusters for supercapacitors	Metal sulfides hollow structures are advanced materials for energy storage applications of supercapacitors and sensors. Geometries and electronic properties of (CdS)2n (n=6-27) nanocages are calculated at the gradient corrected Perdew-Burke-Ernzerh (PBE) of exchange-correlation functional level with relativistic effect considered. The inner radius and charge-transfers along with surface stabilities and ionic semiconductor properties of hollowed (CdS)2n are increased as cage size being increased, the distinct metallic and semiconductor characters in largesize (CdS)2n are revealed. Particularly, the calculated energy gaps for (CdS)2n are generally decreased as size of (CdS)2n being increased, together with absorption spectra moving from short to long wavelength. The energy storage related quantum capacitance is discussed, interestingly, encapsulated nanocage (double-layer cage) has bigger capacitance and stronger capacity for energy storage than the mono-layer CdS nanocages. The particular stable geometry is assigned and comparison with available experimental and theoretical results is made.
