564	Inhibition and formation of plasmonic resonances in flat metallic nanoantennas via periodic proximity	We numerically investigate control of plasmonic modes of strip-like flat metallic nanoantennas via their periodic arrangement in the form of two dimensional arrays (lattices). We demonstrate that via variation of the structural parameters of such lattices, we can adjust their plasmonic and photonic-plasmonic couplings, forming lattice-induced resonances that are characteristically different from the plasmonic modes that occur in individual nanoantennas. Our results show that when the incident light is polarized along the short axes of the nanoantennas, the arrays can dictate formation of bright surface modes far from the corners. By controlling the lattice constants the fields associated with such modes can penetrate deeply into the substrate, form field bridge across two locations of the same nanoanatenna or the neighboring ones, or couple to photonic fields. When the polarization of the incident light becomes polarized along the long axes of the nanoantennas, the presence of strong interplay between photonic-plasmonic hybridization and plasmonic coupling of neighboring nanoantennas can lead to formation of ultrasharp collective resonances. These results highlight how the close arrangement of flat metallic nanoatennas can modify charge distributions at the edges, inhibiting or imposing certain modes.
565	<strong>Acoustic Phonon Engineering in Bulk Crystals via Incorporation of Dopant Atoms</strong>	We report results of Brillouin &ndash; Mandelstam spectroscopy of transparent Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> crystals with <em>Nd</em> dopants. The ionic radius and atomic mass of <em>Nd</em> atoms are distinctively different from those of the host <em>Al </em>atoms. Our results show that even a small concentration of <em>Nd</em> atoms incorporated into the Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples produces a profound change in the acoustic phonon spectrum. The velocity of the transverse acoustic phonons decreases by ~600 m/s at the <em>Nd</em> density of only ~0.1 %. Interestingly, the decrease in the phonon frequency and velocity with the doping concentration is non-monotonic. The obtained results, demonstrating that modification of the acoustic phonon spectrum can be achieved not only by nanostructuring but also by doping have important implications for thermal management as well as thermoelectric and optoelectronic devices.
566	Investigations on the plasma enabled growth of vertical graphene sheets on CNT surface	A theoretical model is developed to describe the plasma-assisted nucleation and growth kinetics of vertical graphene (VG) sheet on the carbon nanotube (CNT) surface. The present model accounts the formalization of charge separation region i.e., plasma sheath between the bulk plasma and substrate surface in one-dimension along with the kinetics of all the plasma species (neutrals, positively charged species, and electrons), rate of charge accumulation on the graphene sheet surface, and growth of VG sheet on the CNT surface owing to defects generation and various processes on the CNT surface. Using the model, we demonstrated that variations in the plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) process control parameters such as the total gas pressure, input power, and substrate bias can be used for significant variation in the plasma composition and characteristics that in turn control the ion bombardment and generation of carbon species on the CNT surface, and consequently tune the VG sheet growth characteristics such as, height, thickness and number density profiles of VG sheet on the CNT surface. The results of the present study indicate that as the total gas pressure is lowered and the input power and substrate bias are enhanced, the number densities and height of the VG sheet on the CNT surface are increased; however, the thickness of the VG sheet is reduced. Some of our theoretical findings are in good agreement with the existing experimental results.
567	<strong>Nanoscopic studies of domain structure evolution in ferroelectric La:HfO<sub>2</sub> capacitors</strong>	Visualization of domain structure evolution under an electrical bias has been carried out in ferroelectric La:HfO<sub>2</sub> capacitors by a combination of Piezoresponse Force Microscopy (PFM) and pulse switching techniques to study the nanoscopic mechanism of polarization reversal and the wake-up process. It has been directly shown that the main mechanism behind the transformation of the polarization hysteretic behavior and an increase in the remanent polarization value upon the alternating current (AC) cycling is electrically induced domain de-pinning. PFM imaging and local spectroscopy revealed asymmetric switching in the La:HfO<sub>2</sub> capacitors due to significant imprint likely caused by the different boundary conditions at the top and bottom interfaces. Domain switching kinetics can be well-described by the nucleation limited switching (NLS) model characterized by a broad distribution of the local switching times. It has been found that the domain velocity varies significantly throughout the switching process indicating strong interaction with structural defects.
568	Design and research on compact high-voltage pulse forming module with hundreds-nanosecond quasi-squared output pulse	A pulse forming module with multifunction of energy storage and pulse shaping is developed to meet the challenge of compact design and square output waveform in high-power Marx generator, as traditional compact Marx generator can only output double-exponential pulse profile. Expression of square waveform is obtained by Fourier series expansion and requirements on inductances and capacitors in a corresponding circuit are drawn. A simplified circuit model constructed by only 2 parallel branches, in which every branch contains an inductance and a capacitor in series has been proposed and investigated carefully to get quasi-square waveform. Pulse forming modules with compact size have been fabricated and tested under the guidance of the model theory. The capacitor is constructed with several folded flexible film capacitors in series for the purpose of getting high withstanding voltage and high energy density. The module is 6.4 L in volume with cuboid profile. It can be charged to 120 kV with stored energy density higher than 40 kJ/m<sup>3</sup>, and generates 180 ns-in-width quasi-square shaped pulse. It can also work repetitive at rep-rate of 50 Hz while the output waveforms show rarely difference. This research has further developed the practical application of pulse forming network to the lowest 2 branches, and it would be very helpful to reduce the size of the Marx-type high power generator system that based on it, while keep a quasi-square output waveform.
569	Growth and in-plane undulations of GaAs/Ge superlattices on [001]-oriented Ge and GaAs substartes: Formation of regular 3D island-in-network nanostructures	Coherently strained superlattice structures of 20-period GaAs/Ge have been epitaxially grown on [001]-oriented Ge and GaAs substrates by metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD). High-resolution X-ray diffraction and dynamic theory simulations revealed an increase in the growth rate of the Ge sublayers (<em>R</em><sub>Ge</sub>) and a decrease in that of the GaAs ones (<em>R</em><sub>GaAs</sub>) when GaAs is used, instead of Ge, as the substrate under otherwise the same growth conditions. They also revealed that the <em>R</em><sub>Ge</sub> is increased from 0.10 (0.11) to 0.22 (0.26) nm/s while the <em>R</em><sub>GaAs</sub> is decreased by ~9.8% (21.6%) on the Ge (GaAs) substrate when the growth temperature is increased from <em>T</em><sub>g</sub> = 560 to 580 &deg;C. Cross-sectional transmission-electron microscopy revealed regular in-plane undulations of the superlattices and their elemental distributions mapped by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy provided evidence that the Ge sublayers were conformally grown on GaAs while the GaAs sublayers were grown in regular in-plane isolated islands that initiated in the valleys of the Ge sublayers. The growth mechanism was discussed based on surface chemical potentials that depend on the balance between the surface-energy and the local strain-relaxation energy. Such three-dimensional periodic nanostructures, i.e., GaAs islands surrounded by Ge networks, can be useful when fabricating thermoelectric devices.
570	The kinetics and Thermodynamics of Nitriding of Nanocrystalline Iron	In this work, the kinetics and thermodynamics of nitriding of nanocrystalline iron were investigated. The nanocrystalline iron was fabricated using a novel surface severe plastic deformation technique called ultrasonic nanocrystal surface modification. The grain boundary effects on nitriding were investigated by conducting gas nitriding of nanocrystalline iron and coarse-grained iron at different temperatures, from 300 to 560 &deg;C. The surface hardness, phase composition and the depth of nitriding layer were characterized. It is concluded that the grain boundary plays a more important role than residual strain/pre-stored dislocation for nitriding efficiency improvement. We further confirmed that, instead of promoting the nitrogen diffusion kinetics, the presence of grain boundary also affects the nitriding thermodynamics by decreasing the formation energy of nanoscale nitride particles. Due to the grain boundary effect, nanoscale nitride particles formed throughout the affected layer, making it possible for nitrogen to diffuse through the relatively high-diffusivity -Fe phase and to form a thicker affected layer. This work provides new understanding for low temperature nitriding of nanocrystalline metal.
571	<strong>Induced-Charge Electrokinetics in Rotating Electric Fields: a Linear Asymptotic Analysis</strong>	Concerning the electroconvective analyte manipulation in microfluidics, we describe the basic physics of fluid flow driven by rotating induced-charge electro-osmosis (ROT-ICEO), which occurs on the planar surface of a single floating electrode in an external rotating electric field. First, based on a linear asymptotic analysis, the dynamic flow stagnation line in ROT-ICEO induced on the bipolar electrode from a <em>rotary Debye screening charge</em> revolves synchronously with the applied rotating fields. A net hydrodynamic torque is then generated that acts on any fluid or particle sample to produce either a synchronous or asynchronous co-field rotation depending on the frequency of the ac signal. Next, from the synergy between the hydrodynamic and electrochemical ion relaxations, an analytical solution of the sample rotation rate subject to ROT-ICEO slipping on an ideally polarizable surface is obtained for different frequency ranges and determined by the transient nature of the rotating electro-osmotic flow oscillating at twice the field frequency. To visualize the flow field in ROT-ICEO, experiments were performed with fluorescent tracer nanoparticles; they exhibited concentric rotational behavior at the polarized phase interface. Formed like the arms of a nebula disk, the four twisted tails of nanoparticles can be arbitrarily directed under voltage-phase rectification. These experimental results are in good agreement with our mathematical simulations using the Debye&ndash;H&uuml;ckel approximation on ROT-ICEO.
572	<strong>Micro-Architecture Embedding Ultra-Thin Interlayer to Bond Diamond and Silicon via Direct Fusion</strong>	The continuous demand on miniaturized electronic circuits bearing high power density illuminates the need to modify silicon-on-insulator-based chip architecture. This is because of the low thermal conductivity of the few hundred nanometers-thick insulator present between the silicon substrate and active layers. The thick insulator is notorious for releasing the heat generated from the active layers during the operation of devices, leading to degrade their performance and reduce their lifetime. To avoid the heat accumulation, we propose a novel method to fabricate the silicon-on-diamond (SOD) micro-structure featured by an exceptionally thin silicon oxycarbide interlayer (~3 nm). While exploiting the diamond as an insulator, we employ spark plasma sintering to render the silicon directly fused to the diamond. Notably, this process can manufacture the SOD micro-architecture via simple/rapid manner, and incorporates the ultra-thin interlayer for minute thermal resistance. The method invented herein expects to minimize the thermal interfacial resistance of the devices and is thus deemed as a breakthrough appealing to the current chip industry.
573	<strong>Gate tunable surface plasmon resonance enhanced graphene/p-GaN heterostructure light-emitting diodes</strong>	By combing surface plasmon enhancement technique with gate effect, a high brightness blue lighting emitting diode (LED) based on graphene/p-GaN heterostructure has been achieved. The surface plasmon enhancement is introduced through coating Ag nanoparticles (NPs) on graphene/p-GaN heterostructure while the gate effect is demonstrated through a graphene/polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA)/graphene sandwich structure, where the top graphene layer acts as the gate electrode. The electroluminescence (EL) emission intensity of Ag NPs/graphene/p-GaN heterostructure is largely enhanced when compared with the initial graphene/p-GaN heterostructure, which is attributed to the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) of Ag NPs. The EL emission intensity of graphene/Ag NPs-PMMA/graphene/p-GaN heterostructure can be gate-tunable through exerting a static voltage between two graphene layers, which sufficiently tunes the Fermi level of graphene contacting with p-GaN. These results indicate that the development of graphene/p-GaN heterostructure LED could be advanced through sophisticated design and becomes a promising candidate for many important optoelectronic applications.
574	Multi-scale Structure Patterning by Digital-Mask Projective Lithography with an Alterable Projective Scaling System	We report a flexible and efficient method to pattern two-dimensional (2D) multi-scale structures by digital-mask projective lithography (DMPL) with an alterable projective scaling system. In the developed DMPL system, femtosecond laser was modulated by digital micromirror device (DMD) to generate a designable intensity distribution with digital image information. The projective law of this DMPL system based on the geometric optics theory verified for different projective scaling lens systematically has been studied. With the combination of the customizable DMD elements and alterable projective scaling system, 2D designable patterned microstructures with multi-scale size range from millimeter to hundred nanometer have been achieved by a single exposure. In addition, an engineered Fresnel zone plate (FZP) with numerical aperture (NA) of 0.36 and focal length of 114 &#xF06D;m has been achieved by a single exposure of 1.2 s. The acquisition of the array of FZP lens shows the stability and efficiency of the pattern process. The proposed method could be expected to play an important role in the flexible and efficient fabrication of engineered 2D multi-scale structures.
575	Modern aspects of Darcy-Forchheimer porous medium and convective condition in nanofluid through carbon nanotubes	This article deals with Darcy-Forchheimer three dimensional (3D) flow of water-based carbon nanotubes (CNTs). A bidirectional nonlinear stretchable surface has been employed to create the flow. Flow in porous space is represented by Darcy-Forchheimer expression. Heat transfer mechanism is explored through convective heating and heat generation/absorption. Results for single-wall (SWCNTs) and multi-wall (MWCNTs) carbon nanotubes have been presented and compared. The reduction of partial differential system into nonlinear ordinary differential system is made through suitable transformations. Optimal homotopy scheme is used for solutions development of governing flow problem. Optimal homotopic solution expressions for velocities and temperature are studied through plots by considering various values of physical variables. Moreover the surface drag coefficients and heat transfer rate are analyzed through plots.
576	<strong>Transport spectroscopy through dopant atom array in silicon junctionless nanowire transistors</strong>	We demonstrate transport spectroscopy through a dopant atom array in n-doped silicon junctionless nanowire transistors (JNTs) within temperature range from 6 K to 250 K. Several current steps are observed at the initial stage of the transfer curves below 75 K, which results from the electron transport from Hubbard bands to one dimensional conduction band. The current-off voltages in the transfer curves have strikingly positive shift below 20 K and negative shift above 20 K due to the electrostatic screening induced by ionized dopant atoms. There exists the minimum electron mobility at the critical temperature of 20 K, resulting from the interplay of thermal activation and impurity scattering. Furthermore, electron transport behaviors at the temperature of 30K have obvious transition from hopping conductance to thermal activation conductance.
577	Measurement of the third order optical nonlinearities of Graphene Quantum Dots in water at 355 nm, 532 nm and 1064 nm	The nonlinear responses of graphene quantum dots (GQDs) suspension in water are investigated at 355nm, 532 nm and 1064 nm using a pulsed Nd:YAG laser in the picosecond regime. The experiments are performed using a Z-scan based technique. The third-order nonlinear refractive index and the nonlinear absorption coefficients are determined. Under UV illumination where the NL response is found to be large, the nonlinear refractive index, the nonlinear absorption and the saturation intensity are estimated for a single graphene nanosheet constituting the GQDs through a simple model. The obtained values are in the order of magnitude of those obtained in bulk materials. We expect the present study to be useful for numerous future fundamental interest or potential applications.
578	Examining the effects of acoustic noise on scanning tunneling microscopy	Scanning tunneling microscopes are used to examine surfaces and surface properties with sub-nanometer precision. However, this high precision means these microscopes are extremely sensitive to vibration. A large body of work has examined vibration isolation systems that damp any vibration mechanically transmitted from the environment to the microscope through solid material. As most of these machines are housed in ultra-high-vacuum systems in order to protect the samples that they are being used to analyze and also to allow for analysis at ultra-low temperatures, mechanical vibration noise and electronic noise are the largest sources of error. Less work has examined the effect of acoustic vibrations transmitted from the environment to the microscope through the gaseous atmosphere. However, this examination is important for STMs housed in different environments, such as air or gloveboxes. In this paper, we demonstrate that even though the acoustical vibrations are enough to significantly degrade the image, the frequency peak of the acoustic vibration peak does not clearly appear in the FFT of the tunneling current during imaging. Thus, the best way to identify and isolate scanning tunneling microscopes from acoustic noise is while the tips are engaged but not scanning. Finally, we demonstrate atomic resolution for an STM housed in a glovebox taken while the pumps were running by acoustically isolating the microscope with a foam-lined acoustic shell.
579	Investigation of the relevant kinetic processes in the initial stage of a double-arcing instability in oxygen plasmas	A numerical investigation of the kinetic processes in the initial (nanosecond range) stage of the double-arcing instability was developed. The plasma-sheath boundary region of an oxygen-operated cutting torch was considered. The energy balance and chemistry processes in the discharge were described. It was shown that the double-arcing instability develops from a field-emission instability when the electric field at the nozzle wall reaches a critical value of &#x2248; 10^7 volts/m for the conditions considered. The field-emission instability drives in turn a fast electronic-to-translational energy relaxation mechanism, giving rise to a very fast gas heating rate of at least &#x2248; 10^9 K/s, mainly due to reactions of preliminary dissociation of oxygen molecules via the highly excited electronic state O2(B3&#x03A3;u-) populated by electron impact. It is expected that this fast oxygen heating rate further stimulates the discharge contraction through the thermal instability mechanism.
580	Nanoscale excitonic photovoltaic mechanism in ferroelectric BiFeO3 thin films	We report an electrode-free photovoltaic experiment in epitaxial thin film BiFeO3 where the picosecond optical absorption arising from carrier dynamics and piezoelectric lattice distortion due to the photovoltaic field are correlated at nanoscale. The data strongly suggest that the photovoltaic effect in phase pure BiFeO3 originates from diffusion of charge-neutral excitons and their subsequent dissociation localized at sample interfaces. This is in stark contrast to the belief that carrier separation is uniform within the sample due to the lack of center of symmetry in BiFeO3. This finding is important for formulating strategies in designing practical photovoltaic ferroelectric device.
581	Dotette: programmable, high-precision, plug-and-play droplet pipetting	Manual micropipette is the most heavily used liquid handling device in biological and chemical laboratories, however, it suffers from low precision for volume under 1&#x00B5;L as well as inevitable human errors. For a manual device, the human errors introduced pose potential risks of failed experiments, inaccurate results, and financial costs. Meanwhile, low precision under 1&#x00B5;L can cause severe quantification errors and high heterogeneity of outcomes, becoming a bottleneck of reaction miniaturization for quantitative research in biochemical labs. Here we report Dotette, a programmable, plug-and-play microfluidic pipetting device based on nanoliter liquid printing. With automated control, protocols designed on computers can be directly downloaded into Dotette, enabling programmable operation processes. Utilizing continuous nanoliter droplet dispensing, the precision of the volume control has been successfully improved from traditional 20%-50% to less than 5% in the range of 100nL to 1000nL. Such a highly automated, plug-and-play add-on to existing pipetting device not only improves precise quantification in low-volume liquid handling and reduce chemical consumptions, but also facilitates and automates a variety of biochemical and biological operations.
582	Emergence of Strain Induced Two Dimensional Metallic State in ReS<sub>2</sub>	We present a highly versatile system ReS<sub>2</sub> , which transforms from a semiconductor to a two dimensional metal under uni-axial compressive strain along &rsquo;a&rsquo; direction in both bulk and monolayer. The 2D nature is realised from highly flat Fermi surfaces and anisotropic transport properties. Moreover the layer independent electronic structure properties are revisited and thermoelectric properties of ReS<sub>2</sub> in bulk, monolayer and bilayer forms reveal the competing thermoelectric (TE) coefficients in each form. The in-plane power-factor shows an enhancement over &rsquo;c&rsquo;-axis value as a function of strain, which is almost two orders of magnitude. In addition, strain induced tunable in-plane anisotropy of almost one order has been observed in both bulk and monolayer ReS<sub>2</sub> (around 20%), which further open up the possibility of TE application as nanowires. Our analysis unveils a<br />wide range of application for ReS 2 in the field of thermoelectrics as bulk and thin films for a large temperature range. The magnitude of TE coefficients are comparable with other well established transition metal dichalocogenides.
583	Influence of H2 flow in photoluminescence intensities of SiOx films deposited by HFCVD	In the present work, we report the influence of the hydrogen flow in the photoluminescence (PL) intensities and structural properties of the SiOx. The method used for the deposit of the SiOx films was the Hot Filament Chemical Vapor Deposition (HFCVD) technique using quartz bars as precursors sources; the SiOx films are obtained at different hydrogen flow at 25, 50, 75 and 100 sccm; also, the films were annealed at 1000 &ordm;C in nitrogen atmosphere. The characterization techniques used for this study were High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), Transmittance, PL and profilometer. HRTEM reveals the presence of high density of Si-nanocrystals with sizes of 1 nm and the formation of Si-nanoislands with different crystal orientation and similar to the substrate. SiOx films exhibit a large broadband PL spectra with main peaks at 650 to 850 nm and the decrement of the intensity of the PL depends of the increment of H2 flows; however, the PL disappear after the annealing in all cases. On the contrary, the profilometer shows an increment of thickness with the increment of the H2 flows. However, FTIR confirms that the deposits are SiOx with the characteristic vibration modes and shows H2 desorption after annealing. The transmittance reveals an increment on the band gap from 2.36 to 3 eV and is related with the PL results using the QC by the Si-nc. The method to obtain Si-ncs and Si-nis is compatible with silicon technology and is clearly very simple and novelty.
584	Deterministic role of frequency, amplitude and concentration regimes on the complex dielectric response of nanocolloids	The present article explores the governing roles played by concentration regimes, frequency and amplitude of the forcing electric field on the dynamic dielectric responses of  nanocolloidal  non-polar suspensions. Frequency dependent complex dielectric constants  were determined  in the band of 1 to 107 Hz at constant temperature  via dielectric spectroscopy. In addition to prevalant literature measurements, influence of field amplitude has also been performed to investigate the role of electric field intensity upon the relaxation behaviors.  The experimental observations reveal that variation of frequency, as well as choice of particle material significantly influences the dielectric responses of nanocolloids. Further, the amplitude of field is found to induce differences in the dielectric response. It is also observed that the relaxation responses are grossly different for concentrated dispersions than the dilute counterparts. The concentration regimes are observed to bring about overlapping relaxation responses  in the colloids.  Good degree of quantitative agreement has been found between the experimental observations and the generic Havriliak-Negami relaxation model.  It has been shown that for a given nanomaterial, reduction of relaxation time scale  is a direct consequence of enhancement  in concentration and the colloids transit from predominantly storage to leaky systems with concentration regimes. .  Additionally, the reported volume diffusion mechanism (VDM)  is found to be in compliance with the experimental findings. The occurrence and shift of peaks and valleys in the dielectric spectra has been explained based on dielectric response theories for electrically heterogeneous media.
585	<strong><strong>Comment on &ldquo;Submicron cubic boron nitride as hard as diamond&rdquo; by Guoduan Liu <em>et al</em>.</strong></strong>	The new phase diagram of nanocrystalline BN can explain well the observed domain structure within nanocrystalline grains. The only source of cubic domain structure is the phase transition from hexagonal to cubic phase during cooling of the sample. This required the lowering of transition line with respect to its position in the phase diagram of bulk crystal. This result is a significant and important improvement of results obtained in the commented paper.
586	Enhanced photon-phonon coupling via dimerization in one-dimensional optomechanical crystals	We show that dimerization of an optomechanical crystal lattice, which leads to folding of the band diagram, can couple flexural mechanical modes to optical fields within the unit cell via radiation pressure. When compared to currently realized crystals, a substantial improvement in the coupling between photons and phonons is found. For experimental verification, we implement a dimerized lattice in a silicon optomechanical nanobeam cavity and measure a vacuum coupling rate of g<sub>0</sub>/2&pi;=1.7 MHz between an optical resonance at &lambda;c = 1545 nm and a mechanical resonance at 1.14 GHz.
587	<strong>The Uniformity Study of Non-oxide Thin Film </strong><strong>at Device Level Using Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy</strong>	Electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) has been widely used as a chemical analysis technique to characterize materials chemical properties, such as element valence states, atoms/ions bonding environment. This study provides a new method to characterize physical properties (i.e., film uniformity, grain orientations) of non-oxide thin films in the magnetic device by using EELS microanalysis on scanning transmission electron microscope. This method is based on analyzing white line ratio of spectra and related extended energy loss fine structures so as to correlate it with thin film uniformity. This new approach can provide an effective and sensitive method to monitor/characterize thin film quality (i.e., uniformity) at atomic level for thin film development, which is especially useful for examining ultra-thin films (i.e., several nanometers) or embedded films in devices for  industry applications. More importantly, this technique enables development of quantitative characterization of thin film uniformity and it would become to be a remarkably useful technique for examining various types of devices for industrial applications.
588	From size-dependent strengthening to softening in nanolaminated Cu/Cu-Zr crystalline/amorphous micropillars	Strength and deformation behaviors of nanolaminated Cu/Cu-Zr crystalline/amorphous micropillars within wide ranges of intrinsic modulation ratio &#x03B7; (0.1-3.0) and extrinsic diameter D (300-1500 nm) were investigated by using microcompression tests. Experimental results revealed a transition of D-dependent deformation mode from homogeneous-like to shear localization at large &#x03B7;, while D-independent homogeneous extrusion of Cu at small &#x03B7;. Furthermore, the flow strength increased with raising D at small &#x03B7;, but decreased at large &#x03B7;, exhibiting a D-insensitive strength at a critical &#x03B7;*~0.5. These unusual results were rationalized in terms of a coupling effect of dislocation actions and shear transformation zone mediated operations.
589	Laser Shock Compression Induced Crystallization of Ce<sub>3</sub>Al Metallic Glass	Laser shock compression studies on Ce<sub>3</sub>Al metallic glass performed using a 3 J Nd:YAG laser indicate shock induced crystallization, evidenced by presence of a two-wave particle velocity profile and observed structural XRD analysis of recovered material. A direct shock compression setup was designed with 25 &micro;m thick Ni driver foil, 40 &micro;m thick Ce<sub>3</sub>Al metallic glass ribbon, and 3 mm thick PMMA backer window for use with input laser energies varying from 100 to 2000 mJ. Below 300 mJ laser input energy, samples were recovered showing no visual or structural changes evidenced via XRD analysis. Velocimetry measurements indicated onset of a two wave structure with the primary wave followed by a smaller secondary wave. At input laser energies of 400 mJ and above, samples are recovered showing visible deformation and crystallization, evidenced by Rietveld analysis of diffraction patterns obtained from recovered samples. The corresponding velocity profiles also showed a distinct two wave structure, with the secondary wave increasing in magnitude with energy and the primary wave maintaining a constant velocity. The overall results reveal possible densification of the glass due to delocalization of 4f electrons in Ce at lower laser shock energies, and increased crystallization with preferred orientation and distortion of the nanocrystals at higher energies.
590	<strong>Enhanced Thermoelectric Efficiency in Topological Insulator Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> Nanoplates via Atomic Layer Deposition-based Surface Passivation</strong>	We report in-plane thermoelectric measurements of Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3 </sub>nanoplates, a typical topological insulator (TI) with Dirac-like metallic surface states, grown by chemical vapor deposition (CVD). The as-grown flakes exposed to ambient conditions exhibit relatively small thermopowers around -34&micro;V/K due to unintentional surface doping (e.g., gas adsorption and surface oxidation). After removal of the unintentional surface doping and surface passivation by deposition of 30nm of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> using atomic layer deposition (ALD), the Seebeck coefficient of these flakes increases by a factor of 5X to -169&micro;V/K. Here, we believe that the ALD-based surface passivation can prevent the degradation of the thermoelectric properties caused by gas adsorption and surface oxidation processes, thus, reducing the unintentional doping in the Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> and increasing the Seebeck coefficient. The high surface-to-volume ratio of these thin (~10nm thick) nanoplates make them especially sensitive to surface doping, which is a common problem among nanomaterials in general. An increase in the sample resistance is also observed after the ALD process, which is consistent with the decrease in doping.
591	<strong>Binary Cu-Zr Thin Film Metallic Glasses with Tunable Nanoscale Structures and Properties</strong>	Motivated by the concept of nanoglass where the nanoscale glassy grains and interfaces can bring unique properties into glassy materials, we develop a series of binary Cu-Zr thin film metallic glasses (TFMGs) with tunable nanoscale structures by using direct-current (DC) magnetron sputtering technique. Depending on the chemical composition and the sputtering parameters, Cu-Zr TFMGs show variable nanoscale structures from nanocolumn to nanogranula. As compared to the metallic glassy ribbons with identical composition, the Cu-Zr TFMGs with nanoscale structures exhibit novel and unique thermal and mechanical properties. From nanoindentation study, it is found that the TFMGs with nanoscale structures display obvious reduced hardness (about 48-52%) and increased elastic modulus (about 7-23.8%) as compared to the metallic glassy ribbons. Moreover, the serrated flow behavior, as commonly observed from the load-displacement response in the nanoindentation of metallic glasses (MGs) is absence for nanostructured TFMGs, indicating the profound effects of nanoscale structural features on the plastic yielding and flow in TFMGs. This study provides a detail insight into a strategy of designing nanostructured TFMGs and obtaining tunable properties which is of great interest in the potential application of micro/nanoscale devices.
592	Electron-vibrational theory of long-range Frenkel exciton polaritons in nanofibers of organic dye	We develop a mean-field electron-vibrational theory of Frenkel exciton polaritons in organic dye structures. The theory contains experimentally measured quantities that make it closely related to experiment, and provides a possibility of generalization to a nonlinear regime. Between other things, we explain the additional red shift of the H-aggregate absorption spectra (that are blue-shifted as a whole). We apply the theory to experiment on fraction of a millimeter propagation of Frenkel exciton polaritons in photoexcited organic nanofibers made of thiacyanine dye. A good agreement between theory and experiment is obtained.
593	<strong>Femtosecond laser-induced transformations in ultra-low expansion glass:  microstructure and local density variations by vibrational spectroscopy</strong>	We report X-ray diffraction, resonance Raman and infrared (IR) results on pristine ultra-low expansion (ULE) glass, a binary titanosilicate glass with 5.67 mol% TiO<sub>2</sub>.  ULE processing by femtosecond (fs) laser radiation leads to nanogratings writing and photo-darkening for imaging and data storage. The knowledge gained here on pristine ULE is employed to understand the transformation mechanisms in this glass by fs laser irradiation at 515 nm. Optical imaging revealed the formation of micro-cavities, and Raman mapping showed molecular oxygen trapped in such cavities of laser-irradiated ULE glass. While titanium in the pristine glass was found predominantly in tetrahedral Ti<sup>4+ </sup>sites highly dispersed in the silicate matrix, Raman and IR reflectance spectroscopy on laser-irradiated ULE indicated the formation of Ti<sup>3+</sup> sites; Ti<sup>3+ </sup>octahedral sites are formed in the shells of cavities and aggregate in amorphous Ti<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-type<sub> </sub>clusters, while the glass around and below cavities contains Ti<sup>3+</sup> tetrahedral sites dispersed in the silicate network. Laser-processed ULE glass was found to exhibit also local restructuring of the silicate matrix. Shifts of the strong IR band at about 1080-1100 cm<sup>-1</sup> were translated into changes of the average Si-O-Si bond angle in the laser-transformed areas, and found to reflect local density variations; the average local density increases relative to silica glass up to about 8% in the shells of micro-cavities and decreases by about 0.5% in the surrounding material. Chemical processes were proposed to account for photo-darkening and local structural transformation effect in the probed areas of the fs laser-processed ULE glasses.
594	<strong>Reduced Thermal Conductivity of Si/Ge Random Layer Nanowires: A Comparative Study against Superlattice Counterparts </strong>	Si/Ge nanowires are considered as promising candidates as efficient thermoelectric materials due to their remarkable thermal insulating performance over bulk counterparts. In this study, thermal insulating performance of Si/Ge nanowires of randomly organized layer thickness, called random layer nanowires (RLNWs), is systematically investigated and compared against superlattice nanowires (SLNWs). The thermal conductivity (TC) of these structures are evaluated via non-equilibrium molecular dynamics simulations and more informative insight is gained by normal mode decomposition and lattice dynamics calculations. It is demonstrated that the modes in random layer structures, in general, exhibit similar characteristics except the degree of localization to the corresponding superlattice counterparts by comparing the mode spectral energy densities, relaxation times, density of states and participation ratios.  For all physical and geometrical conditions investigated here, RLNWs show improved thermal insulating performance over corresponding SLNWs. More importantly, a RLNW of low mean layer thickness attains even lower TC than the corresponding Si/Ge alloy nanowire indicating the effectiveness of the random layer arrangements. An anomalous trend in TC of RLNWs (larger than the bulk counterpart) is observed at higher cross-sectional widths and it is explained as a competing effect of phonon localization and wall scattering.  Moreover, it is illustrated that the effectiveness of thermal insulating performance of RLNW depends on the fraction of coherent phonons that exist and how effectively those phonons are subject to localization under different cases.
595	Effects of nanoscale texturing of PMMA surface by atmospheric pressure plasma jet array on surface wettability	Recently developed atmospheric pressure plasma jet (APPJ) is considered as a novel and efficient technique for uneven surfaces processing and APPJ array effectively expands the treatment area of a single APPJ. In this paper, a two-dimensional (2D) APPJ array in Ar/tetramethylsilane (TMS) is used to improve the surface hydrophobicity of polymethyl methcraylate (PMMA) by depositing silica nanotexture on the PMMA surface. The electrical and optical characteristics of the 2D Ar/TMS APPJ array are measured to optimize experimental conditions. The wettability of PMMA surface is assessed by water contact angle measurement, which increases from 65{degree sign} to a maximum value of 115{degree sign} after 240 s plasma treatment at 0.04% TMS content. Scanning electron microscopy is used to investigate the micro- and nanoscales surface morphologies of PMMA after plasma treatment and it is found there are discrete coral structure clusters with hundreds of nanometers particles attached on the PMMA surface. The nanotextured structure enhances the surface hydrophobicity by the suspension of the water drop. The changes of the chemical composition and chemical bonding on the PMMA surface are further analyzed using Fourier transform infrared and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopies. It is found that the silicon-containing groups such as Si-O-Si, Si-CH3, and Si-H replace oxygen-containing hydrophilic polar groups (C-O and C=O), reduce the surface polarity, decrease the surface tension, and increase the surface hydrophobicity. The results demonstrate that the APPJ array can be a novel tool for the preparation of nanotextured polymeric surfaces in ambient air and has the potentials for the formation of superhydrophobic and superhydrophilic surfaces.
596	<strong>Improving performance of </strong><strong><strong>Si/CdS </strong></strong><strong><strong>micro-/nanoribbon</strong></strong><strong><strong> p-n heterojunction light emitting diodes</strong></strong><strong><strong> by trenched structure</strong></strong>	Realizing high performance silicon based light sources has been an unremitting pursuit of researchers. In this letter, we propose a simple structure to enhance electroluminescence emission and reduce the threshold of injected current of silicon/CdS micro-/nanoribbon p-n heterojunction visible light emitting diodes, by fabricating trenched structure on silicon substrate to mount CdS micro-/nanoribbon. A series of experiments and simulation analysis favors the rationality and validity of our mounting design. After mounting the CdS micro-/nanoribbon, the optical field confinement increases, and absorption and losses from high refractive silicon substrate is effectively reduced. Meanwhile the sharp change of silicon substrate near heterojunction also facilitates the balance between electron current and hole current, which substantially conduces to the stable amplification of electroluminescence emission in CdS micro-/nanoribbon.
597	Upconversion luminescence of Er<sup>3+</sup> ions in new transparent glass-ceramics with BaF<sub>2</sub> nanocrystals in ZnF<sub>2</sub>-BaO-B<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> system and formation of BaF<sub>2</sub>-like migration in the glass	BaF2 nanocrystals were formed by heat-treatment of the Er<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-doped 30ZnF<sub>2</sub>-30BaO-40B<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> glasses, and the crystal size decreased with increasing Er<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> content: particle sizes of 32 and 8 nm were obtained for the non-doped sample and the 1 mol% Er<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-doped sample. The Er<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-doped glass-ceramics showed high optical transparency. Upon continuous-wave laser excitation at 980 nm, both of the glass and glass-ceramic samples showed upconversion luminescence even though borate has high phonon energy, and the shape of the spectrum of the glass resembles that of BaF<sub>2</sub> crystals, indicating the formation of a BaF<sub>2</sub>-like structure in the as-quenched glass.
598	Spectral quasi-linearization method for power-law nanofluid with temperature dependent variable thermal conductivity	A mathematical model is developed to study  MHD free convection in power-law nanofluid flow over an inclined plate in a porous medium in the presence of variable thermal conductivity, Ohmic dissipation, suction/injection and chemical reaction. In this study we consider both  (prescribed surface temperature) PST and (prescribed heat flux) PHF cases. The nonlinear consevation equations of momentum, energy and species mass diffusion were solved using the spectral quasi linearization method (SQLM) over the entire range of physical parameters with appropriate boundary conditions. The SQLM method finds recursive formulae for higher order non-linear equations which are then evaluated using the Chebyshev spectral collocation method. The influence of Brownian motion and thermophoresis parameters on velocity, temperature and concentration fields are studied for both the PST and PHF cases. The numerical data are compared with published work and found to be in excellent agreement.  The velocity, temperature and concentration profiles are increased due to increase the effect of modified thermophoresis parameter in PST and PHF cases and the reverse was seen for the concentration profiles due to increase in the Brownian motion parameter.
599	Dipolar effects on the magnetic phases of superparamagnetic clusters	We report a theoretical study of the impact of dipolar interactions on the room temperature magnetic phases of superparamagnetic nanoparticles confined in spherical and ellipsoidal clusters. We consider Fe3O4 nanoparticles with size ranging from 9 nm to 12 nm, arranged with uniform density in hundred <br />nanometer-sized clusters. We show that one may have large enhancement of the initial susceptibility for ellipsoidal clusters of high eccentricity, as required for most biomedical applications. Spherical clusters display a reduction of the initial susceptibility, due to the early nucleation of new magnetic phases. In densely packed systems the dipolar interaction may lead to thermal stabilization of the individual nanoparticles moments, while keeping the cluster <br />superparamagnetic, with a vanishingly small magnetic moment in the absence of external field. The theoretical model is used to discuss recent findings on quasi-one-dimensional arrays of superparamagnetic Fe and Co nanoparticles, and on spherical clusters of superparamagnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles.
600	Optical stack study by a photon - phonon interaction approach	Two complementary techniques, picosecond ultrasonics (PU) and Brillouin light scattering (BLS), have been performed to measure the mechanical properties of layers involved in an optical stack. One of the advantages of these two techniques is their ability to analyze samples whose thickness varies from a few tens of nanometers (the anti-reflective coating) to several millimeters (the polymer substrate). Since all the layers constituting the optical stack have proved to be isotropic, they are completely elastically characterized thanks to the two techniques. Moreover, as the two independent elastic coefficients are measured by PU and BLS, c<sub>33</sub> and c<sub>44</sub> respectively, the complete stiffness matrix and, hence, the Poisson&rsquo;s ratio and the Young&rsquo;s modulus can be deduced.
601	Abnormal blueshift of the absorption edge in graphene nanodots	In a conventional semiconductor when the dielectric screening effect is suppressed, the exciton binding energy increases and the corresponding excitonic transition would exhibit a redshift in the spectrum. In this work, we study the optical properties of hexagonal graphene nanodots by using a configuration interaction approach and reveal that the edge of the absorption spectrum shows an abnormal blueshift as the environmental dielectric constant &#x03B5;<sub>r</sub> decreases. The two dominant many-body effects in the nanodot, the quasiparticle and excitonic effects are both found to scale almost linearly with &#x03B5;<sub>r</sub><sup>-1</sup>. The former is shown to have a larger proportionality constant and thus accounts for the blueshift of the absorption edge. In opposite to the long-range Coulomb interaction, the on-site Coulomb energy is is found to have a negative impact on the bright excitonic states. With a strong dielectric screening effect in presence, a strong short-range Coulomb interaction is revealed to be responsible for the disintegration of the bright exciton.
602	Macroscopic superhydrophobicity achieved by atomic decoration with silicones	Modulating wetting states of water droplets on a solid surface has a great potential in numerous applications such as self cleaning, heat transfer and water purification. Present strategies to achieve controlled wettability usually employ surface roughness and/or chemical coating at the nanometer-to-micrometer scale. Here we propose that atomic-scale decoration and patterning with silicones can be used to fabricate superhydrophobic surfaces. Atomic decoration, differing from chemical coatings in characteristic size and partial coverage, controls wetting states with the atomic precision (several angstroms) at low cost and maintains a long lifetime. We attribute the mechanism of atomic decoration to the decrease in effective potential-well depth, inducing weak interactions between the substrate and water droplet. Our work pushes water wetting to the limit of atomic scales, hinting for a paradigm shift from macroscopic to atomically-precise engineering of wetting states and providing new insights for fabricating superhydrophobic surfaces.
603	<strong>Efficiency-enhanced AlGaInP light-emitting diodes using transparent plasmonic silver nanowires</strong>	Silver nanowire (AgNW) networks have been demonstrated to exhibit superior transparent and conductive performance over that of indium-doped tin oxide (ITO) and have been proposed to replace ITO, which is currently widely used in optoelectronic devices despite the scarcity of indium on Earth. In this paper, the current spreading and enhanced transmittance induced by AgNWs were analysed, which are two important factors influencing light output power. The enhanced transmittance was studied by finite-difference time-domain simulation and verified by cathodoluminescence measurements. The enhancement ratio of light output power decreased with increasing GaP layer thickness, with values of 79 %, 52 % and 15 % for GaP layer thicknesses of 0.5, 1 and 8 &micro;m, respectively, when an AgNW network was included in AlGaInP light-emitting diodes. This was because of the decreased current distribution tunability of the AgNW network with increasing GaP layer thickness. The large enhancement of light output power was caused by the AgNWs increasing carrier spread out of the electrode and the enhanced transmittance induced by the plasmonic AgNWs. Further decreasing the sheet resistance of AgNW networks could raise their light output power enhancement ratio.
604	<strong>Nanoscale structural parameters based analytical model for GaN HEMTs</strong>	A physics-based analytical model for III-V based high electron mobility transistor is proposed considering the influence of interface trap density on the channel charge. The variations in permittivity caused due to the change in thickness of the semiconductor layers from their bulk counterpart to the nanoscale are integrated into the model for the first time. In addition, the contribution of two lowest energy levels is considered widening the applicability of the model for various device designs. The consistency of the proposed model is demonstrated by comparing modelled results with the experimental results of different device designs and dimensions fabricated from different materials, including GaN.
605	Optical Spectroscopy in pure and Sr doped NiO Nanostructures: A comprenhsive study	Ni<sub>1-x</sub>Sr<sub>x</sub>O (x= 0.0, 0.02, 0.04) nanoparticles calcined at 700 <sup>0</sup>C with crystallite size ranging from 17.92 -22.39 nm have been synthesized using liquid-solid phase route such as sol-gel method. Structural properties have shown that nanoparticles are spherical shaped. Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) was carried out to explore their optical band-gap with associated weak absorption tail (E<sub>WAT</sub>) and Urbach (E<sub>U</sub>) energies that confirm the increased disorder with Sr incorporation into NiO samples. Our samples exhibit low reflectance about 15% and high transmittance 41.48 % in the visible region of the spectrum which more confirm the high transparency in the visible region. The refractive index <em>n (&lambda;)</em> and extinction coefficient k (&lambda;) spectra show normal and anamolous dispersion  in the range 200-800 nm. In addition, optical dielectric constants, optical conductivity ( ), high frequency dielectric constant using dispersion through  both of free carriers and bound carriers, static refractive index (<em>n<sub>o</sub></em>), WDD static refractive index ( ), ratio of free carrier concentration, effective mass (  and plasma frequency ( ) have also been determined. 606	<strong>Improvement of durability and switching speed by incorporating nanocrystals in the HfO<sub>x</sub> based resistive random access memory devices</strong>	Resistive random access memory (RRAM) has attracted significant interest for next-generation nonvolatile memory applications. However, it is somehow difficult to design a high speed RRAM device with enhanced data reliability. This paper deals with the improvement of high speed durable switching in nanocrystals based RRAM (NC-RRAM) devices. The high performance RRAM devices were prepared by incorporating the NCs into the HfO<sub>x</sub> oxide layer. As compared to the without (w/o) NC devices, the NC-RRAM devices are capable to execute uniform switching with higher set speed of 100 ns and reset speed of 150 ns, longer retention time and higher endurance of 10<sup>8</sup> cycles at 85<sup>o</sup>C. The electrical conduction at low resistance state is mostly dominated by Ohmic mechanism, whereas at high resistance state the space-charge-limited current is the best match. The possible switching mechanism is due to the formation and rupture of the conductive filaments (CFs) inside the oxide film. The enhanced electric field intensity on the surface of the NCs can effectively facilitate the formation and rupture of the CFs, hence the improvement in the overall electrical performance of the NC-RRAM devices as compare to the w/o RRAM.
607	Transitions of complex spin spiral magnetic structure in FeGe2 nanowires prepared by chemical vapor deposition	Iron germanium nanowires and films were prepared via a high pressure catalyst free chemical vapor deposition on Ge(111) wafer. Both nanowires and films were identified to be single crystal FeGe2. However, nanowires exhibited a saturation in field dependent magnetization while that of film did not. Magnetic field dependent resisitivity showed two drops in warming curve from 10-300K with a magnetic field of 6T and 9T. These abnoraml drops might attribute to a less scattering of electrons from complex spiral structures. The longtitudinal spiral and transverse spiral magnetic structure could help induce the abormal behaviors.
608	Thermoelectric mechanism of low-field electron emission from nanocarbon films	In previous experiments, sp2-carbon island films (or disordered quantum-dot arrays) were found to be capable of low-field electron emission - starting from ca. 1 V/&#x03BC;m. Comprehensive study of film samples showed absence of high-aspect topography features (nanotubes, fibers, etc.) or areas with substantially lowered workfunction, which complicates explanation of this phenomenon. For these films, we propose a novel mechanism of emission facilitation by thermoelectric field induced by concentrated heat release in nanometer-sized islands serving as emission centers (ECs). The thermoelectric effect in the considered case may be additionally enhanced by ballistic character of phonon flow from ECs into substrate. Quantitative estimates performed for typical experimental conditions and film morphology predicted local thermoelectric field magnitudes as high as ~108 V/m, sufficient for field emission from all forms of carbon. Theoretical consideration of the relationship between thermal and electric parameters (namely, released heat power and EC potential) showed possible existence of a nontrivial solution describing self-maintained equilibrium state. In this state, the emitting carbon island is protected from both overheating and electric breakdown. Low values of threshold field and effective workfunction (derived from emission current characteristics) find natural explanation in the suggested model. The model can be also relevant to other nanostructured emitting materials and films.
609	Crystallization of submicron amorphous hydrogenated silicon films with different hydrogen concentration by nanosecond ruby laser irradiation	The processes of a pulsed ruby laser induced crystallization of submicron (0.7 um) amorphous hydrogenated silicon films with different hydrogen concentration of 2, 12 and 39 atomic % were investigated. The films were prepared on glass substrates by Plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition technique followed by isothermal annealing in nitrogen atmosphere. The laser annealing (&#x03BB; = 694 nm) was carried out at pulse duration of 80 ns (FWHM) in the fluence range from 0.6 to 2.1 J/cm2. The laser fluence thresholds for surface area crystallization were found for different hydrogen concentration in the films. It was supposed, that the increasing of hydrogen concentration leads to increasing of the threshold energy density (laser fluence) for surface area crystallization due to decreasing of light absorption in the films with higher hydrogen concentration.
610	<strong>Size modulated Griffiths phase and spin dynamics in double perovskite Sm<sub>1.5</sub>Ca<sub>0.5</sub>CoMnO<sub>6</sub> </strong>	Griffiths phase like behavior has been investigated in details in size modulated Sm<sub>1.5</sub>Ca<sub>0.5</sub>CoMnO<sub>6</sub> double perovskite, having ferromagnetic entities in the paramagnetic matrix. Temperature dependent real and imaginary part of ac susceptibility confirms that Sm<sub>1.5</sub>Ca<sub>0.5</sub>CoMnO<sub>6</sub>-1150 &deg;C bulk-sample has spin-glass like ordering below T<sub>g </sub>~ 34.88(3) K. This glassy behavior is attributed to the antisite disorders (~7.12%) along with structural and magnetic frustration in the system. However, the ground state of Sm<sub>1.5</sub>Ca<sub>0.5</sub>CoMnO<sub>6</sub>-600 &deg;C nanometric-sample is observed to be antiferromagnetic in nature due to the presence of large antisite disorders (~ 53.58%). The observed unusual co-existence of antiferromagnetism with Griffiths-like phase in Sm<sub>1.5</sub>Ca<sub>0.5</sub>CoMnO<sub>6</sub>-600 &deg;C sample is rare in nature. Interesting magnetic spin dynamics and aging effect are also observed in both the compounds suggesting different spin relaxation processes in low temperature regime. The observed magnetism in these compounds can be tuned by nearest neighbor Co-O-Mn and/or Co-O-Co/Mn-O-Mn exchange interactions as well as the next nearest neighbor Co-O-O-Co/Mn-O-O-Mn interaction.
611	<strong>Giant sensitivity to strain in cracked thin films based on metallic nanoparticles in a dielectric matrix<sup></sup></strong>	<SPAN style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%;">Platinum nanoparticle-based strain gauges are elaborated by means of atomic layer deposition on flexible polyimide substrates. Their electro-mechanical response is tested under mechanical bending at strain levels up to 1%. Sudden changes in electrical resistance are observed above 0.6% strain when straight cracks are formed in the nanostructured thin film. Scanning Electron Microscope experiments reveal that these cracks are preferentially formed next to the interface with aluminum top electrodes. After cracks formation, a giant gauge factor of 2.10<sup>4</sup> is measured at a strain level of 0.3%. This high sensitivity to strain is attributed to the gradual opening (or closing) of the cracks when mechanical strain is applied. Finally, we demonstrate the feasibility of a flexible heart rate monitor which integrates a cracked Pt nanoparticle-based strain gauge.</SPAN>
612	Towards a deeper understanding of nanoscratch-induced deformation in a phosphate glass	In this work, the factors affecting the nanoscratch-induced deformation of oxide glass in the completely ductile range are classified into three independent aspects, including plastic damage, densification and chemistry-enhanced material-removal. Through comparing the deformation volume of a phosphate glass subject to different conditions, viz. in dry or humid air and before or after annealing, the contributions of the three factors to the total deformation were quantified and their evolution mechanisms were clarified for sustained scratching. Analyses indicate that the combined action of plastic damage and densification dominates the glass deformation in fewer-pass scratching, while plastic damage and chemistry-enhanced material-removal together determine the final deformation volume for multi-pass scratching in humid air. The results presented in this study provide further insights into the physics of glass deformation.
613	Characteristics of mixing enhanced by using plasma-synthetic jet actuators in supersonic flow	Votical characteristics of mixing with existence of large scale vortices introduced by pulsed-plasma-synthetic jet array actuators in supersonic shear layer were investigated experimentally. The nanoparticle- based planar laser scattering method and particle image velocimetry are employed. The large scale structures caused by single pulse plasma-synthetic jet array actuators are successfully captured. The pulsed plasma-synthetic jet array actuators may be an effective tool for mixing layers in supersonic flow.
614	Transient dynamics of strongly coupled spin vortex pairs: effects of  anharmonicity and resonant excitation on inertial switching	Spin vortices in magnetic nanopillars are used as GHz oscillators, with frequency however essentially fixed in fabrication. We demonstrate a model system of a two-vortex nanopillar, in which the resonance frequency can be changed by an order of magnitude, without using high dc magnetic fields. The effect is due to switching between the two stable states of the vortex pair,which we show can be done with low-amplitude fields of sub-ns duration. We detail the relevant vortex-core dynamics and explain how field anharmonicity and phase control can be used to enhance the performance.
615	CO adsorption on nanoislands: Ni on Au(111)	The adsorption behavior of CO on Ni islands grown on Au(111) was studied with a combination of TPD, FTIR and surface resistivity measurements. The Au(111) herringbone reconstruction provides a template for the growth of ordered Ni islands, with evidence for the presence of strain and Au atoms within the islands. The islands grow radially until &#x03B8;_Ni&#x2248;0.3 ML, after which subsequent Ni atoms contribute primarily to a second layer. We study saturated CO adsorption at 227 K over a range of Ni island sizes, and find layer-dependent adsorption properties. For single-layer islands at low Ni coverage, CO adsorbs primarily in the atop position and desorbs at lower temperatures than on pure Ni, with a saturation CO coverage of about 0.5 CO/Ni. As second layer Ni grows, saturated CO coverages on the Ni approach unity, with higher desorption temperatures, but still with primarily atop CO. Based on previous studies, we propose that in the first Ni layer ligand effects from Au in the islands and strain due to the Ni/Au lattice mismatch affect the Ni-CO bonds. CO adsorption behavior on the two-layer islands is qualitatively explained by a decrease in Au concentration and the presence of a more expanded/corrugated structure.
616	Kinetically Controlled Dewetting of Thin GaAs Cap from An ErAs/GaAs Nanoparticle Composite Layer	ErAs metal nanoparticles (NPs) embedded in GaAs have multiple applications in plasmonic, terahertz, and tunneling devices. Growing high quality thin GaAs layer over the ErAs NP layer is vital to these applications. In this work, we study the surface stability of GaAs thin cap (1 to 5nm) on single layer of ErAs NPs grown using molecular beam epitaxy in a GaAs matrix. As grown GaAs at low temperature (450{degree sign}C) can be smooth, however, GaAs was found to dewet from ErAs NP layer with increasing temperature (&gt;500{degree sign}C) through the formation of clumps or pinholes depending on the layer thickness. Thermodynamically, this dewetting is driven by the high interfacial energy as a result of different crystal structures, however, as a kinetic factor, surface mobility plays important roles in the process. It has been demonstrated that the dewetting can be prevented by combining a higher As overpressure, a low growth/annealing temperature, lower surface coverage of ErAs NP, and thicker GaAs cap.
617	<strong>Microscale Mechanics of Nanoimprinted Polymer Microstructures</strong>	Nanoimprint has been an important nanofabrication technology that be widely adopted in various electronic, photonic and biomedical applications. During the nanoimprint process, the elevated temperature and high stress applied might lead to mechanical changes of imprinted polymeric materials. The mechanical properties of imprinted materials, especially those under microscale, play an important role in their stability and further industrial applications. In this study, nanoindentation was employed to quantitatively characterize the elastic moduli of PMMA patterned under various imprinting temperatures. We found that the elastic modulus would increase with the increase of embossing temperature, and this should be related to the increasing residual stress introduced by higher flow rate of polymer chains at higher temperature. Quantitative mapping of optical birefringence in imprinted polymer microstructures corroborated this observation. The microscale characterizations of polymeric microstructures by nanoindentation and optical retardation measurements can be useful in optimizing nanoimprinting parameters to achieve best service performance of imprinted polymer microstructures for MEMS applications.
618	Measurement of the Hall effect at nanoscale with three probes	The Hall effect and its varieties such as quantum, anomalous, and spin Hall effects, provide indispensable tools for the characterization of electronic and magnetic properties of materials, metrology, and spintronics. The conventional four-probe Hall configuration is generally not amenable to measurements at nanoscale, due to current shunting by the Hall electrodes. We demonstrate that Hall measurements on the nanoscale can be facilitated by the three-probe Hall configuration that avoids the shunting problem. We illustrate the efficiency of the proposed approach with anomalous Hall effect-based measurements of individual activation events during domain wall motion in magnetic films with perpendicular anisotropy.
619	A Study of Plasma Induced Nanostructure Formation and Surface Morphology Changes on Tungsten at Atmospheric Pressure	The formation of nanostructures such as "fuzz", holes, and flakes were observed on stainless steel and tungsten anodes that in a 1 atm glow discharge with helium as the feed gas. The structures exhibited morphology similar to the tungsten fuzz growth observed in experiments that simulate wall conditions in fusion reactors, suggesting similar physics may be present in both scenarios.  The anode surface temperature ranged between 1000 and 1300 K with an ion fluence rate of order of 1024 s-1m-2.  In this work, scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were used to characterize the evolution of nanostructure formation as a function of time.  Observed nanostructures were found to vary with the morphology of the discharge plasma attachment. The composition of the structures was found to be predominantly the native metal. This work gives some insight into the formation of nanostructures at atmospheric pressure which has not only applications for material processing but also provides potentially another avenue to study fuzz formation processes relevant to fusion plasma-wall interactions.
620	<strong>Transmission low-energy electron diffraction using double-gated single nanotip field emitter<sup></sup></strong>	We explore the spatial coherence of double-gate nanotip single field emitters by low-energy electron diffraction experiments in transmission mode.  This source has the capability of producing collimated electron beams well suited for diffraction. Bragg reflections from suspended graphene were successfully imaged by electrically switching field emission pulses.  This result was obtained without additional optics. In comparison to previous experiments using a double-gate nanotip array cathode, we observed sharper and higher resolution diffraction spots with the single-nanotip double-gate emitters. In particular, we found complete conservation of the size and the shape of the diffraction spots with those of the incident beam on the sample. The result indicates that the transverse coherence of such a nanofabricated double-gate single-tip emitter is much larger than a few nanometers as determined by the apparent diffraction spot size and overall spatial resolution based the observed diffraction pattern.
621	Strongly temperature-dependent recombination kinetics of negatively charged exciton in asymmetric quantum dots at 1.55 &mu;m	We report on strongly temperature-dependent kinetics of negatively charged carrier complexes in asymmetric InAs/AlGaInAs/InP quantum dots (dashes) emitting at telecom wavelengths. Studied structures are highly elongated and of large volume, which results in atypical carrier confinement characteristics with <em>s</em>-<em>p</em> shell energy splittings far below the optical phonon energy, which strongly affects the phonon-assisted electron relaxation. Probing the emission kinetics with time-resolved microphotoluminescence from a single structure, we observe a strongly non-monotonic temperature dependence of the charged exciton lifetime. It may be interpreted in terms of two thermally activated processes that slow down the recombination, separated by an abrupt drop of lifetime at T&asymp;30-50 K. Modeling the recombination cascade kinetics with rate equations, we find that a relaxation side-path through the excited charged exciton triplet states may lead to such a behavior. This, however, involves a singlet-triplet relaxation, for which efficient electron spin flip processes are needed. Hence, we interpret our results as an indirect observation of strongly enhanced electron spin relaxation without magnetic field, most possibly resulting from atypical confinement characteristics in the studied nanostructures.
622	<strong>Chemical </strong><strong><strong>synthesis </strong></strong><strong><strong>of h</strong></strong><strong><strong>ighly active </strong></strong><strong><strong>Eu-</strong></strong><strong><strong>doped ZnO nano</strong></strong><strong><strong>sheet</strong></strong><strong><strong>s for photodegradation</strong></strong><strong><strong> </strong></strong><strong><strong>of Rhodamine B</strong></strong>	Eu-doped ZnO nanosheets were synthesized via a facile and surfactant-free chemical solution deposition method. The detailed characterization studies revealed that the as-synthesized samples were well-crystalline and accumulated by large amount of nanosheets with 25 nm thickness. The Eu ions were successfully doped into the ZnO nanosheets, and the red emissions of Eu<sup>3+</sup> ions attributed to the energy of <sup>5</sup>D<sub>0</sub>&rarr;<sup>7</sup>F<sub>0</sub>, <sup>5</sup>D<sub>0</sub>&rarr;<sup>7</sup>F<sub>1</sub> and <sup>5</sup>D<sub>0</sub>&rarr;<sup>7</sup>F<sub>2</sub><sub> </sub>4f&ndash;4f intrashell transitions were observed in PL spectra. It was also observed that the appropriate Eu doping could increase the separation efficiency of electron-hole pairs and promote the formation of the superoxide ions during the photolysis process, which eventually improved the photodegradation of Rhodamine B under UV light irradiation. A pseudo first order rate was analyzed for the photocatalytic degradation of RhB. A possible explanation for the modification of bandgap was given based on the modified effect of Eu<sup>3+</sup> ions on the electronic structure of ZnO nanosheets, which mainly due to two mechanisms of Burstein-Moss effect and electron-ion/electron scattering.
623	Ab Initio and Theoretical Study on Electron Transport through Polyene Junctions in between Angled-cut Carbon Nanotubes	We investigate the surface Green's function and layer-by-layer local density of states (LDOS) of the armchair carbon nanotube (CNT) leads from the rim into the bulk tube. We find the 3-layer-cycle oscillation of the cross-cut cases, and that the angled-cut cases, exhibiting a zigzag rim at the cut, possess not only the oscillation, but also evanescent edge states that decay into the bulk tube.  We study the single-polyene and two-polyene molecular junctions bridging the angled-cut armchair CNT leads, with both ab initio and tight-binding model approaches, and look into the interference effect between effective transport channels.
624	<strong>Dual Functional Asymmetric Plasmonic Structures for Solar Water Purification and Pollution Detection</strong>	In the past decade, various rational designed plasmonic structures have demonstrated extraordinary functionalities from information, photothermal therapy to solar energy conversion. Recently, plasmon enhanced solar steam generation is attracting a lot of attention for its great potential in desalination, sterilization, etc. Here for the first time we demonstrate an asymmetric plasmonic structure (APS) formed by self-assembly of close packed silver nanoparticles into porous templates with dual functions, solar water purification and pollution detection. The dark porous side of the APS can enable efficient solar steam generation (with energy transfer efficiency ~ 80%) while the shiny metallic side can enable sensitive chemicals detection (with detection limit down to ~ 10<sup>-12</sup> M). Such impressive performance in solar thermal conversion and chemical sensing are stemmed from the broadband and efficient light absorption (solar absorptivity &gt; 90%) as well as pronounced local field enhancement (maximal enhancement factor ~ 10<sup>9</sup>), respectively. As an example of functional integration, this dual functional APS can enable on-site pollution detection and purification of water: water sources contaminated with various kinds of common pollutants have been examined and purified. Both functions of detection and purification exhibit long time durable performance up to ~ 45 days, with &lt; 20% decay in Raman intensity and &lt; 10% decay in energy transfer efficiency, respectively.
625	<strong>Realization of strain-induced giant polychromatic emission in ZnO nanostructures for white light emitting diode application</strong>	In this letter, we report that flower shaped architecture of ZnO assembled by individual nanopetals of an average thickness ~ 93 nm has been achieved by selective self &ndash; etching method.  ZnO nanopetals prepared at 80&deg;C exhibit enhanced polychromatic defect emissions of blue, green and red (BGR) as compared to samples annealed at higher temperatures and the maximum intensity values for BGR are 4.06 &ndash; 4.80 &times;10<sup>6</sup>, 4.89 &times;10<sup>6</sup> and 3.56 &times;10<sup>6 </sup>cps, respectively. These values are much greater than the previous reports in such a way that it is something spectacular to be witnessed. The improved luminescence intensity of BGR is attributed to the higher lattice strain and dislocation density induced in ZnO due to native defects. As the annealing temperature is reduced, the dislocation density increases from 7.60 &times;10<sup>13</sup> to 3.99&times;10<sup>15 </sup>lines/m<sup>2</sup>, whilst, lattice strain increases from 0.0079&times;10<sup>-3</sup> to 1.81&times;10<sup>-3</sup>. The observed high luminescence emission is due to flower shaped architecture making it suitable for the fabrication of solid- state white light emitting diodes.

627	<strong>Synthesis and i</strong><strong>ntrinsic magnetism </strong><strong>of</strong><strong> bilayer graphene nanoribbons</strong>	Pristine bilayer graphene nanoribbons (BLGNRs) with the average width of ca. 9 nm were obtained by longitudinal unzipping the oxalic acid-intercalated double-walled carbon nanotubes followed by annealing at 900 <sup>o</sup>C. The magnetic properties of BLGNRs were investigated. The results reveal that BLGNRs show obvious antiferromagnetic behavior with the N&eacute;el temperature of ca. 66 K. 628	Self-generation of Ag nanoparticle mechanism during Ag sintering process	Self-generation of Ag nanoparticles (AgNPs) with a size less than 10 nm was observed in the Ag sintering process under an air atmosphere, which corresponds to a stronger sintered Ag tension and shear strength than that sintered in nitrogen. It is confirmed that oxygen plays an important role in the generation of AgNPs, which leading to the oxidation processes of Ag grains and the compression stress release at the grain boundaries. Self-generation AgNPs accumulated around the grains and grain boundaries and thus promotes connection and necking between Ag grains during sintering process.
629	<strong>Nanofuel droplet combustion: insights into droplet burning time scale, secondary atomisation and coupling of droplet deformations and heat release</strong>	Combustion characteristics of ethanol-water droplets laden with ceria (CeO<sub>2</sub>) nanoparticle (NP) is investigated in the current work. Using simultaneous high speed shadowgraphy and flame OH* chemiluminescence imaging, spatio-temporal variation of droplet shape and heat release (HR) is analysed.  Present experimental study focuses on three facets of droplet combustion <strong>(i)</strong> burning time scale of droplets with and without NPs, <strong>(ii)</strong> pathways of secondary atomisation and <strong>(iii)</strong> Coupling of droplet shape deformations and flame heat release. A semi-analytical timescale is advocated which incorporates natural convection-based evaporation and mass loss due to daughter droplet ejections. For droplets seeded with ceria NPs, period following initial heat-up exhibit arrested surface undulations although internal ebullition is discernibly enhanced. Formation of gelatinous sheath on nanofuel droplet surface during this period is observed. Presence of this skeletal network provides an analogy with solvent evaporation through porous media. Hence, for nanofuel droplets, semi-analytical time scales are evaluated considering both pure evaporation and flow through porous media. Deformations in EW droplets are traced to the imbalance between local vapour recoil and surface tension leading to surface craters. This pathway of secondary atomisation of EW droplets has been elucidated using a modified local weber number  . We propose a theoretical velocity scale of the ligament which turns out to be of same order as the experimental findings.
