Proper orthogonal technique is utilised for investigating droplet shape and flame HR evolution. Modal analysis of EW and nanoceria droplet reveals presence of chaotic deviations from mean geometry. Nanoceria exhibit arrested surface fluctuations.
630	Low temperature plasmas induced in SF6 by extreme ultraviolet (EUV) pulses	In this work a comparative study of EUV induced, low temperature SF6 - based plasmas, created using two different irradiation systems, was performed. Both systems utilized laser-produced plasma (LPP) EUV sources. The essential difference between the systems concerned formation of the driving, EUV beam. The first one contained an efficient ellipsoidal EUV collector allowing for focusing of the EUV radiation at a large distance from the LPP source. The spectrum of focused radiation was limited to the long-wavelength part of the total LPP emission, &#x03BB; &gt; 8 nm due to reflective properties of the collector. The second system did not contain any EUV collector. The gas to be ionized was injected in the vicinity of the LPP, at a distance of the order of 10 mm. In both systems energies of the driving photons were high enough for dissociative ionization of the SF6 molecules, ionization of atoms or even singly charged ions. Plasmas, created due to these processes, were investigated by spectral measurements in the EUV, ultraviolet (UV) and visible (VIS) spectral ranges. These low temperature plasmas were employed for preliminary experiments concerning surface treatment. Formation of pronounced nanostructures on the silicon surface after the plasma treatment were demonstrated.
631	Spin-relaxation anisotropy in a nanowire quantum dot with strong spin-orbit coupling	We study the impacts of the magnetic field direction on the spin-manipulation and the spin-relaxation in a one-dimensional quantum dot with strong spin-orbit coupling. The energy spectrum and the corresponding eigenfunctions in the quantum dot are obtained exactly. We find that no matter how large the spin-orbit coupling is, the electric-dipole spin transition rate as a function of the magnetic field direction always has a &#x03C0; periodicity. However, the phonon-induced spin relaxation rate as a function of the magnetic field direction has a &#x03C0; periodicity only in the weak spin-orbit coupling regime, and the periodicity is prolonged to 2&#x03C0; in the strong spin-orbit coupling regime.
632	Increasing the refractive index of materials via nanolamination - a-IGZO/TiO<sub>2</sub> superlattices	We investigate nanolamination as a means of increasing the refractive index of materials, with a focus on [a-IGZO/TiO<sub>2</sub>]<sub>i</sub> nanolaminates as composite transparent conducting oxides (TCOs) with tuneable index. We demonstrate that by periodic layering with TiO<sub>2</sub> the refractive index of a-IGZO can be increased by up to &#x0394;n~0.39 while the carrier mobility and conductivity retain 70% of their original values. This is shown to be a result of the alignment of the conduction bands of the a-IGZO and TiO<sub>2</sub>. We also use optical modeling to verify the integral refractive index behaviour of the nanolaminates and outline its range of applicability.
633	Deformation behaviors in Au nanotubes under torsion by molecular dynamics simulations	In this study, the mechanical deformation behaviors of Au nanotubes (Au-NTs) under torsional stress are investigated using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. The inter-atomic interaction is modeled using the embedded-atom potential. In particular, the effects of loading rate, thickness and length of the nanotube, as well as the thermal effects were systematically explored. The results indicated that higher loading rate, longer length and thinner wall thickness all led to a larger value of critical torsional angle (<em>&theta;</em><sub>cr</sub>), which signifies the onset of plastic deformation. On the other hand, <em>&theta;</em><sub>cr</sub> decreases with increasing temperature in all simulated results. Moreover, the torsional buckling deformation behavior and geometrical instability are found to strongly depend on the length of Au-NTs, the applied strain rate and temperature with vastly different underlying mechanisms.
634	<strong>Weak Enhanced Resonant Faraday Rotation in Pure Cobalt Plasmonic Lattices: Thickness Dependent Faraday Rotation Studies</strong>	The thickness dependent magneto-optical Faraday rotation in Co ferromagnetic thin films and perforated periodic Co nano-hole arrays were investigated. It was observed that the optical response and Faraday rotation of Co nano-hole arrays were strongly dependent on the thickness of the film, and the Faraday rotation reached the maximum amplitude at an optimal thickness value of 30 nm to 50 nm, which contrasted with the Co thin films where the Faraday rotation increased with the film thickness. In addition, the Faraday rotation spectra of Co nano-hole arrays showed a weak resonantly enhanced peak at the anti-resonance modes (or Wood&rsquo;s anomalies) on the transmission spectra, which correspond to the localized surface plasmon resonances at the film and surrounding medium interfaces. All experimental results were confirmed by the finite-difference time domain calculations.
635	<strong>Apparent toughening in Ti-Al-N coatings by phase transformation stresses</strong>	<SPAN style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%;">The formation of hcp (ZnS-wurtzite type) AlN precipitates, due to the decomposition of supersaturated fcc (NaCl-type) Ti-Al-N coatings upon annealing, causes the residual macrostresses to increase from -3.9&plusmn;0.3 GPa (as-deposited) to -5.2&plusmn;0.3 GPa (annealed at 900 &deg;C), as determined by X-ray diffraction. This leads to an apparent increase in fracture toughness (K<sub>IC</sub>) &ndash; obtained by cube corner nanoindenation experiments &ndash; from the as-deposited value of ~4.4 MPa&radic;m to ~8.0 MPa&radic;m when annealed at 900 &deg;C. This assessment is supported by studying the phase transformation induced stresses by continuum mechanics modelling using Transformation Field Analysis.</SPAN>
636	Promoting single-file DNA translocations through nanopores usingselectroosmotic flow	Double-stranded DNA translocates through sufficiently large nanopores either in a linear, single-file fashion or in a folded hairpin conformation when captured somewhere along its length. We show that the folding state of DNA can be controlled by changing the electrolyte concentration, pH and PEG content of the measurement buffer. At 1M LiCl or 0.35M KCl in neutral pH, single-file translocations make up more than 90% of the total. We attribute the effect to the onset of electroosmotic flow from the pore at low ionic strength. Our hypothesis on the critical role of flows is supported by the preferred orientation of entry of a strand that has been folded into a multi-helix structure at one end. Control over DNA folding is critical for nanopore sensing approaches that use modifications along a DNA strand and the associated secondary current drops to encode information.
637	Variable Range Hopping Conduction in ZnO Nanocrystal Thin Films	Both Mott and Efros-Shklovskii variable range hopping models have been applied to films of semiconductor nanocrystals to describe their temperature-dependent conductivity. Adding an infill tends to increase conductivity, although the mechanism is uncertain. This paper uses UV exposure to control the carrier concentration by dosing and controllably desorbing surface hydroxyls. This provides a method for obtaining sufficient information to develop a detailed model for how electronic properties are affected by infill in films of ZnO nanocrystals. The technique allows one to transition between the two conduction mechanisms and so extract fundamental parameters of the materials. It is found that the removal of OH increases the localization length but does not significantly change the Fermi level. A model that explains these results is the existence of a quasi-neutral core surrounded by a shell depleted by surface OH trap states. As OH is removed, the core expands. Without infill the edge of the quasi-neutral region approaches the diameter of the NC. The NC-NC interfaces most likely to conduct current are close proximity crystal facets. Delocalization across facets is less complete for infilled samples. This may be due to two effects incomplete facet infill and the subsequent sealing of these spaces. The results suggest that, while the average carrier concentration in the NCs increase with infill and with removal of OH, the primary source of the increased conductivity is an increase in the ability to tunnel from NC to NC due to a reduction in the distance between quasi-neutral cores.
638	Wafer-scale, Stretchable Nanomeshes from an Ultrathin-Support-Layer Assisted Transfer	Metal nanomeshes possess unique electrical and mechanical properties for next&#x2011;generation stretchable electronics. However, a critical unmet need lies in producing stretchable conductive nanomeshes at large scale with high uniformity and intactness. Here we present a wafer-scale nondestructive transfer method by utilizing an ultrathin polyimide layer. This polyimide support layer allows etchant vapor to transmit through to etch the sacrificial layer underneath, while being continuous to support the nanomeshes during transfer and then is removed completely after the transfer. From this simple yet effective method, we developed 4&#x2011;inch-wafer-scale gold nanomeshes with low sheet resistance of 8.35 &#x2126;/&#x25A1;, good transparency of 65% at 550 nm, and stretchability of 70%. Detailed vapor transmission studies reveal that etchant vapor indeed transmitted through the support layer, with realistic sacrificial etching time needed for transfer. Together, these results provide a practical pathway towards fabricating large-scale nanomesh based stretchable electronics, with applications ranging from skin-on electronics to implantable biomedical devices. We also expect this ultrathin support layer approach to be generally applicable to the processing of many other nanomaterials at large scale.
639	GaAs Solar Cells on Nanopatterned Si Substrates	Integrating III-Vs onto Si is a promising route towards tandem photovoltaics and cost mitigation of III-V substrates. While many III-V/Si photovoltaic integration approaches have been studied, epitaxial growth on Si allows for fewer processing steps compared to other approaches. However, current epitaxial pathways utilize expensive techniques, such as thermal cycle annealing or thick buffer layers to control defect densities, undermining the low-cost goal of integrating III-Vs with Si. Here, we present single-junction GaAs solar cells grown directly on Si using selective area growth as an alternative low-cost technique to control material quality with a much thinner buffer. We demonstrate a 10.4%-efficient GaAs device grown on a V-grooved Si substrate which achieved an antiphase domain-free III-V/Si interface and a threading dislocation density of 2&times;10<sup>7</sup> cm<sup>-2</sup>, despite the lack of a graded buffer. We compare this growth on V-grooved Si to solar cells grown on polished Si with and without a patterned silica buffer layer, which demonstrate efficiencies of 6.5% and 6.8%, respectively; the polished Si was patterned using nanoimprint lithography, which is a low-cost patterning technique compatible with III-V selective area growth. Cracking is found to be a critical challenge that hinders solar cell performance, and is exacerbated by the V-grooved Si surface topography. The results in this paper provide a promising pathway towards high-efficiency, low-cost III-V/Si tandem photovoltaics.
640	Synthesis of 15-nm-diameter silver nanowires via a pressure-induced polyol method using AgCl-KBr co-salts: Evolution of low haze-transparent electrode two-dimensional films	We synthesized Ag nanowires (Ag NWs) with diameters ranging from 15 to 45-nm via a pressure-induced polyol method. By optimizing the pressure, we effectively controlled the increase in the thickness of Ag NWs without influencing the longitudinal direction. Under a pressure of 1000 psi, in the present of AgCl-KBr co-salts, ultra-thin sub-15-nm-diameter Ag NWs was obtained. These two-dimensional Ag NW network film exhibited considerably high transmittance (over 90%) and considerably low haze values (1.5% or less) despite the low sheet resistance (10 &#xF057;/sq.). This performance is comparable to that of crystalline indium-tin-oxide glass with the same sheet resistance.
641	<strong>Enhanced Photoelectrochemical Performance of InGaN-based Nanowire Photoanodes by Optimizing the Ionized Dopant Concentration </strong>	InGaN-based nanowires (NWs) have been extensively studied for photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting devices owing to their tunable bandgap and good chemical stability. Here, we further investigated the influence of Si doping on the PEC performance of InGaN-based NW photoanodes. The Si dopant concentration was controlled by tuning the Si effusion cell temperature (T<sub>Si</sub>) during plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy (PA-MBE) growth and further estimated by Mott-Schottky electrochemical measurements. The highest Si dopant concentration of 2.1&times;10<sup>18</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup> was achieved at T<sub>Si</sub>=1120 &deg;C, and the concentration decreased with further increases in T<sub>Si</sub>. The flat-band potential was calculated and used to estimate the conduction and valence band edge potentials of the Si-doped InGaN-based NWs. The band edge potentials were found to seamlessly straddle the redox potentials of water splitting. The linear scan voltammetry results were consistent with the estimated carrier concentration. The InGaN-based NWs doped with Si at T<sub>Si</sub>=1120 &deg;C exhibited the highest current density (1.97 mA/cm<sup>2</sup> at 1.597 V vs NHE), which was 15 times higher than that of the undoped sample. Our systematic findings suggest that the PEC performance can be significantly improved by optimizing the Si doping level of InGaN-based NW photoanodes.
642	<SPAN style="font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%; color: blue;">Experimental and Modeling Investigation on the Self-propagating Combustion Behavior of Al-MoO<sub>3</sub> Reactive Multilayer Films</SPAN>	In order to probe the self-propagating combustion behavior of aluminum/molybdenum trioxide (Al/MoO<sub>3</sub>) reactive multilayer films (RMFs), RMFs with varied modulation periods and widths were deposited by magnetron sputtering method on glass substrate. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) revealed that thermal reaction was in solid-solid phase at nanoscale modulation periods (50 nm and 150 nm), and in liquid-solid phase at microscale (1500 nm). Meanwhile, the peak temperature reduced with thinner modulation period, while the heat release of RMFs-1500 nm was less compared with 50 nm and 150 nm suggesting incomplete reaction. Further since X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis demonstrated the presence of aluminum oxide, the hot spot and pre-oxidation theory of interface in Al/MoO<sub>3</sub> RMFs allowed logical explanation of thermal reaction feature. The RMFs achieved stable self-propagating combustion at nanoscale modulation periods excited by a laser pulse, but not at microscale. The average stable combustion velocity was 6 m/s in 150 nm modulation period and reached 10 m/s for 50 nm. The two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) demonstrated that effect of width on combustion velocity was not significant. Thus, we constructed a one-dimensional (1D) combustion velocity model based on heat transfer theory combing experimental data. The model explored relationship between stable combustion velocity and modulation period and verified that self-propagating combustion velocity was likely controlled by the thermal conduction of substrates.
643	<strong>Growth of ordered arrays of vertical free-standing VO<sub>2</sub> nanowires on nanoimprinted Si</strong>	In recent years, the synthesis and study of individual single-crystal VO<sub>2</sub> nanowires (NWs) have been attracting much interest due to the unique properties of the material related with the single-domain metal-insulator phase transition in such NWs. Although single-crystal VO<sub>2</sub> NWs offer much promise for practical applications, the lack of a technology for forming NW arrays and, especially, ordered arrays of VO<sub>2</sub> NWs still does not permit the mass fabrication of novel VO<sub>2</sub>-based devices and materials. Here, we break this barrier and synthesized ordered arrays of free-standing single-crystal monoclinic VO<sub>2</sub> NWs. Vertically aligned, strongly periodic VO<sub>2</sub> NWs were obtained in a CVD process used to grow VO<sub>2</sub> on nanoimprinted Si substrate. Indicative of a high quality of obtained NW is a sharp rise of conductivity at the phase transition in VO<sub>2</sub> reaching in magnitude four orders as well as a pronounced faceting of the crystals confirmed by x-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements. Our approach paves the way toward a broad application of VO<sub>2</sub> single crystals with desired sizes, shape, and aspect ratio in various fields of nanophotonics and nanoelectronics, and in smart materials.
644	<strong>Precise nanothermal measurements via spatially distributed scanning thermal microscope probes</strong>	Advances in materials design and device miniaturization lead to physical properties that may significantly differ from the bulk ones. In particular, thermal transport is strongly affected when the device dimensions approach the mean free path of heat carriers. Scanning Thermal Microscopy (SThM) is arguably the best approach for probing nanoscale thermal properties with few tens of nm lateral resolution. Typical SThM probes based on a microfabricated Pd resistive probes (PdRP) using a spatially distributed heater and a nanoscale tip in contact with the sample, provide high sensitivity and operation in ambient, vacuum and liquid environments. However, the response of this sensor has been poorly studied, impeding its precision and stability, and, ultimately, impeding the quantitative measurements. Here we build an analytical model of the PdRP sensor taking into account finite dimensions of the heater. While it has been previously assumed that the probe response is identical for heat flowing through a tip to the sample or due to probe self-heating &ndash; here we theoretically and experimentally demonstrate that they can differ by more than 50%, hence introducing significant error in the SThM measurements. Furthermore, we analyzed the effect of environmental parameters such as sample and microscope stage temperatures, and laser illumination, allowed to reduce the experimental scatter by a factor of 10. Finally, varying these parameters, we measured absolute values of heat resistances and compared these to the model for both ambient and vacuum SThM operation, providing a comprehensive pathway improving the precision of the nanothermal measurements in SThM.
645	In situ Voltage-Application System for Active Voltage Contrast Imaging in Helium Ion Microscope	To develop a new electrical potential observation method, we constructed a system whereby helium ion microscope (HIM) observations can be performed while applying any voltage (about {plus minus}5 V) to a sample. The in situ voltage-application system is operated in a high vacuum HIM chamber and consists of a transfer rod, tilt joint, x-, y-, and z-axis mechanisms, and two probes at the end of the transfer rod. We acquired secondary electron (SE) images of the cross-sectional surfaces of multilayer ceramic capacitor (MLCC) with voltages (from 0.5 V to 5 V) applied to the internal electrodes of the MLCC by using the new system. The active voltage contrast corresponding to the electrical potential in the SE images could be observed when the applied voltage is less than or equal to 1.5 V. This technique enables any voltage to be applied to the samples from outside the chamber and can be used to measure nanometer-scale electrical potential distribution of Li-ion rechargeable batteries, solar cells, etc.
646	Fabrication and characterization of urea biosensor using CuO/ZnO based diode	This paper presents fabrication of a compact and low cost printed circuit board (PCB) based urea biosensor using a circular sized indium tinoxide (ITO) coated glass as working electrode. For this, ITO coated glass was subjected to etching using 50 % concentrated sulphuric acid at temperature of 50 &#x02DA;C with a suitable mask to protect the circuit area.  A silver layer was developed around the ITO working electrode on the same glass by thermal evaporation technique and then AgCl paste was coated on the Ag layer for the preparation of Ag/AgCl as reference electrode. A thin layer of mixture of nanostructured copper oxide (Nano-CuO) and nanostructured zinc oxide (Nano-ZnO) was deposited using electrophoretic deposition method on the said working electrode. Urease (Enzyme) was immobilized on the working electrode surface by physical adsorption technique via glutareldehyde as cross-linker. Electrochemical response of this urea bioelectrode was recorded by Keithley Source Meter (KSM) for different urea concentration from 0.1 to 100 mM. This Nano-CuO/Nano-ZnO urea bioelectrode was found to have sensitivity of 488 uA/mM/cm2, shelf life of 180 days under normal laboratory condition and lower limit of detection of 35 uM. This method requires only a small amount of urease~ 2 &#x00B5;l and no extra buffer saline for test. Such small sized nanostructured urea biosensor with high commercial impact can be easily fabricated and mass produced using this methodology.
647	Numerical solution for MHD flow of micropolar nanofluid in the presence of nonlinear thermal radiation and activation energy	The effects of variable thermal conductivity, radiative heat flux, activation energy, viscous dissipation, Ohmic dissipation and MHD on an incompressible micropolar nanofluid flowing over a stretching sheet have been debated in detail. The nonlinaer partial diffential equations (PDEs) for momentum, energy, microrotation and nanoparticle concentration are discussed. These PDEs are converted to a set of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) by utilizing an appropriate transformation and then tackled numerically with the help of shooting method and the MATLAB  built-in solver bvp4c. It is canvassed that by augmenting the microrotation parameter, a boost in the angular velocity profile is seen. The values of sundry parameters like microrotation, Prandtl number, Lewis number, activation energy, thermal conductivity, radiation parameter, Schmidt number, thermophoresis parameter and Brownian motion parameter have been delineated across the velocity profile, angular velocity profile and nanoparticle concentration profiles.
648	Strain Rate and Temperature Dependence of the Mechanical Properties of Polymers: A Universal Time-Temperature Superposition Principle	Establishing the Time-Temperature and Frequency-Temperature Superposition Principles (TTSP and FTSP) to describe the mechanical behavior of polymeric materials is always of paramount significance. In this work, by adopting the classic coarse-grained model, we investigate the validity of these superposition principles for a series of networks; such as the pure polymer network, interpenetrating polymer networks composed of stiff and flexible networks (IPNs-SF), interpenetrating polymer networks composed of different crosslinking networks (IPNs-DC), polymer nanocomposites (PNCs), and surface grafting modified PNCs. The study focuses on the three critical mechanical properties such as the stress relaxation, the storage modulus versus the frequency obtained from the dynamic periodic shear deformation, and the uniaxial tensile stress-strain. The glass transition temperature (Tg) is 0.47 for the simulated polymer network (CL400) and a smooth master curve is obtained for the stress relaxation process by setting Tg as the reference temperature via the horizontal shifting process, indicating the validity of TTSP. Importantly, the Arrhenius and WLF equations are both adopted to quantitatively analyze the TTSP behavior. Furthermore, similar smooth master curves are also achieved for both dynamic periodic shear and uniaxial tensile deformation. Based on the Eyring equation, we establish a quantitative equation between the temperature and the strain rate within a certain range, which is used to obtain a smooth master curve for the stress-strain behavior. For the three mechanical properties, we emphasize that the master curve from TTSP or FTSP is independent of the reference temperature if it is higher than Tg, and based on the linear relation of the shift factor versus the inverse of the temperature higher than Tg, we propose a universal framework for the description of the TTSP or FTSP on the various mechanical properties. Then, we verify that the TTSP seems to be valid for the IPNs-DC system, while it does not hold for both PNCs and IPNs-SF systems because of their structural and dynamic heterogeneity. Furthermore, for PNCs filled with NPs grafted with polymer chains, the TTSP recovers back to be valid because of the enhanced compatibility between polymer and NPs attributed to the grafted polymer chains.
649	Wetting of Chemically Heterogeneous Striped Surfaces: Molecular Dynamics Simulations	Using molecular dynamics simulations, we thoroughly investigated the wetting behaviors of a chemically heterogeneous striped substrate patterned with two different wetting materials, face-centered cubic gold and face-centered cubic silver, at the nanoscale by analyzing the influences on the density distribution, normal stress distribution, surface tensions, and contact angle of a water droplet placed on the substrate. We found that the density and stress profile of the water droplet near the substrate-water interface were noticeably affected by altering the gold and silver contents in the substrate. Specifically, a greater portion of gold (more wetting) or smaller portion of silver (less wetting) in the substrate composition induced higher densities and higher normal stresses in the vicinity of the substrate surface. Also, it was observed that the surface tensions at liquid-vapor interface and solid-vapor interface were not largely impacted by the change of the substrate composition while the solid-liquid surface tension decreased exponentially with increasing fraction of gold. Most importantly, we found that contact angle of a nanometer-sized water droplet resting on the chemically heterogeneous striped substrate does not show linear dependence on corresponding surface fractions like that predicted by Cassie-Baxter model at the macro-scale. Consequently, we proposed a method for successfully predicting the contact angle by including the critical effects of the substrate heterogeneity on both surface tensions and line tension at the three-phase contact line of the water droplet and the chemically striped substrate.
650	Electrospun PVA polymer embedded with ceria nanoparticles as silicon solar cells rare surface coaters for efficiency improvement	This paper introduces electrospun nanofibers embedded with ceria nanoparticles as silicon solar cells coaters, showing their influence on the solar cells efficiency. Ceria nanoparticles can be synthesized to have formed oxygen vacancies (O-vacancies) which are associated with converting cerium ions from the Ce4+ state ions to the Ce3+ ones. These O-vacancies follow the rule of improving silicon solar cells conductivity through hopping mechanism. Besides, under near-ultra violet (near-UV) excitation, the reduced trivalent cerium Ce3+ ions are directly responsible for down converting the un-absorbed UV wavelengths to a resulted green fluorescence emission at ~520nm which are absorbed through the silicon solar cells active layer. When electrospun PVA embedded with ceria nanoparticles on the silicon solar cell, a promising enhancement in the behavior of solar cells I-V curve has observed. The efficiency has improved by about 24% of its initial value due to the mutual impact of improving both electric conductivity and optical conversions from both PVA nanofibers and the embedded ceria nanoparticles.
651	<strong>All-optical switch and transistor based on coherent light-controlling-light of a single two-level atom coupling with two nanowires</strong>	Atom-nanowire strong coupling system is a promising platform for optical quantum information processing. In this paper, three contributions of atomic nonlinearity are specified explicitly for two coherent double-pump drives for the first time. It brings us a new approach to manipulating a strong light with a weak light, which is fundamental to all-optical switch and transistor. An optically controllable switch and transistor without gain medium based on coherent controlling light with light have been proposed at single-atom level in this work. Our findings show potential applications in full-optical devices.
652	<strong>Disorder Enhanced Thermal Conductivity Anisotropy in Two-Dimensional Materials and van der Waals Heterostructures</strong>	Two-dimensional (2D) materials and van der Waals heterostructures can naturally function as directional heat spreaders in nanoelectronics due to their intrinsically anisotropic structure. In real nanoelectronics applications, disorders usually appear in those materials where their effects on anisotropic thermal conductivity are not well-understood. We built simple graphite-like materials models and systematically incorporated mass disorder or structural disorder into the structures. The anisotropic thermal conductivities calculated by equilibrium molecular dynamics simulations show that mass disorder and stacking disorder can effectively and anisotropically tune the thermal conductivity of 2D materials and van der Waals heterostructures. Compared with the pristine graphite, the through-plane thermal conductivity can be reduced up to two orders of magnitude by the through-plane mass disorder and the thermal anisotropy ratio (i.e., the ratio of in-plane to through-plane thermal conductivity) can be enhanced more than ten times.  We attribute this counter-intuitive result to the dramatic decrease of phonon group velocity in the through-plane direction. Our results can shed some lights in the thermal management in electronics incorporating 2D materials and van der Waals heterostructures.
653	<strong>Constructing heterostructure of MX<sub>2</sub> (M=Zr, Hf; X=S, Se) for improved  optoelectronics  and  high-temperature thermoelectrics</strong>	Integrating various two-dimensional monolayers into diverse van der Waals heterostructures with functions has emerged at the cutting edge of nanoscale material research. In the present study, first-principles calculations combined with semiclassical Boltzmann transport theory have been applied to investigate the electronic and thermoelectric properties of van der Waals heterostructures consisting of MX<sub>2</sub> (M= Zr, Hf and X= S, Se) monolayers. Type-II band alignment is readily available between ZrS<sub>2</sub> and HfSe<sub>2</sub>, facilitating charge separation for optoelectronics and solar energy conversion. All studied heterostructures possesses remarkably higher electrical conductivity and larger power factor values at 1200 K, showing great potentials for future efficient high-temperature thermoelectrics.
654	Flexoelectricity in a metal/ferroelectric/semiconductor heterostructure	The flexoelectricity in a 100 nm-thick BaTiO<sub>3</sub> (BTO) thin film based metal/ferroelectric insulator/semiconductor (MFS) heterostructure was reported in this letter. The transverse flexoelectric coefficient of the BTO thin film in the heterojunction structure was measured to be 287-418 &micro;C/m at room temperature, and its temperature dependence shows that the flexoelectric effect in the BTO thin film was dominated in the paraelectric phase. We showed that the BTO thin film capacitance could be controlled at multi-levels by introducing ferroelectric and flexoelectric polarization in the film. These results are promising for understanding the flexoelectricity in epitaxial ferroelectric thin films, and the enhanced flexoelectricity poses great potential in nanoscale devices.
655	<strong>Magnetoresistance in CoFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>/BiFeO<sub>3</sub> Core-Shell Nanoparticles Near Room Temperature</strong>	A systematic study of near room temperature magnetoresistance (MR) behavior is carried out for CoFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>-BiFeO<sub>3</sub> core-shell nanoparticles, which in an earlier study were found to be magnetoelectric active [J. Appl. Phys. 123, 064101 (2018)]. The analysis of MR data reveals that the MR is guided by anisotropic magnetoresistance (AMR) and giant magnetoresistance (GMR) effect. GMR effect is predominant in sample having maximum shell thickness whereas; the AMR effect dominates the least shell thickness and bare CoFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>. Analysis of the MR data in conjunction with the resistivity, suggests that the electrical conduction in these samples is due (a) tunneling and (b) hopping of electron across the domains. The impedance and modulus spectra analysis shows that the core-shell particles as a whole is participating in the relaxation process, thus indicating a strong coupling between the core and shell, which may be highly desirable while fetching its magnetoelectric based applications.
656	Bismuth Ferrites/MXene Nanocomposites for Efficient Dye Degradation	Our work proposes a nanohybrid system of Bismuth ferrite nanoparticles with two-dimensional (2D) MXene sheets namely, the BiFeO3 (BFO)/Ti3C2 (MXene) nanohybrid for enhanced photocatalytic activity. We have fabricated the BFO/MXene nanohybrid using hydrothermal method. The SEM and TEM images show that the BFO nanoparticles were attached onto the MXene surface and in the inter-layers of two-dimensional (2D) MXene sheets. The photocatalytic application is tested for the visible light irradiation which showed the highest efficiency among all pure-BFO based photocatalysts, i.e. 100% degradation in 42 min for colored organic dye (Congo red) and colorless organic dye (acetophenone) in 140 min, respectively.
657	<strong>Amorphous aluminum-oxide supercapacitors</strong>	<strong>An amorphous</strong><strong> aluminum</strong><strong>-oxide device could store a large amount of electric charge on its blackish, uneven Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3-x</sub> surface, which had a convexity of 21 nm, a concavity of 10 nm, AlO<sub>6</sub> clusters, and a high resistivity of 16.5 G&Omega;cm. The electric storage can be elucidated by extreme enhanced electron trapping resulting from both the quantum-size effect and the offset effect from positive charges at oxygen-vacancy sites. Here, a supercapacitor, which is characterised by </strong><strong>high surface area of ~</strong><strong>2,400 m<sup>2</sup>/g and formation of large numbers of electric double layers, demonstrated a vertical line in the Nyquist diagram and rapidly increased the imaginary impedance and phase angle was deduced to </strong><strong>&minus;</strong><strong>90&deg; with decreasing frequency in the Bode diagram using a distributed constant-electric circuit with a parallel assembly of</strong><strong> nanometer</strong><strong>-sized capacitors on a highly insulating amorphous</strong><strong> aluminum</strong><strong> surface. The supercapacitor indicated a </strong><strong><strong>switching effect for both positive (~+66 V) and negative (~&minus;11 V) potential. <strong>The mechanism can be interpreted by the &ldquo;quantum petal effect&rdquo; and the &ldquo;quantum anti-petal effect&rdquo;, respectively.</strong></strong></strong>
658	<strong>METAL-MATRIX COMPOSITES REINFORCED BY FULLERENES</strong>	In this work we present a new technological approach to obtain anti-friction dispersion-hardened by nanoparticles materials based on of TiC &ndash; AlC &ndash; and FeC with inclusions of the C<sub>n0</sub> (n=6 or 7) phases alloys with high heat resistance, strength and durability for use in aircraft and rocket technology. Mixtures of elemental powders of Al&ndash;Ti&ndash;&#x0421; and Fe&ndash;Ti&ndash;&#x0421; systems are used as base objects for development of new composite materials by high voltage electric discharge treatment in kerosene (dispersion, activation and synthesis). These systems as shown micro-Raman data contain refractory components (fullerenes, carbides), MAX-phases of Ti-Al-C system with increasing thermo-stability, strength and wear resistance while maintaining ductility how can it be predicted.
659	A laboratory X-ray microscopy study of cracks in on-chip interconnect stacks of integrated circuits	Laboratory transmission X-ray microscopy (TXM) with a spatial resolution of about 100 nm was used to image 3D interconnect structures and failures in microchips during mechanical loading, applied by a novel micro double cantilever beam (micro-DCB) test. High-resolution 3D image sequences based on nano X-ray computed tomography (nano-XCT) are used to visualize crack opening and propagation in fully integrated multilevel on-chip interconnect structures of integrated circuits. The non-destructive investigation of sub-micron cracks during the in-situ micro-DCB test allows to identify the weakest layers and interfaces, delamination along Cu/dielectrics interfaces (adhesive failure) and fracture in dielectrics (cohesive failure), as well as to evaluate the robustness of Backend-of-Line (BEoL) stacks against process-induced thermomechanical stress.
660	<strong>High thermal conductivity and superior thermal Stability of amorphous PMDA/ODA nanofiber</strong>	The applications of polymers and their nanocomposites for thermal dissipation/management are limited by their low thermal conductivity and inferior thermal stability due to their disordered molecular chains. In this paper, we demonstrate experimentally the high thermal conductivity in individual suspended PMDA/ODA nanofiber which is fabricated by the typical electrospinning technology. More interestingly, the PMDA/ODA nanofibers possess high temperature thermal stability up to <em>T</em>=450K, far beyond the hot spot temperature of integrated circuits. The observed high thermal conductivity and high temperature thermal stability enable PMDA/ODA nanofibers to be a potential candidate for efficient TIMs in the future applications.
661	Structural Surface Waves Properties of Amorphous-State Bi2Te3 by Pulsed Laser Deposition in Visible and Near-Infrared regions	Owing to the unique properties of evanescent field, surface waves show great applications in near field enhancement and the break of the resolution limit. In this work, we found the amorphous-state Bi2Te3 film deposited by Pulsed Laser Depositions exhibits properties of surface waves in an ultrawide waveband from visible to near-infrared regions. We analysis the surface wave in the three respects: the propagation form, localized form and the coupling with a gold nanobar. This work not only breaks the strict limit of Bi2Te3 topological insulator crystalline but also widens the wavelength region of surface waves compared with the previous report.
662	Shaping and functionalizing models for chemically powered nanomotors	Self-propelled particles are tiny machines that generate a motor force from converting locally a source of energy into directed motion. The basic phenomenon of self-propulsion has been investigated via both experiments and computational models, with a distinctive inventiveness from experimentalists in terms of motor geometries and propulsion mechanisms. We use dedicated Molecular Dynamics simulations, in which the chemical activity, thermal fluctuations, and hydrodynamics are embedded, to present a modeling strategy that is amenable to reproduce any geometry and catalytic patches for chemically powered nanomotors. We apply this method to the spherical Janus particle then to the L-shape nanomotor, showing for the first time computer simulations of circling motion as an emergent feature of the coupled solvent-colloid system.
663	Influence of anisotropic Si(111)-(4x1)-In surface on growth of nanoscale In islands	Reflectance Anisotropy Spectroscopy (RAS) and Scanning Tunneling Microspcopy (STM) are used to study the growth of In on the anisotropic Si(111)&#x2212;In(4&#x00D7;1) surface at room temperature. RAS shows that epitaxial growth of In is accompanied by the disappearance of the surface optical anisotropy at 1.9 eV which is the fingerprint for the (4x1)-In surface reconstruction and the appearance of a large minimum at 1.4 eV which is at the same energy as interband transitions observed on bulk crystalline In. Subsequent spectra taken on the surface show that this minimum decreases and eventually disappears along with the reappearance of the original RAS signature of the (4x1)-In surface. STM of this surface shows elongated, anisotropic Indium crystal islands on top of a (4x1)-In reconstructed surface. The shape of the islands is due to anisotropy in diffusion driven growth, from the underlying anisotropic (4x1) reconstruction. Upon annealing the surface to 670 K, RAS of this surface shows a large positive anisotropy at about 1.5 eV with STM showing regions covered with a phase that resembles the (&#x221A;7x&#x221A;3)-In reconstruction. The epitaxial Indium islands now show a tetragonal shape, unlike on the (4x1) surface structure. Thus the growth morphology of the islands is shown to be dependent on the initial surface reconstruction. We attribute these findings to Ostwald ripening of the Indium islands mediated by In diffusion which is dependent on the structurally different In wetting layers on the Si substrate.
664	Core-Shell Super-Structures via Smart Deposition of Naphthothiadiazole and Benzodithiophene-Possessing Polymer Backbones onto Carbon Nanotubes and Photovoltaic Applications Thereof	Core-shell super-structures were developed via &#x03C0;-stacking of poly[benzodithiophene-bis(decyltetradecyl-thien) naphthothiadiazole] (PBDT-DTNT) and poly[bis(triiso-propylsilylethynyl) benzodithiophene-bis(decyltetradecyl-thien) naphthobisthiadiazole] (PBDT-TIPS-DTNT-DT) as conductive shells onto carbon nanotubes (CNTs). Structure of conjugated polymers substantially determines their deposition model onto CNTs. Regioregular poly(3-hexyl thiophene) (P3HT) chains with hexyl side chains developed  delicate nanofibrils with a base attached to CNT surface. However, PBDT-DTNT and PBDT-TIPS-DTNT-DT complicated conductive polymers with fused and infused thiophenic and benzenic rings preferred to be &#x03C0;-stacked with a face-on manner onto CNT surface and fabricate shells. Grafting of CNT surface with a polythiophene such as poly(3-dodecyl thiophene) (PDDT) introduced some defects onto the shell structure; because PBDT-DTNT and PBDT-TIPS-DTNT-DT polymers were not able to be &#x03C0;-deposited onto CNT surface grafted with PDDT. The PDDT grafts were considered as hindrances against the stacking of complicated polymers. The thickness of PBDT-DTNT and PBDT-TIPS-DTNT-DT shells ranged in 10&#xF02D;12 and 5&#xF02D;8 nm, respectively. Higher hindrance of TIPS side structures in PBDT-TIPS-DTNT-DT chains reflected thinner shells. By developing core-shells based on PBDT-TIPS-DTNT-DT and PBDT-DTNT, the conductivity reached 10.11 and 12.15 S/cm, respectively. Donor-acceptor core-shell nano-hybrids were then applied in active layer of photovoltaics. Efficiencies for CNT (core)-PBDT-DTNT (shell) and CNT (core)-PBDT-TIPS-DTNT-DT (shell) were 4.07 and 2.34%, respectively.
665	Dynamic and Photonic Phenomena in GaN/Si Nanowire Ensemble	Optical phenomena in high-quality GaN nanowires (NWs) ensemble grown on Si substrate have been studied by reflectance and time-resolved luminescence. Such nanowires form a structure that acts as a virtual layer that specifically reflects and polarizes light and can be characterized by an effective refractive index. In fact we have found that the NW ensembles of high NW density (high filling fraction) behave rather like a layer of effective medium described by Maxwell Garnett approximation. Moreover, light extinction and strong depolarization are observed that we assign to scattering and interference of light inside the NW ensemble. The wavelength range of high extinction and depolarization correlates well with transverse localization wavelength estimated for such ensemble of NWs, so we suppose that these effects are due to Anderson localization of light.<br />We also report results of time-resolved measurements of polarization of individual emission centers including free and bound excitons (D<sup>0</sup>X<sub>A</sub> , 3.47 eV), inversion domain boundaries (IDB, 3.45eV) and stacking faults (SF, 3.42 eV). The emission of the D<sup>0</sup>X<sub>A</sub> and SF lines is polarized perpendicular to GaN c-axis while the 3.45 eV line is polarized along the c-axis what supports hypothesis that this line is emitted from IDBs. Time-dependent depolarization of luminescence is observed during the first 0.1 ns after excitation and is interpreted as the result of interaction of the emission centers with hot particles existing during short time after excitation.
666	Persistent Photoconductivity Without Photoconductivity in Nanocrystalline Germanium/Amorphous Silicon Composite Thin Films	A light-induced increase in the dark conductivity is observed in composite thin films consisting of hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) containing nanocrystalline germanium (nc-Ge) inclusions, synthesized by co-deposition in a dual-chamber plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition system. Unlike the Staebler-Wronski effect or persistent photoconductivity observed in amorphous semiconductors, the composite nc-Ge/a-Si:H films exhibiting this photo-induced excess conductivity have a minimal photosensitivity. The decay of the excess conductivity follows a simple exponential time dependence, with a temperature independent time constant, suggesting that tunneling through the germanium nanocrystalline inclusions is involved in the removal of this effect.
667	Optimum Conditions for Ultra-Low Power Light Emission via Avalanche Breakdown in Suspended Carbon Nanotubes	We explore near infrared light emission in suspended carbon nanotube field effect transistors (FETs) over a wide range of gate and bias voltages. In particular, we study the minimum bias voltage required to reach the light detection limit of our experimental setup as a function of the applied gate voltage. Here, we find that there is a relatively small region over which low power (~nW) avalanche emission is observed. By plotting the relative luminescence efficiency (i.e., light intensity/electrical power) as a function of the gate and bias voltages, we observe a very sharp feature over which the electroluminescence efficiency is 2-3 orders of magnitude higher that under all other conditions corresponding to avalanche emission. A steep increase in current with bias voltage (i.e., large dI/dVb), which signifies the onset of the avalanche process, is observed at the same gate and bias conditions of the highly efficient electroluminescence. We believe that these results demonstrate new mechanistic evidence for achieving highly efficient light emission in carbon nanotubes via avalanche breakdown.
668	Laser-induced electron emission from Au nanowires: a probe for longitudinal polarization	Photoelectron field emission, induced by femtosecond laser pulses focused on metallic nanotips, provides spatially coherent and temporally short electron pulses. <br />Properties of the photoelectron yield give insight into both the material properties of the nanostructure and the exciting laser focus.<br />Ultralong nanoribbons, grown as a single crystal attached to a metallic taper, are novel sources of electron field emission.<br />In this report, photoemission from gold nanoribbon samples is studied and compared to emission from tungsten and gold tips. <br />We observe that the emission from sharp tips generally depends on one transverse component of the exciting laser field, while the emission of a blunted nanoribbon is found to be sensitive to<br />both components. <br />We propose this property makes photoemission from nanoribbons a candidate for a novel position-sensitive detector for longitudinal field components in a tightly focused beam.
669	Guided ionization waves: the physics of repeatability	Guided ionization waves, or plasma streamers are increasingly important for many applications spanning materials processing and biomedicine. The highly-reproducible, repeatable behavior of the most puzzling kind of the streamers - plasma bullets is highly attractive as it promises a high degree of control in many applications. However, despite a dozen years since the discovery of this phenomenon, the exact reasons for such behavior still remain essentially unclear. To understand the dynamics of the guided ionization wave (plasma bullet), a large number of works has been carried out and many interesting results have been reported. Here we critically examine the available results, and generalize the physical mechanisms of the guided ionization waves, which are of particular interest to practical applications of atmospheric-pressure plasma discharges in general. The critical examination of the fundamental principles will show that, in order to propagate in a repeatable-mode, the plasma bullet must propagate in a channel with a high seed electron density (HSED), which is on the order of 109 cm-3. This review concludes that to distinguish guided ionization waves from traditional positive streamer discharges, it is most appropriate to describe an atmospheric-pressure discharge featuring a plasma bullet behavior as an HSED discharge. When the HSED condition is met, the dynamics of a plasma plume appears to be repeatable. On the country, it propagates in an unrepeatable mode and emerges more like a positive streamer discharge when the HSED condition is not satisfied. According to this theory, the transition of the propagation mode of the plasma bullet between the repeatable mode and the stochastic mode can be well explained. Besides, by controlling the seed electron density around the transition region between the HSED discharge and the traditional positive streamer, this knowledge will help better understanding of the positive streamer discharges in air, in cases relevant to practical applications of such plasma discharges in materials processing technologies, industrial chemistry, nanotechnology and health care.
670	Numerical simulation of magnetohydrodynamic  Jeffrey nanofluid flow and heat transfer over a stretching  sheet  considering Joule heating and viscous dissipation	The purpose of  the present study is to examine numerically the impact  of silver, titanium oxide and alumina nanoparticles on the steady 2D magnetohydrodynamic boundary layer  flow  and heat  transfer  of Jeffrey fluid  over a  stretching sheet  with Joule heating and viscous dissipation. The governing non-linear  partial differential  equations (PDEs) are reduced to the non-linear ordinary differential equations (ODEs) by using  appropriate dimensionless variables and then solved numerically by using Keller-box technique. The impacts of nanoparticle volume fraction,  magnetic parameter, Deborah number,  Prandtl number and Eckert number  on the velocity  and temperature profiles, local Nusselt number and skin friction drag coefficients are investigated with the assistance of graphs and tables. Results indicate that the  velocity, skin friction and local Nusselt number for the  silver-water nanofluid are comparatively less than those of the base fluid, however the temperature is enhanced through the inclusion of nanoparticles.  It is found  that both the skin friction and the Nusselt number increase by increasing the  Deborah number whereas they decrease by increasing the magnetic parameter.
671	<strong>Ultrathin amorphous ZnGe<sub>x</sub>SnO films for high performance ultra-thin-film transistors</strong>	Ultrathin amorphous ZnSnO (<em>a</em>-ZTO) films and ultrathin amorphous ZnGeSnO (<em>a</em>-ZGTO) films with various Ge contents were deposited by pulsed laser deposition for ultra-thin-film transistors (UTFTs). The thicknesses of the channel layers are approximately 3.2 nm. The properties of these ultrathin films and behaviors of these UTFTs were comparatively studied in detail. The <em>a</em>-ZTO ultrathin film exhibited a low concentration of oxygen vacancy (V<sub>O</sub>) compared to <em>a</em>-ZGTO ultrathin films. Among all the UTFTs, the <em>a</em>-ZTO UTFT demonstrated the undoubtedly best performance with an on/off current ratio of more than 10<sup>7</sup>, the largest filed-effect mobility of 23.2 cm<sup>2</sup>V<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>, a positive threshold voltage of 2.0 V, a very small subthreshold swing of 0.31 V/decade and the best long-term stability under bias stress, suggesting the introduction of V<sub>O</sub> suppressors is dispensable with such a small thickness. Above all, the concentration of oxygen vacancy is easily controlled in the ultrathin <em>a</em>-ZTO nanofilms, leading to the UTFTs operating in the enhancement mode with high field-effect mobility of 23.2 cm<sup>2</sup>V<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup> and excellent long-term stability. The <em>a</em>-ZTO ultrathin film and ultra-thin-film transistor are very potential for future electrical applications with their novel properties.
672	<strong>Energetic nanocomposites: Review on Metal based Nanothermites </strong>	A brief review on metal based nanothermites is presented in this paper for better understanding on exothermic behavior of nanoenergetic composites. Nanoenergetic composites are extensively young and interesting field in energetic materials because of their high reactivity and very low ignition temperatures. Metal based thermites have a huge range of applications theoretically which are yet to be approached practically. A better understanding in their characterization is required to continue the work; this paper presents the methods and parameters affecting the performance of nanoenergetic composites. Results of various studies on affecting parameters including particle size and passivation methods are also been presented and compared to give a clear understanding to the readers. A qualitative review has been reported here from synthesis of the composites to their initiation methods which help the researchers in further approach on nanothermites.
673	Explicit screening full band quantum transport model for semiconductor nanodevices	State of the art quantum transport models for semiconductor nanodevices attribute negative (positive) unit charges to states of the conduction (valence) band. Hybrid states that enable band-to-band tunneling are subject to interpolation that yield model dependent charge contributions. In any nanodevice structure, these models rely on device and physics specific input for the dielectric constants. This paper exemplifies the large variability of different charge interpretation models when applied to ultrathin body transistor performance predictions. To solve this modeling challenge, an electron-only band structure model is extended to atomistic quantum transport. Performance predictions of MOSFETs and tunneling FETs confirm the generality of the new model and its independence of additional screening models.
674	<strong>Formation of self-assembled lipid bilayer on CVD-grown MoS<sub>2</sub></strong>	Two-dimensional (2D) materials have been studied vigorously due to their outstanding mechanical, optical, and electrical properties. Among 2D materials, transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have recently been spotlighted as the channel material of the field-effect transistor, which has been used for various applications. Many studies demonstrated applications in biological areas using MoS<sub>2</sub> as a TMD because of its sensitivity and stability. In this study, we built a fundamental bioelectronic platform with a lipid bilayer spread over large-area MoS<sub>2</sub> films via surface treatment. Firstly, we synthesized MoS<sub>2</sub> film on a sapphire substrate via a chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method. To form a stable lipid bilayer on the MoS<sub>2 </sub>film, the surface was treated with O<sub>2</sub> plasma, changing it from a hydrophobic to a hydrophilic surface. We performed surface characterization of the plasma-treated MoS<sub>2</sub> film with contact angle measurement and Raman spectroscopy. X-ray photoelectrons spectroscopy (XPS) characterizations were used for identification of the chemical states of elements before and after plasma surface modification. Moreover, we studied the physical properties of the lipid hybrid structure using fluorescence measurement and the fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) test. Finally, we fabricated an electronic device with an MoS<sub>2</sub>-lipid bilayer hybrid structure and confirmed its sensing capability. Two-dimensional assembly of lipids and nanomaterials provides a platform for biosensing and bioelectronics applications.
675	Direct measurement of the optical shear angle of Nomarski prism beyond the diffraction limit	We propose and demonstrate a direct method to precisely characterize the Nomarski prism giving spatial resolution of the optical shear angle below 0.5 &mu;rad.  The method is demonstrated in a series of Nikon Nomarski prisms used as the key component of the differential interference contrast microscope module. With the application of the localization analysis at nanoscale, we accurately determine the central positions of highly overlapped intensity spots with orthogonal polarizations and we show that the achieved resolution of the shear angles of the measured prisms is beyond the diffraction limit.
676	Thermal effects on current-related skyrmion formation in a nanobelt	We report an <em>in-situ</em> Lorentz transmission electron microscopy (LTEM) investigation to study the thermal effect on the generation of magnetic skyrmions within a nanobelt. Under an action of a moderate current pulse, magnetic skyrmions appear even at temperature range far below the critical temperature. Finite element simulation reveals that the Joule heating plays a key role in this behavior. Our results also uncovers the importance of the cooling conditions in the current-related <em>in situ</em> LTEM research.
677	Correlation of Structure with UV-visible Spectra by Varying SH Composition in Au-SH Nanoclusters	Structure and optoelectronic properties of thio protected Au (Au$_n$SR$_m$) nanoclusters are very important due to their extensive applications in various fields. To avoid the extensive computations, we model the artificial neural network (ANN) potentials for Au$_n$SR$_m$ nanoclusters in the range of $n$ = 10  to $n$ = 38 with accuracy of DFT. The modelled ANN potential is utilised to run extensive molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. The accuracy of ANN potential is tested by comparing global minimum (GM) structures of Au$_n$SR$_m$ nanoclusters at saturated amount of SH (experimentally and theoretically reported) composition. The GM structures are reported for the first time at lower SH compositions. We have studied the fluxional behaviour of Au$_n$SR$_m$ nanoclusters based on the probability study at 400 K by varying SH composition. The probability study indicates that Au$_n$SR$_m$ nanoclusters shows fluxional behaviour at lower SH compositions and hence their properties can be represented by ensemble of low-lying structures. Further, we correlate the structures of Au$_n$SR$_m$ nanoclusters with UV-visible spectra based on TDDFT calculations. The UV-visible spectral analysis revealed that significant spectroscopic features are observed at different SH compositions. This study provides the fundamental understanding of structural morphological changes and trends in optoelectronic properties with decreasing SH compositions and with increasing size of nanocluster.
678	Model of dielectric breakdown in hafnia-based ferroelectric capacitors	Ultra-thin ferroelectric hafnia-based thin film is a very promising candidate for nanoscale ferroelectric random access memories, but dielectric breakdown has been a main failure mechanism during repeated polarization switching. We generalized Lou <em>et al.</em>&rsquo;s local phase decomposition model, originally for ferroelectric fatigue, and proposed a dielectric breakdown model for ferroelectric hafnia. Charge injection during the polarization reversal is regarded as a key step, while the eventual phase separation of Hf cluster accounts for the dielectric breakdown. Using this model, we explained why TaN/HfO<sub>2</sub>/TaN ferroelectric capacitor is more prone to dielectric breakdown than TiN/HfO<sub>2</sub>/TiN, and concluded that the lower Schottky barrier for the TaN/<em>Pca</em>2<sub>1</sub>-HfO<sub>2</sub> interface stabilizes the neutral oxygen vacancies within the dielectric. On the other hand, with TiN electrodes the oxygen vacancies tend to be positively charged, which can pin the domain walls to cause ferroelectric fatigue. The relation between conductive filament formation, dielectric breakdown, wake up and fatigue in ferroelectric HfO<sub>2</sub> are discussed within our model framework.
679	Seebeck coe;cient of AuGe thin films for thermoelectric applications inorganic nanoscale devices	We experimentally study the thermoelectric properties of an AuxGe1-x thin film alloy close to the metal-insulator transition. The thermoelectric characterization of the thin film alloy reveals a Seebeck coe;fficient comparable to that of Au thin film while preserving good thermal sensor electrical properties, revealing the interest to use it for thermoelectric applications in organic nanoscale devices where it can fulll the double role of in-situ local heater and high resolution thermometer.
680	<strong><em>Facile synthesis and Characterization of undoped, Mn doped and Nd co-doped CuO nanoparticles for optoelectronic and magnetic applications</em></strong>	Copper oxide (CuO) nanoparticles were prepared by sol-gel method, doped with Manganese (Mn) and co-doped with Neodymium (Nd) elements. The properties of synthesized nanoparticles were examined by XRD, SEM/EDX, FT-IR, DR spectroscopy, photoluminescence spectroscopy, Hall effect measurement using two probe method and vibrating sample magnetometry for magnetic studies. Structural studies using XRD indicate the presence of a monoclinic structure of CuO for all the prepared samples with no other impurity phases detected. The images from scanning electron microscope have revealed that the grains are clusters structure. FTIR results of prepared CuO nanostructures support the monoclinic structure of CuO as in the case of XRD result. Using Tauc relation, the optical band gap is found to be 1.77eV for undoped CuO nanostructures, and is decreased to1.73 eV for Mn and1.71eV for the Nd co-doping. This decrease in the optical band gap on doping may be attributed to the fact that the impurity band merges with the conduction band of CuO. Hall measurements reveal that the conductivity of the sample increases for the doping of Mn and Nd co-doping. The magnetic studies using VSM show that the prepared nanostructures are found to have a maximum value of saturation magnetization at 3 wt% for Mn, Nd co-doped CuO, (i.e.) 0.07 emu/g.
681	Wavevector and Polarization Resolved Analysis of Phonon Scattering from Embedded Nanoparticles	Embedded nanocrystals are capable of dramatically reducing the thermal conductivity of alloy semiconductors through increased phonon scattering, but many aspects of thermal wavelength phonon interactions with embedded nanoparticles remain understudied.  Here, the wavevector- and polarization-resolved capabilities of the Frequency Domain Perfectly Matched Layer (FDPML) computational technique are exploited to study several fundamentally important phonon scattering problems across the entire Brillouin zone.  We compare the atomistic predictions of FDPML against continuum mechanics approaches for spherically embedded particles.  For long to mid wavelength phonons, reasonable agreement is found with continuum theories that consider the Mie regime accurately, while commonly used `patching' theories which empirically connect the Rayleigh scattering to the geometric limit are shown to have poor agreement with more rigorous approaches.  Next, the scattering cross section of optical phonons from nanoparticles is explored for the first time.  We show that scattering behavior of optical phonons is fundamentally different than their acoustic counterparts in that long wavelength optical phonons exhibit a scattering cross section nearly independent of wavelength, which we interpret as being due to zone folding of short wavelength acoustic modes from the geometric scattering regime into long wavelength optical modes. Finally, we study the scattering cross section of nanoparticles exhibiting atomic interdiffusion at the matrix-particle interface, where we find that interdiffusion both suppressed Mie oscillations and substantially increases the scattering cross section at short wavelength, compared to a solid nanoparticle with the same number of impurity atoms.
682	Ultrahigh refractive index sensitivity via lattice-induced meta-dipole modes in flat metallic nanoantenna arrays	We investigate control of plasmonic-photonic coupling in flat metallic nanoantenna arrays. We demonstrate that when the nanoantennas are packed together along their short axes (transverse lattice constant) and the incident light polarization is along their long axes, they can support lattice-induced plasmonic resonance coupled to a super-photonic mode that densely fills the superstrate. At a certain wavelength this resonance joins the plasmonic tip modes of the nanoantennas, forming meta-dipole modes. These modes have field profiles similar to those of the normal plasmonic dipole modes of individual nanoantennas but they occur at much shorter wavelengths and offer a very high bulk refractive index sensitivity (912 nm/RIU). We show that with increase of the transverse lattice constant such a sensitivity decreases as the meta-dipole modes disappear. Under this condition, the refractive index sensitivity supported by normal modes of the nanoantennas increases, as the plasmonic edge mode suppression caused by charge rearrangement decreases.
683	Effect of growth interruption in 1.55 &mu;m InAs/InAlGaAs quantum dots on InP grown by molecular beam epitaxy	<strong><strong>We report the effect of growth interruptions on the structural and optical properties of InAs/InAlGaAs/InP quantum dots using molecular beam epitaxy. Growth interruption after InAs quantum dot deposition red-shifted photoluminescence wavelength peak from 1.58 &mu;m to 1.78 &mu;m, while the morphology of the uncapped InAs quantum dots remained unchanged. We find that the surface quantum dots experience unintended ripening process during the sample cooling stage, and this reshaped the uncapped InAs nanostructures. Partial capping effectively inhibited structural reconfiguration of surface InAs nanostructures during cooling stage and revealed evolution of InAs/InAlGaAs quantum dashes to quantum dots as the growth interruption time increased. Transmission electron microscope studies confirmed the presence of quantum dashes in a sample without growth interruption while atomic force microscope measurements showed quantum dots on the surface.</strong></strong>
684	Dynamic multiple-scattering treatment of X-ray absorption: Parametrization of a new classical force field for Myoglobin	We present a detailed analysis of the XANES data on the Fe K-edge of CO Myoglobin based on a combined procedure of Molecular Dynamics (MD) calculations and MXAN data analysis that we call D-MXAN. The ability of performing quantitative XANES data analysis allows us to refine classical force field MD parameters, thus obtaining a reliable tool for the atomic investigation of this important model system for biological macromolecules. The iterative procedure here applied corrects the greatest part of the structural discrepancy between classical MD sampling and experimental determinations. Our procedure, moreover, is able to discriminate between different heme conformational basins visited during the MD simulation, thus demonstrating the necessity of a sampling in the order of tens of nanoseconds, even for applications such XAS data analysis.
685	Comprehensive Dependence of Triboelectric Nanogenerator on Dielectric Thickness and External Impact for High Electric Outputs	Triboelectric nanogenerators (TENGs) have aroused extensive interests in recent years, and their energy conversion efficiency increased gradually under massive efforts. Applied force and dielectric thickness are two important factors account for high output performance. Nevertheless, for the most commonly used TENGs in contact-separation mode, the comprehensive dependence of dielectric thickness and impact force are still expected to be further deeply researched and optimized. Hence, we fabricated a nylon-PTFE TENG (NP-TENG) in contact-separation mode and explored the dual influence of dielectric thickness and applied force on the output performance. Results indicate that the dielectric thickness and impact force have comprehensive influence on the outputs, which is due to the dual effect of charge transport properties and the deformation at different thicknesses. Mostly, the optimum thickness concentrates at 0.5 mm, and it increases under a gradually increase of impact force but stays steadily with varying of fabric count. With the continuous enlargement of impact force, the dielectric thickness reaches a boundary limitation of 0.8 mm. This work contributes greatly not only to the design and optimization of TENG devices, but also to the deeper understanding of the nano-triboelectric effect mechanism.
686	<strong>Fabrication of Single-Electron Transistors with Electromigrated Ni Nanogaps</strong>	We analyze single-electron transistors (SETs) fabricated with electromigrated Ni nanogaps using the Korotkov and Nazarov (KN) model. First, we investigate nanogap-based SETs consisting of multiple Ni islands placed between the source and drain electrodes by a field-emission induced electromigration technique known as &lsquo;activation.&rsquo; After the activation procedure is performed using a preset current <em>I</em><sub>s</sub> of 3 &mu;A, the drain current-drain voltage characteristics of SETs with single-island structures are obtained and analyzed by using the KN model and considering the offset charges on the islands. We determine the equivalent circuit parameters from the electrical properties of the SETs. The parameters can be explained using the geometrical structures of the SETs that are observed in both scanning electron and atomic force microscopy images after the activation procedure. This approach allows the electrical and structural properties of the single-island structures of the SETs fabricated using the activation method to be determined.
687	Spectroscopic Studies of Laser produced plasma of doped nano-structured material by Laser Induced Breakdown Spectroscopy	We present the qualitative and quantitative use of laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) for the compositional characterization of doped material of Zinc (Zn) & tin (Sn) nanoparticles. The transition metal Zinc doped tin nanoparticles were synthesized via co-precepitation and hydrothermal routes. A single laser operating at wavelengths around 532 nm is used to produce ablated plasma. The detailed analysis of emission spectrum of ablated plasma reveal qualitative information which can be correlated with identification of target material. The Boltzmann plot, standard two line and Saha-Boltzmann plot methods were used to determine the plasma temperature of nanoparticles while stark broadening method and  Saha-Boltzmann equation were used to estimate electron number density of ablated plasma. Calibration free (CF-LIBS), one line calibration free (OLCF) and Calibration curve  (CC-LIBS) approaches have been used  for quantitative analysis of doped nano-structured materials with low and high concentrations. In CF-LIBS and OLCF-LIBS, quantitative analysis of sample are carried out using Boltzmann plots & Saha Boltzman equations, respectively  while in calibration based LIBS , quantitative results based on calibration curves were obtained and limits of detection of nanoparticles were also determined using these calibration curves.  Quantitative results estimated from calibration free and Calibration based approaches were compared and validated with results from standard techniques such as Laser Ablation Time of fllight (LA-TOF) spectroscopy and EDX . The present work establishes LIBS as an effective analytical tool for qualitative and quantitative estimation of the doped nanomaterials from atomic emission spectra.
688	<strong>Simulation of Nanofluid Natural Convection in a U-Shaped Cavity Equipped by a Heating Obstacle: Effect of Cavity's Aspect Ratio</strong>	Research on nanofluid for heat transfer enhancement of thermal systems has received great attention owing to the lack of energy sources. In this study, fluid flow and natural convection heat transfer of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-Water or TiO<sub>2</sub>-water nanofluid inside a U-shaped cavity consist of a hot obstacle has been investigated numerically by lattice Boltzmann method (LBM). In this paper, different parameters are investigated such as Rayleigh number, the solid volume fraction of the nanoparticles, the U-shaped cavity's aspect ratio and heating obstacle's height on the flow field and heat transfer in the enclosure. The results showed that the Rayleigh number (Ra), cavity aspect ratio (AR) and obstacle's height can be affected on isotherms, streamlines and local and average Nusselt number. The average Nusselt number of the obstacle sides increased by increasing the <em>Ra</em> number and solid volume fraction of nanoparticles (&phi;) regardless the AR. In addition, by increasing the AR, the average Nusselt number increased. At low Ra, the effect of nanoparticles on enhancement of heat transfer for narrow cavities was more than that for wide ones.
689	<strong>Ultralight and Ultraelastic Sponge/Al@Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>Nanocomposite with Tunable Electromagnetic Properties</strong>	Electromagnetic absorption/shielding materials are highly desirable for high-rapidly developing microelectronic devices. However, it is still lack for a specific material with dynamic tunable properties to solve issues in complex environments. We herein report a hybrid composite consisting of three-dimensional porous melamine sponge and core@shell Al@Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles, possessing multiple merits of low density (12.47 mg/cm<sup>3</sup>) and high elasticity. By compressing/decompressing the hybrid, the electromagnetic performances can be reversibly tuned between 18-26.5 GHz, ascribed to the tunable conductivity raised from the three-dimensional continuous conductive paths. The present work provides a concept for the design of &ldquo;dynamic&rdquo; electromagnetic materials.
690	Bending deformation behavior of Zr65Cu17.5Ni10Al7.5 bulk metallic glass with different solidification cooling rate	In order to further clarify the relationship between the free volume and bending plasticity, the bending properties of Zr65Cu17.5Ni10Al7.5 bulk metallic glass (BMG) samples with different thicknesses corresponding to different solidification cooling rates were investigated. The results show that the bending plasticity of Zr65Cu17.5Ni10Al7.5 BMG decreases with the decrease of cooling rate, which is consistent with the evolution of shear bands density revealed by the investigation of microstructure. These phenomena are mainly attributed to the decrease of free volume content with the decrease of cooling rates, although the increase of nanocrystallization fraction. These results further confirm that free volume plays an important role in the deformation process of the BMGs.
691	Control of thermal boundary resistance by increasing Ge ratio in nanocomposite with MnSi<sub>1.7</sub> and SiGe	Thermal boundary resistance (TBR) was controlled by changing the Ge ratio in MnSi<sub>1.7</sub>-based nanocomposite with SiGe to investigate effects of TBR on thermal transport. We demonstrated a continuous reduction of thermal conductivity with the Ge ratio down to 1.2 W/Km, which is less than the minimum thermal conductivity of MnSi<sub>1.7</sub>, even in granular structures: practical forms of thermoelectric (TE) technologies. The TBR between MnSi<sub>1.7</sub> and SiGe was estimated quantitatively in multilayered structures to be as high as 5.6&times;10<sup>-9</sup> m<sup>2</sup>K/W and detailed analysis suggests that 20-30% of the thermal conductivity reduction can be attributed to the TBR in granular structures. Our results shed light on the importance of controlling TBR in TE material design towards a widespread use of TE technologies, instead of utilizing rare materials or uneconomical nanostructures.
692	<strong>Ultrafast Time-Resolved Measurement of Energy Transport at the Metal-Liquid Interface</strong>	<strong>The light-matter interaction near metallic interfaces has many important applications in nanotechnology, especially when it comes to enhance the surface-to-volume ratio and to achieve high spatial energy confinement. The ultrafast time-resolved responses of photo-excited metallic structures have intensively studied using the transient transmittance spectroscopy (TAS). Here we report a new ultrafast time-resolved measurement to study photo-excited energy transport at the metal-liquid interfaces of colloidal gold nanoparticles (AuNPs). 693	Three dimensional MHD Couple stress nanofluid flow over an exponentially stretching surface with convective heat and new mass flux condition	We have discussed the three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic flow of the couple stress nanofluid with joule heating and viscous dissipation effects past an exponentially stretched surface. The analysis is performed in the presence of Brownian motion and thermophoresis with the amalgamation of convective heat condition. Here, different from previous literature, recently introduced more realistic boundary condition for nanoparticle volume fraction model i.e., zero mass flux condition has also been introduced first time for 3D couple stress nanofluid model as far as the exponential stretched surface is concerned. By applying this condition on the boundary, active control of the nanoparticle volume fraction at the boundary is eliminated. Self-similar transformations are engaged to obtain a system of ordinary differential equations with high nonlinearity from the system of boundary layer partial differential equations. An analytic solution is constructed in the form of series via Homotopy Analysis method (HAM). Numerically calculated values of Skin friction and local Nusselt number are also given with appropriate discussion. Moreover, influences of sundry parameters on velocity distribution, heat, and mass transfer rate are deliberated and depicted through graphs. Based on the obtained results, it is seen that Biot number and Hartmann number possess similar effect on temperature distribution. To authenticate our obtained results, a comparison in limiting case is also given.
