694	Gold Nanoparticles Passivated with Functionalized Alkylthiols: Simulations of Solvation in the Infinite Dilution Limit	Solvation of gold nanoparticles passivated with end group functionalized alkylthiols, namely CH<sub>3</sub>, NH<sub>2</sub> or COOH is studied in solvents of varying degrees of repulsion-dispersion and electrostatic interactions ranging from strongly polar SPC/E water to modified hybrid water models, where the Lennard-Jones contribution to the potentialsenergy is enhanced relative to SPC/E to completely non-polar, decane. The effects due to solvent reorganization around the nanoparticle as a function of the ligand and solvent chemistry are monitored using the nanoparticle-solvent pair correlation functions and tetrahedral order parameter. The solvent penetration inside the ligand shell is maximum for decane, indicating better solute-solvent interaction in decane compared to other solvents. The COOH end group functionalized nanoparticle breaks the tetrahedral structure of water molecules more as compared to other nanoparticles used in this study. The ligand reorganization and its effect on solvation are monitored using radial density profiles (RDPs), radius of gyration (R<sub>g</sub>) and ligand asymmetry parameter (&#x0394;). RDP and R<sub>g</sub> values show significant stretching of ligands in decane than in model waters, which is also consistent with &#x0394;. The ligand shell anisotropy for all nanoparticles is maximum in SPC/E water and minimum in decane. The isotropic potential of mean force (VPMF (r)) between two identical end group functionalized nanoparticles have been calculated in vacuum, SPC/E water and H3.00 modified hybrid water, which consistently shows attractive well depth.sDistance-dependent fluctuation driven anisotropy has also been examined. The implications for self-assembly of passivated gold nanoparticles from aqueous dispersions as well as the dependence of calculated quantities on ligand and solvent chemistry are highlighted.
695	Spectral Quasi-Linearization for analysis of Non-Newtonian nanofluid flow over a horizontal surface imbeddedin a non-Darcy porous medium with convective boundary condition	The boundary layer nanofluid flow over a horizontal plate imbedded<br />in a non-Darcy porous medium is investigated in this study.<br />Non-Newtonian power-law fluid is considered as the base fluid. The<br />nanofluid model incorporated the effects of Brownian motion and<br />thermophoresis. A mixed convective boundary condition which is more<br />useful in practise, is employed at the surface instead of Dirichlet<br />or Neumann boundary conditions. The flow and convective heat<br />transfer has engineering and industrial applications such as the<br />thermal design of industrial equipment dealing with molten plastics<br />and polymeric liquids; and applications in nuclear plants and<br />thermal energy storage processes. The main aim of this study is to<br />use the spectral quasi-linearization method to study the effects of<br />non-Newtonian nanofluid flow over a horizontal surface for porous<br />medium. The objective is to explore both the accuracy and the<br />convergence of the method through the evaluation of residual errors<br />and error norms and to investigate the impact of specific parameters<br />on the flow behavior and heat transfer characteristics.
696	<strong>Standard and Inverse Microscale Chladni Figures in Liquid</strong>	<strong>We report on the first experimental demonstrations of standard and inverse Chladni figures at <em>sub-100&micro;m scale</em> in both one- (1D) and two-dimensional (2D) fashions in liquid.  Silica microbeads (1&ndash;8&micro;m in diameter) dispersed on top of resonating doubly-clamped beams (100&times;10&times;0.4&micro;m<sup>3</sup>) are observed to aggregate at <em>antinodal</em> points, forming 1D <em>inverse</em> Chladni figures, while microbeads atop square trampoline resonators (50&times;50&times;0.2&micro;m<sup>3</sup>) cluster at <em>nodal</em> lines/circles, creating 2D <em>standard</em> Chladni figures, such as </strong><strong>&lsquo;+</strong><strong>&rsquo;, &lsquo;o&rsquo;, &lsquo;&times;&rsquo;, &lsquo;\&rsquo;, </strong><strong>manifesting the multimode resonances.</strong><strong>  These observations suggest two distinct Micro-Chladni figure patterning mechanisms in liquid.  Combining analytical and computational modeling, we elucidate that streaming flow dominates the <em>inverse</em> Chladni pattern formation in the 1D beam experiments, while the vibrational acceleration dictates the <em>standard</em> Chladni figure generation in the 2D trampoline experiments.  We further demonstrate dynamical patterning, switching, and removal of 2D micro-Chladni figures in rapid succession by simply controlling the excitation frequency.  Our results render better understandings of Chladni patterning at the microscale, and may facilitate fast, non-invasive and versatile manipulation and patterning of micro/nanoscale biological objects (<em>e.g.</em>, cells), toward relevant biosensing and biophysical applications.  </strong>
697	Thermoelectric properties of graphene nanoribbons with roughness surface	By means of nonequilibrium Green&rsquo;s function method, we theoretically investigate the ballistic thermoelectric performance of graphene nanoribbons with roughness surface. The results show that the roughness surface could dramatically reduce the thermal conductance of graphene nanoribbons, and thus leading to the boosting of thermoelectric performance of graphene (the figure of merit can be as high as 3.7 at room temperature). Meanwhile, the electron transport properties of different edged rough graphene nanoribbons exhibit distinctive anisotropic behaviors, i.e., the thermal power of armchair edged is significantly increased while that of zigzag edged is nearly unchanged, which is mainly contributed to the edge effect. The findings presented in this paper qualify roughness surface as an efficient approach to enhance the thermoelectric performance of graphene nanoribbons.
698	<strong>Hybrid Photo-Magnetic Modulation of Magnetite/Gold Nanoparticle Deposited Dextran Covered Carbon Nanotubes for Hyperthermia Applications</strong>	The hybrid photo-magnetic (PMA) stimulation effect was characterized on magnetite (Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>) and gold (Au) nanoparticle (NP) decorated dextran covered carbon nanotube (CNT) structures (DIGCNTs). The observed PMA response was stronger compared to the stand-alone magnetic and photo-thermal effects; additionally the hybrid irradiation produced a temperature elevation of &gt;20&ordm;C at a DIGCNT concentration of only 50<em>&micro;</em>g/mL. The designed nano-structures did not launch any apoptotic machinery of the neural cell model up to a concentration of 200<em>&micro;g</em>/mL; however severely affected the viability of tumor suppressor protein p53 deficient NE-4C cells in culture when activated by the PMA stimulation at a concentration as low as 50<em>&micro;g</em>/mL. The intensity of this hybrid irradiation inducing significant cell apoptosis by hyperthermic ablation, but not through the innate toxicity of the nanostructures was found to be significantly less than the reported values for magnetic, optical, or radiofrequency (RF) field activation for similar applications thus far. Acute toxicity of this unique hybrid actuation-hybrid material combination, coupled with excellent base level biocompatibility, may be extremely relevant to the development of <em>in-vivo</em> PMA hyperthermia.
699	Comparison of ZnO Surface Modification with Gas-Phase Propiolic Acid at High and Medium Vacuum Conditions	Recent advances in preservation of the morphology of ZnO nanostructures during dye sensitization required the use of a two-step preparation procedure. The first step was the key for preserving ZnO materials morphology. It required exposing clean ZnO nanostructures to a gas-phase prop-2-ynoic acid (propiolic acid) acid in vacuum. This step resulted in the formation of a robust and stable surface-bound carboxylate with ethynyl groups available for further modification, for example, with click chemistry. This paper utilizes spectroscopic and microscopic investigations to answer several questions about this modification and to determine if the process can be performed under medium vacuum conditions instead of high vacuum procedures reported earlier. Comparing the results of the preparation process at medium vacuum of 0.5 Torr base pressure with the previously reported investigations of the same process in high vacuum of 10-5 Torr suggests that both processes lead to the formation of the same surface species, confirming that the proposed modification scheme can be widely applicable for ZnO sensitization procedures and does not require the use of high vacuum. Additional analysis comparing the computationally predicted surface structures with the results of spectroscopic investigations yields the more complete description of the surface species resulting from this approach.
700	<strong>Rheology Modulated Enhancement in Electrochemomechanical Energy Conversion in Soft Nanofluidic Channels</strong>	In this article, we devise a mathematical model to examine the effect of fluid rheology of viscoelastic fluids on the generation of streaming potential in a nano fluidic channel, whose walls are grafted with ion-penetrable and solvent-permeable polyelectrolyte layer (PEL) of thickness . For describing the rheology of the viscoelastic fluids, we use the simplified Phan-Thien-Tanner (sPTT) model. By invoking a few approximations in the present calculations, we obtain the velocity expressions for all sPTT models and well ahead, we report the plausible amendments in the enhancement of streaming potential, electroviscous effect and Electrochemomechanical efficiency with the changes in Debye-Huckel parameter of the electrolyte , drag constant of PEL , applied pressure gradient  and PEL thickness . The shear-dependent extra normal stresses  of the viscoelastic fluids enhances the convection of the counter-ions and generate comparatively high amount of streaming potential in the soft nanochannel, leading to more energy conversion than that obtained from the Newtonian fluid. Finally, we show that, for a given set of other parameters remaining same, the viscoelasticity of the fluid gives rise to an enhancement of 2% to 15% in the electrochemomechanical efficiency over the transport of Newtonian fluid.
701	Preparation and measurement of subwavelength bilayer metal wire grid polarizers on flexible plastic substrate	This study demonstrates fabrication of subwavelength bilayer metal wire grid polarizers and characterizes their performance. Polarizers with 278 nm period were fabricated on flexible plastic substrates by nanoimprint lithography followed by aluminum deposition. Transmission efficiency exceeding 0.55 and an extinction ratio exceeding 32 dB were achieved in the visible range when polarizer aluminum thickness is 70 nm. Using a polarization analyzer with a 6-channel sensor prototype, average error was obtained at 0.2002{degree sign}, with a maximum of 1.105{degree sign} and standard deviation of 0.7255{degree sign}. The proposed fabrication method will be suitable for many optics applications, including compound eye structure manufacture.
702	Role of Stone-Wales Defects on the Interfacial Interactions among Graphene, Carbon Nanotube, and Nylon 6: A First-Principles Study	We present results of our computational investigation on effect of Stone-Wales (SW) defect on interfacial interactions among graphene, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and Nylon 6. Our calculations were carried out using both first-principles density functional pseudopotential method, and empirical force-field. Both pristine and SW-defected carbon nanomaterials were examined in our investigation. The computed results show that the presence of SW-defects in CNTs weakens the CNT-graphene interactions. Our results that CNT-graphene interaction is much stronger than CNT-CNT interaction- indicate that graphene would be able to promote the dispersion of CNTs in the polymer matrix. Our results demonstrate that carbon nanomaterials form stable complexes with Nylon 6, and that the van der Waals interactions, as revealed by the electron density difference maps, play a key stabilizing role in the interactions between CNTs and graphene, and also between carbon nanomaterials and Nylon 6. Using density of states calculations, we observed that the band gaps of CNT and graphene were not significantly modified due to their interactions with Nylon 6.
703	Fabrication and evaluation of controllable deposition distance for aligned pattern by multi-nozzle near-field electrospinning	To mass-volume fabricate micro- and nano-scales aligned pattern, multi-nozzle near-field electrospinning (NFES) direct-writing technology is well proposed as a high-efficiency method in electrohydrodynamic (EHD) printing process. However, the interference effect among adjacent nozzles and coupling effect of various parameters have restricted to investigate deposition characteristic of multi-nozzle NFES and control EHD multi-jet deposition accuracy. In order to improve the accuracy of EHD multi-jet deposition with high-efficiency printing process, the experimental result compared with theoretical method were discussed. In this work, the influence of multi-nozzle geometry distribution and electrospinning parameters on deposition characteristic was studied with multi-nozzle NFES setup, and nozzles were in linear array. The deposition distance and homogeneity of aligned nanofibers were measured and explained with coefficient of dispersion on electric field among nozzles by simulation. Moreover, deposition distance of multi-nozzle NFES process was evaluated by modified theoretical derivation based on our previous studies. The modified theoretical derivation showed a good agreement with experiment results, and indicated that multi-nozzle NFES could accurately and efficiently direct-write aligned array pattern in future.
704	<strong>Ultrafast scanning electron microscope applied for studying the interaction between free electrons and optical near-fields of periodic nanostructures</strong>	In this paper we describe an ultrafast scanning electron microscope setup developed for the research of inelastic scattering of electrons at optical near-fields of periodic dielectric nanostructures. Electron emission from the Schottky cathode is controlled by ultraviolet femtosecond laser pulses. The electron pulse duration at the interaction site is characterized via cross-correlation of the electrons with an infrared laser pulse that excites a synchronous periodic near-field on the surface of a silicon nanostructure. The lower limit of 410 fs is found in the regime of a single electron per pulse. The role of pulse broadening due to Coulomb interaction in multielectron pulses is investigated. The setup is used to demonstrate an increase of the interaction distance between the electrons and the optical near-fields by introducing a pulse-front-tilt to the infrared laser beam. Further we show the dependence of the final electron spectra on the resonance condition between the phase velocity of the optical near-field and the electron propagation velocity. The resonance is controlled by adjusting the initial electron energy/velocity and by introducing a linear chirp to the structure period allowing to increase the final electron energy gain up to a demonstrated 3.8 keV.
705	<strong>Broadband photodetectors based on electron-ion conductor composite nanostructures graphene/RbAg<sub>4</sub>I<sub>5</sub>: response characteristics and mechanisms</strong>	We have developed an electron-ion conductor using a composite nanostructure based on monolayer graphene and a RbAg<sub>4</sub>I<sub>5</sub> film (gr/RbAg<sub>4</sub>I<sub>5</sub>) that exhibited desirable photoelectric properties when illuminated with short wavelength light. The photoelectric response of gr/RbAg<sub>4</sub>I<sub>5</sub> was primarily caused by dissociation and recombination of ion-electron bound states (IEBS). Moreover, ultraviolet-induced photodesorption was also found to participate in the photoelectric response. Combined with our previous work, a complete theoretical model combing both the photodesorption effect and the dynamics of IEBS yielded excellent agreement with the photocurrent-power curves at all wavelengths that were measured. These studies are a significant step towards realizing broadband photodetectors containing the gr/RbAg<sub>4</sub>I<sub>5</sub> composite nanostructures.
706	<strong>Multi-Peak Negative Differential Resistance in Silicene Superlattice: Toward Multi-Valued Silicene Logic Devices</strong>	Negative diffrential resistance (NDR) in two dimansional materials have been the subject of strong interest for ultra-low power nanoelectronic applications. Here, we report NDR characterstics of silicene superlattice (SSL) at low bias voltages. Tansport process manipulated by miniband regime for low bias region and Wannier-Stark ladder (WSLs) regime with multi-peak NDR for higher bias windows. Local tunneling peaks rise from hybridization of Wannier-Stark (WS) rungs in certain bias voltages. Bias position of WS states crossings down shifted with increasing device dimansion leading to red shifted NDR window and increase peak to valley ratio (PVR) values. The multiple NDR windows are represented by changing the size and the number of well/barriers in SSL. Maximum PVR of 8 obtained for device with low height barriers. Multi-peak NDR with same PVR values in very low bias regime can find key applications in multi-valued memories with low static power dissipation.
707	<strong>Formation of some Au-based nanoalloys in condensation-coalescence process: A thermodynamic and structural MD investigation</strong>	In this research, we have investigated surface energy and relative stability of some Au-based clusters formed during gas-phase condensation using MD simulation. Trend of relative stability (the &Delta; parameter) of the formed clusters obeys the order: &Delta;<sub> Au-Pt</sub>&lt; &Delta;<sub> Au-Rh</sub>&lt; &Delta;<sub> Au-Cu</sub>&lt; &Delta;<sub> Au-Ag</sub>&lt; &Delta;<sub> Au-Pd</sub> . The results showed that the Au atoms tend to lie at the clusters surface whereas the other atoms lie at the cluster cores. In the Au-Ag nanocluster, the Au atoms tend to lie at the cluster cores. It is also shown at the following order of the surface energy exists at all simulation times: E<sub>S (Au-Pt)</sub>&lt; E<sub>S (Au-Rh)</sub>&lt; E<sub>S (Au-Ag)</sub>&lt; (E<sub>S (Au-Pd)</sub> , E<sub>S (Au-Cu)</sub>) which is in good agreement with the stability trend of the formed nanoclusters (with the exception of the Au-Cu cluster). Surprisingly, it is observed that the formed Au-Rh and Au-Pt had negative values of the surface energy which is in agreement with the &#x2206; parameter results and is due to the much stability of the formed Au<sub>0.5</sub>Rh<sub>0.5</sub> and Au<sub>0.5</sub>Pt<sub>0.5</sub> nanoclusters during the gas-phase condensation process. Our results also indicated some ordered structures such as fcc-like or hcp-like structures within the Au-Rh, Au-Pt, and Au-Ag clusters.
708	<strong>Probing the pathway of an ultrafast structural phase transition to illuminate the transition mechanism in Cu<sub>2</sub>S</strong>	Disentangling the primary order parameter from secondary order parameters in phase transitions is critical to the interpretation of the transition mechanisms in strongly correlated systems and quantum materials. Here we present a study of structural phase transition pathways in superionic Cu<sub>2</sub>S nanocrystals that exhibit intriguing properties. Utilizing ultrafast electron diffraction techniques sensitive in both momentum-space and the time-domain, we distinguish the dynamics of crystal symmetry breaking and lattice expansion in this system. We are able to follow the transient states along the transition pathway and so observe the dynamics of both the primary and secondary order parameters. Based on these observations we argue that the mechanism of the structural phase transition in Cu<sub>2</sub>S is dominated by the electron-phonon coupling. This mechanism advances the understanding from previous results where the focus was solely on dynamic observations of the lattice expansion.
709	Phase transformation stresses and fracture toughness in Ti-Al-N	The formation of hcp (ZnS-wurtzite type) AlN precipitates, due to decomposition of supersaturated fcc (NaCl-type) Ti-Al-N coatings, causes the residual macrostresses to increase from -3.9{plus minus}0.3 GPa (as-deposited) to -5.2{plus minus}0.3 GPa (annealed at 900 {degree sign}C), as determined by X-ray diffraction. This leads to an increase in measured fracture toughness (KIC) - obtained by cube corner nanoindenation experiments - from the as-deposited value of ~4.4 MPa&#x221A;m to ~8.0 MPa&#x221A;m when annealed at 900 {degree sign}C. This assessment is supported by studying the phase transformation induced stresses by continuum mechanics modelling using Transformation Field Analysis.
710	<strong>Reconfigurable magnetic and microwave properties of a ferrimagnetic-type artificial crystal</strong>	We have demonstrated a ferrimagnetic-type anti-parallel remanent state of rhomboid shaped nanomagnets of two different widths alternated in a dipolar coupled nanomagnetic array. Anti-parallel state is reconfigured to a parallel remanent state by using a simple field initialization process. Magnetic states were directly visualized using magnetic force microscopy technique. Due to a variation of the stray field distributions for the two different remanent states, distinct dynamic responses are found using broadband ferromagnetic resonance spectroscopy technique without applying any external bias magnetic field. Experimental observations were supported by the micromagnetic simulations. The results are important in the context of bias-field-free and reprogrammable microwave magnetic devices and creation of artificial ferrimagnetic crystal.
711	<strong>Convective flows of generalized time-nonlocal nanofluids </strong><strong>through a vertical rectangular channel</strong>	Time-nonlocal generalized model of natural convection heat transfer and nanofluid flows through a rectangular vertical channel with wall conditions of Robin type are studied. The generalized mathematical model with time-nonlocality is developed by considering the fractional constitutive equations for the shear stress and thermal flux defined with the time-fractional Caputo derivative. The Caputo power-law non-local kernel provides the damping to the velocity and temperature gradient, therefore, transport processes are influenced by the histories at all past and present times.s<p>Analytical solutions for dimensionless velocity and temperature fields are obtained by using the Laplace transform coupled with the finite sine-cosine Fourier transform which is suitable to problems with boundary conditions of Robin type.</p>s<p>Particularizing the fractional thermal and velocity parameters, solutions for three simplified models are obtained (classical linear momentum equation with damped thermal flux; fractional shear stress constitutive equation with classical Fourier&rsquo;s law for thermal flux; classical shear stress and thermal flux constitutive equations).</p>s<p>It is found that the thermal histories strongly influence the thermal transport for small values of time t. Also, the thermal transport can be enhanced if the thermal fractional parameter decreases or by increasing the nanoparticles volume fraction. Velocity field is influenced on the one hand by the temperature of the fluid and on the other by the damping of the velocity gradient introduced by the fractional derivative. Also, the transport motions of the channel walls influence the motion of the fluid layers located near them.
712	On the resolution of subsurface atomic force microscopy and its implications for subsurface feature sizing	Ultrasound atomic force microscopy (AFM) has received considerable interest due to its subsurface imaging capabilities, particularly for nanostructure imaging. The local contact stiffness variation due to the presence of a subsurface feature is the origin of the imaging contrast. Several research studies have demonstrated subsurface imaging capabilities with promising resolution. However, there is limited literature available about the definition of spatial resolution in subsurface AFM. The changes in contact stiffness and their link to the subsurface resolution are not well understood. We propose a quantitative approach to assess the resolution in subsurface AFM imaging. We have investigated the influences of several parameters of interest on the lateral resolution. The quantification of the subsurface feature size can be based on threshold criteria (full width at half maximum and Rayleigh criteria). Simulations and experimental measurements were compared, revealing that the optimal choice of parameter settings for surface topography AFM is suboptimal for subsurface AFM imaging.
713	Instability of insulator state towards nanocrystallinity in (La<sub>0.5</sub>Y<sub>0.5</sub>)<sub>0.7</sub>Ca<sub>0.3</sub>MnO<sub>3</sub> compound: Enhancement of low field magnetoresistance	The present study shows the modification of the insulator state to metallic state with reduction of particle size in (La<sub>0.5</sub>Y<sub>0.5</sub>)<sub>0.7</sub>Ca<sub>0.3</sub>MnO<sub>3</sub> compound by magnetotransport measurements. The decrease in the activation energy, as well as increase in the effective density of states near Fermi level, is observed with particle size reduction. This modification leads to the decrease in the<br />resistivity in the nanoparticle in the low-temperature regime (T &lt; 150K). On the other hand, the temperature dependent dc susceptibility data shows the evolution of the non-Griffiths phase to Griffiths phase with reduction of particle size in the temperature range 100K &lt; T &#x0014; 200K. This evolution from non-Griffiths phase to Griffiths phase leads to the formation of large ferromagnetic<br />clusters at the expense of antiferromagnetic interactions which is responsible for the non-Griffiths phase. The presence of the large ferromagnetic clusters helps to create percolation path for electronic transport and is the probable reason for the enhancement of magnetoresistance in this temperature range. On the other hand, enhancement of low field magnetoresistance (LFMR)<br />observed below 100 K has been attributed to the increased spin polarized tunneling (SPT) component due to the increase in the size of the ferromagnetic clusters in the nanoparticle compares with that of bulk.
714	Saltwater Transport through Pristine and Positively Charged Graphene Membranes	Transport of saltwater through pristine and positively charged single-layer graphene nano-pore membranes are investigated using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. Pressure driven flows are induced by motion of specular reflecting boundaries at the feed and permeate sides with constant speed. Unlike previous studies in the literature, this method induces a desired flowrate and calculates the resulting pressure difference in the reservoirs. Due to the hexagonal structure of graphene, hydraulic diameters of the nano-pores are used to correlate the flowrate and pressure drop data. Simulations are performed for three different pore sizes and flowrates for the pristine and charged membrane cases. In order to create better statistical averages for the salt rejection rate ten different initial conditions of Na+ and Cl- distribution in the feed side are used for each simulation case. Using data from 180 distinct simulation cases and by utilizing the Buckingham Pi theorem we developed a functional relationship between the volumetric flowrate, pressure drop, pore-diameter and the dynamic viscosity of saltwater. A linear relationship between the volumetric flowrate and pressure drop is observed.  For the same flowrate and pore size, charged membranes exhibited larger pressure drops. Graphene membranes with 9.90 &#x00C5; pore dimeter resulted in 100% salt rejection with 104.9 L/h-cm2 water flux, requiring a pressure drop of 35.02 MPa.
715	Ferromagnetism in undoped ZnO thin films grwon by reactive sputtering	The observation of room-temperature ferromagnetism in undoped zinc oxide (ZnO) crystalline nanostructures has been attributed to point defects in the bulk and/or near the nanostructure surface.  One of the main candidates for this induced ferromagnetism is oxygen vacancies (V<sub>O</sub>).  In this work, the effect of V<sub>O</sub> on the ferromagnetic behavior of ZnO thin films deposited by reactive magnetron sputtering is studied.  The oxygen to argon ratio (O<sub>2</sub>/Ar) in the sputtering gas was changed from oxygen-deficient (20 %) to oxygen-rich (70 %) conditions.  The films were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (EPR) and vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM).  The largest concentration of V<sub>O</sub>, smallest crystallite size and largest saturation magnetization were obtained for the film grown at the lowest O<sub>2</sub>/Ar ratio of 20 %, while the films grown at 30 % and 50 % showed a larger crystallite size and were diamagnetic.  These results suggest that the ferromagnetic behavior can be linked to a high concentration of V<sub>O</sub>.  Surprisingly, the film grown at an O<sub>2</sub>/Ar ratio of 70 % showed a weak ferromagnetic signal, indicating that another type of defect may also play an important role.
716	Enhancement of bioactivity of glass by deposition of nanofibrous Ti using high intensity laser induced reverse transfer method	Bioglass is a new generation of biomaterials that has desirable properties for biomedical applications. The aim of this research is to develop a new method for the enhancement of biocompatibility of glass and transparent materials by the deposition of Ti nanofibrous structures generated by a high intensity laser induced reverse transfer method (HILIRT). Titanium nanofibers with different porosity, fiber diameter, and biocompatibility are synthesized at various ranges of pulse frequency, power, and scanning speed combined with the HILIRT method. Features and biocompatibility of these deposited Ti coatings before and after 7 days immersion in simulated body fluid were compared. The results show increasing laser frequency and power leads to more Ti nanofiber generation and enhanced biocompatibility, while increasing laser scanning speed results in lower Ti nanofiber growth and lower biocompatibility. Combination of the laser parameters such as frequency, power, and scanning speed can optimize the deposited Ti nanofiber properties for a wide range of biomedical applications using transparent biomaterials.
717	Virtual Bound States Elements and their Effects on Magnetic and Electrical Properties of Fe-Ni based Metal Amorphous Nanocomposites	Metal amorphous nanocomposite (MANC) alloys, with compositions (Fe<sub>70</sub>Ni<sub>30</sub>)<sub>80-x</sub>Nb<sub>4</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>B<sub>14</sub>TE<sub>x</sub> (0 &le; x &le; 5) and (Fe<sub>70</sub>Ni<sub>30</sub>)<sub>80-y</sub>Nb<sub>4+y</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>B<sub>14</sub> (0.5 &le; y &le; 2) were synthesized by planar flow casting. Samples were annealed at 440 &deg;C and strain-annealed at 440 &deg;C and 300 MPa. Resistivity was found to increase with small substitutions of TE elements. For V, further increases resulted in reduced B<sub>S</sub> from 1.2 T to 0.5 T, lower permeability, and higher H<sub>C</sub>. For Mo, further additions lowered B<sub>S</sub> to 0.6 T, and consistently reduced the permeability of strain-annealed ribbon, but had a smaller effect on the permeability of annealed ribbon. For Cr and Nb series, resistivity increased, and strain-annealed permeability was lower than the annealed permeability. There was no systematic worsening of B<sub>S</sub> or H<sub>C</sub>. XRD scans revealed a residual amorphous phase, and fcc Fe-Ni peaks. Lastly, toroidal core losses on (Fe<sub>70</sub>Ni<sub>30</sub>)<sub>79.5</sub>Nb<sub>4</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>B<sub>14</sub>V<sub>1</sub> yielded W<sub>1.0/400 </sub>= 2.1 W/kg, and W<sub>1.0/1k</sub> = 6.0 W/kg.
718	Microwave probe stations with three-dimensional control of the magnetic field to study high-frequency dynamics in nanoscale devices	We present two microwave probe stations with motorized rotary stages for adjusting the magnitude and angle of the applied magnetic field. In the first system, the magnetic field is provided by an electromagnet and can be adjusted from 0 to ~ 1.4 T while its polar angle (&#x03B8;) can be varied from 0<sup>o</sup> to 360<sup>o</sup>. In the second systemsthe magnetic field is provided by a Halbach array permanent magnet, which can be rotated and translated to cover the full range of polar (&#x03B8;) and azimuthal (&#x03C6;) angles with a tunable field magnitude up to ~ 1 T. Both systems are equipped with microwave probes, bias-Ts, ampliers, and spectrum analyzers, to allow for microwave characterization up to 40 GHz, as well as software to automatically perform continuous large sets of electrical and microwave measurements.
719	Investigation of the relevant kinetic processes in the initial stage of a double-arcing instability in oxygen plasmas	A numerical investigation of the kinetic processes in the initial (nanosecond range) stage of the double-arcing instability was developed. The plasma-sheath boundary region of an oxygen-operated cutting torch was considered. The energy balance and chemistry processes in the discharge were described. It is shown that the double-arcing instability is a sudden transition from a diffuse (glow-like) discharge to a constricted (arc-like) discharge in the plasma-sheath boundary region arising from a field-emission instability. A critical electric field value of &#x2248; 10 MV/m was found at the cathodic part of the nozzle wall under the conditions considered. The field-emission instability drives in turn a fast electronic-to-translational energy relaxation mechanism, giving rise to a very fast gas heating rate of at least 1 K/ns, mainly due to reactions of preliminary dissociation of oxygen molecules via the highly excited electronic state O2(B3&#x03A3;u-) populated by electron impact. It is expected that this fast oxygen heating rate further stimulates the discharge contraction through the thermal instability mechanism.
720	<strong>Thermodynamic and structural investigation of some Au-based nanoalloys formed in condensation-coalescence process </strong><strong>using MD simulation</strong>	Catalysts which contain structurally-defined noble metal nanoclusters are of significant interests in the recent years due to their high activity, selectivity, and physical and chemical stability, relative to the corresponding monometallic components. In this research, we have investigated surface energy and relative stability of some Au-based clusters formed during gas-phase condensation using MD simulation. Trend of relative stability (the &Delta; parameter) of the formed clusters obeys the order: &Delta;<sub> Au-Pt</sub>&lt; &Delta;<sub> Au-Rh</sub>&lt; &Delta;<sub> Au-Cu</sub>&lt; &Delta;<sub> Au-Ag</sub>&lt; &Delta;<sub> Au-Pd</sub> . The results showed that the Au atoms tend to lie at the clusters surface whereas the other atoms lie at the cluster cores. In the Au-Ag nanocluster, the Au atoms tend to lie at the cluster cores. It is also shown at the following order of the surface energy exists at all simulation times: E<sub>S (Au-Pt)</sub>&lt; E<sub>S (Au-Rh)</sub>&lt; E<sub>S (Au-Ag)</sub>&lt; (E<sub>S (Au-Pd)</sub> , E<sub>S (Au-Cu)</sub>) which is in good agreement with the stability trend of the formed nanoclusters (with the exception of the Au-Cu cluster). Surprisingly, it is observed that the formed Au-Rh and Au-Pt had negative values of the surface energy which is in agreement with the &#x2206; parameter results and is due to the much stability of the formed Au<sub>0.5</sub>Rh<sub>0.5</sub> and Au<sub>0.5</sub>Pt<sub>0.5</sub> nanoclusters during the gas-phase condensation process. Our results also indicated some ordered structures such as fcc-like or hcp-like structures within the Au-Rh, Au-Pt, and Au-Ag clusters.
721	<strong>Forming-free resistive switching in solution-processed silicon nanocrystal thin film</strong>	We report a forming-free resistive switching using a solution-processed silicon nanocrystal (Si NC) thin film. A Si NC thin film is formed on an ITO/glass substrate by spin-coating a colloidal Si NC solution in air. The Si NC thin film shows bipolar resistive switching without a forming process. Electrical characteristics at low temperatures and in various gas environments suggest that a non-stoichiometric SiO<sub>x</sub> shell on Si NCs contributes to the resistive switching. We propose that the origin of the resistive switching is a conductive filament of oxygen vacancies in the SiO<sub>x</sub> shell by an electric field.
722	Phonon abundance-lifetime-stiffness transition by confinement and polarization	Combining the differential and the ultrafast phonon spectrometrics has reconciled, for the first time, the phonon abundance&ndash;lifetime&ndash;stiffness cooperative transition from the mode of ordinary water to the NaBr hydration and nano-confinement. The fraction coefficient of bond transition f<sub>NaBr</sub>(<em>C</em>) &micro; 1&ndash;exp(&ndash;<em>C</em>/<em>C</em><sub>0</sub>) follows the universal form for the concentrated salt solutions (C) and the f<sub>droplet</sub>(<em>D</em>) = 3DD/D follows the core&ndash;shell volume ratio for the sized nanostructures (<em>D</em>) with shell thickness D<em>D/2</em> = 0.90 &Aring; of the dangling H&ndash;O bond length. The phonon lifetime t<sub>solution</sub>(<em>C</em>) &micro; f<sub>NaBr</sub>(<em>C</em>) features the effect of ionic polarization and the t<sub>droplet </sub>(<em>R</em>) = t<sub>polarization</sub>(<em>D</em>) + t<sub>confinement</sub>(<em>D</em>) discriminates the skin polarization from the droplet boundary reflection. The polarization and boundary reflection lengthen the phonon lifetime by hindering the vibration&ndash;energy dissipation.
723	High efficient photothermal energy conversion of topologic insulator Bi2Se3 nanosheets thin film	The photothermal conversion has become rather attractive to realize the energy application. A simple, rapid and scalable optical-controlling Bi2Se3 nanosheets film heater is prepared by softly nondestructive rubbing technology and transferring to PET substrate under the assistance of PVA. The optical-controlling film heater exhibits the excellent adjustability, accuracy and stability of temperature. The film heater is first tested by using laser irradiation at 410 mW and the corresponding temperature rapidly increased to the 53.2 {degree sign}C in the 50 seconds for SThin, and 53.2 {degree sign}C in the 50 seconds for SThick. The SThin and SThick film display a flat transmittance of ~60% and from the visible to near-IR region, respectively. The optical-controlling film heating can be easily incorporated for optical or optical-electrical device without preparation of electrode. These exotic properties of Bi2Se3 nanosheets optical-controlling heater suggest exciting prospects for the temperature dependence flexible optoelectronics and electronic device.
724	<strong>Direct evidence for coexistence of nanoscale high -conductive and </strong><strong>low-conductive phases in VO<sub>2</sub> film</strong>	<strong> </strong>In this work, we carried out a systematic study on the nanoscale conductivity behaviors of VO<sub>2</sub> films by using conductive atomic force microscopy. Other than the macro-scale resistance-temperature characteristics, which demonstrate a steep insulator-metal transition of VO<sub>2</sub> at transition temperature, our present work demonstrated that nanoscale high-conductive phase and low-conductive phase will always coexist in either macroscale insulating state or metal state. The nanoscale high-conductive region appears at room temperature, at which the VO<sub>2</sub> film exhibits macroscale high resistance state. On the other hand, the nanoscale low-conductive phase appears at temperatures higher than the insulator-metal transition temperature. The area of the high-conductive region will increase with the increase of measurement temperature. The nanoscale current-voltage measurement indicate that the high-conductive state is not a good metal state, and the charge transport behaviors will change from a space charge limited current dominated mechanism to Shockley emission dominated mechanism, when the temperature increase from below to above phase change temperature.
725	NiMoO4 nanorods supported on nickel foam for high-performance supercapacitor electrode materials	Well-aligned hierarchical NiMoO4 nanorods are successfully grown on nickel foam by a facile hydrothermal method, and which can be directly used as integrated electrodes for supercapacitors without the addition of other ancillary materials such as binders or additives to enhance electrode cycling stability or conductivity. The samples are characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), fourier transform infrared (FT-IR), galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements. It is demonstrated that the achieved NiMoO4 nanorods are uniformly grown on nickel foam, and its diameter and length is estimated to be 100 nm and 3 &#x03BC;m on average, respectively. The results indicate that the NiMoO4 nanorods samples deliver high specific capacitances of 3412, 2490, 1740, 1496 F/g at 1, 4, 7 and 10 A/g, respectively. Furthermore, the excellent rate capability of the NiMoO4 nanorods based supercapacitors have been obtained in KOH electrolyte, demonstrate the as-prepared products can be a promising electrode material for supercapacitor.
726	Local carrier distribution imaging on few-layer MoS<sub>2</sub> exfoliated on SiO<sub>2</sub> by scanning nonlinear dielectric microscopy	We demonstrate that scanning nonlinear dielectric microscopy (SNDM) can be used for the nanoscale characterization of dominant carrier distribution on atomically thin MoS<sub>2</sub> mechanically exfoliated on SiO<sub>2</sub>. For stable imaging without damaging microscopy tips and samples, SNDM was combined with peak-force tapping mode atomic force microscopy. The identification of dominant carriers and their spatial distribution becomes possible even for single and few-layer number MoS<sub>2</sub> on SiO<sub>2</sub> using the proposed method allowing differential capacitance (d<em>C</em>/d<em>V</em>) imaging. We can expect that SNDM can also be applied to the evaluation of other two-dimensional semiconductors and devices.
727	Structural, magnetic and mechanical properties of Nd6.8Fe63.3Nb4.0Co1.3Cr1.1Zr0.9B22.6 nanocrystalline hard magnet prepared by injection casting method	Microstructural, magnetic and mechanical properties of nanocrystalline Nd6.8Fe63.3Nb4.0Co1.3Cr1.1Zr0.9B22.6 hard magnets produced by injection casting and subsequent thermo-magnetic annealing have been investigated in this study. X-ray diffraction studies reveal that phases present in the as-cast Nd6.8Fe63.3Nb4.0Co1.3Cr1.1Zr0.9B22.6 alloy are 60% Nd2Fe14B, 16% &#x03B1;-Fe, 9% Fe3B and 15% amorphous phases, whereby, Nd2Fe14B being the majority phase. Thermo-magnetic annealing induces a complete crystallization of the amorphous phase and develops an ideal trade-off balance between the fractions of magnetically soft and hard phases. The optimum hard magnetic properties such as coercivity (iHc) of 861 kA/m, remanence (Br) of 0.68 T and maximum energy product (BH)max of 81.9 kJ/m3 were obtained after magnetic annealing the Nd6.8Fe63.3Nb4.0Co1.3Cr1.1Zr0.9B22.6 alloy at 993 K for 15 min. Transmission electron microscope and magnetic property analysis reveal that good magnetic properties result from the magnetically exchange coupled Nd2Fe14B, &#x03B1;-Fe and Fe3B grains. The as-cast Nd6.8Fe63.3Nb4.0Co1.3Cr1.1Zr0.9B22.6 magnet with a diameter of 2 mm and 27 mm in length demonstrates the micro-Vickers hardness (Hv) of 960 {plus minus} 20 and compressive stress (&#x03C3;f) of 1270 {plus minus} 10 MPa, which tend to decrease by annealing process.
728	Two-Parameter Quasi-Ballistic Transport Model for Nanoscale Transistors	We show that by adding only two fitting parameters to a purely ballistic transport model, we can accurately characterize the current-voltage characteristics of nanoscale MOSFETs.  The model is an extension of Natori&rsquo;s model (J. Appl. Phys. 76, 4879 (1994)) and includes transmission probability and drain-channel coupling parameter. The latter parameter gives rise to a theoretical R<sub>ON</sub> that is significantly larger than those predicted previously. To validate our model, we fabricated n-channel MOSFETs with varying channel lengths.  We show the length dependence of these parameters to support a quasi-ballistic description of our devices.
729	Dielectric meta-walls for surface plasmon focusing and Bessel beam generation	Tailoring the wavefronts of surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) freely is a central goal in plasmonics, but conventional approaches exhibit low efficiencies and/or require bulky devices. Here, we propose to utilize <em>ultrathin</em> dielectric meta-walls placed vertically on a plasmonic metal to <em>efficiently</em> reshape the wavefront of the launched SPP beam. Based on such a strategy, we experimentally demonstrate two effects in the microwave regime, which are focusing and Bessel beam generations of spoof SPPs. Near-field scanning measurements are in excellent agreement with full wave simulations. This work can inspire many applications related to SPP manipulations, such as enhanced nonlinear effect, nano-particle trapping, and so on.
730	Evidence for Glassy Relaxation in Crystals at High Deformation Rates	When investigated as a function of deformation rate and short time, model nano-crystals exhibit a clear threshold in mechanical and relaxation behavior, this observation being valid in both the Hooke (elastic) and plastic regime. At low deformation rate ($\dot\epsilon$~&lt;~$\dot\epsilon_c\simeq$5.10$^5$~s$^{-1}$), materials are able to equilibrate with ongoing deformation over the ns timescale, whereas ultra-fast deformations bring the system out off equilibrium on the same timescale. The time evolution of stress is investigated and suggests features that are typical of glassy relaxation with a stretched exponential behavior for stress relaxation that is only encountered for large deformation rates. Related relaxation times furthermore reveal a rapid increase with $\dot\epsilon$. These results actually link general aspects of plastic deformation, irreversibility at and thermal equilibrium.
731	Interfacial Properties of Water/Heavy Water layer Encapsulated in Bilayer Boron Nitride Nanochannel	Water interaction and transport through nanochannels of two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials due to capillary pressures are in high demand. This letter reports interfacial properties of water/heavy water within boron nitride (BN) nanochennels with significant infrastructure applications. We demonstrate a series of <em>ab initio</em> based on density functional theory (DFT) computation on correlating the stability of adsorption and interfacial properties, decoding various synergies in the complex interfacial interations of water on BN nanocapillaries including the role of intermediate pressure of heterogeneous. We also provide a comparison of phonon vibrational modes of water and heavy water (D<sub>2</sub>O) captured in bilayer BN (BLBN) to compare their mobility as a key factor for separation mechanism. This finding, combined with the fundamental insights into the nature of interfacial properties provides key hypotheses for design of nanochannels.
732	Darcy-Forchheimer Flow of Micropolar Nanofluid in the Rotating Frame with Non-Uniform Heat Generation/Absorption	The present research aims to examine the Darcy-Forchheimer three-dimensional micropolar nanofluid between parallel and horizontal plates in a rotating system. The micropolar nanofluid in permeable media is described by assuming the Darcy-Forchheimer model where drenching permeable space obeys the Darcy-Forchheimer expression. The thermal radiation impact is taken to be varing in the absorption/generation for the purpose, to see the concentration as well as the temperature modifications between the nanofluid and the surfaces. The flow of micropolar nanofluid has been assumed in steady state. The rudimentary leading equations have been transformed to a set of differential nonlinear and coupled equations using suitable similarity variables. The homotopic approach has been used to acquire the solution of the modelled problems. The other physical impacts that is Skin friction, heat flux and mass flux have been studied. The influences of the porosity, rotation, inertia coefficient, Brownian motion and thermophoresis analysis of micropolar nanofluid have been mainly focused in this work.
733	Membrane-based methodology for scanning tunneling measurements in epitaxial quantum dot systems	Scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and spectroscopy (STS) are key techniques for the advance of nano- and atomic scale science. Their use is, in a large extent, depending on ultra-high vacuum conditions, in which clean surfaces are obtained by in-situ procedures such as growth, annealing, sputtering or cleavage of the materials of interest. In this sense, a number of technical limitations are imposed to the study of nanostructures and thin films. Here we show that the use of chemically etched nanomembranes allows to carry out STS measurements in a system which was otherwise studied mainly under in-situ conditions. We were able to acquire STS spectra with energy level resolved response on InAs quantum dots grown within a 15nm-thick GaAs single-crystalline film transferred to a Au (111) surface. The presence of a native oxide layer does not affect the result, keeping the reliability of the usual UHV procedures. The use of nanomembranes also opens up the possibility of tailoring properties via additional variables such as nanomembrane thickness and surface charge depletion.
734	Modelling linear and non-linear rheology of polylactide/layered silicate nanocomposite regarding shear rate, temperature and formulation	The aims of this study were to bring mathematical models for numerical simulations and to improve the understanding of the rheological behaviour of nanocomposites based polylactide with different amounts of organo-modified clay. A modelling method was proposed to describe this behaviour under various variables: shear rate, temperature, clay loading, and molar mass. Ostwald-de Waele and Carreau-Yasuda laws were taken as basic models and then were completed by adding new dimensions on each parameter. Rheological measurements were corroborated by morphological observations to reveal three domains responding to different models. By separating the effect of the molar mass from that of the clay, the results suggested the decrease of shear viscosity compared to that of the neat polylactide essentially assigned to the molar mass degradation. Clay loading effect showed a three-way variation of the general level of non-linear shear viscosity, including a contribution between 1 wt% and 5 wt% to the previous decrease of shear viscosity. Time-temperature superposition principle was employed and highlighted a double distinct trend in function of the clay loading.
735	Comprehension of peculiar local emission behavior of InGaAs quantum well by co-localized nanocharacterization combining cathodoluminescence and electron microscopy techniques	Electronic and structural properties of an In_x Ga_(1-x) As quantum well (QW) stacking between AlAs barriers grown on 300mm (001) silicon substrate by metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) were investigated. A nanometer scale and spatially co-localized characterization combining low temperature cathodoluminescence (CL) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) was performed. The combined interpretation of luminescence and strain measurement provides an exhaustive landscape of such complex sample. Particularly, the obtained results provide a comprehensive analysis of specific peculiar luminescence feature. These luminescent regions, detected all over the sample, seems to be correlated to the local increase in the carbon content in AlAs barriers and in indium concentration in the InGaAs QW induced by local strain variations. These modifications alter the InGaAs QW properties and thus its optical efficiency.
736	<strong>The Study of Nanoheterostructures Transport Properties by The Local Cathodoluminescent Technique</strong>	A method for the study of the transport properties of nanoheterostructures in the direction of their growth is proposed. This technique is based on the dependence of cathodoluminescent area generation on the energy of electron beam. The size of the cathodoluminescence generation area is determined by the electron penetration interaction region and by the transport of electro-hole pairs to the place of their recombination. Several models for the description of the electro-hole pairs transport in nanogeterostructures were purposed. The transport properties of nanoheterostructures can be quantitatively compared for structures of different composition and design. This method was used for studying the heterostructures based on  ZnCdSSe and AlGaN.
737	Enhanced Room Temperature Ferromagnetism in ZnO Nanorods Decorated with Nanocrystalline (nc)-Au particles.	Enhanced room temperature ferromagnetism has been observed when nanocrystalline (<em>nc</em>) gold (Au) particles are decorated with ZnO-nanorods (ZnO-NRs) surface. The magnetic moment in <em>nc</em>-Au/ZnO-NRs with the optimum amount of <em>nc</em>-Au loading comes from mettalic electrons at the <em>nc</em>-Au/ZnO-NRs interface that includes large orbital magnetic moment at the interface. The presence of intrinsic defects like zinc materials (Zn<sub>i</sub>) and oxygen vacancies (V0) are established using Raman spectroscopy, X-ray Photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy(UPS). Oxygen vacancy related surface defects were obtained from the O 1s XPS peak of different <em>nc</em>-Au/ZnO-NRs structure. The valence band maximum position and the work function (&#x0424;) of ZnO-NRs and <em>nc</em>-Au/ZnO-NRs hybrid nanostructures were obtained from UPS (He-I) measurement. The UPS (He-II) spectra suggests that the valence band density of states in the valence band of O 2<em>p</em> - Zn 4<em>sp</em> hybridized states of <em>nc</em>-Au/ZnO-NRs hybrid structure thin films is higher than pure ZnO-NRs thin film that could be correlated with higher magnetization. First principle density functional theory calculations show the enhancement of the density of states at the valence band region with decoration of optimum content <em>nc</em>-Au in ZnO-NRs surface along with increase of oxygen vacancies in <em>nc</em>-Au/ZnO-NRs that further confirms the enhancement of magnetization.
738	The surface effect of solid and hollow nanowires under diametral loading	The size effect of the surface parameters on the mechanical behavior of the solid and hollow nanowires is investigated under diametral loading. In order to address the newly proposed diametral compression test on the nanowires, the analytical solutions of solid and hollow nanowires under diametral loading are developed by considering the surface effect at the boundaries of the bulk materials. The solutions are validated by degenerating to other analytical solutions and comparing against the surface conditions. The surface effect on the circumferential stress is tested by varying the surface parameters, size of the nanowires, as well as the residual stress separately. Taking aluminum nanowires for example, certain surface parameters are found to have profound effects in changing the local stress distributions, especially when the outer radius of a nanowire is below 10nm. The mechanical response is also affected when the residual stress arrives a certain magnitude relative to the applied loading.
739	A high temperature gas flow environment for neutron total scattering studies of complex materials	We present the design and capabilities of a high temperature gas flow environment for neutron diffraction and pair distribution function (PDF) studies available at the Nanoscale Ordered Materials Diffractometer (NOMAD) instrument at the Spallation Neutron Source (SNS).  Design considerations for successful total scattering studies are discussed, and a set of best practices for planning experiments, preparing samples, and collecting and reducing data are defined.  The new capabilities are demonstrated with an in situ decomposition study of a battery electrode material under inert gas flow and an in operando carbonation/decarbonation experiment under reactive gas flow. This capability will aid in identifying and quantifying the atomistic configurations of chemically reactive species and their influence on underlying crystal structures.  Furthermore, studies of reaction kinetics and growth pathways in a wide variety of functional materials can be performed across a range of length scales spanning the atomic to the nanoscale.
740	Dynamical Analysis for Nanofluid Slip Rheology with Thermal Radiation, Heat Generation / Absorption and Convective Wall Properties	In this analysis, we have presented the nanofluid rheology with slip effects over a convective wall. Simultaneous effects of non-linear thermal radiations and internal heat generation / absorption properties are taken into the account. Hydro-magnetic flow in the presence of a porous medium, thermophoresis and Brownian motion effects is analyzed. Mathematical modelling has been performed in order to obtain the governing relations of the physical problem. Numerical solutions for the velocity, temperature and mass fraction profiles have been computed using the finite-difference approach (FDM). Various graphical and numerical illustrations for several parameters have been presented into order to investigate physics behind the mathematical equations.
741	<strong>High-performance</strong><strong> structure of a coil-shaped soft-actuator consisting of polymer threads and carbon nanotube yarns</strong>	We fabricated thermally driven metal-free soft-actuators consisting of poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET) threads as the actuator and carbon nanotube (CNT) yarns as the heating source. The mechanical force and response behavior of various structures of the coil-shaped soft-actuators were characterized. The performance of the soft-actuators containing a homogenous arrangement of PET threads and CNT yarns in their cross-section profile was the highest. The results of the calculations based on the heat diffusion equations indicated that inhomogeneous heat generation in the soft-actuator causes parts of the actuator to remain unheated and this interferes with the mechanical motions. Homogenous thermal distribution in the soft-actuators, <em>i.e</em>., the use of the multifilament structure, provides the highest performance in terms of mechanical force.
742	3D graphene-like carbon/Polydimethylsiloxane nanocomposite for tensile and compressive strain sensors	Elastomeric matrix filled with carbon nanotubes or graphene has been focused for making resistive-type strain sensors. Here, we report the synthesis of 3D graphene-like carbon nanostructures by exploiting the chemical reaction between magnesium and carbon disulfide, and made piezoresistive nanocomposites of as-prepared carbon nanomaterials and polydimethylsiloxane rubber for tensile and compressive strain sensors. The stretchable strain sensor shows fast response and high gauge factor ~35. The compressive strain sensor is elaborated designed as in-plane and miniature concept. It also shows fast response to external force and good stability.
743	Dose regularization via filtering and projection: an open-source code forsoptimization-based proximity-effect-correction for nanoscale lithography	A new method for dose regularization in optimization-based proximity-effect-correction is proposed. In contrast to the commonly adapted approach of adding penalty terms to the objective function, a modified scheme is demonstrated where dose regularization is achieved via filtering and projection techniques. The resulting dose patterns are simple and two-toned, and can thus readily be adopted in production.  The validity of the scheme is assessed in experiments, where the resolvable feature size of the considered 30 kV electron-beam lithography system is decreased from around 100 nm to a few tens of nm. A Python implementation of the scheme is made freely available.
744	<strong>Tailoring the failure morphology of 2D bicrystalline graphene oxide</strong>	Aim of this article, is to study the effect of oxide functionalisation on the failure morphology of bicrystalline graphene. Molecular dynamics based simulations in conjunction with reactive force field were performed to study the mechanical properties as well as failure morphology of different configurations of bicrystalline graphene oxide. Separate simulations were performed with hydroxyl and epoxide functionalisation, and later on the same simulations were extended to study the graphene oxide as a whole. Authors have predicted that epoxide functionalisation helps in transforming the catastrophic brittle behavior into ductile. Failure morphologies depict that epoxide groups tend to boost the ductility through altering the fracture path and not affecting the grain boundaries either. Also, the epoxide to ether transformations were found to be the decisive mechanism behind the plastic response shown by epoxide groups. Simulations help in concluding a ductile failure for bicrystalline graphene in conjunction with oxidation of selective atoms in the nanosheet, which further opens new avenues for the application of these graphene sheets in nanodevices and nanocomposites.
745	<strong>LaFeO<sub>3</sub>- Pb(Zr<sub>0.58</sub>Ti<sub>0.42</sub>)O<sub>3 </sub>Multiferroic Nanocomposite: </strong><strong>Magnetoelectric Coupling, Electrical Transport and Dielectric Response</strong>	Room temperature magnetoelectric coupling of <em>x</em>LaFeO<sub>3</sub>-(1-<em>x</em>) Pb(Zr<sub>0.58</sub>Ti<sub>0.42</sub>)O<sub>3</sub> (<em>x</em> = 0.2 and 0.3) nanocomposites prepared through low temperature pyrophoric reaction process has been investigated. The magnetoelectric response has been measured as a function of applied magnetic field at different frequencies, which attributes the presence of magnetostriction properties of the piezomagnetic material. The study of dielectric constant of those nanocomposites gives evidence of Maxwell-Wagner interfacial or space charge polarization in the sample at low frequency regime. The ac electrical properties of those nanocomposites have been studied with different applied magnetic fields and temperatures. Complex impedance spectra have been fitted using parallel combinations of grain boundaries resistance and grain boundaries capacitance circuit. This supports the dominating role of grain boundaries contribution in electrical transport of the sample. Impedance study at different temperatures shows temperature dependent electrical relaxation process in the system. The activation energy is estimated from Nyquist plots, dc conductivity data by using the Arrhenius relation, which indicates that the same kind of charge carriers are responsible for relaxation process in grain boundaries of the sample. Furthermore, the ac conductivity of the nanocomposites has been investigated at different temperatures and fitted by Jonscher&rsquo;s power law. The conduction mechanism is mainly due to the small and large polaronic hopping in the system.
746	<SPAN style="font-size: 14.0pt; color: black;">Superlong uniform Light Tunnel Created by Focusing Radially Polarized Vortex Beam</SPAN>	A method of generating a super-long nanoscale light tunnel with longitudinal intensity variation less than three percent of the maximum is presented. A radially polarized vortex beam with topological charge of two can be focused into a relatively short light tunnel when the ring-like annular amplitude filter is used to block the outer annular part of the light beam or when an objective with relatively low numerical aperture is used. A fan-shaped division of the central part of light beam cross section with phase modulation scheme is adopted to generate four relatively short light tunnels simultaneously with exactly the same intensity distribution and optimized axial shaft. Based on these foundations, a super-long nanoscale light tunnel with uniform intensity is demonstrated both in simulation and experiment.<em>          </em>
747	Thermoelectric characterization of nickel-nanowires and nanoparticles embedded in silica aerogels	Embedded nickel nanowires (NiNWs) and nickel nanoparticles (NiNPs) in silica aerogels at three different concentrations are characterized by scanning thermal microscopy, a Hot disk method and four probe measurements to consider them as potential thermoelectric materials. NiNW samples exhibit 9 orders of magnitude improvement in thermoelectric figure of merit while the embedded NiNPs samples show a 6 orders of magnitude improvement when the concentrations are increased from 0 to 700 ppm. The electrical resistivity is highly sensitive to the concentration of NiNWs and NiNPs in the silica aerogels, while the thermal conductivity remains largely unchanged. The electrical conductivity &#x1D70E; is shown to follow a percolation scaling law of the form &#x1D70E;&prop;(&#x1D44A;&minus;&#x1D44A;&#x1D450;)<sup>&#x1D461;</sup> with critical weight fraction (&#x1D44A;&#x1D450;) to form a conductive network of approximately at 0.04-0.6 Wt% and 0.08-0.1 Wt% for embedded NiNWs and NiNPs, respectively. The results suggest that optimizing the concentration of NiNWs could yield promising thermoelectric properties.
748	<strong>Molecular beam epitaxy of single-crystalline aluminum film</strong><strong> for low threshold ultraviolet plasmonic nanolasers</strong>	High-quality single-crystalline aluminum films have been grown on Si(111) substrates by molecular beam epitaxy. X-ray diffraction rocking curve of the (111) plane of the Al film shows a full width at half maximum of 564 arcsec for the sample grown at 100&deg;C, where the surface is atomically flat with a root-mean-square roughness of 0.40 nm in a scanned area of 3&times;3 &mu;m<sup>2</sup>. By using such high-quality Al film, we have demonstrated a room temperature ultraviolet surface-plasmon-polariton nanolaser at wavelength of 360 nm with a threshold as low as ~ 0.2 MW/cm<sup>2</sup>, which provides a powerful evidence for potential application of single-crystalline Al film in plasmonic devices.
749	Diameter dependent threshold voltage modification of resistive state switching in organometallic single nanowire devices (diameter ~ 10-100 nm)	Reversible electrical resistive state switching (ERSS) and memory effect have been investigated for a wide range of organometallic compounds and device configurations where underlying mechanism is still not fully explored. We synthesized nanowires (NWs) of organometallic charge transfer complexes between pre-fabricated electrodes with diameter (<em>d</em>) 10 &le;<em> d &le; </em>100 nm and their ERSS properties have been systematically investigated at 300K encompassing versatile measurement techniques. The lowest dimensional NW with <em>d ~ </em>10 nm, switched to its low resistive state with very low applied voltage. It appeared as metallic in switched state as confirmed by its current-voltage characteristics and temperature (<em>T</em>) dependent resistivity for 100 <em>&le; T &le; </em>300 K. Supported by a theoretically simulated model, we proposed a possible mechanism for the single metallic filament formation in an almost defect-free 10 nm wire in its switched state considering the migration of metal ions created by a strong electric field between two very closely spaced electrodes. We also experimentally demonstrated that the diameter dependence of the threshold voltage (<em>V<sub>th</sub></em>) for switching follows a power law (<em>V<sub>th </sub>&infin; d<sup>&delta;</sup></em>) which is independent of the electrode configurations and growth mechanism. The results explained the strategies to engineer the ERSS properties of single NW devices and might be beneficial for further research and development.
750	<strong>Self-assembled single-digit nanometer memory cells</strong>	The current spintronics research focuses on lowering switching energy and maintaining good thermal stability of nanomagnets which could ensure further development of memory technology. Here, we investigate single-digit nanometer magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ) composed of self-assembled FePt nanopillars isolated by the crystallized ZrO<sub>2</sub>. We find that the lateral size range of the operational device could be sub-7-nm by maintaining outstanding thermal stability.
751	Ag-Cu Nanoparticles Supported on N-Doped TiO2 Nanowire Arrays for Efficient Photocatalytic CO2 Reduction	Photocatalytic reduction of CO2 into various types of fuels has attracted great interest, and serves as a potential solution to address current global warming and energy challenges.  In this work, Ag-Cu nanoparticles are densely supported on N-doped TiO2 nanowire through a straightforward nanofabrication approach.  The light absorption range of N-doped TiO2 can be tuned to match the plasmonic band of Ag nanoparticles, which allows synergizing a resonant energy transfer process with the Schottky junction.  Meanwhile, Cu nanoparticles can provide active sites for CO2 reduction.  As a result, the photocatalytic performance in photocatalytic CO2 reduction is improved to achieve a CH4 production rate of 720 &#x03BC;mol&#x00B7;g-1&#x00B7;h-1 under full-spectrum irradiation.
752	Synergistic Enhancements in the Performances of DSSC by the Scattering and Plasmon Resonance of Au-Nanoparticle Hollow Multishell Microspheres	Novel hollow multishell SiO2@Au@TiO2 (HSAT) microspheres are synthesized by multi-step method to form their composite photoanodes and dye sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). The composite photoanodes and DSSCs with different amount of HSAT microspheres are studied. The study indicates that the HSAT microspheres have enhanced the scattering and absorption of incident light in the photoanode, reduced the interface transmission resistance, increased the electron lifetime, and thus significantly improved the short-circuit current (Jsc) and photoelectric conversion efficiency (PCE) of the DSSCs. The maximal Jsc and PCE of the optimal DSSC doped with HSAT microspheres are 15.83 mA cm-2 and 7.21 %, greatly enhanced by 21.0 % and 20.4 %, respectively, than those of the conventional DSSC with pure TiO2 photoanode. These remarkable enhancements in the properties of the DSSCs can be attributed to the dual effects of HSAT microspheres, i.e., the localized surface plasmon resonance of Au nanoparticles inside the shells and the strong light scattering of hollow spheres, their synergistic and complementary effects have significantly improved the absorption and utilization on incident light and thus the PCE of DSSC. Such synergistic and complementary effects of the different functions are also likely expected to play roles in the performance improvements in other similar solar cells.
753	Nonlocal and nonlinear contributions to the thermal and elastic high-frequency wave propagations at nanoscale	We analyze the role played by nonlocal and nonlinear effects in the propagation of thermal and elastic high-frequency waves in nanosystems. The study is performed both in the case of a rigid body (i.e., for heat pulse propagation), and in the case of a non-rigid body (i.e., for thermoelastic pulse propagation). In the framework of Extended Irreversible Thermodynamics the compatibility of our theoretical models with second law is proved.
754	<strong>Plasmonic surface relief gratings for tunable optical band-pass filter </strong><strong><strong>application</strong></strong>	The experimental results of optical diffraction of plasmonic surface relief grating having a periodicity of 10, 5 and 3.4 &micro;m are presented. These structures find a major application as a band-pass filter in visible spectral range. The fabrication of grating structures on the silver halide based film is carried out using the electron beam raster scan in a conventional scanning electron microscopic. Morphological characterization of the gratings is performed using an atomic force microscope. It shows that the period, height and profile of the grating depend upon the lines per frame, beam spot, single line dwells time, beam current, and accelerating voltage of the electron beam. Optical transmission of 10 &micro;m period grating show a well-defined localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) dip in the spectra. This LSPR dip corresponds to gelatin embedded silver nanoparticles in the grating structure. The LSPR dip becomes prominent as the period of the grating is reduced. The maximum first-order optical diffraction efficiency and bandwidth for a 10 &micro;m period grating are observed as 4% and 400 nm in the visible wavelength range respectively. As the periodicity has reduced both optical diffraction efficiency and bandwidth reduces. The optical diffraction efficiency and bandwidth for 3.4 &micro;m periodic grating were observed as 0.03% and 100 nm respectively. The profile of optical diffraction efficiency is significantly flat within the bandwidth for each of the gratings. Finally, an assessment of the role of LSPR absorption and varied grating period in the development of the optical diffraction efficiency profile is presented.
755	Design of FPGA based system identification module with application to atomic force microscopy	The science of system identification is widely utilized in modeling input-output relationships of diverse systems. In this article we report field programmable gate arrays (FPGA) based implementation of a real-time system identification algorithm which employs forgetting factors and bias compensation techniques. The FPGA module is employed to estimate mechanical properties of surfaces of materials at the nano-scale with atomic force microscopy (AFM). The FPGA module is user friendly which can be interfaced with commercially available AFMs. Extensive simulation and experimental results validate the design.
756	Synthesis and electrochemical properties of Si(Silicide)/Exfoliated graphite nanocomposite anode for lithium-ion rechargeable batteries	Silicon-based nanocomposites have been attracted noteworthy attention as an anode material for lithium-ion secondary batteries. In this work, nano-scale Si-FeSi2 powders encapsulated in the exfoliated graphite (EG) to prepare a novel nanocomposite Si-FeSi2/EG anode synthesized by a scalable two-stage high-energy mechanical milling.  Remarkably, the Si-FeSi2/EG electrode demonstrate stable reversible capacity about 1002 mAhg-1 even at 50th cycle with a coulombic efficiency ~99.8%. The irreversible capacity loss after the 1st, 3rd and 50th cycle was 21, 2.2 and 0.2, respectively. The significant cyclic performance was mainly ascribed to the silicon particle size and encapsulation of active Si-FeSi2 in the exfoliated graphite.
757	In-situ plasma monitoring of PECVD nc-Si:H films and influence of dilution ratio on structural evolution	We report plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) hydrogenated nano-crystalline silicon (nc-Si:H) thin films. In particular, the effect of hydrogen dilution ratio (R= H2/SiH4) on structural and optical evolutions of the deposited nc-Si:H films were systematically investigated including Raman spectroscopy, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and low angle X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (XRD). Measurement results revealed that the nc-Si:H structural evolution, primarily the transition of nano-crystallization from the amorphous state to the nanocrystalline state, can be carefully induced by the adjustment of hydrogen dilution ratio (R). In addition, in-situ plasma diagnostic tool of optical emission spectroscopy (OES) was used to further characterize the crystallization rate index (H&#x03B1;* / SiH*) that increases when hydrogen dilution ratio (R) rises whereas the deposition rate decreases. Another in-situ plasma diagnostic tool of quadruple mass spectrometry (QMS) also confirmed that the "optimal" range of hydrogen dilution ratio (R=30-40) can yield nano-crystalline silicon (n-Si:H) growth due to the depletion of higher silane radicals.
758	<strong>Asymmetric-structure-induced self rectifying for the pure HfO<sub>2</sub> 1R selector in nanoscale RRAM array</strong>	<strong>Asymmetric-structure-induced self-rectifying selector was realized in Pt/HfO<sub>2</sub>/n<sup>+</sup>-Si </strong><strong>resistive random access memory (RRAM) using a pure HfO<sub>2</sub> layer with asymmetric structure. The device exhibits repeatable self-rectifying resistive switching (RS) behavior with relatively high rectifying ratio. The nanoscale electrostatic effect induced by the asymmetric structure is responsible for the diode-like rectifying behavior of HfO<sub>2</sub> layer. Since this kind of rectifying is based on universal nanoelectronical physics, it is thus released from the material limitation, and thus paves a new way for resolving sneak current issue in RRAM arrays. </strong>
759	Fluorescent nanopowders for biosensing applications	NA
760	Virtual Bound States Elements and their Effects on Magnetic and Electrical Properties of Fe-Ni based Metal Amorphous Nanocomposites	Metal amorphous nanocomposite (MANC) alloys, with compositions (Fe<sub>70</sub>Ni<sub>30</sub>)<sub>80-x</sub>Nb<sub>4</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>B<sub>14</sub>TE<sub>x</sub> (0 &le; x &le; 5) and (Fe<sub>70</sub>Ni<sub>30</sub>)<sub>80-y</sub>Nb<sub>4+y</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>B<sub>14</sub> (0.5 &le; y &le; 2) were synthesized by planar flow casting. Samples were annealed at 440 &deg;C and strain-annealed at 440 &deg;C and 300 MPa. Resistivity was found to increase with small substitutions of TE elements. For V, further increases resulted in reduced B<sub>S</sub> from 1.2 T to 0.5 T, lower permeability, and higher H<sub>C</sub>. For Mo, further additions lowered B<sub>S</sub> to 0.6 T, and consistently reduced the permeability of strain-annealed ribbon, but had a smaller effect on the permeability of annealed ribbon. For Cr and Nb series, resistivity increased, and strain-annealed permeability was lower than the annealed permeability. There was no systematic worsening of B<sub>S</sub> or H<sub>C</sub>. XRD scans revealed a residual amorphous phase, and fcc Fe-Ni peaks. Lastly, toroidal core losses on (Fe<sub>70</sub>Ni<sub>30</sub>)<sub>79.5</sub>Nb<sub>4</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>B<sub>14</sub>V<sub>1</sub> yielded W<sub>1.0/400 </sub>= 2.1 W/kg, and W<sub>1.0/1k</sub> = 6.0 W/kg.
