761	Observation of the Growth of Single-Crystalline MAPbBr3 Thin Film Based on Space-Confined Method	Organic-inorganic hybrid perovskite single-crystalline thin films (SCTFs) are promising for enhancing photoelectric device performance. Here, we found that weak wetting substrate could reduce friction force and promote precursor ion diffusion, which enabled a continuous growth of SCTFs along in-plane direction.We observed some signs of island growth model. Pyramid-shaped island formed first and then converged, to achieve lateral growth of SCTFs. However, the lateral crystal growth was limited by the inefficient and anisotropic long range transportation of precursor ions along the micrometer-size or nanometer-size gap. Low ion diffusion is the main constraint for the preparation of the larger and thinner SCTFs.
762	<strong>Suppression of coffee ring: (Particle) size matters</strong>	<em>Coffee ring pattern in drying sessile droplet, is undesirable in various practical applications. Here, we experimentally demonstrate that on hydrophobic substrates, the coffee ring can be suppressed just by increasing the particle diameter. Larger size of the particles flocculate within the evaporation timescale leading to significant gravimetric settling (for Pe&gt;1) triggering a uniform deposit. Interestingly, the transition to a uniform deposit is found to be independent of the internal flow field and substrate properties. Flocculation of particles also alters the particle packing at nanoscale resulting in order to disorder transitions. In this letter, we exhibit a physical exposition on how particle size affects morphodynamics of the droplet drying at macro-nano length scales.</em>
763	<strong>Twinned boron nitrate nanocrystals as a proof of size-induced hexagonal-to-cubic phase transition</strong>	The explication of the origins of twinned structure of nanocrystalline grains of cubic boron nitride (c-BN) is presented. Such domain structure is a proof on structural transition from hexagonal to cubic phase during experimental path. As a result, the size based reduction in the transition temperatures required the change of phase diagram of nanocrystalline BN with respect to the diagram of bulk crystal.
764	<strong>Sequential subtractive and additive fabrication of tungsten micro-nano hierarchical structures under femtosecond laser irradiation</strong>	Femtosecond laser processing based top-down and bottom-up methods are both desired for the controllable preparation of ordered micro-nano functional structures. Here, taking tungsten as an example, we demonstrate that the femtosecond laser irradiation on solid surfaces can be developed as not only a top-down approach via the subtractive ablation process but also a bottom-up approach via the additive self-deposition process. The critical conditions for both processes to occur alternately and sequentially are investigated, with a unique kind of micro-nano hierarchical structures featuring with ordered micro cone arrays capped by controllable sand-dune like structures being fabricated. The uncovered laser-matter interaction mechanism can be inspiring for the development of new femtosecond laser fabrication techniques, and provide us more flexibility in designing and preparing the functional micro-nano surface structures.
765	<strong>Nanoclusters of &alpha;-Fe naturally formed after martensitic transformation in twinned martensite</strong>	Various Fe-C binary alloys with carbon content from 0.05 to 2.0 (wt.%) have been prepared and water-quenched at austenitizing temperatures. Fine structure of the twinned martensite in the quenched samples has been investigated by means of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) in order to understand the initial products during the formation of martensite structure. In the twinned structure (body-centered-cubic {112}&lt;111&gt;-type twin), TEM dark field observations have revealed that both matrix and twinned crystal regions are fully composed of ultra-fine particles (&alpha;-Fe nano-crystallites). The particles tend to have the same preferred direction (or texture) in the twinned martensite and the size is almost the same (1~2 nm). The ultra-fine particle structure has been commonly observed regardless of carbon content, but the existence of the fine particle structure is limited in the twinned martensite. After in-situ TEM heating, recrystallization occurred and the fine particles merged into larger &alpha;-Fe grains; at the same time, the twinned relationship also disappeared.
766	Time Resolved Photoluminescence Studies of degradation in GaInP/GaAs/Ge solar cells after 1MeV electron irradiation	The electrical properties of solar cells would degrade in space due to radiation environment. Among all the electrical parameters, lifetime of minorities is most sensitive one. Time resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) is a powerful method to character the behaviors of carriers as it has high time revolution that could reflect the reactions of carriers within nanoseconds. However the complex drift and diffusion in solar cells make the spectroscopy analysis much difficult. One dimension numerical calculations are used to investigate the diffusion, drifting and recombination of carriers, and the time-dependent photoluminescence decay was simulated. Calculation shows that both lifetime of minorities and light intensities would change the line shape of TRPL. The bimolecular recombination would change the curve from single-exponential to non-single-exponential one.<strong> </strong>By comparing with measured TRPL curves, one could get the lifetime of minorities in GaAs sub-cell. GaInP/GaAs/Ge solar cells were fabricated and irradiated by 1MeV electrons to study the decay of lifetimes of minorities. Fitting results show that the damage factor of lifetime of minorities in the middle GaAs solar cell under 1MeV electron irradiation is about <em>K&tau;</em>=4.8&times;10<sup>-15</sup> cm<sup>2</sup>/ns, which is similar with the calculated result from photoluminescence (PL) measurements.
767	Energy dissipation contributed on the machined depth via dynamic plowing lithography of AFM	In this study, the atomic force microscopy (AFM) tip-based dynamic plowing lithography (DPL) approach is employed to scratch on the poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) thin-film surface. A theoretical model is established based on the relationship between the tip energy dissipation and material removal volume, and the corresponding experiments are also conducted. Both the theoretical and experimental results show that the drive amplitude is proportional to the square of the machined depth of the nanoscale grooves. The mean deviations between the predicted and experimental depths are less than 10%. It is also indicated that the scratching velocity in the range of 0.01-80 &#x03BC;m/s is proportional to the square of the depth (1/h2), and the mean deviations between the predicted and experimental depths are also less than 7%. In addition, based on the above conclusions, a uniform ripple with desired dimensions can be achieved successfully by overlapping the machined nanogrooves. The wavelength and amplitude of the ripples are determined by controlling the feature size of nanogrooves.
768	<strong>Quantification of charge carriers participating in AFM to WFM magnetic phase transition in Na doped LaFeO<sub>3</sub> nano multiferroics</strong>	Multiferroic La<sub>1-x</sub>Na<sub>x</sub>FeO<sub>3</sub> (x=0.0, 0.05, 0.10 and 0.15) nanoparticles have been synthesized by citrate sol-gel auto combustion method. It is uniquely known for homogeneous distribution of particle size due to low temperature synthesis condition.  The Rietveld refinement of the X-ray diffraction pattern has exhibited the single phase orthorhombic perovskite structure. It is confirmed from micro Raman analysis that hole doping (Na) produces a structural crossover from Pnma to Pbnm space group. The red shift observed in UV-visible spectroscopy indicates shrinkage of band gap. Photoluminescence analysis independently supports the band gap shrinkage by the existence of violet-blue emission due to charge disproportion by oxygen related defects.  A changeover from semiconductor to metallic nature accompanied by the hopping of charge carrier between Fe<sup>3+</sup> to Fe<sup>2+</sup>/Fe<sup>4+ </sup>exchange interaction has revealed considerable increase in conductivity and dielectric constant. Finally, the doping helps to induce an antiferromagnetic (AFM) to weak ferromagnetic (WFM) state due to free carrier concentration. It is found that the hole driven Fe<sup>3+</sup> to Fe<sup>2+</sup>/Fe<sup>4+ </sup>exchange interactions with change in the Bohr magneton values from 4 &micro;<sub>B</sub> to 4.9 &micro;<sub>B</sub> are responsible for variation in the magnetization values.
769	<strong>Epitaxial ferroelectric Hf<sub>0.5</sub>Zr<sub>0.5</sub>O<sub>2</sub> thin film on buffered YSZ substrate through interface reaction</strong>	In this study, we used pulsed laser deposition to successfully grow epitaxial Hf<sub>0.5</sub>Zr<sub>0.5</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (HZO) films on yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) substrates using TiN as bottom electrode. It is found that the dual regulation structure of a TiO<sub>2</sub> buffer layer formed by interface reaction is the key to the epitaxial growth. The epitaxial HZO films exhibit ferroelectric behaviour with a remnant polarization up to 20 mC/cm<sup>2</sup>. X-ray diffraction and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy reveal the presence of nano domains, and clear epitaxial relation among different layers whose interfaces are relaxed by reconstruction. X-ray absorption spectroscopy provides deep insight into the microstructural origin of ferroelectricity in HZO, where the interface strain engineered ferroelectric state is manifested by the pseudo Jahn-Teller type of non-centrosymmetric <em>P</em>ca2<sub>1</sub> distortions.
770	<strong>Local lateral integration of 16-nm thick Ge nanowires on silicon on insulator substrates</strong>	In this contribution, we report on the growth of horizontal Ge nanowires inside extremely thin tunnels surrounded by oxide. This is achieved through selective lateral growth of Ge on silicon-on-insulator (001) substrates. The 16 nm high tunnels are formed by HCl vapor etching of Si followed by Ge growth in the same epitaxy chamber. Firstly, the benefit of growing the Ge nanowires at high temperature was highlighted to homogenize the length of the nanowires and achieve a high growth rate. Afterwards, we showed that increasing the tunnel depth led to a significant reduction of the growth rate. Finally, transmission electron microscopy showed that no defects were present in an array of ten Ge nanowires. These results are encouraging for the planar co-integration of heterogeneous materials on Si.
771	<strong>Dimension effect on the in-depth phase transition of MnAs/GaAs(001): from a thin film to a nano rod</strong>	We explore the dimension effect on the in-depth phase transition behavior of MnAs thin films on GaAs substrate by investigating the in-depth strain distribution with experiments and simulations. The strain distribution along the film growth direction is verified to be changed when a two-dimension thin film is thinned into a one-dimension nano-rod as a cross-section transmission electron microscopy (TEM) specimen, thus resulting in a significantly different transition behavior. Our work brings more insights into the transition mechanism of MnAs thin films and illustrates a noteworthy issue in TEM studies of the phase transition at the interface of epitaxial thin films.
772	<strong>AsH<sub>3</sub> Gas-Phase Ex-Situ Doping 3D Silicon Structures</strong>	Dopant incorporation in Si can be done in-situ during epitaxial growth, or ex-situ for localised material modification from a variety of sources including ion, solid, liquid, or gas. Gas-phase doping has the advantage that it does not require a thin film deposition, it should be more effective at entering tight spaces than a liquid, and it should be less damaging and more conformal than a beam-line ion implant. In this work we apply arsine (AsH<sub>3</sub>) gas at ~atmospheric pressures in order to n-type dope three-dimensional (3D) Si device structures. It was observed that the gas-phase doping can be either corrosive or gentle to thin-body Si depending on the process conditions. Initial doping processes caused damage to the Si due to etching but after process optimisation the structural integrity of the Si nanostructures could be maintained successfully. Moreover, it was noted that evaluating doping processes entirely on planar Si surfaces can be misleading: processes which appear promising initially may not be transferrable to non-planar thin-body structures like fins or nanowires, due to the unwanted Si etching effect. Overall, we found that gas-phase doping with AsH<sub>3</sub> could provide &gt;10<sup>20</sup> cm<sup>-3 </sup>electrically active As concentrations. This high As incorporation makes gas-phase doping very attractive for future gate-all-around devices, where the space between features will decline with continued transistor scaling.
773	Correlation anisotropy and stiffness of DNA molecules confined in nanochannels	The anisotropy of the orientational correlations in DNA molecules confined in cylindrical channels is explored by Monte Carlo simulation using a coarse-grained model of dsDNA. We find that the correlation function &lt;C(s)&gt;&#xF05E; in the transverse (confined) dimension exhibits the region of negative values in the whole range of channel sizes. Such a clear-cut sign of an opposite orientation of the chain segments represents a microscopic validation of the Odijk deflection mechanism in the narrow channels. At moderate-to-weak confinement, the negative &lt;C(s)&gt;&#xF05E; correlations imply a preference of DNA segments for transverse looping. The inclination for looping can explain the reduction of stiffness as well as enhanced knotting of confined DNA relative to that in bulk detected earlier at some channel sizes. Furthermore, it is shown, that the orientational persistence length Por fails to convey the apparent stiffness of DNA molecules in channels. Instead, the correlation lengths P&#x2551; and P&#xF05E; in the axial and transverse directions, respectively, encompass the channel-induced modifications of DNA stiffness.
774	Photonic trimming of quantum emitters via direct fabrication of metallic nanofeatures	In this paper we demonstrate the control of the emission of a GaAs quantum dot embedded in a GaAs/AlGaAs nanowire by the post-fabrication of a plasmonic grating on its surface. Using a direct electron beam induced deposition of Pt nanowires, we demonstrate an enhancement of the emission efficiency for the polarization parallel to the nanowires of 45%, with a 17% reduction of the photon lifetime. We believe that these results will help establish a new hybrid nanophotonic platform for efficient single photon sources.
775	Morphology and optical properties of Eu&sup2;&#x207A;-sensitized CsI(Na) thick film	Eu co-doping of CsI(Na) thick film was deposited by thermal evaporation on quartz substrate coated with a nano-reflective layer. The morphology and structure of these studied films, using SEM images and XRD patterns, had no distinguishable differences. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy ICP (OES) was utilized in order to measure sodium and europium concentrations in the deposition. Moreover, their optical properties were investigated by UV absorption, excitation, and emission spectroscopy in the wavelength region 200&#x2012;800 nm. The results indicated that Eu-sensitizing material enhanced the luminescence intensity of the CsI(Na) columnar-structure film compared to a conventional CsI(Na) scintillator. This increase was attributed to both Eu high quantum efficiency and energy transfer between the activator and sensitizer, considered with a view to improving scintillator properties. Ion beam induced luminescence (IBIL) measurements also confirm the luminescence results.
776	Correlation between Raman shift, Neel temperature, and optical band gap of NiO nanoparticles and their size dependences	With structural miniaturization down to the nanoscale, the detectable parameters of materials no longer remain constant but become tunable. For NiO nanoparticles example, Raman shift and Neel temperature increase while optical band gap decreases with increasing the nanoparticle size. Herein, we developed the models to describe the size dependences of these seemingly uncorrelated parameters for NiO nanoparticles, based on the size-dependent cohesive energy model. Consistency between our theoretical predictions and the corresponding experimental results not only verified the accuracy of our developed models but also provided straight forward insight into the essentiality of cohesive energy in describing the effect of size on the materials properties of NiO nanoparticles.

778	Improving detection efficiency of superconducting nanowire single-photon detector using multilayer antireflection coating	Double-cavity with backside optical coupling is one of the prevalent optical structures for superconducting nanowire single photon detector. A single layer anti-reflection coating (ARC) on the backside of the substrate was often adopted to enhance the transmittance to the substrate. We here applied a multilayer ARC to further increase the transmittance from 94.5% to 99.5%. NbTiN SNSPD made on such a substrate with double cavity structure presented a system detection efficiency of 90.1% at a dark count rate (DCR) of 100 Hz, which is the best value reported for backside optical coupled SNSPD at 1550 nm. 779	<strong>Thermally Activated Delayed</strong><strong><strong> </strong></strong><strong><strong>Fluorescence Organic Dots for Two-Photon Fluorescence Lifetime Imaging</strong></strong>	Auto&#xFB02;uorescence is a major challenge in complex tissue imaging when molecules present in the biological tissue compete with the &#xFB02;uorophore. This issue may be resolved by designing organic molecules with long fluorescence lifetimes. The present work reports the two-photon absorption properties of a thermally activated delayed fluorescence molecule with carbazole as electron donor and dicyanobenzene as electron acceptor (i.e., 4CzIPN). Our work aptly demonstrates that TADF molecules are promising candidates of nonlinear optical probes for developing next-generation multiphoton FLIM  applications.
780	Large-scale preparation of zno nanostructure from electric arc furnace dust	Abstract: zinc oxide nanostructures are prepared in a large scale through selective leaching zinc from electric arc furnace dust (EAF) using a deep eutectic solvent (DES), followed by precipitation of ZnO from DES upon introduction of a simple antisolvent water. The zinc and lead are selectively dissolved in ChCl-urea deep eutectic solvent and the lead ions in leaching solution are removed by cementation with zinc plates. The addition of deionized water to the resulting solution leads to formation of mixed precipitate of ZnO and zinc carbonate hydroxide, calcination of which generates ZnO nanostructures. The ZnO nanostructures are spherical which is composed of ultrathin mesoporous nanosheets with a thickness of around 10 nm and pore sizes about 10-40 nm. Especially, this ZnO nanoclusters have a high specific surface area and exhibit excellent photocatalytic activity as good as that of a commercial photocatalyst P-25 TiO2 in the terms of photocatalytic degradation of methyl orange.
781	High energy X-ray radiography of laser-shock metal dynamic fragmentation using high-intensity short-pulse laser	The dynamic fragmentation of shock-loaded high-Z metal is of considerable importance for both basic and applied science. The areal density and mass-velocity distribution are crucial factors in understanding this issue. Experimental methods, such as pulsed X-ray radiography and proton radiography, have been utilized to obtain information on such factors; however, they are restricted to a complex device and the spatial resolution in the order of 100 &#x03BC;m. In this work, we present the high-quality radiography of the dynamic fragmentation of laser shock-loaded tin, with good two-dimensional (2D) spatial resolution. Dynamic fragmentation is generated via the intense nanosecond-laser shock-loaded tin. A high-energy X-ray source is realized by the interaction of intense picosecond-pulses with an Au micro-wire target, attached to a low-Z substrate material. A high 2D resolution of 12 &#x03BC;m is achieved by point-projection radiography. The dynamic-fragmentation radiography is clear, and the signal-to-noise ratio is sufficiently high, for a single-shot experiment. This unique technique has potential application in high energy density experiments.
782	Temperature and carrier density dependence of electron effective mass and band gap in semiconductor carbon nanotubes at elevated temperature: analytical calculations	The effects of temperature and carrier density on the self-energy of electrons in semiconductor carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are theoretically studied by using the Matsubara Green's function approach. We show that the band gap is slightly changed whereas the eletron effective mass is strongly affected by the temperature and electron density. Furthermore, an interesting discrepancy of the results obtained from the screening dynamical approximation and that from the Hartree-Fock approximation is shown. Especially, the calculated quantities are compared to the results obtained in a recent experiment and a good agreement for the energy shift is seen. These results could help clarifying the role of the Coulomb interaction and the correlation and exchange energy on the optical properties of CNTs in a wide range of temperature and density.
783	<strong>Universal rotation of nanowires in static uniform electric fields in viscous dielectric liquids</strong>	Wide utilization of nanomanipulation as a promising approach in microorganisms, nanoelectromechanical systems and assembly of nanostructures remarks the importance of nanostructures&rsquo; motion in electric fields. Here, we study the rotational dynamics of metallic and non-metallic nanowires (NWs) in a static uniform electric field in viscous dielectric liquids. For metallic NWs, it has been theoretically shown that the electric field-induced rotation is practically independent of the geometrical dimensions and electrical properties of NWs. Our experimental results for suspended silver (Ag) NWs in microscope oil are perfectly in agreement with this model. However, in the case of TiO<sub>2</sub> NWs, as an example of non-metallic NWs, we surprisingly observe the exactly same electromechanical torque as metallic Ag NWs under the same experimental conditions. This is mainly explained by NWs&rsquo; high aspect-ratio which allows to ignore the non-axial component of the electric field inside the NWs. Therefore, all high-aspect-ratio metallic Ag and non-metallic TiO<sub>2</sub> NWs demonstrate an identical rotational speed in the same dielectric liquid and electric field. This result can be used for controllable alignment or synchronous rotation of an ensemble of different type of NWs for hybrid and advanced devices.
784	<strong>CNTs-H2O Nanofluid Thin Film Flow over a Nonlinear Extending Disc</strong>	The aim of this research is the improvement towards the consumption of energy in the field of engineering and industry. The efforts have been paid to the enhancement of heat transmission and cooling process through a nanofluid coating of a nonlinear stretching disc. The combination of Water (H2O) and multiple walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) / single walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNT) have been used as a nanofluid.  The spreading of a thin nano-layer with variable thickness over a nonlinear and radially stretching surface has been considered. The estimated results of the problem have been accomplished using the optimal approach. The important physical parameters of skin friction and Nusselt number have been calculated and discussed. The other embedding parameters like generalized magnetic parameter, Prantl number, nanofluid volume fraction and Eckert number have been intended and discussed.
785	Ultraviolet Relaxation Dynamics in Uracil: Time-resolved Photoion Yield Studies Using a Laser-based Thermal Desorption Source	Wavelength-dependent measurements of the RNA base uracil, undertaken with nanosecond ultraviolet laser pulses, have previously identified a fragment at m/z = 84 (corresponding to the C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>4</sub>N<sub>2</sub>O<sup>+</sup> ion) at excitation wavelengths {less than or equal to}232 nm. This has been interpreted as a possible signature of a theoretically predicted ultrafast ring-opening occurring on a neutral excited state potential energy surface. To further investigate the dynamics of this mechanism, and also the non-adiabatic dynamics operating more generally in uracil, we have used a newly-built ultra-high vacuum spectrometer incorporating a laser-based thermal desorption source to perform time-resolved ion-yield measurements at pump wavelengths of 267 nm, 220 nm and 200 nm. We also report complementary data obtained for the related species 2-thiouracil following 267 nm excitation. Where direct comparisons can be made (267 nm), our findings are in good agreement with previously reported measurements conducted on these systems using cold molecular beams, demonstrating that the role of initial internal energy on the excited state dynamics is negligible. Our 220 nm and 200 nm data also represent the first reported ultrafast study of uracil at pump wavelengths &lt;250 nm, revealing extremely rapid (&lt;200 fs) relaxation of the bright S<sub>3</sub>(<sup>1</sup>&#x03C0;&#x03C0;*) state. These measurements do not, however, provide any evidence for the appearance of the m/z = 84 fragment within the first few hundred picoseconds following excitation. This key finding indicates that the detection of this specific species in previous nanosecond work is not directly related to an ultrafast ring opening process. An alternative excited state process, operating on a more extended timescale, remains an open possibility.
786	In-doped Sb nanowires self-assembled by MOCVD for high speed phase change memories	We investigated the Phase Change Memory (PCM) behavior of In-doped Sb nanowires (NWs) with diameters of about 20 nm, which were self-assembled by Metalorganic Chemical Vapor Deposition (MOCVD) via the vapor-liquid-solid mechanism, catalyzed by Au nanoparticles. The PCM behavior of the NWs was proved, and it was shown to have low reset power (~ 400 &mu;W) and energy (~ 10 pJ) consumption, as well as faster switching capabilities with respect to standard Ge-Sb-Te based devices. In particular, reversible set and reset switches by voltage pulses as short as 25 ns were demonstrated. The obtained results are useful for understanding the effects of downscaling in PCM devices and for the exploration of innovative PCM architectures and materials.
787	<strong>Numerical Study of MHD Nanofluid Natural Convection and Aspect Ratio in a Baffled U-shaped Enclosure </strong>	In this study, nanofluid natural convection and cavity aspect ratio in a baffled U-shaped enclosure in present of magnetic field is investigated. Lattice Boltzmann method (LBM) is used to study present problems. KKL (Koo-Kleinstreuer-Li) correlation, which considering the effect of Brownian motion on the nanofluid effective thermal conductivity, is applied to calculate the nanofluid effective thermal conductivity and viscosity. Effect of Rayleigh number, Hartmann number, nanoparticle volume fraction and aspect ratio on the fluid flow and heat transfer characteristics have been investigated. The results reveal that the average Nusselt number is an increasing function of the Rayleigh number and nanoparticle solid volume fraction regardless the cavity aspect ratio. The rate of heat transfer increases with increasing the aspect ratio. Moreover, it can be found that the heat transfer rate is suppressed by magnetic field.
788	<strong>MHD three dimensional boundary layer flow and heat transfer of Cu- and Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>&ndash;water nanofluids over an exponentially stretching sheet with convective heat and mass transfer boundary conditions</strong>	Present article analyze the magnetohydrodynamic three dimensional flow comprising Cu and Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>water based nanofluids. The effects of heat and mass transfer with the effects of nanoparticles are carried out in the presence of thermal radiation, viscous dissipation, and convective heat and mass transfer boundary conditions. By applying the appropriate similarity transformations the governing partial differential equations of velocity, temperature and nanoparticle volume fraction are reduce to a system of nonlinear ordinary differential equations. An optimal homotopy analysis method (OHAM) is applied to evaluate the convergent power series solutions. The influences of pertinent parameters on the dimensionless velocity, temperature and nanoparticle volume fraction are depicted through graphs. Calculations of Nusselt number, skin friction coefficients and the local Sherwood number are evaluated through tables. An excellent comparison also has been made with the previously published literature.
789	<strong>The Dependence of Hot-Electron Temperature and Hot-Phonon Lifetime on Electric Field in GaN-based Heterostructures </strong>	Experimental and analytical investigations of two-dimensional electron gas (2DEG) channel in Al<sub>0.3</sub>Ga<sub>0.7</sub>N/AlN/GaN heterostructures with and without <em>in situ</em> Si<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> surface passivation layer were carried out at high electric fields using nanosecond pulsed I-V measurements. The longitudinal optical (LO)-phonon lifetime was estimated from the measured and calculated dependence of hot-electron temperature on supplied electric power. The hot-electron temperatures in these heterostructures with and without <em>in situ</em> Si<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> surface passivation layer were calculated as 496 K and 515 K at 175 kV/cm, respectively. Dependence of hot-phonon lifetimes on the applied electric field was compared and discussed for the investigated samples. It was found that the hot-phonon lifetime changes from 2.3 to 5.4 fs with the increasing electric field.
790	<strong>The dependence of Schottky (I&#x2012;V) characteristics on the metal probe size in nano metal&#x2012;semiconductor contacts</strong>	We have studied the dependence of Schottky (I&#x2012;V) characteristics on the metal contact size in nanoscale metal&#x2012;semiconductor (M&#x2012;S) junctions. Using special nano&#x2012;probes in conductive atomic force microscope, we have shown that the Schottky (I&#x2012;V) characteristic of M&#x2012;S junction depends strongly on the metal contact size, rather than the semiconductor bulk properties as in the planar microscale M&#x2012;S junctions. The theoretical calculations from our model show good agreement with the experimental (I&#x2012;V) data for a wide range of nano&#x2012;probe sizes. Our results indicate the strong correlation between electric field at the M&#x2012;S interface and the Schottky rectification behavior. The calculated (I&#x2012;V) data show a smooth transition from the reverse rectification behavior to the normal rectification behavior as the nano&#x2012;probe radius increases from sub-10 nm to 100 nm. Our results clearly demonstrate the effect of metal contact size in nano Schottky diodes, which would help in designing a new type of nano-devices at sub-10 nm scale.
791	Development of a tomographic Mueller-matrix scatterometer for nanostructure metrology	In this paper, we describe the development of a novel instrument, tentatively called tomographic Mueller-matrix scatterometer (TMS), which enables to illuminate sequentially a sample by a plane wave with varying illumination directions, and to record, for each illumination, the polarized scattered-field along various directions of observation in the form of scattering Mueller matrices. The incidence angle is varied from 0{degree sign} to 65.6{degree sign} with the rotation of a flat mirror that changes the position of the focal point of a light beam on the back focal plane of a high numerical aperture objective lens. The scattering Mueller matrices are collected over a wide range of scattering angles (0{degree sign}~67{degree sign}) and azimuthal angles (0{degree sign}~360{degree sign}). The developed instrument was then applied for the measurement of nanostructures in combination with an inverse scattering problem solving technique. The experiment performed on a periodic nanostructure preliminarily demonstrates the performance of TMS as well as its potential in nanostructure metrology. It is expected that the TMS would be a powerful tool for characterizing the polarized scattered-field distributions and measuring nanostructures in nanomanufacturing.
792	The nitrogen acceptor in 2H-polytype synthetic MoS2 assessed by multifrequency electron spin resonance	Electron spin resonance (ESR) study on 2H-polytype synthetic MoS2had revealed the N acceptor dopants as being characterized by a spectrum of axial symmetry [g&#x2225; = 2.032(2); g&#xF05E;= 2.270(2)], typical for a hole-type center in MoS2. The N impurities substitute for S sites, with density of ~2.3 x 1017 cm-3, which accounts for the overall p-type doping. Observed for the applied magnetic field directed along the c-axis, the signal consists of a 14N primary hyperfine triplet of splitting constant A&#x2225; = 14.7 {plus minus} 0.2 G superimposed on acorrelated Gaussiansingle central line (CL) of peak-to-peak width&#x0394;Bpp = 15.3 {plus minus} 0.5 G, the latter making up only ~26% of the total signal intensity.Current ESR signal saturation studiesindicatea N acceptor spin-lattice relaxation time T1(4.2 K)&#x2248; 3 x 10-4s, notably different from the much smallerAs acceptor'sT1in geological MoS2. Concerning the thermal stability of the dopant, the N acceptoris found to be drastically passivated when exposed to H2at ~500 {degree sign}C. Yet, subsequent reactivation attempts in vacuum at temperatures up to 740 {degree sign}C appear unsuccessful, urginggreat caution with conventional forming gas treatments at T&#x2273;500{degree sign}C. Combination of careful K- and Q-band ESR monitoring of the T-dependent signal intensity resulted in the consolidation of the N dopant as a shallow acceptor of activation energy Ea = 45 {plus minus} 7 meV. The total of the results establish N as a promising candidate for stable covalently bonded p-type doping of MoS2 layers intended for application in novel nanoelectronic devices.
793	Stacked multilayer organic WORM memory	The present work reports on a successful fabrication of stacked multilayer write once read many times (WORM) organic memory devices, where the active material is a nanocomposite composed of carbon nanospheres/epoxy resin (CS/ER). The I<sub>ON</sub>/ I<sub>OFF</sub> ratio reached 10<sup>4</sup>, with the low threshold voltages between 2.0 V - 3.2 V.
794	Comparative optimization of squeezing flow through entropy generation accounting five different types of nanoparticles	The main objective of this article is to analyze the comparative study of five water base nanofluids. Nanofluids are comprises of Titanium oxide or Titania (<em>TiO</em>2), Aluminum oxide or Alumina (<em>AL</em>2<em>O</em>3), Copper oxide (<em>CuO</em>), Copper (<em>Cu</em>) and Silver (<em>Ag</em>) and water (<em>H</em>2<em>O</em>). Consider flow is unsteady between two sheets. Upper sheet squeezing towards lower sheet and lower sheet is porous and stretchable. Moreover thermal radiation, applied magnetic field, viscous dissipation and joule heating effects are accounted. Entropy generation effect is also evaluated. Second law of thermodynamics is implemented for the entropy generation. PDE's are transformed to ODE's by transformations procedure. ODE's system is numerically solved by shooting technique. Influences of various flow parameters on velocity, temperature, entropy generation and Began number is examined in graphs. Numerical results for skin friction and Nusselt number is tabulated. The obtained results show that velocity decays for larger values of magnetic parameter and porosity while it enhanced through squeezing parameter. Temperature is increasing function of Eckert number, magnetic parameter, squeezing parameter and nanoparticles volume fraction. Entropy generation is increased with thermal radiation, Prandtl number, volume fraction and Eckert number.
795	Wafer-Scale Fabrication of CMOS-compatible, High Aspect Ratio Encapsulated Nanochannels	Nanochannels are of great interest in nanofluidics for DNA sequencing, chromatography and drug delivery. However, typical nanochannel fabrication methods are ill-suited for full integration with other microfabricated components or devices. Here, we demonstrate nanochannels with an aspect ratio (length to cross-sectional dimension) greater than 400,000-where the width (35-40 nm) and height (140-150 nm) of the channels are sufficiently small to elongate macromolecules-at channel lengths on the order of mm. We fabricate these channels with a CMOS-compatible tool set, allowing for the batch fabrication of a multitude of channels and with the further potential of full integration with solid-state electronic and photonic devices on the same wafer. Last, we demonstrate the versatility of our nanochannel fabrication platform by loading the channels with six different liquids and verify that the fluid flow dynamics for each liquid can be well-estimated with Washburn's equation.
796	Exploring Fractality of Microcrystalline Diamond Films	Diamond is renowned as a material with superlative physical qualities, most of which originate from the strong covalent bonding between its atoms. The possibility to deposit polycrystalline diamond films via chemical vapor deposition (CVD) methods on large areas and on a large variety of substrates is posing numerous scientific challenges but also enables relevant industrial applications. Especially for small grain sizes, the grain&rsquo;s misorientation and consequently the atomic structure of grain boundaries play a significant role on transport properties and mechanical properties. Hence, the size and shape of the crystallites of poly- and nanocrystalline diamond films are one important key to optimize film properties for their specific applications. Fractal theory helps to find and define order in systems where disorder seems to prevail. Therefore, we apply fractal geometry analysis to characterize the grain morphology and surface topology of CVD grown diamond films.
797	Superhydrophobic, Carbon-Infiltrated Carbon Nanotubes on Si and 316L Stainless Steel with Tunable Geometry	Use of carbon nanotubes to create superhydrophobic coatings has been considered due to their ability to offer a relatively uniform nanostructure.  However, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) may be considered delicate with a typical diameter of tens of nanometers for a multi-walled CNT; as-grown carbon nanotubes often require the addition of a thin-film hydrophobic coating to render them superhydrophobic.  Furthermore, fine control over the diameter of the as-grown CNTs, or overall nanostructure is difficult. This work demonstrates the utility of using carbon infiltration to layer amorphous carbon on multi-walled nanotubes to improve structural integrity and achieve superhydrophobic behavior with tunable geometry.  These carbon-infiltrated carbon nanotube (CICNT) surfaces exhibit an increased number of contact points between neighboring tubes, resulting in a composite structure with improved mechanical stability.  Additionally, the native surface can be rendered superhydrophobic with a vacuum pyrolysis treatment, with contact angles as high as 160&deg; and contact angle hysteresis on the order of 1&deg;.  CICNT diameter, static contact angle, sliding angle, and contact angle hysteresis were examined for varying levels of carbon-infiltration to determine the effect of infiltration on superhydrophobicity.  The same superhydrophobic behavior and tunable geometry was also observed with CICNTs grown directly on stainless steel without an additional catalyst layer.  The ability to tune the geometry while maintaining superhydrophobic behavior offers significant potential in condensation heat transfer, anti-icing, microfluidics, anti-microbial surfaces and other bio-applications where control over the nanostructure is beneficial.
798	Comparative catalytic and bacteriostatic properties of silver nanoparticles biosynthesized using three kind of polysaccharide	Silver nanoparticles (Ag NPs) were biosynthesized using konjac glucomannan (KGM), &#x03BA;-carrageenan (CRG) and inulin as reducing and capping agent through one spot method. The structure and morphology of Ag NPs were investigated with UV-visible spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) and X-Ray diffraction (XRD). The catalysis and antibacterial properties were further comparative investigated. The results illustrated that Ag NPs were fabricated affected by the incubation temperature and polysaccharide category. CRG displayed a stronger reduction of Ag+ than KGM, and the lowest was inulin. Higher incubation temperature promoted the reduction of Ag NPs. As for Ag100 NPs, the kapp of CRG, inulin and KGM based Ag NPs were 5.80&#x00D7;10-2 s 1, 2.14&#x00D7;10-2 s 1, and 2.16&#x00D7;10-2 s 1 respectively. The further bacteriostatic test displayed excellent antimicrobial activity of Ag NPs for Escherichia coli and Staphyloccocus aureus. The results convinced that natural polysaccharide could be green and effective reducing and stabilizing agent for Ag NPs biosynthesis. Their excellent antibacterial and catalytic properties may provide good choice in medical, food and biological field.
799	Efficiency enhancement of flexible OLEDs by using nano-corrugated substrates and conformal Ag transparent anodes	In flexible OLEDs (FOLEDs), the traditional ITO anode has disadvantages such as refractive-index mismatches among substrate and other functional layers, leads to light loss of nearly 80%, meanwhile, the brittle nature and lack in raw material of ITO anode hinder its further applications. We investigated an efficient FOLED using a semi-transparent silver (Ag) anode, whereas the whole device was built on a nano-corrugated flexible polycarbonate (PC) substrate prepared by thermal nanoimprint lithography. The corrugations were well preserved on each layer of the device, both the micro-cavity effect and surface plasmon polariton (SPP) modes of light loss were effectively suppressed. As a result, the current efficiency of the FOLED using a conformal corrugated Ag anode enhanced by 100% compared with a planar Ag anode device, and enhanced by 13% with conventional ITO device. In addition, owing to the quasi-periodical arrangements of the corrugations, the device achieved broad spectra and Lambertian angular emission. The Ag anode significantly improved the bending properties of the OLED as compared to the conventional ITO device, leading to a longer lifetime in practical use. The proposed manufacturing strategy will be useful for fabricating nano corrugations on plastic substrate of FOLED in a cost-effective and convenient manner.
800	Coupling between the localized plasmon resonance excitation and the longitudinal magneto-optical Kerr effect in Au/Co/Au plasmonic nanostructures	We report the observation and enhancement of the longitudinal magneto-optical Kerr effect in anisotropic Au/Co/Au plasmonic nanostructures. We fabricated Au/Co/Au rectangular patch arrays with different short axis lengths varied from 125 to 245 nm. When linearly polarized light with wavelength of 785 nm was illuminated to the structure, local-mode surface plasmons were resonantly excited in the structure with 200 nm length. In this condition, significant enhancement of the magnitude of the complex Kerr rotation was observed. Our results suggest that the local mode plasmon resonance couples with and enhances the longitudinal magneto-optical Kerr effect.
801	<strong>Huge Magnetoresistance in p-type Silicon Nanowires</strong>	Silicon nanowires (SiNWs) were formed by metal &ndash;assisted chemical etching of crystalline silicon, in a mixture of aqueous HF and AgNO<sub>3</sub> chemical solutions. The magnetic field effects on the current of Ag/SiNWs/Si/Al structures have been studied. Magnetoresistance (MR) measurements, at room temperature, revealed positive and negative MR depending on the etching time and the applied voltage. Huge positive MR of about 1200 % has been observed at low field. The negative MR  is attributed to the weak localization (WL) effect, while the positive one is related to the ohmic regime, where holes control the current. The MR effect depends on the applied voltage and the length of the SiNWs. The huge MR effect in SiNWs can be exploited in magnetic-field sensor devices.
802	Effect of Addition of SiC and Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> Refractories on Kapitza Resistance of Antimonide-Telluride	Invoking Effective Media Percolation theory (EMPT), Hasselaman and Johnson effective media theory (EMT), and Nan and Birringer EMT, the effect of addition of SiC and Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>nanoparticles on Kapitza resistance (<em>R<sub>Bd</sub></em>) of Ni<sub>0.05</sub>Mo<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5.4</sub>Te<sub>1.6</sub> was investigated. Pore size and their volume distribution, and surface area were characterized using BET technique to correlate pore effect and surface area on <em>R<sub>Bd</sub></em>. Bounds for effective thermal conductivity were determined using Lipton&ndash;Vernescu model. Variation of thermal conductance with respect to temperature was studied and compared with the results of other materials. According to EMPT, <em>R<sub>Bd</sub></em> in Ni<sub>0.05</sub>Mo<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5.4</sub>Te<sub>1.6</sub>/SiC composites ranged from 3.84 &times; 10<sup>-7</sup> to 5.42 &times; 10<sup>-7</sup> m<sup>2</sup>KW<sup>&ndash;1 </sup>and 3.36 to 3.86 m<sup>2</sup>KW<sup>&ndash;1 </sup>for Ni<sub>0.05</sub>Mo<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5.4</sub>Te<sub>1.6</sub>/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> composites. Kapitza radius (<em>a<sub>K</sub></em>) for SiC samples was ranged between 2.01 - 2.84 &mu;m; for Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples it was 1.86 &mu;m. Hasselman-Johnson model gave <em>R<sub>Bd</sub></em> values, 55%, 51%, and 8% more than what EMPT is predicting, but of the same order and higher <em>a<sub>K</sub></em> values for SiC samples and lowest for Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> samples. Nan-Birringer model yielded large <em>a<sub>K</sub></em> of 7.25 &mu;m and <em>R<sub>Bd</sub></em> ~ 1.4 &times; 10<sup>&ndash;6  </sup>m<sup>2</sup>KW<sup>&ndash;1 </sup>for Ni<sub>0.05</sub>Mo<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5.4</sub>Te<sub>1.6</sub>/SiC. So obtained parameters are reasonable estimates. Mechanical properties were studied using micro&ndash;indentation technique and their effect on effective thermal properties was ascertained. Addition of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles aided in enhancing mechanical properties of bulk material.
803	Ag nanoparticles surface plasmon enhanced electroluminescence from n-ZnO/InAlN/p-GaN heterojunction light-emitting diodes	Ag nanoparticles (NPs) were used to demonstrate the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) enhanced electroluminescence from n-ZnO/InAlN/p-GaN heterojunction light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Ag NPs were hydrothermally synthesized with an average diameter as 30 nm that was well matched to the predicted optimal result of the finite-difference-time-domain (FDTD) calculation. An 1.7-fold and 1.4-fold enhancement in photoluminescence intensity were measured by top excitation of Ag NPs coupled with GaN and ZnO, respectively. An 1.2-fold enhancement in electroluminescence intensity was obtained by lighting the n-ZnO/InAlN/p-GaN heterojunction LEDs coupled with Ag NPs.
804	<strong>The role of convection in gas and liquid phases at droplet evaporation</strong>	The article presents the measuring results of droplet velocity and temperature fields using non-contact optical methods: Particle Image Velocity (PIV), Planar Laser Induced Fluorescence (PLIF) and Thermal imager. The analysis of experimental data has shown that in the initial period of water drop evaporation, the predominant role in the heat exchange is played by the thermal Marangoni convection. However, for an aqueous salt solution, in spite of the strong influence of the surfactant, the dominant role passes to the solutal Marangoni convection (<em>Ma<sub>C</sub></em>). The results of the analysis contained in this article can be used to describe not only drops and thin films of solutions, including nano- and micro-coatings, but drops falling on the wall. This is due to the fact that in the first seconds after the drop falling, convection and heat transfer in the liquid are maximum. Under such conditions it is important to realize an accurate numerical simulation to assess the degree of the wall cooling and to calculate the non-stationary evaporation. When simulating heat transfer, it is incorrect to neglect free convection in gas or liquid due to their strong nonlinear influence on each other. The heat exchange in the drop is extremely conservative to convection in the liquid (the Peclet number <em>Pe</em> = 100 and the Nusselt number <em>Nu</em> = 4).
805	Force-detected high-frequency electron spin resonance spectroscopy of fast-relaxing spin systems using magnet-mounted SiNx nanomembrane	While force-detected electron spin resonance (ESR) using microcantilever can achieve high spinssensitivity, it has several technical and principle problems when used as a spectroscopic technique. Insthis study, we report a conceptually novel broadband high-frequency ESR spectroscopic technique.sIn contrast to the ordinary force-detected ESR technique, which detects the magnetization changesdue to the saturation effect, this method measures the increase in temperature in the process ofsspin relaxation by using the temperature-dependent magnetization. To demonstrate its principle,swe developed a silicon nitride nanomembrane-based force-detected ESR spectrometer, which can besstably operated even at high magnetic elds. Test measurements were performed for samples withsdifferent spin relaxation times. We succeeded in obtaining a seamless ESR spectrum in magneticselds of 15 T and frequencies of 636 GHz without signicant spectral distortion. A high spinssensitivity of 10^12 spins/G was obtained, which was independent of the spin relaxation time. Thesesresults show that this technique can be used as a practical method in research elds where thesHFESR technique is applicable.
806	Suppression of charge ordering and stabilization of ferromagnetism in Pr0.5Sr0.5MnO3 Nanomanganite	Particle size effects on nanosized half-doped Pr0.5Sr0.5MnO3 (PSMO) manganite has been investigated by ac-susceptibility, electronic- transport and dc- magnetic measurements. We have found ground state low temperature charge-ordering is suppressed and ferro-antiferromagnetic transition is smeared out in PSMO nanoparticles. Ac-susceptibility and dc-magnetic measurements exhibit ferromagnetic nature in low temperature regime with a signature of metastable magnetic state. Temperature dependent resistivity under various external magnetic fields confirms the suppression of charge ordering state and exhibit metallic-insulator transition around 160 K. We report maximum 60% magneto resistance is estimated for lowest particle size around transition temperature. Appearance of ferromagnetism and metallicity in PSMO nano manganite has been explained in limelight of enhanced surface disorder.
807	<strong><strong>Spatial potential fluctuation at CdSe nanowire/Au Schottky junctions</strong></strong>	Understanding the electrical transport mechanism across the interface of metal/semiconductor nanostructure is of significant importance for the fabrication of high performance nano&ndash;electric and nano&ndash;optoelectric devices. In this paper, we have fabricated Schottky junctions based on single CdSe nanowires (NWs), in which Au was used as the Schottky contact, and In/Au was used as the Ohmic contact with CdSe NW. The Schottky junctions exhibit a clear rectification behavior. At room temperature, the turn&ndash;on voltage of a typical Schottky junction is about 0.85 V, and the rectification ratio is about 1&times;10<sup>4</sup>. The temperature&ndash;dependent electrical transport characteristics of typical CdSe NW/Au Schottky junctions were characterized and analyzed. The ideality factor decreases and the zero&ndash;bias barrier height increases monotonously with an increase in temperature from 287 to 402 K. We attributed the temperature&ndash;dependent electrical transport characteristics to the barrier height inhomogeneity at the CdSe NW/Au interface. The electrical transport characteristics have been analyzed quantitatively with a spatial potential fluctuation model, in which the Schottky barrier height obeys the Gaussian distribution. The standard deviation of the barrier height distribution is up to 13.6% of the zero&ndash;bias mean barrier height, which indicates large inhomogeneity at the CdSe NW/Au interface.
808	Suppression of higher diffraction orders in the extreme ultraviolet range by a reflective quasi-random square nano-pillar array	Higher diffraction orders of a grating introduce so-called harmonics contamination that leads to ambiguity in the spectral data. They are also present in "monochromatic" output beams processed by grating monochromators at synchrotron radiation facilities, making calibration results of optical elements and detectors imprecise. The paper describes a new design of a reflective quasi-random square nano-pillar array grating to reduce the amount of data of the grating relief pattern that is ten centimeters in size and suppresses higher diffraction orders in the extreme ultraviolet range. In addition, a laboratory-scale grating monochromator equipped with the grating has been developed to test its spectroscopy characteristics in the grazing incident mode. The results illustrate that it can suppress higher diffraction orders and maintain the spectrum resolution power as an ordinary grating in the grazing incident mode. The grating has great potential in harmonics suppression in the field of synchrotron radiation, spectral diagnostics of plasma, and astrophysics.
809	<strong>Learning mechanisms in memristor networks based on GaN nanomembranes </strong>	We demonstrate experimentally that single crystalline GaN nanomembranes arranged in simple networks exhibit learning mechanisms such as habituation and dishabituation followed by storage of the response to a certain electrical stimulus. These artificial learning mechanisms are analogous to non-associative learning processes which are identical in simple animals and human beings. We found that the learning time depends on the number of GaN membranes in parallel, this parameter decreasing with 30% when three memristors are connected in parallel compared to the learning time of a single memristor. Moreover, an increased number of parallel memristors reduces the eventual asymmetry in the temporal response of the circuit at positive and negative step voltages.
810	<strong>Ni/Graphitic Carbon Core-Shell Nanostructured based Light Weight Elastomeric Composites for Ku-Band Microwave Absorbing Applications </strong>	Graphitic carbon coated Ni metal core nanoparticles are synthesized using controlled thermal treatment of Ni-hydroxide in aniline-formaldehyde copolymer matrix under N<sub>2</sub> atmosphere. The structural and microstructural studies substantiate the formation of graphitic shell on metallic nickel core. The 850&deg;C heat treated core-shell structured material is ferromagnetic in nature with high saturation magnetization. The blocking temperature is above the room temperature. The sample with the highest value of magnetic moment is impregnated in rubber matrix to prepare composite samples with core-shell nanomaterials for different weight fractions. The sample with 70 wt% Ni/Graphitic carbon core-shell in elastomeric rubber matrix showed the optimal microwave absorption at fairly low thickness of ~ 1mm. This is attributed to the optimized combination of the effective impedance matching and interfacial polarization losses. Further increase in Ni/Graphitic carbon filler material resulted into reduced microwave absorption due to greater mismatch of impedance as compared to the desired free space impedance of ~377&Omega;. Thus, the optimized composite material is of great potential for microwave absorption in Ku band.
811	2D nanoporous membrane for cation removal from water II. Maximum desalination by iron flocculation	In our previous work [J. Chem. Phys. 148, 222804 (2018)] we have studied the effectiveness of nanoporous graphene and molybdenum disulfide to remove cations with distinct valences from water. Inspired by that work, we now employ Molecular Dynamics simulations of a mixture of 1:1 and 3:1 salts. We explore the effect of adding ferric chloride as a flocculant to an aqueous sodium chloride solution. The NaCl rejection by the nanomembranes is enhanced due to the addition of the multivalent cation from ~70% to 100%. Our findings indicate that the mechanism behind this effect is the ionic clustering due to the presence of the multivalent ion combined with the dielectric discontinuity at the nanopore. This result shows that a simple flocculant can maximize the water desalination by nanopores.
812	<strong>Simultaneous dispersive and covalent monolayer MoS<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> cluster heterostructures: Insights into their enhanced photocatalytic activity</strong>	Tuning electron transfer at interface, largely depending upon interfacial interaction, is paramount to rationally designing nanoscale heterostructures with desirable performance for future electronics, optoelectronics, and solar energy conversion. Here, we explore the interfacial interaction between monolayer MoS<sub>2</sub> and TiO<sub>2</sub> cluster to elucidate the mechanism of the enhanced photocatalytic activity of their hybrids. It is firstly revealed that both dispersive (van der Waals forces) and covalent interactions can simultaneously exist in the monolayer MoS<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> cluster heterostructures, which depends on their relative orientations. The Ti-S and O=S bonds in covalently bonded heterostructures and flat bands in noncovalent heterostructures lead to an effective separation of photoexcited charge carriers between two constituents, therefore enhanced photocatalytic activity. The small band gap enables the MoS<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub> cluster heterostructures having strong optical absorption in the whole visible light. Moreover, the Mo and S atoms at basal plane, which are catalytically inert, turn into catalytic active sites, making the monolayer MoS<sub>2</sub> to be a highly active co-catalyst. These findings disclose the elusive microscopic mechanism behind the enhanced photocatalytic activity of MoS<sub>2</sub>/TiO<sub>2 </sub>hybrids, and provide a systematic step towards a better understanding of interfacial interaction in layered MoS<sub>2</sub>-based heterostructures.
813	<strong>Influence of Vacancy Defect Concentration on the Combustion of Reactive Ni/Al Nanolaminates</strong>	Self-propagating reactions in Ni/Al nanolaminates have been widely studied for their high combustion temperatures surpassing 1900 K and rapid combustion wave speeds exceeding 10 m/s.  These combustion characteristics have motivated unique industrial applications, such as soldering of electrical components, and possible military applications.  Unfortunately, there is a limited understanding of the effect of lattice defects on combustion characteristics. This work explores the effect of vacancy concentration on the combustion rate and peak temperature of reactive Ni/Al nanolaminates.  Increasing vacancy concentration increases both reaction rates and peak reaction temperatures.  For the reaction rate, vacancy concentration effects are shown to be interdependent with bilayer thickness, initial temperature and hydrostatic pressure.  The effects on reaction peak temperature are independent of these other system parameters.  A new method for mapping vacancy and composition profiles is presented to demonstrate the formation and migration of vacancies during the self-propagating reaction.
814	<em></em>Enhanced localized surface plasmon resonance by inter-band transitions in nanoshell structures	We theoretically study the interactions between the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) and the inter-band transition (IBT) of a Au nanoshell structure based on Mie theory with the dielectric function of Drude-Lorentz mode. It shows that with changing the core radius of shell, the LSPR is modulated in the same regime with the IBT. As a result, the process of LSPR and IBT strongly interacts with each other. The two processes of LSPR and IBT couple and then split into new modes. Our results show that LSPR can be enhanced by the IBT. This enhancement is relevant to be applied to improve biosensor signal and advanced plasmonic applications.
815	A Nanosecond Pulsed Generator Based on Fast-Solid-State Switch fors Synchronous Discharge of Plasma Synthetic Jet Actuators	The plasma excited by the pulsed power generator is an efficient method for flow control. In this paper, a nanosecond pulsed generator based on a fast-solid-state switch is designed for producing synchronous discharges of paralleled plasma synthetic jet (PSJ) actuator. The generator produces high-voltage pulses by switching on and off the input DC voltages. The output voltage ranges from 0 to 20 kV with a rise time of 20 ns and a full width at half maximum of 200 ns. The repetition rate ranges from 1 Hz to 5.5 kHz. Furthermore, the pulsed generator is used to excite the paralleled PSJs in atmospheric air. The relative experimental results show that the nanosecond-pulse generator is able to sustain synchronous discharges of three PSJ actuators. The amplitude of the discharge current exceeds 90 A and the deposited energy per pulse reaches 45 mJ. Furthermore, a schlieren system is used to capture the evolution of the flow field of the PSJ actuator. The results show that with the excitation of the nanosecond pulse generator, the evolution of the three PSJ actuators has high synchronization. The time delay among the three PSJ actuators is 20 ns. In addition, the PSJ actuators can produce a jet with a maximum velocity of 60 m/s and a precursor wave with the velocity of 350 m/s.
816	Fractional rheology of muscle precursor cells	We propose a wavelet-based decomposition of creep fluctuation signals recorded from living muscle precursor cells that revisits the traditional computation of their power spectrum from FFT-based decomposition. This decomposition offers a higher sensitivity for detecting the occurrence of fractional fluctuations and for quantitatively estimating the power-law exponent &#x03B2; of this spectrum as a signature of the scaleinvariantsrheology of living cells. This new method has also the unprecedented advantage to provide a test of the validity of the commonly assumed "monofractal" self-similar (as compared to "multifractal" intermittent) nature of these fluctuations and hence to accredit the use of a single rheological exponent &#x03B1; = &#x03B2;/2. We report and discuss results obtained when applying this method to creep experiments performed with an AFM nanoindenter placed in contact with single myoblasts and myotubes, adherent on collagen coated coverslips, and in different culture conditions.
817	<strong>Analysis of magnetotransport properties and microstructure in current-perpendicular-to-plane pseudo spin-valves using Co<sub>2</sub>Fe(Ga<sub>0.5</sub>Ge<sub>0.5</sub>) Heusler alloy and Ag/Mg-Ti-O/Ag-based spacer</strong>	Current-perpendicular-to-plane giant magnetoresistance (CPP-MR) devices using Co<sub>2</sub>Fe(Ga<sub>0.5</sub>Ge<sub>0.5</sub>) Heusler alloy as ferromagnetic electrodes and Ag/Mg-Ti-O (MTO)/Ag tri-layer as a spacer were studied. Large voltage output of 16 mV with magnetoresistance ratio of 46% and resistance-area product <em>R</em><sub>p</sub><em>A</em> in the parallel magnetization state of approximately 200 m&Omega; &mu;m<sup>2</sup> are obtained. The microstructure characterization reveals that upon annealing at 550 &ordm;C, nanoscale Ag channels are formed penetrating the MTO layer, which are responsible for the large MR output. At room temperature, for all the devices, <em>R</em><sub>p</sub><em>A</em> decreases with increasing the bias voltage <em>V</em><sub>b</sub>, which is contradictory to the conventional CPP-GMR devices with current-confined-path (CCP) structure, in which the <em>R</em><sub>p</sub><em>A</em> decreases with increasing <em>V</em><sub>b</sub>. Such a <em>V</em><sub>b</sub> dependence of <em>R</em><sub>p</sub><em>A</em> is in accord with the temperature dependence of <em>R</em><sub>p</sub><em>A</em>. These results suggest that the magneto-transport channels comprise semiconducting current confined paths, bringing new perspectives for the design and engineering of CPP-MR devices with conductive oxides-based multilayer spacers.
818	Control of ion transport through a carbon nanotube by the pressure-driven water flow	Control of water and ion transport through nanochannels is not only important to biological activities but also useful for the design of nanofluidic devices. In this work, using molecular dynamics simulations, we systematically analyze the effect of ionic conditions such as ionic species and concentration, on the transport of water and ions through a carbon nanotube under the pressure difference. We find a linear relationship between the water flux and pressure difference for both of the monovalent and divalent salts, leading to similar linear behaviors for the ion flux. Interestingly, due to the blockage of trivalent cations at the channel entrance, the water flux shows an abnormal decreasing behavior with the increase of pressure difference, where the corresponding ion flux is close to zero. The translocation time of water and ions exhibit power law decreases with the pressure difference for both of the monovalent and divalent salts. Furthermore, due to the blockage of ions, the water flux decreases monotonously with the increase of salt concentration; while the ion flux has a maximum because of the competition between ion amount and blockage. Our results demonstrate that the ion transport can in a highly controllable fashion by the pressure-driven water flow, depending on the ionic conditions. The revealed new physical insights into the coupling transport of water and ions provide great implications in the design of novel nanofluidic devices.
819	FABRICATION OF SYMMETRIC AND ASYMMETRIC NANO/MICRO STRUCTURES USING MULTIPLE BEAM MODULATED INTERFERENCE LITHOGRAPHY TECHNIQUE FOR SURFACE MORPHOLOGICAL TEXTURE	A method for fabrication of symmetric nano/micro array patterned structure is demonstrated by the use of multi-beam modulated interference lithography (MBIL) technique. The generated periodic 1D, 2D and 3D micro/nano array structures are done using MATLAB. The obtained results show that the complexity of the pattern structures varies with the variation in position of beams and angle of incidence. The interference parameters such as wavelength, slit separation, distance between slit and screen influence in generation of periodic array pattern structures. The maximum intensity occurs at an angle of incidence 45 degree.sThe simulation shows that the variation in slit separation from 0.02 mm to 0.6 mm, beyond which only the constructive interference exist. So we conclude that lesser the slit separation which results in higher penetration of beam in the screen. The periodicity of the pattern exist in the range of 0.58. By tuning the input parameters, the periodicity, density and aspect ratio of the generated pattern can be controlled. The generated pattern structures are then fabricated over structure layered in Polymeric materials polyimide (PI) for &#x03BB;=1064 nm, slit separation d =0.6 mm and L= 0.005 m. The generated nano/micro structures on various substrates could be potentially utilized for the applications of Plasmonic Devices, MEMS, NEMS, Quantum Dots, Quantum wires, Functional surfaces for sensors and devices etc. We can also extend this techniques to generate complex symmetric and asymmetric structures.
820	Fabrication and characterization of transparent conducting reduced graphene oxide/Ag nanowires/ZnO:Ga composite thin films on flexible substrates	In recent years, flexible transparent conducting films (TCFs) have attracted considerable research interest because they are essential materials in flexible optoelectronic devices, which are still limited by the lack of suitable electrode materials. Some materials, including conducting polymers, carbon nanotubes, graphene, and metal nanowires, are considered to be possible alternatives for flexible TCFs. However, the resistivity of graphene films is high, and silver nanowire (AgNW) mesh films are easily oxidized, which limits their practical applications. In this study, a highly stable, transparent, and flexible composite electrode was developed using reduced graphene oxide (rGO)/AgNWs/Ga-doped zinc oxide (GZO) composite thin films. The rGO film was first spin coated on flexible substrates and used as an adhesion enhancement layer. The AgNWs, which were used as a primary conductor, formed a random percolating network embedded between the rGO and GZO films. The GZO film was sputtered on the surface of the AgNWs and was used as a protective layer to prevent the oxidation of the AgNWs. The rGO/AgNWs/GZO composite thin film exhibited excellent electrical conductivity and superior stability to a monolayer or a bilayer TCF. The sheet resistance of the composite film slightly increased from 5.04 to 5.42&#x03A9;/&#x25A1; when exposed to the atmosphere for 30 days. The rGO/AgNWs/GZO composite film exhibited an optical transmittance of approximately 85% at a wavelength of 550 nm. A bending test was conducted for 600 cycles with a curvature radius of 1 cm, and the test results revealed that sheet resistance of the composite film varied by less than 10%. The developed rGO/AgNW/GZO transparent conducting thin films have potential for use in future flexible optoelectronic device applications.
821	Hydration mediated interfacial transitions on mixed hydrophobic/hydrophilic nanodroplet interfaces	Interfacial phase transitions are of fundamental importance for climate, industry and biological processes. In this work, we observe a hydration mediated surface transition in supercooled oil nanodroplets in aqueous solutions using second harmonic and sum frequency scattering techniques. Hexadecane nanodroplets dispersed in water freeze at a temperature ~ 15 {degree sign}C below the melting point of the bulk alkane liquid. Addition of a trimethylammonium bromide (CXTA+) type surfactant with chain length equal or longer to that of the alkane causes the bulk oil droplet freezing transition to be preceded by a structural interfacial transition that involves water, oil and the surfactant. Upon cooling, the water loses some of its orientational order with respect to the surface normal, presumably by forming more tightly bonded hydrogen bond network that are oriented more parallel to the oil interface. This is followed by the surfactant alkyl chains losing some of their flexibility, and this chain stretching induces alkyl chain ordering in the bulk of the alkane phase, which is then followed by the bulk transition occurring at a 3 {degree sign}C lower temperature. This behavior is reminiscent of surface freezing observed in planar tertiary alkane/surfactant/water systems but differs distinctively in that it appears to be induced by the interfacial water and requires only a very small amount of surfactant.
822	<strong>Spitzer shaped 1D ZnO nanostructures for enhancement of field electron emission behaviors</strong>	We observed enhanced field emission (FE) behavior for spitzer shaped 1D ZnO nanowires synthesized via hydrothermal approaches. The spitzer shaped and pointed tipped 1D ZnO nanowires of average diameter 120 nm and length ~5-6 &mu;m were randomly grown over the ITO coated glass substrate. The turn-on field (<em>E<sub>on</sub></em>) of 1.56 V/&micro;m required to draw current density of 10 &micro;A/cm<sup>2</sup> from spitzer shaped 1D ZnO nanowires is significantly lower than that of pristine and doped ZnO nanostructures, and MoS<sub>2</sub>@TiO<sub>2</sub> heterostructure based FE devices. The orthodoxy test performed confirms the feasibility of field enhancement factor (<em>&beta;<sub>FE</sub></em>) of 3924 for ZnO/ITO emitters. The enhancement in FE behavior can be attributed to the spitzer shaped nanotips, sharply pointed nanotips and individual dispersion of ZnO nanowires. The ZnO/ITO emitters exhibited considerably stable electron emission with current fluctuations of &plusmn; 13 %. Our investigations suggest that the spitzer shaped 1D ZnO nanowires holds the potentials for further improvement in electron emission and other functionalities after forming their tunable nano-hetero-architectures with metal or conducting materials.
823	Metrological large range magnetic force microscopy	A new metrological large range magnetic force microscope (Met. LR-MFM) with a measurement volume up to 25 mm x 25 mm x 5 mm has been built up. The instrument works in a scanning sample principle. A dual-stage design, which combines a highly dynamic piezo stage and a large range precision mechanical positioning stage (referred to as a nanomeasuring machine, NMM), has been applied for scanning samples along three axes. The dual-stage design enables both a large range MFM measurements and a high scanning speed. The NMM applies high precision nanometric laser interferometers and angular sensors for measuring all six degree-of-freedoms of the sample position in full compliance with the Abbe principle, offering excellent positioning and measurement accuracy at the nm level. Experimental results show that its position stability reaches 0.15 nm, 0.2 nm and 0.6 nm along the x-, y- and z-axes, respectively. A home-built atomic force microscopy (AFM) head is applied in the instrument. It utilizes the optical lever principle for measuring the bending and torsion of cantilevers. The AFM head is capable of measuring in the contact, intermittent- and non-contact AFM mode. Three different measurement strategies referred to as Topo&MFM, MFMXY and MFMZ, respectively, have been developed for MFM measurements. The Topo&MFM measures the topography profile of the surface in the intermittent-contact mode first, and then the tip is lifted with a given height for non-contact MFM measurements, which is similar to conventional MFMs. The MFMXY differs from the Topo&MFM such that it does not measure the topography profile of surfaces at the 2nd and successive lines, thus reducing the tip wear and saving measurement time. To account for the influence of the instrument drift particularly along the z-axis, a drift compensation mechanism is implemented in the measurement strategy. The measurement strategy MFMZ offers the capability for imaging the stray field in the XZ or YZ planes. A number of measurement examples on a multilayered thin film reference sample made of [Co(0.4nm)/Pt(0.9nm)]100 and on a patterned magnetic multilayer [Co(0.4nm)/Pt(0.9nm)]10 with stripes with 9.9 &#x03BC;m line width and 20 &#x03BC;m periodicity are demonstrated, indicating the excellent measurement performance of the developed instrument.
824	Competing growth of titanium nitrides and silicides in Ti thin films processed in expanding microwave plasma: Morphology and microstructural properties.	The diffusion of nitrogen into Ti silicides allows the performance of complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) components to be improved. In this work, the thermochemical treatment is carried out in an expanding microwave plasma reactor using (Ar-33%N2-1%H2) gas mixtures. This process promotes the chemical reactions on the surface of the film. The diffusion of nitrogen into the film is improved by the reducing effect of NHx and/or H species towards passive layers such as oxides which form a barrier of diffusion in the surface layers during the process. The simultaneous formation of Ti nitrides and silicides at the surface and at the film-substrate interface, respectively gives rise to two competing processes which result in the growth of the Ti nitride phase at the expense of the Ti silicide phase at a critical temperature of 800{degree sign}C. This paper reports on a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of TiSi2 and TiN phases and the microstructural properties of films by means of X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy and selected area electron diffraction investigations. Square shaped crystals of TiN are identified on the top of round shaped crystals of TiSi2. The growth of the TiN phase at the expense of TiSi2 induces a catastrophic decrease of the intensity of the (040) diffraction line of TiSi2 and a huge increase of the (220) reflection line of TiN. The microstructural properties change during the process such as the formation of TiN crystals of nanometric size in the bulk of the TiSi2 phase as well as the migration of  free Si which epitaxially grows at the film-substrate interface have been evidenced by very detailed investigations for the first time. The results are related to the mechanism of formation of TiN from the reaction between TiSi2 and nitrogen.
825	Pulsed ionized mesh-like assembly of hybrid silica nanostructures with controlled resistivity	The adaption and inclusion of electrical technologies with various applications have motivated researchers to develop the most efficient and effective sensors, batteries and capacitors for safe, reliable and prolonged operations. However, miniaturization of sensors and practically associated with batteries and capacitors have driven them to employ nanofibers and nanotubes made of various material for reliable operations. Considering wide acceptance and available research for silicon material, nanofibers and nanoparticles made using silicon can be a great candidate for manufacturing of such sensors and electrical components. To employ nanofibers for those applications, understanding of its resistive characteristics can be crucial. In our study, we have manufactured hybrid silicon nanofibrous structure using novel approach of pico-second laser ablation and performed 4-point resistivity test to comprehend the change in its electrical behavior with variation in different laser parameters like frequency, power and scanning parameter of number of loops. Significant change in resistivity was observed with increase in all three laser parameters with remarkable topological differences for surface ablated with various laser and scanning parameters.
826	Effect of the dipolar coupling on the precessional magnetization switching in two dimensional arrays of single-domain nano-ellipses	Various spintronic devices use single-domain magnetic nanoparticles as unit cells.
