We have investigated interparticle dipole-dipole interactions in arrays of Permalloy single-domain nano-ellipses through micromagnetic simulations. In this study, we have varied not only the aspect ratio and the spacing between ellipses, but also the magnetization distribution and the 2D lattice type. When integrating the Landau-Lifshitz-Gilbert equation with zero external magnetic field, we have obtained the equilibrium magnetic configurations for each array. For small values of the spacing between ellipses, they interact strongly, such that the shape anisotropy is locally modified by the distribution of the magnetization. Moreover, we have studied the effect of the dipolar coupling on the precessional magnetization reversal. The minimum field strength required to switch the magnetization depends on the magnetization distribution in a strongly interacting magnetic system. Thus, we have estimated the minimum spacing between particles in which single-domain nano-ellipses becomes a weakly interacting magnetic system.
827	<strong>Enhanced thermal stability of dielectric, energy storage and discharge efficiency in a structurally frustrated piezoelectric system: Erbium modified Na<sub>0.5</sub>Bi<sub>0.5</sub>TiO<sub>3</sub>-BaTiO<sub>3</sub></strong>	We have systematically investigated the effect of rare earth erbium (Er<sup>3+</sup>) substitution on the structural, ferroelectric, piezoelectric and dielectric behaviour of the morphotropic phase boundary lead-free piezoelectric 0.94Na<sub>0.5</sub>Bi<sub>0.5</sub>TiO<sub>3</sub>-0.06BaTiO<sub>3</sub> (NBT-6BT). We found that the system shows very remarkable improvement in the thermal stability of energy storage density, discharge efficiency and dielectric permittivity. Detailed structural studies confirmed that Er modification induces a great deal of structural frustration in the system due to complex interplay of competing lattice instabilities in the midst of  positional disorder inherent in non-ergodic relaxor ferroelectric state of NBT-6BT. Our results therefore suggest that the good thermal stability of the different functionalities is intimately associated with very sluggish variation in the correlation length of the polar nano regions with temperature in this structurally frustrated system.
828	<strong>Localized surface plasmons of supershape nanoparticle dimers </strong>	In this work, the all plasmonic bands of supershape nanoparticle dimers were investigated using finite difference time domain simulations. The localized surface plasmons of dimers were extracted from extinction spectra. The effects of different surrounding materials and dimer gaps were reported on dimer plasmons. The obtained results showed that there exist the multiple plasmonics modes in supershape nanoparticle dimers. The electric field distribution of supershape nanoparticle dimers were studied at resonance wavelength of dimer plasmons. We found that formation bonding modes in dimers can be related to creation hot spots in low dimer gap. This study can be a base for the characterization of multiple dimer plasmons in plasmonic devices for sensing applications.
829	<strong>Transverse structure of the wave function of field emission electron beam determined by intrinsic transverse energy</strong>	The average transverse energy of electron beams is one of the important factors that governs the transverse beam divergence and the intrinsic beam brightness. The transverse beam properties of the thermionic emission and photoemission have been extensively studied in the past to elucidate the intrinsic limitation by cathode materials and to develop high brightness cathodes. However, similar investigations for field emission beams are rare, despite the significance of the average transverse energy of the field emission beam on the virtual source size, hence on the transverse spatial coherence. The present study aims at elucidating the impact of the intrinsic average transverse energy of field emission beams on the transverse structure of the wave function. For this purpose, we calculated the wave function of field emission electrons including the transverse motion of the electrons by taking into account the restriction imposed by Fermi sphere of electrons in metals. We obtained a Gaussian-beam-type solution that exhibits a minimum transverse width at the cathode surface as determined by the average transverse energy, and propagates with limited transverse spread for the first few nanometers. Some implications of the obtained solution in practical situations are discussed.
830	<strong>On conductivity in 2D molecular <em>&pi;</em>-stack with an outlook at charge transport in DNA solid state devices</strong>	Transport in naphthalene &pi;-stack system can exhibit switching behavior due to variation in its redox state. We study this phenomenon in molecular p-stack with an outlook on insight into charge transport in DNA solid state devices (DNAssd). Model molecular p-stack was based on naphthalene tetracarboxyl diimide (NTCDI) structure, which was assembled by molecular layer epitaxy (MLE) method. MLE method enables controllable growth of two-dimensional organic frameworks, which features ordered <em>&pi;</em>-stacked arrays of aromatic molecules. These molecular stacks are grown in <em>in-plane</em> direction in respect to surface and covalently bonded to inorganic semiconducting substrate. In this system the reduced NTCDI-acceptors form redox polarons, in which the charge is shared over several molecules within p-stack. We study an experimental conditions required to sustain efficient transport in this redox-capable NTCDI molecular p-stack. The transport in this redox-active system follows behavior of polarons, which occurs below HOMO-LUMO gap in molecular system, for which Ln <em>I</em> ~ <em>-E</em><sup>-2/3</sup>. We also study the case of redox blockade for NTCDI molecular p-stack.  We demonstrated that the same model (Ln <em>I</em> ~ <em>-E</em><sup>-2/3</sup>) is applicable for transport through DNA molecule, which was positioned between nano-electrodes. Study of transport in molecular &pi;-stack enables to elucidate phenomenon of conductivity switching, which may responsible for discrepancy between different transport experiments with DNA solid state devices (DNAssd). We propose a generalized efficient medium approach to describe the redox polaron transport in molecular stack based on a fully compensated semiconductor model. Presented model requires future experimental and theoretical approval.
831	<strong>Improvement in Piezoelectric Performance of a ZnO Nanogenerator by modulating interfaces engineering of CuO-ZnO heterojunction</strong>	In this paper, we demonstrate a approach of enhancing output performance of nanogenerators by modulating interfaces engineering of ZnO-CuO nano-heterojucnction. By properly modulating the preparation technology sequence of ZnO-CuO PN junctions, excessive electrons in ZnO can be highly suppressed. Using this approach, we obtained an output current up to ~1200 nA measured under the same compressive force of ~1kgf, which is a 25-fold higher output current, compared with the NG based on pure ZnO NWs. The corresponding working mechanisms was also discussed in this paper by using a interface energy band theory. This work may provide a potential approach to boost the piezoelectric performance of ZnO-CuO PN junctions NGs.
832	Nanometer-scale bioimaging via tunable terahertz plasmons	A nanometer-scale structured illumination microscopy (SIM) scheme via tunable plasmons is proposed. The sample is located on a semiconductor heterostructure and terahertz plasmons generated by a current-driven instability illuminate the sample.  Full coverage of the spatial frequency regime is obtained by tuning the plasmons through the control on  gate voltage. Hence, it is possible to reconstruct an image with a resolution up to two orders of magnitude beyond the diffraction limit. Due to the linear nature of the technique, only a weak illumination signal is required, therefore which minimizes the likelihood of sample damage and has potential application in bioimaging.
833	<strong>Enhancing thermoelectric performance in p-type ZrCoSb based </strong><strong>half-Heusler alloys employing nanostructuring and compositional modulation</strong>	Despite half-Heusler (HH) alloys being potentially considered for thermoelectric (TE) based power generation applications owing to their high thermal stability, good mechanical properties and enhanced power factor, their high thermal conductivity has remained a major impediment for further improvement in their thermoelectric figure-of-merit (ZT), especially p-type HH alloys. In the present work, a state-of-the-art <em>ZT</em> ~ 1 at 873K was realized in p-type nanostructured Zr<sub>1-x</sub>Hf<sub>x</sub>CoSb<sub>0.9</sub>Sn<sub>0.1 </sub>alloys employing compositional modulation of the Zr site with its heavier homologue Hf, which leads a substantial increase in its power factor coupled with a concurrent decrease in its thermal conductivity. These alloys were synthesized using high-energy ball-milling of the arc-melted ingots, followed by the spark plasma sintering of the resulting HH alloy nano-powders.  The partial substitution of Hf at the Zr site results in an alloy disorder and local potential energy fluctuations, which modify the band-structure and favorably optimizing the carrier concentration, leading to an enhancement in the power factor. Concurrently, a reduction in the phonon mean-free-path is observed on Hf-substitution, which is comparable to the average crystallite size (~25 nm), thus resulting in an abundant scattering of heat-carrying phonon scattering by nano-scale grain boundaries, leading to a very low thermal conductivity of ~2.2 Wm<sup>-1</sup>K<sup>-1</sup> at 873K, which is amongst the lowest reported in HH alloys.  The TE device characteristics, estimated using cumulative temperature dependence model for quantitative evaluation of TE performance, yielded an output power density of ~10 Wcm<sup>-2 </sup>&shy;in p-type with a leg efficiency of ~10% in these synthesized Hf-substituted nanostructured samples.
834	Electronic and Geometric Stabilities of Ti<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>n </sub>(n=3-24) Clusters	We performed the genetic algorithm (GA) incorporated with density functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the atomic and electronic properties of a series of Ti<sub>2</sub>Sin (n=3-24) clusters. Comprehensive consideration on the formation energy, the second difference in cluster energy and the addition energy of Si to a Ti<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>n&#x2212;1</sub> cluster as well as the HOMO-LUMO gap, our results show that Ti<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>4</sub> cluster is the most stable one in the series of clusters, followed by the Ti<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>13</sub>, Ti<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>21</sub>, Ti<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>15</sub> and Ti<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>7</sub> clusters, which can be understood by the combination of symmetry and electron shell filling rule. The silicon cage could be obviously enhanced by doping double Ti atoms making it a promising nanoscale materials.
835	Effect of gain medium and graphene on the resonance energy transfer between two molecules positioned near a plasmonic multilayer nanoparticle	In this study&#x200E;, &#x200E;we investigate the transfer of energy from a donor molecule to an acceptor molecule close a spherical multilayer nanoparticle consisting of a core surrounded by two shells (core@shell@shell nanoparticle), with focus on the role of the graphene and gain medium on the resonance energy transfer between molecules&#x200E;&#x200E;. We derive an analytical expression for the interaction energy in a hybrid plasmonic nanoshell-molecular system consisting of a pair molecules positioned near a plasmonic three-layer nanoparticle. &#x200E;Owing to more flexible tunability of multishell nanoparticles&#x200E;, &#x200E;the resonance energy transfer can be enhanced and tuned from IR-visible-UV regions by controlling the size of the nanosphere core or shells&#x200E;. In addition to the effect of the gain medium which enhances the plasmonic resonance in order of magnitude&#x200E;, &#x200E;the impact of graphene-coated three-layer nanosphere on the energy transfer is studied by taking into account the role of dipolar&#x200E;, &#x200E;quadrupolar&#x200E;, &#x200E;octupolar&#x200E;, &#x200E;hexadecapolar&#x200E;, &#x200E;triakontadipolar plasmonic modes&#x200E;.
836	Fabrication of a precise ellipsoidal mirror for soft X-ray nanofocusing	In X-ray focusing, the grazing incidence mirror offers advantages of no chromatic aberration and high focusing efficiency. Although nanofocusing mirrors have been developed for hard X-ray regions, there is no mirror with nanofocusing performance in soft X-ray regions. Designing a focusing system smaller than 100 nm at an X-ray energy of less than 1 keV requires a numerical aperture larger than 0.01. This leads to difficulties in the fabrication of a soft X-ray focusing mirror with high accuracy. Ellipsoidal mirrors enable soft X-ray focusing with a high numerical aperture. In this study, we report a fabrication process for ellipsoidal mirrors involving mandrel fabrication and replication processes. The fabricated ellipsoidal mirror was assessed under partial illumination conditions at the soft X-ray beamline (BL25SU) of SPring-8. A focal size of less than 250 nm was confirmed at 300 eV. The focusing tests indicated that the proposed fabrication process is promising for X-ray mirrors with a solid of revolution, including Wolter mirrors.
837	Effect of thickness, impurity concentration, surface roughness and temperature on transport coefficients and thermoelectric properties of ultra-thin silicon nanowires	The electronic, thermal, and thermoelectric coefficients of ultra-thin silicon nanowires are calculated analytically taking into account acoustic phonon, surface roughness, and impurity scattering as the dominant scattering mechanisms. The quantum-wire electronic subbands and chemical potential are obtained within effective mass and envelope function approximation. To determine the low-field electron mobility and lattice thermal conductivity, relaxation time approximation within linear response theory is employed. Thermoelectric properties are studied over a wide range of thicknesses (3--11 nm), doping densities (3 10<sup>15</sup>--10<sup>19</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup>), and temperatures (200--700 K). It is shown that the thermoelectric figure of merit ZT of ultra-thin silicon nanowires increases with increasing temperature and doping density in the range investigated. Furthermore, the ZT variation with quantum confinement or nanowire cross-section reaches a peak value of 0.23 at 8 nm thickness, at room temperature and doping density 10<sup>19 </sup>cm<sup>-3</sup>. The results of this comprehensive analytic study are found to be in good agreement with elaborate Monte Carlo simulations where available, while the method also allows for better physical understanding of the effects of different factors involved.
838	Effective patterning and cleaning of graphene by plasma etching and block copolymer lithography for nanoribbons fabrication	Patterning 2D materials at a sub-20 nm resolution is mandatory in a large number of applications to bring or control the overall material's and device's properties. In this work, we present our results on the fabrication of graphene nanoribbons using a block copolymer thin film as lithography mask. A special emphasis is given to the development of needed plasma etching processes to pattern graphene and to chemically clean the fabricated nanostructures. At the end, clean 10 nm wide graphene nanoribbons are obtained as confirmed by Raman spectroscopy, XPS, AFM and SEM characterizations. Block copolymer lithography and proper plasma etching conditions allow an ease of graphene patterning at large area capabilities and low-cost processing.
839	Nonlinear shear and dilatational rheology of viscoelastic interfacial layers of cellulosenanocrystals	We present a nonlinear rheological investigation of model rod-like particles at the air/water interface in dilatation and shear. Cellulose nanocrystals (CNC) were chemically modified to vary their surface hydrophobicity, creating a range of surface-active particles with varying contact angle. The interfacial shear properties were studied using a series of frequency sweeps in small amplitude oscillatory shear (SAOS), large amplitude oscillatory shear (LAOS), and large amplitude oscillatory dilatation (LAOD) in a range of amplitudes to include the nonlinear behavior. A multi-mode Maxwell model was used to fit the frequency sweeps that were performed during the formation of the interfacial layer. A shift towards longer relaxation times was found, more pronounced for particles with higher hydrophobicity. Lissajous plots in LAOS revealed strain stiffening, yielding, and unconstrained flow of the interfacial layers. They had a rhombus-like shape at high deformations for particles with high hydrophobicity and a leaf-like shape for particles with low hydrophobicity. Lissajous plots in LAOD revealed strain hardening in compression and strain softening in expansion, increasing with surface pressure and with particle hydrophobicity. While interfacial layers commonly show gel or solid-like behavior, our findings imply a weakly aggregated system. The differences in relaxation times and yielding behavior indicate the formation of larger clusters within the interfacial layers of particles with high hydrophobicity as compared to smaller clusters within the interfacial layers of particles with low hydrophobicity. The particle-particle interactions therefore vary with hydrophobicity, suggesting capillary interactions are important for the formation of these microstructures.
840	Non-uniform heat source-sink effect on MHD stagnation point Maxwell-nanofluid flow over a convectively heated stretching surface with chemical reaction	An analysis is made to examine the effect of non-uniform heat source/sink on the boundary layer hydro-dynamic stagnation point flow of an upper-convected Maxwell-nanofluid over a convectively heated stretching surface with chemical reaction. The governing partial differential equations (PDEs) are transformed into the ordinary differential equations (ODEs) by suitable similarity transformations. The shooting technique is used to solve the set of ODEs with the help of the MATLAB. To strengthen the numerical results obtained through the shooting technique, the built-in MATLAB function bvp4c is also invoked. The effects of non-dimensional physical controlling parameters such as Deborah number (0 {less than or equal to} &#x03B2; {less than or equal to} 6.0), chemical reaction parameter (0 {less than or equal to} &#x03B3; {less than or equal to} 1.5), magnetic parameter (0 {less than or equal to} Mg {less than or equal to} 7.0), Prandtl number (1.0 {less than or equal to} Pr {less than or equal to} 5.0), stretching ratio parameter (0 {less than or equal to} St {less than or equal to} 10.0), Lewis number (0 {less than or equal to} Le {less than or equal to} 1.0), thermal Grashof number (0 {less than or equal to} Gr {less than or equal to} 1.5), solutal Grashof number (0 {less than or equal to} Gc {less than or equal to} 4.5), space dependent heat generation/absorption coefficient (0 {less than or equal to} A* {less than or equal to} 0.4), time dependent heat generation/absorption coefficient (0 {less than or equal to} B* {less than or equal to} 0.9), Biot number (0 {less than or equal to} Bi {less than or equal to} 5.0), Brownian motion parameter (0 {less than or equal to} Nb {less than or equal to} 1.2) and thermophoresis parameter (0 {less than or equal to} Nt {less than or equal to} 3.0) on the velocity, temperature and concentration profiles are examined and presented in graphical form. The velocity field decreases for the increasing values of the magnetic parameter and chemical reaction parameter while the opposite behavior is observed in the velocity field for the Maxwell parameter.
841	Morphology Controlling of Ultrathin MoS2/MoO2 Nanosheets Grown by Chemical Vapor Deposition	The morphology of MoS2 plays an important role in its applications and properties, such as electronics and catalysts. Herein, the morphology of as-grown MoS2, synthesized by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) using S and MoO3 powder as reactants, were study by tuning the distance between MoO3 and substrate and the distance between S and MoO3 powder. The distance between MoO3 and substrate was deliberately reduced to obtain a sharp gradient of MoO3 precursor concentration on the growth substrate, and the region of sulfur was changed to obtain different sulfur concentration and initial reaction temperature, as a result, morphology evolution including two-dimensional (2D) MoS2 and MoS2/MoO2 freestanding nanosheets was observed. A mechanism was proposed to explain the morphology transformation between horizontal 2D flake and freestanding nanosheets. Based on this mechnism, syntheses method of dense, ultrathin, large size MoS2 freestanding nanosheets were proposed. These results may be further generalized to create novel nanostructured devices.
842	A new leak element built from graphene oxide membranes	A leak element built from a graphene oxide membrane has been developed using the modified Hummers' and vacuum filtration methods. He, Ne, Ar, and Kr leak rates across the element were measured using a quadrupole mass spectrometer. The various gases flows across the leak element occured via molecular flow at pressures of up to 500 kPa since graphene oxide (GO) is a nanoporous material. The leak rates of various gases at particular pressures could be predicted based on knowing the leak rate of one gas at a specific pressure. When the membrane thickness was below 600 nm, the main gas permeation paths were aligned defects across the GO membrane and the leak rate had an exponential relationship with the thickness. In contrast, the main gas permeation paths were spaces between layers and the leak rate was inversely proportional to the membrane thickness when the latter exceeded 600 nm.
843	Effective Charge Collection Area during Conductive and Photoconductive Atomic Force Microscopy Measurements	Conductive atomic force microscopy (C-AFM) has been widely used to map the nanoscale electrical properties of conducting polymers, nanomaterials, and organic electronic devices. While these measurements provide valuable insight into the spatial dependence of electrical performance, reported current densities and electrical conductivities measured by C-AFM are consistently much higher than those measured at the macroscopic scale. Here, we demonstrate that these anomalously high current densities and conductivities arise from ignoring current spreading and hence underestimating the current-carrying area. We present a simple experimental means of estimating the effective charge collection area during C-AFM measurements. Using semiconducting polymer poly(3-hexylthiophene) films as a test case, we find that the effective charge collection area can be as much as three orders of magnitude larger than the mechanical contact area between the probe and film. Calibrated conductivity maps are obtained, with a quantitative correspondence with accepted values, and C AFM photocurrent measurements of a nanostructured hybrid organic-inorganic solar cell active layer yield short-circuit current densities that match those reported for macroscopic devices. Finally, we address the observation that current spreading increases the effective charge collection area beyond the size of the probe-sample contact, but does not preclude an imaging resolution below 10 nm.
844	Sign identification of electron and hole out-of-plane g factors by utilizing nuclear spin switch in single quantum nanostructures	The electron and hole g factors are the key quantities for the spin manipulations in semiconductor quantum nanostructures. However, for the individual nanostructures, the separate determination including the signs of those g factors is difficult by using some methods adopted conventionally in bulks and quantum wells. We report a convenient optical method for the sign identification of out-of-plane g factors in the individual quantum nanostructures, which utilizes the optically-induced nuclear spin switch. The method is demonstrated in typical single self-assembled In$_{0.75}$Al$_{0.25}$As/Al$_{0.3}$Ga$_{0.7}$As quantum dots and InAs/GaAs quantum rings, where the g factors with the opposite sign for electron and the same sign for hole are proved.
845	<SPAN style="font-size: 16.0pt; line-height: 175%; color: windowtext;">Theoretical prediction of monolayer SnP<sub>3</sub> as an ultrafast and reversible anode for high-performance Na-ion batteries</SPAN>	Tin (Sn) as a cheaper and more environment-friendly alternative to lead has been widely used in the field of green energy. Especially, Sn-based nano-materials have attracted tremendous attention in Na-ion batteries. Interestingly, the layered bulk structure of SnP<sub>3 </sub>has been experimentally synthesized since 1970, which is metallic and stable at room temperature. Based on first-principles calculations, we predict that the production of monolayer SnP<sub>3 </sub>by<sub> </sub>exfoliation of bulk crystal could be feasible with the moderate cleavage energy (~1.10 J/m<sup>2</sup>). Due to strong interlayer quantum confinement effects, the single-layer SnP<sub>3</sub> is an indirect semiconductor with a small band gap (0.68 eV). Furthermore, we explore SnP<sub>3</sub> as an anode for Na-ion batteries. Upon Na adsorption, the semiconducting SnP<sub>3 </sub>transforms to a metallic state, ensuring a good electrical conductivity. Specially, the ultra-low energy barrier (0.03 eV) of Na diffusion on SnP<sub>3</sub> indicates an ultrafast charge/discharge rate. During the Na adsorption process, the slight volume variations (&lt; 4 %) suggest a good cycling reversibility. The theoretical specific capacity (253.31 mA&middot;h&middot;g<sup>-1</sup>) and moderate average electron potential (1.29 V) are in between those of commercial anodes, graphite and TiO<sub>2</sub>. These results demonstrate that SnP<sub>3</sub> has the potential for application in high-performance Na-ion batteries.
846	Nanoindentation of a Steigmann-Ogden surface bounding an elastic half-space	Literature studies demonstrate that, for nanostructures under transverse bending, the effective Young's modulus is appreciably greater (in magnitude) than that of the same elements under axial loads. Therefore, in addition to the conventional residual surface tension and membrane stiffness, the curvature dependence of surface energy is desired for inhomogeneously strained nanostructures. In this paper, we aim to reevaluate the size-dependent elastic behavior of an elastic half-space subjected to nanosized frictionless tractions, by the use of both the curvature-independent Gurtin-Murdoch and curvature-dependent Steigmann-Ogden models of surface elasticity. The nanoindentation problem is solved by the integration of Bousssinesq's method of displacement potentials and Hankel integral transforms. As examples, the effects of residual surface tension, tensile stiffness and bending rigidity of the half-space boundary are parametrically analyzed in detail for a uniform circular pressure and a concentrated normal force. The observations in semianalytical calculations suggest a significant difference in nanoindentation hardnesses predicted from the two popular models of surface mechanics. In most cases, the inclusion of bending rigidity results in lower displacements and stresses, and therefore higher indentation hardness. Based on physically interpretable numerical values of surface material properties, we show that a curvature-dependent model of surface elasticity is required in order to correctly characterize the size-dependent feature of nanoindentation problems.
847	<strong>The dependence of Schottky (I&#x2012;V) characteristics on the metal probe size in nano metal&#x2012;semiconductor contacts</strong>	We have studied the dependence of Schottky (I&#x2012;V) characteristics on the metal contact size in nanoscale metal&#x2012;semiconductor (M&#x2012;S) junctions. Using special nano&#x2012;probes in conductive atomic force microscope, we have shown that the Schottky (I&#x2012;V) characteristic of M&#x2012;S junction depends strongly on the metal contact size, rather than the semiconductor bulk properties as in the planar microscale M&#x2012;S junctions. The theoretical calculations from our model show good agreement with the experimental (I&#x2012;V) data for a wide range of nano&#x2012;probe sizes. Our results indicate the strong correlation between electric field at the M&#x2012;S interface and the Schottky rectification behavior. The calculated (I&#x2012;V) data show a smooth transition from the reverse rectification behavior to the normal rectification behavior as the nano&#x2012;probe radius increases from sub-10 nm to 100 nm. Our results clearly demonstrate the effect of metal contact size in nano Schottky diodes, which would help in designing a new type of nano-devices at sub-10 nm scale.
848	Perspective: How to Understand Electronic Friction	Electronic friction is a  correction to the Born-Oppenheimer approximation, whereby nuclei in motion experience a drag in the presence of a manifold of electronic states. The notion of electronic friction has a long history and has been (re-)discovered in the context of a wide variety of different chemical and physical systems including, but not limited to, surface scattering events, surface reactions or chemisorption, electrochemistry, and conduction through molecular-(or nano-) junctions.  Over the years,  quite a few different forms of electronic friction have been offered in the literature. In this perspective, we briefly review these developments of electronic friction, highlighting the fact that we can now isolate a single, unifying form for (Markovian) electronic friction. We also focus on the role of electron-electron interactions for understanding frictional effects, and offer our thoughts on the strengths and weaknesses of using electronic friction to model dynamics in general.
849	Ferroelectricity and piezoelectricity in monolayers and nanoplatelets of SnS	The ground-state structure of monolayers and nanoplatelets of SnS with a thickness from two to five monolayers is calculated from first principles. It is shown that nanoobjects with only odd number of monolayers are ferroelectric. The ferroelectric, piezoelectric, and elastic properties of these polar structures are calculated. The appearance of polarization in these nanoobjects is explained by an uncompensated polarization that exists in antiferroelectric structure of bulk SnS. The mechanism of ferroelectricity in which the ferroelectric distortion results from short-range ordering of lone pairs can be regarded as a way of creating ferroelectrics with high Curie temperature.
850	Integration of ferroelectric Pb(Zr<sub>0.52</sub>Ti<sub>0.48</sub>)O<sub>3</sub> thin films on conducting nanocrystalline diamond for high performance device applications.	We report on the direct integration of Pb(Zr<sub>0.52</sub>Ti<sub>0.48</sub>)O<sub>3</sub> (PZT) thin film on hot filament chemical vapor deposition (HFCVD) grown conducting boron doped nanocrystalline diamond (B-NCD) film. A conducting B-NCD thin film with grain size less than 100 nm and surface roughness close to 8 nm is used as a metallic bottom electrode. X-Ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectroscopy revealed the single phase perovskite ferroelectric nature of the PZT thin film deposited directly on the conducting B-NCD film. The macroscopic and nanoscale polarization switching experiments are performed to confirm ferroelectric nature of the PZT/B-NCD heterostructures. The narrow degradation of remanent polarization ( 10%) even after 10<sup>10</sup> switching cycles of the sample demonstrates the excellent ferroelectric performance of the heterostructures.
851	<strong>Ferroelectric Monoclinic Phases in Strained K<sub>0.70</sub>Na<sub>0.30</sub>NbO<sub>3</sub> Thin Films Promoting Selective Surface Acoustic Wave Propagation</strong>	We present a detailed analysis of the ferroelectric domain structure of K<sub>0.70</sub>Na<sub>0.30</sub>NbO<sub>3</sub> thin films on (110) TbScO<sub>3</sub> grown by metal organic chemical vapor deposition. Upon piezoresponse force microscopy and nanofocus X-ray diffraction measurements we derive a domain model revealing monoclinic M<sub>C</sub> domains. The complex domain pattern is formed out of four co-existing in-plane orientations of the shearing direction of the monoclinic unit cell resulting in four types of superdomains each being composed of well-ordered stripe domains. Finally, we present surface acoustic wave (SAW) experiments that exhibit extraordinary signal intensities given the low thickness of the tested film. Moreover, the SAW propagation is found to occur selectively along the identified shearing directions.
852	Noble rotary trigger double spark gap switch for high-repetitive nanosecond pulse generator and production of silver nano-colloid	High-voltage, high-repetition nanosecond pulse generation technology plays a key role for underwater discharge applications such as water treatment and metal nano-colloid production. For this application, a high-voltage, high-speed switching technology is crucial for fast transferring the energy stored in the capacitor to the electrodes in water. In this study, a noble rotary trigger double spark gap switch was developed for this purpose. Two spark gaps for charge and discharge are arranged in this switch, and they eliminate the irregular and unstable pulse generation due to the simultaneous charging and discharging in the pulse generating circuits. Using this technique, pulses with 12 kV, 100 ns rise time were generated at a repetition rate of 150 pulse per second and applied to underwater discharge to produce silver nano-colloid.
853	<strong>Electronic transition processes related to deep levels in a p-GaN layer analyzed by time-resolved photoluminescence using various excitation photon energies</strong>	Electronic transition via deep levels of GaN is investigated using two types of excitation laser photon energies in time resolved photoluminescence analysis: higher than the bandgap energy (<em>E</em><sub>g</sub>) (AEG) and lower than <em>E</em><sub>g</sub> (BEG). Various color luminescence components are observed for both the excitation conditions. The spectra in the energy region below <em>E</em><sub>g</sub> for the BEG excitations have no clear peaks as observed by the AEG excitations. It is thought that the luminescence components caused by the BEG excitations originate from the electronic transitions from the deep levels to the states in the vicinity of the valence band (NVB), which is different from the transitions from the states in the vicinity of the conduction band (NCB) to the deep levels observed by AEG excitations. The decay rates of the transitions from the deep levels to the NVB states are in the order of tens of nanoseconds, which is shorter than the values of hundreds of nanoseconds to microseconds for the transitions from the NCB states to the deep levels obtained in the present analysis and previous reports.
854	<strong>Secondary electron emission characteristics of the TiN coatings produced by RF magnetron sputtering</strong>	Multipactor, a detrimental effect in space high power systems, can degrade the performance of space microwave components or even cause a devastation. Surface coatings with low secondary electron yield (SEY) have been verified to mitigate multipactor efficiently, and some literatures indicate that Titanium Nitride (TiN) coating is an excellent multipactor suppressor due to its recognized low SEY. Whereas, so far, theoretical analysis for interpreting the secondary electron emission (SEE) characteristics of TiN coatings is scarce. In this work, we experimentally and theoretically investigate SEE characteristics of TiN coatings. We fabricate seven TiN coatings under different N<sub>2 </sub>concentration by RF sputtering. Microscopic analysis indicates that the nanostructured TiN coatings are more likely to be formed at low N<sub>2</sub> concentration, inversely, it is more likely to form the compact TiN films when N<sub>2</sub> concentration is high. SEY measurement shows the nanostructured TiN coatings are more efficient to trap the electrons than the compact TiN films does. Furthermore, via measuring the resistivity, we find a novel regularity that the variation of SEY largely depends on the resistivity for the compact TiN films. Namely, SEY of the compact TiN films linearly decreases as their resistivity exponentially declines. Then, we establish an equation to describe the SEY as a function of resistivity via applying semiconductor conductivity theory to the Dionne&rsquo;s SEE model. The equation qualitatively interprets the experiment regularity. This work presents a probability to control SEY of the TiN coatings by adjusting resistivity, and is of significance to comprehend the SEE of semiconductors.
855	Bimodal distribution of defects energy states in Gd<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>:Er nanoparticles probed by photoluminescence quenching	The advantage of Gd<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>:Er nanoparticles as a material for energy applications lies in an alternative channel for UV-visible conversion through Gd<sup>3+</sup>&rarr;Er<sup>3+</sup> energy transfer, which doesn&rsquo;t require special introduction of donor ions into the matrix since this role is played by defective cations. The influence of Gd<sup>3+</sup> defective nature on excitation-relaxation processes determining the overall conversion efficiency remains poorly understood. From analysis of luminescence temperature behavior, we found a bimodal distribution of energy barrier for Er<sup>3+</sup> emission quenching after indirect excitation. The reason for this is assumed to the different energy structure of defective Gd<sup>3+</sup> donors, which occupy structurally non-equivalent cationic positions in Gd<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> host lattice. This study provides a new knowledge about behavior of excited states and regularities of energy conversion in rare-earth nanoscale materials.
856	Low-threshold, mid-infrared backward-wave parametric oscillator with periodically poled Rb:KTP	We report on the development of a nanosecond mirrorless OPO pumped at 1 &#x00B5;m. The gain medium of the OPO was periodically poled Rubidium-doped KTP with a grating period of &#x039B; = 509 nm for first order quasi-phase matching. For grating periods of this length, we demonstrate backward propagation of the signal field and forward propagation of the idler field. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time such a counter-propagating geometry has been demonstrated in mirrorless OPOs. Pumping with a maximum energy of 6.48 mJ, the OPO yielded an overall conversion efficiency exceeding 53 % with signal and idler energies of 1.96 mJ and 1.46 mJ respectively. The generated signal and idler field spectra were measured to show narrowband linewidths on the order of 0.5 nm. We motivate that such a MOPO is ideal for seeding applications and discuss further improvements and work.
857	<strong>The role of convection in gas and liquid phases at droplet evaporation</strong>	The article presents the measuring results of droplet velocity and temperature fields using non-contact optical methods: Particle Image Velocity (PIV), Planar Laser Induced Fluorescence (PLIF) and Thermal imager. The novelty of the work is that the influence of free convection in gas and liquid is investigated experimentally and theoretically and that the key criteria affecting heat and mass transfer are determined. The analysis of experimental data has shown that in the initial period of water drop evaporation, the predominant role in the heat exchange is played by the thermal Marangoni convection. However, for an aqueous salt solution, in spite of the strong influence of the surfactant, the dominant role passes to the solutal Marangoni convection (<em>Ma<sub>C</sub></em>). The results of the analysis contained in this article can be used to describe not only drops and thin films of solutions, including nano- and micro-coatings, but drops falling on the wall. This is due to the fact that in the first seconds after the drop falling, convection and heat transfer in the liquid are maximum. Under such conditions it is important to realize an accurate numerical simulation to assess the degree of the wall cooling and to calculate the non-stationary evaporation. When simulating heat transfer, it is incorrect to neglect free convection in gas or liquid due to their strong nonlinear influence on each other. The heat exchange in the drop is extremely conservative to convection in the liquid (the Peclet number <em>Pe</em> = 100 and the Nusselt number <em>Nu</em> = 4).
858	<strong>Exploitation of nanoparticle-protein interactions for early disease detection</strong>	The main diagnostic tools for primary and metastatic central nervous system tumors are the anamnestic neurological examination and the imaging tests, which are expensive and lack of specificity. In recent years, the shell of macromolecules that forms on nanoparticles when they are exposed to human blood, also known as hard corona (HC) became a powerful tool in diagnostics. Indeed HC can act as a &ldquo;nano-concentrator&rdquo; of serum proteins and can detect minor changes in protein concentration at the very early stages of disease development. In this paper, we characterized HC of blood samples from patients affected by meningeal tumorson lipid nanoparticles. We found that the HCs of meningeal tumor patients could be discriminated from those of healthy subjects. Our results show that emerging HC-based technologies could open new horizons towards central nervous system cancer early diagnosis.
859	Multiscale simulations of critical interfacial failure in carbon nanotube-polymer composites	Computational investigation of interfacial failure in composite materials is challenging because it is inherently multi-scale: the bond-breaking processes that occur at the covalently bonded interface and initiate failure involve quantum mechanical phenomena, yet the mechanisms by which external stresses are transferred through the matrix occur on length and time-scales far in excess of anything that can be simulated quantum mechanically. In this work, we demonstrate and validate an adaptive quantum mechanics / molecular mechanics (QM/MM) simulation method that can be used to address these issues and apply it to study critical failure at covalently bonded carbon nanotube (CNT)-polymer interface. In this hybrid approach, the majority of the system is simulated with a classical forcefield, while areas of particular interest are identified on-the-fly and atomic forces in those regions are updated based on QM calculations. We demonstrate that the hybrid method results are in excellent agreement with fully-QM benchmark simulations and offers qualitative insights missing from classical simulations. We use the hybrid approach to show how chemical structure at the CNT-polymer interface determines its strength and we propose candidate chemistries to guide further experimental work in this area.
860	<strong>Photoluminescence and optical properties of MO<sub>3</sub>-B<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-CeO<sub>2</sub>-Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (M= Mo or W) glasses and their counterparts nano-glass-ceramics</strong>	8MO<sub>3</sub>-30B<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-<em>x</em>CeO<sub>2</sub>-(62-<em>x</em>)Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> glasses (where M= Mo or W and <em>x</em>= 2,5,8; in mol%) were fabricated employing the conventional melt-quench method. The amorphous nature of the glasses was demonstrated using X-ray diffraction. From the ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy, it was found that increase of the CeO<sub>2</sub> content led to a red-shift, i.e. shift towards longer wavelengths, in the optical absorption edge of glasses, a gradual decrease in their band gap energy and a slight increase in the refractive index. Differential thermal analysis was utilized to determine the peaks of crystallization temperatures at which a successful nano-crystallization has been achieved. The obtained nano-glass-ceramics include nano-crystallites of monoclinic bismuth molybdate (Bi<sub>2</sub>MoO<sub>6</sub>) and orthorhombic Russellite (Bi<sub>2</sub>WO<sub>6</sub>) as major crystalline phases within the Mo- and W-containing glassy matrices, respectively. Morphology of these nano-crystallites was investigated by High resolution transmission electron microscope which revealed average crystallites sizes in the range of 6-26 nm. Photoluminescence (PL) of the as-quenched glasses as well as their counterparts nano-glass-ceramics was studied and discussed. PL spectroscopy indicated that the glasses are red phosphors emitting red light at 600 and 610 nm upon UV excitation at 300 nm. The nano-glass-ceramics exhibited very broad emission spectra, extending in a wide range in the visible region, which consist of prominent bluish-violet emissions with a minority of green and red emission bands under UV excitation at 254 and 280 nm.
861	Gold nanoparticle distribution in polyelectrolyte brushes loaded at different pH conditions	Composites made of polymer brushes with inclusions of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) combine the responsive nature of polymer brushes with the optical properties of the AuNPs, which offers the possibility to be used as colorimetric sensors. To this end, it is crucial to know how AuNPs are distributed inside the brush. Here, this distribution was elucidated by reflectometry (NR) with contrast variation, and a self-consistent reflectivity analysis based on the analytical parametrization of the volume fraction profiles of all chemical components. In contrast to former studies this analysis allows the determination of the spatial distribution of components separately from each other: polyelectrolyte, AuNP and water. Cationic poly-[2-(Methacryloyloxy) ethyl] trimethylammonium chloride (PMETAC) brushes were loaded with 5 nm AuNPs, which were coated with a pH-sensitive capping. The pH was varied during the incubation of the brush in the AuNP suspension. At lower pH, AuNPs form aggregates in suspension and are attached to the brush periphery. They adsorb into the brush but do not fully penetrate it due to their bulkiness. At higher pH, AuNP suspensions are electrostatically stabilized and the AuNPs penetrate the brush entirely. However, the AuNP distribution over the brush is not homogeneous but decreases gradually towards the substrate. Penetration of the AuNPs leads to a more extended conformation of the brush. According to the results of the detailed analysis of all components, increase in water content could be excluded as a reason for brush swelling but a replacement of water by the AuNP was observed.
862	<strong>Highly transparent tactile sensor based on a percolated carbon nanotube network</strong>	<strong>The demand for transparent and flexible electronic devices, which are an emerging technology for</strong> the<strong> next generation of sensors, continues to grow in both applications and development due to their potential to make a significant commercial impact in a wide variety of areas. Here, we demonstrate a highly transparent tactile sensor with 92% optical transparency in </strong>the <strong>visible range based on solution-processed 99% metallic CNTs attached on a polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) film. We efficiently reconstructed the pressed, stimulated spatial location by increasing the injection current (<em>I<sub>injection</sub></em>) during electrical resistance tomography (ERT) that computed </strong>the <strong>internal two-dimensional (2-D) resistivity distribution. </strong>
863	Mask-free Fabrication and chemical vapor deposition synthesis of ultra-thin zinc oxide nanoribbons on Si/SiO2 and 2D substrates	Authors report on fabrication and characterization of thin zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoribbons with controlled geometries produced on the substrates via direct-write patterning (DWP) approach. A two-step process was employed to selectively grow precise patterns of thin ZnO nanoribbons. Direct write patterning (DWP) of iron (Fe) catalytic ink and subsequent chemical vapor deposition (CVD) synthesis was utilized in the fabrication of ZnO nanoribbons on different substrates. It was found that iron aqueous ink promoted the formation of ZnO nanostructures at patterned locations. High-quality ZnO nanoribbons were fabricated with optimized patterning parameters and specific growth conditions. The ability to control the thickness of ZnO nanoribbons on Si/SiO2 was demonstrated through the adjustment of the writing-speeds. It was determined that higher speed of writing resulted in thinner ZnO nanoribbons, while slower speeds facilitated the thicker nanoribbons formation during the growth.  Arrays of ZnO nanoribbons with controlled thicknesses, of 2nm, 4nm, and 8nm, were produced on Si/SiO2 substrate with the widths ranging from 3-6 &#x00B5;m. This mask-free scalable two-step protocol was also employed to produce arrays of ZnO nanoribbons on two-dimensional (2D) materials, such as Graphene and Boron Nitride thin films, effectively creating ZnO/2D heterostructures. These experiments demonstrated the compatibility of grapahene (Gr) and boron nitride (BN) surfaces with the ZnO fabrication process, and could provide opportunities for the integration of patterned ZnO thin film into different types of architectures for improved and more efficient devices and scalable technologies.
864	<strong>Biosensor response from target molecules with inhomogeneous charge localization</strong>	We analyzed the sensor response from aptamer-modified carbon nanotube thin film transistors that adsorb immunoglobulin E (IgE) with an inhomogeneous charge distribution. The net charge of the target molecules within the Debye length reflects the polarity of the electrical sensor signal. The complicated sensor response, which depends on the Debye length, can be interpreted by two kinds of adsorption states considering the influence of steric hindrance by previously adsorbed IgE molecules. These results explain the anomalous behavior of the sensor response in previous reports and pave the way to control the dynamic range.
865	Relativistic ultrafast electron microscopy with MeV femtosecond electron pulses	We have developed a prototype relativistic ultrafast electron microscope (UEM) with a 3.1 MeV femtosecond-pulsed electron beam generated by a radio-frequency gun. In demonstrations of the relativistic UEM, high-quality single-shot electron diffraction images have been detected from gold single crystals. TEM images of 400-nm-diameter gold nanoparticles were observed, and the dependence of the images on the pulse number was investigated. The results demonstrate that relativistic UEM using the rf gun can be applied to the study of ultrafast structural dynamics in femtosecond or picosecond time regimes if we can increase further the brightness of the pulses to 10<sup>12</sup> e<sup>-</sup>/mm<sup>2</sup>mrad<sup>2</sup>.
866	Analysis of the Nanoclusters in a High Silicon Content Cast Aluminum Alloy Utilizing an Atom-Probe Tomography	Magnesium and silicon nanoclusters in a cast aluminum alloy consisted of Al &ndash; 6.7 at.% Si &ndash; 0.33 at.% Mg, after aging heat treatment were studied utilizing an atom-probe tomography. To define and characterize the nanoclusters, a well-known maximum separation algorithm was applied to the APT data. Applying input parameters to the cluster selection algorithm, Mg<sub>2</sub>Si nanoclusters in &alpha;-aluminum matrix were quantitatively analyzed and their size distributions and average sizes were determined. The results presented herein are crucial to understand the age-hardening process as a function of solid solution aluminum decomposition sequence.
867	<strong>Modeling of Large Permittivity of poly(vinylidenefluoride-co-trifluoroethylene) and Nanospring Single-Walled Carbon Nano Tubes-polyvinylpyrrolidone Nano Composites </strong>	The highly dispersible nanospring single-walled carbon nano tubes (NS-CNTs) is incorporated in the P(VDF-TrFE) copolymer, one of widely scrutinized ferro- and piezo-electric polymer, up to the value of 15 wt% as nanofillers. The relative dielectric constant (<em>K</em>) of polymer nanocomposite, at 1 kHz, was greatly enhanced from 12.7 to the value of 62.5 at 11 wt% contents of NS-CNTs, corresponding to a 492 % increase compared to that of pristine P(VDF-TrFE) with only a small dielectric loss tangent (<em>D</em>) of 0.1. Based on two theoretical models called Bruggeman equation and self-consistent effective medium theory (SC-EMT), the experimental data of the permittivity of P(VDF-TrFE) and NS-CNTsnanocomposites have been simulated to estimate the dielectric constant of NS-CNTs while changing both the shape of nanofillers and the volume fraction of the interface with the increase of the number of NS-CNTs piled layers in P(VDF-TrFE) matrix. The number of NS-CNTs layers was counted from HRTEM images to calculate the interfacial volume fraction and used to infer the Eshelby tensor of NS-CNTs in the SC-EMT model. As the result, experimentally measured dielectric constants of the composite films were well fitted with the Bruggeman equation and SC-EMT theory in the range of dielectric constant <em>k</em>=240-360, which means that NS-CNTs nanofillers are considered electrically semiconductive.
868	<strong>Deterministic role of frequency, amplitude and concentration regimes on the complex dielectric relaxation of colloidal complex fluids</strong>	The present article explores the governing roles played by concentration regimes, frequency and amplitude of the forcing electric field on the dynamic dielectric responses of  nanocolloidal non-polar suspensions. Frequency dependent complex dielectric constants were determined in the band of 1 to 10<sup>7 </sup>Hz at constant temperature via dielectric spectroscopy. In addition to prevalant literature measurements, influence of field amplitude has also been performed to investigate the role of electric field intensity upon the relaxation behaviors.  The experimental observations reveal that variation of frequency, as well as choice of particle material significantly influences the dielectric responses of nanocolloids. Further, the amplitude of field is found to induce differences in the dielectric response. It is also observed that the relaxation responses are grossly different for concentrated dispersions than the dilute counterparts. The concentration regimes are observed to bring about overlapping relaxation responses in the colloids.  Good degree of quantitative agreement has been found between the experimental observations and the generic Havriliak-Negami relaxation model.  It has been shown that for a given nanomaterial, reduction of relaxation time scale is a direct consequence of enhancement in concentration and the colloids transit from predominantly storage to leaky systems with concentration regimes. Additionally, the reported volume diffusion mechanism (VDM) is found to be in compliance with the experimental findings. The occurrence and shift of peaks and valleys in the dielectric spectra has been explained based on dielectric response theories for electrically heterogeneous media.
869	Dynamics of material modifications during a high-power nanosecond laser irradiation in fused silica	The real-time responses of the optical performance of fused silica, including transmission, reflection, and scattering, during a nanosecond laser irradiation at 355 nm were simultaneously measured using a time-resolved technique, which enables the analysis of material modifications that occur throughout the high-power laser irradiation with a picosecond sampling interval. During a single pulse irradiation, once the transient power exceeded the threshold, the transmission exhibited a sudden and significant reduction at the rising edge of the high-power laser pulse, accompanied with an increase in reflection, attributed to stimulated Brillouin scattering (SBS). With the increase of the single pulse intensity, following the sudden occurrence of SBS, the appearance of a scattering spike indicated the generation of damage; the scattering ratio continued to increase during the irradiation, revealing the growth of the damage. By combining a spectral analysis and image acquisition, a broadband emission emerging from the creation of plasma was observed during the damage event. Considering the filamentary structure of the damage, the interaction among the SBS, plasma, and formation of the laser damage in fused silica was discussed.
870	Descriptors for the Reactivity of Au Nanocatalysts: Evaluating the Performance of the <i>d</i>-band center, the Effective Coordination Number and the Dual-Center Descriptor	Though extended gold systems are inert, gold nanoparticles have been found to be reactive and good catalysts for several commercially important reactions. Their efficacy as catalysts is known to be sensitive to parameters such as size, morphology and charge state. With a view to aiding catalyst design, we evaluate the performance of three suggested descriptors for reactivity, viz., the popular <i>d</i>-band center &#x03B5;<sub><i>d</i></sub>, and two less-known alternatives:  effective coordination number, ECN, and the dual-center descriptor, &#x0394;&#x03B5; = &#x03B5;<sub><i>sp</i></sub> - &#x03B5;<sub><i>d</i></sub> (where s&#x03B5;<sub><i>sp</i></sub> is the center of the <i>sp</i>-bands). Using the strength of binding to O<sub>2</sub> as a measure of reactivity, we evaluate the success of the three descriptors in correctly predicting trends in reactivity: (a) when the coordination number is lowered by varying the structure and/or dimensionality in real and hypothetical Au systems, (b) when the adsorption site within an Au nanocluster is varied, and (c) when the charge state is modified. All three descriptors are successful to  varying extents in the different situations considered; however, the only descriptor that is able to correctly predict trends in binding in all cases is &#x0394;&#x03B5;. This reflects the fact that <i>s</i> and <i>p</i> electrons often play a significant role in the reactivity of gold nanoparticles; their behavior should therefore ideally be incorporated within an effective descriptor.
871	Truly random number generator based on thermally activated magnetization backhopping in nanoscale ring-shaped magnetic tunnel junctions	A true random number generator based on the magnetization backhopping process in nano-ring magnetic tunnel junctions with no applied field is demonstrated in this work. Backhopping occurs at higher current beyond the critical switching current. The impact of environmental temperature (<em>T</em>) and current pulse width (<em>&tau;</em>) on backhopping is investigated statistically in experiments, micromagnetic simulation and theoretical analysis. The backhopping probability increases at high <em>T </em>and wide <em>&tau;</em>, explained by the combined effect of thermal fluctuation and spin-transfer-torque noise. The magnetoresistance at backhopping is randomly distributed over a large operational range. This manifestation of backhopping in magnetic tunnel junctions can be used as the basic unit of a true random number generator.
872	Oxidation mechanisms of Y doped CrAlSiN coatings at 1100{degree sign}C	The oxidation mechanisms of Y doped CrN/AlSiN nanolayered coatings were investigated at 1100{degree sign}C. Although Y doping showed limited effects in stopping the penetration of oxygen into the coating, it played an important role of slowing down phase segregation within the coating and diffusion across the coating-substrate interface. It changed the coating oxidation process from being driven by outward diffusion of Cr+ to one that is driven by inward penetration of O-, which could be explained by a complete suppression of Cr+ out diffusion and growth of Cr2O3 scales on the coating surface.
873	Atomic-scale investigation of fast oxidation kinetics of nanocrystalline CrMnFeNiCo thin films	Atom probe tomography was combined with transmission electron microscopy to characterize the oxidized structure of nanocrystalline CrMnFeNiCo thin films after exposure to air at 500{degree sign}C for 5 min. Mn and Cr oxide scales were observed on the surface of the sample, agreeing with literature reports on bulk samples. Depletion of Mn and Cr below the surface of the sample due to oxidation together with partial phase decomposition yield a FeCo-B2 phase. The fast oxidation of the nanocrystalline material was attributed to an enhanced outwards diffusion of Cr and Mn along grain boundaries and within the newly formed B2 phase.
874	Sensing and cooling of a nanomechanical resonator with en electron beam and a capacitive force	A model of the cooling properties of a nanocantilever by a free electron beam is presented for a capacitive interaction. The optimal parameters for position sensing and cooling applications are estimated from  previous experimental conditions. In particular, we demonstrate that a purely capacitive force can lower the temperature of a nanocantilever by several orders of magnitude in striking contrast with the conventional  electrostatic damping regime. We propose a step by step protocol to extract the interdependent parameters of the experiments. This work will aid for future developments of ultra sensitive force sensors in electron microscopes.
875	Magnetization reversal and magnetotransport properties of[Au/Co/Pd]n thin films and nanostructures	[Au (10 &Aring;)/Co (6.6 &Aring;)/Pd (10 &Aring;)]10 multilayers with perpendicular magnetic anisotropy have been grown by DC magnetron sputtering on silicon oxide substrates. Standard magnetometry and magnetic force microscopy imaging enable to extract the main magnetic parameters (saturation magnetization, anisotropy, domain size, exchange constant). The magnetoresistance and the extraordinary Hall effect of the material have been characterized using nanostructures patterned on the multilayer. Both the magnetization reversal mode and the magnetotransport properties are found to depend strongly on the nanowire width. The relatively low coercive field, the high anisotropy, and the possibility to control domain wall motion in sub-100 nm wires make this system an interesting alternative to Pt-based multilayers for spin-transfer torques experiments.
876	A BIMODAL THERANOSTIC NANODELIVERY SYSTEM BASED ON [GRAPHENE OXIDE-CHLOROGENIC ACID-GADOLINIUM/GOLD] NANOPARTICLES	A nanodelivery system based on graphene oxide, composed of a natural chemotherapeutic agent, chlorogenic acid (CA) and contrast agents, gadolinium (Gd) and gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) for  magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). CA and Gd were simultaneously loaded on the GO nanolayers using various chemical interactions to form GOGCA, and subsequently the AuNPs were doped on the surface of the GOGCA to form a bimodal theranostic nanodelivery system (BIT). The BIT developed was subjected to various characterizations. The cytotoxicity studies showed high efficacy in HepG2 cancer cells and null toxicity in the 3T3 normal cells. The BIT also showed positive MRI contrast.
877	Performance Enhancement of Planar Perovskite Solar Cells by Fullerene Doping with Silver Nanoparticles	Herein, we demonstrate p-i-n planar perovskite solar cells with the structure ITO/PEDOT/MAPbI<sub>3</sub>/PCBM/Ni:Au, where the PCBM electron extraction layer  (EEL)  was intentionally modified with variable amounts of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs). Small cross-section AgNPs placed at rear-part of the solar cell avoids the parasitic absorption of the nanoparticles which is the biggest barrier for plasmonic structures when acting as photocurrent enhancers. The addition of small amounts of AgNPs (e.g. 5 wt%) into the PCBM improved the overall reproducibility of the solar cell fabrication process and the main performance figures of merit after optimization. Plasmonic simulations suggest that any plasmonic-optical effects are relatively small compared to sample absorbance due to perovskite alone. It has been concluded that plasmonic-electrical effects play a major role in performance improvement. Therefore, the addition of small AgNP in low concentration to EEL layer account for higher J<sub>sc</sub>, V<sub>oc</sub> and FF as result of a better perovskite coverage by the EEL and an improved charge carrier collection as evidenced by morphological and electrical analysis.
878	<strong>Acoustic Signals Induced by </strong><strong>Pulsed Electric Field </strong><strong>for Therapy Monitoring </strong>	Acoustic signals induced by a pulsed electric field are used for electrotherapy monitoring in real-time. This technique relies on the fact that pulsed electric fields induce ephemeral and localized temperature rises, followed by rapid thermal expansion, which then induces acoustic waves that can be detected outside the body and used to monitor absorbed electric energy. An experimental system was designed and implemented, which consists of three major components: a pulsed electric field generator, an ultrasound receiver, and a data acquisition system. Details of the system design and signal detection are presented. Characterization of these nanosecond electric pulse (nsEP) induced acoustic signals reveals a strong peak at 462 kHz, corresponding to a pulse duration in the microseconds range. A linear relationship between the intensity of the applied electric field and the intensity of the acoustic signal has also been observed. This study demonstrates the feasibility of applying a new technique for real-time monitoring of electrotherapy performed <em>in situ</em> in a non-invasive manner in clinical applications.
879	Thermal recrystallization of short-range ordered WS<sub>2</sub> films	The integration of van-der-Waals materials in nanoelectronic devices requires the deposition of few-layered MX<sub>2</sub> films with excellent quality crystals covering a large area. In recent years, astonishing progress in the monolayer growth of WS<sub>2</sub> and MoS<sub>2</sub> was demonstrated, but multilayer growth resulted often in separated triangular or hexagonal islands. These polycrystalline films cannot fully employ the specific MX<sub>2</sub> properties since they are not connected in-plane to the other domains. To coalesce separated islands, ultra-high temperature post-deposition anneals in H<sub>2</sub>S are applied, which are not compatible with bare silicon substrates. Starting from the deposition of stoichiometric short-ordered films, the present work studies different options for subsequent high-temperature annealing in inert atmosphere to form crystalline films with large grains from stoichiometric films with small grains. The rapid thermal annealing (RTA), performed over a few seconds, is compared to excimer laser annealing (ELA) in the nanosecond range, which are both able to crystallize the thin WS<sub>2</sub>. The WS<sub>2</sub> recrystallization temperature can be lowered using metallic crystallization promoters (Co and Ni). The best result is obtained using a Co cap, due to the circumvention of Co and S binary phase-formation below the eutectic temperature. The recrystallization above a critical temperature is accompanied by sulfur-loss and 3D regrowth. These undesired effects can be suppressed by the application of a dielectric capping layer prior to annealing. A SiO<sub>2</sub> cap can suppress successfully the sulfur loss during annealing and reveals improved material quality in comparison to non-capped films.
880	<strong><em>ITO-Free Localized Surface Plasmon-Enhanced Transparent Conducting Electrode for High-Efficiency Light Emitting Diode</em></strong>	Transparent conducting electrodes (TCEs) are important components of high- efficiency light emitting diodes (LEDs). Metal nanowire such as silver nanowire (Ag NW) is widely studied as a promising candidate for replacement of indium tin oxide (ITO)-based TCEs in LEDs. However, the efficiency of LEDs with metal nanowire is inferior to that of LEDs with ITO. In this work, we demonstrate an ITO-free Ag NW-based localized surface plasmon (LSP)-enhanced transparent conducting electrode (TCE). To find a mechanism for improvement in LED efficiency through LSP-enhanced TCEs, internal quantum efficiency (IQE) by quantum well (QW)-LSP coupling and light extraction efficiency (LEE) by TM light&ndash;LSP coupling is studied by controlling the thickness of p-GaN. We found that the enhancement of IQE by QW-LSP coupling is dominant for InGaN-based blue LEDs. To optimize the efficiency of LEDs, we suggest the NW + NP-based TCEs, where NPs work as leak mode and scattering center. The efficiency of LEDs with Ag NW + NP-based TCE is increased by 20% compared to that of LEDs with only Ag NW.
881	Multi-scale electron microscopy of overnitrided Sm-Fe-Mn-N powder	Multi-scale electron microscopy technique that combines transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and focused ion beam - scanning electron microscopy (FIB-SEM) was utilized to investigate the influences of the change in microstructure of Sm2(Fe0.95Mn0.05)17Nx by overnitridation on the magnetic properties. The recent high-contrast backscatter electron imaging technique in SEM machines enabled us to reveal the formation events of cell-like microstructure from a quite large field of view. In addition, detailed TEM observations revealed the crystallographic orientations of the cells as well as the local chemical fluctuation. The combination of these techniques allows us to understand the microstructural hierarchy in this material, verifying that the original orientations of the individual particles are inherited to the nanocrystalline cells formed by overnitridation.
882	Tunable Direct-Indirect Band Gaps of ZrSe<sub>2</sub> Nanoribbons	The atomic and electronic structures of armchair and zigzag  ZrSe<sub>2</sub>  nanoribbons have been investigated systematically. Both the armchair and zigzag  ZrSe<sub>2</sub>  nanoribbons are nonmagnetic semiconductors, while their band gaps show quite different behaviors depending on ribbon width. We find that all the zigzag ribbons possess direct energy gaps, which smoothly decline with the increasing ribbon width. On the other hand, energy gaps for the armchair ribbons change from direct gaps to indirect ones as the ribbon width increases, and exhibit a width-dependent oscillation behavior. Moreover, the semiconducting behaviors and the band gap types are robust, they remain unchanged in bilayer and  multilayered thin films with inter-layer interactions. These findings indicate that ZrSe<sub>2</sub> nanoribbons are promising candidate materials for applications in nanoelectronic devices.
883	<strong>Electricity-mediated plasmonic tip engineering on single Ag nanowire for SERS </strong>	An electricity-mediated plasmonic engineering was applied on a single Ag nanowire to engineer its tip for surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS). Under this constant photoelectric field treatment, a significant sharpening of the tip and reduction of the surface fluctuation was observed for the Ag nanowire tip via in situ atomic force microscopy. A significant SERS signal enhancement was thus obtained after the tip engineering. The relevant dynamic mechanisms of the tip engineering, including the light-induced plasmonic phase transition and electrostatic force driven flow on the Ag nanowire tip are discussed in detail. It is expected that this type of tip engineering will greatly enhance the signal of single metal nanowire SERS probes and provide new insights into fabrication technologies for metal nanostructures.
884	<strong>Analysis of Nanomechanical Sensing Signals; Physical Parameter Estimation for Gas Identification</strong>	Nanomechanical sensors&mdash;emerging chemical sensors which detect changes in mechanical properties caused by gas sorption&mdash;have been attracting much attention owing to their high sensitivity and versatility. In the data analysis of sensing signals, empirically extracted signal features have been commonly employed to identify the gas species. Such an empiric approach cannot be optimized further without a solid guideline, resulting in a limited identification performance. Therefore, a new analytical protocol based on intrinsic physical properties of a target gas and a receptor material has been highly demanded. In this study, we have developed a parameter estimation protocol based on a theoretical model for a cantilever-type nanomechanical sensor coated with a viscoelastic material. This protocol provides a practical estimation method for intrinsic parameters, which can be used for gas identification. As a demonstration of gas identification based on intrinsic parameters, we focused on the time constant for gas diffusion , which reflects the physicochemical interaction between gas species and a receptor material. Based on  estimated from different receptor materials, we succeeded in the identification of solvent vapors. This parameter estimation protocol not only enables the gas identification based on the intrinsic property of target gases, but also provides a scientific guideline for the selection and optimization of receptor materials for nanomechanical sensors.
885	On-demand single photon generation via quantum interference in a &Chi;<sup>(2)</sup> nonlinear nanocavity	A scalable on-chip single photon source at telecom wavelength is essential in quantum communication networks. In this work we numerically construct an on-demand single photon source based on an optical parametric amplifier in a photonic crystal nanocavity. Under the condition of pulsed excitation, we study photon statistics of the source by the Monte Carlo wave function method. The results show that there exits an optimal excitation pulse width for generating high purity single photons, while the source brightness monotonously increases with the increasing of the excitation pulse width.
886	Optimal measurements of a microwire's flexural vibrations using micro-lens optical fiber interferometer	Optical interferometer has been utilized as powerful tools in studying vibrations of a nano/micro-mechanical resonator - an essential ingredient for ultrasensitive detection of small mass, force, displacement. Conventional optical fiber interferometer setup adopts light interference effect only. When a microwire mechanical resonator vibrates along a direction away from the optical axis, the interference signal will be not optimal for the measurements of such vibration. In this work, we theoretically analyze optimal measurements of a microwire's vibrations using micro-lens optical fiber interferometer, where we take both interference and scattering effect of light interacting with a microwire into account. Then, on a home-built micro-lens optical fiber optics system, we confirmed our analysis by measuring a microwire that was driven in varies directions regarding to the optical axis. Our result shows that detection sensitivity can be optimized for a microwire that vibrates in arbitrary directions. The result is also useful in studying flexural vibration modes of a microwire and their applications in vectorial force detections.
887	<strong>Biocompatibility Enhancement of Graphene Oxide-Silver Nanocomposite by Functionalization with Polyvinylpyrrolidone</strong>	The promising graphene-based materials sheets hold a great potential for biological applications owing to its unique properties and relatively low cost. Thus their antimicrobial activity and biocompatibility need the light to be thrown on. This work highlights the importance of functionalization of graphene oxide (GO) sheets using polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and decorating them with silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) in order to enhance their antimicrobial activity and biocompatibility. Decoration of the surface of GO and FGO sheets with AgNPs was carried out easily since GO and FGO sheets can act as stabilizing agent for NPs. The structural and morphological characterizations were performed by UV-Visible, Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR), and Raman Spectroscopic techniques, X-ray Diffraction (XRD) and High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HR-TEM). The antimicrobial activities of the prepared samples against Gram-positive, Gram-negative bacteria and fungi were studied. The cytotoxicity and cell viability of prepared materials were tested against BJ1 normal skin fibroblasts. The results indicated that the decoration with AgNPs showed a significant increase in the antimicrobial activity of GO and FGO sheets, and functionalization of GO sheets and GO-Ag nanocomposite with PVP improved the cell viability by about 40% and 35%, respectively.
888	Wetting characteristics  of vertically aligned graphene nanosheets	The change in water contact angle  (from 103o to 135o) with vertically aligned  graphene nanosheets, as a function of change in the surface geometry, is analysed. Theoretical calculations and comparison with the experimental data shows that the apparent contact angle values of VAGNS are closer to that of fully non-wetting mode or ideal Cassie mode of wetting. Ideal Cassie mode of wetting also explains the variation of the water contact angle of VAGNS with surface morphology of the material and predicts how surface parameters can be modified to get a required wettability for a certain application of this material.
889	<strong>Linear-field plasma jet arrays excited by high-voltage alternating current and nanosecond pulses</strong>	Atmospheric pressure plasma jet arrays can expand the treatment dimension of a single jet to large scales effectively, and the arrays with a good downstream uniformity have a great potential for applications in materials surface treatment and biomedicine. In this paper, a linear-field jet array with a ring-ring electrode structure in Ar is excited by alternating current (AC) and nanosecond (ns) pulse voltage, and the characteristics and downstream uniformity of the array and their dependence on the applied voltage and gas flow rate are investigated and compared through optical, electrical and Schlieren diagnosis. The electrical and hydrodynamic interactions between the jets in the array are analyzed and discussed. The results show that the ns pulse excited jet arrays can generate relatively large-scale plasma with better uniformity, longer plumes and higher intensity active species with a higher energy efficiency than the AC excited ones. No visible deviation of the plume and gas flow trajectories in the light emission and Schlieren images is observed for the ns pulse excited arrays. On the other hand, deviation of plume trajectories is shown to depend on the applied voltage and gas flow rate for the AC excited arrays. The better uniformity of ns pulse excited jet arrays is due to the effective suppression of hydrodynamic and electrical interactions among the jets in the arrays with a ns pulse applied voltage, which induces a lower gas temperature and limits of the cumulative effect of repetitive Coulomb force compared with the AC excitation case.
