890	<strong>Response to &ldquo;Comment on &lsquo;Excellent field emission properties of VO<sub>2</sub>(A) nanogap emitters in air&rsquo;&rdquo;</strong>	This is a short response to a comment (APL18-CR-02110)about our recent paper in Applied Physics Letters (MS # APL18-CR-02110).
891	Enhanced light coupling into periodic arrays of nanoscale semiconducting fins.	In this paper, we study experimentally and theoretically the light coupling into periodic arrays of nanoscale semiconducting fins among others to explain its enhancement when increasing the fin pitch, i.e. the spatial periodicity. With Raman spectroscopy on Si fin arrays, we show the enhancement of the light coupling into the fins in arrays of increasing pitch. We prove that this enhancement is due to the excitation of an electromagnetic mode, which is confined and guided inside the fins, and is more efficiently excited as the pitch increases. Finally, we propose a quantitative analytical model describing the physical mechanism responsible for the light coupling into nanoscale semiconducting fins arranged into periodic arrays of narrow sub-50 nm pitch.
892	<strong>Fabrication and manipulation of nanopillars using electron induced excitation</strong>	This work demonstrates the successful fabrication and in-situ manipulation of nanopillars made of Pt-C composite by means of electron induced bending (EIB) inside a dual beam scanning electron microscope system. Indeed, controlled maneuvering of nanostructures has been of great interest because of its wide possible applications in nanotechnology. Here, Pt-C nanopillars were fabricated and used as building blocks for several nanostructures such as self-assembled nano-cage, nano-switches, nano-grabber, etc. EIB is found to be an efficient way to drive the fabricated nanopillars to yield to different nano-devices. The optimized conditions for EIB manipulation in terms of energy and dose are determined experimentally and Monte Carlo simulations. The suggested mechanisms responsible for the nanopillars response are discussed and they seem to be directly linked to the phase transformation from inherent amorphous phase to crystalline structure of C-Pt. This all-in-one fabrication and manipulation offered by the EIB showed an easy way and low cost in designing 3D nanostructures to be considered for various applications that can be applied to a wide range of metallic/non-metallic structures. Moreover, EIB can be scaled up to mass maneuvering process and extended to other nanoscale structures
893	The single-line-of-sight, time-resolved x-ray imager diagnostic on OMEGA	The single-line-of-sight, time-resolved x-ray imager (SLOS-TRXI) on OMEGA is one of a new generation of fast-gated x-ray cameras comprising an electron pulse-dilation imager and a nanosecond-gated, burst-mode, hybrid complementary metal-oxide semiconductor sensor. SLOS-TRXI images the core of imploded cryogenic deuterium-tritium shells in inertial confinement fusion experiments in the ~4- to 9-keV photon energy range with a pinhole imager onto a photocathode. The diagnostic is mounted on a fixed port almost perpendicular to a 16 channel, framing-camera-based, time-resolved Kirkpatrick-Baez microscope, providing a second time-gated line of sight for hot-spot imaging on OMEGA. SLOS-TRXI achieves ~40-ps temporal resolution and better than 10-&#x03BC;m spatial resolution. Shots with neutron yields of up to 1 &#x00D7; 10^14 were taken without observed neutron-induced background signal. The implosion images from SLOS-TRXI show the evolution of the stagnating core.
894	A strong saddle-shaped surface-to-volume ratio effect on the Young&rsquo;s modulus of silicon nanotubes	Single crystalline silicon nanotubes (NTs) along [001] direction with different outer diameters and wall thicknesses have been successfully prepared via high-fidelity nanofabrication process by combining electron-beam lithography and reactive-ion etching method, achieving a higher specific surface-to-volume ratio compared with other solid one dimensional (1-D) nanomaterials. <em>In situ</em> compression results indicated that the strength of NT increases when the outer diameter decreases with constant wall thickness, but decreases with the decrease of the wall thickness with constant outer diameter. The ultimate strain is over 20% and the maximum strength is almost 16 GPa, approaching the theoretical strength of silicon. More importantly, a strong saddle-shaped surface-to-volume ratio effect on the Young&rsquo;s modulus has been revealed. The Young&rsquo;s modulus increases to a peak at surface-to-volume ratio value of 0.04 nm<sup>-1</sup> and then decreases at higher surface-to-volume ratio. A single core with double shells model was proposed to interpret this unique saddle-shaped surface-to-volume ratio effect on the Young&rsquo;s modulus, which may play a guiding role in designing the nanoscale objects for device applications.
895	Synthesis of CdS nanoparticle by sol-gel method as low temperature NO2 sensor	In the present work, NO2 gas sensor based on Cadmium sulphide (CdS) nanostructures were prepared by using the chemical route technique. CdS thin film of different thickness were prepared by spin coating technique with different speed (1000, 2000 and 3000 rpm). Prepared thin films were characterized using different techniques, such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and Ultraviolet-Visible spectroscopy (UV-Vis), which offered the information about the chemical structure and morphology of CdS thin film. Gas sensing measurements for detecting 20 ppm NO2 gas were carried out on CdS thin film prepared on interdigital electrodes patterned corning glass substrate and a maximum response  of ~1.73&#x00D7;102 at 70 {degree sign}C operating temperature was observed.
896	Ultrafast electron solvation in room temperature ionic liquid observed by femtosecond time-resolved near-IR spectroscopy	The solvation process of electrons generated by femtosecond UV excitation in pure room-temperature ionic liquid N, N, N-trimethyl-n-propylammonium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)amide, [N<sub>1113</sub><sup>+</sup>][NTf<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup>], was directly observed by femtosecond transient absorption spectroscopy with near-IR probe in the range 0.80 eV - 1.30 eV. A broad band centered at 1.12 eV, which is assigned to the solvated electrons, formed within the instrument response time after the UV photoirradiation at 5.17 eV. This broad band showed continuously blue-shifted of 0.09 eV within one nanosecond. The continuous blue-shift indicates clearly that the solvation process of electron in this ionic liquid proceeds in a continuous way. The peak shift kinetics is represented by a stretched exponential decay function, indicating the presence of two or more distinctively different solvation environments in this ionic liquid.
897	Modeling and characterization of surface roughness effect on fluid flow in a PDMS microchannel using a fractal based hybrid lattice Boltzmann method	In micro and nano flows, the fluid flow pattern is sensitive to many intrinsic parameters such as surface rough-<br />ness. In this letter, we have presented the capture of variations in fluid flow in Polydimethylsiloxane(PDMS)<br />microfluidic channels with respect to surface roughness. The velocity of the fluid is measured experimentally<br />and also simulated using a hybrid mesoscopic lattice Boltzmann method (LBM). For simulations, the surface<br />roughness is implemented using a fractal based approach. The Weierstrass-Mandelbrot(WM) mathematical<br />function is explored for realizing various rough surfaces by tuning the fractal dimension parameter. The re-<br />sults show that the computational fluid dynamics model, which incorporated surface roughness, has a better<br />agreement with the experimental results than the model without roughness.
898	Bimetal Seleno-Sulfide CuNiSeS Nanosheet Catalyst for Methylene Blue Degradation in the Dark	To overcome the photocatalytic degradation reaction with the need of light excitation, the exploration of catalyst for the organic degradation reaction without light has become one of the core challenges in catalysis and pollution control. Here we report a novel CuNiSeS nanosheet catalyst with a hexagonal structure by a feasible preparation method. The structure and composition of CuNiSeS were well characterized by X-ray diffractometry and electron microscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectrometry, respectively. The result indicated that the best CuNiSeS-2 of 25 mg displayed excellent activity even in the dark to complete the degradation of 100 ml MB solution of 10 ppm within 5 min. This catalyst also performed relatively good stability and durability for the reusability tests. The reasons for the fast MB degradation in the dark were investigated and the reaction kinetic mechanism was proposed.
899	<strong>Enhancement in Device Memory by inserting an Insulator layer in Lead free Ferroelectric film for Non-Volatile Memory Applications</strong>	We report the structural and electrical properties of Al/SBN/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/Silicon gate stack for non-volatile memory applications. RF magnetron sputtering was used for thin film deposition of SrBi<sub>2</sub>Nb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>9</sub>, Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and their stack on the silicon substrate. Structural characterization using X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) show the perovskite structure of SBN film annealed in the temperature range of 500-800<sup>0</sup>C. Multiple angle ellipsometric analysis carried out on the deposited film annealed at different temperatures shows the refractive index (n) in the range of 2.0941 to 2.1804 for the SBN and 1.7-1.73 for sputtered Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>. Metal-Ferroelectric-Semiconductor (MFeS), Metal-Ferroelectric-Metal (MFeM) and Metal-Ferroelectric-Insulator-Semiconductor (MFeIS) structures were fabricated to investigate the memory window, leakage current density, hysteresis and fatigue characteristics. The Effect of introducing Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> buffer layer, its thickness and its annealing temperature on the structural and electrical properties were investigated. The capacitance-voltage (C-V) data shows the memory window improvement from 1.977 V for MFeS to 2.88 V for MFeIS structure with 10 nm sputtered Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>buffer layer. MFeI<sub>(10nm)</sub>S structures shows leakage current density in the range of nano-amperes/cm<sup>2</sup> with no fatigue for the iteration cycles 10<sup>11</sup>.
900	<strong>Probing the dimerization and refractive index of gold nanoparticle in HeLa cells using single particle spectroscopy</strong>	<strong>Fluorescence based non-destructive, non-invasive high-resolution imaging had been extensively used to visualize living cells without the use of any contrasting agent to track or analyze biological molecules or interactions. However, due to photo bleaching and photo blinking properties of fluorophore, an alternative technique founded on plasmonic nanoparticle based single molecule detection and single molecule spectroscopy has received much interest to monitor the dimerization, to probe the </strong><strong>intracellular refractive index (RI) of gold nanoparticles (AuNP) inside biological cells and to determine biomolecular interaction.</strong>s<p><strong>In this manuscript, we performed a systematic in-depth study to identify the single particle and dimer form of gold nanoparticle (AuNP) embedded in PVA matrix using confocal laser scattering microscopy which has been extended further to identify the dimerization, intracellular refractive index (RI) and biomolecular interaction inside living cells using the hyperspectral imaging and darkfield scattering microscopy. Moreover, we demonstrated a direct more accurate method compared to previously reported indirect measurement which is based on ensemble of AuNPs to identify the single particle and dimer and intracellular RI. In conclusion, these findings will provide a new insight in monitoring cellular dynamics and tracking the targeted nanoparticles within live cells, enabling us to use plasmonic nanoparticles as an intracellular biosensor.</strong>
901	<strong>Optical addressing of nanomechanical metamaterials with subwavelength resolution</strong>	Metamaterials that offer &ldquo;on-demand&rdquo; control of individual metamolecules are termed &ldquo;randomly accessible metamaterials&rdquo;. They can be useful for manipulating the wavefront of electromagnetic radiation, tailoring of the nearfield, and ultimately for multichannel data processing. Here we demonstrate how light can be used to actuate individual metamaterial elements on demand. Selectivity is achieved by constructing the metamaterial from nanomechanical elements that are designed to have slightly different mechanical resonance frequencies. Actuation is controlled by modulation of the optical control signal at the mechanical resonance frequencies of targeted elements, providing an all-optical route to randomly accessible metamaterials with spatial resolution beyond the diffraction limit.
902	Light-Trapping Front Textures for Solar Cells made from a Tailored Mixture of Nanospheres	We report on highly efficient anti-reflection textures for solar cells that allow a fabrication using a two-step bottom-up approach. Hereby, nanospheres of tailored sizes are deposited as a monolayer on a substrate and the resulting height profile is used as a template for structuring the silicon surface. By applying these textures to crystalline silicon solar cells, we numerically show that such interfaces provide excellent broadband suppression of reflection while also enhancing the effective path-length through oblique-angle scattering into the medium. Reflectance values around 5% can be reached and sustained for incident angles up to 40&deg;. The absorption in the crystalline silicon layer reaches values that are comparable to the case of a Lambertian front texture. Considering the simplicity and low costness of the approach, these textures may serve as a promising alternative to other often used anti-reflection textures, especially for large-scale devices.
903	<strong>Direct modulation of a single InP/InAs nano-wire light-emitting diode</strong>	Telecom-band single nanowire (NW) light-emitting diodes (LEDs) on silicon platforms are promising for use as future on-chip light sources. To realize such an LED, we grew p-i-n junction InP/InAs NWs by the vapor-liquid-solid method and used them to fabricate single NW-LED composites on Si wafers. Using a micro-photoluminescence system and current injection probe setup, we were able to estimate the optical and electrical properties. In addition, we demonstrated the dynamic signal modulation capabilities of our device through a digital eye diagram with a pseudorandom binary sequence signal. This telecom-band single nanowire LED using Gbps signal modulation has the potential for use as an on-chip light source.
904	<strong>Fabrication, characterization and hydrogen gas sensing performance of nanostructured V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> thin films prepared by plasma focus method</strong>	Nanocrystalline V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> thin films were deposited on glass substrates at room temperature using a low energy (1.3 kJ) plasma focus device. The effect of number of shots on the structural, morphological and hydrogen gas sensing properties of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> films has been investigated using different methods. The structural properties and phase composition of the films were studied by means of X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman scattering analysis. The results obtained from scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and atomic force microscopy (AFM) analyzes indicated that the size of nanoparticles/agglomerates and surface roughness of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> films strongly depend on number of shots. The variation in the gas response of the films for 1000 ppm concentration of hydrogen gas at different operating temperatures (150 <sup>o</sup>C &ndash; 350 <sup>o</sup>C) revealed an optimal operating temperature of 275<sup>o</sup>C. Moreover, among all the V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> films studied, the sample deposited with 10 shots showed the maximum gas response to various H<sub>2</sub> concentrations at optimal operating temperature.
905	Quantifying Hg(II) ions in solution and bound to Insulin by robust gold nanoclusters	Gold Nanoclusters (Au NCs) synthesized within a protein (human serum albumin) template exhibited intense red luminescence accompanied with a quantum yield &gt;10% and remarkable photo and cluster-core stability for a prolonged period (more than a year). These photoluminescent NCs were resistant to chemical and thermal perturbations but were found to breakdown and exhibit selectivity and high sensitivity for the detection of mercury (II) ions. From application point-of-view, the synthesized Au NCs were efficient to quantify the mercury ions bound to the hormone, Insulin. Interestingly, by exploiting the auto-fluorescence of these protein templated Au NCs, it was demonstrated successfully for the first time that Au/HSA NCs were able to sense Hg(II) ions at single molecule sensitivity using Fluorescence Correlation Spectroscopy highlighting a detection limit in the sub-nanomolar regime.
906	<strong>Optical and Mechanical Properties of the Double-layer Diamond-like Carbon Film Prepared by Double Laser Beams</strong>	On the soft and easy-corrosive silicon window, double-layer diamond-like carbon film was designed and prepared: the inner oxygen-doped DLC layer deposited by femto-sencond laser in the oxygen atmosphere was taken as the infrared anti-reflective layer because of its low refractive index and high transmission, and then the outer pure DLC layer deposited by nano-second laser in the high vacuum was taken as the protective layer based on its high hardness and corrosion resistance. The extreme different properties of the atomic bonds, microscopic structure and optical properties between the pure and oxygen-doped diamond-like carbon films were researched, and different thickness ratios of the two layers in the double-layer film were tried to balance the anti-reflective effect against the protective effect. The tests showed that nanohardness and transmission in the medium infrared band of the samples increased and decreased respectively when thickness of the outer pure DLC layer increased. The pure DLC layer was proved nice corrosion resistance by the corrosion tests, and it must be some thick to prevent the alkaline solution effectively from soaking into the deep-seated depth to corrupt the inner oxygen-doped DLC layer.
907	<strong>Tin-Vacancy in Diamond for Luminescent Thermometry</strong>	Color centers in diamond have shown promising potential for luminescent thermometry. So far, the nitrogen-vacancy (NV) color center has demonstrated a high sensitivity for optical temperature monitoring in biological systems. However, the NV center requires microwave excitation which can cause unwanted heating, and the NV is also sensitive to non-axial magnetic fields, both of which can result in inaccurate temperature measurements. To overcome this drawback, silicon-vacancy (SiV) and germanium-vacancy (GeV) color centers in diamond have recently shown good optical temperature sensitivity via by the temperature shift of their optical zero-phonon line wavelengths. Here we report optical temperature measurements using the recently discovered tin-vacancy (SnV) color center in diamond, and show sensitivity better than 0.2<sup>o</sup>K in 10 s integration time. Also, we compare the relative merits of SnV with respect to SiV and GeV for luminescent thermometry. These results illustrate that there are likely many future options for nanoscale thermometry using diamonds.
908	<strong>Study of the adhesion and friction drag on the rough hydrophobic surface: sandblasting aluminum</strong>	Roughness is a crucial prerequisite for fabricating the superhydrophobic surface. However, due to the enormous economic costs for fabricating the rough surfaces, it seriously prevents application of the superhydrophobic surface in life. In this paper, we presented an uncomplicated, low cost, friendly quick method to fabricate the rough surface with micro- and nanostructured features. Through changing the sandblasting pressure, we fabricated the different roughness surfaces on the aluminum sheets, which were then decorated with the polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) to reduce the surface energy. As a result, the contact angle, slip velocity, slip length and drag reduction ratio increased with the increase of sandblasting pressure, and the maximum contact angle with droplet, slip velocity, length and drag reduction ratio was 151.74&plusmn;1&deg;, 0.1617 m/s, 0.04276 mm and 19.2 % at the sandblasting pressure 0.8 MPa, respectively. The adhesive force of the samples decreased with the sandblasting pressure increase, the minimum of which was 0.096 mN. The process of entrapped air escaped from the samples surface, which was visualized by fluent software. Results showed that the lowly adhesive and lowly frictional property of the superhydrophobic surface, originating from their ability to entrapped air into the space between the protrusions, which could effectively avert the water moving into the space.
909	Calibration sample and related method for wide-range resistance measurements with a conducting probe Atomic Force Microscope	A specialized sample for a direct calibration of resistance measurements by conducting probe Atomic Force Microscope is presented. Combined with an adapted operating method, it enables to test any commercial or home-made current-sensing device proposed for these microscopes in a wide resistance range covering ten decades. This contribution is thought as a first step towards easier, best-mastered quantitative electrical measurements at nanoscale.
910	Electromagnetic proximity effect in planar superconductor-ferromagnet structures	The spread of the Cooper pairs into the ferromagnet in proximity<br />coupled superconductor - ferromagnet (SF) structures is shown to cause a<br />strong inverse electromagnetic phenomenon, namely, the long-range transfer of<br />the magnetic field from the ferromagnet to the superconductor. Contrary to the<br />previously investigated inverse proximity effect resulting from the spin<br />polarization of superconducting surface layer, the characteristic length of<br />the above inverse electrodynamic effect is of the order of the London<br />penetration depth, which usually much larger than the superconducting<br />coherence length. The corresponding spontaneous currents appear even in the<br />absence of the stray field of the ferromagnet and are generated by the<br />vector-potential of magnetization near the S/F interface and they should be taken into account at the design of the nanoscale S/F devices. Similarly to the well-known Aharonov-Bohm effect, the discussed phenomenon can be viewed as a new<br />manifestation of the role of vector potential in quantum physics.
911	Driving useful morphological changes in magnetic nanoparticle structures through the application of acoustic waves and magnetic fields	The growing interest in acoustic manipulation of particles in micro to nanofluidics using surface acoustic waves, together with the many applications of magnetic nanoparticles---whether individual or in arrays---underpins our discovery of how these forces can be used to rapidly, easily, and irreversibly form 1D chains and 2D films. These films and chains are difficult to produce by other methods yet offer many advantages over suspensions of individual nanoparticles by making use of the scale of the structures formed, 10 nm to 10 &micro;m, and by taking a balance of the relevant external and interparticle forces, the underlying mechanisms responsible for the phenomena become apparent.<br />For loosely-connected 1D chains, the magnetic field alone is sufficient, though applying an acoustic field drives a topology change to interconnected loops of ~10&ndash;100 particles. Increasing the acoustic field intensity drives a transition from these looped structures to dense 2D arrays via interparticle Bjerknes forces. Inter-particle drainage of the surrounding fluid leaves these structures intact after removal of the externally applied forces. The self-evident morphology transitions depend solely upon the relative amplitudes of the Brownian, Bjerknes, and magnetic forces.
912	<strong>Non-regular hexagonal 2D - Carbon: an allotrope of graphene</strong><strong>- A First principle study</strong>	Recently there has been a tremendous research activity in the area of sp2 carbon-based nanostructures. This research has led to a number of fundamental discoveries in materials physics and their applications. Theoretical and computational modelling has been playing an important role in this field. In a first principle study, using density functional theory, we have identified three types of  2D carbon sheets, made entirely of non-regular hexagons. In one case we get a system where the non regular hexagons have two sides same length (<em>d</em><sub>1</sub>=1.416&Aring;) and four sides same length (<em>d</em><sub>2</sub>=1.68&Aring;). In another two cases the non regular hexagons have three pairs (opposite sides) of different lengths (<em>d</em><sub>1</sub>=1.529&Aring;, <em>d</em><sub>2</sub>=1.567&Aring; d <em>d</em><sub>3</sub> = 1.612&Aring; ; <em>d</em><sub>1</sub>=1.387&Aring;, <em>d</em><sub>2</sub>=1.348&Aring; and <em>d</em><sub>3</sub> = 1.387&Aring;) as their opposite sides. By propper choice of  the non-regular hexagon sides one could arrive at a 2D carbon systemDue similar to graphene, but with a tunable band gap. The structure is more stable when the system has  more number of regular C-C bonds  than the longer C-C bonds. Due to its non-regular hexagons - special atomic configuration, this system may have, like graphene,  unusual properties. It is semiconducting and  there is no need to functionalize it for opening the band gap as is the case with graphene
913	Pyrolysis-induced shrinking of three-dimensional structures fabricated by two-photon polymerization: Experiment and theoretical model	Suspended carbon nanowires were fabricated by pyrolysis of photoresist microstructures written using two-photon polymerization (TPP). Upon pyrolysis, the TPP photoresist microwires exhibited shrinkage by as much as 72%, resulting in predominantly carbon microstructures, as confirmed by energy dispersive spectroscopy. The linewidth of the carbon nanowires ranged from 400 nm to 800 nm and was found to be dependent on the TPP exposure parameters, even after the thermal decomposition induced by the pyrolysis step. Furthermore, we present a theoretical model that describes the dependence of the feature size of the carbon structures on the TPP fabrication parameters. It is expected that this model can be extended to analyze and optimize other micro/nano-carbon geometries
914	<strong>Development and characterization of a wire-plate air bubbling plasma for wastewater treatment </strong><strong>using nanosecond pulsed high voltage </strong>	Upscaling plasma-based reactors is one of the challenges for implementing this technology to treat large volumes of wastewater. This study is aimed at developing a prototype reactor that can be easily scaled up for wastewater treatment using a wire-plate air bubbling plasma. The electrical characteristics of the developed reactor were deeply investigated at different operating parameters and solution conductivities. The performance of the reactor was examined on the basis of energy efficiency and methylene blue (MB) decoloration efficiency. Moreover, the impact of the treatment process on the TOC and the physicochemical properties, including the pH, the conductivity and the temperature of the treated solution was assessed. The analysis of current discharge and average power consumed showed that the discharge behaved like dielectric barrier discharge, where streamer was the mode of discharge. Interestingly, the solution conductivity had no effect on the average power consumed at a low applied voltage, due to the confining of the discharge in a small area around the discharge electrode in the gas phase. However, at a relatively high voltage, the effect of conductivity on the average power consumed was noticeable, yet it had no effect on the decoloration efficiency at the same average power. The present reactor showed a high energy efficiency value of 42 g/kWh at 50% decoloration of 30 mg/L MB solution, but it dropped to 14 g/kWh at 97% decoloration. A first-order kinetics model described well the decoloration reaction rates and the overall rate constant, correlated linearly to the average power.
915	<strong>Structural instability and dynamic fluctuations in ZnO random lasers </strong>	We report experimental results on the structural stability of optically pumped zinc oxide random lasers. We find that the lasing threshold is not entirely stable and depends on the accumulated light exposure received in pulsed optical pumping. We show that an accumulated exposure below ~1 J improves the lasing efficiency and lowers the threshold. Beyond that value, however, lasing efficiency and threshold begin to degrade. Electron microscopy shows that the degradation is accompanied by morphological changes characteristic of melting. These changes become visible at exposures of ~0.5 J. We suggest that the melting initially remains localized within nanometer areas and that the initial improvement is due to defect annealing. For exposures &gt;1 J the melting zones connect leading to deterioration. The findings mostly affect random lasers used in the incoherent lasing regime.  If stable output from ZnO random lasers is desired, a lower lasing thresholds or higher damage threshold are needed.
916	High-frequency measurements of thermophysical properties of thin films using a modified broad-band frequency domain thermoreflectance approach	In this work we present the implementation of a new method to perform high-frequency thermoreflectance measurements on thin films. The so-called Differential Broad-Band Frequency Domain Thermoreflectance (DBB-FDTR) method follows BB-FDTR developed previously [Rev. Sci. Instrum. 84, 064901 (2013)], without the use of expensive electro-optic modulators. Two techniques are introduced to recover the thermal phase of interest and to separate it from the unwanted instrumental contributions to the recorded phase. Measuring a differential thermal phase by either varying the spot size or offsetting the pump and probe beams, the thermophysical properties of materials can be extracted. This approach enables the study of nanoscale heat transport where non-equilibrium phenomena are dominating.
917	A DPM hybrid continuum-atomistic model for electrokinetics in nanofluidics	The ever-growing field of micro and nanotechnology has a great deal of interest in simulating dynamic phenomena of multiscale systems. Hybrid approaches that produce a trade-off between accuracy and computational costs play a key role in this area. In this study, an improved hybrid continuum-atomistic model is proposed for the simulation of electroosmotic flows in nanochannels. The aqueous solvent phase is modeled by the continuum four-way coupled Navier-Stokes equations while a Lagrangian approach is used for the ion transport. Different forces, including the drag, buoyancy, Brownian, electrostatic, and ion-ion/wall-ion collision, and torques, including the drag and collision, govern the motion of the ion particles. The ion-ion/wall-ion collision is taken into account by a Discrete Phase Model (DPM) and the electric field is derived by the Poisson-Boltzmann closure. The results of the model, such as the change of bulk velocity with the surface electric charge density, are validated by several molecular dynamics simulations and experimental observations available in the literature. It is shown that the present hybrid model is capable of predicting the main features of the problem. Moreover, the significance of different forces and the other alternative for modeling the external electric field, i.e. the discrete Coulomb&rsquo;s approach with the Modified Particle Mesh Ewald boundary treatment, are also examined. The proposed model would be extremely useful for future studies on the electrokinetics in nanochannels, esp. in more complex geometries where the MD approaches are limited due to the computational costs.
918	Full-wave theory for WGM lasing of fully anisotropic nanoparticles beyond visible	A full-wave theory for the prediction of the complex whispering-gallery-mode (WGM) resonances beyond visible, of fully anisotropic nano/microresonators, is presented. The theory is based on the volume integral equation (VIE) method, supported by appropriate perturbation theory which enables analytical closed-form expressions valid for extremely large indices of the involved spherical wavefunctions. These closed-form expressions allow for the instant computation of the eigenbasis required for the solution of the VIE. The theory is applied to the calculation of WGM spectra of uniaxial semiconductor crystals beyond visible, to gyroelectric magnetic garnets, and to geometrical birefringence (GB) enhancement due to large Verdet constants. Combined with a state-of-the-art open-source algorithm for complex roots computation, this theory constitutes a rigorous tool for the interpretation of experimental data obtained from photonic and optomagnonic applications, including WGM lasing of fully anisotropic nanoparticles and magneto-optical (MO) coupling.
919	Optimized nanocrystalline silicon oxide emitter and back surface field for silicon heterojunction solar cells	In this work, a p-type (boron-doped) wide-gap hydrogenated nanocrystalline silicon oxide (p-nc-SiO<sub>x</sub>:H) as an emitter window layer was investigated for silicon heterojunction solar cell applications. We present a p-type nc-SiO<sub>x</sub>:H material with a &ldquo;sandwich&rdquo; type structure (p-&mu;c-Si:H/p-nc-SiO<sub>x</sub>:H/p-&mu;c-Si:H). The P-&mu;c-Si:H on top of the p-nc-SiO<sub>x</sub>:H improves the p-emitter/n-type Transparent Conducting Oxide (TCO) contact and enhances the built-in electric field of the P-N junction. The P-&mu;c-Si:H under the p-nc-SiO<sub>x</sub>:H serves as the seeding layer and enhances the initial nucleation of the emitter. A higher external quantum efficiency (EQE) response and fill factor of the solar cells can be achieved using the novel p-type nc-SiO<sub>x</sub>:H material. In addition, the use of n-type (phosphorus-doped) nc-SiO<sub>x</sub>:H as the back surface field (BSF) of the solar cell further improves the fill factor. A solar cell with a conversion efficiency of 19.76% and current density of 40.2 mA/cm<sup>2</sup> was obtained.
920	Time-dependent interfacial thermal resistance for transient ballistic-diffusive heat transport	Interfaces play an important role in nanoscale thermal transport. However, more attention are paid to interfacial thermal resistance (ITR) in steady state conditions, leaving that in transient cases still less understood. In this work, ballistic heat wave propagation through bilayer nanofilms is simulated as a representative transient phonon ballistic-diffusive transport using phonon Monte Carlo method. It is found that ITR in transient ballistic-diffusive heat transport is not constant, but changes over time instead. The significant time dependence is caused by time-dependent angle distribution of phonons scattered at interface, i.e. degree of non-equilibrium of phonons at interface in wave vector space, and that contribution to ITR differs for phonons impinging on interface with different angels. A theoretical model based on weighted sum of angles of phonons scattered at interface is derived to well describe the time-dependent ITR. Also, Minimum ITR is predicted when phonon initial emission direction is vertical to the boundary and phonon transport is then in completely ballistic regime. This work is expected to promote understanding on ITR and help to guide heat transport through interface.
921	New candidates for the global minimum of medium-sized silicon clusters: A hybridsDFTB/DFT genetic algorithm applied to Si<sub>n</sub>, n = 8-80	In this study, we perform a systematic search to find the possible lowest energy structure of silicon nanoclusters Si<sub> n</sub> (n = 8-80) by means of an evolutionary algorithm. The fitness function for this search is the total energy of density functional tight binding (DFTB). To be on firm ground, we take several low energy structures of DFTB and perform further geometrical optimization by density functional theory (DFT). Then we choose structures with the lowest DFT total energy and compare them with the reported lowest energy structures in the literature. In our search, we found several lowest energy structures that were previously unreported. We further observe a geometrical transition at n = 27 from elongated to globular structures. In addition, the optical gap of the lowest energy structures is investigated by time-dependent DFTB (TD-DFTB) and time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT). The results show the same trend in TD-DFTB and TD-DFT for the optical gap. Wesalso find a sudden drop in the optical gap at n = 27, precisely where the geometrical transition occurs.
922	Metastable vortex-like polarization textures in ferroelectric nanoparticles of different shapes and sizes	The dependence of the polarization textures topology in dielectric matrix embedded ferroelectric PbTiO3 nanoparticles on the particle shape and size was investigated with a time-dependent Landau-Ginzburg-Devonshire approach combined with coupled-physics finite-element-method based simulations. Particle shapes belonging to the superellipsoidal family were probed, including octahedral, cubic and intermediate geometries. For each shape, a parametric sweep of particle sizes ranging from 2 to 40 nm was conducted, revealing a general trend for the texture transformations from a monodomain, through a vortex-like, to a multidomain state, as the size increases. Critical particle sizes for the texture instabilities were found to be strongly dependent on the particle shape, with octahedral particles undergoing transitions at much larger volumes, compared to the cubic particles. Furthermore, for all the considered non-spherical shapes of appropriate size, it was possible to align the paraelectric polar-vortex cores with every rotational axis of the particle point symmetry group. The shape-dependent metastability of the vortex-like textures opens up new avenues for controlling polarization at the nanoscale in a variety of technological applications.
923	Room Temperature Ferromagnetic Resonance in Hetero-Epitaxial $BTO-BFO/LSMO$ Magnetoelectric Composite	We observed small Gilbert damping ($\alpha=$0.004) and the absence of large inhomogeneous broadening, in a film with 80 nm thickness of BTO-BFO on LSMO (110). This fact offers opportunities for employing this material system for spin transfer in multifunctional materials where controlling magnetization by a flow of spin angular momentum, or spin current, is crucial toward developing nanoscale spin-based memory and devices. Magnetic insulators, such as BTO-BFO on LSMO, are potentially excellent candidates for pure spin current without the existence of charge current.
924	<strong>A bottom-up approach for controlled deformation of </strong><strong>carbon nanotubes through blistering of supporting substrate surface</strong>	Tuning the band structure and, in particular, gap opening in 1D and 2D materials through their deformation is a promising approach for their application in modern semiconductor devices. However, there is an essential breach between existing laboratory scale methods applied for deformation of low-dimensional materials and the needs of large-scale production. In this work, we propose a novel method which is potentially well compatible with high end technological application: single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) first deposited on the flat surface of a supporting wafer, which has been pre-implanted with H<sup>+</sup> and He<sup>+</sup> ions, are deformed in a controlled and repetitive manner over blisters formed after subsequent thermal annealing. By using resonant Raman spectroscopy, we demonstrate that the SWCNTs clamped by metallic stripes at their ends are deformed over blisters to an average tensile strain of 0.15 &plusmn; 0.03 %, which is found to be in a good agreement with the value calculated taking into account blister&rsquo;s dimensions. The principle of the technique may be applied to other 1D and 2D materials in perspective.
925	<strong>The formation of relatively low temperature crystalline phase of </strong><strong>Y<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7 </sub>from mesoporous silica and Y<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>:Ln<sup>3+</sup>: Luminescence studies</strong>	Mesoporous silica nanoparticles (mSiO<sub>2</sub>) have been used in many applications including drug delivery, catalysis, sensing. In drug delivery, tracing of mSiO<sub>2 </sub>needs incorporation of organic dyes or radio nuclei, etc.  However, organic dyes are unstable under various mediums or in longer duration. To overcome this, one of ways is use of lanthanide ions (Ln<sup>3+</sup>) such Eu<sup>3+</sup>, Tb<sup>3+</sup> or Dy<sup>3+</sup>, which show luminescence in visible as well as near infrared (NIR) regions. In this work, nanocomposites of mSiO<sub>2</sub> and Y<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>:Ln<sup>3+</sup> have been prepared. These are characterized by many techniques. mSiO<sub>2</sub> is stable up to 500 <sup>o</sup>C and microstructure of mesoporous collapses at 900 <sup>o</sup>C. Interestingly, mSiO<sub>2</sub> reacts with Y<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> to form Y<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7 </sub>phase at 900 <sup>o</sup>C. On the other hand, such phase was not formed from Y<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and amorphous SiO<sub>2</sub> at same temperature. This finding of the formation of highly crystalline Y<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7 </sub>at lower temperature 900 <sup>o</sup>C is the first report to the best of authors&rsquo; knowledge. Their luminescence studies are performed by single or multi doping of Ln<sup>3+</sup> ions. Their energy transfer processes are discussed. The crystallinity of Y<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> or Y<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> is improved after co-doping of Ce<sup>3+</sup> to Ln<sup>3+</sup>. Such nanocomposites are highly dispersible in distilled water, methanol and PBS (Phosphate Buffered Saline).
926	<strong>The effect of second phase particles on light transmission of ZnS/diamond nanocomposite</strong>	The effect of second phase size (200, 400, 600 and 800 nm) and volume fraction (10, 20 and 30%) on light scattering behavior of ZnS/diamond composite was simulated using Mie theory and FDTD. To &#x200B;validate&#x200B; this approach&#x200B;, simulation results of Mie theory and FDTD method were compared with experimental light transmission (T) of 50%-50% vol Y2O3-MgO composite. &#x200B;&#x200B;The results showed that the difference between simulation curves based on Mie theory and FDTD method became more significant with increasing second phase size particularly at greater volume fractions. &#x200B;&#x200B;Using the simulated curves of ZnS/diamond nanocomposite using FDTD method, the optimized second phase was found to be &le; 200 nm in volume fractions 10, 20 and 30%&#x200B;. &#x200B;&#x200B;In the other words for ZnS/diamond nanocomposite&#x200B;,&#x200B; &#x200B;with &#x200B;&#x200B;volume fraction of 10, 20 and 30 vol% of diamond,  the effect of diamond &#x200B;particles on  light transmission can be ignored.
927	Dispenser Cathode Modified with Nanocarbon	The technique of manufacturing a metal-porous emitter with two kinds of carbon nanoparticles: the sulfo-adduct of graphene-type particles (Ugleron&#x00AE;) and polyhedral multilayer toroidal particles (Astralen&#x00AE;,) embedded in the active substance and metal sponge is presented. This modification has a goal to improve the emission properties of this type of electron source. The new technology is aimed at increasing the durability of the electri&#x0441; vacuum devices over 100,000 hours. sThe results of emission tests of the modified cathodes are presented. The prototype with Ugleron&#x00AE; particles in the emission substance display service life-time over 30,000 h, and now trials are continuated. The prototype using Astralenes&#x00AE; and Uglerons&#x00AE; in sponge and emission material, respectively with emission current up to 20A/cm2 shows the results comparable with the standard cathode. However, assuming that the cathodes with Astralenes&#x00AE; and Ugleron&#x00AE; have a lower rate of evaporation of the active substance, longer service life-time in comparison with the standard model with the same emission current could be predicted.
928	Structural and optical properties of black TiO2 nanorods	In this communication, XPS, TEM, Raman and UV-visible techniques are used to examine the composition and microstructure of black TiO2 (B-TiO2) nanorods. We find that B-TiO2 presents 89.3% rutile and 10.7% anatase phases, and the rutile TiO2 nanorods with diameter of 5-7 nm plays an important role in enhancing the optical absorption under visible-light region. Besides, we firstly demonstrate that the optical absorption coefficient is closely correlated with the imaginary component of dielectric constant.
929	Angular Dependence of Magnetisation Behaviour in NiFe Nanowires by Micromagnetic Simulations	The Object Oriented Micromagnetic Framework (OOMMF) modelling has been systematically carried out to investigate the magnetization reversal process of ferromagnetic Ni<sub>81</sub>Fe<sub>19</sub> (permalloy) nanowires. These investigations have been executed on two different geometric shapes which were  cylindrical and rectangular nanowires of different diameters/thicknesses (W) up to 150 nm of the same length of 1 &micro;m. For both geometries, there was a slight reduction in the remanent magnetization by increasing the nanowires W up to 100 nm, which then decreased rapidly up to 150 nm. This was attributed to the formation of multidomain structures as confirmed by micromagnetic configurations which indicates that the shape anisotropy is less significant in relatively thick nanowires. There was a reduction in the remanent magnetization by increasing the nanowires angle with respect to the field applied and showed a good agreement with the theoretical calculations. The angular dependence of switching was compared with the literature and with the classical Stoner-Wohlfarth and curling models. Cylindrical nanowires showed slightly higher switching fields than their counterparts rectangular nanowires and was attributed to the discretization effect or the existence of sharp corners in such wires which could prevent the occurrence of the vortex state at their edges. The magnetic reversal response for nanowires of &le;30 nm was well described by the Stoner-Wohlfarth model, whilst, for nanowires of &ge;50 nm was designated by the curling model. The micromagnetic spin structure obtained at different angles of relatively thick nanowires suggested that the reversal is not a simple behavior as predicted by curling model.
930	Neutron Diffraction and Quasielastic Scattering Studies on Layer Nanostructures and Related Dynamics in Imidazolium-based Ionic Liquids	Alkyl-methyl-imidazolium ionic liquids CnmimX (n: alkyl-carbon number, X: anion) have layer nanostructures consisting of ionic and neutral (alkylchain) domains. To investigate the temperature dependences of the inter-layer, inter-ionic group and inter-alkylchain correlations, we have measured the neutron diffraction (ND) of C16mimPF6, C9.5mimPF6 and C8mimPF6 in the temperature region from 4 K to 470 K. The quasielastic neutron scattering (QENS) of C16mimPF6 was also measured to study the dynamics of each correlation. C16mimPF6 shows a first-order transition between liquid (L) and liquid crystalline (LC) phases at Tc = 394 K. C8mimPF6 exhibits a glass transition at Tg = 200 K. C9.5mimPF6, which is a 1:3 mixture between C8mimPF6 and C10mimPF6, has both transitions at Tc = 225 K and Tg = 203 K. In the ND experiments, all samples exhibit three peaks corresponding to the correlations mentioned above. The widths of the inter-layer peak at ca. 0.2 &#x00C5;-1 changed drastically at the L-LC transitions, while the inter-ionic peaks at ca. 1 &#x00C5;-1 exhibited a small jump at Tc. The peak position and area of the three peaks did not change much at the transition. On the other hand, the structural changes were minimal at Tg. The QENS experiments demonstrated that the relaxation time of the inter-layer motion increased tenfold at Tc, while those of other motions were monotonous in the whole temperature region. The structural and dynamical changes mentioned above are characteristic of the L-LC transition in imidazolium-based ionic liquids.
931	Thermal conductivity reduction in highly doped mesoporous silicon: the effect of nano-crystal formation	We present a study regarding the thermal transport properties in mesoporous silicon fabricated from highly doped p-type and n-type silicon wafers. We employed a laser induced transient thermal grating technique (TTG) to obtain the effective (in-plane) thermal conductivity (<em>k</em>), which presents a reduction by two orders of magnitude with respect to the bulk value. Furthermore, we show that the main factor for the decrease in <em>k</em> is the reduction in the phonon mean free path (MFP) due to the formation of nano-crystalline domains, which are a consequence of the wet etching fabrication method. Additionally, we present in-plane thermal conductivity calculations employing an effective medium approach, which we modify in order to include MFP reduction due to the presence of both the nanometric pores and the nano-crystalline domains. Our results indicate the importance of considering the phonon MFP reduction of by the nano-crystals when calculating the thermal conductivity of porous samples.
932	A comparative study of individual influences of suspended multiwalled carbon nanotubes and alumina on Rayleigh-Benard convection in water	The generalized Lorenz model for studying the Rayleigh-Benard convection in water-multiwalled carbon nanotubes and water-alumina suspensions in the presence of heat source/sink is derived using a tri-modal, Fourier series representation under the assumption of the Boussinesq approximation and small-scale convective motion. On the premise that the nanoparticles undergo all motions which the liquid particles undergo the single-phase description of the Khanafer-Vafai-Lightstone model can be adopted. The thermophysical properties of water-multiwalled carbon nanotubes and water-alumina are calculated using the phenomenological laws and traditional mixture theory. The transition of the dynamical Lorenz system from stability to chaos is explained in detail by calculating maximum Lyapunov exponent for different values of the eigenvalue (thermal Rayleigh number). Specially, the individual effect of multiwalled carbon nanotubes and alumina on stability of dynamical system is investigated from a new perspective of time series solution and attractors of the generalized Lorenz model. We then study the individual influence of multiwalled carbon nanotubes and alumina on onset of convection and heat transport in terms of such a time series analysis. The findings of a feasibility study indicate that less expensive spherical alumina nanoparticles are preferable in heat transfer applications over the more expensive multiwalled carbon nanotubes, in spite of the latter having larger surface area and higher thermal conductivity. It is found that exactly the same amount of heat transfer obtained by using multiwalled carbon nanotubes can be achieved by replacing them with a slightly higher volume fraction of the much cheaper alumina nanoparticles.
933	Reactive Molecular Dynamic Simulation of Thermal Decomposition for Nano-Aluminized Explosives	Aluminized explosives have important applications in civil constructions and military armaments, but their thermal decomposition mechanisms are not well characterized. Here, the thermal decomposition of TNT, RDX, HMX and CL-20 on Al nanoparticles is examined by reactive dynamic simulations using a newly parameterized reactive force field with low gradient correction (ReaxFF-lg). The partially passivated Al nanoparticles were constructed and mixed with TNT, RDX, HMX and CL-20 crystals and then the mixed systems are heated to high temperature in which the explosives are fully decomposed. The simulation results show that the aluminized explosives undergo three main steps of thermal decomposition, which were denoted as "adsorption period" (0-20 ps), "diffusion period" (20-80 ps) and "formation period" (80-210 ps). These stages in sequence are the chemical adsorption between Al and surrounding explosive molecules (R-NO2-Al bonding), the decomposition of the explosives and the diffusion of O atoms into the Al nanoparticles, and the formation of the final products. In the first stage the Al nanoparticle removes the decomposition reaction barriers of RDX (1.90 kJ/g), HMX (1.95 kJ/g) and CL-20 (1.18 kJ/g), respectively, and decreases the decomposition reaction barrier of TNT from 2.99 to 0.29 kJ/g. Comparing with the crystalline RDX, HMX and CL-20, the energy releases are increased by 4.73-4.96 kJ/g in the second stage. The numbers of produced H2O are increased by 25.27%-27.81% and the numbers of CO2 are decreased by 47.73%-68.01% in the third stage. These three stages are confirmed further by the evolutive diagram of the structure and temperature distribution for the CL-20/Al system. The onset temperatures (To) of generating H2O for all the aluminized explosives decrease, while that of generating CO2 for aluminized HMX and CL-20 increases, which are in accord with the experiment of aluminized RDX.
934	Superconducting coincidence photon detector with short timing jitter	We demonstrate the operation of a new coincidence photon detector with short timing jitter consisting of two superconducting nanowire single photon detectors (SSPDs) and a single flux quantum (SFQ) circuit. By utilizing the timing discrimination capability of the SFQ coincidence circuit, the full width at half maximum (FWHM) timing jitter of the entire coincidence photon detector was evaluated as 32.3 ps, which is 36 ps less than that of the standard commercial time correlated single photon counting (TCSPC) module, and the timing jitter of SSPD was estimated as ~15 ps. Owing to short timing jitter characteristics, our coincidence photon detector could correctly capture the effect of pulse-width broadening by insertion of an optical bandpass filter. We have also demonstrated that our coincidence photon detection clearly shows Hong-Ou-Mandel (HOM) interference with a weak coherent pulse. These results are a crucial step to realizing high timing resolution coincidence measurements, ushering in a new technology to perform timing measurement based multi-photon quantum interference.
935	Entropy generation in Tangent Hyperbolic nanofluid flow due to metachronal wave of cilia	This study presents the advantage of entropy generation in Tangent hyperbolic nanofluid. The blood flow (Tangent hyperbolic nanofluid) is induced by ciliary movement which develop the metachronal wave. The Tangent hyperbolic fluid flows through a symmetric ciliated tube (wavy surface). The momentum and energy equation of the considered fluid flow are modeled with small Reynold's number. The resulting systems of partial differential equations are solved by analytic technique HPM. The mathematical expression of velocity, temperature and entropy generation are calculated analytically and their graphically results for emerging parameters are also presented in last section.
936	<strong>Edge mode based graphene nanomechanical resonators for high-sensitivity mass sensor</strong>	We perform both molecular dynamics simulations and theoretical analysis to study the sensitivity of the mass sensor based on graphene nanomechanical resonators, which are actuated following the global extended mode or the localized edge mode. We find that the mass detection sensitivity corresponding to the edge mode is about three times higher than that corresponding to the extended mode. Our analytic derivations reveal that the enhancement of the sensitivity originates in the reduction of the effective mass for the edge mode due to its localizing feature. Our findings shed light on improving the sensitivity of the graphene based mass spectrometry by utilizing the localized edge mode.
937	Maxwell-Boltzmann versus non-ergodic events in the velocity distribution of water molecules evaporated from protonated water nanodroplets	Measurement of velocity distributions of evaporated water monomers from small mass- and energy-selected protonated water clusters allows probing the extent of thermalization after excitation of these ultimately small nanodroplets. Electronic excitation of a molecule in the cluster is here induced by a single collision with an argon atom in the keV energy range. The measured velocity distributions of the departing neutral molecules exhibit bimodal shapes with a lower-velocity part consistent with a complete redistribution of the deposited energy in the entire cluster and a higher-velocity contribution corresponding to evaporation before complete energy redistribution. Statistical molecular dynamics calculations reproduce the bimodal shape of the velocity distributions by assuming an initial spreading of the excitation energy among all modes, thereby reproducing the lower velocity contribution of the distribution. In contrast, assuming the deposited energy to be initially localized among the modes of a single molecule leads to calculated distributions with two components in accordance with the experimental results. The characteristics and the relative abundance of these two contributions in the velocity distributions obtained are presented and discussed as a function of the number of molecules (n=2-10) in the ionized nanodroplet H+(H2O)n.
938	Reduced Scaling CASPT2 Using Supporting Subspaces and Tensor Hyper-Contraction	We present a reduced scaling formulation of the state specific CASPT2 method requiring O(N4) operations and O(N2) memory for a fixed active space, where N is proportional to system size. Motivated by the properties of the Kronecker sum, we introduce the supporting subspace technique (SST), which decomposes the CASPT2 linear equations into two parts: a single-reference MP2 energy term using dressed orbitals, plus a reduced linear system with dimension scaling as O(N2). Together with Laplace quadrature, the supporting subspace technique allows us to reformulate CASPT2 using a MP2 energy computation and Fock builds. By further applying the tensor hyper-contraction (THC) approximation, the MP2-like term can be computed with O(N4) operations, and the remainder can be solved with O(N3) operations using the preconditioned conjugate gradient method. This is the first application of THC in the context of multi-reference methods. We also developed an efficient implementation of the method by utilizing graphical processing units and exploiting spatial sparsity in tensor operations. We benchmark the accuracy of the new method against conventional CASPT2 for reactions in the gas phase. We apply the new method to Menshutkin SN2 reactions in carbon nanotubes, demonstrating the feasibility of CASPT2 calculations with O(100) atoms.
939	<strong>Functionalizing self-assembled nanostructured a-Si:Al films</strong>	The immiscibility of Si and Al may be utilized to produce a thin film of vertically aligned Al nanowires of 5 nm diameter within an amorphous silicon matrix (a-Si). In this work we study functionalization of these structures by removal of the Al nanowires. The nanowires have been etched by an aqueous solution of HCl, which results in a structure of vertically aligned nanochannels in a-Si with admixture of SiO<sub>x</sub>. The removal of Al nanowires has been monitored by several electron microscopy techniques, X-ray diffraction, Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy and optical reflectance. It has been established that optical reflectance measurements can reliably identify the complete removal of Al, confirmed by other techniques. This provides a robust and relatively simple method for controlling the nano-fabrication process on a macroscopic scale.
940	Silicon slot waveguide Fano resonator	The growing interest for Fano resonators during the past decade is due to the narrow line shape observable in their optical spectrum. The drastic phase shift occurring at the resonance yields a steep drop from a high to a low amplitude. Fano resonances can be obtained by a combination of nanostructures. Such a system is extremely sensitive both in terms of geometrical parameters and environmental conditions. Here, we study a complex arrangement of photonic crystal cavities and slot waveguides on a silicon chip. Our structure, composed of several cavities in parallel, has a particular response superimposing a shallow photonic band gap and a resonance with a Fano line shape. It provides a low noise and a clear asymmetric resonance. We demonstrate it experimentally and show the potential of such a device for sensing. A sensitivity of 92 nm/RIU is measured.
941	In situ thermo-mechanical bending behavior of VO<sub>2</sub> microcantilevers across metal insulator transition	Thermomechanical bending response of VO<sub>2</sub> microcantilever has been investigated at different temperatures across the metal insulator transition using multipoint bending protocol in a nanoindentation system.  Sharp metal-insulator transition and structural change were captured at around 68 &deg;C by resistance-temperature  and differential scanning calorimetry  plots prior to the microcantilever bending experiments respectively. Load-deflection curves were obtained before and after the transition temperature by applying load at a point with systematic variation in distance from fixed end of cantilever. Temperature dependent bending modulus and spring constant of different phases for VO<sub>2</sub> microbeam, anchored at one end have been estimated from the measured cantilever deflection values using Euler-Bernoulli beam theory. An abrupt increase in bending modulus varying from 142 GPa  to 170 GPa between 65 &deg;C  and 75 &deg;C is observed. Spring constant of the microcantilever is found to increase by a factor of ~ 1.35 during the structural phase transition of VO<sub>2</sub> from monoclinic to rutile structures. The studied bending behavior of VO<sub>2</sub> across the phase transition with large changes in stiffness values are important for understanding the mechanical response for improving the design towards efficient cantilever and MEMS devices.
942	Tunable and selective transmission based on multiple resonance modes in side-coupled sectorial-ring cavity waveguide	We report a novel plasmonic nanodevice in side-coupled sectorial-ring cavity waveguide, and study the transmission performance of the novel system. It is found from the two-dimensional simulation that the novel system excites the extra non-integer resonance modes, in contrast to the circular-ring cavity resonator system which can support only the classical integer resonance modes. The results show that the multiple resonance modes of the novel system can be highly tuned and modified by manipulating the size of central angle or the position of symmetry plane angle, the central angle has the similar and different influences on resonance wavelengths and minimum transmittances, and the left- or right-handed symmetry plane angle is the same effect. Interestingly, these resonance modes are extremely sensitive to the symmetry plane angle, and the associated modes can be efficiently selected and improved by the enhancing, weakening, exciting or disappearing of resonance mode. The proposed structure not only is oversize central angle, alterable symmetry plane angle and fixed radius and gap, but also forms split-ring-like, realizes asymmetrical cavity and achieves tunable and selective transmission. Our results indicate that the plasmonic nanodevice is a promising candidate as a tunable and selective multi-channel nanofilter or nanosensor in plasmonic nanophotonics applications, and the optical technique provides a good flexibility to accurately design the transmission spectrum with prospective modes in integrated nano-optics devices.
943	<SPAN style="font-size: 20.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; color: windowtext;">Rapid Dip-Dry MWNT-rGO Ink Wrapped Polyester Elastic Band (PEB) For Piezoresistive Strain Sensor Applications</SPAN>	Herein, we report the fabrication as well as application of the multiwall carbon nanotubes- reduced graphene oxide polyester band (MWNT-rGO@PEB) piezoresistive strain sensor for the human-machine interfacing applications. The addition of unzipped functionalized MWNTs in the rGO ink assists in providing the propagation path to the charge carriers. The sensing mechanism involved for this strain sensor comprises of two regimes, one with GF 150 (0 % to 25 %) and other one is 650 (28 % to 40 %) with the change in the resistivity at low strain value since the fibres entangled together and wrapped with conductive rGO flakes gets separated very slightly apart while at higher stain values, the flakes wrapped on the fibres backbones are separated far apart such that percolation path for the charges got disconnected. This kind of sensing mechanism is potential enough to detect small scale as well as large scale motions with excellent reproducibility over 2000 cycles. Some heath monitoring applications such as forearm motion, cheek bulging, finger bending, etc have been successfully demonstrated in the real time by using this piezoresistive strain sensor. The significant advantages of these sensors are that its cost is low; it is easy to fabricate (one step); and it has a versatility that renders it favourable to health-monitoring applications.
944	MHD flow of Carreau nanofluid over a stretching surface with suction/injection and slip effects by using Haar wavelet quasilinearization method	The purpose of this paper is to present the Carreau nanofluid model for the magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) flow induced by stretching surface with velocity slip boundary where the presence of suction and injection parameters are taken into account. The governing system of equations is reduced to the ordinary differential equations with boundary conditions by similarity transformation. These equations are numerically solved by using Haar wavelet quasilinearization method (HWQM). The behavior of various pertinent parameters such as local Weissenberg number, Hartman number, velocity slip parameter, suction/injection parameter, Biot number, thermophoresis parameter, Brownian motion parameter, Prandtl number, thermal radiation parameter, Eckert number and Schmidt number on velocity, temperature, concentration, surface drag force and heat transfer rate are computed and analyzed through graphs and tables. Comparison with published results in the literature is made under some special and limited cases and an excellent agreement is found.
945	Engineering Half-Metallicity and Magnetic Phase Transition for Phagraphene Nanoribbons by Functional Groups and Electric Field	Magnetic nanomaterials with the desirable nature are the basis for developing future spintronic devices, and research for them is of fundamental interest. Here, we explore the realization of half-metallicity and magnetic phase transition for phagraphene nanoribbons in virtue of functional groups (OH and CN) with different coverage fraction and external electric field. The first-principles calculations show that a single-edge CN functionalization only makes a intrinsic spin-degenerate semiconducting ribbon converted to a quasi-metal or metal, while a single-edge OH modification leads to an occurrence of the half-semiconducting nature regardless of the coverage fraction of groups. Interestingly, the half-metal behavior for the CN and OH double-edge modified ribbons can be achieved either in the zero-electric-field intrinsic state for most of functionalized systems or at a very low electric field, 0.1 V/&#x00C5;. More importantly, the observed critical electric field for the transition from ferromagnetic to nonmagnetic phase is lowered significantly almost for all systems, this benefits to design a low electric-field-controlling magnetic switch which can reversibly work between both magnetic and nonmagnetic states. The calculated Gibbs free energy confirms that the group-modified ribbons generally hold a more favorable energy stability in most of the cases, facilitating likely experimental realization.
946	<strong>The Piezotronic Effect in ZnO/ZnS Core-Shell Nanowires and Used as a Flexible Force Sensor</strong>	Investigating the piezotronic effect in the core-shell structure based on ZnO piezoelectric semiconductor is important for developing a complete piezotronic theory and designing novel multifunctional devices. Uniformly and vertically ZnO/ZnS core shell nanowires arrays were successfully prepared through a low temperature solution method. The piezotronic effect in individual core-shell structure ZnO/ZnS nanowire was systematically investigated by using conductive atomic force microscopy. The results showed that the energy band structures and electronic transport properties can be effectively modulated by the external force and it can be treated as piezotronic transistor. We further demonstrated a robust flexible force sensor based on ZnO/ZnS nanoarrays and could detect different forces with the change of output voltages. These results demonstrated here broaden the scope of piezotronics and extend its potential applications in electronics, optoelectronics, and human-machine interfacing.
947	Effect of Zn interstitials on the violet emission from &lt;101&gt; directed ZnO nanostructure	Oxidation of metallic Zn powder on Si substrates at 600 &deg;C produces ZnO nanostucrure which possess a predominant &lt;101&gt; orientation in wurtzite structure as found in the XRD pattern. Room-temperature photoluminescence (PL) spectra exhibited a reduced typical exciton emission or near-band-edge emission in the UV region at 370 nm, whereas a strong violet emission at ~430 nm was surveyed in the visible region. The creation of the interstitials Zn sites within ZnO network creates the &lt;101&gt; preferred crystallographic orientation where the violet  emission arises due to the probable transition of electrons entrapped at Zn interstitial (Zn<sub>i</sub>) defects to the valence band of ZnO. Due to the quantum mechanical hybridization between the electronic orbital&rsquo;s of the relevant donor and acceptor states, the O vacancy and Zn<sub>i</sub> interstitial have the analogous formation energies that happens through Columbian interaction. The high-concentration Zn interstitial defect which constructs the &lt;101&gt; crystallographic orientation and the consequential strong violet PL emission are projected to advance clarification of the mechanisms of defect related emission and expand the opto-electronic applications of ZnO matrix.
948	<strong>High Performance Self-Gating Graphene/MoS<sub>2 </sub>Diode Enabled by Asymmetric Contacts</strong>	Graphene-MoS<sub>2</sub> (GM) heterostructure based diode is fabricated using asymmetric contacts to MoS<sub>2</sub> as well as an asymmetric top gate (ATG). The GM diode exhibits a rectification-ratio of 5 from asymmetric contacts which is improved to 10<sup>5</sup> after the incorporation of ATG. This improvement is attributed to the asymmetric modulation of carrier concentration and effective Schottky barrier height by the ATG during forward and reverse bias. This is further confirmed from the temperature dependent measurement, where a difference of 0.22 eV is observed between the effective Schottky barrier height for forward and reverse bias. Moreover, the rectification ratio also depends on carrier concentration in MoS<sub>2</sub> and can be varied with the change in temperature as well as back gate voltage. Under laser light illumination, the device demonstrates strong opto-electric response with 100 times improvement in the relative photocurrent as well as responsivity of <em>1.9 A/W</em> and a specific detectivity of <em>2.4 &times; 10<sup>10</sup> Jones</em>. These devices can also be implemented using other two dimensional materials and suggest a promising approach to incorporate diverse 2D materials for future nano-electronics and optoelectronics applications.
949	Dissolutive flow in nanochannels: transition between plug-like and Poiseuille-like	Dynamic properties of dissolutive flow in nanochannels were investigated by molecular dynamics simulations. It turned out that the liquid flow pattern changes greatly after the dissolution effect taken into consideration. Liquid inside the channel has a plug-like velocity profile when the dissolubility is low, whereas a Poiseuille-like flow was observed as the dissolubility increases. By introducing the dissolution term to molecular kinetic theory, we explained the physical mechanisms of velocity transition. During which a modified dimensionless Galilei number was proposed to describe the effect of main forces qualitatively. The results showed that in pressure-driven flow, when the dissolubility is low, the dominant dissipation is the viscous dissipation and the theoretical model of insolubility is acceptable. However, as the dissolubility increases, the dissolving dissipation takes priority, which results in the velocity profiles becoming Poiseuille-like. In addition, we analyzed the evolution of fluid density, number of dissolved solid particles and concentration distribution of solute. Specifically, the liquid density varying from layered oscillation to uniform distribution was obtained, which can be described by a critical number. The analysis of solute concentration helps to establish the scaling relationship among the dissolution rate, convection velocity, and diffusion coefficient. These findings not only help to understand the physical mechanisms of dissolutive flow but also help to control and optimize the flow patterns in dissoluble channels.
950	<strong>Impedance spectroscopy of gold conjugated PCR products on robust PCB micro-chips</strong>	Molecular diagnostics have always been in the forefront for disease identification and control. Various approaches for carrying out molecular diagnostics through identification of genes or proteins exist and are largely deployed in the laboratories for testing although there exist a wide possibility of refinement in these existing processes. In this respect, impedance based methods of detection comprise of one of the most deployable methods primarily due to their easy integrability with micro-electronic systems. Impedance assisted detection strategies are very robust and easy. Impedance assisted technique is very commonly used for detection of DNA and DNA amplification through the Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) although it does not really make a very specific identification system parallel to some other optical techniques; like TAQMAN PCR or Molecular beacon assisted detection of DNA sequences.  In the current article, we have developed a strategy through nanoparticle labeling which enhances the specificity of identification of tagged- amplified DNA samples coming out of a PCR process. Impedance characteristics with respect to various number of PCR cycles with a product consisting of nanoparticle labeled DNA samples are measured with respect to increasing concentration. A significant differentiation is observed between the unlabeled DNA non-specifically amplified and the labeled specifically amplified sequence through varied impedance signals. The eventual goal here is to integrate this strategy with micro-chip PCR to evolve a paradigm shift in the PCR micro-chip technology.
951	Calorimetric investigations in a particle clusteraggregation source	A gas aggregation source based on DC magnetron sputtering was investigated using a passive thermal probe and supplementary diagnostics (Langmuir probe and quartz crystal microbalance). Parameter variations of pressure, axial distance and magnetron current have been performed for three different targets (pure Cu, pure W, composite Cu/W) in argon discharge. The measurements showed the energy flux to be significantly higher for the case of the pure tungsten and the composite target compared to the copper target, which is likely a result of the strongly increased amount of neutrals being reflected from the heavier targets. Furthermore, gas rarefaction by the sputtered atoms was found to be essential for the understanding of the observed energy flux and that the dominant contributors to the energy flux in the higher pressure regime are comparable to those observed in the conventional lower pressure regime. Selected deposited films have been investigated ex-situ by scanning electron microscopy, which allowed to gain insight into the nanoparticle formation in relation to the observed energy conversion.
952	<strong>Enhanced optical and X-ray photon response in solution-synthesized CsPbBr<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles wrapped by reduced graphene oxide</strong>	CsPbBr<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles uniformly distributed on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) to form CsPbBr<sub>3</sub>/rGO nanocomposites are synthesized by a facile method. Their corresponding optical and X-ray photon responses are investigated. UV-visible absorption spectra and photoluminescence measurements confirm that loading CsPbBr<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles with an even distribution onto rGO surface can enhance the absorption and photon-generated carrier transportation. Thus, a significant enhancement in optical and X-ray photon response is demonstrated in CsPbBr<sub>3</sub>/rGO nanocomposites as compared with pure CsPbBr<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles. Clear conductive switching phenomenon with a state conversion between &ldquo;on&rdquo; and &ldquo;off&rdquo; is also observed under the intermittent light exposure. These results may provide a new potential application of CsPbBr<sub>3</sub>/rGO nanocomposites for optical and X-ray photon detection.
953	Thermal sensing in fluid at the micro-nano-scales	Temperature is one of the most fundamental parameters for the characterization of a physical system. With the rapid development of lab-on-a-chip and biology at the single cell level, a great demand has risen for the temperature sensors, which can be used in liquid environments with high spatial, temporal and thermal resolution. Nevertheless, measuring temperature in liquid environment is always a technical challenge. Various factors may affect the sensing results, such as the fabrication parameters of the built-in sensors, thermal property of the electrical insulating layer and stability of fluorescent thermometers in liquid environment, etc. In this review, we focused on different kinds of micro/nano-thermometers applied in the thermal sensing for microfluidic systems and cultured cells.
