We discussed the advantages and limitations of these thermometers in specific applications, and challenges and possible solutions for more accurate temperature measurements in further studies.
954	Separation of Polymer Mixtures by Length Using a Series of Nanopores Connected by Nanochannels	Multiscale coarse-grained simulations were used to explore the dynamics of semi-flexible polymers driven through a series of nanopores connected by nanochannels as a method of separating polymers by length. A multi-scale approach was employed in which each polymer was modelled as a chain of beads near the nanopores and as a single particle in the bulk of the nanochannels. By observing that polymers rarely escape back into the bulk of the nanochannels after coming sufficiently close to the nanopores, simulations at these two length scales were decoupled. The dynamics across many independent nanopore-nanochannel devices in series were then deduced mathematically from simulations across a single device. As expected, the time to translocate across a single nanopore increased with chain length. Conversely, however, the time to cross the nanochannels from one nanopore to the next decreased with chain length. Whereas longer chains drifted directly from nanopore to nanopore, smaller chains explored more of the nanochannel volume between translocations. The time between translocations could thus be adjusted by changing the size and shape of the nanochannels. In this way, different geometries are able to sort polymers by increasing length, decreasing length, or non-monotonically by length such that polymers of an intermediate size emerge first.
955	Fast spontaneous emission and high F&ouml;rster resonance energy transfer rate in hybrid organic/inorganic plasmonic nanostructures	We report an experimental study of the plasmon-assisted spontaneous emission and the F&ouml;rster resonance energy transfer between organic molecules and semiconductor colloidal quantum dots. The localized plasmonic field in the nanogap between a gold nano-popcorn&rsquo;s tips and a 5-nm separated gold film supports high photonic density of states and provides pathways for the light-matter interaction mechanisms. We demonstrate that, besides the spontaneous emission enhancement with Purcell factor up to 66 for molecules and quantum dots, the F&ouml;rster resonance energy transfer efficiency and rate constant are simultaneously modified.  While the energy transfer efficiency is reduced from 82% to 35% due to the non-radiative quenching effect and fast donor spontaneous emission rate, the energy transfer rate constant is significantly increased from 3 to 32 ns<sup>-1</sup>. Our results have quantitatively elucidated decay mechanisms that are important toward understanding and controlling of the light-matter interaction at the nanoscale.
956	Cell with flat liquid interfaces for small angle x-ray scattering of nanoparticle self-assembly	The use of cells with walls at angles matching the contact angle of the liquid substrate or layer can significantly reduce the size of the meniscus, improving the probing of a liquid surface or interface by small angle x-ray scattering (SAXS). For ordered arrays of nanoparticles at a liquid/gas interface, this enables extremely high degrees of order to be visible in the SAXS images.
957	Fractal dimension effect on the magnetization curve of exchange-coupled cluster of magnetic nanoparticles	The effect of the fractal dimension of exchange-coupled clusters of magnetic nanoparticles on their magnetization curves has been predicted earlier on the base of random anisotropy model. This provides the basis for an indirect measurement technique of the fractal dimension in nanoparticle cluster from the magnetization curve analyses. The reliability of this technique is verified by means of micromagnetic modeling. It is shown that the effective fractal dimension of the magnetic correlation volume, estimated from the approach to magnetic saturation analysis, agrees with the fractal dimension of the cluster calculated directly by box counting method. The fractal dimension, estimated from the grain-size dependence of the coercive force, strongly divergent with values estimated from an analysis of the cluster morphology by box counting as a result of dipole-dipole interaction between the nanoparticles.
958	Nanoscale Fingerprinting with Hyperbolic Metamaterials	We develop a new concept for optical sub-wavelength discrimination of nanostructures positioned on a hyperbolic metamaterial (HMM) surface using only far-field measurements of the spectral scattered intensity. The device demonstrating our approach consists of a HMM structure, one strong scatterer on top of the HMM at an a priori known location, and the target nanostructures to be sensed on the opposite interface of the HMM. Under far-field illumination from the top, highly localized beams are generated within the HMM by the top scatterer, with wavelength-dependent propagation directions. If the incident wavelength is varied, the localized beam will sweep across the target(s) and the far-field scattered intensity versus wavelength from the bottom target(s) can be measured. We show that this far-field measurement can be used to determine the location of the target(s) with deep-subwavelength accuracy. In addition, discrimination of targets made from different materials can be achieved.
959	A Physical SBT-Memristor-Based Chua's Circuit and Its Complex Dynamics	SBT memristor is a physical memristor built on Sr0.95Ba0.05TiO3 nanometer film, described by a deterministic flux-controlled mathematical model. A new physical SBT-memristor-based Chua's circuit is presented in this paper, using the memristor to replace the Chua diode to connect with a negative conductance in parallel. The circuit can be well modeled by a fourth-order nonlinear system in the voltage-current domain and a third-order nonlinear system in the flux-charge domain, respectively. The dependence of the circuit stability on both the initial state value of the SBT memristor and the linear resistance in the circuit is analyzed theoretically, verified by numerical simulations, which shows that the circuit system has complex dynamics with multiple behaviors, including sink, periodic cycle, limit cycle, chaos, and some complicated transient dynamical behaviors. The new findings shed lights to future research on the physical realization of the SBT-memristor-based Chua's circuit and other similar devices.
960	<strong>Flexible Fiber-Shaped Liquid/Quasi-Solid-State Quantum Dot-Sensitized Solar Cells Based on Different Metal Sulfide Counter Electrodes</strong>	Flexible fiber-shaped quantum dot-sensitized solar cells (QDSSCs) were fabricated by assembling the CdS/CdSe quantum dot (QD) deposited TiO<sub>2</sub> nanotube photoanodes and different metal sulfide (i.e., NiCo<sub>2</sub>S<sub>4</sub>, Ni<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8 </sub>and Co<sub>3</sub>S<sub>4</sub>) counter electrodes (CEs) all grown on Ti wires with a liquid or gel polysulfide electrolyte. Using the NiCo<sub>2</sub>S<sub>4</sub> CEs, the best power conversion efficiencies of 3.41% and 2.76% were obtained for the resultant fiber-shaped QDSSCs with the liquid and gel polysulfide electrolytes, respectively. Impressively, all the metal sulfide electrodes showed considerable stability under electrochemical cycling tests.
961	<strong>Electromagnetic and thermomechanical analysis of near-field heat transfer in heat-assisted magnetic recording heads </strong>	Heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR) is a relatively new data storage technology that promises to satisfy the increasing demands for higher storage densities. During the operation of a HAMR hard-disk drive, heat transfer across the few nanometers head-disk gap does not follow classical heat transfer principles. The HAMR technology relies on laser heating of a sub-diffraction-limit region of the magnetic medium to lower its coercivity and allow the magnetic head to write data in the form of tightly packed bits. The thermal protrusion produced as a result of laser heating is strongly affected by near-field heat transfer. A typical HAMR head model with all key components was used in a coupled electromagnetic-thermomechanical analysis to investigate the effect of near-field heat transfer on the thermal characteristics of the magnetic head. The effects of various heat sources and read/write conditions on the development of thermal protrusion and surface temperature distribution at the trailing edge of the slider body are examined in the context of simulation results.
962	Electronic transport decay factor in a junction of oligophenylene-linked molecule between graphene nanoribbon electrodes	It is generally believed that the nonresonant tunneling decayingsthrough a molecular junction is exponentially dependent on thesproperties of molecule and its contact to electrodes. Here we studysthe dependence of electrode-materials on the transport for asmolecular junction with different graphene nanoribbon (GNR)selectrodes, in which the molecule consisting one, two, and threesphenyls are considered, respectively. By the \emph{ab initio}scalculations, we demonstrate that the current via a zigzag-edge GNRs(ZGNR) electrode junction reaches to the magnitude of $\mu$A with asconvex-arc-shaped dependence under low bias, which is different fromsthat via a similar Au-electrode junction ($\sim$nA) with a linearsrelationship over the same bias scope. Interestingly, the currentsdrops to $\sim$pA with a nonlinear dependence when the electrodessare replaced by the same width conducting armchair-edge GNR (AGNR)sin connection with molecule at the insulating carbon-dimer chains,sbut when the connection is moved to a conducting chain of AGNR thescurrent increases up to $\sim$nA. Further, the current through asjunction with chiral GNR-electrodes (more general case) is ofsdifferent orders of magnitude (few to hundreds of nA), but show thessimilar \emph{I-V} characteristics to that for AGNR-electrode one.sNonetheless, for all types of GNR-electrode junctions thesrelationship between the resistance and the molecular length issalways a straight line in the semilog coordinate but with differentsslopes, implying different decay factors. Therefore, although thestransport exponential law itself is electrode-independent,simportantly, the decay factor is sensitively dependent not only onsthe nature of electrode materials but also on the morphology ofselectrode-molecule coupling. Our results here have demonstrated asuniversal feature in electronic transport for molecular junctions.
963	<strong>Self-assembly of Nickel: From Nanoparticles to Foils with</strong> <strong>Tunable Magnetic Properties</strong>	<strong>In this letter, self-assembly of nickel from nanoparticles to nanowires and foils can be achieved through controlling the concentrations of sodium citrate(Na3Cit) during electroless deposition process. As the concentrations of Na3Cit increased, the morphology of nickel gradually evolved from nanoparticles into nanochains, nanowires, nanowire nonwoven fabrics and foils, respectively. The coercivity of metal nickel was as follows: nanoparticles (75 Oe), nanochains (100 Oe), nanowires (290 Oe), nanowire nonwoven fabrics (280 Oe) and macroscopic foils (130 Oe). This feasible approach shows an effective strategy to fabricate magnetic materials assembly.</strong>
964	<strong>Resonance-Antiresonance behavior in a disorder dielectric composite of BiNiFe<sup>3+</sup> in Microwave Frequency</strong>	In this paper we are studying synthesized and electromagnetic parameters of BiNiFe<sup>3+</sup> nanomaterial. The complex part of the permeability, impedance and refractive index are found to be negative in the entire frequency of X- band. We observed resonance-antiresonance in the nanomaterials, resonance in the permittivity and antiresonance in the permeability. The resonance-antiresonance may be due to the Mie resonance associated by the negative &mu;&Prime;. The nanocomposite material of thickness 3mm has the maximum microwave absorption of -21dB (95%) at 9.50GHz. The nanocomposite material has the intrinsic metamaterial characteristics.
965	<strong>Fiber biosensor exploiting microfiber light polarization modulation induced by magnetic nanoparticles self-assembly</strong>	An optical fiber biosensor is demonstrated exploiting the detection of microfiber light polarization modulation. Microfiber is directly immersed in the magnetic fluid (MF) which contains carboxylated magnetic nanoparticles (CMNPs), without needing the modification of the microfiber surface. While, only an external magnetic field is utilized. Self-assembly of CMNPs is induced after adding bovine serum albumin (BSA) into the MF. The microfiber light polarization modulation relaxation time is prolonged, when external magnetic field is applied or removed for a given period of time. The concentration of BSA solution can be detected by detecting the maximum light polarization degree, or detecting the difference between the maximum and minimum polarization degree. In our experiments, compared with the pure MF, BSA solution which has a concentration as low as 0.05&mu;g/mL induces obvious light polarization modulation. The signal processing system of the biosensor is not only simple but also cost effective. Moreover, biomasses, such as virus, biotin, DNA, and phosphate compounds can also be detected using our scheme.
966	Negative Poisson's ratio in monolayer blue phosphorene nanoribbon with edge sulfur passivation	Motivated by the recent successful growth of monolayer blue<br />phosphorus (BlueP), here we study the mechanical property in<br />connection with microstructure for zigzag BlueP nanoribbons<br />(zBluePNRs) with different edge chemical modification. Based on the<br />first-principles calculations, strikingly, we find that a narrow<br />zBluePNR ($\sim$2 nm) with edge sulfur (S) passivation under an<br />uniaxial tensile strain exhibit an important effect of negative<br />Poisson's ratio because of the particularity of the P-S bonds at<br />edges, and as the ribbon width increases the Poisson's ratio varies<br />from negative to positive. Meanwhile, the S-passivation also induces<br />magnetism, and applying a strong enough strain can transfer a<br />zBluePNR from magnetic metal state to half-metal one.
967	<strong>Enhancement in photocatalytic antibacterial activity of ICP assisted plasma sputtered N-doped TiO<sub>2</sub> thin films</strong>	Specific plasma engineering based synthesis can induce interesting photocatalytic antibacterial activities in TiO<sub>2</sub> films. This work studied the conjugation of pulsed DC plasma with inductively coupled plasma (ICP) to synthesize undoped and N-doped TiO<sub>2</sub> thin films by plasma sputtering. The surface properties of resulting films were systematically analysed in details and correlated to the photocatalytic antibacterial activity against Gram negative <em>Escherichia coli</em>. The addition of ICP source to pulsed-DC discharge generated TiO<sub>2</sub> films with enriched surface roughness due to the bombardment of highly activated species on the substrate. The ICP assisted films exhibited the morphology of nanoclusters with clear defined boundaries, higher O content and higher surface wettability. It was found that N-doping and addition of ICP source significantly increase the eradication of bacteria both in dark as well as in white light (artificial indoor light). Higher antibacterial activity of N-doped TiO<sub>2</sub> films in white light has been explained by photocatalytic degradation mechanism.
968	Abnormal Liquid-Liquid Phase Transition in Nanoconfined Silicon-oxygen Mixture Liquids	We confirm the existence of liquid-liquid phase transition (LLPT) in quasi-2D silicon-oxygen mixture liquid with different ratio of oxygen to silicon (0.55, 1.0, 2.0, respectively) under nanoslit confinement by molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. Layering transitions induced by increasing silt size (SS) and pressure are the typical characteristics of the LLPT. The appearance of the small shoulder peak between the first and second peak in pair correlation function as SS decreases and pressure increases further indicate the LLPT. In addition, the density (&#x03C1;), pressure perpendicular to walls (P&#x22A5;), average potential energy (Ep) and diffusion coefficient (D) show abrupt change during the LLPT. LLPTs usually occur in all liquids which are similar in layering transition but not appear synchronously in different liquids.
969	<em>Coherently strained epitaxial YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>7</sub><sub>-d</sub> films grown on NdGaO<sub>3</sub> (110) </em>	YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>7</sub><sub>-d</sub> is a good candidate to systematically study high-temperature superconductivity by nanoengineering using advanced epitaxy. An essential prerequisite for these studies are coherently strained YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>7</sub><sub>-d</sub> thin films, which we present here using NdGaO<sub>3</sub> (110) as a substrate. The films are coherent up to at least 100 nm thickness and have a critical temperature of 89 +- 1 K. The a and b lattice parameters of the YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>7</sub><sub>-d</sub> are matched to the in-plane lattice parameters of NdGaO<sub>3</sub> (110), resulting in a large reduction of the orthorhombicity of the YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>7</sub><sub>-d</sub>. These results imply that a large amount of structural disorder in the chain layers of YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>7</sub><sub>-d</sub> is not detrimental to superconductivity.
970	Impact of photothermal on light-induced ultrafast insulator-to-metal transition in VO2 nanofilms	Ultrafast detection and switching of light are key processes in high-speed optoelectronic devices. However, the performances of VO<sub>2</sub>-based optoelectronics are strongly degraded by photothermal. The mechanism of the latter is still unclear. Here, by using femtosecond-laser (<em>fs</em>-laser) driven kinetic terahertz wave absorption, we quantitatively separate slow photothermal response and ultrafast photodoping response (e.g. light-induced insulator-to-metal transition) from second- to picosecond-timescales, and discover the competing interplay between them. With photothermal, the ultrafast transition time was degraded by 190% from 50 <em>ps</em> to 95 <em>ps</em>, the ultrafast transition threshold was decreased to 82% from 11mJ/cm<sup>2</sup> to 9mJ/cm<sup>2</sup>, while the amplitudes of the two photoresponse are competing. Percolation theory, along with the macroscopic conductivity response, is used to explain the competing interplay. Our findings are relevant for designing and optimizing VO<sub>2</sub>-based ultrafast optoelectronic devices.
971	Solvent-mediated interactions between nanostructures: from water to Lennard-Jones liquid	Solvent-mediated interactions emerge from complex mechanisms that depend on the solute structure, its wetting properties and the nature of the liquid. While numerous studies have focused on the two first influences, here, we compare results from water and Lennard-Jones liquid in order to reveal to what extend solvent-mediated interactions are universal with respect to the nature of the liquid. Beside the influence of the liquid, results were obtained with classical density functional theory and brute-force molecular dynamics simulations which allows us to build connections between these two numerical techniques.
972	<strong>The effects of nonlocal parameter, aspect ratio, boundary conditions and medium modolus on the buckling behavior of nanocompsite plate by using of</strong> <strong>DQM</strong>	In this paper, the mechanical buckling of a multi-layered nanocomposite rectangular plate reinforced by single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) on Pasternak elastic medium subjected to in-plane loadings is investigated. The equilibrium and stability equations are derived using the higher-order shear deformation plate theory (HSDT) considering the nonlocal theory of Eringen and variational approach. Uniformly distributed carbon nanotubes (CNTs) plate is considered. Differential quadrature method (DQM) has been used to solve the governing equations for various boundary conditions. Next, the effects of nonlocal parameter, aspect ratio, boundary conditions and medium modolus on the buckling behavior of nanocompsite plate are studied. Finally, the results of simpler examples studied are verified by other references.
973	Bioinspired, Nanoscale Approaches in Contemporary Bioanalytics	The genesis for this review stems from the interdisciplinary Biointerfaces International conference 2016 (BI 2016) in Zurich, Switzerland wherein the need for advances in analytical tools was both expressed and addressed by recent and exciting developments in the field of bioanalytics. Pushing the limits of detection for characterizing individual components, such as single proteins, single drug-delivery vehicles, or probing single living cells in a more natural environment, will contribute to our understanding of the complex biomolecular systems central to a number of applications including medical diagnostics, tissue engineering as well as in drug screening and delivery. Starting with the field of single nanoparticle analytics, a review is presented with an emphasis on two emerging techniques. The first technique is based on single-particle tracking of nanoparticles tethered to mobile supported lipid bilayer, enabling the simultaneous characterization of both size and composition of individual nanoparticles. The second technique is based on probing variations in the ionic conduction across nanoscale apertures for detection of, not only nanoparticles but also, membrane-tethered proteins, thereby allowing a multiparameter characterization of individual nanoscopic objects, addressing their size, shape, charge and dipole moment. Thereafter, the complementarity and usefulness of such approaches are addressed by way of an application critically dependent on advanced bioanalytics, namely the development of biomimetic lipid- and polymer-based assemblies as stimuli responsive artificial organelles and nanocarriers designed to optimize delivery of next generation high-molecular-weight biological drugs. Finally, a technique based on probing and manipulating the content of an individual living cell via fluidic force microscopy will be summarized in the context of single-cell analysis while considering the potential use of this and related methods to explore the fate of cells treated with, for example, biomimetic drug-containing nanoparticles. By highlighting a concerted movement in the field of bioinspired, nanoscale surface approaches in bioanalytics, positioned in the context of drug delivery, and by concluding with an outlook projecting future directions in this area, it is our aim to evaluate progress in the field of single component bioanalytics and to emphasize the impact of initiating and maintaining a fruitful dialogue among scientists, together with clinicians and industry, to steer innovation to successful translation.
974	<strong>Electromagnetic and thermomechanical analysis of near-field heat transfer in heat-assisted magnetic recording heads </strong>	Heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR) is a relatively new data storage technology that promises to satisfy the increasing demands for higher storage densities. During the operation of a HAMR hard-disk drive, heat transfer across the few nanometers head-disk gap does not follow classical heat transfer principles. The HAMR technology relies on laser heating of a sub-diffraction-limit region of the magnetic medium to lower its coercivity and allow the magnetic head to write data in the form of tightly packed bits. The thermal protrusion produced as a result of laser heating is strongly affected by near-field heat transfer. A typical HAMR head model with all key components was used in a coupled electromagnetic-thermomechanical analysis to investigate the effect of near-field heat transfer on the thermal characteristics of the magnetic head. The effects of various heat sources and read/write conditions on the development of thermal protrusion and surface temperature distribution at the trailing edge of the slider body are examined in the context of simulation results.
975	Influence of degree of complex network on heat conduction	Devices made of nanotubes and nanowires networks are of great interests for applications and have caught<br />an increasing attention in recent years. In this work, we study the heat conduction in a network model with<br />nodes being atoms and links being 1D chains of atoms. It is found that heat conduction in the complex network<br />is fundamentally different from that of regular lattices. It depends very sensitively on the average degrees of<br />complex networks and the degree of nodes that attached to the two heat baths. For example, when the two heat<br />source nodes have the same degree ki, the heat flux decreases with the increase of ki. In other words, the sparse<br />network is more favorable to heat flux. Thermal rectification effect is found when the two heat source nodes<br />have different degrees. Theoretical analysis is provided to explain the numerical results.
976	Pore diameter dependence of catalytic activity: p-nitrobenzaldehyde conversion to an aldol product in amine-functionalized mesoporous silica	Reaction yield for conversion of p-nitrobenzaldehyde (PNB) to an aldol product in amine-functionalized mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSN) exhibits a 20-fold enhancement for a modest increase in pore diameter, d. This enhanced catalytic activity is shown to reflect a strong increase in the "passing propensity", P, of reactant and product species inside the pores. We find that P &#xF0BB; 0, corresponding to single-file diffusion, applies for the smallest d. In this regime of narrow pores, d still significantly exceeds the linear dimensions of PNB and the aldol product, but these elongated species must align with each other and with the pore axis in order to pass. Thus, P reflects both translational and rotational diffusion. Langevin simulation accounting for these features is used to determine P versus d. The results are also augmented by analytic theory for small and large d where simulation is inefficient. Connection with catalytic activity and yield is achieved by incorporation of results for P into a multi-scale modeling framework. Specifically, we apply a spatially coarse-grained (CG) stochastic model for the overall catalytic reaction-diffusion process in MSN. Pores are treated as linear arrays of cells from the ends of which species adsorb and desorb, and between which species hop and exchange, with the exchange rate reflecting P. CG model predictions including yield are assessed by Kinetic Monte Carlo simulation.
977	Nanoscale Cavitation in perforation of cellular membrane by shock-wave induced nanobubble collapse	The collapse of the bubble induced by the shock wave leads to nano-jet, which is able to perforating cellular membrane. This phenomenon is investigated by Martini coarse-grained molecular dynamic (CG-MD) simulations in the present study. It is found that the occurrence of cavitation nucleation at the nanoscale can be observed during the perforating process. The cavitation locates near the puncture of the cell membrane and its ultimate evolutionary form presents a ring-like structure. The volume of the cavitation is calculated for different initial bubble size, and it is found that the maximum volume of the cavitation area has a correlation with the initial bubble size. To understand the underlying physics of the cavitation phenomenon, the classical nucleation theory based on the Rayleigh-Plesset equation is applied to the non-equilibrium nanoscale system after the pressure field is obtained by using Irving-Kirkwood-Noll procedure. The consistence between the results of CG-MD and the theory reveals that the average pressure of the local environment plays a crucial role in cavitation occurrence on the non-equilibrium system subjected to strong inertia, e.g., shock wave and nano-jet.
978	Nitrogen plasma-induced HfSiON film growth from Hf nanoscale islands on SiO<sub>2</sub>/Si	HfSiON films for high-k dielectric applications is synthesized from Hf nanoscale islands on SiO2/Si(100) substrates using nitrogen inductive coupled plasma (ICP) exposure. The process consists of the novel interfacial reaction of nanoscale islands with the substrate induced by plasma-derived radicals and ions. The Hf metal islands nucleate on SiO2/Si(100) surface by strain-induced engineering during electron beam evaporation. In-vacuo AFM measurement shows the N2 ICP exposure collapses the islands to form films. XPS analysis shows the ICP exposure initially nitrides Hf islands in 1 minute; then it induces interfacial reaction of the base SiO2 layer and HfN in the following stage. The rapid nitridation of Hf is the unique feature of the process initiated from nanoscale islands. The chemical composition ratio of Hf: Si: N in the film can be roughly controlled to be 1: 1: 1 with the ICP exposure time of 20 minutes. The uniformity of the grown films depends on the initial uniformity of the islands and the surface diffusion of materials. The study is a unique example of the film growth method based on the nanoscale interaction of the surface nucleated islands and the substrate material induced by plasmas.
979	Silver nanowire plasmon-assisted and ultraviolet light induced graphene oxide coatings reduction for highly transparent electrodes	In this paper, we prepared a transparent conducting composite electrode composed of silver nanowires (Ag NWs) and reduced graphene oxide (r-GO). Here we present a simple approach to obtain the good weldings at cross-positions of Ag NWs by employing weights at a relatively low temperature (100 {degree sign}C). The Ag NWs/r-GO composite films have been explored not only for the protective effect, but also Ag NWs can be used as plasmonic NWs assisted ultraviolet (UV) light to reduce the GO, and the coatings of r-GO to form Ag NWs/r-GO composite structure can enhance the conductivity of the film by providing more efficient electron conductive pathways. The G/D intensity ratios of GO and r-GO produced by a UV light-induced method without or with Ag NWs were 0.95, 1.01, 1.04, respectively. The lowest sheet resistance of the composite films was 7 ohm/sq with about 82% transparency in the visible spectrum region, and no degradation was observed after two months. The excellent environmental stability might facilitate applications of Ag NWs/r-GO composite films in optoelectronic devices.
980	<strong>Molecular </strong><strong>D</strong><strong>ynamics </strong><strong>S</strong><strong>imulation of </strong><strong>the T</strong><strong>hermal </strong><strong>P</strong><strong>ulse </strong><strong>E</strong><strong>xplosion</strong><strong> of</strong><strong> Metal</strong><strong> N</strong><strong>anowire</strong>	Molecular dynamics simulation of the thermal pulse explosion of metal nanowire, which modeled the slow mode electric explosive of metal wire, was carried out. The potential calculated in the framework of the embedded atom method (EAM). The energy fluctuation, expansion velocity, and products composition in the simulated system were investigated. Overheated state and early expansion shock were observed in the simulation. It is shown that this method can simulate the slow mode electric explosive of metal wire (EEW) effectively.
981	<strong>Kapitza Resistance for Nanoscale Crystalline and Amorphous Silicon Carbide</strong>	Due to the phonon mean free path approaching or overpassing typical characteristic dimension in nanomaterials, thermal transport across interfaces can dictate the overall thermal resistance in nanosystems. However, the fundamental mechanisms at nanoscale interfaces are difficult to predict and control since the thermal boundary conductance across interfaces is intimately related to the characteristics of the interface. In this paper, the thermal boundary resistance (Kapitza resistance) of a crystalline and amorphous silicon carbide(SiC&#xFF09;heterojunction has been investigated by using Non-equilibrium molecular dynamics simulations. It is found that Kapitza resistance at crystalline and amorphous SiC interface depends on the interfacial coupling strength remarkably. In other words, Kapitza resistance in the strong interfacial coupling is significantly lower than that in weak coupling. The thickness of the heterojunction and temperature dependence of Kapitza resistance have also been examined. The results have shown that the Kapitza resistance decreases monotonically with the increase of temperature (from 300K to 800K). Moreover, Kapitza resistance can be effectively tuned by cross-plane strain. A 5% compressive strain is able to reduce the Kapitza resistance by 380% and 50%, respectively, in weak and strong coupling case. In contrast, a 5% tensile strain can increase Kapitza resistance by 13% and 35%, respectively, with weak and strong interfacial coupling. Our study provides useful guidance to control phonon scattering and thermal transport for the design of nano-electronics devices, in particular, for crystalline and amorphous silicon carbide nanosystems.
982	Spin transition of ferropericlase under shock compression	Planar shock compression experiments are performed at 9-105 GPa on polycrystalline ferropericlase (Mg<sub>0.94</sub>Fe<sub>0.06</sub>)O to investigate its Fe<sup>2+</sup> spin transition. Forward and reverse impact configurations are used to obtain Hugoniot and shock-state sound velocities. While wave profiles, shock velocity-particle velocity and pressure-density measurements show negligible/weak indications of a phase transition, the shock-state sound speed data manifest clearly a phase transition in the range of 36-62 GPa at the nanosecond time scales. These shock data reveal the phase transition as the spin transition identified in static compression experiments and first-principles calculations.
983	Time resolved surface photovoltage measurements using a big data capture approach to KPFM	Optoelectronic phenomena in materials such as organic/inorganic hybrid perovskites depend on a complex interplay between fast (electronic) and slower (ionic) processes, which are known to be heavily influenced by structural inhomogeneities such as interfaces and grain boundaries. While Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) is ideally suited to map surface potentials on relevant length scales, it lacks sufficient temporal resolution to extract the meaningful system dynamics. Here, we develop a time resolved surface photovoltage (SPV) measurement based on full information capture of the photodetector stream during open loop Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) operation. G-mode KPFM allows quantification of SPV with microsecond temporal and nanoscale spatial resolution. We demonstrate the advantage of adopting big data analytics including unsupervised clustering methods to quickly discern spatial variability in the information rich SPV dataset. Using this technique, we observe concurrent spatial and fast temporal variations in the SPV generated across a methylammonium lead bromide (MAPbBr3) thin film, indicating that structure is likely responsible for the heterogenous behavior.
984	Perspective: Chain dynamics of unfolded and intrinsically disordered proteins from single-molecule FRET spectroscopy	The dynamics of unfolded proteins are important both for the process of protein folding and for the behavior of intrinsically disordered proteins. However, methods for investigating the global chain dynamics of these structurally diverse systems have been limited. A versatile experimental approach is single-molecule spectroscopy in combination with F&#x00F6;rster resonance energy transfer (FRET) and nanosecond correlation analysis. The concepts of polymer physics offer a powerful framework both for interpreting the results and for understanding and classifying the properties of unfolded and intrinsically disordered proteins. This information on long-range chain dynamics can be complemented with spectroscopic techniques that probe different length- and timescales, and integration of these results greatly benefits from recent advances in molecular simulations. This increasing convergence between experiment, theory, and simulation is thus starting to enable an increasingly detailed view of the dynamics of disordered proteins.
985	Self-removal of Multiple and Multi-size Nanodroplets on Nanostructured Surfaces	Coalescence-induced jumping on superhydrophobic surfaces has attracted extensive interest. It&rsquo;s recently discovered that the spontaneous removal is also possible for the nanodroplets. However, current studies focus on an ideal coalescence of two equally sized nanodroplets, the dynamics of nanodroplets and the mechanism of coalescence are not well understood when considering other practical factors. This work numerically investigated the practical coalescence processes of nanodroplets using molecular dynamics simulation, and systematically discussed the negative effects of nanodroplets number, initial size and initial size ratio by analyzing the variation of jumping velocity and energy conversion efficiency. On the basis of all calculated results, we provided forecasts for jumping velocity and energy conversion efficiency of two coalescing nanodroplets with different sizes, the results show that both the jumping velocity and energy conversion efficiency decrease roughly with increasing nanodroplet size and size ratio. The simulation results in this study demonstrate the possibility of coalescence-induced jumping of multiple nanodroplets with different sizes, and are very useful for predicting jumping velocities for nanodroplets coalescence events.
986	<strong>A miniature fiber-optic high-intensity focused ultrasound device using a candle soot nanoparticles-polydimethylsiloxane composites-coated photoacoustic lens<sup></sup></strong>	We present a miniature fiber-optic ultrasound transmitter for generating high-intensity focused ultrasound (HIFU) based on photoacoustic transduction. The HIFU device consists of a fiber and a photoacoustic lens. We develop a simple fabrication procedure for making the photoacoustic lens, which is coated with candle soot nanoparticles-polydimethylsiloxane composites. The fiber is used to deliver pulsed laser for photoacoustic excitation, which facilitates the use of the HIFU device by eliminating the need of free-space optical alignment. The HIFU device (8.2 mm in diameter) produces focused acoustic pressures up to &gt;30 MPa in peak positive with a tight &minus;6-dB focal volume of ~100 &mu;m and ~500 &mu;m in the lateral and axial directions, respectively. Acoustic cavitation induced by the HIFU device is demonstrated. The miniature HIFU device facilitates handheld operation. It holds promise for clinical applications in intracavitary and intraoperative high-precision HIFU therapy.
987	Application of multiwall carbon nanotubes to conductive manipulation-probe tips for <em>in-situ</em> transmission electron microscopy of nanometer-sized material: Electrical measurement of a silicon nanoparticle	We investigated electrical conduction of an individual nanometer-sized silicon (Si) particle by <em>in-situ</em> transmission electron microscopy using multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) as manipulation-probe tips. MWNTs could be used to manipulate Si nanoparticles individually and act as conductive probes. A Si nanoparticle covered with an amorphous-Si natural oxide layer was sandwiched between the tips of two MWNTs in the microscope and current-voltage properties of the Si nanoparticle were measured. Electrical conduction through the surface oxide layer of the Si nanoparticle was elucidated. The present study showed that the MWNT manipulation-probe tips are feasible tools for manipulating individual nanometer-sized particles and investigating their electrical properties.
988	<strong>Electromigration effect on the surface morphology during the Ge deposition on Si(111) at high temperatures</strong>	The directional atom drift under direct electric current (DC) flowing through a sample is a unique tool for the surface morphology manipulation, which was previously studied in detail for Si surfaces. We show that electromigration can significantly influence the heterostructures growth process. Without electromigration, the surface morphology is formed under the action of two driving forces determined by a surface and strain energy minimization. DC shifts the balance between them in favor of one of them, depending on the DC direction, producing unusual surface nanostructures during the Ge deposition on Si(111) at 850-900 &deg;C.
989	<strong>Electronic, magnetic and transport properties of zigzag silicene nanoribbon adsorbed with Cu atom: A first-principles calculation <sup></sup></strong>	This paper aims to provide a detailed analysis of the electronic, magnetic and spin-dependent transport properties of Cu-adsorbed zigzag silicene nanoribbons within the density functional theory framework. The possibility of diffusion between different stable positions is studied by Nudge Elastic Band (NEB) method. As to zigzag graphene nanoribbons, the center of nearest hexagonal to the edge is the most favorable site for adsorbing Cu atom. Total energy analysis for spin-polarized calculations indicates that the antiferromagnetic (AFM) state is the magnetic ground state of zigzag silicene nanoribbons whereas adding the Cu adatom on the near edge yields ferromagnetic (FM) state with the total magnetization about 0.98 . As a consequence of charge transfer from Si atoms to Cu, the spin distribution symmetry of the edges is broken and the spin magnetic moment is considerably localized on the edge without adsorbing. Further verification of the electronic properties is obtained through investigating the conductivity behavior of the device using the current-voltage (I-V) characteristics based on density functional theory with non-equilibrium Green&rsquo;s function included. Although the spin-up current increases with the bias monotonically, a spin negative different resistance phenomenon is observed for spin-down electrons. Additionally, spin up transmission shows higher values in comparison with that for spin down in bias window which leads to the higher current. The results hold promising applications for future nano-electronics and spintronic devices.
990	Flexible, transparent resistive switching device based on topological insulator Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>- organic composite	Two dimensional topological insulator (TIs) bismuth selenide (Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>) nanosheets embedded in Poly-methyl methacrylate (PMMA)  are employed for the first time for the resistive switching (RS) application. Hexagonal 2D Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3 </sub>nanosheets (NSs) are synthesized by a simple solvothermal method and combine with PMMA at different weight percentage of 2D Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>. Field emission scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy along with other characterization such as X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS)  &amp; Raman spectroscopy were performed for the characterization of Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3 </sub>@ PMMA hybrid system. Composite was deposited on transparent, flexible PET substrate to form Ag/Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@PMMA/ITO memory cell. I-V characteristics of the device revealed stable and non-volatile memory effect. The device shows a significantly high resistance ratio &gt; 10<sup>3</sup> (R<sub>HRS</sub>/R<sub>LRS</sub>) with high reproducibility over a large number of (10<sup>5</sup>) ac cycles. From the experimental data RS performances are explained by using a charge trapping&ndash;detrapping mechanism. Owing to the increasing interest in flexible electronics, bending tests were carried out at various bending diameters (10-30 mm) to show the mechanical robustness of the proposed device.
991	<strong>INTERDIFFUSION REGIMES DURING THE INTERMEDIATE PHASE GROWTH IN POLYCRYSTALS</strong>	<em>Parabolic, cubic, fo</em><em>u</em><em>rth power diffusion regimes for different scales from nanometers to micrometers and millimeters are analyzed.</em> <em>A model of describing the diffusion phase growth from point sources inside polycrystals grains is regarded. 992	Development of Nanostructured TiO2 for the Fabrication of Efficient Dye Sensitized Solar Cell:  A Critical Review	The outlay of non-renewable resources is a thoughtful issue and is a big challenge for our civilization at present century. All over the world, countless investigations are going on for renewable alternatives. The Sun is a conspicuous source of clean and cheap energy. One of the prominent routes for the conversion of solar to electrical energy is photo-voltaic technology. Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells (DSSCs) are the eco-friendly and economic developments, which may help us to resolve the energy crisis. A DSSC consists of photoanode, photo-sensitizer dye, electrolyte and counter electrode. To develop a proficient photoanode is a big challenge for scientific communities. Presently, various semiconductors include TiO2, Nb2O5, SnO2, and ZnO are used as photoanode. Among them, TiO2 plays lead role owning its low photo-corrosion and excellent optical as well as electrical properties. Hence, this review is about the discussion regarding the researches and developments of various nanostructures (0-D, 1-D, 2-D, 3-D) of TiO2 to fabricate more efficient and environment-friendly DSSCs. Moreover, it was observed that 2-D nanostructures, in particular, mesoporous TiO2 films synthesized by screen printing technique are most suitable and prominent photoanodes for DSSC application.
993	Capacitive and Memristive Behaviours in Metallic Nanowire Networks	Random nanowire networks (NWNs) are promising synthetic architectures for non-volatile memory devices and hardware-based neuromorphic applications due to their history-dependent responses, recurrent connectivity, and neurosynaptic-like behaviours. Such brain-like functions occur due to emergent resistive switching phenomena taking place in the interwire junctions which are viewed as memristive systems; they operate as smart analogue switches whose resistance depends on the history of the input voltage/current. We successfully demonstrated that NWNs made with a particular class of memristive junctions can exhibit a highly-selective conduction mechanism which uses the lowest-energy connectivity path in the network identified as the &ldquo;winner-takes-all&rdquo; state. But these complex networks do not always behave in the same fashion; in the limit of sufficiently low input currents (preceding this selective conduction regime), the system behaves as a leakage capacitive network and its electrical activation is driven by cascades of breakdown-based switching events involving binary capacitive transitions. Understanding these two regimes is crucial to establish the potential of these materials for neuromorphics and for this we present two computational modelling schemes designed to describe the capacitive and memristive responses of NWNs interrogated adiabatically by voltage/current sources. Our findings reveal the fault-tolerant aspect in the slow-switching dynamics of memristive networks in contrast with the abrupt activation response obtained in the fast-switching process of binary capacitive networks. Our results are corroborated by experimental evidence that reveal the fine electrical properties of NWN materials in their respective formation (capacitive) and conducting (memristive) stages.
994	<strong>Study of Electrospun PVA-Based Concentrations Nanofibre Filled with Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> or WO<sub>3</sub> as Potential X-ray Shielding Material </strong>	This study was successfully fabricated the electrospun PVA/Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and PVA/WO<sub>3</sub> nanofibre mats with different weight percentages (wt%) of the PVA concentrations with variable wt% of filler loading (Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and WO<sub>3</sub>) from 0 &ndash; 40wt%. The characterisation of the electrospun composite samples was evaluated and analysed for the purposes of the X-ray shielding criteria such as density, thickness and mass attenuation coefficient ( . Besides that, the characteristics of the surface morphology and the dispersion patterns of the nanoparticles inside the PVA nanofibres were also been performed by using SEM. In addition, the effect of X-ray energies prior to the X-ray attenuation was determined by using XRF for the energy between 8.64 &ndash; 25.20 keV. Other than that, electrospun 15PVA with 35wt% of the Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> showed the high value of  when being tested for all type of X-ray energies compared to other electrospun composite samples. In contrast, WO<sub>3</sub> filler showed the lowest  compared to the Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> filler even though they were embedded into the same PVA concentration. This was due to the higher atomic number (Z) of the Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> compared to WO<sub>3</sub>. As a conclusion, the higher density of the sample, the higher probability of the X-ray photon being attenuated by the sample. Moreover, the SEM image elucidated the smaller number of fibre diameter, less number of agglomeration and bead formations occurred within the nanofibres for 15PVA with 35wt% of the Bi<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, thus was chosen as the best potential of the X-ray attenuation shielding material candidate for the X-ray shielding applications.
995	<strong>Electromigration effect on the surface morphology during the Ge deposition on Si(111) at high temperatures</strong>	The directional atom drift under direct electric current (DC) flowing through a sample is a unique tool for the surface morphology manipulation, which was previously studied in detail for Si surfaces. We show that electromigration can significantly influence the heterostructures growth process. Without electromigration, the surface morphology is formed under the action of two driving forces determined by a surface and strain energy minimization. DC shifts the balance between them in favor of one of them, depending on the DC direction, producing unusual surface nanostructures during the Ge deposition on Si(111) at 850-900 &deg;C.
996	<strong>The Ultrafast Carrier Dynamics of Two-dimensional Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>x</sub>Se<sub>3-x</sub> Nanosheets based on </strong><strong>photoluminescence lifetimes</strong><strong> and </strong><strong>pump-probe</strong> <strong>system</strong>	<strong>The ultrafast dynamics properties of Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>x</sub>Se<sub>3-x </sub>Nanosheets are investigated by time-resolved photoluminescence (PL) and pump-probe techniques in visible wavelength and near-infrared wavelength separately. The steady state PL peaks of three nanosheets are asymmetric, because of strong spin-orbit coupling. All the PL lifetimes in 400 nm are around 0.2 ns, dominanted by the charge separation</strong><strong>&#xFF1B;</strong><strong>all the </strong><strong>PL lifetimes in 500~550 nm are around 1.2 ns, which are associated with the thermal effects. But in 450nm, with the increase of Se atoms, the ratio of these two effects changes from 2:8 to 6:4, meaning an obvious reverse of dominant mechanism. The electron-phonon relaxation lifetime, measured by pump-probe in near-infrared wavelength (1550 nm), is changed from 1.49 ps to 0.85 ps with the value of X from 3 to 0. It proves indirectly the previous conclusion that the increase of Se atoms could enhanced the thermal effects. This essay suggests a method for quantitative comparison of the dominant mechanism transform in topological Insulator Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>x</sub>Se<sub>3-x</sub>  nanosheets or other similar materials, which is beneficial to  their photoelectric applications.</strong>
997	<strong>The influence of nickel oxide nanoparticle dispersion on the thermo stability of lubricant oil </strong>	The homogeneous and substantial dispersion of nanoparticles into base fluids is vital since the final properties of any nanolubricants are estimated by their quality of stability. This paper addresses the study on the effect of NiO nanoparticles dispersion into SN500 lubricant oil on its non-isothermal thermo stability. The dispersion of NiO nanoparticles is achieved by ultrasonication method. The thermo stability is estimated by Thermo Gravimetric Analysis (TGA), Differential thermal analysis (DTA) and Differential Scanning Colorimety (DSC). The result shows that the thermo stability of base fluid enhances up to 0.3 wt% particle concentration then it decreases due to agglomeration of dispersed nanoparticles. The findings recommend that 0.1 wt% and 0.3 wt% of NiO-nanolubricant can be used for the temperature dependent applications up to 200 &deg;C.
998	<strong>Enhanced bremsstrahlung X-ray emission from Ag nanoparticles irradiated by ultrashort laser pulses</strong>	<em>A thin planar water jet containing Ag nanoparticles (20 nm size) is irradiated by ultrashort (150 fs) laser pulses of intensity ~ 10<sup>15 </sup>W/cm<sup>2</sup> to produce bremsstrahlung X-rays of up to 100 keV photon energy. An enhancement of 30-fold is observed in the X-ray yield compared to the precursor salt solution. This is a consequence of the surface plasmon assisted local electric field enhancement in the nanoparticles, resulting in enhanced multiphoton ionization. Continuous circulation of the nanoparticles through the liquid jet ensures long-term stability towards laser irradiation. In comparison, only an 18-fold enhancement of X-ray yield is measured in Au NPs, when measured under identical conditions. The relatively lower ionization potential of Ag nanoparticles makes them better candidates for bright X- ray generation, with variety of applications including dynamics studies, microscopy, and lithography.</em>
999	Stable plasmon excitations in quantum nanowires	Stable electrostatic plasmon excitations due to propagation of Gaussian electron pulse are studied in a cylindrical nanowire of radius "a" and length "L". For this purpose, we consider conduction electrons that follow the quantum hydrodynamical model to account for quantum statistics, quantum diffraction and exchange-correlation effects in the presence of classical static ions. The use of well-known Fourier transform technique and Trivelpiece-Gould configuration leads to the generalized dispersion for plasmon with finite mode quantization effects via the radial and azimuthal mode indices, as well with quantum settings. The excitations of plasmon wakefield appear when the electron beam propagates with a constant velocity along the axial direction of nanowire. The stability conditions are also analyzed for the existentence of wakefield excitations by solving three important inequalities using typical parameters of gold nanowire. The results may prove useful for understanding the plasmon excitations in quantum nanowires, where electrons can be trapped and accelerated in the wakefield to emit radiation in the extreme-ultraviolet range.
1000	<strong>Surface morphology formation of Ti films in laser induced forward transfer</strong>	Titanium is frequently adopted in laser induced forward transfer (LIFT) due to its unique industrial advantages (low density, high specific strength and good corrosion resistance). To understand the LIFT process assisted with Ti films, topographies of on Ti films with a thickness  irradiated by ultraviolet nanosecond laser pulses are investigated. Five different topographies (the pit, blister, bump, spray and strip) are observed and classified, among which the pit, with the film surface sinks in the center, is first addressed in this work. Probability distribution of these types with respect to laser fluence on 435 nm and 1250 nm Ti films is provided and an analytical model is developed to explain the driving mechanism of the ablation threshold and the formation of different topographies.
1001	Culturing and patch clamping single cells on nanowire substrates	Nanowire substrates play an increasingly important role for cell cultures as an ap- proach for hybrid junctions between semiconductors and biological systems. In order to establish such a setup, we address the question if high density vertical nanowire substrates can serve as culturing substrate for Jurkat T lymphocytes and cerebellar neurons from mice, while fundamental electrophysiological properties remain con- served. The electrophysiological responses of the cells cultured on highly ordered and randomly distributed nanowires covered in a thin aluminum oxide passivation layer are compared to planar control substrates. Patch clamp recordings on each sub- strate performed with a custom-built upright patch clamp setup to handle opaque substrates show similar electrophysiological properties, such as resting membrane potential, membrane capacitance and specific ion channel gating. Cross sections pre- pared with focused ion beam are used examine the membrane nanowire interface at the nanowire tip and show a wrapping of the very tip the the nanowires. The similar electrophysiological activity demonstrates that the characteristic of the nanowire sub- strate plays a subordinate role and opens up the arena for a large range of nanowire substrates in a functionalized application.
1002	Localized Surface Plasmon Resonance on Two-Dimensional Monolayer and Multilayer HfSe<sub>2</sub>	In this work, we theoretically evaluated localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) excited on two-dimensional (2D) monolayer and multilayer semiconducting HfSe<sub>2</sub>, and quantitatively compared the in-plane and out-of-plane anisotropic properties. The LSPR was excited by Au sphere nanoparticles on 2D HfSe<sub>2</sub>, and its properties including internal field, polarizability, scattering and absorption cross-section, and radiative efficiency <em>etc.</em> were analyzed using Mie theory. Due to the unique anisotropic nature of 2D HfSe<sub>2</sub>, the LSPR excited on the monolayer HfSe<sub>2</sub> was clearly observed in the in-plane direction but effectively suppressed in the out-of-plane direction. In contrast, for the multilayer HfSe<sub>2</sub>, the LSPR showed a very comparable response in both the in-plane and out-of-plane directions, suggesting an isotropic-like light-matter interaction. In addition to this unique anisotropy-to-isotropy transition as the layer number increases, a red-shift of the LSPR wavelength was also found. Our work has demonstrated the unique anisotropic light-matter interaction on the monolayer HfSe<sub>2</sub> and the isotropic-like interaction on the multilayer HfSe<sub>2</sub>, which holds great potential for broad photonic and optoelectronic applications such as sensing, imaging, light concentration, and energy conversion <em>etc</em>.
1003	Nondestructive high-speed fiber laser shock processing of Al alloys	Laser induced shock wave processing has aroused a special interest in the micro/nano machining fields, while the low processing efficiency and the difficult control of the shock wave are the bottleneck problems impeding its practical applications. In this study, a nondestructive high-speed fiber laser shock processing (FLSP) technique was researched to improve the performance of the micro/nano shock machining. A laminar-flow-based high-speed FLSP system was developed using a galvanometer scanner and a compact fiber laser with less than 1 mJ pulse energy. Nondestructive microdent arrays with adjustable depths (200 ~ 1000 nm) in nano-scale precision have been achieved on Al alloy surfaces in a large scale (20 mm &#x00D7; 20 mm) with a shock processing rate of 1 kHz. The processing efficiency can be further improved up to hundreds of times with the extension of the processing area. An obvious increase in surface microhardness of 19% and a generation of compressive residual stress of -140 MPa were also observed. The effect of impact times, peak power densities, pulse durations, sacrificial coating thickness, and water-flow rates was systematically investigated. The results laid the groundwork for the practical application of FLSP in the micro/nano machining.
1004	Roll-to-roll fabrication of hierarchical superhydrophobic surfaces	In this letter, we report a roll-to-roll fabrication method to develop a hierarchical nanopatterened superhydrophobic surface. The hierarchical pattern includes a primary micropattern with an overlayed secondary nanopattern. The primary pattern of 15 - 30 microns length scales was fabricated through UV nanoimprint lithography. The secondary nanopattern of 20 nm size was generated through a subsequent scalable spray coating with hydrophobic silica nanoparticles to create a nanoscale random roughness over the primary pattern. The secondary nanocoating over primary pattern resulted in enhanced contact angle resulting in superhydrophobicity and reduced hysteresis. Freezing droplet measurements performed, demonstrated a five-fold increase in the time for the droplet to freeze on a superhydrophobic surface compared to a primary hydrophobic structure.
1005	Fermi level tuning of <u>resistive</u> switching behavior of graphite/Nb$:$<u>SrTiO</u>$_3$ interfaces	Layered electrodes based on <u>graphene</u> or transition metal <u>dichalcogenides</u> have enriched the development of <u>nanoelectronics</u> due to their uniqueness in flexibility, transparency, thermal stability and electronic structure. Here we report on the <u>resistive</u> switching behaviors observed in graphite/Nb:<u>SrTiO<sub>3</sub></u> (Gr/<u>NbSTO</u>) junctions. Straightforward <em>in <u>situ</u></em> bromine <u>intercalation</u> of graphite modulates the transport properties of Gr/<u>NbSTO</u> devices, an effect which cannot be achieved using traditional metal electrodes. At low temperatures, the strong electric field dependence of the dielectric constant of Nb:<u>SrTiO</u>3 is also plays an important role in further enhancing the <u>resistive</u> switching performance. Our findings here suggest that to optimize the performance and to perform more complex functions, <u>tunability</u> of the Fermi level of the layered graphite electrode in combination with the nonlinear dielectric constant of the <u>NbSTO</u> substrate are critically important for interface-type <u>resistive</u> switching devices.
1006	<strong>Bipolar to unipolar mode transition and imitation of metaplasticity in oxide based memristors with enhanced ionic conductivity</strong>	Neuromorphic engineering offers a promising route toward intelligent and low power computing systems that may find applications in artificial intelligence and internet of things. Construction of neuromorphic systems, however, requires scalable nanodevices that could implement the key functionalities of biological synapses. Here we demonstrate an artificial synaptic device consisting of a Ti/yttria-stabilized-zirconia (ZrO<sub>2</sub>:Y)/Pt memristive structure, where the loss microstructure, high oxygen vacancy concentration and resultant high ionic conductivity in ZrO<sub>2</sub>:Y facilitate the oxygen vacancy migration and filament evolution in the devices, leading to a bipolar artificial synapse with low forming and operation voltages. As the thickness of ZrO<sub>2</sub>:Y film increases, a transition from bipolar to unipolar resistive switching was observed, which can be ascribed to the competing vertical and radial ion transport dynamics. The emergence of unipolar switching has in turn allowed the device to exhibit metaplasticity, a history dependent plasticity that is important for memory and learning functions. This work thus demonstrates on-demand manipulation of ionic transport properties for building synaptic elements with rich functionalities.
1007	Quantized optical near-field interactions measured with a superconducting nanowire detector	The quantum nature of optical near-fields is interesting from a theoretical perspective and of importance for practical applications, such as high-resolution imaging, sensing and antenna-coupled quantum light sources. In this work we use a custom-designed superconducting nanowire single-photon detector (SNSPD) to directly read out the near-field interaction between source and detector. We use a subwavelength-sized aperture at the end of an optical fiber to record spatial near-field maps and to measure the distance dependence of the optical near-field interaction. Our measurements can be well described by a superposition of evanescent source fields with no noticeable probe-sample coupling. Our approach can be used for further studies of quantum near-field interactions and for the development of near-field imaging techniques with single quantum sensitivity.
1008	<strong>Multiple Internal Resonances in MEMS Arch Resonators</strong>	Micromachined shallow arch resonant beams have attracted significant attention thanks to their rich dynamical behavior, inherent nonlinearities, and the potential to excite various internal resonances. Currently, there is a lack of comprehensive experimental studies for the various types of internal resonances in arches and particularly at the micro and nano scales. Here, we aim to investigate and identify different types of internal resonances of an initially curved beam, electrothermally actuated and electrostatically driven, by electrical characterization techniques. Upon changing the electrothermal voltage of silicon micromachined arches, the second symmetric natural frequency of an arch is adjusted to near twice, three times, and four times the fundamental natural frequency, which gives rise to 2:1, 3:1, and 4:1 autoparametric resonances between the two modes. These resonances are demonstrated experimentally. We show various frequency-response curves of the total response around the excitation frequency and highlight the contribution of each mode before, during, and after the internal resonances. Allan-deviation results are also shown indicating enhanced frequency stabilization of the arch oscillation when experiencing internal resonances. These studies motivate further research in this direction to exploit internal resonances of micromachined resonators for practical applications, such as sensors and mechanical amplifier.
1009	Fast water flow through nanocapillaries: a continuum model approach involving the microscopic structure of confined water	Water inside a nanocapillary becomes ordered, resulting in unconventional behavior. A profound enhancement of water flow inside nanometer thin capillaries made of carbon nanotubes or graphene has been observed. Here we explain these enhancement to the large density and the extraordinary viscosity of water inside the nanocapillaries. Using the Hagen-Poiseuille theory with slippage-boundary condition {and incorporating disjoining pressure term in combination with} extensive molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, we present an analytical theory that elucidates the origin of the enhancement of water flow inside hydrophobic nanocapillaries. Additionally, we determine the contact angle of water inside nanocapillaries to be very close to 90$^o$ {and a slip length of about 600&Aring;. Our work reveals a very distinctive dependence of water flow in a nanocapillary on the structural properties of nanoconfined water in agreement with experiment, which opens a new avenue in nanofluidics.
1010	High temperature magnetic studies on Bi<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Ca<em><sub>x</sub></em>Fe<sub>1-<em>y</em></sub>Ti<em><sub>y</sub></em>O<sub>3-</sub><sub>d</sub> nanoparticles: Observation of Hopkinson-like effect above T<sub>N</sub>	Magnetic properties of Bi<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Ca<em><sub>x</sub></em>Fe<sub>1-<em>y</em></sub>Ti<em><sub>y</sub></em>O<sub>3-</sub><sub>d </sub>(BCFO: <em>y</em>=0 and BCFTO: <em>x</em>=<em>y</em>) nanoparticles are studied across a wide range of temperatures (20 K to 960 K) for different Ca (and Ti) concentrations [<em>x</em> (= <em>y</em>) = 0, 0.025, 0.05, 0.1]. X-ray diffraction and electron microscopy revealed gradual emergence of orthorhombic phase (P<em>nma</em>) with increase in Ca<sup>2+</sup> content in BCFO, contrary to the retention of parent rhombohedral symmetry (<em>R3c</em>) in Ca<sup>2+</sup>-Ti<sup>4+</sup> co-doped BCFTO. XPS indicates the presence of 3+ valence states for Bi and Fe, and under-coordinated defect peaks in O 1<em>s</em> spectra. Ordering of oxygen vacancies in BCFO affect the FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedral alignment resulting in a systematic shift of Fe-O Raman modes. Oxygen vacancies formed due to Ca<sup>2+</sup> doping in BCFO, and non-magnetic Ti<sup>4+ </sup>ion at Fe<sup>3+</sup> site in BCFTO disrupt the spin-cycloid propagation in BiFeO<sub>3</sub>, largely influencing the magnetic properties. These substitutional changes, in addition to the large surface area, are the sources of net magnetization in these systems. Magnetic hysteresis and field dependent ZFC-FC curves indicate the combined presence of anti-ferromagnetic and ferromagnetic components in BCFO and BCFTO nanoparticles. High temperature magnetic studies present a clear bifurcation of magnetic N&eacute;el transition centered at ~ 600 K associated to the structural variation in BCFO. A strong anomaly observed at 860 &plusmn; 40 K in all the samples suggest a Hopkinson-like effect arising due to sudden loss of anisotropy by the FM component.
1011	<SPAN style="font-size: 14.0pt; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif;">Enhancement and Reduction of Thermal Conduction </SPAN> <SPAN style="font-size: 14.0pt; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif;">via Phonon Spectral Coupling</SPAN>	We demonstrate a new approach to enhance and reduce thermal conductivities in layered nanostructures by using a novel understanding of phonon spectral coupling. We uncover the underlying phonon injection mechanisms and show the determining role of layer spacings and interface properties in obtaining thermal conductivity modulations. We show that the thermal conductivity of an embedded Ge film between Si cladding layers can be enhanced beyond its free-standing thin-film value. The same mechanism in a modified architecture can also be used to reduce the thermal conductivity of a Si thin-film below its free-standing value. The results of this work open new avenues within the rational thermal design by creating a new method to increase and reduce thermal conductivities, and advance the basic understanding of nanoscale thermal transport by incorporating the role of phonon spectral coupling. The prospects of being able to modulate the thermal conductivity can radically change how we control heat flow in electronic, optoelectronic, and thermoelectric materials.
1012	Two-Dimensional Multiferroic Semiconductors with Coexisting Ferroelectricity and Ferromagnetism	Low-dimensional multiferroicity, though highly scarce in nature, has attracted great attention due to both fundamental and technological interests. Using a combination of first-principles calculations and Landau theoretical analysis, we show that ferromagnetism and ferroelectricity can coexist in four monolayer transition metal phosphorus chalcogenides (TMPCs) CuCrP<sub>2</sub>S<sub>6</sub>, CuCrP<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>6</sub>, CuVP<sub>2</sub>S<sub>6</sub>, and CuVP<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>6</sub>, which represent the first class of 2D multiferroic semiconductors that simultaneously possess ferroelectric and ferromagnetic orders. In these monolayer materials, Cu atoms spontaneously move away from the center atomic plane, resulting in finite electric dipole moment along the plane normal, while ferromagnetism originates from the indirect exchange interaction between Cr/V atoms. The out-of-plane ferroelectricity in these semiconducting 2D TMPC crystals allows for facile control of electric polarization by external vertical electric field and opens up avenues for realizing 2D nanoscale switching and memory devices patterned with top and bottom electrodes.
1013	The role of ultrasound in surface modification of CuO nanoparticles and synthesis of poly)vinyl chloride)/CuO-BSA nanocomposites: Characterization and physicochemical properties	The main aim of this project is the improvement of physicochemical properties of poly)vinyl chloride) (PVC) through combining it with copper oxide nanoparticles (CuO NPs). For this purpose, at first, Bovine Serum Albumin (BSA) as a biocompatible coupling agent was used for the surface modification of the CuO NPs. Then, nanocomposite (NC) films with different percentages of CuO-BSA (3, 6, and 9 wt%) were fabricated by using ultrasonication method following by solution casting technique. Finally, the prepared samples were studied by different characterization techniques including Fourier transform infrared spectra, X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, transmission electron microscopy, and ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy. The aforementioned techniques revealed that the reinforcing of PVC with CuO-BSA NPs led to the improvement of some physicochemical properties of the PVC/CuO-BSA NCs such as mechanical, thermal, optical, and hydrophilicity.
1014	A plantar pressure sensing system with balancing sensitivity based on tailored MWCNTs/PDMS composites	This paper presents a flexible plantar pressure sensor with simple structure and easy accessibility suited for everyday use. In this study, the design, fabrication and characteristics of both the composite and the sensor are involved. By using the solution method, the piezoresistive composite is fabricated by uniform dispersion of multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) into the polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) matrix. The proposed sensor consists eight sensing elements with a laminated structure. The upper layer is the sensing layer made of the piezoresistive composite, and the lower layer is a flexible printed circuit board working as electrodes. A particular design of sensing elements is carried out by using different doping concentrations according to the arrangement positions under the feet to obtain a balancing sensitivity. A signal processing system to convert the variable resistance signal into the voltage by current-to-voltage method is designed. Experimental results prove that the designed sensor shows repeatable response with a sensitivity of 11.5 mV/kPa within the range of 260 kPa. Also, an actual application verifies that the designed plantar pressure sensor can measure the pressure under the foot and can be used for gait detection and disease diagnosis purposes.
1015	Experimental study on the discharge ignition in a capillary discharge based pulsed plasma thruster	Low power capillary discharge based pulsed plasma thrusters (CDPPTs) are electrothermally dominated thrusters and they have aroused renewed interest in the investigation and enhancement of the basic performance for the application of mi-cro/nano satellites recently. Research on the ignition mechanism of a CDPPT has been conducted to provide insight into the optimization of the structure design and promotion of the lifetime performance. It has been found that the electrical parame-ters, geometry parameters and the cumulative effect of discharge jointly determine the discharge ignition characteristics. A single ignition process is divided into the breakdown of igniter and the development of the main discharge, while the results shows that the jitter of the ignition delay time is mainly introduced from the former. Shorter ignition delay time and lower jitter are obtained with a higher ignition energy and main charging voltage or a shorter and narrower cavity, which is positively correlated to the electric field distribution along the propellant surface. Moreover, with long duration experiments, the surface deposits and morphology of propellant and igniter are the dominant factors that cause the dispersity of the ignition effect and main discharge characteristics.
1016	<strong>Ferromagnetic Resonance in Coupled Magnetic Nanostructured Arrays </strong>	The modulated field sweep ferromagnetic resonance (FMR) spectroscopy was used to study the magnetization dynamics in large arrays of interacting cubic nanomagnets. A 60nm thick Permalloy (Ni<sub>80</sub>Fe<sub>20</sub>) thin films were patterned into several large arrays of 60 x 60 nm<sup>2</sup> nanostructures where the spacing between the magnetic nanocubes was varied to control the strength of dipolar coupling. The films were deposited using magnetron sputtering and patterned with electron beam lithography. DC magnetic properties were evaluated using alternating gradient force magnetometer (AGFM). In the FMR measurements, the orientation of DC bias magnetic field was varied from the in-plane to out-of-plane with respect to the 2D plane of the arrays. The FMR peak splitting and multiple FMR modes were observed in the evolution of the FMR spectra as the function of the bias field orientation, and were strongly influenced by the nanomagnet geometry and the spacing between the nanomagnets. Two resonance modes, shape and lattice, were particularly well pronounced in the observed FMR spectra. These modes are characterized by effective demagnetizing factors representing different symmetries of the system of interacting nanomagnets. Micromagnetic modeling suggest that micromagnetic texture within the nanomagnets modulated by the stray fields from the neighbors correlates with the FMR spectra.
1017	<strong>Tutorial: Fabrication and Three-Dimensional Integration of Nanoscale Memristive Devices and Arrays<sup></sup></strong>	To accelerate neural networks with growing complexity, hybrid integrated systems with high-density nanoscale memristive devices are in huge demand. In this Tutorial, we first introduce the methodology in fabrication of memristor crossbars with sub-10 nm feature size, including nanoimprint lithography that provides excellent resolution at low cost. Technical issues in the fabrication process such as critical dimension (CD) control, overlay alignment accuracy and reliable mold cleaning are discussed in detail. On the other hand, as lateral scaling becomes more challenging, three-dimensional (3D) integration presents an alternative solution to further increase the packing density, and to implement new functionalities. Some early demonstrations of 3D hybrid circuits are reviewed and fabrication related issues are discussed. Successful implementation of large-scale 3D memristive system will enable new technologies in future computing applications.
1018	<strong>Effect of water vapor on the thermal resistance between amorphous silica nanoparticles </strong>	Nanoparticle-based materials are of interest because of their unique thermal properties. Possessing the lowest thermal conductivities of any solid materials known, they have been widely used as insulating materials. However, the presence of water vapor has been shown to a large influence on those properties. In this work, we investigate the effect of water vapor on the heat transfer between nanoparticles using non-equilibrium molecular dynamics simulations. We calculate the total thermal resistance and thermal boundary resistance between adjacent amorphous spherical silica nanoparticles, when water molecules are allowed to diffuse as vapor into the interstitial pores between particles. The thermal resistance between nanoparticles is shown to decrease rapidly when water vapor is introduced into the pores between particles. The largest decrease in interparticle resistance occurs as a result of the silanization of the silica particle surfaces.
