A secondary decrease is attributable to the liquid bridge that forms as water molecules condense around the contact point between nanoparticles. Most of the decrease in resistance between nanoparticles occurs when water vapor is first introduced at relative humidities (rh) of less than 1%. As relative humidity increases above 1%, the interparticle thermal resistance decreases more slowly, approaching a constant value near 50% rh. Numerical results are compared to experimental measurements of heat transfer across packed beds of 20 nm silica nanoparticles exposed to water vapor. The simulation results are shown to be consistent with the experimental measurements for relative humidities below 15% rh, while underpredicting the experimental measurements above 15% rh.
1019	Suppression of Walker breakdown in gapped magnetic nanowires	We report our numerical study on efficient and controllable suppression of the Walker breakdown along nanowires by positioning nanogaps with periodicity matching to that of transformational spin structure of magnetic domain wall. While the Walker breakdown is suppressed, the transverse spin<br />structure is found to be stably maintained without formation of antivortex core throughout the propagation, shedding a light in faster spintronic devices based on the domain wall motion.
1020	<strong>Influence of Ni-Zn-Cu-Ferrite on Electroactive &beta;</strong><strong>-Phase</strong><strong> in </strong><strong>Poly(vinylidene fluoride)-</strong><strong>Ni-Zn-Cu-Ferrite Nanocomposite Film: Unique Metamaterial for Enhanced Microwave Absorption</strong>	In search of a new radar absorbing material for microwave applications Ni<sub>0.40</sub>Zn<sub>0.40</sub>Cu<sub>0.20</sub>Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> (NZCF) nanoparticles are successfully incorporated in the matrix of poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) and this NZCF-PVDF nanocomposite system has evolved as the potential one for absorbing radiations in the microwave/GHz frequency range. The enhancement of electroactive &beta;-phase of PVDF has been observed in the NZCF-PVDF nanocomposite system due to the formation of NZCF-PVFD interfaces. Also, magnetic dipoles of ferrite nanoparticles are present in the same resultant nanocomposite system. Both these two factors will play the significant role for the interaction of microwave radiation with the medium of NZCF-PVDF nanocomposite system. The optimization of wave matter interaction leads to the superior reflection loss property of the NZCF-PVDF nanocomposite system. The simultaneous contributions of both magnetic nano-fillers and polar PVDF polymer makes this NZCF-PVDF nanocomposite system a unique metamaterial for enhanced microwave absorption. Many articles have been published on polymer-ferrite/hexaferrite systems but in true sense the involvement of NZCF-PVFD interfaces as the active centre during wave matter interaction has not been considered by anyone else. Reflection loss property for all the NZCF-PVDF nanocomposite films has been observed and a maximum of -49.7 dB at 13.2 GHz is obtained for 10 weight % of NZCF loaded PVDF nanocomposite film. This is basically the highest reflection loss ever found in these types of polymer based metamaterials. Also, the high value of reflection loss in NZCF-PVDF nanocomposite films (X and K<sub>u</sub> bands) makes them most suitable one for the applications in microwave devices.
1021	<strong>Structure transformation of sp3 carbon assisted carbon nanotube growth</strong>	In this study, we investigated the effect of hydrocarbon composition on carbon nanotube (CNT) growth using an iron catalyst via the thermal chemical vapor deposition process. The presence of atomic hydrogen and active carbon species appeared to be essential for nucleation and growth of CNT arrays. With increasing in atomic hydrogen content, the interface layer distance of the CNTs decreased from 3.7 to 3.4 &Aring;. The shifts in the G-band in the Raman spectra of the CNTs indicated that the hydrogen atoms affected the generation of C&ndash;C bonds in graphene layers.
1022	Negative Photoconductivity of WS<sub>2</sub> Nanosheets Decorated with Au Nanoparticles	Tungsten disulfide (WS<sub>2</sub>) nanosheets (NSs) decorated with Au nanoparticles (NPs) were synthesized by sputtering and electron beam irradiation, and the effect of the Au NP decoration on the photoresponse of the WS<sub>2</sub> NSs was investigated. The WS<sub>2</sub> NSs decorated with Au NPs showed photoresponsivity of 39.9 mA&middot;W<sup>-1</sup>, which was 25.7 times higher than the WS<sub>2</sub> NSs without Au NPs decoration. With the Au NP decoration, the change from positive photoconductivity to negative photoconductivity (NPC) was observed under 450-nm laser illumination. However, compared with the WS<sub>2</sub> NSs without an Au NP decoration, the WS<sub>2</sub> NSs decorated with Au NPs showed longer rising and falling times of 18 and 468 s, respectively. The origin of the enhanced photoresponse and NPC for the WS<sub>2</sub> NSs decorated with Au NPs were investigated. A finite-difference time-domain calculation was conducted, and an NPC mechanism based on electron trapping was proposed.
1023	<strong>Construction and characterization of </strong><strong>ZnFe<sub>2-x</sub>Eu<sub>x</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@mTiO<sub>2</sub>@N-GQDs Biocompatible Nano-devices for Smart Drug Release with pH and Microwave Irradiation</strong>	In the present study a pH/microwave-responsive drug smart nano-device based on superparamagnetic core-shell ZnFe<sub>2-x</sub>Eu<sub>x</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@mTiO<sub>2</sub>@N-GQDs ternary nano-hybrids (TNHs) and ZnFe<sub>2-x</sub>Eu<sub>x</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@mTiO<sub>2</sub> binary nano-hybrids (BNHs) was prepared. The smart nano-device composed of a superparamagnetic ZnFe<sub>2-x</sub>Eu<sub>x</sub>O<sub>4 </sub>core and mesoporous TiO<sub>2 </sub>(m TiO<sub>2</sub>) and nitrogen-doped graphene quantum dots (N-GQDs) interlayer shell which was synthesized by a facile sol-gel and/or sono-chemical method. These nano-devices were used for pH/microwave-controllable doxorubicin hydrochloride (DOX) release. These nano-devices was characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscope (SEM), photoluminescence spectra (PL), vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) and zeta potential value. The in vitro cytotoxicity testing exhibited negligible cytotoxicity of as-prepared nano-devices even at the concentration as high as 150 &mu;g/mL. The DOX (an anticancer drug) loading capacity of this nano-device was as high as 1.81 mg/mg. The  loaded  DOX  can  be  sustainably  smart released,  which  was  apt  to  be  controlled  by  microwave irradiation and pH adjustment. Thus, this core-interlayer-shell TNHs was suitable for in vivo biomedical targeting delivery and controlled DOX release using pH and microwave irradiation.
1024	Impact of Varying Strain Energy in Oxide on the Random Telegraphic Noise and Time Constants in Narrow Diameter Silicon Nanowire p-MOSFETs	Multi-level random telegraphic noise (RTN) in 15 nm diameter gate-all-around (GAA) silicon nanowire p-MOSFET shows gate voltage overdrive dependent inter-state transitions, statistical count of which indicates existence of oxide traps having different time constants. Following detail extraction of the capture and emission times with gate bias, we have found both to deviate from the usual trend, as predicted by the conventional Shockley-Read-Hall (SRH) statistics. Two traps in the gate oxide have been found, in which the near interface is found to respond through the altered RTN activation energy barrier by spatially varying oxide residual strain energy, whereas the farther is found to respond under the weak influence of the oxide strain energy. On the other hand, emission time of near interface trap has been found to follow similar strain influenced activation barrier, but magnitude of the emission time of the farther trap shows hole emission through the p+ polysilicon gate-oxide interfacial trap, aided by electrostatic field in oxide. From RTN distributions and time lag plots, inter-state transitions and state suppression in RTN are explained under the framework of two trap postulate, in order to elucidate unusual gate bias dependency of the measured trap time constants in silicon nanowire MOSFETs
1025	Direct Hydroxylation of Benzene to Phenol Mediated by Nanosized Vanadium Oxide Cluster Ions at Room Temperature	Gas-phase vanadium oxide cluster cations and anions are prepared by laser ablation. The small cluster ions (&lt; 1000 amu) are mass-selected using a quadruple mass filter and reacted with benzene in a linear ion trap reactor; large clusters (&gt; 1000 amu) with no mass selection are reacted with C6H6 in a fast flow reactor. Rich product variety is encountered in these reactions, and the reaction channels for small cationic and anionic systems are different. For large clusters, the reactivity patterns of (V2O5)n+ (n = 6-25) and (V2O5)nO- (n = 6-24) cluster series are very similar to each other, indicating that charge state has little influence on the oxidation of benzene. In sharp contrast to the dramatic changes of reactivity of small clusters, a weakly size dependent reaction behavior of large (V2O5)6-25+ and (V2O5)6-24O- clusters is observed. Therefore, the charge state and the size are not the major factors influencing the reactivity of nanosized vanadium oxide cluster ions toward C6H6, which is not common in cluster science. In the reactions with benzene, the small and large reactive vanadium oxide cations parallel similar reactivity of hydroxyl radicals (OH&#x2022;) toward C6H6 at higher and lower temperatures, respectively; different numbers of vibrational degree of freedoms and the released energy during the formation of adduct complexes can explain this intriguing correlation. The reactions investigated herein might be used as the models of how to realize the partial oxidation of benzene to phenol in a single step, and the observed mechanisms are helpful to understand the corresponding heterogeneous reactions, such as those over vanadium oxide aerosols and vanadium oxide catalysts.
1026	Investigation of the temperature dependence of random telegraph noise fluctuations in nanoscale polysilicon-channel 3-D Flash cells	By gathering statistical data from the floating-gate cells in a state-of-the-art 3-Dimensional (3-D) NAND Flash memory array, in this letter we explore the temperature dependence of random telegraph noise (RTN) fluctuations in nanoscale polysilicon-channel metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors. Experimental results highlight some major differences in the RTN temperature behavior with respect to monocrystalline silicon devices. In particular, not only the time constants but also the amplitude of RTN fluctuations appear to significantly change with temperature, with the latter displaying an average increase when temperature is reduced. The change of the fluctuation amplitude with temperature is correlated neither with the fluctuation time constants nor with their activation energy. Results are explained in terms of a more relevant role played by polysilicon grain boundaries when temperature is reduced, leading to a more percolative conduction in the transistor channel and to a stronger impact on the source-to-drain current of RTN traps placed close to the grain boundaries. These results should be carefully considered when attempting spectroscopic investigations based on the assumption, valid for monocrystalline devices, that only the time constants and not the amplitude of RTN flutuations change with temperature.
1027	<strong>&ldquo;Planetary&rdquo; silver nanoparticles held in orbit by electric charge</strong>	In a gas aggregation cluster source, nanoparticles are formed by aggregation of single atoms to particles as well as by agglomeration of smaller particles to form larger particles. Because the small particles are often electrically charged, it is possible that particles are mutually attracted or repelled by electric forces. In this work we report the observation of &ldquo;planetary&rdquo; bound multi-particle systems which are the result of the electrical and centrifugal forces acting on nanoparticles in a magnetron sputtering cluster source. Transmission electron microscopy analysis of deposited &ldquo;planetary&rdquo; nanoparticle systems exhibit characteristic interparticle distances and sizes, as well as different charge states of the particles. Simulations confirm the presence of stable planetary nanoparticle systems up to at least 6/7 satellites. The discovery of such &ldquo;planetary&rdquo; nanoparticle systems inside a cluster source opens up possibilities for more research into their properties and how they can be further controlled and explored.
1028	Density and viscosity profiles governing nanochannel flow	The density and viscosity profiles across the nanochannel height were respectively compared between the flow factor approach model and molecular dynamics simulation for the Poiseuille flow in a nanochannel, when the agreements between these two approaches were good in calculating both the flow velocity profile across the channel height and the volume flow rate through the channel. It was found that except close to the confining wall, the comparisons in the two regards showed satisfactory agreements; Because of the solidification of the thin layer close to the wall, the errors of the flow factor approach model in calculating both the local density and local viscosity close to the wall can not considerably affect its calculation accuracy of both the flow velocity profile across the channel height and the volume flow rate through the channel, both of which were actually governed by the density and viscosity profiles of the flowing media in the middle section of the channel height.
1029	Density and viscosity profiles governing nanochannel flow	The density and viscosity profiles across the nanochannel height were respectively compared between the flow factor approach model and molecular dynamics simulation for the Poiseuille flow in a nanochannel, when the agreements between these two approaches were good in calculating both the flow velocity profile across the channel height and the volume flow rate through the channel. It was found that except close to the confining wall, the comparisons in the two regards showed satisfactory agreements; Because of the solidification of the thin layer close to the wall, the errors of the flow factor approach model in calculating both the local density and local viscosity close to the wall can not considerably affect its calculation accuracy of both the flow velocity profile across the channel height and the volume flow rate through the channel, both of which were actually governed by the density and viscosity profiles of the flowing media in the middle section of the channel height.
1030	Topology Optimization of 3-Translational-DOF Spatial Compliant Mechanism	The mainly feature of topological structure is hingeless (or hidden hinges), so it is important to find an exactly pseudo-rigid-body model (PRBM) for the spatial compliant mechanism with a topological structure. Considering the Jacobain matrix maps the velocity of the joint space of the robot to the end velocity of the Cartesian space, a novel topology optimization approach is proposed in this paper for the design of three Translational degree-of-freedom (DOF) spatial compliant mechanisms by combination the optimized Jacobain mapping matrix with the solid isotropic material with penalization (SIMP) topological method. Firstly, by using the condition number method, the structural parameters of UPU type parallel prototype manipulator are optimized, and then, the differential Jacobain mapping matrix is calculated by using differential infinitesimal equivalence method with micro/nano scale motion characteristics. Secondly, comparing with the diver configuration and twist/wrench constraint conditions of the UPU type parallel prototype manipulator, the topological algorithm combined SIMP with optimized Jacobian mapping matrix is proposed. Finally, a novel spatial compliant mechanism with three translational DOF is derived, and a numerical simulation results are reported to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.
1031	Electron beam-based metrology after CMOS	We review post-CMOS challenges facing electron-based metrology, using directed self-assembly, nanophotonics/plasmonics, and memristive switches as exemplars of post-CMOS technologies. Novel materials, devices, and architectures pose new metrology requirements: defect detection, in soft materials, accurate measurement of size, shape, and roughness of nanophotonic structures, contamination-free measurement of surface-sensitive structures, and identification of subtle structural, chemical, or electronic changes of state in non-volatile memory-element switching. Electron-beam techniques are examined in light of these requirements. Strong electron-matter interactions provide measurable signals from small samples, rendering electron-beam methods suitable for nanometer-scale metrology, but many measurement challenges remain. The seeds of possible solutions are identified.
1032	<strong>Fracture toughnesses and crack growth angles of three types of carbon allotropes</strong>	Recently, Shang et al. [Angew. Chem. Inte. Ed., 2018, 57(3):774-778] have developed a method to synthesize ultrathin (around 1.9 nm) graphyne nanosheets. We reported here the mixed-mode I-II fracture toughnesses and crack growth angles of cyclicgraphene and graphyne as well as supergraphene using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and finite element (FE) method based on the boundary layer model, respectively. The various carbon-carbon (C-C) bonds of the three carbon allotropes in the FE method is equivalent into a nonlinear Timoshenko beam based on the Tersoff-Brenner potential, where all the parameters of the nonlinear beams are completely determined based on the continuum modeling. All results from the present FE method are reasonable by comparison with those from our MD simulations using REBO potential. The present results show that both critical stress intensity factors (SIFs) and crack growth angles strongly depend on their chirality and loading angle <em>&phi;</em> (<em>&phi;=</em>90&ordm; and <em>&phi;=</em>0&ordm; represent the pure mode I and the pure mode II, respectively). The critical equivalent SIFs are derived as 1.55 &lt;<em>K</em><sub>eq-cy</sub> (cyclic) &lt;1.95 nN &Aring;<sup>-3/2</sup>, 1.64 &lt;<em>K</em><sub>eq-gy</sub> (graphyne) &lt; 2.64 nN &Aring;<sup>-3/2</sup> and 0.61 &lt;<em>K</em><sub>eq-su</sub> (super) &lt; 2.04 nN &Aring;<sup>-3/2</sup> in corresponding zigzag and armchair sheets using MD simulations, while the SIFs are 0.32 &lt;<em>K</em><sub>eq-cy</sub> (cyclic) &lt;0.48 nN &Aring;<sup>-3/2</sup>, 1.96 &lt;<em>K</em><sub>eq-gy</sub> (graphyne) &lt; 2.49 nN &Aring;<sup>-3/2</sup> and 1.42 &lt;<em>K</em><sub>eq-su</sub> (super) &lt; 2.95 nN &Aring;<sup>-3/2 </sup>using FE method. These findings should be great help for understanding fracture properties of carbon allotropes and designing the carbon-based nanodevices.
1033	Yagi-Uda Nanoantenna Enhanced Metal-Semiconductor-Metal Photodetector<strong></strong>	An array of 400 nanolithographic Yagi-Uda antennas on a metal-semiconductor-metal rectifier photodetector demonstrates control of wavelength selectivity and directivity.  The nanoantenna array response is obtained using a direct electrical measurement approach.  Resonances in rectified photocurrent are detected at incident electromagnetic radiation of free-space wavelengths 1110 nm and 1690 nm, corresponding to scaled effective wavelengths of 388 nm and 776 nm respectively.  The scaling is consistent with theory based on plasmonic effects in nanoscale devices at optical frequencies, and the two resonance wavelengths are found to match respectively full-wavelength and half-wavelength operation of the detector dipole element.
1034	Generation of UV-induced radiation defects in calcite	The effect of UV light on the most common mineral on Earth - calcite (CaCO3), has been little investigated, despite its significant implications for many areas of research, such as photodegradation of CaCO3-containing materials, conservation of historical objects, dosimetry and dating. In this study, conducted on nano- and micro-grained calcite samples using Electron Paramagnetic Resonance spectroscopy, we provide a detailed analysis of the radiation defects (paramagnetic centers) generated by UV radiation, including their identification, location (surface- or bulk-related) and stability during the period up to 4 years after irradiation. The observed paramagnetic centers, such as isotropic and anisotropic CO2-, CO3-, SO2-, SO3-, NO32- and NO22- ions, are analogous to gamma-induced species, which contradicts a widely-held belief that low-energy radiation cannot create radiation defects in wide band-gap materials, such as calcite. We present a mechanism of UV-induced generation of carbonate paramagnetic species in calcite based on retrapping the 'secondary electrons', i.e. the electrons released from non-carbonate traps by UV light. The efficiency of this process is strongly connected with the size and morphology of calcite grains, which can be especially relevant, considering the variety of CaCO3 particles used in the industry and available in nature.
1035	Edge mode based graphene nanomechanical resonators for high-sensitivity mass sensor	We perform both molecular dynamics simulations and theoretical analysis to study the sensitivity of the mass sensor based on graphene nanomechanical resonators, which are actuated following the global extended mode or the localized edge mode. We find that the mass detection sensitivity corresponding to the edge mode is about three times higher than that corresponding to the extended mode. Our analytic derivations reveal that the enhancement of the sensitivity originates in the reduction of the effective mass for the edge mode due to its localizing feature. Our findings shed light on improving the sensitivity of the graphene based mass spectrometry by utilizing the localized edge mode.
1036	Electron hole plasma dynamics in pristine and Ag-doped ZnO nanorods	Femtosecond two color pump-probe transmission experiments are carried out at large carrier densities, much higher than the Mott density on pristine and Ag doped ZnO nanorod ensembles. The data shows tri-exponential decay: ultrafast electron-phonon thermalization (~ 0.40 ps), trap mediated decay with time constant (~ 9 ps), and electron-hole recombination with time constant (~ 650 ps). As the carrier density is increased, the first two decay processes get longer on contrary to the recombination time which gets shorter. Carrier density dependent studies coupled with detailed two temperature model suggest interplay of complex variation of electron-phonon interaction and trap states.
1037	<strong>Theoretical analysis and optimization of high k dielectric layers for designing high performance and low power dissipated nanoscale double gate MOSFETs</strong>	The carrier transport and tunnelling mechanism in nanoscale double gate (DG) metal oxide field effect transistor (MOSFET) for different dielectric layers is investigated here by a simple two dimensional analytical model, which finds good agreement with the drift diffusion and hydrodynamic models at lower gate voltages. The model is utilized to optimize the performance of the MOSFET by minimizing the carrier leakage and improving the gate control on the carrier transport through the channel. It is well known that thicker physical layers of high k dielectrics can be used to reduce gate tunnelling current without compromising on the gate controllability over the channel conduction as it provides the same equivalent oxide thickness (EOT) as SiO<sub>2</sub>. However, lower conduction band offset of the dielectric layer over Si MOSFET can cause appreciable tunnelling through the gate as found through our computational results for the TiO<sub>2</sub> layer. Our findings suggest a combination of dielectric layers; one having higher dielectric constant and the other having larger conduction band offset over Si, to minimize gate leakage. Tunnelling current is analysed for different combinational dielectric layers along with optimization of its thickness. Our study predicts minimum current leakage for the MOSFET with 4&Aring; La<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/ 9&Aring; TiO<sub>2</sub> combinational dielectric layer having the drain induced barrier lowering (DIBL) factor of 29 mV/V, &lsquo;off&rsquo; state power dissipation of 2.3 nW and a high I<sub>on</sub>/I<sub>off</sub> ratio of 1.6&times;10<sup>7</sup>. The study thus predicts the suitability of this MOSFET for low power devices and logic circuits.
1038	<strong>Comparative Study on Exothermic Behavior of Nano Composites (Al/CuO, Mg/CuO and Al/Mg/CuO)</strong>	Comparative experimental study on exothermicity of nano energetic composites has been conducted in this study. Three different composites consisting of CuO and each one of the following: Al, Mg and Al/Mg were prepared using physical mixing. The composites prepared consist of 100% excess oxidant to provide more oxygen for oxidation process. The particles were not passivated with any coating to study their unique parameters. Differential Scanning Calorimeter, Thermo-Gravimetric Analysis and Differential Thermal Analysis have been carried out on all three composites to compare them. Scanning Electron Microscope was used for imaging the composite&rsquo;s homogeneity. The main objective of the study is to improve heat generation and lower the ignition temperatures of the composite by formulating the composite with two different metal fuels. The composite made of both Al and Mg in CuO showed high reactivity, low ignition temperature and high heat generation than the composites prepared of individual metal fuels. These results of heat generation and weight loss help in fundamental understanding of chemical reactions undergoing in the composites. This study might help in further advancements in the field of energetic materials.
1039	<strong>Ultrastable water suspension of luminescent carbon quantum dots</strong>	Crystalline graphite microparticles are good source for fabricating graphene or carbon quantum dots. The low toxicity, chemical stability and fluorescence properties make these quantum materials suitable for applications in biomedical and water purification technologies. In this paper, we show that by nanosecond laser irradiation of graphitic microparticles in water, a highly stable water suspension of carbon quantum dots of high purity and strongly luminescent in the green is generated. The size of the quantum dots can be tuned in the range of 5 nm to 15 nm by varying the laser irradiation time. During the laser interaction, the ionization of the material and the surrounding water layer creates functional groups &ndash;HC=O, C&ndash;O&ndash;C and C&ndash;O attached to the surface of the quantum dots. Further, the presence of similar charges on the surface of the quantum dots developed during the laser ablation process helps in obtaining a highly stable water suspension of the quantum dots.
1040	Distribution of label spacings for genome mapping in nanochannels	In genome mapping experiments, long DNA molecules are stretched by confining them to very narrow channels, so that the locations of sequence-specific fluorescent labels along the channel axis provide large-scale genomic information.  It is difficult, however, to make the channels narrow enough so that the DNA molecule is fully stretched. In practice its conformations may form hairpins that change the spacings between internal segments of the DNA molecule, and thus the label locations along the channel axis. Here we describe a theory for the distribution of label spacings that explains the heavy tails observed in distributions of label spacings in genome mapping experiments.
1041	Lipids with bulky head groups generate large membrane curvatures by small compositional asymmetries	Glycolipids such as GM1 have bulky head groups consisting sof several monosaccharides. sWhen these lipids are added to phospholipid bilayers, they sgenerate large  membrane curvatures even for small compositional sasymmetries between the two leaflets of the bilayers. sOn the micrometer scale,  these bilayer asymmetries lead to the sspontaneous  tubulation of giant vesicles as recently observed sby optical microscopy.  sHere, we study these mixed membranes on the nanometer sscale using coarse-grained molecular simulations. sThe membrane composition  is defined by  the mole fractions s$\phi_1$ and  $\phi_2$  of the large-head lipid in the two leaflets sof the bilayer.  sSymmetric membranes are obtained for  $\phi_1 = \phi_2 \equiv \phi_\rle $, sasymmetric ones for $\phi_1 \ne \phi_2$.  sIn both cases, we compute the density and stress profiles sacross the membranes. sThe stress profiles are used to identify the tensionless states sof the membranes. sSymmetric and tensionless bilayers are found to be stable  within sthe whole composition range $0 \leq \phi_\rle \leq 1$. s For these symmetric bilayers,  both the area compressibility s modulus and the bending rigidity are found to  vary non-monotonically s with the leaflet mole fraction $\phi_\rle$.  s For asymmetric bilayers, we compute the product  of bending s rigidity and spontaneous curvature from the first moment of the stress s profile and determine  the bending rigidities of the  asymmetric s membranes using the $\phi_\rle$-dependent rigidities of the single leaflets. s When we combine these   results,  the compositional asymmetry s $\phi_1 - \phi_2$  is found to generate the spontaneous curvature s $(\phi_1- \phi_2)/ ( 0.63 \,  \ell_\rme)$ s with  the membrane thickness $\ell_\rme \simeq 4\,$nm. s Therefore,  the spontaneous curvature increases linearly with s the compositional asymmetry. Furthermore,   s  the  small compositional asymmetry $\phi_1 - \phi_2 = 0.04$s leads to the large spontaneous curvature $1/(63\,$nm) and the  s increased asymmetry $\phi_1 - \phi_2 = 0.2$  generates the huge s spontaneous curvature $1/(13\,$nm). sThese large values  of the spontaneous curvature will facilitate future simulation studies of various membrane processes such sas bud formation and  nanoparticle  engulfment.
1042	<strong>Absorption enhancement in an amorphous silicon using a cluster of plasmonic  hollow ring nano-antennas </strong>	Enhancement of absorption and extending its bandwidth is of major interest for solar cells, photo detectors, and variety of applications. This letter presents a nano-structure formed of an array whose elements are in the form of a 3X3 cluster of metal rings having similar outer diameter but with various inner diameters. Thus each ring size produces certain resonance frequency and the result of the cluster arrangement is a staggered responses that possess larger bandwidth. Simulations using the periodic unit cell approach and the CST microwave studio suite showed that the average absorption power in an amorphous silicon layer has been improved by 3.32 times compared to that without rings. The obtained response covers the frequency range from 230 THz to 360 THz.
1043	Study of signal enhancement in collinear femtosecond-nanosecond double-pulse laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy	The study of spectral emission intensity in a femtosecond-nanosecond double-pulse laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy with collinear configuration (fs-ns DP-LIBS collinear configuration) was presented. The experiment was carried out in air at atmospheric pressure using Si sample irradiated by a femtosecond laser beam and a nanosecond laser beam. In order to explore the advantages of this configuration (fs-ns DP-LIBS collinear configuration), the experiments of femtosecond SP-LIBS and nanosecond SP-LIBS were also performed for the same Si sample. The experimental data indicated that the shorter laser pulse (femtosecond) was efficient in coupling to the sample and the longer laser pulse (nanosecond) is suitable for re-heating the produced plasma. In the meantime, the used fs-ns DP-LIBS collinear configuration can be considered as an efficient technique for enhancing the spectral intensity during the ablation processes.
1044	Coercive field enhancement in Co nanodisks: Single-domain to vortex switching	We report in plane magnetic measurements of Ti/Co/Nb nanodisks with the Co layer fabricated in the range of thicknesses between 6 to 14 nm. Additionally micromagnetic simulations were carried out with OOMMF giving magnetic domain structure and hysteresis loops which were later compared with those obtained experimentally using vibrating sample magnetometry. Simulation and experiment indicate a peak in coercive field at a critical thickness that clearly separates the two phases; single domain and vortex phase. This peak is characterized by a substantially larger coercive field opening the possibility to investigate such enhancement in other ferromagnetic materials.
1045	<strong>Nanoplasmonic-whispering gallery mode hybrid microresonator for enhancing single molecule Raman scattering and fluorescence</strong>	For the first time, we propose the enhancement of Raman scattering signal using a nanoplasmonic-whispering gallery mode (WGM) hybrid microresonator (HMR). Using the reactive sensing principle, analytical theory is developed for estimating the enhancement of single molecule Raman signal (<em>&eta;</em>) by an HMR relative to the conventional surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) technique. Theoretical simulations have been carried out using developed theory to understand the dependence of <em>&eta;</em> on quality factor of WGM, input light power, wavelength of incident light. It is observed that the HMR is better for obtaining more enhancement as long as efficient evanescent coupling exists for proper launching of laser light into the HMR. Hence, this hybrid device can be used for studying single molecule Raman scattering and for the same purpose, an experimental setup has been proposed. This device is also found better in enhancing single molecule fluorescence as compared with the conventional surface enhanced fluorescence (SEF) technique. Finally, suitable nanoplasmonic structures are proposed for making efficient hybrid microresonators (HMRs) for studying single molecule Raman scattering/fluorescence and their local field strengths are estimated using finite element method (FEM).
1046	Plasmonics effects arising from the rotational metal/dielectric nanostructures	We have investigated the plasmonic effects on a two-dimensional periodic array of composite metal/dielectric nanostructures which the integration of the localized surface plasmon resonance (SPR) and hollow plasmon resonance (HPR) properties is performed. The unit cell of the array is composed of the combination the silver core-shell nanorod and dielectric nanosphere in a single structure. We make use of the finite element method to obtain the simulation results which demonstrate that the localized SPR and HPR originating from the rotational metal/dielectric nanostructures enhance the near field intensity and transmittance dip, which provides additional degrees of freedom in the control of light wave at the nanoscale. Numerical results show that the depth of transmittance dip and sensitivity can be elevated to a value of 73.91% and 2.5 times, respectively, when the rotational angle of metal/dielectric nanostructures varies from 00 to 900, and the characteristics can be extensive applications for nanophotonic devices.
1047	Shape-dependent magnetoelectric coupling in nanoscale BiFeO$_3$	The nanorods and nanocuboids of multiferroic BiFeO$_3$ exhibit remarkable shape dependence of crystallographic, ferroelectric, and magnetoelectric properties. The nanorods, for example, assume R3m space group (as against R3c observed both in bulk and nearly spherical nanosized particles) and are found to be oriented preferentially with long axis $\parallel$ [101]. The magnetic and electric coercive fields as well as magnetoelectric coupling - measured from change in remanent polarization under a magnetic field - are found to be larger in nanocuboids. The shape dependence of multiferroic properties originates from that of microstrain and anisotropy.
1048	<strong>Structural and optical study of Zn-doped As<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> thin films: Evidence for photoinduced formation of ZnSe nanocrystallites</strong>	Amorphous Zn-doped As<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> films with a nominal zinc content <em>x</em> up to 10 at.% were prepared by thermal evaporation. Their structure is characterized by atomic force microscopy (AFM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS), and Raman spectroscopy. The AFM data show a considerable increase of the film surface roughness for films with <em>x</em> &gt; 5 at.%. A strong gradient of the Zn content decreasing into the film depth is confirmed by the EDX and XPS data. Heavily Zn-doped (above 7 at.%) As<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> films reveal photostructural changes in the course of the Raman measurements. New Raman features are attributed to TO and LO vibrations of ZnSe nanocrystallites formed in the film under laser illumination. Depending on the laser wavelength and power density, the ZnSe nanocrystallites can experience tensile strain in the film due to a photoplastic effect in the As<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> film (partial removal of the material from the laser spot). The tensile strain value, estimated from the TO and LO phonon frequency shift, is shown to reach up to 2.9 GPa.
1049	Negative differential resistance in twisted graphene nanoribbons	In this work, we analyze the electron transmission through twisted graphene nanoribbons with armchair or zigzag edges connected to leads and subjected to an external electric field. The combination of both electric field and helical conformation of the nanoribbon induces a periodic potential for electrons transmitting from the source to the drain. The periodic potential results in allowed bands and gaps that lead to negative differential resistance and the N-shaped current-voltage characteristics in the case of zig-zag nanoribbons. In addition, the electric field can efficiently control the current flowing through the nanoribbon. This opens the possibility to use the proposed device as a field-effect transistor or active element in amplifiers or generators.
1050	Two-dimensional Au-1,3,5 triethynylbenzene organometallic lattice: Structure, half-metallicity and gas sensing	On the basis of first-principles calculations, we investigated the structural and electronic properties of two-dimensional (2D) Au-1,3,5 triethynylbenzene (Au-TEB) framework, which has been recently synthesized by homocoupling reactions in experiments. Featured by C-Au-C linkage, 2D Au-TEB network has a kagome lattice by Au atom and a hexagonal lattice by organic molecule within the same metal-organic framework (MOF), which exhibits intrinsic half-metallicity with one spin channel metallic and the other spin channel fully insulating with a large energy gap of 2.8 eV. Two branches of kagome bands are located near Fermi level, with each branch including one flat band and two Dirac bands, which originates from the out-of-plane dxz and dyz orbitals of Au and may lead to many exotic topological quantum phases. We further studied the adsorption of F, Cl atoms, and small gas molecules including O2, CO, NO2 and NH3 on Au-TEB network, aiming to exploit its potential applications in gas sensors. Detailed analyses on adsorption geometry, energy, molecular orbital interaction and electronic structure modification suggest the great potential of Au-TEP as a promising alternative for gas sensing. We expect these results to expand the universe of low-dimensional half-metallic MOF structures and shed new light on their practical applications in nanoelectronics/spintronics.
1051	<strong>Low-voltage dielectric elastomer actuators </strong><strong>with stretchable electrodes fabricated by supersonic cluster beam implantation</strong>	Supersonic Cluster Beam Implantation (SCBI) of Ag nanoparticles is proposed for the fabrication of stretchable and compliant electrodes for Dielectric Elastomer Actuators (DEAs) with reduced thickness. Thanks to the low-energy and finely tunable implantation process, a nanocomposite Ag/PDMS electrode layer is produced with moderate stiffening effect for the DEA in contrast with common deposition strategy for electrodes. Thin DEAs with overall thickness of 17 mm were fabricated and tested under different preloading conditions, demonstrating a max uniaxial actuation strain of 2.5% at an actuation voltage of 765 V, lower than typical voltage values of DEAs. The electrodes remained conductive up to 40% strain and they fully recovered original resistance after 70% stretching. Our results represent a significant step towards the development of DEAs operating at reduced actuation voltages, by stacking of micrometer-thick elastomer films, paving the way to novel applications in soft robotics.
1052	Remote control of liquid crystal elastomer random laser using external stimuli	We present a new design for a random laser based on a composite material consisting in an elastomeric liquid crystal with embedded TiO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles. Random lasing action can be controlled by an external, non-contact light stimulus; this induces a rearrangement of the elastomeric liquid crystals that moves the laser body in and out of the focal plane of a pump laser, pushing its emission above or below the lasing threshold.
1053	Enhancing the figure-of-merit of refractive index sensors by magnetoplasmons in one-dimensional nanograting	The sensing performance of one-dimensional metallic-magnetic grating based on magnetoplasmons was investigated. The predictable Kerr reversal and enhancement are achieved in our experiment. The further result shows that the shift of Kerr null point has a linear relationship with the surrounding refractive index in a wide range. Thus a huge figure of merit (FoM) of 1728  is achieved, which is 1 order of magnitude higher than the results reported. The experiment and theory confirm that the excitation of surface plasmons leads to the Kerr reversal and enhancement, resulting in a huge FoM.
1054	<strong>Effect of NiSb nanoparticle coating on the thermoelectric properties of bulk Antimonide-Telluride particles </strong>	NiSb nanoparticles by 0.034, 0.074 and 0.16 volume fractions were successfully coated on bulk Ni<sub>0.05</sub>Mo<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5.4</sub>Te<sub>1.6</sub> thermoelectric (TE) particles through solvothermal route without deteriorating the bulk Ni<sub>0.05</sub>Mo<sub>3</sub>Sb<sub>5.4</sub>Te<sub>1.6 </sub>material. For samples of 0.074 NiSb and 0.16 NiSb, layers of 100-300 nm NiSb nanoparticles were observed. The samples were consolidated through hot pressing and their thermoelectric(TE) properties were characterized. At 400 K, 500 K, and 600 K, 0.074 NiSb sample exhibited a 22%, 16% and 11.3% increase in power factor (<em>P.F.</em>) compared to bulk. The main contributing factor to this enhanced power factor is the elevated electrical conductivity. For the same sample, the reciprocal relationship between Seebeck coefficient and electrical conductivity is decoupled. Sample 0.16 NiSb exhibited the highest electrical conductivity among the three samples. The thermal conductivity of the 0.16 sample is less temperature sensitive compared to other samples. HRTEM and SEM tools were applied to comprehend microstructural features and their relation to TE transport properties. Pore effect on the thermal and electrical conductivity was elucidated. This study shows that grain- boundary manipulation via this wet chemistry technique is indeed economically viable method to fabricate and optimize the transport properties of bulk TE materials.
1055	<strong>Fabrication and investigation of a thermoacoustic loudspeaker based on carbon nanotube coated laser scribed graphene</strong>	Thermophones are known since a century ago, however, high operational voltage and low sound pressure level are the main drawbacks which have constrained their wide application.Utilizing graphene in thermophones has been proposed as an attractive solution, due to its high electrical and thermal conductivity and inherent high surface area. These unique properties are beneficial to enhance the heat transfer, and lowering the required electrical input power. In this paper, laser scribed graphene layer is utilized to realize graphene-based thermophones, which has shown high sound pressure level of about80 dB (P<sub>in</sub>=0.6 W). Furthermore, a layer of carbon nanotubes isincorporated on theprepared graphene sheets. The realized CNT based layerbenefits from bothrandomly oriented CNTs over the surface of rGO sheets, andsuspended CNTs, which act like heat exchangernano-fins on rGO sheets, and efficient heat generators, respectively. The input voltagefor CNT/rGO based thermophones is measured 7 times lower than the prepared rGO based samples, in order to generate the same sound pressure level (75 dB). The achieved sound pressure, normalized to the input power, has increased about 80 dB by incorporating CNTs, which entitles the proposed structure as a promising candidate for novel thermophones.
1056	Side Chain Dynamics in Semi-Conducting Polymer MEH-PPV	The characteristic nanoscale dynamics of the alkyl side groups in the light-emitting polymer MEH-PPV or poly[2-methoxy-5-(2'-ethyl-hexyloxy)-1,4-phenylene vinylene] have been investigated using quasi-elastic neutron scattering (QENS). The measurements were taken at temperatures below the polymer glass transition (T {less than or equal to} Tg &#x2243; 353 K), where the main backbone is in a rigid state and does not contribute to the broadening of the QENS signal. An analytical diffusion model consisting of a static term and two dynamical components, characterizing the flexible side groups, provide an excellent fit to the experimental data. The two observed dynamical processes are all localized in character, with no meaningful dependence on temperature. The faster process, with characteristic time scale of &#x223C; 18 ps at room temperature (RT), can be linked to the average mobility of the protons at the terminal end of the alkyl chain, while the slower process, with characteristic time scale of &#x223C; 170 ps at RT, to those protons at the other end of the alkyl chain, closest to the backbone. While the fraction of mobile protons contributing to the QENS signal increases with increasing temperature, the characteristic time scale and confining volume within which the protons are able to move locally depend chiefly on the polymer conformational state.
1057	Solid State Streak Camera Prototype Electronic Performance Testing and Improvements to Dynamic Range	Streak Cameras are an essential diagnostic tool used in shock physics and high energy density physics experiments.  Such experiments require well calibrated temporally resolving diagnostics for studying events that occur on the nanosecond to microsecond time scales.  The Nevada National Security Site (NNSS) and Sandia National Laboratories (SNL) has built a 42-channel solid state streak camera (SSSC) prototype as a proof of concept for use as a streak camera replacement.  This work is part of an ongoing project to develop the technology to a level competitive with analog streak cameras.  The device concept, results from electronic testing and recent improvements to increase the device's dynamic range will be discussed in this manuscript.
1058	Simulation and Verification of the Dielectric Strength in Polyethylene-Montmorillonite Nanocomposites	In order to explore the microscopic mechanism of mechanical properties and dielectric strength in polyethylene-montmorillonite (PE-MMT) nanocomposites, the molecular model and molecule&rsquo;s structure are simulated by simulation software, and the mechanism of various complex phenomena of mechanical properties and dielectric strength in PE-MMT nanocomposites can be understood more profoundly in the paper. Some important findings emerge from the simulation results. First of all, interlayer spacing of organic modified MMT is expanded to 20&Aring; due to octadecyl trimethyl ammonium chloride cation, which is increased by 79% compared with that of MMT without organic. Meantime, the expansibility of nanocomposites is obvious compared with that of organic modified MMT. Second, when the mass fraction of organic modified MMT reaches 4.0wt%, the hydrogen bonding interaction obviously exists in PE-MMT nanocomposites and the interaction energy between polyethylene molecules and MMT layers has the maximum that is up to -444.46kcal/mol, which lead to the stable structure of nanocomposites and the significant improvement of the interaction between MMT and PE. Third, mechanical properties and dielectric strength are significantly improved in nanocomposites under elastic deformation. Young's modulus, bulk modulus and shear modulus are increased by 106%, 116% and 105% respectively, and the dielectric strength is increased by 43%. Finally, it is found that the experimental dielectric strength of 4.0wt% organic modified MMT in nanocomposites is increased by 13.64% compared with that of polyethylene. Furthermore, the simulation results are consistent with the experimental ones, which can prove that the method of modeling of PE-MMT nanocomposites is correct and effective.
1059	From C60 'trilliumons' to 'trilliumenes': self-assembly of 2D fullerene nanostructures on metal-covered silicon and germanium	We discovered a set of C60 nanostructures that appear to be constructed using a universal building block made of four C60 molecules on Si(111) or Ge(111) surfaces covered by an atomic layer of Tl, Pb, or their compound. The building block is a four-C60 cluster having a shape reminiscent of the three-petal flower 'white trillium'. Therefore, we call it 'trilliumon' and the various 2D ordered nanostructures derived from it 'trilliumenes'. Self-assembly of the trilliumenes is a result of an intricate interplay among the adsorbed C60 molecules, metal atoms, and semiconductor substrate. Remarkably, that all metal layers triggering formation of trilliumenes on Si(111) surface have recently been reported to be the thinnest 2D superconductors. In this respect, the trilliumenes show promise to be 2D nanostructured superconductors which properties are awaiting their exploration.
1060	GaN nanowire surface recombination by light-induced ion trapping	Nanowires intrinsically exhibit a large surface area, which makes them sensitive to physical and chemical interactions with their environment. Here, we investigate the surface recombination at m-plane side walls of selective area-grown GaN nanowires on Si (111) subjected to different environmental conditions. In contrast to the stable photoluminescence observed from c-plane surfaces of films, nanowires exhibit a distinct time-dependent photoluminescence quenching by over 90% within the time scale of seconds in the presence of air or dissociated liquids. This quenching is most pronounced for 50 nm diameter nanowires with interwire spacings larger than 500 nm due to internal electric field and external light field distributions. Ion- and pH-sensitive measurements, in combination with an externally applied voltage allows the assignment of this effect to anions from the surroundings accumulate at the nonpolar GaN side walls of the UV-exposed GaN nanowires. The decay times of the luminescence signal follow the dynamics of valence band holes, which deplete GaN surface states and positively charge the nanowire surfaces. This, in turn, induces the buildup of a capacitive anion shell around the nanowires, leading to an enhanced nonradiative surface recombination of photo-generated charge carriers from the GaN nanowire. In the absence of UV light, a recovery of the photoluminescence signal within tens of minutes indicates the dissolution of the anionic shell via charge balancing. The impact of light-induced electronic and ionic charge redistribution on photocarrier recombination represents and important mechanism of function for GaN nanowire-based devices, ranging from sensors to photocatalysts.
1061	The ice-like vortex states in a nanostructured superconducting film with a dice lattice of elongated antidots	We study the degeneracy of the superconducting vortex ground state in a dice lattice of elongated antidots within the Ginzburg-Landau (GL) theory. It is found there are two kinds of unit cells in this dice lattice, namely $z6$ unit cell where six antibars meet and $z3$ unit cell where three antibars meet. This can result in more complicated vortex arrangements in the unit cells than that in the Kagome lattice. We demonstrate that the vortex patterns at specific fractional magnetic fields can be determined by the local constraints, which presented the ice-like configuration based on the degeneracy rules. This is the reason that the vortex system follows the rule of "two vortices in, one vortex out" or "two vortices out, one vortex in" at each vertex of $z3$ unit cell. The so-called degeneracy rules are explored by considering nearest-neighbor interaction. Thus, it is possible to realize a rich variety of ice-like vortex configurations in a large area of the sample. Moreover, there is little difference of the free energy and critical current density for the degenerate vortex states, which implies the existence of the degeneracy in the dice lattice.
1062	Scalable integration of periodically aligned 2D-MoS<sub>2</sub> nanoribbon array	Despite a recent growing interest in 2D-MoS<sub>2</sub> nanostructures for versatile platforms of sensor applications, robust and practical 2D-MoS<sub>2</sub> nanostructures have rarely been reported to date due to the absence of a facile, scalable and repeatable nanofabrication method.  Herein, we show the fabrication of periodically aligned 2D-MoS<sub>2</sub> nanoribbons (MNR) array with an area of 2.25 cm<sup>2</sup> via direct metal transfer (DMT). The MNR width is scalable from 463 nm to 135 nm at 650 nm pitch, and the smallest width is approximately 80 nm. The robust and stable material characteristics are confirmed via various spectroscopic analyses and application sensor devices.
1063	<strong>Self-induced birefringence of white-light continuum generated by interaction of focused femtosecond laser pulses with fused silica</strong>	White-light continuum can be induced by intense ultrashort laser pulses interaction with condensed materials. A self-induced birefringence of continuum was observed when focusing amplified femtosecond laser pulses into fused silica, an isotropic material in ordinary optical field. The self-induced birefringence of continuum shows a growth and saturation feature with the time evolution. The dependence of self-induced birefringence of continuum on the laser energy and the sample thickness was also investigated. A mechanism based on the formation of anisotropic nanostructures which modulate the transmission of the generated continuum explains well the experimental observation.
1064	Nanorods Structure Dependent Low Temperature and Low Concentration Hydrogen Sensing a Platform for Self Powered Sensing	The today&rsquo;s economy augmentation depends on fossil fuels. But fossil fuel is going to end in near future. Hydrogen can replace fossil fuels. Use of hydrogen as the fuel is risky because it is highly inflammable gas. For safe use of hydrogen, its detection up to few (1-10ppm) ppm and at low temperature (room temperature) is crucial. Last decades have seen tremendous advancement in sensor technology, but even today we have not a single sensor which can detect hydrogen with low ppm and at room temperature. The most interesting the nanorods was not decorated with any catalyst material like Pt, Pd, and Au.
1065	Tunable Anderson localization of propagating graphene surface plasmonmodes in a random modulated graphene monolayer	Graphene is a two-dimensional material that has attracted a lot of attention due to the excitation of surface<br />plasmons in the mid-infrared region. In this letter, we present the emergence of Anderson localization of propagating surface plasmon in a monolayer of graphene imbedded on a silicon Bragg-grating nanostructure. <br />In this proposed plasmonic structure a silica medium lays between the silicon substrate grating and a mono-layer of graphene. Introducing moderate randomness to the period of the grating leads to the trapping of the propagating surface plasmons in di&#xFB00;erent e&#xFB00;ective local cavities along the graphene sheet. Also, several new localized graphene surface plasmon (GSP) modes appear inside and outside the stopband of the propagating surface plasmons in a periodic substrate structure. The &#xFB01;eld intensity distribution and the quality factor of localized GSPs modes show an enhancement by a factor of 9 and 7 respectively respect to the corresponding intensity and quality factor in the periodic structure. Although controlling and tuning the values of the resonance wavelengths belonging to Anderson localized GSPs is a di&#xFB03;cult task due to its random nature, here we tune these wavelengths by using an external gate voltage to adjust the Fermi energy of the monolayer graphene.
1066	<strong>Controllable doping of graphene quantum dots by chlorine for </strong><strong>ultrahigh performance of photodetector</strong>	Graphene had attracted tremendous attention in a wide range of scientific fields. However, the absence of band-gap in the intrinsic graphene structure makes it unsuitable for optoelectronic applications. Thus opening and tailoring of a band gap in graphene for specific application is an important mission. Doping provides an effective pathway to open the band gap of graphene for electronic devices. Up to now, very few investigations on the band modulation of GQDs and their photovoltaic detectors have been reported. Herein, we report that chlorine-doped graphene quantum dots (Cl-GQDs) with the typical diameter of 3.3 nm have been prepared by a facile co-combustion method (T-X-J method) which can easily tune the doping concentration. Meanwhile, a nanocomposite of Cl-GQDs and ZnO QDs has been achieved by chemical route which was then used as the photo-active material. The photodetectors based on ZnO QDs/Cl-GQDs nanocomposite shows an excellent performance for light response from 365 to 650 nm, showing the important application value in optoelectronics.
1067	Time-Resolved and Multiple-Angle Thomson Scattering on Gas Puff Z-Pinch Plasmas	A 526.5 nm, Thomson scattering diagnostic laser enables probing of the plasma conditions of neon gas-puff z-pinch implosions with temporal resolution. Splitting the laser into two 2.5 J pulses, both 2.3 ns in duration and separated by 4 ns, allows observation of sub-nanosecond time-resolved spectra for a total  time of 7 ns. Collection optics are set at 90 degrees and 30 degrees to the laser, observing the same on-axis scattering volume with a radial extent of 0.4 mm. The spectra from both angles were collected by the same streak camera, using a coupling system that allows us to obtain temporal, spectral, and angular resolution in the same image. By comparing the spectra from the two angles, we determined electron temperature and a range of possible electron densities from the ion acoustic feature. Measurements made in the 1-3 ns period before pinch time show best fit (determined by a least-squares method) electron densities of around 2x10^19 cm^-3, increasing to 1.5x10^20 cm^-3 in the 3 ns following the start of the x-ray burst (t=0 ns) from the pinch. The electron temperature increases from 300 eV to 500 eV at t=0 ns before decreasing to below 300 eV after pinch time. With the present parameters (probe beam, collection angles, and electron temperature and density) this technique of electron density measurement proves to be too insensitive to provide precision.
1068	A design method for nanofluidic circuits	A design method was proposed for nanofluidic circuits, based on the flow equation for a nanoscale fluid flow. This method incorporates the use of the concepts of the flow resistance, the flow rate, the pressure drop and the power loss, as like in electric circuits. The equations for calculating the flow resistance and the power loss in exemplary nanofluidic circuits including in a nanotube tree are presented. It was found that the nanotube size and the fluid-tube wall interaction both have great influences on the flow resistance and the power loss in nanochannel flow. Exemplary design analysis was given for some nanofluidic circuits, based on the proposed method.
1069	Illumination impact on monolayer MoS<sub>2</sub> chemical sensor arrays	Molybdenum disulfide (MoS<sub>2</sub>) is a promising nanomaterial for chemical sensing due to its exceptional properties.  However, it is extremely sensitive to illumination and converts the energy of photons absorbed into photocurrent, which has hampered efforts to explore the sensing performance and underlying transduction mechanism of intrinsic MoS<sub>2</sub>.  Here we systematically explored the sensing behavior of intrinsic MoS<sub>2</sub> and the impact of illumination.  Without illumination, MoS<sub>2</sub> demonstrated record-high sensitivity reaching 1030 for pH change by 1 unit.  Its photoresponsivity (1300 A/W) can be tuned by ions in electrolyte.  Photon absorption not only substantially reduced the response of intrinsic MoS<sub>2</sub> by up to 95%, but also changed its sensing mechanism.  After revealing the remarkable sensing performance of intrinsic MoS<sub>2</sub>, we demonstrated the possibility of the integration of MoS<sub>2</sub> sensors functionalized with ionophore.  Multiplex trace detection of Na<sup>+</sup>, Hg<sup>2+</sup>, and Cd<sup>2+</sup> was realized on a 1 cm&times;1 cm chip with tunable sensitivity by illumination.  The ion sensing results demonstrated outstanding selectivity, detection limit (10 &mu;M), and response rate (10 s).  Our results show the prominent advantages of intrinsic MoS<sub>2</sub> as a chemical sensing material.
1070	Localized surface plasmon resonance property of bi-layer split ring-rods nanostructure	Metal nanostructures have been broadly applied in surface enhancement fluorescence, circular dichroism, filtering and many other aspects due to their unique optical properties. In this paper, a Bi-layer split ring-rods nanostructure is designed and the different responses of the nanostructure to the left-handed circularly polarized light and right-handed circularly polarized light are simulated by finite element method. The results show that this structure can produce operable circular dichroism and circular polarization filtering effect by adjusting the symmetry and the size of the structure. We illustrate this phenomenon by analyzing the resonance modes of the equivalent dipole between the upper and lower layers under the two excitation modes.
1071	Enhanced luminescence in Tb<sup>3+</sup> doped transparent germanate glass ceramic scintillators containing CaF<sub>2</sub> nanocrystals	Transparent Tb<sup>3+</sup> doped germanate glass ceramics containing CaF<sub>2</sub> nanocrystals were successfully prepared by melt quenching method with subsequent heat treatment.
