The synthesized MWCNTs and PEDOT: PSS nanocomposites were prepared and deposited by the spin coating method on flexible Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) polymer substrates. The thin films were characterized for their nanostructure and subsequently evaluated for their piezoresistive response. The applied pressure was changed from 0 to 130Pa at speed of 0.2 mm/min. The highest conductivity of the MWCNT-PEDOT: PSS thin film was observed for 0.1 wt% i.e. 13.5 S/m. The highest gauge factor of 22.8 for 0.1 wt% of MWCNTs in PEDOT: PSS matrix on the application of 6% strain was achieved. The fabricated thin film is suitable to develop the flexible electronic-skin, interactive wearable devices and touch screens in strain sensing applications.
1137	Millimeter Wave (220 GHz-330 GHz) Characterizations of Carbon Nanotube Films	A carbon nanotube (CNT) film on a substrate is characterized at millimeter waves (220 GHz&ndash;330 GHz) by metal rectangular waveguide scattering parameters (<em>S</em>-parameters) measurements. The anisotropy of the CNT film is investigated for different orientations of the on-substrate CNT film. The standard Nicolson&ndash;Ross&ndash;Weir (NRW) approach has been adopted to extract the complex permittivity (<em>&epsilon;</em><sub>r</sub>=<em>&epsilon;</em>&prime;-<em>j&epsilon;</em>&Prime;) and permeability (<em>&mu;</em><sub>r</sub>=<em>&mu;</em>&prime;-<em>j&mu;</em>&Prime;) of the on-substrate CNT film from the measured <em>S</em>-parameters. The effective medium theory is then applied to remove the impact of the substrate and characterize the intrinsic CNT film. The observed frequency independent and anisotropic behaviors of the CNT film are very promising indicators that this material could be invaluable for a range of millimeter-wave applications.
1138	<strong>Robust laser-structured asymmetrical PTFE mesh for underwater directional transportation and continuous collection of gas bubbles</strong>	We report a simple, efficient method to fabricate micro/nanoscale hierarchical structures on one side of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) mesh surfaces, using one-step femtosecond laser direct writing technology. The laser-treated surface exhibits superhydrophobicity in air and superaerophilicity in water, resulting in the mesh possesses the hydrophobic/superhydrophobic asymmetrical property. Bubbles can pass through the mesh from the untreated side to the laser-treated side, but cannot pass through the mesh in the opposite direction. The asymmetrical mesh can therefore be designed for the directional transportation and continuous collection of gas bubbles in aqueous environments. Furthermore, the asymmetrical mesh shows excellent stability during corrosion and abrasion tests. These findings may provide an efficient route for fabricating a durable asymmetrical mesh for the directional and continuous transport of gas bubbles.
1139	<strong>Effect of size and shape on the excitonic lasing process in ZnO microstructures</strong>	We investigate the emission properties of various ZnO microstructures with different size and shape in the temperature region from 3 to 300 K using a nanosecond pulsed laser as an excitation source. Room temperature stimulated emission is observed only from the sphere-like ZnO particles with size of a few micrometers. It is probable that individual particles serve as effective resonators with positive energy feedback. Temperature dependent measurements reveal that the mechanism of optical gain at temperatures below ~150 K is the exciton-exciton scattering, whereas at temperatures from ~150 K to room temperature the gain results from the exciton-electron scattering without any contribution from electron-hole plasma lasing. The observed temperature-induced transition between exciton-exciton and exciton-electron scattering is similar to the one reported recently for the micrometer-thick ZnO film [R. Matsuzaki <em>et al. </em>Phys. Rev. B 96, 125306 (2017).]. Thus, the excitonic lasing along with its temperature dependence is common in micrometer-sized ZnO crystals with appropriate optical feedback.
1140	<strong>Fabrication and characteristics of nano-bridge Josephson junctions based on Fe<sub>0.94</sub>Te<sub>0.45</sub>Se<sub>0.55</sub> thin film</strong>	In this paper we have fabricated the nano-bridge Josephson junction on Fe<sub>0.94</sub>Te<sub>0.45</sub>Se<sub>0.55 </sub>thin film by using a focused ion beam etching. We investigate the Josephson effect of this nano-bridge. The current&ndash;voltage characteristics of junction shows resistively and capacitatively shunted junction-like behaviors. The critical current is 16.1 mA at 4.2 K. The product of the critical current and normal state resistance (<em>I</em><sub>c</sub><em>R</em><sub>n</sub>) exhibits high value. The thermal conductance of the nano-bridge increases with the resistance value increasing, indicating enhancement of thermal transfer. The noise equivalent power value of the nanobridge is comparable to NbN bolometer, which is on the order of 10<sup>-12</sup>WHz<sup>-1/2</sup>. This nano-bridge has the potential for the bolometer device.
1141	Numerical simulation of Buongiorno's relation for 3D unsteady flow of Carreau fluid by considering magneto nanoparticles with variable properties	Nanofluids preserve notable consideration that have engrossed numerous examiners owing to their utilization in the arena of nanoscience and nanotechnology. A mathematical relation is established for 3D flow of a magneto-Carreau nanoliquid influenced by a bidirectional stretched surface in this exploration. To visualize the properties of Brownian motion and thermophoresis on the magneto-Carreau nanoliquid the Buongiorno's relation is exploited in a more proficient tactic. Variable thermal conductivity with the possessions of heat source/sink are pondered for heat transfer mechanisms. Suitable conversion is used to change the PDEs into non-linear ODEs. Numerically bvp4c scheme is prompted to crack the resulting ODEs. The discrete behaviors for shear-thinning/thickening of nanoliquid temperature and concentration field are described and deliberated in aspect for somatic parameters. It is exposed that the Carreau liquid temperature declines for advanced magnetic parameter M and conflicting trends is being noted for Brownian N_{b} and thermophoresis parameters N_{t}. Moreover, heat transfer amount diminish for higher Brownian N_{b} and thermophoresis parameters N_{t}. An assessment between two different approaches namely, bvp4c and homotopy analysis method (HAM) is also presented in tabular form in this scrutiny which spectacles that our outcomes is more precise.
1142	Phase transformations in the W-Cr system at the nanoscale	To enhance the thermal stability of nanomaterials, it is important to understand phase transformations at the nanoscale. In this study, the phase transformations in the W-Cr system were investigated using nanometallic multilayers to shift the kinetics of nucleation and increase the diffusivities of W and Cr. The multilayers were tailored to favor the formation of W rich solutions. In addition, the higher diffusivities made it possible to observe the nucleation of W<sub>3</sub>Cr. In this study, the use of nanometallic multilayers is proposed as an approach to modify the thermal evolution of nanocrystalline systems and study phase transformations at the nanoscale.
1143	Preface: Special Topic on Frontiers on THz Photonic Devices	THz photonic devices are now exploiting emerging materials systems, while novel device designs utilise plasmonic effects, nanophotinics and metamaterials. The scope of this special topic highlights and reviews the recent cutting-edge THz photonic devices, which have been revolutionised from the advances in the above research areas.
1144	Coagulation growth kinetics of nanoparticles in dynamic plasma	Coagulation growth kinetics of nanoparticles in plasma is affected by inter-particle electrostatic forces due to charging phenomenon. In stationary plasmas, unipolar charging of particles results in retardation of particles growth and may result in limitation on a particle size. We demonstrate opposite effect that is an enhancement of the particles growth in atmospheric pressure non-stationary arc discharge. Modeling of the growth kinetics revealed the formation of bipolar charge distribution of nanoparticles. As a result, Coulomb forces reversal from repulsive to attractive between nanoparticles promotes enhanced growth rates that allows to form micrometer size particles in a few millisecond time scale.
1145	Appearance of ferromagnetism property for Si nano-polycrystalline body and vanishing of electrical resistances at local high frequencies.	Reduction in the skin effect for the sintered Si nanopolycrystalline body as an electricity conductor at a high frequency due to its nano-structure was studied. Singular vanishing of electrical resistances near a local high magnetic harmonic frequency of a few MHz was observed. This phenomenon has not been observed for conventional ferromagnetic metals. The measured electrical resistances changed to almost 0 mohm at room temperature. At the same time, negative resistance of the sintered Si nano-polycrystalline body was observed. It will be applicable to electronic transmittance lines or semiconductors. Numerical calculation was also performed on the electrical resistance with frequency dependency while considering the electric field and magnetic field in the sintered Si nanopolycrystalline body. The calculation could explain the variation of the relative permittivity of the Si nanopolycrystalline and the phenomenon for vanishing the resistivity at frequency of MHz theoretically. Reduced Si nanoparticles from SiO<sub>2</sub> powder were synthesized by laser ablation in liquid. A Si nano-polycrystalline body made of the reduced Si nanoparticles was fabricated. It was found by measuring the magnetization property of the body that the sintered Si nano-polycrystalline body has ferromagnetism. High-density dangling bonds cause the sintered Si nanopolycrystalline to have ferromagnetism. The density of the unpaired electrons in the sintered Si nanopolycrystalline was also observed using ESR. It has been clarified that the Si nanopowder and the sintered Si nanopolycrystalline have numerous dangling bonds. Both densities of the dangling bonds were evaluated.
1146	Aptamer- based colorimetric determination of Pb2+ using a paper- based microfluidics platform	In this research, a novel paper-based microfluidic aptasensor was designed in order to detect different concentrations of lead in water. The principle based on which this aptasensor works is the interaction of gold nanoparticles with NaCl which leads to a color change from red to purple in the presence of lead ions due to the AuNPs aggregation. Furthermore, two types of filter paper, namely Whatman No.1 and nylon filters were used as the platform of this paper-based microfluidic assay, and the properties of each one was investigated. It was seen that Pb2+ can be detected with linear trends for the calibration of each paper type in concentrations within the 10 nM to 1 mM range in both Whatman No.1 and nylon filter papers. A detection limit of 1.2 nM and 0.7 nM was obtained for Whatman No.1 and nylon filter papers, respectively. Moreover, the Whatman No.1 filter paper was used for the detection in real water sample, which showed a good potential for the detection of Pb2+ in environmental samples.
1147	<strong>Solubility-induced highly crystalline regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) nanorods for field effect transistors</strong>	Manipulation of solubility may favorably impudence the crystallization and orientation of the macroscopic morphology in conducting polymer, which is directly associated to the performance of electronic devices. Here, we used combination of marginal solvent (dichloromethane) and ultrasonication to obtain highly crystalline, oriented and ordered nanorods morphology of regioregular poly (3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) for high performance organic field-effect transistors (OFETs). High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and grazing incidence X- ray diffraction (GIXD) demonstrated highly crystalline nature of spin coated film of P3HT on SiO<sub>2</sub> substrate. Macroscopically ordered and oriented nanorods morphology of P3HT is confirmed by atomic force microscopy (AFM), are used as channel material for OFETs with filed-effect mobility 0.05 cm<sup>2</sup>/Vs under ambient conditions. The calculated mobility is 50 fold higher that P3HT film prepared in good solvent (chloroform). The results are further supported by UV-Visible spectroscopy, cyclic volttammetry and theoretical calculation.
1148	<strong>Thermal Percolation in Composite Materials with Electrically Conductive Fillers</strong>	We measured the thermal conductivity and electrical conductivity in the organic/inorganic composites with Ag nanowires (NWs) embedded in the poly(vinylidene fluoride) matrix. High thermal and electrical conductivities are achieved to be  8.43 W/mk and 1.02x10<sup>6</sup> S/m , respectively, when the volume fraction of Ag NWs reaches 28.34% . Both measured electrical and thermal conductivity obey the universal power law commonly described in the percolation theory. The percolation behaviors of thermal and electrical conductivity are clearly observed when the volume fraction of Ag NWs is above the critical volume fraction (2.25%), due to the formation of percolation network. Further calculations on the Lorenz number as a function of Ag NWs volume fraction also confirms the percolation behaviors. The power-law exponent for the thermal percolation is slightly smaller than that for the electrical percolation, which is likely due to the &lsquo;dead-end&rsquo; structures that do not contribute to electrical percolations. To understand the effect of contact resistance between Ag NWs, we modeled the electron contribution to the electrical and thermal resistance at the contact with a simple potential barrier. The non-ideal contact between Ag NWs will cause the interfacial thermal resistance increase much more than the electrical contact resistance. The interfacial Lorenz number will decrease from the Sommerfeld value to a much lower value if the contact is non-ideal. Our work can shed some light on the thermal percolation in composite materials.
1149	<strong>The preparation of Co<sub>2</sub>FeAl@C core-shell nanoparticles with satisfied microstructure and magnetic properties</strong>	Co<sub>2</sub>FeAl@C nanoparticles were prepared by co-precipitation and annealed in a gas mixture. Firstly, the effects of annealing temperature on the structure and magnetic properties of Co<sub>2</sub>FeAl@C nanoparticles were studied. Secondly, the oxidation resistance of Co<sub>2</sub>FeAl@C nanoparticles was explored. When the annealing temperature was 400 <sup>o</sup>C, pure carbon-coated Co<sub>2</sub>FeAl alloy nanoparticles were prepared. With the increasing of annealing temperature, the crystallized degree, grain size and saturation magnetization of Co<sub>2</sub>FeAl@C nanoparticles increased gradually. When the annealing temperature was 800 <sup>o</sup>C, the saturation magnetization of Co<sub>2</sub>FeAl@C nanoparticles reached a maximum value (149.6 emu/g). These Co<sub>2</sub>FeAl@C nanoparticles with good oxidation resistance have great potential in some industrial fields.
1150	Janus nanostructures for heterogeneous photocatalysis	Water treatment, the hydrogen evolution reaction and carbon capture are examples of the potential applications for solar photocatalysis. This has led to significant effort in the search for suitable heterogeneous catalysts. However, materials developed to-date often suffer from disadvantages such as charge recombination, low quantum efficiency, chemical instability and poor economy of production/operation. These factors have made it difficult for the technology to develop beyond laboratory demonstrations. A potential solution to the problem lies with the appropriate design of the catalyst itself, particularly with respect to particle morphology. This review aims to highlight recent efforts directed towards the development and application of an anisotropic, bi-phasic heterodimer, or 'Janus' catalyst. While the topic is in its relative infancy, it has been shown that a Janus morphology can improve catalyst performance by almost an order of magnitude. Hence, a systematic review has been undertaken to highlight and assess recent advances in this field. The review begins with the fundamentals of heterogeneous photocatalysis and proceeds to classify modern catalysts, including Janus particles. This is followed by a detailed description of the relevant studies involving Janus morphology and their demonstrated photocatalytic applications. Finally, an overview of the current challenges and future prospects is discussed along with a summary of the key highlights. It is observed that a Janus morphology can impart several intriguing advantages such as amplification of electric near-field and efficient charge separation. In order to unlock the full potential of Janus photocatalyst, further research in this direction is warranted.
1151	Investigation on the Silver Nanowire/Graphene Transparent Electrode in Electrochromic Device	In this work, we fabricated a flexible silver nanowires (Ag NWs)/graphene transparent conducting film on polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrate, which was applied in an electrochromic device. The graphene layer was coated on the surface of the Ag NW film utilizing the electrostatic adsorption in order to improve the stability of the metallic nanowire layer and the performance of the electrochromic device. The Ag NW/graphene composite film exhibited an optical transmittance of 82.5% at 550 nm and a sheet resistance of 57.5 &#x03A9;/sq. With the concentration of the adsorbed graphene sheets increased, the transmittance and conductivity of the composite film both decreased. Furthermore, the lifetime of the electrochromic devices based on the tungsten oxide (WO3) thin film and the Ag NW/graphene composite electrodes was greatly extended, compared to that utilizing the pristine Ag NW electrodes. The results indicate that the introduction of the graphene layer could protect the Ag NW film from corrosion of the electrolyte layer, and greatly improve the lifetime and cycle numbers of the electrochromic device.
1152	Nonlinear frequency conversion in one dimensional lithium niobate photonic crystal nanocavities	We demonstrate flexible nonlinear frequency up-conversion in high-Q lithium niobate photonic crystal nanobeam resonators. The high optical Q together with strong optical mode confinement allow us to observe clear second harmonic generation and sum frequency generation with an optical power around only tens of microWatts. These demonstrations show that high-Q lithium niobate photonic crystal nanoresonators are of great promise for nonlinear photonic applications.
1153	<strong>Analytical study of electronic conductance in a lengthy armchair graphene nanoribbon including vacancies, defects or impurities</strong>	<SPAN style="font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">In this paper, we present an analytic method to study the electronic (magneto-) conductance of a lengthy armchair graphene nanoribbon with a definite width in the presence of some vacancies, defects, impurities or in a small part of it. For this purpose, we employ the Green's function technique within the nearest neighbor tight-binging approach. We first convert the Hamiltonian of an ideal semi-infinite nanoribbon to the Hamiltonian of some independent polyacetylene-like chains. Then, we derive an exact formula for self-energy of perturbed part due to the existence of ideal parts in the nanoribbon. The method gives fully analytically formulation for some cases such as infinite ideal nanoribbon or the one including linear symmetric defects. We calculate transmission coefficient for some different configurations of a nanoribbon with special width including a vacancy, edge geometrical defects and two impurities. An example for a fully analytically solvable case for symmetric linear defect is presented. Finally, the method is used for a nanoribbon including a vacancy when a region around the vacancy is put in a uniform magnetic field.</SPAN>
1154	<strong>Bandgap properties of piezoelectric phononic crystal nanobeam with surface effect</strong>	This paper extends the traditional plane wave expansion (PWE) method to calculate the band structure of proposed piezoelectric phononic crystal (PC) nanobeam with surface effect. The first four orders are chosen to investigate the influence rules of electric field, surface effect and geometric parameters on band gaps. Applied external electric voltage is chosen as the influencing parameter of electric field. Residual surface stress and material intrinsic length are chosen as the influencing parameters of surface effect. Lengths of material PZT-5H and material epoxy in a unit cell, width and thickness of PC nanobeam are picked as the influencing geometric parameters. All the results are expected to be of helpful for the design of piezoelectric nanobeam-based devices.
1155	<strong>Bunching and antibunching in four wave mixing NV center in diamond</strong>	The determination of classical and quantum states through photon bunching and anti-bunching like phenomena may have potential applications in quantum information processing and long-distance quantum communications. We report the photon bunching and multi anti-bunching like phenomena by generating multi-order fluorescence and four wave mixing (FWM) at room temperature using the Nitrogen-vacancy (NV) center in diamond. We have implied four-wave mixing (FWM) process to demonstrate the interference pattern emerging from NV of nano-crystals in both classical, non classical and intermediate(classical and non classical) regimes. Intersystem crossing is controlled by the power of incident beams. The interference pattern from dominant ionization of NV<sup>-</sup> to NV<sup>o</sup> and NV<sup>o</sup> to NV<sup>-</sup> suggests the bunching and anti-bunching like phenomena of photons.
1156	<strong>Thermal conductivity of Si nanowires with &delta;-modulated dopant distribution by self-heated 3&omega; method and its length dependence</strong>	Dopant engineering has been generally adopted to tune the electrical properties of nanostructured materials, whereas their impact to the thermal transport in nanodevices is yet unresolved. Here, we report the thermal conductivity measurement of B-doped Si nanowires with &delta; dopant modulation on the surface using the self-heated 3&omega; method, which resembles the thermal dissipation in operating electronic devices. The thermal conductivity for &delta;-modulated Si nanowire of 45 nm diameter (~23 W/mK) is found to agree well with that of non-doped Si nanowires reported previously, which is attributed to the dominant surface boundary scattering and the highly confined dopant distribution at surface. Further, through a length dependent study of the thermal conductivity (&kappa;) from 400 nm to 4 &micro;m, we found an apparent length dependence of &kappa; at L&lt;2 &micro;m. The phenomenon could not be simply interpreted by solely considering the ballistic effect in thermal transport, but can be accounted by including the additional resistive processes that are associated with the thermalization of joule-heating emitted phonons, which opts in to suppress the thermal conductivity of nano-systems under the ballistic thermal transport regime.
1157	<strong>The temperature-insensitive and significant magnetoresistance observed in Co-doped (La<sub>0.7</sub>Sr<sub>0.3</sub>)MnO<sub>3</sub> with relaxor-like magnetic state</strong>	Ferroelectric relaxor is a type of functional materials that can display temperature-insensitive dielectric constants within a large temperature window, which origins from the sluggish relaxation of nanometer-scale ferroelectric domains. Inspired by this ideal, we intentionally doped different amounts (0.025-0.1) of paramagnetic/low-spin Co<sup>3+</sup>/Co<sup>2+</sup>species into epitaxial (La<sub>0.7</sub>Sr<sub>0.3</sub>)MnO<sub>3</sub> thin films. The evolution of electrical, magnetic, magneto-transport, and valence state of this series of Co-doped (La<sub>0.7</sub>Sr<sub>0.3</sub>)MnO<sub>3</sub> have been systematically characterized. Remarkably, the magnetoresistance in 0.1Co-doped (La<sub>0.7</sub>Sr<sub>0.3</sub>)MnO<sub>3 </sub>can reach 35% within an extremely large temperature window (from 40 to 200 K). Other Co-doped epitaxial (La<sub>0.7</sub>Sr<sub>0.3</sub>)MnO<sub>3</sub> thin films show similar sharp MR-peaks around Curie temperature as that in (La<sub>0.7</sub>Sr<sub>0.3</sub>)MnO<sub>3</sub> matrix. The temperature-insensitive MR of 0.1Co-doped (La<sub>0.7</sub>Sr<sub>0.3</sub>)MnO<sub>3</sub> may be attributed to relaxor-like magnetic state. Our work demonstrates the engineering of artificial relax-like ferromagnet is an effective way to optimize magneto-resistivity of manganites.
1158	Strain Tunable Phononic Topological Bandgaps in Two-Dimensional Hexagonal Boron Nitride	The field of topological mechanics has recently emerged due to the interest in robustly transporting various types of energy in a flaw and defect-insensitive fashion.  While there have been a significant number of studies based on discovering and proposing topological materials and structures, very few have focused on tuning the resulting topological bandgaps, which is critical because the bandgap frequency is fixed once the structure has been fabricated.  Here, we perform both lattice dynamical calculations and molecular dynamical simulations to investigate strain effects on the phononic topological bandgaps in two-dimensional monolayer hexagonal boron nitride.  Our studies demonstrate that while the topologically protected phononic bandgaps are not closed even for severely deformed hexagonal boron nitride, and are relatively insensitive to uniaxial tension and shear strains, the position of the frequency gap can be efficiently tuned in a wide range through the application of biaxial strains.  Our findings shed light on the tunability of the topological bandgaps in nanomaterials.
1159	Plasmon-induced enhancement of efficiency of solar cells modified by metallic nano-particles: material dependence	We analyze the material dependence of the near-field coupling to band electrons of surface plazmons in metallic nanoparticles deposited on the top of a semiconductor substrate in nano-modified solar cells. Various materials for metal and substrate are considered for comparison upon the Fermi Golden Rule approach to theoretical modeling of plasmon-electron coupling. <br />The material dependence of the plasmon effect in two types of solar cells, multi-crystalline Si and CIGS (copper-indium-gallium-diselenide), modified by various metallic nano-particles is illustrated by experimental data.
1160	<strong>Characteristic oscillation phenomenon after head-on collision of two nanofluid droplets</strong>	One falling liquid droplet impacting with a sessile droplet and then undergoing oscillation is a common phenomenon in both nature and industry. However, to our best knowledge, the head-on collision of two nanofluid drops has not been studied when both the nanoparticle and surfactant exist in the drop. In this work, the characteristics of oscillation after head-on collision of two TiO<sub>2</sub>-water nanofluids drops were investigated experimentally. The effects of impact velocity, drop size and nanoparticle concentration have been considered to understand how they influence the drop spreading, recoiling and rebounding. For the influence of drop size, it shows that in 0% and 0.001% of nanoparticle concentrations, the relative spreading radius of small drop size is higher than that with large size, while it is reverse in 0.01% and 0.1% of nanoparticle mass fractions. Interestingly, it was found that there is an optimal nanoparticles mass fraction of 0.1% for nanofluid droplet where the oscillation head-on collision can be damped much more rapidly than that for nanoparticle-free droplet. A hypothesis considering comprehensive interaction of surfactant redistribution, surfactant gradient and particle initial effect was proposed to explain the observed phenomenon. This work will be of significant reference to various practical applications especially when the drop collision oscillation characteristics are supposed to be under control.
1161	Tailoring spin qubit in a nitrogen-vacancy by a breathing magnetic skyrmion	Spin qubit in a nitrogen-vacancy (NV) of a diamond is a promising integrant of quantum computing for its room temperature stability and long coherent time while magnetic skyrmion is an emerging focus in spintronics for its smaller size and easy tunability as binary information carriers. Here we bridge these two fields and demonstrate that a breathing skyrmion can coherently control the spin qubits in a NV center via dipolar interaction. The typical Rabi oscillation of the spin qubit is identified and the influence of detuning from the resonance frequency is discussed. Our finding provides an alternative route to manipulate quantum qubits with low power consumption and high precession in the nanoscale.
1162	Thickness dependence of superconductivity in single-crystal Ta<sub>4</sub>Pd<sub>3</sub>Te<sub>16</sub> nanoribbons	We present the thickness-dependent electrical properties of mechanically exfoliated single crystal Ta<sub>4</sub>Pd<sub>3</sub>Te<sub>16</sub> nanoribbons. By decreasing the nanoribbon thickness in the range of 500-20 nm, we observed a suppression of superconductivity driven by both the thickness and external magnetic field. In particular, for the thinner nanoribbons with thickness less than 40 nm, there is a non-zero resistance state extending down to low temperature, followed by the loss of superconductivity when the thickness is decreased to the order of coherence length. We found that the theory of thermally activated phase slip can well describe the temperature dependence of the resistance below T<sub>c</sub>. And the disorder-induced enhanced Coulomb interaction with the decrease of thickness is expected to be dominant in the gradual crossover behavior from superconducting to normal or very weakly insulating behavior in the low-dimensional system.
1163	<strong>Micro/nano structures on the surface of titanium by one-step nanosecond laser irradiation without focusing</strong>	This paper represents the method of the one-step nanosecond laser irradiation without focusing to fabricate micro/nano structures on the surface of titanium. The microstructure is formed via the crack growth behavior of titanium, and the nanostructure is formed due to the interference of the laser beam on the surface with certain roughness. With desired parameters, the micro/nano structures show good anti-reflectivity, where the reflectivity is about 10% in the spectrum from 800 to 1800 nm.
1164	Ferromagnetic resonance force microscopy of individual domain wall	We report on ferromagnetic resonance force microscopy (FMRFM) based investigations of the ferromagnetic resonance of a single domain wall (DW) in a V-shaped planar permalloy nanowire (NW) which is bent by 60&deg;. A pronounced resonance associated with the DW is observed at 1.6 GHz. FMRFM imaging at the resonance frequency confirms the localization of the resonant mode in the DW area. The measured spectra and spatial distribution of the resonant signal are in a good agreement with the results of micromagnetic modeling.
1165	A Walnut Inspired Silicon Carbon Composites As Stable Lithium Ions Battery Anodes	The distinct quality of silicon (Si) makes it a natural choice for use as an anode material in rechargeable high-performance lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) for practical applications. Herein, the Si nanoparticles coated predigest by few-layer graphene (Gra) has been well wrapped into a 3D honeycomb porous carbon (Pc) framework with excellent Si-C tectonism contact and open void by a simple freeze drying strategy assisted with the atmospheric chemical vapor deposition. The walnut type structured Si@Gra@Pc with porous architecture can shorten the ions transfer distance and provide high electrical conductivity for fast ions and electrons transport. The novel 3D structure allows the free expansion of Si during long cycling while preserving stable structural integrity owing to the brawny mechanical strength of Gra and 3D Pc framework. More significantly, it is found that the Si@Gra@Pc composites show excellent rate capability and cycling stability companying no obvious capacity decay even after 1000 cycles at a current density of 1C (1C=3500 mA g-1). The present walnut structured Si@Gra@Pc composites are one of stable Si-based anode materials and an important candidate in the development of next-generation advanced LIBs.
1166	Numerical Simulation of Magnetic Drug Targeting to the Stenosis Vessel Using Fe3O4 Magnetic Nanoparticles Under the E&#xFB00;ect of Magnetic Field of wire	In the present paper, the magnetic drug targeting (MDT) using drug coated Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles to the stenosis region of the vessel was investigated. The Reynolds number was considered to be 100. The problem was solved for various magnetic numbers. Moreover, the e&#xFB00;ect of the location of the wire, as a magnetic source, on the MDT was studied. The governing equations of continuity, momentum and volume fraction were solved by taking into account the e&#xFB00;ects of Kelvin force and Magnetophoresis. Finite volume method is used for discretization of unsteady two-phase &#xFB02;ow equations. Two main phenomena of drug droplet formation as a positive factor and vortices generation were observed as a negative factor in MDT. The results showed that in a speci&#xFB01;c magnetic number, the MDT function could be<br />optimal. Furthermore, if the wire is located in the upstream region of the stenosis, it will have a small positive e&#xFB00;ect on the concentration of the drug in the target tissue.
1167	<strong>Facile microwave oven synthesis and spectroscopic investigation of ceria:graphene nanocomposites: band gap widening and luminescence quenching</strong>	In this work, we discussed about the synthesis and optical properties of pure ceria (nanospheres) and ceria:graphene nanocomposites (nanorice like morphology) by using commercial microwave oven as a cost effective and environmental friendly approach. The influence of graphene on the crystallinity, morphology, band gap energy and luminescence of the synthesized samples was discussed. The average crystallite size obtained by using <em>Scherrer</em> formula of the CeO<sub>2</sub> nanostructures showed a decreasing trend with increasing the graphene loading. The higher graphene loaded ceria clearly depicted the morphology of nanorice like in shape with the diameter below 10 nm and the length over below 50 nm.  The presence of graphene and ceria related vibrational modes (100-4000 cm<sup>-1</sup>) confirmed the successful formation of nanocomposites. The observed increase in band gap (blue shift) with the loading amount of graphene was discussed. Further, the luminescence related to various <em>F</em>-centers and its quenching in the nanocomposites was discussed.
1168	<strong>Study on Thermal Conductivities of Si Thin Films and Porous Si</strong><strong>Structures Based on a New Lattice Boltzmann Method</strong>	In this work, a new type of lattice Boltzmann method (LBM) is developed to predict the thermal conductivity of silicon thin films and porous silicon structures, in which model a probability parameter is introduced to determine whether a phonon collision event happens at a specific lattice point. The thickness-dependent silicon-thin-film thermal conductivities calculated using this method show good agreement with prior experimental and simulation results. We also use this approach to study the porosity and pore-size dependence of the thermal conductivity of porous silicon structures. Furthermore, the computed porous silicon thermal conductivities are found to agree well with previously reported data. The new algorithm offers substantial computational improvement as compared to existing LBM models and enables us to understand the thermal transport in various structures of interest at the nanoscale.
1169	Structure transformation by sp2 hydrocarbon assisted carbon nanotube growth	In this study, we investigated the effect of hydrocarbon species composition on carbon nanotube (CNT) growth using an iron catalyst by the chemical vapor deposition. The atomic hydrogen and active carbon species from hydrocarbon affect to the nucleation and growth of CNT arrays. With increasing in atomic hydrogen content, the interface layer distance of the CNTs decreased from 3.7 to 3.4 &#x00C5;. The shifts in the G-band in the Raman spectra of the CNTs indicated that the hydrogen atoms affected the generation of C-C bonds in graphene layers.
1170	<strong>A distributed electrical model for superconducting nanowire single photon detectors</strong>	To analyze the switching dynamics and output performance of a superconducting nanowire single photon detector (SNSPD), the nanowire is usually modelled as an inductor in series with a time-varying resistor induced by absorption of a photon. Our recent experimental results show that, due to the effect of kinetic inductance, for a SNSPD made of a nanowire of sufficient length, its geometry length can be comparable to or even longer than the effective wavelength of frequencies contained in the output pulse. In other words, a superconducting nanowire can behave as a distributed transmission line so that the readout pulse depends on the photon detection location and the transmission line properties of the nanowire. Here, we develop a distributed model for a superconducting nanowire and apply it to simulate the output performance of a long nanowire designed into a coplanar waveguide. We compare this coplanar waveguide geometry to a conventional meander nanowire geometry. The simulation results agree well with our experimental observations. With this distributed model, we discussed the importance of microwave design of a nanowire and how impedance matching can affect the output pulse shape. We also discuss how the distributed model affects the growth and decay of the photon-triggered resistive hotspot.
1171	Tunable mechanical and electrical properties of high density polyethylene / multi-walled carbon nanotube nanocomposites determined by a novel rheological approach	Fast and efficient determination of the optimal mechanical properties and prediction of the conductive percolation regions of a polymer/CNT nanocomposite is crucial to develop conductive nanocomposites. This work established a novel rheological approach to evaluate the tunable mechanical and electrical properties of high density polyethylene (HDPE) / multi-walled carbon nanotube (MWCNT) nanocomposites with and without compatibilizer. Results illustrate that three types of nanocomposites exhibit obvious gel plateau in the dynamic rheological curves and the gel points of nanocomposites with compatibilizer shift to the low MWCNTs loading. The gel point of HDPE/MWCNT nanocomposites are correlated with the conductive threshold but not with the super-toughness points of these composites. However, the super-toughness points of HDPE/MWCNT nanocomposites with compatibilizer show the correspondence with the gel points acquired from the rheological data and the gel points are located in the conductive percolation regions, indicating that the dynamic rheology is an effective way to determine the super-toughness points and predict the conductive percolation regions of HDPE/MWCNT nanocomposites with compatibilizer. Furthermore, unique network structure at the gel points is directly observed and the new mechanism of toughness is proposed. This study provides new insights and approach towards effective control of the structures and properties for compound design of polymer/CNT nanocomposites.
1172	<strong>Photoresponse of Nonvolatile Resistive Memory Device</strong><strong> Based on All-Inorganic Perovskite CsPbBr<sub>3</sub> Nanocrystals </strong>	<strong> </strong>In this work, the resistive memory devices were fabricated based on CsPbBr<sub>3 </sub>nanocrystals (NCs) embedded into the insulating polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) with a configuration of Au/PMMA/PMMA:CsPbBr<sub>3 </sub>NCs/PMMA/indium doped tin-oxide (ITO). The devices exhibit nonvolatile multi-level resistive switching and show the distinct photoresponse in different high resistance states (HRS). In HRS with low current, the devices witness the prompt photoresponse under irradiation. And the resistive switching behaviors in another HRS, especially switching voltages, can be affected by the ultraviolet irradiation. Combined with the energy band evolution, the resistive switching and photoresponse of Au/PMMA/PMMA:CsPbBr<sub>3 </sub>NCs/PMMA/ITO devices were elucidated by considering the photosensitive property and role of trapping/de-trapping centers of CsPbBr<sub>3</sub> NCs.
1173	Reversible and magnetically unassisted voltage-driven switching of the magnetization in FeRh/PMN-PT	Minimizing power consumption in spintronic devices requires sizeable and reversible control of magnetization by electric fields without being assisted by subsidiary magnetic field or electric current. Upon increasing temperature, FeRh displays an uncommon antiferromagnetic to ferromagnetic phase transition linked to a unit cell volume expansion. Thus, using the strain exerted by an adjacent piezoelectric layer, the relative amount of antiferromagnetic and ferromagnetic regions can be tuned by electric field applied to the piezoelectric material. Indeed, large variation of the saturation magnetization by electric field application have been observed in FeRh films grown on piezoelectric substrates. In view of applications, the variations of the remanent magnetization rather than those of saturation magnetization are most relevant. Here, we show that even in absence of any bias external magnetic field, permanent and reversible magnetization changes as large as 34% can be induced by electric field, which remain after zeroing it. Bulk and local magnetoelectric characterization reveal that the ultimate reason for the observed large magnetoelectric response at remanence is the expansion (rather than the nucleation) of new ferromagnetic nanoregions and that the most efficient magnetic reversal is achieved at ferroelectric domain walls, where local 180<sup>o</sup> switching is observed.
1174	Connectedness percolation of hard convex polygonal rods and platelets	The properties of polymer composites with nanofiller particles change drastically above a critical filler density known as the percolation threshold. Real nanofillers, such as graphene flakes and cellulose nanocrystals, are not idealized disks and rods but are often modeled as such. Here we investigate the effect of the shape of the particle cross section on the geometric percolation threshold. Using connectedness percolation theory and the second-virial approximation, we analytically calculate the percolation threshold of hard convex particles in terms of three single-particle measures. We apply this method to polygonal rods and platelets and find that the universal scaling of the percolation threshold is lowered by decreasing the number of sides of the particle cross section. This is caused by the increase of the surface area to volume ratio with decreasing number of sides.
1175	A theoretical study of the size- and edge-effect cohesive energy and shear strength between graphene, carbon nanotubes and nanofibers	Explicit expressions for the size- and edge-effect cohesive energy and shear stress between two finite-sized graphene (graphene/graphene), two finite-sized carbon nanotubes (CNTs) (CNT/CNT) and two finite-sized nanofibers (nanofiber/nanofiber) are obtained through continuum modeling of van der Waals (vdW) interactions between them. The close-form solutions of the cohesive energy and shear stress between these structures at different positions are derived by using Gaussian quadrature. The analytical results of the edge-effect cohesive energy show that both of the maximum repulsive and attractive shear stresses are always close to the initial intersecting positions between them. Checking against present molecular dynamics (MD) calculations and available experimental results shows that the continuum solutions are reasonable, in which the main reason of their difference is also revealed in detail. The obtained analytical solutions should be of great help for understanding the size- and edge-effect interactions between these nanostructures and designing nanoelectronic devices.
1176	Monte Carlo Simulation of Cylinders with Short-Range Attractions	Cylindrical or rod-like particles are promising materials for the applications of fillers in nanocomposite materials and additives to control rheological properties of colloidal suspensions. Recent advances in particle synthesis allows for cylinders to be manufactured with short-ranged attractions to study the gelation as a function of packing fraction, aspect ratio and temperature. In order to aid in the analysis of small-angle scattering experiments of rod-like particles, computer simulation methods were used to model these particles with specialized Monte Carlo algorithms and optimized superquadric potentials. The attractive interaction between neighboring rods increases with the amount of locally-accessible surface area, thus leading to patchy-like interactions. We find that the cylinders form homogenous fluids, clusters, gels or glasses as a function of the attraction strength, volume fraction and aspect ratio. Computer simulations are used to predict the conditions at which the above phases are observed. Comparisons with the experimental scattering results are also presented, which are in agreement.
1177	<strong>Spin readout via spin-to-charge conversion in bulk diamond nitrogen-vacancy ensembles</strong>	We demonstrate optical readout of ensembles of NV center spins in a bulk diamond sample via spin-to-charge conversion. A high power 594 nm laser is utilized to selectively ionize the paramagnetic defects in the <em>m</em><sub>S</sub>=0<sub> </sub>spin state with a contrast of up to 12%. In comparison with the conventional 520 nm spin readout, spin-to-charge-conversion-based readout provides higher signal-to-noise ratio, with tenfold sensing measurement speedup for millisecond long pulse sequences. This level of performance was achieved for an NV<sup>-</sup> ionization of only 25%, limited by the ionization and readout laser powers. These observations pave the way to fast, high-sensitivity nanoscale sensing with ensembles of coherent NV center spins in bulk diamond.
1178	Spin wave modes of two magnetostatic coupled spin transfer torque nano-oscillators	A detailed analytical and numerical study of the spin wave modes  of two nanopillar spin torque nano-oscillators coupled by magnetostatic interactions, is presented under the macrospin approximation. Results show that the normal modes of the system oscillate with the magnetizations in-phase or anti-phase in both disks. The frequencies  and critical current densities necessary to induce auto-oscillations of the spin wave modes of the coupled system depend on the relative position of the nanopillars and the applied magnetic field.  If the oscillators are identical, these modes are degenerate at a certain relative position of the nanopillars, while if the oscillators are non-identical such degeneracy is removed. Then, we can conclude that the magnetostatic coupling between two spin transfer torque nano-oscillators is a powerful mechanism to control the spin wave modes of this system.
1179	In-situ tuning of individual position-controlled nanowire quantum dots vialaser-induced intermixing	We demonstrate an in-situ technique to tune the emission energy of semiconductor quantum dots. The technique is based on laser-induced atomic intermixing applied to nanowire quantum dots grown using a site-selective process that allows for the deterministic tuning of individual emitters. A tuning range of up to 15meV is obtained with a precision limited by the laser exposure time. A distinct saturation of the energy shift is observed, which suggests an intermixing mechanism relying on grown-in defects that are subsequently removed from the semiconductor material during annealing. The ability to tune different emitters into resonance with each other will be required for fabricating remote quantum dot-based sources of  indistinguishable photons for secure quantum networks.
1180	<strong>Two-dimensional (2D) few-layers WS<sub>2</sub> nanosheets: an ideal nanomaterials with tunable electromagnetic absorption performance<sup> </sup></strong>	In this study, few-layers (FL) WS<sub>2</sub> nanosheets were fabricated through liquid phase exfoliation, and the dielectric and electromagnetic absorption (EA) properties were first reported. The results show that a composite consisting of 30 wt% FL-WS<sub>2</sub> exhibited an effective EA bandwidth  of 4.6 GHz at a thickness of 2.5 mm. Meanwhile, the strongest absorption point (RL<sub>str</sub>) can reach &minus;63.0 dB. The most noteworthy is that FL-WS<sub>2 </sub>based composite can completely absorb the electromagnetic energy from X (8-12 GHz) and Ku (12-18 GHz) band. These results indicate that FL-WS<sub>2</sub> has practical application against electromagnetic pollution in the future.
1181	Controlling the electrical conductive network formation in nanorod filled polymer nanocomposites by tuning nanorod stiffness	In this work, by employing a coarse-grained molecular dynamics simulation, we have investigated the effect of the nanorod (NR) stiffness on the relationship between the NR microstructure and the conductive probability of NR filled polymer nanocomposites (PNCs) under the quiescent state and under the shear field. The conductive probability of PNCs is gradually enhanced with the increase of NR stiffness in the quiescent state; however, it first increases and then decreases under the shear field. Under the shear field, the largest conductive probability appears at the moderate NR stiffness, which results from the competition between the improved effective aspect ratio of NR and the breakage of the conductive network. Meanwhile, compared with in the quiescent state, under the shear field the decrease or the increase of the conductive probability depends on the NR stiffness. At low NR stiffness, the increase of the effective aspect ratio of NR enhances the conductive probability. While at high NR stiffness, the breakage of the conductive network reduces the conductive probability. For flexible NRs, the conductive probability first increases and then decreases with increasing the shear rate. The maximum effective aspect ratio of NRs appears at the moderate shear rate, which is consistent with the conductive probability. In summary, this work presents some further understanding how NR stiffness affects the electric conductive property of PNCs under the shear field.
1182	<strong>Oxygen desorption kinetics of ZnO nanorod&ndash;gated AlGaN/GaN HEMT-based UV photodetectors</strong>	This study investigated the effect of gate length and surface area of the ZnO ultraviolet (UV) absorbing structure on the transient characteristics of AlGaN/GaN HEMT based UV photodetectors. The gate-areas of AlGaN/GaN HEMTs with 2, 6 and 18 &mu;m lengths with same width of 100 &mu;m were covered with ZnO thin film and nanorods (NR). The fabricated devices show enhancement in response speed with the reduction of gate length or the increase of ZnO surface area. The best response speed of ~10 ms response time and ~190 ms recovery time is measured from the NR-gated device with a gate length of 2 &mu;m. A model for the oxygen desorption kinetics is proposed for the first time which theoretically shows that that the response speed is dependent on two key parameters; light absorbing surface area and gate length. From our model analysis, it is shown that predicted response time is a strong function of these two device parameters, and the calculations show a good agreement with the experimental measurements.
1183	Origin of the Elinvar Anomaly in Fe-Ni-Cr Alloy: Strain Glass Transition	We report experimental evidences of a strain glass transition in a commercial Elinvar alloy Ni-Span C, such as frequency dispersion of storage modulus, continuous formation of ferromagnetic BCT structured nanodomains of martensite. Accompanying such a transition, the gradual modulus softening of austenite compensates the smooth modulus hardening due to the vibrational anharmonicity of nanodomains, leading to the temperature-independent elastic modulus over a broad temperature range. Our findings provide new insights into the origin of Elinvar anomaly in Fe-Ni based alloys, and shed light on the research and development of novel Elinvar materials with the principle of strain glass transition.
1184	<strong>Picosecond x-ray radiography of microjets expanding from laser shock-loaded grooves</strong>	Material ejection upon the breakout of a shock wave at a rough surface is a key safety issue for various applications, including pyrotechnics and inertial confinement fusion. For a few years, we have used laser driven compression to investigate microjetting from calibrated grooves in the free surface of shock-loaded specimens. Fast transverse optical shadowgraphy, time-resolved measurements of planar surface and jet tip velocities, and post-shock analysis of some recovered material have provided data over ranges of small spatial and temporal scales, short loading pulses (ns-order) and extremely high strain rates. In the new experiment reported here, picosecond laser irradiation of a thin copper wire generates an ultrashort x-ray burst which is used to radiograph the microjets expanding from plane wedged-shape grooves in tin and copper samples shock-loaded by a longer, nanosecond laser pulse. Such ultrafast radiography provides estimates of the density gradients along the jets and of the total ejected mass at different times after shock breakout. Furthermore, it reveals regions of low density inside the samples deep beneath the grooves, associated to damage due to tension induced by the interaction of rarefaction waves. Thus, combining this x-ray probe with our former experimental techniques provides a more complete insight into the physics of microjetting at very high loading rates and the ballistic properties of the resulting ejecta.
1185	<strong>Nano-scaled Transistor&rsquo;s Performance and Reliability Characterization at Nano-second Regime</strong>	In this work, we developed a novel sub-ns measurement method for reliability behavior characterization of nano-scaled transistors. The experimental results show that, due to the severe self-heating effect (SHE) and interfacial defect trapping in the device, the I-V measurement speed could significantly affect the characterization results of the nanoscale transistor including its threshold voltage shift (<em>V</em><sub>TH</sub>) and saturation drive current (<em>I</em><sub>DSAT</sub>) degradation. Due to the inevitable SHE and interfacial defect in the transistor channel caused by the long measurement time, the <em>V</em><sub>TH</sub> shift and <em>I</em><sub>DSAT</sub> degradation would be misestimated, leading to an overestimation of the HCI and PBTI lifetime.
1186	Atmospheric discharge plasma chemistry in aqueous solution: Importance of the generation of water vapor bubbles for the plasma onset and its evolution	Discharge plasma formed in aqueous solution has attracted much attention for the application to environmental purification and material syntheses. Discharge in water under atmospheric pressure produces abundant hydroxyl and hydrogen radicals, acting as a strong oxidizing and reducing species, respectively. Here, the onset and the evolution of discharge plasma and those transient reactive species in the aqueous solution are successfully monitored with micrometer spatial resolution and nanosecond temporal one. Combination of custom-made microscopic discharge system and high-speed camera provides direct evidence that the preceding formation of the water vapor bubble by the thermal phase transition at the tip of the electrode and its connection to the other one play crucial roles to ignite and sustain the plasma in water. It is also found that the firstly ignited plasma only lasts for sub-100 ns and quenches rapidly but regenerates in the water vapor bubble. These two distinct generation and successive steps, i.e. the ignition plasma (IP) and following successive plasma (SP) correspond to dielectric breakdown and glow-like plasmas, respectively. By time-resolved micro-spectroscopic imaging approaches, the difference in the spatial distributions between hydrogen and hydroxyl radicals at the initial stage of the plasma formation was also detected. These results provide a direct evidence for the proposed mechanism for plasma evolution in water and important information for the efficient control of the discharge plasma to its applications to waste-water treatments, nanomaterial syntheses with plasma oxidation-reduction reactions, and the chemical modification of the materials surfaces in aqueous solutions with green-chemistry manner.
1187	Luminescence of atomic barium in rare gas matrices - a 2D-Excitation/emission spectroscopy study	A detailed characterisation of the distinct sites occupied by atomic barium isolated in the three rare gas hosts Ar, Kr and Xe is made with excitation scans extracted from the recorded total 6s6p 1P1 &#xF0AE; (6s)2 1S0 fluorescence.  Extensive use has been made of two dimensional excitation-emission (2D-EE) spectroscopy to achieve a comprehensive characterisation for the wide variety of sites present in the Ba/RG matrix systems.  The 2D-EE technique has proved to be a very powerful method to probe the effects of strong inter-site reabsorption when extensive spectral overlap occurs between emission and resonance 6s6p 1P1 &#x2190; (6s)2 1S0 absorption of barium atoms occupying multiple sites.  2D-EE scans have also been used in this study to monitor the effects of sample annealing and thereby identify the thermally stable sites of isolation.  Sites of the same type occupied by atomic barium in the three host solids are identified in resolved excitation spectra and are associated on the basis of the observed matrix-shift versus host polarisablity.  Following site associations, the photophysical properties of each matrix site were characterised revealing that the Stokes shift was greatest in the blue site, smallest for the violet and intermediate for the green site.  Emission temperature dependences and excited state lifetimes were recorded indicating that measured radiative lifetimes of 4-5 ns were in good agreement with the gas phase value of 8.4 ns when corrected for the effective field of the solids.  The only exception to this was the blue site in Ba/Xe where a non-radiative quenching channel exists even at 9.8 K that competes effectively with the nanosecond fluorescence.  An unusual, asymmetric 2+1 excitation band has been recorded for atomic barium in the three rare gas hosts in addition to the 3-fold split, Jahn-Teller bands typically observed for P &#x2190; S absorptions of matrix-isolated metal atoms. Possible assignments of the sites responsible for the Ba/RG bandshapes are made on the basis of recent Ba/Xe spectral simulations [J. Chem. Phys., 148, 124308 (2018)] obtained from molecular dynamics calculations.
1188	<strong>Electrical </strong><strong>nucleation and detection of single 360&deg; N&eacute;el domain walls measured using the </strong><strong>anomalous Nernst effect</strong>	<strong>We demonstrate electrically the </strong><strong>nucleation and detection of a single 360&deg; N&eacute;el domain wall (DW), formed by an independently nucleated pair of 180&deg; N&eacute;el DWs having the same helicity in a </strong><strong>perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (PMA) </strong><strong>track. The domain wall formation is governed by strong interfacial Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction (DMI) and detected at room temperature using the </strong><strong>anomalous Nernst effect (ANE)</strong><strong>. A large DMI can be generated at the interface, which breaks the symmetry between a material having a large spin-orbit coupling and a thin ferromagnetic layer. </strong><strong>The ANE voltage, </strong><strong><em>V</em></strong><strong><sub>ANE </sub></strong><strong>&prop;</strong> <strong>&nabla;</strong><strong><em>T</em></strong><strong>&times;</strong><strong><em>M</em></strong><strong>, is sensitive to the magnitude of out-of-plane magnetization <em>M</em> through a confined thermal in-plane temperature gradient </strong><strong>&nabla;</strong><strong><em>T </em></strong><strong>and </strong><strong>allows for the direct thermo-electrical detection of the DW position with nanoscale accuracy along the track</strong><strong>. Here </strong><strong>we present evidence that independently nucleated pairs of 180&deg; N&eacute;el DWs in microwire devices can be pushed together by an applied magnetic field to form a 360&deg; N&eacute;el DW, and that a</strong><strong> strong magnetic field</strong> <strong>needs to be applied in order to annihilate the </strong><strong>360</strong><strong>&deg;</strong> <strong>DW</strong><strong> due to a strong interfacial DMI in our </strong><strong>Pt/Co/AlO<sub>x</sub> multilayers</strong><strong>. In addition to enabling a high magnetic storage and data transfer rate with low power consumption in novel computational and storage devices, such DWs facilitate a reduction in bit size down </strong><strong>to a few nanometer</strong><strong>s with metastability.</strong>
1189	Light-Induced Magnetization Changes in Aggregated and Isolated Cobalt Ferrite Nanoparticles	The light-induced magnetization changes in cobalt ferrite nanoparticles are reinvestigated to probe the mechanism of photomagnetic behavior and to uncover the essential criteria required to observe the effect.  Irradiation with white light results in pronounced demagnetization as evidenced by a decrease in the coercivity (&Delta;Hc &sim; 3 kOe at 10 K) and a drop in the high field magnetization at 70 kOe.  Wavelength dependent studies show the optical excitation driving the effect is broad in nature.  Power and temperature (<em>T</em>) dependent measurements reveal strikingly different photomagnetic behavior for the high field magnetization and coercive fields with energy scales of 25 K and 200 K, respectively.  Importantly, the magnitude of the light-induced change in the magnetization is found to be specific to the synthetic protocol, with aggregated nanoparticles showing a larger effect than isolated particles.  M&ouml;ssbauer spectroscopy provides additional evidence of the differences between the aggregated and isolated nanoparticle samples.  For T &le; 25 K, the photo-response arises from magnetic disorder generated by an elevated electronic temperature in the surface layer of the particles, thereby leading to a decrease in magnetic volume.  For 25 K &le; <em>T</em> &le; 200 K, the electronic and phononic reservoirs are more intimately coupled, so the photo-induced magnetic response follows the temperature dependence of the magneto-crystalline anisotropy.  A similar response in manganese ferrite suggests the mechanism is general.
1190	Protein Encapsulation via Polyelectrolyte Complex Coacervation: Protection against Protein Denaturation	Complex coacervation can be used as a route to compartmentalize a variety of solutes such as organic small molecules, inorganic nanoparticles as well as proteins within microscale coacervate droplets. To obtain insight into the accumulation of proteins within complex coacervate phases, the encapsulation of BSA within complex coacervates containing cationic polyelectrolyte poly(allylamine hydrochloride) (PAH) and anionic polyelectrolyte poly (acrylic aid) (PAA) was investigated as a function of mixing sequence, total polyelectrolyte concentration, BSA overall concentration, as well as the mixing molar ratio of PAA/PAH. Mixing BSA having a negative net charge with the polycation PAH before coacervation, increasing the total polyelectrolyte concentration and PAA/PAH molar ratio, or decreasing the BSA overall concentration led to more efficient protein encapsulation. Preservation of secondary structure of BSA during the complex coacervation process was confirmed using circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy. Our study shows that PAA-PAH coacervates can serve as protective system against the denaturation of BSA when exposed to extremes of pH, high temperatures, as well as in solution of urea. Additionally, it was found that by encapsulation of protein within coacervates via complex coacervation, the complexation between protein and heavy metal can be efficiently inhibited. Protection of BSA against severe environmental conditions via encapsulation within polyelectrolyte coacervates provides new insights and methods to issues of maintaining stability and function of proteins.
1191	Nonlinear Constitutive Models for Nano-scale Heat Conduction	We present a rigorous approach that leads, from a many-particle description, to a nonlinear, stochastic constitutive relation for the modeling of transient heat conduction processes at nanoscale. By enforcing statistical consistency, in that the statistics of the local energy is consistent<br />with that from an all-atom description, we identify the driving force as well as the model parameters.
1192	<strong><em>Modeling photothermal induced bistability in vanadium dioxide/1D photonic crystal composite nanostructures </em></strong>	We theoretically investigate the absorption bistability behavior of a nanostructure consisting of a vanadium dioxide (VO2) layer grown on top of a one-dimensional photonic crystal. The proposed structure is illuminated by a continuous wave pump laser, resulting in heat generation within the VO2 layer, and a subsequent phase transition which drastically affects the optical response of the nanostructure. We solve a multiphysics problem containing electromagnetism and thermodynamics in order to show that the optically induced transitions in the VO2 layer can lead to a bistable response in the nanostructure over some ranges of incident intensities during the VO2 heating and cooling modes. Interestingly, when the laser is well set up in an appropriate wavelength, the high contrast of two absorption values in the hysteresis loop indicate bistability and the possibility of achieving near-unity absorption. These properties give our structure promise for designing tunable VO2-based absorbers and optical switching devices.
1193	Theoretical prediction electronic properties of Group-IV diamond nanothreads	We have investigated the atomic and electronic structures, and carrier mobility on Group-IV diamond nanothreads (DNTs-C, DNTs-SiC, DNTs-Si and DNTs-Ge) using density functional theory. It is shown that all of Group-IV diamond nanothreads are wide gap semiconductors(&gt;3eV). The highest electron (hole) mobility value is even up to ~1.15&times;10<sup>5</sup> (1.38&times;10<sup>3</sup>)cm<sup>2</sup>V<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>. Due to the huge difference mobility in hole and electron, DNTs-Si and DNTs-Ge can be considered as <em>p</em>-type semiconductors, and DNTs-C can be considered as <em>n</em>-type semiconductor. Our results suggest that Group-IV diamond nanothreads can be considered as a new material for applications optoelectronics and nanoelectronic devices in some special conditions, such as high- temperature devices, wide-gap semiconductors, transparent conductors and so on.
1194	<strong>Epitaxial GaAs and pHEMT on &ldquo;aluminum&rdquo; nanofilms</strong>	Heterogeneous epitaxial growth between semiconductors and metals boosts novel device development and enables various applications. In this work, we have investigated the epitaxial growth of GaAs layers on top of a nanoscale aluminum film. The grown GaAs layers are single-crystalline and of high-quality, that has been evidenced by using various material characterization methods and by fabricating their high-electron mobility transistors. We found that an intriguing process named as &ldquo;arsenidation&rdquo; of aluminium film plays a key role in the successful epitaxy. Our work opens a window for growing semiconductor/metal hetero-structures for various device applications in the future.
1195	Pattern quality and defect evaluation based on cross correlation and power spectral density methods	Precise detection of a nanometer-scale pattern's edge positions in a SEM image is challenging for next generation patterning technology development. Here we propose two different edge detection methods, one is based on a normal method employing the edge threshold algorithm and the other is based on a cross-correlation method by calculating the real image with a reference. By using different SEM images without noise and with noise, we summarize the pros and cons of the abovementioned two methods. With the implementation of the power spectral density method, the comparison shows that the cross-correlation method suppresses the metrology uncertainty of edge positions and edge roughness. Besides, cross-correlation method also calculates all potential edge defects, especially the footing defects and the top loss defects. The method has high application potential in 3D reconstruction process by using different reference waves, in addition to that it enables novel FEM metrology such as the roughness FEM and defect FEM.
1196	<strong>  Molecular dynamics study of copper nanosprings with/withou twin boundary structures</strong>	Using molecular dynamics simulation, we extract the deformation mechanism in Cu nanosprings with/without nanotwinned structures for the superior elongation. The dislocation-driven deformation mechanism in nanosprings is found, which mainly depends on the geometry of nanosprings. Severe distortion caused by local dislocation emission is frequently observed at the plastic stage, especially for nanosprings with large wire diameters. It is proved that small twin boundary spacings can improve the mechanical behaviors of nanosprings by limiting the dislocation emission and twin boundary migration. By calculating the spring constant of nanosprings with/without twin boundary structures, we find that the stiffness of nanosprings with larger wire diameters, smaller helix pitches or smaller twin boundary spacings would become larger, and the classical theory is still valid in nanosprings.
1197	Shaping single atomic junctions in ultra-thin Ag structures by electromigration	Electromigration, originally thought of only as a detrimental effect for metallic nanostructures, is <br />demonstrated here as a useful structuring tool to form reproducibly atomic point contacts in ultrathin (5 nm) and ultra-small (minimum width 16 nm) Ag nanostructures deposited on hydrogen <br />terminated low-doped Si(100) samples. Single contacts were always obtained once the smallest <br />width of the structures was below the average grain size of the Ag films and competing thermal <br />migration was suppressed. These ultra-thin and laterally open structures on Si provide complete <br />accessibility for local characterisation of the molecular junction.
1198	Ion size effect on electrostatic and electroosmotic properties in soft nanochannels with pH-dependent charge density	We report a theoretical study of ion size effect on various properties in a soft nanochannel with pH-dependent charge density. We develop a free energy based mean-field theory taking into account ion size as well as pH-dependence of charged polyelectrolyte layer grafted on a rigid surface in an electrolyte. The influence of ion size on properties in a soft nanochannel is evaluated by numerically calculating ion number densities and electrostatic potential. We demonstrate that unlike in point-like ions, for finite sizes of ions, a uniform distribution of chargeable sites within the polyelectrolyte layer causes unphysical discontinuities in ion number densities not only for hydrogen ion but also for other kinds of ions. It is shown that the same cubic spatial distribution of chargeable sites as for point-like ions is necessary to ensure continuity of ion number density and zero ion transport at the polyelectrolyte layer - rigid solid interface. We find that considering finite ion size causes an increase in electrostatic potential and electroosmotic velocity and a decrease in ion number densities. More importantly, we demonstrate that in polyelectrolyte layer, pH-dependence of polyelectrolyte charge density makes accumulation of hydrogen ions stronger than for the other positive ion species in the electrolyte and such a tendency is further enhanced by considering finite ion size. In addition, we discuss how consideration of finite ion size affects the role of various parameters on electrostatic and electroosmotic properties.
1199	Numerical and experimental investigation of 4 mm wavelength microwave oscillator based on high-current compact accelerator	The concept of two-wave relativistic Cherenkov oscillator for generation of nanosecond micro-wave pulses at ~72 GHz central frequency has been applied. Moderately oversized sectioned slow wave structure (average diameter &#x2248; 2.5 wavelength) provides interaction of electrons sim-ultaneously with slow (or surface) TM01 wave and the fast (or volume) TM02 wave, which gov-erns the microwave energy output. The generation of 85 MW, 1.3-ns long microwave pulses has been demonstrated in a single pulse operation with a pulsed guiding magnetic field of 3.8 T on the base of desktop high-current accelerator RADAN-303.
1200	<strong>Polyallylamine hydrochloride coating enhances the fluorescence emission of Human Serum Albumin encapsulated gold nanoclusters</strong>	<strong>A method of increasing the fluorescence emission of Human Serum Albumin (HSA) encapsulated gold nanoclusters (AuNCs) via a Polyallylamide hydrochloride (PAH) coating. PAH molecules with a molecular weight of ~17,500 Da can enhance the fluorescence emission of HSA-AuNCs by 3-fold when the protein/polymer concentration ratio is 2:1 in solution. AuNCs fluorescence lifetime decreases while native tryptophan (TRP) fluorescence lifetime decreases during enhancement. The zeta potential of the system was observed to be zero during maximum enhancement causing the formation of large aggregates. This suggests PAH binds to the HSA-AuNCs acting as a linker; causing aggregation and rigidification, which results in a decrease in separation between native TRP of HSA and AuNCs; improving F&ouml;rster Resonance Energy Transfer (FRET) and enhancing emission. These findings are critical to the development of brighter protein encapsulated AuNCs.</strong>
1201	<strong>Effect of morphology on optical and efficiently enhanced electrical properties of W-ZnS for UV sensor Applications</strong>	The influence of morphology on the transport properties of the ZnS nanostructures has been assessed by the electrical measurements on different ZnS nanostructures. High-quality poly (vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) capped wurtzite-ZnS (w-ZnS) micro and nanostructures have been prepared through one step hydrothermal method at low temperature. A detailed structural investigation based on XRD results and morphological analysis has been carried out using FE-SEM, TEM, SAED and HR-TEM techniques. In order to examine the formation of compound ZnS, atomic ratio of Zn to S has been found from the EDS. The bandgap of the samples calculated from the UV-visible absorption spectra in reflectance mode at room temperature. Dependence of size and shape on excitonic and trap-state emission features of the nanostructures have been investigated from the photoluminescence (PL) studies and the enhancement in PL intensity in ID nanostructures also discussed. High yield and highly crystalline long nanorods and nanowires can be considered as an excellent candidate for advanced optoelectronic systems of the future since it has a better photoconductivity as compared with micro-particles and nanoparticles.
1202	Surface plasmon resonances in a branched silver nanorod	The properties of surface plasmon-polariton (SPP) resonance modes were investigated in a branched silver nanorod consisting of two nanorods using high energy resolution electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) combined with scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM). The experimental EELS maps of the SPP excitation showed a specific distribution depending on the resonance mode. The analytical formulas of the EELS signal and the resonance conditions for SPP resonance in the branched nanorod were derived by expanding the method reported for a one-dimensional straight resonator, and these were applied to interpret the experimental results. The SPP resonance in the branched nanorod can be attributed to Fabry-Perot type resonance that propagates in any of three different resonance paths. It was also demonstrated that the modes of SPP resonance are changed by the position of the crossing point in the branched structure, which indicates that the combination of the lengths of the respective branches can be used to control the propagation path and the resonance energy of SPP waves in branched structures.
1203	<strong>Excellent thermal stability thanks to Ge and C Doping in Sb<sub>2</sub>Te for high-speed phase change memory</strong>	<strong>Ge<sub>2.3</sub>Sb<sub>2.0</sub>Te phase change material was proposed to feature high thermal stability (10-year data retention above 220</strong><strong><sup>o</sup></strong><strong>C</strong><strong>) and fast transition speed (SET programming speed up to 5 ns) for electronic memory application. In mushroom-shaped device cells, the nanocomposite alloys implement an endurance life nearly 1&times;10<sup>5</sup>cycles with clear distribution of resistance values. Such operation speed among alloys with high-temperature characteristic is the best ever reported. And the moderate incorporation of C offers intriguing benefits that include the enhanced thermal stability and reduced RESET voltage in Ge-rich Sb<sub>2</sub>Te-based memory cells. Through microscopic analysis, the local segregation of C dopants can further refine crystalline grains and thus induce a less volume change and roughness upon heating process. These properties are crucial regarding the application potential in high-performance and high-density embedded memories.</strong>
1204	A simple model for the wall depletion length of nanoconfined DNA	We have measured the wall depletion length of DNA confined in 38 nm wide, square silicon dioxide nanochannels for five different ionic strengths between 15 mM and 75 mM. Experiments used the BioNano Genomics Irys platform for massively parallel data acquisition,  attenuating the effect of the sequence-dependent persistence length and finite-length effects by using nick-labeled E. coli genomic DNA with contour length separations of at least 30 &#x03BC;m (88,325 base pairs) between nick pairs. In excess of 5 million measurements of the fractional extension were obtained from 39,291 labeled DNA molecules.
