Analyzing the stretching via Odijk's theory for a strongly confined wormlike chain yielded a linear relationship between the depletion length and the Debye length that is in qualitative agreement with previously defined analytical models.
1205	Electric-field tuning of the valley splitting in silicon corner dots	We perform an excited state spectroscopy analysis of a silicon corner dot in a nanowire field-effect transistor to assess the electric field tunability of the valley splitting. First, we demonstrate a back-gate-controlled transition between single quantum dot and double quantum dot regimes that allows tuning the device in to corner dot formation. We find a linear dependence of the valley splitting on back-gate voltage, from 880 &mu;eV to 610 &mu;eV with a slope of -45 &plusmn; 3 &mu;eV/V (or equivalently a slope of -48 &plusmn; 3 &mu;eV/(MV/m) with respect to the effective field). The experimental results are backed up by tight-binding simulations that include the effect of surface roughness, remote charges in the gate stack and discrete dopants in the channel. Our results demonstrate a way to electrically tune the valley splitting in silicon-on-insulator-based quantum dots, a requirement to achieve all-electrical manipulation of silicon spin qubits.
1206	<strong>Rutherford backscattering spectrometry analysis of InGaAs nanostructures</strong>	In this paper, we demonstrate that Rutherford backscattering spectrometry (RBS) can be extended from a metrology concept applied to blanket films towards a method to analyze confined nanostructures. By a combination of measurements on an ensemble of devices and extensive simulations, it is feasible to quantify the composition of InGaAs nanostructures (16-50 nm) embedded periodically in a SiO<sub>2</sub> matrix. The methodology is based on measuring multiple fins simultaneously while using the geometrical shape of the structures, obtained from a transmission electron microscopy analysis, as input for a multitude of trajectory calculations. In this way, we are able to reproduce the RBS spectra and to demonstrate the sensitivity of the RBS spectra to the quantitative elemental composition of the nanostructures as a function of depth, to variations of their shape and mean areal coverage down to one nanometer. Thus, we establish Rutherford backscattering spectrometry as a viable quantitative characterization technique to probe the composition and structure of periodic arrays of nanostructures.
1207	Modeling of Quantum Dot Pattern Formation on Pit-Patterned Semiconductor Substrates	We develop a properly parameterized, three-dimensional continuum-scale kinetic model for monitoring the surface morphological evolution of coherently strained heteroepitaxial thin films that captures the morphological response of epitaxially grown Ge thin films on pit-patterned Si{100} substrates. The model accounts for curvature-driven atomic diffusion on the film surface, biaxial lattice misfit strain in the film, and the wetting potential between the film and the substrate. Self-consistent dynamical simulations based on our model show formation of complex nanostructures on the epitaxial film surface, including nanorings at the rims of pits, a single quantum dot at the center of a pit, as well as multiple quantum dots inside pits with rectangular openings, consistent with experimentally observed nanostructures. Our simulation results reproduce the variation in the formed nanostructural features observed experimentally by properly varying the key experimental parameters, namely, the pit size and the pit geometry. Our study sets the stage for designing systematic experimental protocols toward precise control of complex nanoring and quantum dot patterns forming on surfaces of epitaxially grown coherently strained semiconductor thin films.
1208	Three-dimensional Magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) flow of Maxwell nanofluid containing gyrotactic micro-organisms with heat source/sink	This paper discusses the three-dimensional flow of Maxwell nanofluid containing gyrotactic micro-organisms over a stretching surface. The effects of magnetic field and heat source/sink are also considered. Theory of microorganisms is utilized to stabilize the suspended nanoparticles through bioconvection induced by the effects of buoyancy forces. Analytic solution for the governing nonlinearsequations is obtained by using homotopy analysis method (HAM). The effects of Deborah number, Hartmann number, mixed convection parameter, buoyancy ratio parameter, bioconvection Rayeigh number, stretcing ratio parameter, brownian diffusion and thermophoresis diffusion parameters, Prandtl number, Lewissnumber, bioconvection Lewis number, bioconvection Peclet number and the microorganisms concentration difference parameter on velocity, temperature, nanoparticle concentration and density of motile microorganisms are discussed graphically.sThe local Nusselt, Sherwood and motile micro-organisms numbers are also analyzed graphically. Several known results have been pointed out as the particular cases of the present analysis.
1209	<strong>The role of ZrO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles on interface reactions between electrodes and films to enhance dielectric strength of sol-gel Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> films</strong>	Taking Al as top electrode, a repairing layer with ultrahigh breakdown strength and resistivity was generated between the interface of sol-gel Al2O3 films and electrodes due to the interfacial anodic oxidation reaction, which effectively repaired the interfacial defects and improved the dielectric strength. More importantly, it was found that adding ZrO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticle into the matrix film could further enhance the dielectric strength, since the ZrO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticle is conductive to forming the repairing layer. According to the analysis of ac conduction properties, the calculation results showed that the addition of nano-ZrO<sub>2</sub> resulted in a lower potential barrier and a longer hopping distance for ionic migration. In addition, the electric field simulation indicated that nano-ZrO<sub>2</sub> addition induced a local region of high electric field in the Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> matrix and thus accelerated ionic migration. As a result of these two factors, the nanocomposite structure of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/nano-ZrO<sub>2</sub> was favorable for ionic transport and further promoted interfacial reactions at the electrode-film interface. With the stronger interfacial reaction, Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/nano-ZrO<sub>2</sub> films exhibited significantly enhanced dielectric strength of ~550 MV/m, in contrast with 385 MV/m for pure Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>films.
1210	<strong>Large depth focus-tunable photoacoustic tomography based on clinical ultrasound array transducer</strong>	Multi-element photoacoustic tomography (ME-PAT) systems either have an unmovable focus or have non-uniform light on the region of interest, effectively limiting the imaging depth-of-field and resolution of the technique. In this study, we developed a focus-tunable photoacoustic tomography (FT-PAT) based on a clinical ultrasound array transducer with uniform laser excitation to achieve relatively high-resolution imaging in deep tissue. Laser excitation uses an adjustable line-focus structure and ultrasound confocal reception through a delay receiving algorithm. Different depths of carbon rods were used to evaluate the zoom ability in the tissue phantom. <em>In vivo</em> depth zoom imaging performance was demonstrated by carbon nanoparticles-labeled present in living nude mouse under chicken breast. The proposed FT-PAT system was shown a great potential in clinical environment to be used in deep tumor detection.
1211	A critical assessment of the line tension determined by the modified Young's equation	Although the modified Young's equation is frequently applied to evaluate the line tension of droplets, debate concerning the value and even the sign of the line tension is ongoing. The reason for this is that the line tension defined in the modified Young's equation is not a pure line tension but an apparent line tension, which includes the effects of the Tolman length and the stiffness coefficients. In this paper, we employ molecular dynamics (MD) to simulate three-dimensional water nanodroplets on platinum surfaces, and determine their apparent line tensions by applying a linear fit to the relation of the cosine of the contact angle to the curvature of the contact line. The effects of the Tolman length and the position of the solid-liquid dividing interface on the measured line tension are investigated. On one hand, our results elucidate the reason why MD results for line tensions are so scattered, and also lend numerical support to Schimmele et al.'s theoretical predictions [J. Chem. Phys. 127, 164715 (2007)]. On the other hand, our MD simulation results demonstrate that the modified Young's equation is a useful tool to predict the macroscopic contact angle based on a linear fit of the measured contact angles at the nanoscale. The apparent line tension is, however, sensitive to the chosen position of the solid-liquid dividing interface.
1212	<strong>Size effects in TiAlNiAu thin film metal systems used to form ohmic contacts to nitride structures</strong>	In this paper, the relation between the geometry of metric space of TiAlNiAu thin film metal system and the geometry of normed functional space of its sheet resistances (functionals), that are elements of the functional space, is investigated in local approximation. The investigation provides a means to describe a lateral size effect that involves a dependency of sheet resistance R<sub>sq</sub> of TiAlNiAu metal film on its lateral linear dimensions (in (<em>x</em>,<em>y</em>) plane). This dependency is defined by fractal geometry of dendrites, or, more specifically, it is a power-law dependency on fractal dimension <em>D<sub>f</sub></em> value. The revealed relation has a great practical importance both for a precise calculation of thin film metal system <em>R<sub>sq</sub></em> values in designing discreet devices and ICs, and for controlling results at micro- and nanoscale in producing workflow for thin metal films and systems based on them.
1213	<strong>Deterministic Construction of Low Noise Avalanche Photodetector Materials</strong>	Over the past 40+ years, III-V materials have been intensively studied for avalanche photodetectors, driven by applications including optical communications, imaging, quantum information processing,<sup> </sup>and autonomous vehicle navigation. Unfortunately, impact ionization is a stochastic process that introduces noise, thereby limiting sensitivity and achievable bandwidths, leading to intense effort to mitigate this noise through the identification of new materials and device structures. Exploration of new materials has seen limited success as it has proceeded in a largely <em>ad hoc</em> fashion, due to little consensus regarding which fundamental properties are important. Here we report the first deterministic design of low-noise avalanche photodetector materials by alternating the composition at the monolayer scale; this represents a dramatic departure from previous approaches, which have concentrated on either new compounds/alloys or nanoscale band-engineering. In particular, we demonstrate how to substantially improve upon the noise characteristics of the current state-of-the art telecom avalanche multipliers, In<sub>0.52</sub>Al<sub>0.48</sub>As grown on InP substrates, by growing the structure as a strain-balanced digital alloy of InAs and AlAs layers, each only a few atomic layers thick.  The effective <em>k</em>-factor, which has historically been considered a fundamental material property, was reduced by 6-7&acute;. We also demonstrate that these &ldquo;digital alloys&rdquo; can significantly extend photodetector cutoff wavelength well beyond those of their random alloy counterparts.
1214	Lattice constant, bond orientational order, and solid solubility of PdPt bimetallic nanoparticles	Crystal structure deviations of bimetallic Pd-Pt nanoparticles (NPs) were investigated using synchrotron high-energy X-ray diffraction. The samples comprised Pd NPs and bimetallic Pd-Pt NPs featuring those with a Pd-core/Pt-shell structure as well as PdPt solid-solution NPs with varying diameters of 6.1, 6.7, 8.1, and 11.2 nm. The Rietveld method was used to find the lattice constant of the Pd NPs, which was larger than the bulk value; while reverse Monte Carlo modeling revealed they possessed a highly disordered structure. The lattice constants of the Pd-Pt bimetallic NPs were found to vary with the NP Pt content. For Pd-core/Pt-shell structure NPs, the lattice constants decreased with Pt content owing to lattice relaxation at the core/shell interface. After a reaction process of hydrogen absorption/desorption, the lattice constant of the resulting PdPt solid-solution NPs increased with NP Pt content, which followed Vegard&rsquo;s law. The degree of disorder of the solid-solution NPs was evaluated by the <em>P<sub>BOO</sub></em> values (i.e., structural parameters describing the deviation of the local structure from an ideal crystal structure) and was found to decrease with NP Pt content. A short-range-order parameter was introduced using a three-dimensional reverse Monte Carlo configuration structure to evaluate the atomic-scale solid solubility of the Pd<sub>0.92</sub>Pt<sub>0.08</sub> and Pd<sub>0.79</sub>Pt<sub>0.21</sub>NPs. The parameter values obtained were close to randomly dispersed in the solid-solution NPs.
1215	<strong>A study of Brownian Motion and Thermophoresis Effects on Unsteady Stagnation Point Flow of Eyring-Powell Nanofluid over a Stretching Sheet</strong>	This article concerns with the analysis of an unsteady stagnation point flow of Eyring-Powell nanofluid over a stretching sheet. The influence of thermophoresis and Brownian motion is also considered in transport equations. The nonlinear ODE set is obtained from the governing nonlinear equations via suitable transformations. The numerical experiments are performed by means of Galerkin scheme. A tabular form comparison analysis of outcomes attained via Galerkin approach and numerical scheme (RK-4) is available to show the credibility of Galerkin method. The numerical exploration is carried out for various governing parameters namely; Brownian motion, steadiness, thermophoresis, stretching ratio, velocity slip, concentration slip, thermal slip, and fluid parameters, and Hartmann, Prandtl, Schmidt numbers. The velocity of fluid enhanced with an increase in fluid and magnetic parameter for the case of opposing but the behavior is reverse for assisting case. The Brownian motion and thermophoresis parameters causes an increase in temperature for both cases (assisting and opposing). The Brownian motion parameter provide a drop in concentration while an increase is noticed for thermophoresis parameter. All the outcomes and the behavior of emerging parameters is illustrated graphically. The comparison analysis and graphical plots are endorsing the appropriateness of Galerkin method. It is concluded that the said method could be extended to other problems of complex nature.
1216	Understanding the microscopic origin behind heterogeneous properties of water confined in and around A&#x03B2;<sub>17-42</sub> protofilaments	Aggregation of amyloid beta (A&#x03B2;) peptide in the brain is responsible for onesof the most devastating neurodegenerative diseases, namely the Alzheimer'ssdisease (AD). In this study we have carried out atomistic molecular dynamicsssimulations to explore the effects of non-uniform structural distortions ofsA&#x03B2;<sub>17-42</sub> pre-fibrillar aggregates of different sizes on the microscopic structure and ordering of water molecules confined within their amphiphilic nanocores. The calculations revealed non-uniform peptide-water interactions resulting in simultaneous existence of both highly ordered and disordered water molecules within the spatially heterogeneous confined environment of the protofilament cores. Importantly, it is found that the high degree of ordering originates from a sizable fraction of core water molecules that are doubly-coordinated within their first coordination shells, while the randomly oriented ones are those that are coordinated with three neighbors in the first coordination shells. Further, it is quantitatively demonstrated that relative fractions of these two types of water molecules are correlated with the topology of the protofilament cores and the degree of confinement within those. It is proposed that the ordered core waters are likely to stabilize thesA&#x03B2; protofilaments by screening the residue charges and favoring water-mediated salt bridge formations, while the randomly oriented ones can drive further growth of the protofilaments by being displaced easily during the docking of additional peptides. In that way both types of core water molecules can play equally important roles in controlling the growth and stability of thesA&#x03B2; aggregates.
1217	<strong>Torsional strain effects on intertube friction in carbon nanotube: strain engineering in friction</strong>	The possibility of strain engineering of friction in carbon nanotube is explored by employing the molecular dynamics simulations. By study the intertube friction in carbon nanotube subjected to torsional strain, it is found that the friction can be tuned by torsional strain. It shows that the temperature has great influence on torsional strain effects on intertube friction. Mechanism and physical insight of torsional strain effects are revealed by numerical and phonon spectra analysis. The work in this letter implies the potential of strain engineering in nanoscale friction and brings new insight into fundamental understanding of strain effect mechanism in nanoscale friction.
1218	Investigation of spin Seebeck effect and magnetic damping in nanometer thick Cerium Yttrium Iron garnet films	Growth of nm thick Cerium Yttrium Iron garnet films, their magnetic damping properties and observation of Spin Seebeck effect in the films has been reported. The films in the range of 23-148 nm have been grown on gadolinium gallium garnet substrates through pulsed laser deposition technique (PLD). The films possess very good quality and smooth surfaces with a roughness of less than 0.3nm. The 148 nm thick film showed a 9.2 GHz FMR linewidth of about 14.06 mT and a damping constant of 2.5 x 10<sup>-2</sup>. The FMR line width exhibited a linear response with frequency indicating the absence of two magnon scattering. The spin Seebeck voltage in the longitudinal direction was obtained on sputtering a 10 nm thick hall bar patterned Rh on the films.
1219	Bending deformation behavior of Zr65Cu17.5Ni10Al7.5 bulk metallic glass with different solidification cooling rate	In order to further clarify the relationship between the free volume and bending plasticity, the bending properties of Zr65Cu17.5Ni10Al7.5 bulk metallic glass (BMG) samples with different thicknesses corresponding to different solidification cooling rates were investigated. The results show that the bending plasticity of Zr65Cu17.5Ni10Al7.5 BMG decreases with the decrease of cooling rate, which is consistent with the evolution of shear bands density revealed by the investigation of microstructure. These phenomena are mainly attributed to the decrease of free volume content with the decrease of cooling rates in spite of the increase of nanocrystallization fraction, which further confirm that free volume plays a crucial role in the deformation process of the BMGs.
1220	MHD flow of Fe&#x2083;O&#x2084;-nanofluid over a stretching surface with dusty particles	The present analysis examines hydromagnetic flow of dusty nanofluid by an exponentially stretching sheet. Flow in porous space is examined. Mathematical modeling is presented in presence of heat generation/absorption aspects. Homotopy algorithm leads to solutions computations. Convergence intervals are explicitly identified. Velocity and temperature are examined. Coefficient of skin friction and heat transfer rate are discussed.
1221	<strong><em>Ultrafast Laser Induced Nanostructured ITO for Liquid Crystal Alignment and Higher Transparency Electrodes </em></strong>	Femtosecond laser nanostructured indium tin oxide (ITO) coated glass is shown to act both as liquid crystal (LC) alignment layer and electrode with higher transparency.  The nano patterns of 120nm period were created by directly on ITO films without any additional spin coating materials or lithography process.  Nine regions of laser-induced nanostructures were fabricated with different alignment orientations and various pulse energy levels on top of the ITO confirming the follow-up of the LC director to the lines orientation. The device interfacial anchoring energy was found to be , comparable to the anchoring energy of nematic LC on photosensitive polymers. The transparency as an electrode was found to improve due to the better antireflection and lower absorption expected from a nanostructured surface.
1222	A compact microwave plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition based on a household microwave oven	I design an efficient compact microwave plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (MW PECVD) from a household 2.45 GHz MW oven. The MW plasma sparked by a piece of Cu foil in a low pressure down to 1 Pa. In the MW PECVD, the SiC plate is used as MW heater to realize rapid MW heating up and used to prevent the reflected power damaging the magnetron. 1223	<SPAN style="font-size: 18.0pt; line-height: 200%; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; font-style: normal;">Aggregation of human islet amyloid polypeptide revealed by hyperspectral imaging </SPAN>	The amyloid aggregation of proteins is a ubiquitous phenomenon associated with over 50 human diseases. Here we demonstrated the use of hyperspectral imaging of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) grafted with citrate and polyethylene glycol (PEG400 and PEG3000) as probes for identifying the aggregation states of human IAPP, a peptide associated with type 2 diabetes. Complemented by COMSOL simulation we revealed a distinct anticorrelation between increased IAPP aggregation and decreased red shifts they incurred in AuNP plasmonic resonance. 1224	Magneto-hydrodynamic flow and heat transfer of a hybrid nanofluid in a rotating system between two parallel plates in the presence of thermal radiation and Joule heating	In this paper, the researchers explore heat transfer and magneto-hydrodynamic hybrid nanofluid flow in a rotating system between two parallel plates. The upper and lower plates of the system are assumed penetrable and stretchable, respectively. The thermal radiation and Joule heating impacts are considered. A similarity transformation is applied to alter the governing momentum and energy equations into non-linear ordinary differential equations that contain the appropriate boundary conditions and used the Duan-Rach Approach (DRA) to solve them. The impacts of diverse active parameters including the rotation parameter, the suction/blowing parameter, the radiation parameter the Reynolds number, the hybrid nanofluid volume fraction, and the magnetic parameter on the temperature and the velocity profiles are examined. Also, a correlation for the Nusselt number has been developed in terms of the active parameters of the present study. The outcomes indicate that the Nusselt number acts as an increasing function of the injection and radiation parameters, as well as the volume fraction of the nanofluid.
1225	Suction/injection process and thermal radiation impacts on magneto-hydrodynamic squeezing nanofluid flow and heat transfer between parallel disks considering Joule heating	In this paper, the unsteady squeezing flow and heat transfer of magneto-hydrodynamic nanofluid between two parallel disks under a suction/blowing process are studied. Thermal radiation, Joule heating and viscous dissipation impacts are considered. The researchers first converted the boundary conditions and governing momentum/energy equations into a non-dimensional form and solved them with DRA. Unlike ADM (Adomin Decomposition Method), this method permits us to discover an analytical solution without applying a numerical procedure to compute the missing parameters. The water based nanofluid is comprised of copper, copper oxide and alumina. The impacts of different parameters such as the suction/blowing parameter, the magnetic parameter, the solid volume fraction, the squeeze number, and the radiation parameter on flow and heat transfer attributes are investigated. Moreover, the value of the Nusselt number is calculated and illustrated in figures. The outcomes demonstrate that the fluid velocity ascends with the rise of the suction parameter while the temperature profile descends with the ascendance of the suction parameter.
1226	Low field manifestation of spiral ordering in sheet like BiFeO<sub>3</sub> nanostructures	Magnetic phase diagram of a material could be tuned through structural modication. Here we show significant lowering of magnetic field (H<sub>i</sub> ) required from transition from cycloidal to canted antiferromagnetic state in sheet like nanostructures of BiFeO<sub>3</sub>, in comparison to reported bulk single crystals of BiFeO<sub>3</sub>. Structural analysis of this sheet like nanostructured BFO suggests that there is more tilting in FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedra that reduces Fe-O-Fe distance in comparison to bulk BFO, leading<br />to decrease in H<sub>i</sub> through the reduction of exchange interaction strength.
1227	Random Lasing Mode Control by Application of an External Magnetic Field	This study experimentally demonstrates lasing mode switching within a ZnO nanoparticle film coated onto a magnetic thin film of NiFe alloy. When a neodymium magnet is brought close to or moved away from the film, switching behavior is observed in the lasing modes, although such change is induced in a ZnO nanoparticle film on a glass substrate. Our results suggest that the observed changes in lasing modes are because of a magnetic Kerr effect at the surface of the NiFe thin film. The small Kerr rotation would be enhanced by localized fields near the surface, inducing suppression or enhancement of the lasing modes in response to the surrounding environments, and accounting for the lasing mode switching.
1228	From MoO<sub>2</sub>@MoS<sub>2</sub> Core-shell Nanorods to MoS<sub>2</sub> Nanobelts	One-dimensional (1D) atomically thin crystals have attracted considerable interests due to their unique properties and potential applications. For example, reducing graphene physical size down to nanoscale to nanoribbons opens up band gaps, which makes graphene useful in electronic devices. Here, we report a facile approach to produce single- and bi-layered MoS<sub>2</sub> nanobelts by PMMA assisted decoupling of MoO<sub>2</sub>@MoS<sub>2</sub> core-shell nanorods. Atomic force microscopy (AFM), Raman and photoluminescence (PL) results show that the decoupled monolayer staple-like MoS<sub>2</sub>-shells can fold into bilayer nanobelts or not depending on the PMMA removal method. Raman, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) results reveal that the left MoO<sub>2</sub> nanorods exhibit high crystal-quality. Our findings provide a method to produce 1D MoS<sub>2</sub> or MoO<sub>2</sub> nanomaterials, which have potential applications in electronics and catalysis.
1229	Many-Body Dissipative Particle Dynamics Simulations of Nano-Droplet Formation in 3D Nano-Inkjet Printing	Nano-droplet formation is a critical process in the development of 3D nano-inkjet printing. We show that Many-Body Dissipative Particle Dynamics (MDPD) can be used to predict nano-droplet formation in nano-sized nozzles with good accuracy.  A conversion methodology is also introduced to overcome the problem of large coarse-graining factor, which results in unphysical results when the simulation is scaled up to real units. Using our MDPD model and the new conversion methodology, insights into possible trends of physical quantities in nano-droplet formation of polymeric UV ink can be gained. It was found that higher temperature and applied pressure reduce droplet break-up time. In addition, higher temperature increases the droplets&rsquo; diameter while higher effective pressure reduces it. These findings suggest that the physical environment can be tuned to achieve the desired droplet properties for 3D nano-inkjet printing. Due to the technical challenges that impedes experimental testing, this work demonstrates that MDPD provides a low-cost alternative to study nano-droplet formation in 3D nano-inkjet printing.
1230	<strong>The role of ZrO<sub>2 </sub>nanoparticles on interfacial reactions between electrodes and films to enhance dielectric strength of sol-gel Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> films</strong>	Taking Al as top electrode, a repairing layer with ultrahigh breakdown strength and resistivity was generated between the interface of sol-gel Al2O3 films and electrodes due to the interfacial anodic oxidation reaction, which effectively repaired the interfacial defects and improved the dielectric strength. More importantly, it was found that adding ZrO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticle into the matrix film could further enhance the dielectric strength, since the ZrO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticle is conductive to forming the repairing layer. According to the analysis of ac conduction properties, the calculation results showed that the addition of nano-ZrO<sub>2</sub> resulted in a lower potential barrier and a longer hopping distance for ionic migration. In addition, the electric field simulation indicated that nano-ZrO<sub>2</sub> addition induced a local region of high electric field in the Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> matrix and thus accelerated ionic migration. As a result of these two factors, the nanocomposite structure of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/nano-ZrO<sub>2</sub> was favorable for ionic transport and further promoted interfacial reactions at the electrode-film interface. With the stronger interfacial reaction, Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/nano-ZrO<sub>2</sub> films exhibited significantly enhanced dielectric strength of ~550 MV/m, in contrast with 385 MV/m for pure Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>films.
1231	Phase Transitions in BiFeO<sub>3</sub> driven by etching highly strained thin films to nanodots	We propose a novel method to drive phase transitions by etching strained BiFeO<sub>3</sub> thin films to nanodots. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) measurements reveal that the amount of rhombohedral-like (R)  phase increases as the BiFeO<sub>3</sub> thin films with tetragonal-like (T) matrix are etched to nanodots and larger fraction of R phase is obtained with the size reduction from 1 mm to 200 nm, indicating the T to R phase transition induced by partial release of substrate clamping. Using piezoresponse force microscopy (PFM), it is demonstrated that rhombohedral-like (R) to tetragonal-like (T) phase transitions can be reversibly achieved under DC electric field in BFO nanodots. Large electromechanical response has been observed in BFO nanodots as well. This approach can be extended to other strained oxide films and provide guidance for the development of high-performance electromechanical lead-free materials.
1232	<strong>Ferroelectric Polymer Nanostructure with Enhanced Flexoelectric Response for High-Density Memory</strong>	Through utilizing individual nanodots as smallest memory unit to convert stress into readable electronic information, we report force-induced high-density data storage in periodic nanostructure of ferroelectric polymer fabricated by nanoimprinting lithography. The nanostructure is ideal for stress concentration and increased non-uniformity of strains, thus leading to strain gradients inversely proportional to the feature size. A force as low as 400nN is applied to generate internal electric field in response to strain gradients, and switch polarization state of each memory unit. It can achieve storage density theoretically up to TB/inch<sup>2</sup> with the up-to-date nanofabrication technology to miniaturize unit size.
1233	Resistive Switching Behavior and Mechanism of Room-temperature-fabricated Flexible Al/TiS<sub>2</sub>-PVP/ITO/PET Memory Devices	The mixture of two-dimensional (2D) TiS<sub>2</sub> nanoflakes and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) exhibits a nonvolatile, bipolar resistive switching behavior with a low resistance state (LRS)/high resistance state (HRS) current ratio of ~10<sup>2</sup> in the devices with a flexible Al/TiS<sub>2</sub>-PVP/indium tin oxide (ITO)/polyethylene terephthalate (PET) structure. The polymer-assistant liquid-phase exfoliation of 2D nanoflakes from TiS<sub>2</sub> bulk material is processed in low-boiling solvent. And the fabrication process of these devices is performed entirely at room temperature. Such an energy-saving and scalable production process indicates a huge potential of large-scale industrial application. The AFM and TEM characterizations showed that the exfoliated 2D TiS<sub>2</sub> are flakes at micrometer scale with a layer-number of mostly 7 or 8. Both the HRS and the LRS can be kept for more than 10<sup>4</sup> s. The endurance of devices was obtained over 100 direct current (DC) sweeping cycles with remarkable separations between different resistive states. The distributions of writing (set) and erasing (reset) voltages show that set and reset voltages are small (&lt; 2 V). Also, the resistive switching characteristics of the devices are stable during 1000 bending cycles. The switching behavior is explained by the thinning and recovery of Schottky barriers within devices.
1234	Effects of tension-induced plastic deformation on mechanical and electrical conductivity response of &#xFF08;100&#xFF09;monocrystalline copper	The physical properties of a material can be affected by different stress states. In this paper, nanoindentation experiments with a maximum load of 100mN and strain-sensitive resistance tests were conducted on (100) monocrystalline copper with tension-induced plastic deformation to investigate the influences of plastic deformation on mechanical and electrical characteristics. By theoretical and experimental analysis, indentation depth, recovery rate of total work, contact area, pile-up, apparent hardness and elastic modulus for the deformed and virgin material were obtained and comparatively investigated. The results showed that under the same experimental conditions, more penetration depth (maximum and residual indentation depth) would be needed to reach the same load for the tension-deformed material. As the plastic deformation increased in the uniform plastic region, both the total and elastic indentation work increased, while the recovery rate of total work, contact area, apparent hardness and elastic modulus decreased. Meanwhile, the contribution of plastic deformation to electrical resistivity was also investigated. The quantitative relation between electrical resistivity and plastic strains was extracted from experiments. The understanding of the role of plastic deformation in mechanical and electrical properties of monocrystalline copper would be helpful to the application in damage detection systems and strain sensing sensor.
1235	Superhard Metal Borides: A Look Forward	Previous efforts towards the synthesis of superhard materials have focused on binary metal borides with short covalent bonds. We discuss the methods of enhancing the intrinsic and extrinsic hardening factors used to achieve these properties. As the realm of binary borides has all but been exhausted, there is a need to move to ternary and higher borides and to achieve greater morphological control at the nanoscale. The use of ternary and higher borides as starting materials provides a multitude of diverse compositional and structural combinations and merit further investigation as they offer the potential for the optimization of mechanical properties.
1236	Silicon nano-cone formation via low-energy helium ion sputtering	In this study, the effect of low-energy (100 eV) He+ ion irradiation on Si surface morphology is explored. Si (100) and (111) samples were irradiated with 100 eV He+ ions at an elevated sample temperature of 600 {degree sign}C and to fluences in the range 5.0&#x00D7;1019 - 2.0&#x00D7;1020 ions cm-2. Through a combination of high ion flux and high sample temperature, it was found that continued He+ ion irradiation facilitates the formation of homogeneously populated, high aspect ratio silicon nano-cones (NCs) (~50 - 100 nm base; ~200 - 400 nm height). Resulting surface morphology is shown to have excellent anti-reflective properties, suggesting potential application toward enhanced light absorption in photovoltaic and other optical applications. Furthermore, similar irradiations at reduced sample temperature show comparable structuring mechanisms but with smaller cone diameter. These results indicate that NC size and number density (and related wavelength-dependent reflectivity properties) may be tailored by carefully tuning ion irradiation conditions. Utilizing very low-energy He+ ions as the irradiating species, these studies also demonstrate an added benefit to limiting metallic surface contamination through reduced probability of sputtering in-vacuum components.
1237	<strong>Tailored tunneling magneto-dielectric effects in Co&ndash;MgF<sub>2</sub> granular nanostructures by in-situ insertion of thin MgF<sub>2</sub> layers </strong>	We propose a structural strategy that inserting several thin MgF crystalline layers into the super-paramagnetic granular structure of Co<sub>0.23</sub>&ndash;(MgF)<sub>0.77</sub>, to tailor the frequency response of tunneling magneto-dielectric (TMD) effect. The results indicate that increasing MgF interlayer thickness (<em>t</em>) from 0 to 4 nm causes the position of peak dielectric change (&Delta;<em>&epsilon;</em>&prime;/<em>&epsilon;</em>&prime;<sub>0</sub>) at a specific frequency <em>f</em><sub>TMD</sub>, to shift from 300 to 3 kHz, while also retaining a slight decrease in &Delta;<em>&epsilon;</em>&prime;/<em>&epsilon;</em>&prime;<sub>0</sub> from 2.9% to 2.4%. The magnitude of &Delta;<em>&epsilon;</em>&prime;/<em>&epsilon;</em>&prime;<sub>0</sub> was capable of being controlled by varying the Co content in the granular layers. Theoretical curve fittings predict that the TMD effect in the heterostructure arises from both the granular layers and interlayers, and a change in inter-granular distance within the interlayers leads to a shift in the position of <em>f</em><sub>TMD</sub>. This study may suggest a route toward tailoring the TMD response to a particular frequency, with potential applications in room-temperature magnetoelectric devices with high TMD response at any frequency.
1238	Ultrahigh supercapacitance in cobalt oxide nanorod film grown by oblique angle deposition technique	Nanorod films of cobalt oxide (Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>) have been grown by a unique oblique angle deposition (OAD) technique in an e-beam evaporator for supercapacitor electrode applications. This technique offers a non-chemical route to achieve large aspect ratio nanorods. The fabricated electrodes at OAD 80<sup>o</sup> exhibited a specific capacitance of 2875 F/g. The electrochemically active surface area was 1397 cm<sup>-2</sup>, estimated from the non-Faradaic capacitive current region. Peak energy and power densities obtained for Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> nanorods were 57.7 Wh/Kg and 9.5 kW/kg, respectively. The Co<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> nanorod electrode showed a good endurance of 2000 charge-discharge cycles with 62% retention. The OAD approach for fabricating supercapacitor nanostructured electrodes can be exploited for the fabrication of a broad range of metal oxide materials.
1239	<strong>Atomistic Insights into Mechanical and Thermal Properties of Stanene with Defects</strong>	Stanene a two-dimensional, graphene-like buckled honeycomb structure material, has been synthesized in a recent experimental study. It is considered to be a potential material for the next generation nano-electronics application. In electronic applications, the materials are subjected to both thermal and mechanical loadings. In addition, structural defects are inevitable during synthesis of nanomaterials. Therefore, it is essential to study the mechanical and thermal properties of stanene with various structural defects. We investigated the effects of point vacancy, bivacancy and Stone-Wales defects on tensile response and thermal transport of single-layer stanene sheets using classical molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. MEAM potential is used to describe the inter-atomic forces to predict the properties of the stanene adequately. We probed the deformation process of defective stanene by applying uniaxial tensile loading. Our study suggests that tensile strength and elastic modulus of stanene decrease with the increment of defect concentrations. Using non-equilibrium molecular dynamics (NEMD) method, we found that, the phonon thermal conductivity of stanene is highly sensitive to defect concentrations. Only 0.1% of defect concentrations result in about 40% reduction in thermal conductivity. To elucidate the underlying mechanism responsible for this reduction, vibrational density of states (vDOS) are calculated. Overall, our reported results provide an insight into the effect of defects in mechanical and thermal properties of defective stanene and will facilitate further tailoring of the design of stanene based nanoelectronics device.
1240	<em>Gas flow at the ultra-nanoscale: universal statistical predictive model and validation in nanochannels of &Aring;ngstrom resolution</em>	We report a theoretical and experimental analysis of gas transport in channels ranging in size from the ultra-nano- to the sub-microscale. A theoretical approach quantitatively predicting pressure driven gas flow in the Knudsen and transition regime was developed. This approach is equivalent to, but much more physically transparent and simple than existing Navier-Stokes descriptions of the problem with Maxwell boundary conditions. In order to benchmark our model against a precisely defined experimental system, we manufactured extremely reproducible membrane with slit nanochannels, whose sizes ranged from 2.5 to 250 nm. Volumetric gas ow in the Knudsen number range from 0.2 to 20 was measured. Excellent agreement between theoretical predictions and experimental data was found, demonstrating the effectiveness of this approach.
1241	Low-temperature homoepitaxial growth of two-dimensional antimony superlattices in silicon	We present a low-temperature process for the homoepitaxial growth of antimony superlattices in silicon. We have used low-temperature molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) to embed atomically thin (2D), highly concentrated layers of dopant atoms within nanometers of the surface. This process allows for dopant densities on the order of 10<sup>13</sup>-10<sup>14</sup> cm<sup>-2</sup> (10<sup>20</sup>-10<sup>21</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup>); higher than can be achieved with three-dimensional (3D) doping techniques. This effort builds on our prior work with n-type delta doping; we have optimized our growth processes to achieve multiple, spatially-confined delta layers with sharp dopant profiles. By transitioning from a standard effusion cell to a valved cracker cell for antimony evaporation, we have achieved carrier densities approaching 10<sup>21</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup> with peak distribution at ~10 &#x00C5; FWHM, the thinnest reported to date. We will discuss details related to growth optimization, and show results from in situ monitoring by electron diffraction. We will also report on elemental and electrical characterization of our films.
1242	<strong>High-performanc</strong><strong>e photodetector based on hybrid </strong><strong>of MoS<sub>2</sub> and reduced graphene oxide</strong>	Two dimensional materials are promising new class materials for next generation optoelectronic devices owing to its appealing optical and electrical properties. Pristine MoS<sub>2 </sub>is widely used in next generation photovoltaic and opto-electronic devices, but its low photo-dark current ratio prevents its uses in highly efficient photo detection applications. Here, we decorated crumpled reduced graphene oxide (rGO) particles on large-area vertically aligned MoS<sub>2</sub> flakes network for enhancing the performance of the MoS<sub>2</sub> based photodetector by forming multiple nanoscale p-n heterojunctions.The rGO/MoS<sub>2 </sub>device exhibited a significantly improved photo-responsivity of  ~ 2.10 A/W along with a good detectivity of ~ 5 &times; 10<sup>11</sup> Jones (Jones = cm Hz<sup>1/2</sup>/W) than that of MoS<sub>2</sub> photodetector in ambient atmosphere. Moreover, the rGO/MoS<sub>2</sub> photodetector showed a fast response of ~18 ms with excellent stability and reproducibility in ambient air even after three months. The high performance of the photodetector is attributed to enhanced photoexcited carrier density and suppressed photo generated electron-hole recombination due to strong local built-in electric field developed at the rGO/MoS<sub>2 </sub>interface. Our results showed that integration of rGO with MoS<sub>2</sub> provides an efficient platform for photo detection applications.
1243	<strong>Crystallization of amorphous silicon thin films induced by gold nano-particles </strong>	This work investigates the metal induced crystallization of hydrogenated amorphous silicon thin films using gold nano-particles as crystallizing mediator metal. Starting from colloidal gold solutions, electrophoresis deposition method was used to coat &lt;100&gt; oriented silicon substrates with various small amounts of Au nano-particles. Three samples were prepared for various electrophoresis deposition times. Afterwards, gold coated substrates were covered with a-Si: H films elaborated by plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition. All samples were submitted to a rapid thermal annealing at a fixed temperature 600&deg;C and for 90 min under N<sub>2</sub> atmosphere. Furthermore, Raman back scattering analysis allowed the determination of structural characteristics related to processed amorphous Si films such as the crystalline fraction, residual stresses and crystal sizes. On the basis of kinetic and thermodynamic considerations and accordingly to additional characterizations provided by both scanning electronic microscopy images and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, we emphasis on highlighting the competition that took place between nucleation and growth mechanisms and led to the partial crystallization of amorphous silicon thin films.
1244	Biomedical sensing and imaging with optical fibers: innovation through convergence of science disciplines	The probing of physiological processes in living organisms is a grand challenge that requires bespoke analytical tools. Optical fiber probes offer a minimally-invasive approach to report physiological signals from specific locations inside the body. This Perspective article discusses a wide range of such fiber probes developed at the Australian Research Council Centre of Excellence for Nanoscale BioPhotonics. Our fiber platforms use a range of sensing modalities, including embedded nanodiamonds for magnetometry, interferometric fiber cavities for refractive index sensing, and tailored metal coatings for surface plasmon resonance sensing. Other fiber probes exploit molecularly sensitive Raman scattering, or fluorescence where optical fibers have been combined with chemical and immunosensors. Fiber imaging based on interferometry and computational imaging are also discussed as emerging in vivo diagnostic methods. We provide examples to illustrate how the convergence of multiple scientific disciplines generates opportunities for the fiber probes to address key challenges in real-time in vivo diagnostics. These future fiber probes will enable the asking and answering of scientific questions that were never possible before.
1245	<strong>Intrusion of two strained-Si layers in the channel region of HOI MOSFET</strong>	A heterostructure design with two strained silicon (s-Si) layers on either side of the strained silicon germanium (s-SiGe) layer, forming a tri-layered channel heterostructure on insulator (HOI) metal oxide semiconductor field effect transistor (MOSFET) have been developed. Quantum carrier confinement ensued within both the ultrathin s-Si layers, which instigates mobility enhancement, and hence counter balances the threshold voltage roll-off induced by the strained layers in the channel region. A comparison of the conventional single s-Si on relaxed SiGe channel HOI MOSFET with double s-Si channel HOI MOSFET have been perceived leading to eloquent drain current enhancement of ~49% for channel length, L<sub>g</sub>=100nm due to the captivity of carriers with small reduction in the threshold voltage caused on the additional bottom s-Si layer. An in depth analysis of the device in the nanoscale regime for Device-B (L<sub>g</sub>=50nm) and Device-C (L<sub>g</sub>=40nm) have exemplified superior device characteristic without scaling down the overall device geometry, leading to prominence of velocity overshoot condition under low-scattering effect, augmenting mobility and drift velocity, while approaching to the quasi-ballistic transport mechanism in the channel region, therefore remarkably improving drive current of the nano-MOSFET.
1246	<strong>Diffuse discharge generation and evolution of the repetitive nanosecond pulsed dielectric barrier discharge in airflow</strong>	Diffuse dielectric barrier discharge excited by repetitive nanosecond pulses is achieved in airflow. On the introduction of airflow to the gas gap, the discharge state transforms from a filamentary one into a diffuse one at first, followed by the generation of a thin filamentary discharge at a high airflow rate. It is observed that the diffuse discharge and the thin filamentary discharge are ignited from the electrode boundary, which move towards the downstream region with a velocity below the corresponding airflow rate. Subsequent to hundreds of pulse cycles, a stationary discharge state is formed with the thin filamentary discharge in the upstream region, together with the diffuse discharge in the downstream region. The length of the thin filamentary discharge region is associated with the airflow rate, pulse repetition frequency, and applied voltage. The observations presented above are ascribed to the transverse electric field at the electrode boundary and the redistribution of charges under the action of airflow.
1247	Optical manipulation of dielectric microscopic particles and biocells using an elongated photonic jet	Flexibility trapping and manipulation of mesoscopic objects or cells in a wide range are extremely important for wide applications in physics, biology, bio-chemistry, bio-medicine, and so on. A most striking and specific feature of an elongated photonic jet (EPJ) is the extremely high spatial localization of light field in transverse direction, which can lead to a large working distance with high intensity. Based on the simulation and calculation results, we report an EPJ strategy of realizing highly flexible trapping and pushing of erythrocytes in wide-bound using a graphene-coated fiber tip. Furthermore, a photonic nanojet can also be obtained by adjusting the parameters of the EPJ.
1248	Elinvar Behavior of Deformed Fe-Ni Invar Alloy	We report a deformation induced Elinvar behavior in a prototype Fe-Ni Invar alloy. We observe that the temperature-dependent elastic modulus is associated with a premartensitic transformation characterized by forming nano-scale domains, and the transformation can be impeded by restricting the growth of nanodomains. Upon appropriate deformation, the modulus softening accompanying the transformation compensates the modulus hardening due to vibrational anharmonicity upon cooling, leading to Elinvar behavior over a wide temperature range. This work develops an alloy with Invar and Elinvar effects simultaneously, and may enhance the understanding on the nature of Invar and Elinvar anomalies from the aspect of structure.
1249	Tuning the Electronic Structure of Single-Walled Carbon Nanotube by High-Pressure H<sub>2</sub> Exposure	We report on an electronic structure change of single-walled carbon nanotube (SWNT) on hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) due to electron doping via high-pressure H<sub>2</sub> exposure. Raman spectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were carried out to support the <em>in situ</em> electrical measurements. The XPS data shows the fractional coverage of hydrogenated carbon atoms to be <em>&theta;</em><em> </em>= 0.165 (1.34 weight %), which is consistent with <em>&theta; </em>= 0.163 calculated from the <em>I</em><sub>ds</sub>-<em>V</em><sub>g</sub> measurements. In particular, we used the dissociative Langmuir-type model to yield the desorption coefficient <em>k</em><sub>des</sub> by fitting it to the <em>in situ</em> electrical data. Finally, we adopted this hydrogenation method for the SWNT network on the commercial Si/SiO<sub>2</sub> substrate to open the possibility of the scalable logic circuits made of the SWNT network with conventional semiconductor fabrication process.
1250	Numerical Investigation on Effects of Curvature and Wettability of Particle on Heterogeneous Condensation	The incipient process of water vapor condensation around an insoluble nanoscale particle is studied by Molecular Dynamics method and the emphasis is placed on the effects of nucleus surface curvature and wettability. With a high initial saturation, two different linear nucleation stages are observed. At the first stage, clusters are formed by the water molecules adsorbed on the surface such that the nucleation rate is significantly affected by both water molecule flux towards the surface and adsorption probability. The former decreases with the surface curvature and the latter is in proportion to the wettability. At the second stage, the nucleation rate is enhanced by the contribution of homogeneous clusters adsorbed to the surface and reduced by cluster merging because of the space limitation on small nucleus. As a result, the nucleation rate is basically not affected by the nucleus size. The average size of clusters keeps constant for a while, then starts to grow with a gradually increased growth rate. It is concluded that both curvature and wettability of nucleus surface promote the cluster growing.
1251	Speed-of-sound estimation of dual-acoustic waves using laser-activated nanodroplets	Inhomogeneity of speed of sound in a medium can cause degradation of photoacoustic and ultrasound signals due to phase aberration. To achieve a high coherency of the received waves in time-delay focusing during photoacoustic and ultrasound imaging, the actual speed of sound is required. This study evaluates the feasibility of a speed-of-sound estimation method for dual photoacoustic and ultrasound imaging using laser-activated phase-change perfluorohexane nanodroplets (PFHnDs). In our speed-of-sound estimation method, PFHnDs play a critical role because the nanodroplets can generate both photoacoustic and ultrasound signals upon laser irradiation. The photoacoustic waveforms generated from the PFHnDs are used to identify the actual speed of sound in the medium by iteratively comparing the estimated delay from the delay-compensated waveforms and geometric delay of the PFHnDs. The proposed method demonstrates that the estimated sound of speed (ESS) is close to the expected speed of sound for the medium (deviation = 0.3%). Compared with the typically assumed speed of sound in tissue (1,500 m/s), ESS significantly improved lateral resolution and coherence factor in the photoacoustic (up to 2.8 and 1.7 times, respectively) and ultrasound (up to 3.3 and 3.6 times, respectively) images. Therefore, the proposed speed-of-sound estimation method using PFHnDs can be useful for phase aberration correction in dual ultrasound and photoacoustic imaging.
1252	Investigation of various Magnetic features of spinel type Cobalt ferrite nanoparticles tuned by annealing temperature	Cobalt ferrite (CoFe2O4) nanoparticles synthesized by chemical co-precipitation method were studied to see the effect of annealing temperatures on the structural parameters and magnetic properties of the sample. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscope (TEM) and SAD pattern demonstrated that single face (fcc) spinel structure of CoFe2O4 has been formed showing particles in completely crystalline state which was further confirmed by the lattice parameter and the unmixed hkl values. The particle size is in the range of about 5-10 nm depending on the annealing temperature from 200{degree sign}C to 400{degree sign}C. The grain growth occurred monotonically with the increase of annealing temperature. The magnetic properties demonstrated a strong dependence on particle size. The saturation magnetization Ms, remanent ratio Mr/Ms and coercivity Hc increased with the increase of particle size. The hysteresis curves for samples of different grain size showed the ferrimagnetic behavior which is completely analogous to the slow relaxation sextet peaks of M&#x00F6;ssbauer spectroscopy. Other parameters such as chemical shift, quadruple splitting and hyperfine field and site occupancy of Fe3+ were determined by M&#x00F6;ssbauer spectroscopy. Ferrimagnetic to superparamagnetic transition temperature known as blocking temperature TB was determined from the temperature dependent magnetization curves. With the increase of grain size, Blocking temperature also increases. Maximum entropy changes due to magnetic phase transition were also observed for mentioned annealing temperatures in the context of Magnetocaloric effect.
1253	A Novel Shadow Mask Aligner based on Three Points Leveling for Wedge Error Compensation	This paper reports a novel shadow mask aligner, which is capable of aligning planar with ~ 1 &#x00B5;m alignment error as well as provision to compensate the wedge error by using movements of three precision linear actuators, spotted under optical microscope. The use of three points leveling also overcomes the common error of the upper assembly bending, which could occur with time after its continuous use. The reported wafer/ mask holding mechanism is able to accommodate substrates of 3 inch to 6 inch diameter. The unique magnetic clamping mechanism after alignment has been successfully demonstrated. The fabricated system is useful for alignment of mask and wafer, as well as for other applications like  nano-imprint and micro-contact printing lithography, where molds/ stamp has to be aligned with the patterned/ un-patterned target substrate; to create complex 3D structures, micro-assembly of independently fabricated 2D components by proper aligning and clamping.
1254	<strong>A Surface Potential based Compact Model for 2D-FETs with Disorders Induced Transition Behaviors</strong>	A surface potential based compact model for two-dimensional field effect transistors (2D-FETs) is proposed to incorporate the structural disorders induced transition behaviors among variable range hopping (VRH), nearest neighbor hopping (NNH), and band-like transport in most 2D materials. These functions coupled with effective transport energy and multiple trapping and releasing theory enable our developed model to predict the temperature and carrier density dependent current characteristics. Its validity is confirmed by the experimental results such as the metal insulator transition (MIT) in transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) and VRH-NNH transition in black phosphorus nanoribbon (BPNR). Based on this model, the band-tail effects on the crossover gate voltage of MIT behavior are quantitatively investigated. It is found that the transition behavior is closely related to the distribution of the band-tail states. Furthermore, this model is implemented in Verilog-A for circuit-level prediction and evaluation of 2D-FETs to provide deeper insight into the relationship between material properties, device physics and circuit performances.
1255	<strong>Effect of gadolinium on magnetization, MCD and EMR of </strong><strong>&epsilon;-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles arising in borate glasses</strong>	A series of K<sub>2</sub>O-Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-B<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> glasses doped with 1.5 mass % of Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and different concentrations of Gd<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>from 0.1 to 1.0 mass % was prepared using a conventional melt quenching technique and subjected to an additional thermal treatment. The morphology and structure of the glasses were characterized by means of energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy and high resolution electron microscopy. Static magnetic measurements, magnetic circular dichroism and electron magnetic resonance (EMR) were used to study the properties of the glasses. In all thermally treated glasses magnetic nanoparticles are formed. The distribution of the dopants in the glass matrix and the nanoparticle characteristics greatly depend on Gd<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> contents. The nanoparticle structure and magnetic characteristics bear a certain similarity with those of &epsilon;- Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>. Meanwhile, in the presence of Gd<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> Gd<sup>3+</sup> ions are partially substituting Fe<sup>3+</sup> ions in the nanoparticle lattice, thus altering their structural parameters and lowering the nanoparticle magnetization. Analysis and computer simulations of EMR spectra of the glasses allow separating the contribution of electron paramagnetic resonance of diluted iron ions and demonstrate a superparamagnetic character of the nanoparticle EMR.
1256	<strong>Enhanced pyroelectric properties of 1-3 nanocomposites achieved by uniaxial stretching</strong>	Ceramic-polymer pyroelectric composites with favorable flexibility hold great potential for wearable sensors and energy harvesters, and the further improvement in pyroelectric properties would push them closer to practical application. In this work, we propose a uniaxial stretching method to optimize the perfor&shy;mance of lead zirconate titanate nanowires (PZT NWs)/polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) 1-3 composites with a combination of the enhanced pyroelectric coefficient by inducing more <em>&beta;</em> phase PVDF and decreased permittivity by reorientation of NWs in the polymer matrix. As a result, the figure of merit (FOM) of the stretched composite with orientated PZT NWs increases to the value of 2.18&times;10<sup>-10</sup> C&middot;cm<sup>-2</sup>&middot;K<sup>-1</sup>, which is 619% higher than that of untreated samples around room temperature. This work could provide an efficient approach to fabricate high-performance ceramic-polymer pyroelectric composites.
1257	Mean-field density functional theory of a nanoconfined classical, three-dimensional Heisenberg fluid. II. The interplay between molecular packing and orientational order	As in part I of this series of papers [S. M. Cattes et al., J. Chem. Phys. 144, 194704 (2016)], we study a Heisenberg fluid confined to a nanoscopic slit pore with smooth walls. The pore walls can either energetically discriminate specific orientations of the molecules next to them or are indifferent to molecular orientations. Unlike in part I we employ a version of classical density functional theory that allows us to explicitly account for the stratification of the fluid (i.e., the formation of molecular layers) as a consequence of the symmetry-breaking presence of the pore walls. We treat this stratification within the White Bear version (Mark I) of fundamental measure theory. Thus, in this work we focus on the interplay between local packing of the molecules and orientational features. In particular, we demonstrate why a critical end point can only exist if the pore walls are not energetically discriminating specific molecular orientations. We analyze in detail the positional and orientational order of the confined fluid and show that reorienting molecules across the pore space can be a two-dimensional process. Last but not least, we propose an algorithm based upon a series expansion of Bessel functions of the first kind with which we can solve certain types of integrals in a very efficient manner.
1258	The evolution of structural topology of forming nanocrystalline silicon film by atomic-scale mechanism-driven model based on realistic continuous network	In order to establish the description of realistic structural evolution of growth film&#xFF0C;we propose a local definite continuous random network (CRN) structure combination with kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) method based on the atomic-scale mechanism from first-principles density-functional-theory computations and molecular-dynamics computations to elucidate the evolution of elaborate topological structure and the transformation from amorphous phase to nanocrystalline phase of silicon films, which is essentially attributed to the atomic interactive behavior of film growth. It predicts the realistic structural networks of growing film at various temperatures based on various atomic-scale mechanisms competing with each others, which not only essentially drive the radical from physisorption to chemisorption with film surface, but also cruelly influence the chemical composition of film surface. Especially, we find the evolution of topological structure critical dependence on the compositions of film surface and H-induced crystallization mechanism, which give the important information to the optimized strategy of deposition condition for forming local crystalline. The results of evolution of structural network indicate that the structure of film is similar the continuous random network model's representation at relative lower temperature, and is in full agreement with the inhomogeneous crystalline model at relative higher temperature. Our CRN-KMC realistic structure model has significances for exploring the relation of various atomic-scale mechanisms to the phase transformation of growing film.
1259	<strong>From MoO<sub>2</sub>@MoS<sub>2</sub> Core-shell Nanorods to MoS<sub>2</sub> Nanobelts</strong>	One-dimensional (1D) atomically thin crystals have attracted considerable interests due to their unique properties and potential applications. For example, reducing graphene physical size down to nanoscale to nanoribbons opens up band gaps, which makes graphene useful in electronic devices. Here, we report a facile approach to produce single- and bi-layered MoS<sub>2</sub> nanobelts by PMMA assisted decoupling of MoO<sub>2</sub>@MoS<sub>2</sub> core-shell nanorods. Atomic force microscopy (AFM), Raman and photoluminescence (PL) results show that the decoupled monolayer staple-like MoS<sub>2</sub>-shells can fold into bilayer nanobelts or not depending on the PMMA removal method. Raman, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) results reveal that the left MoO<sub>2</sub> nanorods exhibit high crystal-quality. Our findings provide a method to produce 1D MoS<sub>2</sub> or MoO<sub>2</sub> nanomaterials, which have potential applications in electronics and catalysis.
1260	<strong>Entropy analysis for radiative flow of Cu and SWCNT-nanofluid past static/moving wedge subject to viscous dissipation and convective condition</strong>	<em>The steady tow-dimensional boundary layer flow of nanofluid by static or moving wedge is studied. Entropy generation is analyzed in the presence of thermal radiation and viscous dissipation with convective boundary condition. Two different types of nanoparticles, namely copper Cu and single wall carbon nanotube SWCNT with water as the base fluid are considered. The governing partial differential equations (PDE) are transformed into a set of nonlinear ordinary differential equations (ODE). The optimal homotopy asymptotic method (OHAM) is applied to derive an explicit analytical solution, which provides an effective technique for solving strongly nonlinear ordinary differential equations. The analytical results of the dimensionless temperature and velocity have been validated with </em><em>fourth-fifth order Runge-Kutta-Fehlberg numerical solution and numerous researchers results [28,48-50]. Further the analytical results for the entropy generation number and Bejan number are also presented These results show the effects of thermal, dynamic and geometric parameters on entropy production.</em>
1261	Dramatic enhancement in heat conduction ability of graphene nanoplatelets through edge compared to basal plane functionalization	We demonstrate, through molecular dynamics simulations and non-equilibrium Green&rsquo;s function calculations, that edge-functionalized graphene nanoplatelets can provide up to 70% higher enhancement in thermal conductivity of polymer composites compared to basal plane functionalized nanoplatelets. This larger effectiveness of edge-bonded nanoplatelets is found to be due to a combination of two effects, first, edge bonding couples all of the layers of the nanoplatelet with the polymer matrix, enabling the entire nanoplatelet to be effective in heat transfer, and second, interface thermal conductance is found to be higher for a polymer chain bonded on the edge compared to basal plane of the nanoplatelet. Understanding of the role of nanoplatelet geometry and grafting density of polymer chains in modifying the advantage of edge bonding is provided. These results can have important implications for developing high thermal conductivity polymer-graphene nanocomposites.
1262	Atmospheric pressure Non-thermal Plasma-liquid interactions for template-free synthesis of Al doped CdS nanorods	In this study, Al doped CdS nanorods were grown via a novel non-thermal plasma-liquid interaction (PLI) at atmospheric pressure. Cd (SO4), Al (NO3)3 and Na2S2O3 were used as precursors and Thioglycolic acid as capping agent. Crystalline structure, morphology and optical properties of nanomaterials have been characterized by means of X-ray diffraction (XRD), Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), photoluminescence (PL) and UV-Vis analyses. XRD patterns showed that as Al incorporates into CdS, the hexagonal phase of CdS developed in new crystalline planes. The FESEM imaging confirmed that one directional Al doped CdS nanorods (NRs) were fabricated via PLI method. It was also depicted that NRs size increases simultaneously when plasma treatment time increases till it reaches a diameter and length of 80 and 500nm, respectively, after 50 minutes of plasma treatment. EDS analysis demonstrated that Al was introduced in CdS structure successfully via this plasma method. The optimal PL intensity of QD NRs was reached after 40min synthesis time and Al concentration of 1%. Also as treatment time increases, PL and absorption spectra is red-shifted. The nanostructures indicated a good activity for methyl orange photo-degradation as a pollution, in which the activity largely increased after Al-doping. Impedance spectroscopy indicated an enhancement of the electron transport via Al insertion in CdS nanorods.
1263	<strong>Role of the conducting polyaniline interphase on the electric and magnetic transport of manganite nanocomposites</strong>	In the present report, we aim to show the synergistic effect of conducting polyaniline and manganite based nanocomposites focusing on the electrical and magneto-electric transport. We gave special attention on the different contribution of both, manganite nanoparticles and conducting polyaniline thin interphase, in a broad range of temperatures and low applied magnetic fields. Our results showed a small increment on the electrical conductivity and enhancement on the magnetoresistance for low polyaniline additions with respect to the manganite unloaded samples. We also found that close to room temperature, the changes in magnetoresistance are mostly due to an increment of the spin polarization and the spin disorder with respect to pure manganites. However, at intermediate temperatures (T=200 K) the polyaniline interphase intrinsic magnetoresistance showed a notorious contribution to the total negative magnetoresistance response. At low temperatures, no enhancement on the magnetoresistance response was observed, possibly due to a negative-to-positive transition of polyaniline intrinsic magnetoresistance.
1264	<strong>Tears of an evaporating meniscus </strong>	We identify the formation of an unstable rim at the three-phase contact line of an evaporating methanol meniscus due to the autophobic nature of the liquid. Undulations along the rim rupture at a consistent frequency, leaving behind a regular pattern of droplet tears as the contact line recedes. We characterize the geometry and undulation dynamics of the rim. The rim movement exhibits slip at the contact line; the measured ratio of rim width to undulation wavelength matches the critical unstable Rayleigh ratio for an intermediate slip regime. Unlike previously observed rim instabilities, the rim volume here is replenished from the evaporating bulk meniscus and maintains a constant thickness, such that the instability wavelength remains constant and droplets are generated with a consistent, nano-liter volume and deposited in a regular pattern. Occurrence of this unstable rim during an evaporation-driven dewetting process may allow for rapid, controlled deposition of small droplets from the fast-moving contact line of a highly volatile fluid.
1265	Mophology dependence of low temperatures exchange bias Co/CoO core-shell nanoparticles/spheres by eco-friendly solvothermal route	The present work reports the magnetic effect of particle shape and superparamagnetic property in a Co/CoO core-shell exchange bias system. Co/CoO core-shell nanoparticles/spheres (NPSs) of different sizes including regular and irregular mophologies were synthesized by the decomposition of cobalt acetate under solvothermal conditions. Unlike irregular nanoparticles with excess PVP stabilizer, the Co/CoO NPSs with stabilizer are uniform spheres because the size and shape of these samples can be well tuned by suitable stabilizer. Regular and irregular Co/CoO NPSs all display superparamagnetism at room temperature. It can be seen in hysteresis loop patterns that the saturation magnetization (MS) values of the Co/CoO NPSs are 100.6, 76.1, and 75.9 emu/g, whose diameters are 16, 200 and 300 nm, respectively. The measurements are carried out after the field-cooling at different temperatures across the Neel temperature of the antiferromagnetic (AFM) CoO shell. It's a surprise that all of regular Co/CoO NPSs reveal exchange bias field at low temperature whereas irregular ones disappear. what's more with the reducing ferromagnetic (FM) Co core diameter, the exchange bias increases.
1266	<strong>Enhanced anharmonic coupling of surface optical phonon with Raman scattering in CdTe thin film</strong>	Surface optical phonon modes (SO) are characteristic atomic vibrations confined within the first several atom layers of the free surface of a polar solid material. Raman scattering of the SO modes is hardly to be observed due to extremely weak scattering from the few surface atom layers. In principle the SO modes are associated with a long-range Fr&ouml;ehlich interaction with the optical modes in a polar material and would lead to strong or weak anharmonic coupling with these modes depending on mode polarization. This coupling in an ultra-thin film would have a profound effect on carrier transport when a polar material is the active layer in an electronic device. In this report both the SO and the bulk Raman scattering efficiency were dramatically enhanced in CdTe thin films by employing silver nano-plasmonic enhanced Raman scattering and maximized free surface atomic vibration. Raman scattering phonon overtones of the longitudinal optical mode (A1 LO) up to the fifth order were observed. Strong and rich information on the multi-phonon anharmonic coupling of the SO with the LO mode and the overtones were well resolved and clarified.
1267	Synthesis of &beta;-FeSi<sub>2</sub> nanowires by using silicon nanowire templates	Si nanowires templates were grown by a Cu-catalyzed vapor&ndash;liquid&ndash;solid process and used for the preparation of &beta;-FeSi<sub>2</sub> nanowires on a Si substrate. The silicon nanowires were transformed into &beta;-FeSi<sub>2</sub> nanowires by annealing with additional source material containing FeCl<sub>2</sub> and Si powder. In contrast to uniform Si nanowire templates along the &lt;111&gt; direction, the synthesized nanowires were deformed irregularly. The electron diffraction pattern of the nanowires synthesized from the template corresponded to that of single-crystalline &beta;-FeSi<sub>2</sub> and the longitudinal direction of the nanowire was along the &lt;104&gt; direction. The energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence analysis confirmed that the nanowire contained Fe and Si in an atomic ratio of approximately 1:2. The results confirmed that &beta;-FeSi<sub>2</sub> nanowires on a Si substrate were synthesized from the Si nanowire templates.
1268	Appearance of ferromagnetism property for Si nano-polycrystalline body and vanishing of electrical resistances at local high frequencies	Reduction in the skin effect for the sintered Si nanopolycrystalline body as an electricity conductor at a high frequency was studied. Singular vanishing of electrical resistances, close to 0 m&#x03A9;, near a local high magnetic harmonic frequency of a few MHz was observed at room temperature. Also, negative resistance was observed. It will be applicable to electronic transmittance lines or semiconductors. Sintered Si nano-polycrystalline body has ferromagnetism judged by the measured magnetization property. High-density dangling bonds cause the sintered Si nanopolycrystalline to have ferromagnetism. The density of the unpaired electrons in the sintered Si nanopolycrystalline was estimated using ESR.
1269	The ultrafast charge transfer in the CVD-grown WS<sub>2</sub>/WSe<sub>2</sub> heterostructure	A WS<sub>2</sub>/WSe<sub>2</sub> heterostructure is constructed by stacking a WS<sub>2</sub> monolayer on the top of WSe<sub>2</sub> monolayer fabricated with chemical vapor deposition (CVD) technique. Ultrafast transient spectroscopy is used to demonstrate the ultrafast charge transfer and dynamics in the heterostructure. When the WS<sub>2</sub>/WSe<sub>2</sub> heterostructure was photoexcitated at 617 nm (A-exciton of WS<sub>2</sub>), an ultrafast photobleaching was observed around the A-exciton transition of WSe<sub>2</sub> layer at 749 nm. The bleaching signal lasts several nanosecond, which is much longer than the A-exciton lifetime in both the WS<sub>2</sub> and WSe<sub>2</sub> monolayer film. Moreover, by selectively photoexcited the heterostructure at wavelength of 749 nm (A-exciton of WSe<sub>2</sub>), an ultrafast photobleaching was identified around the A-exciton transition of WS<sub>2</sub>, the recovery of the bleaching shows a single exponential relaxation with typical time constant of ~1.8 ps. The very fast relaxation in the heterostructure probing around 620 nm suggests that there are rich defect states in WS<sub>2</sub>, which can trap these electrons transferred from the WSe<sub>2</sub> upon photoexcitation.
