Our spectroscopic results reveal that our CVD-grown WS<sub>2</sub>/WSe<sub>2</sub> bilayer film has a type II heterostructure in nature at room temperature. With photoexcitation, electrons and holes can be separately confined in WS<sub>2</sub> and WSe<sub>2</sub> layer, respectively.
1270	Modeling of Electron and Phonon Contributions to Thermal Conductivity of Crystalline and Amorphous TiN Nanotubes in the Sub 20 nm Regime	Size reduction in microelectromechanical systems leads to a more complex treatment of physical parameters affected by quantum mechanical effects. Besides specific electrical resistance, thermal conductivity is a characteristic variable for designing application-specific MEMS. Nanotubes are able to realize an electrical contact between a sensor element and CMOS substrate by an increased thermal isolation. A model for the prediction of thermal conductivity of nanotubes, compounded of alloys like titanium nitride, is presented here. Therefore crystal structure is taken into account to demonstrate the most limiting parameters of mean free path for electrons and phonons in thin layer geometries in combination with an 3D-2D transition in density of states. Concerning these effects, the dominating thermal conductance mechanism varies between phonons and electrons in TiN.
1271	<strong>Au-Si plasmonic platforms: synthesis, structure and FDTD simulation</strong>	Plasmonic platforms based on Au nanostructures have been successfully synthesized by directional solidification of eutectic of Au thin films. In order to determine homogeneous shape and space distribution, the influence of annealing conditions and the initial thickness of Au film on nanostructures was analyzed. For the surface morphology studies, SEM and AFM measurements were performed. The structure of platforms was investigated using XRD and XPS methods. Structural investigations confirmed, that nanostructures consist of metallic Au,  growing in (111) direction. The most homogeneous seems to be platform obtained by solidification of 2.8 nm Au film, annealed at 550&deg;C for 15 min. This sample was subsequently chosen for theoretical calculations. Simulations of electromagnetic field propagation through the produced samples were  performed using FDTD method. The calculated absorbance, as a result of the FDTD simulation shows a quite good agreement with experimental data, obtained in UV-Vis range.
1272	<strong>Synthesized Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> nanoflowers coated Mach Zehnder Interferometer as magnetometer with large dynamic range</strong>	Promising application after synthesis of Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> nanoflowers to stimulate magnetic field detection in large dynamic range using Mach Zehnder Interferometric approach is presented. Technology relevant aspects of present study and current limitations are also highlighted. Earlier developed sensors for the magnetic field detection using magnetic fluid covers up to around 400 mT, which limits the application for higher magnetic field sensing. In present study, we first time proposed a fiber optic Mach Zehnder interferometer (MZI) based magnetic field sensor in the range of 0 to 1.5 Tesla by optimizing the coating of prepared magnetic nanoflower around the sensing probe. The interaction between modes of tapered fiber and <em>magnetic nanoflowers coated on the probe, shift the interference pattern on the application of applied magnetic field. This facilitates in providing larger operating range to the device which can be used in Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) for online monitoring of magnetic field.</em>
1273	Field operating window of nanodevices employing the domain wall propagation through the stripes intersection: numerical optimization	In this paper, we present the detailed numerical study of the domain wall (DW) dynamics in thin magnetic stripes and in nanostructures containing intersections of such stripes. We focus on the DW propagation through these intersections (crosses), because they are the key element in field-based multiturn sensors and magnetic logic devices. The DW propagation through such intersections is the main bottleneck by ensuring the functional reliability of the above mentioned devices due to the strong pinning of a DW at these crosses and the risk that a wrong cross 'shoulder' is reversed by the DW propagation. By means of micromagnetic simulations, the operating field range for the desired DW propagation through the stripes intersection in devices with a constant stripe width is determined and the drawbacks of this simple design are discussed. To overcome these drawbacks, we suggest a new sensor design employing the stripes with a modulated width. We show that sensors with this design are expected to have a higher reliability, and that their field operating window can be controlled in a more flexible way.
1274	Evidence of interface driven thermal rectification in a graphene-bilayer graphene junction	We report on a series of controlled computational experiments based on nonequilibrium molecular dynamics and show that at the nanoscale the thermal rectification is determined by the thermal boundary resistance and cannot be explained without it. In the graphene--bilayer graphene system that we study, the sign of the thermal rectification is opposite to the value predicted based on bulk-derived models, i.e. phonons preferentially flow in the opposite direction, outlining the importance of properly accounting for the active role of the interface.
1275	Long-lived quantum speedup based on plasmonic hot spot systems	Long-lived quantum speedup serves as a fundamental component for quantum algorithms. The quantum walk is identified as an ideal scheme to realize the long-lived quantum speedup. However, one finds that the duration of quantum speedup is too short in real systems to implement the quantum algorithms. The speedup can last only dozens of femtoseconds in the photosynthetic light-harvesting system, which was regarded as the best candidate for quantum information processing. Here, we construct one plasmonic system with two-level molecules embodied in the hot spots of one-dimensional nanoparticle chains to realize the long-lived quantum speedup. The coherent and incoherent coupling parameters in the system are obtained by means of Green's tensor technique. Our results reveal that the duration of quantum speedup in our scheme can exceed 500 fs under strong coherent coupling conditions, which is several times larger than that in the photosynthetic light-harvesting system. Our proposal presents a competitive scheme to realize the long-lived quantum speedup, which is very beneficial for quantum algorithms.
1276	Dramatic enhancement in heat conduction ability of graphene nanoplatelets through edge compared to basal plane functionalization	We demonstrate, through molecular dynamics simulations and non-equilibrium Green&rsquo;s function calculations, that edge-functionalized graphene nanoplatelets can provide up to 70% higher enhancement in thermal conductivity of polymer composites compared to basal plane functionalized nanoplatelets. This larger effectiveness of edge-bonded nanoplatelets is found to be due to a combination of two effects, first, edge bonding couples all of the layers of the nanoplatelet with the polymer matrix, enabling the entire nanoplatelet to be effective in heat transfer, and second, interface thermal conductance is found to be higher for a polymer chain bonded on the edge compared to basal plane of the nanoplatelet. Understanding of the role of nanoplatelet geometry and grafting density of polymer chains in modifying the advantage of edge bonding is provided. These results can have important implications for developing high thermal conductivity polymer-graphene nanocomposites.
1277	Stable plasmon excitations in quantum nanowires	Stable electrostatic plasmon excitations due to propagation of Gaussian electron pulse are studied in a cylindrical nanowire of radius "a" and length "L". For this purpose, we consider conduction electrons that follow the quantum hydrodynamical model to account for quantum statistics, quantum diffraction and exchange-correlation effects in the presence of classical static ions. The use of well-known Fourier transform technique and Trivelpiece-Gould configuration leads to the generalized dispersion for plasmon with finite mode quantization effects via the radial and azimuthal mode indices, as well with quantum settings. The excitations of plasmon wakefield appear when the electron beam propagates with a constant velocity along the axial direction of nanowire. The stability conditions are also analyzed for the existentence of wakefield excitations by solving three important inequalities using typical parameters of gold nanowire. The results may prove useful for understanding the plasmon excitations in quantum nanowires, where electrons can be trapped and accelerated in the wakefield to emit radiation in the extreme-ultraviolet range.
1278	Transient Analysis of Avalanche Transistor-based Marx Circuit with Pulse Output of Sub-nanosecond Rise Time and High Repetition Frequency	Avalanche transistor-based Marx circuit can produce the short pulse with sub-nanosecond rise time and several kilovolts (kV) amplitude, which is used in ultra-wideband (UWB) radiation, bioelectromagnetics, discharge plasma, and etc. The main contribution of this paper is the analysis of two transient processes for this kind Marx circuit to produce pulses. For the transient analysis of pulse forming process, the signal integrity is crucial due to the high frequency characteristic. A Marx circuit model considering segmented transmission line is established, which not only contains the distribution parameters, but also can be used to analyze the traveling wave process in the pulse forming process. The transient analysis of charging process is divided into three periods, and the transistor recovery process after avalanche breakdown is focused on. The main limiting factors affecting the avalanche recovery time is analyzed considering the physical mechanism of avalanche breakdown, which restricts the highest repetition frequency of output pulses. Based on the two transient processes, some new circuit designs are presented, including the adjustment of the pulse tail, the multistage series of Marx circuit for pulse amplitude modulation and high repetition frequency Marx circuit.
1279	Percolation probability in a system of cylindrical particles	A broad variety of materials, ranging from composites and heat transfer nano-fluids to electrochemical energy storage electrodes, widely employ cylindrical particles of various aspect ratios, such as carbon nanotubes. These particles are generally excellent conductors of heat and electricity, and when dispersed in a continuous medium influence dramatically the transport properties of the heterogeneous material by forming a percolating network. While significant numerical and analytical works explore the critical particle density leading to the onset of percolation, there is less work devoted to the heterogenous material's properties at particle densities significantly beyond percolation threshold. The most widely-used theory is based on the scaling hypothesis, which is only appropriate for small deviations from percolation threshold. In an effort to develop analytical theories based on network microstructure rather than the scaling hypothesis, we here present an analytical probabilistic model capturing the contact number distribution and percolation probability at all particle concentrations for a network of randomly positioned, soft-core, cylindrical particles with finite aspect ratio. We show that our analytical theory agrees well with numerical and experimental results predicting the percolation threshold. Our theory further predicts a scaling parameter, the particle aspect ratio multiplied by particle concentration, and networks with identical values are expected to exhibit similar macroscopic behavior. The model presented here capturing the percolating network topology can serve as the foundation for analytical composition-structure-property relationships for heterogeneous materials with conducting cylindrical particles.
1280	Space-charge and current non-uniformities, and contact resistivity of end-bonded metal contacts to thin heavily doped semiconductor nanowires	Prior work calculated the contact resistivity, <em>&rho;<sub>cN</sub></em>, of <em>end-bonded</em> metal contacts on n-type silicon NanoWires (NWs) of radius, <em>R</em> = 5-10 nm<sup> </sup>and doping, <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> = 10<sup>18</sup>-10<sup>20</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup>; it described the internal physics briefly and qualitatively, and considered long NWs and high barrier heights, <em>&Phi;</em><em><sub>b0</sub></em> = 0.8-1.0 V. The present work extends the <em>&rho;<sub>cN </sub></em>calculations to low <em>&Phi;<sub>b0</sub></em> = 0.4-0.6 V contacts with long NWs, and to low to high <em>&Phi;<sub>b0</sub></em> = 0.4-0.8 V contacts with short NWs of length, <em>L<sub>NW</sub></em> &le; long NW space-charge width. It calculates the space-charge and current distributions in contacts with <em>L<sub>NW</sub></em> = 50 nm - 2 &mu;m and low to high <em>&Phi;<sub>b0</sub></em> = 0.4-0.8 V to provide the following insights: (i) Radial non-uniformity in space-charge width and current are high enough to violate the plane space-charge edge assumption employed to model NW junctions analytically. The non-uniformity peaks at <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> where bulk depletion width &asymp; 2.14<em>R</em>, for large metal and small surface charge. (ii) Low <em>&Phi;<sub>b0</sub></em> contacts are tunneling dominated, and their <em>&rho;<sub>cN</sub></em> versus <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> behavior differs qualitatively from that of high <em>&Phi;<sub>b0 </sub></em>contacts. (iii) Practical <em>L<sub>NW</sub></em> can be &le; long NW space-charge width, for <em>N<sub>d</sub></em> &le; 10<sup>19</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup>. Shortening the <em>L<sub>NW</sub></em> reduces the space-charge non-uniformity and increases (reduces) the tunneling (GR) current. However, the current non-uniformity is unaffected, and the change in current or <em>&rho;<sub>cN </sub></em>is disproportionately smaller than that in <em>L<sub>NW</sub></em>, since the tunneling or GR causing these occur over a small region near the junction that is less affected by NW shortening.
1281	<strong>Compression and Shear Behavior </strong><strong>of Ultrathin Coated Nanoporous Gold: A Molecular Dynamics Study</strong>	This paper investigates the compressive and shear properties of nanoporous gold (np-Au) coated with different ultrathin metallic materials (i.e., platinum and silver) via molecular dynamics simulations. Atomistic models used for the geometric representation of coated and uncoated np-Au structures are generated through a new modelling technique, which is based on the Voronoi tessellation method. Three different coating thickness values are used to examine the role of thickness for the coating performance under compressive and shear loading by comparing the mechanical characteristics of the atomistic models such as Young's modulus, yield, and ultimate strengths. Moreover, adaptive common neighbor analyses (aCNA) are carried out by monitoring the evolution of the crystal structure of the specimens during the loading process. In this way, the deformation mechanisms of coated and uncoated nanoporous specimens are identified thoroughly. As a main finding from the simulation results, it is observed that the mechanical properties of np-Au are highly dependent on the type of the coating material. However, a significant improvement on the toughness within the plastic regime is demonstrated for all types of coating materials and loading conditions.
1282	<strong><SPAN style="font-size: 14.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Solution-Processed graphene oxide and molybdenum oxide (GO: MoO<sub>3</sub>) nanocomposite as hole transport layer in Polymer Solar Cells</SPAN></strong>	<SPAN style="font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Organic solar cells (OSCs) have shown a great attraction worldwide as a low-cost photovoltaic technologies for the conversion of solar energy into electrical energy. Recently, the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of ~ 15% has been achieved in OSCs by the researchers due to their continuous efforts. Interfacial layer engineering is one of the parameters which plays an important role (electron transport layer, ETL or hole transport layer, HTL) in enhancing the PCE and the stability of OSCs. Hence, tailoring of interfacial layer materials and their impact on the performance of OSCs should be understood in-depth. Therefore, herein we demonstrate a simple method of direct blending of graphene oxide (GO) with MoO<sub>3</sub> to form GO:MoO<sub>3 </sub>nanocomposite. The morphology of graphene oxide (GO), MoO<sub>3</sub> and GO: MoO<sub>3</sub> is analysed using XRD and SEM characterization techniques. Further, we have fabricated OSCs having the structure of ITO/GO/PCDTBT:PC<sub>71</sub>BM/Al, ITO/MoO<sub>3</sub>/PCDTBT:PC<sub>71</sub>BM/Al and ITO/GO:MoO<sub>3</sub>/PCDTBT:PC<sub>71</sub>BM/Al, in which the active layer consists of <SPAN style="letter-spacing: .3pt; background: white;">Poly[N-9&prime;-heptadecanyl-2,7-carbazole-alt-5,5-(4&prime;,7&prime;-di-2-thienyl-2&prime;,1&prime;,3&prime;benzothiadiazole)](PCDTBT) </SPAN><SPAN style="font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; letter-spacing: .3pt; background: white;">:</SPAN><SPAN style="font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">[6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester (PC<sub>71</sub>BM) as donor and acceptor respectively. We compared the results of the fabricated devices experimentally along with its theoretical simulation and found that the device having GO:MoO<sub>3</sub> nanocomposite as hole transport layer exhibit better device parameters with respect to GO and MoO<sub>3</sub> as HTL. Hence, GO: MoO<sub>3</sub> is better hole transporting/electron blocking layer for OSCs. </SPAN></SPAN><SPAN style="font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"></SPAN>
1283	Comparing between low F and high Si concentrations influencing on structures, mechanical and tribological properties of diamond-like carbon films	The results obtained from a study of the influence of low F and high Si concentrations on the properties of diamond-like carbon films are reported. The structures of the films were characterized using Auger electron spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy and atomic force microscopy. The mechanical properties, including adhesion strength, hardness and elastic modulus, were evaluated by scratch and nanoindentation hardness testing. The friction behavior was assessed using ball-on-disk friction testing and optical microscopy. The results indicated that the deposited DLC films contained 0.6-4.9 at.% F and 26.7-39.5 at.% Si. The addition of F and Si to the DLC film affected the growth rate: a decreasing growth trend was observed with increasing F content, and an increasing trend was observed with as the amount of Si in the films increased. The root-mean-square roughness increased when F and Si were doped into DLC films (approximately 2.6 and 1.3 times increased for the F-DLC and Si-DLC films, respectively). However, a decrease of 1.5 times in the hardness and elastic modulus was obtained as F increased in concentration, which was the opposite of the behavior observed in the Si-DLC films with an increase of 1.1 times. This was due to the shifting in the G-peak position. Furthermore, the strong adhesion between the film and the substrate was observed in both the F-DLC and Si-DLC films of approximately 1.2 and 1.4 times compared to the pure DLC film. When measured in ambient air, the addition of Si into the DLC film strongly influenced the friction coefficient, whereas doping with F only slightly influenced the films, as shown by their wear scars. Only a 4.9 at.% F-DLC film exhibited poor mechanical properties, i.e., low hardness and elastic modulus, causing easy peel off and high friction coefficients compared to the results from the DLC film. In addition, the pure DLC, 0.6 at.% F-DLC and 26.7 at.% Si-DLC films showed super low friction coefficients when measured in dry air, as evidenced by their wear scars. Therefore, the addition of low F (0.6 at.%) and high Si (26.7 at.%) concentrations to DLC films can be considered beneficial for improving mechanical and tribological performance.
1284	Electroviscous effect and electrokinetic energy conversion in time periodic pressure-driven flow through a circular nanotube with surface charge-dependent slip	Electroviscous effect and electrokinetic energy conversion efficiency of time periodic pressure-driven flow of incompressible viscous Newtonian liquid through a nanotube with surface charge-dependent slip are studied using a separation of variable technique. Electric potential, velocity and streaming electric field are obtained analytically and further energy conversion efficiency is computed using them. The effects of surface charge-dependent slip and electroviscous effect on velocity and energy conversion efficiency are mainly discussed. The main results show that the velocity amplitude and energy conversion efficiency of the surface charge-dependent flow are reduced compared with those of the surface charge-independent flow.
1285	Food Analysis Employing High Energy Nanosecond Laser and Low Pressure He Ambient Gas	We report the results of an experimental study of food analysis using Nd:YAG nanosecond (ns) laser at various pulse energies in atmospheric ambient air and He ambient gas at different pressures. In contrary to previous results indicating the unfavorable applications of LIBS to food analysis using lower pulse energies and atmospheric ambient air, this study demonstrates clearly the excellent spectral quality obtained from a number of food samples of different hardnesses with high energy (132 mJ) ns laser pulses and 20 Torr He ambient gas. A series of energy dependent intensity measurements show that the intensities generally increase with higher laser energies and harder samples which can be attributed to the generation of stronger shock wave plasma and the subsequently induced He assisted excitation (HAE) mechanism which is responsible for the sharp emission lines and the very low spectral background. Using mochi samples with different Cu impurity contents, this experiment further reveals the existence of a linear calibration line and a detection limit of sub ppm level. The results of this study have thus suggested the promising development of low cost and practical technique for quantitative food analysis in place of more expensive and bulkies picosecond laser used before.
1286	<strong>Characterization of longitudinal acoustic phonons in InGaAsP multi</strong><strong>ple </strong><strong>quantum well</strong><strong>s</strong><strong> by asynchronous optical sampling</strong>	We performed time-resolved reflectivity measurements and characterized the time-varying oscillations of longitudinal acoustic phonons in InGaAsP multiple quantum wells (MQWs) by asynchronous optical sampling with Er-doped fiber lasers. Oscillations of longitudinal acoustic phonons ranging from a few tens to a few hundred gigahertz were observed, which were induced by forward and backward Raman scattering in unfolded and first zone-folded acoustic phonon modes. To characterize the time-varying oscillations of each phonon mode, we analyzed the experimental data with a continuous wavelet transformation. While the oscillations of the first zone-folded acoustic phonons vanished in less than a nanosecond, the oscillations of the unfolded acoustic phonons lasted up to a few nanoseconds, which is more than one order of magnitude longer than the propagation time in the MQW.
1287	<strong>THz Bio-Chemical Sensor </strong>	Optical methods have been essential in the field of chemical and biological analysis, and the terahertz (THz) spectral region has received tremendous attention for its low energy characteristics which allows for non-destructive sensing. However, a major hindrance to terahertz bio-chemical sensing is the large absorption of terahertz radiation in an aqueous environment. Here, we overcome the limitation of high absorption of water in the THz frequency region through experimental demonstration of a metamaterial sensing platform that confines aqueous solution in nanometric volume. Split-ring resonator (SRR) and Fano resonator were selected as typical metamaterial configuration for sensing, and both resonator design exhibit clear resonance in the transmitted THz spectrum under aqueous environment. As a demonstration of chemical sensing, the THz spectra of three alcoholic solutions with different concentrations were measured. Selective adenosine triphosphate (ATP) sensing was demonstrated through ATP-aptamer functionalization on gold metamaterials, where a decrease in the transmittance value was observed as the ATP concentration increased. Hence, the device allows for sensing of chemical and biological samples in aqueous solution in the THz region. The proposed sensing approach have the potential to be an effective tool for molecular analysis through exploiting the advantages offered by THz wave resonant with metamaterials and integrated with nanofluidic technologies.
1288	<strong>Strain Engineering the Structures and Electronic Properties of </strong><strong>Janus Monolayer Transition-metal Dichalcogenides</strong>	Using first-principles calculations, we studied the structure and electronic properties of janus transition-metal dischalcogenides (TMDs) monolayers <em>MXY</em> (<em>M</em> = Mo, W ;<em> X &ne; Y</em> = S, Se, Te). Electronic band structure and density of states calculations reveal that all of the <em>MXY </em>monolayers behavior semiconducting characteristics. Particular attention has been focused on the bandgap engineering by applying <em>in</em>-plane biaxial compressive and tensile strain. Both for tensile and compressive biaxial strains, the shrinking of the energy band-gap of monolayers <em>MXY</em> with increasing level of applied strain is observed. And a semiconductor-to-metal transition can be undergoing at a critical value of strain. The possibility of the tunable energy gap over a wide range makes <em>MXY</em> monolayers potential candidates for nanoelectronics and optoelectronics.
1289	Improving characterization capabilities in new single-photon avalanche diode research	Many novel and promising single-photon avalanche diodes (SPADs) emerged in recent years. However, some of them may demonstrate a very high dark count rate (DCR), even tens of MHz, especially during development phase or at room temperature, posing new challenges to device characterization. During test of such SPADs, nanosecond gating operation has to be used to eliminate the dark avalanche event not coincident with photon arriving time. However, the fast-gating operation usually induces large fixed-pattern noise, such as spikes with a magnitude over 100mV and possible ringing, making weak avalanche signals difficult to detect. The noise is usually removed (either completely or partially) using various cancellation techniques based on dedicated circuits. Here we present an alternative method and setup to characterize such SPADs. Fast-gating operation is applied and a high-speed digital oscilloscope (DSO) is used to extract the weak avalanche signals from the large noise by waveform subtraction. In this way, the gating width can be down to 1ns or lower while the avalanche detection threshold can be reduced to 5% of the full vertical scale of the DSO or 5mV, whichever is greater. The timing resolution can be better than 2ps for typical avalanche signals. The optical alignment and calibration is easy. The feasibility of on-wafer test with an RF probe station is discussed. All the advantages and features above make this method very useful in new SPAD research.
1290	Voltage controlled sub-THz detection with gated planar asymmetric nanochannels	This letter reports on Self-switching diodes (SSD) fabricated on a AlGaN/GaN heterostructure on Si substrate. By means of free-space measurements at 300 GHz, we demonstrate that the responsivity and noise equivalent power (NEP) of sub-THz detectors based on planar asymmetric nanochannels can be improved and voltage controlled by means of a top gate electrode. A simple quasi-static model based on the DC measurements of the current-voltage curves is able to predict the role of the gate bias on its performance. The best values of voltage responsivity and NEP are achieved when the gate bias approaches the threshold voltage, around 600 V/W and 50 pW/Hz<sup>1/2</sup>, respectively, with a good agreement between modeled results and those obtained from RF measurements under probes at low frequency (900 MHz) and in free-space at 300 GHz.
1291	The origin of optimal sensing temperature in Pt/Ta<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>/MoO<sub>3</sub> Schottky contacted nanobelt straddling heterojunction	Nanostructured Schottky barrier gas sensors have emerged as novel semiconductor devices with large surface areas and unique electronic characteristics. Although it is widely known that operating these gas sensors requires heating to an optimal temperature for the highest sensitivity, the fundamental mechanism that governs the temperature-dependent sensitivity has yet been well understood. In this work, we present new evidence to support that thermionic field emission is the dominant transport mechanism for Schottky contacted nanostructured heterojunction gas sensors at their optimal sensing temperature. Through the fabrication and characterization of Pt/MoO<sub>3</sub> Schottky contacts and Pt/Ta<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>/MoO<sub>3</sub> heterojunctions, we found the previously unreported connection between TFE transport and optimal gas sensing temperature. This connection enables the description of Schottky barrier gas sensing performance using transport theory, which represents a major step towards systematic engineering of nanostructured oxide gas sensors with layered high-<em>k</em> material.
1292	Extending the hierarchical quantum master equation approach to low temperatures and realistic band structures	The hierarchical quantum master equation (HQME) approach is an accurate method to describe quantum transport in interacting nanosystems. It generalizes perturbative master equation approaches by including higher-order contributions as well as non-Markovian memory and allows for the systematic convergence to the numerically exact result. As the HQME method relies on a decomposition of the bath correlation function in terms of exponentials, however, its application to systems at low temperatures coupled to baths with complexer band structures has been a challenge. In this publication, we outline an extension of the HQME approach, which uses a re-summation over poles and can be applied to calculate transient currents at a numerical cost that is independent of temperature and band structure of the baths. We demonstrate the performance of the extended HQME approach for noninteracting tight-binding model systems of increasing complexity as well as for the spinless Anderson-Holstein model.
1293	<strong>Realization of GaN nanostructured ultraviolet photodetector via non-homogeneous Au-GaN interfaces</strong>	We report the fabrication of ultraviolet photodetector based on GaN nanostructures, epitaxially grown on silicon substrate. The surface illustrated GaN nanoislands which lead to a significant enhancement in sensitivity of the device to 1.83&times;10<sup>2</sup> at 13mW in power dependent studies. Whereas, voltage dependent analysis revealed high responsivity and detectivity values of 40.3 mA/W and 5.3&times;10<sup>10</sup> Jones, respectively at 3V. The current&ndash;voltage characteristics revealed inhomogeneous Au-GaN interfaces, responsible for zero-bias operation revealing a self-powered mode with good performance parameters. Additionally, the photoresponse measurement endorsed an effective charge collection by nanoisland networks, leading to a fast rise and fall time constants of 18 and 27 ms, respectively. Such nanostructured GaN photodetector can be employed for energy efficient optoelectronic applications.
1294	<strong>Nanocomposites of Ferroelectric Liquid Crystals and FeCo Nanoparticles: Magnetic Response to the Application of a Small Electric Field </strong>	Nanocomposites of liquid crystals and nanoparticles have been used for a variety of bioapplications using a small applied magnetic field. We explore the use of nanocomposites of ferroelectric liquid crystals and magnetic nanoparticles for their potential to create an internal ordered magnetic field when excited with an applied electric field. Ferroelectric liquid crystals need a small electric field to achieve this. We find out that the concentration of the magnetic nanoparticles facilitates this effect by reducing the switching time and making it constant, which in turn will reduce the rotational viscosity, and hence, the applied electric field. The nanocomposite shows promise as a potential voltage-sensitive contrast agent that may be useful with modalities that can measure local magnetic field changes such as magnetic resonance imaging.
1295	Thermionic cooling efficiency of functionalized carbon nanotube thin films	A large thermionic cooling effect is observed from a functionalized carbon nanotubes cathode surface, and the cooling efficiency, defined as thermionic cooling power as a percentage of total input heating power to the surface, is reported. The cathode consists of a thin tungsten ribbon covered with low work function barium strontium oxide coated carbon nanotubes. It has both a low work function surface and a large Schottky field effect induced by the carbon nanotubes. The combination of the two leads to a strong thermionic emission and hence a relatively large thermionic cooling effect and high cooling efficiency. Detailed measurements of the cathode temperature profiles are presented together with the analysis of the cooling efficiency. The highest cooling efficiency found in this study was 5.9% obtained at 1099 oC cathode temperature and 114.5 mA of thermionic emission current. The dependences of the cooling efficiency on the cathode temperature, and on the emission current are also presented. Prospects of further improvements are discussed as well.
1296	Shear thickening performance of ceria and silica mixed nanoparticles suspension	In this work, the shear thickening (ST) performance of a novel suspension of ceria and silica mixed nanoparticles was systematically studied. Ceria/silica-shear thickening fluids (CeO2/SiO2-STFs) of different concentrations were prepared by using an ultrasonication and mechanical stirring technique. The presence of ceria nanoparticles and their interaction with the SiO2 nanoparticles in the STF were analyzed using scanning electron microscopy, energy-dispersive spectroscopy and X-ray diffractometry. Steady-shear rheological tests showed that distinct rheological behaviors and clear ST effects existed in CeO2/SiO2-STFs with different mass ratios. The viscosity increased from 50.97 (SiO2-STF) to 111.51 Pa&#x2022;s (CeO2/SiO2-STF), and the critical shear rate decreased from 63.09 to 19.95 s-1 when the concentration of the ceria nanoparticles was 12 wt%. An oscillatory dynamic rheological analysis showed that the 12O2/20%SiO2-STF suspension not only had significant energy storage and energy dissipation capacities but also presented excellent elastic behaviors when subjected to low stress and significant energy dissipation under high stress. The results also showed that temperature exerted little influence on the viscosity of the CeO2/SiO2-STF suspension but had a significant influence on the ST effect. Furthermore, the current carried by the CeO2/SiO2-STF suspension increased with the increasing ceria nanoparticle content, indicating improved conductivity. This work provides a novel method for the production of high-performance STFs.
1297	<strong>Negative/Zero Thermal Expansion in Black Phosphorus Nanotubes</strong>	Black phosphorus nanotubes (BPNTs) as new one-dimensional materials have very promising prospects in nanoelectronics devices. Taking into account that the effect of finite temperature on nanoelectronic devices is indispensable, we perform a comprehensive first-principles study of thermal expansion of BPNTs. It is surprisingly found that the negative and zero thermal expansion behaviors can occur in BPNTs. The abnormal thermal expansion can be tunable by changing diameter and bonding in the unique configurations of armchair and zigzag BPNTs. In pristine BPNTs, the size effect appears in armchair nanotubes where the positive thermal expansion (PTE) is weakened generally with increasing diameter. In contrast, the thermal expansion of the zigzag nanotubes is diameter independent. Some zigzag nanotubes exhibit nearly zero thermal expansion (ZTE). For processed BPNTs with changed bonding, both types of nanotubes present negative thermal expansion (NTE) behavior. Differing from the diameter independence of NTE in processed zigzag nanotubes, the NTE in the processed armchair nanotubes is weakened gradually to nearly ZTE with increasing diameter. This work demonstrates that the special characteristics of edge shapes, size and bonding can play crucial roles in determining the abnormal thermal behaviors in BPNTs.
1298	<strong>Determining the polarity of droplet epitaxy grown AlGaN nanorods by piezoresponse force microscopy</strong>	We report a unique methodology for determining the polarity of Al<sub>0.97</sub>Ga<sub>0.03</sub>N nanorods oriented in different crystallographic directions by the non-destructive technique of piezoresponse force microscopy. Al<sub>0.97</sub>Ga<sub>0.03</sub>N nanorods are grown by the plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy technique under extreme group III rich condition. Droplet epitaxy process is employed for the formation of well-faceted nanorods with smooth morphology. The phase formation is investigated by the Raman spectroscopic analysis. Spatial distribution of piezoresponse of Al<sub>0.97</sub>Ga<sub>0.03</sub>N nanorods is mapped, and the polarities of the different crystalline planes of <em>m</em> and <em>c</em> are determined. The corresponding piezoresponse is explained on the basis of spontaneous and induced polarization in a unit cell of the hexagonal crystal, which is further confirmed using piezoresponse spectroscopy. A high value of piezoelectric coefficient, <em>d</em><sub>33 </sub>~ 9.0 pm/V for nanosize Al<sub>0.97</sub>Ga<sub>0.03</sub>N is attributed to the availability of free boundary for volume expansion or contraction at the nanoscale.
1299	Size confinement and origins of two-photon absorption and refraction in CdSe quantum dots	Tuning a semiconductor nanomaterial with large two-photon absorption cross section in the near infrared and investigating the correlation and origins between its size and third-order nonlinear optical properties is very important in possible applications. So in this work, CdSe quantum dots (QDs) with various sizes were successfully prepared, and their size-confined third-order nonlinear optical properties were investigated by Z-scan technique with 100 fs laser pulses at 800 nm wavelength. Both the two-photon absorption and nonlinear refraction were enhanced with size decrease and then weakened with further size decrease. QDs with the diameter of 4.9 nm had the largest susceptibility of 7.8&times;10<sup>-12</sup> esu. The effects of intrinsic dipole moment, photoinduced dipole moment, local electric field and defects in CdSe QDs were discussed.
1300	Absolute cross section for DNA damage induced by low-energy (10 eV) electrons: experimental refinements and sample characterization by AFM	This work describes multiple experimental improvements for measuring absolute cross sections of DNA damage induced by low-energy electrons (LEE) in nanometer-thick films in vacuum. Measurements of such cross sections are particularly sensitive to film thickness and uniformity. Using atomic force microscopy (AFM) in 70% ethanol, we present a novel and effective method to determine plasmid DNA film thickness and uniformity that combines height histograms and force-distance curves. We also investigate film deposition with DNA intercalated with 1,3-diaminopropane (Dap) on tantalum-coated substrates as a convenient and cost-effective alternative to the previously-used HOPG substrate. The new substrate permits deposition of films very similar to those formed on the graphite substrate. Using these refinements and further optimizations of the experimental procedure, we measure an absolute cross section of (4.7 {plus minus} 1.5) x10-14 cm2 for conformational damage to a 3197 base-pair plasmid induced by 10 eV electrons, which we believe should be considered as a reference value.
1301	<strong>Heat Transfer Foot Print on Ceramics after Thermal Shock with Droplet Impingement: Development of Thermal Shock Tolerant Material with Hydrophobic Surface</strong>	We perform a systematic study of the thermal shock experienced by the alumina during quenching by cold water droplet impingement with heated surface temperature ranging from 125&deg;C to 475&deg;C for Weber number &asymp;32. We explore the effect of surface heat transfer mode on the thermal shock experienced by the material. It is found that the variation of residual strength translates into the mode of boiling heat transfer, hence surface heat flux. The material remembers the degree of thermal shock; the heat transfer foot print is embedded in the residual strength. This finding speaks to a possibility of developing a ceramic detector for heat transfer modes in extreme environments. This study finds that superior thermal shock tolerance can be achieved by removing the heat transfer footprint with reduced heat flux. By promoting the film boiling with nano-fractal hydrophobic surface, we achieved superior thermal shock tolerance for alumina substrates. This is a novel approach to reduce thermal shock by controlling the heat transfer with surface modification, different from conventional, yet expensive, method of improving the bulk material properties.
1302	The extremely enhanced photocurrent response in the Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>2</sub>Te nanosheet with high conductance	The photocurrent was performed in the Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>2</sub>Te topological insulator with different conductances at a wavelength of 532 nm. The photocurrent is linear with light power intensity, and proportional to the dark current. The higher photocurrent is observed in the nanosheet with higher conductance. The responsivity is proportional to the nanosheet conductance. The responsivity and gain at V=0.1V reaches 731 and 1706 at the nanosheet with conductance of 0.06 S. These are higher than all reported values in (Sb, Bi)<sub>2</sub>(Te, Se)<sub>3</sub> topological insulators, low-dimensional materials and only lower than several reported heterostructure.
1303	Bulk turbostratic graphene deposition on aluminum substrates via high-pressure graphite blasting	This work presents the mechanical exfoliation of graphite into graphene nano-platelets via high pressure blasting onto metallic substrates. After ensuring successful graphene deposition via Raman spectroscopy, the substrates are then tested to detect the enhancement of their thermal, optical and electrochemical properties. The process is facile and straightforward, with no special requirements in terms of energy addition or isolation and is capable of depositing graphene over large surface areas. The application of such approach is suitable for solar thermal absorbers.
1304	<strong>Designing front dielectric and back plasmonic wire grating for efficient light trapping inside perovskite solar cells<sup></sup></strong>	Thin film perovskite (CH3NH3PbI3) solar cells have been emerged as good alternatives to conventional silicon solar cells due to their low cost, low fabrication temperature, high carrier collection efficiency, and high-power conversion efficiency (PCE). However, the small thickness of perovskite solar cells limits light absorption of the long wavelengths. In this work, we proposed a theoretical design for enhancing light absorption to achieve maximum theoretical photocurrent using front dielectric and back plasmonic wire grating. Using finite element method (FEM) three-dimensional optical model, the optimum size and periodicity of the studied wire grating nanostructures were identified. Additionally, the electrical model revealed a satisfactory enhancement in PCE over that of the planar structure counterpart. The simulation results showed an average enhancement of 22.4% in total generation rate for the entire simulated wavelength, and more than 85% enhancement in narrow-band wavelength compared to the planar structure counterpart
1305	<strong>Quantum Steps in Nano Scale Body SOI-MOSFET as Experimental Probe of Quantum Energy Levels</strong>	In the efforts to address the need of developing ultra-fast computers based on combined electronic and optical signal processing using silicon-based nanoscale devices, new types of transistors have been developed.  Ultra-Thin Body (UTB) and Nano-Scale Body (NSB) SOI-MOSFET devices, sharing a similar W/L but with a channel thickness of respectively 46nm and down to 1.6nm, have been fabricated using a selective Gate-Recessed Channel (GRC) process on the same silicon wafer, and electrically tested at room (300K) and low (77K and 4.7K) temperatures. In addition to the observed drain current values, which were found different by three orders of magnitude, quantum steps have been identified in the NSB transfer curves when measured at low temperatures. Since the NSB device&rsquo;s channel is part of a quantum well structure, the steps can point to discrete levels of energy. Such approach can lead the way to some opportunities towards inter-subband emitting devices. Location of discrete steps is evidence of indirect-to-direct transition in ultra-thin silicon.
1306	Microstructure of Cu<sub>2</sub>S Nanoprecipitates and Its Role as Carrier Bank and Phonon Scattering Center in Thermoelectric Cu<sub>2</sub>Zn<sub>0.2</sub>Sn<sub>0.8</sub>S<sub>3</sub> Ceramics	The microstructures of the Cu<sub>2</sub>Zn<sub>0.2</sub>Sn<sub>0.8</sub>S<sub>3 </sub>ceramics were investigated by a combination of SAED, HRTEM, EDS and AFM. The metastable Cu<sub>2</sub>S nanoprecipitates show clear orientation relationships with the matrix that the plates align with three crystal axes of cubic lattice. KPFM and CAFM reveals that the nanoprecipitates have much lower potential than the matrix to promote electrical properties. A mechanism of phonon scattering is proposed based on the effects of the occupation disorder of Cu atoms in Cu<sub>2</sub>S nanopercipitates, coherent heterointerfaces between Cu<sub>2</sub>S and matrix, and the extended strain field in the matrix regions adjacent to the Cu<sub>2</sub>S nanoprecipitates.
1307	Research on the selective adhesion characteristics of polydimethylsiloxane layer	Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) is a widely used inexpensive, non-toxic material which has many advantages. But it is generally considered that PDMS does not adhere to the other substrates without the special treatments due to its low surface energy. However, in this paper, it is the first time that we found that the PDMS adhered on the silicon dioxide substrate to form an adhesive layer only by the routine cast molding process. The mechanism of the PDMS adhesion on the silicon dioxide substrate during the process was illustrated in detail. The smooth, thin, transparent, hydrophobic and selective PDMS adhesion layer can be used as a functional coating to improve the special performances of the micro/nano devices. Finally, as an example, a facile approach is proposed to realize the superhydrophobic surfaces by combining the SiO2 microstructure with the PDMS adhesion layer.
1308	<strong>Charge transfer induced anomalous magnetic behavior in 2D &alpha;-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanosheets grown on Graphene surface</strong>	To overcome the detrimental effect of charge transfer from transition metal to 2D substrates like graphene we have grown ultrathin antiferromagnetic &alpha;-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> layers on graphene surface. Anomalous magnetic behavior viz. both coercivity and exchange bias increase with increasing temperature with strong ferromagnetic ordering. The highest values of coercivity and giant exchange bias are obtained as 3335 Oe and 2361Oe respectively. Giant enhancement (646%) in exchange bias is observed with increase in temperature from 2K to 70K. Interlayer exchange coupling which also increases with increasing temperature becomes strongest at 300K to achieve ultra-low coercivity of 22 Oe by growing &alpha;-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> phase on both sides of graphene surface. Maximum 32% negative magnetoresistance is observed as a result of exchange bias which changes with temperature. All these results are explained on the basis of charge transfer effect at the interface of graphene/&alpha;-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> at low temperature region and spin canting effect of surface spins at higher temperature region. Theoretical support using first principle calculation is also provided to understand the interface interaction, quantitative evaluation of charge transfer and density of states.
1309	Enhanced bremsstrahlung X-ray emission from Ag nanoparticles irradiated by ultrashort laser pulses	Ag nanoparticles flowing through a thin water jet are irradiated by femtosecond laser pulses to produce bremsstrahlung X-rays of up to 100 keV energy. The jet ensures long-term stability of nanoparticles during laser irradiation. A 30-fold enhancement is observed in the X-ray yield compared to the precursor salt solution, owing to the enhanced multiphoton ionization resulting from surface plasmon assisted local field enhancement. A lower 18-fold enhancement is measured in Au nanoparticles under identical conditions. The relatively lower ionization potential of Ag nanoparticles makes them better suited for X- ray generation, with variety of applications including dynamics studies, microscopy, and lithography.
1310	<strong>Angle dependent localized surface plasmon resonance from silver nanoparticles embedded in SiO<sub>2</sub> thin film</strong>	<SPAN style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%;">Near surface silver nanoparticles embedded in silicon oxide were obtained by 40 keV silver negative ion implantation without the requirement of an annealing step. Ion beam induced local heating within the film leads to an exo-diffusion of the silver ions towards the film surface resulting in the protrusion of larger nanoparticles. Cross-sectional transmission electron microscopy (XTEM) reveals the presence of poly-disperse nanoparticles (NPs), ranging between 2 nm-20 nm, at different depths of the SiO<sub>2</sub> film. The normal incidence reflectance spectrum shows a double kink feature in the vicinity of 400nm, indicating a strong localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) from the embedded NPs. However, due to overlap of the bilayer interference and LSPR, the related features are difficult to separate. The ambiguity in associating the correct kink with the LSPR related absorption is cleared with the use of transfer matrix simulations in combination with an effective medium approximation. The simulations are further verified with angle dependent reflectance measurements. Additionally, transfer matrix simulation is also used to calculate the electric field intensity profile through the depth of the film, wherein an enhanced electric field intensity is predicted at the surface of the implanted films.</SPAN>
1311	Spin-current diodes based on germanene and stanene subjected to local exchange fields	We propose and demonstrate a spin-current diode based on germanene and stanene nanoribbons. The results reveal that the germanene or stanene nanoribbon simultaneously under x- and z-direction local exchange fields exhibits excellent rectification characteristics, and that the spin current is blocked in a certain range of spin voltage. The proposed spin-current diodes have three main features: (1) the breakdown voltage of the diodes can be controlled by the strength of exchange fields; (2) the polarity direction of the diodes can be reversed just by adjusting the direction of local exchange fields; and (3) the spin diode effects can be well maintained at 300 K room temperature. All of the results indicate that the proposed germanene and stanene nanosystems are promising candidates for spintronic devices.
1312	<strong>The frequency dependence of hysteresis behaviors in columnar-grained BaTiO<sub>3</sub> nano films</strong>	By taking into account the effects of the epitaxial strain, the influence of defects, the low-permittivity surface layer and the grain boundary, a phase-field model is developed to investigate the influence of loading frequency on the ferroelectric properties of columnar-grained BaTiO<sub>3</sub> nano films. The results showed that the hysteresis response consists of two phases. In the low-frequency phase, the electrical polarizations are observed to follow closely with the variation of electric filed, causing a complete 180&deg; polar reversal. As the frequency increases within this phase, the remnant polarization increases slightly and the coercive field exhibits a sharper increase, while the dielectric constant and piezoelectric constant decrease severely. In the high-frequency phase, a higher loading speed leaves less time for the electric dipole to fully rotate, leading to a less switched state. The remnant polarization decreases with increasing frequency. The coercive field, the dielectric constant and the piezoelectric constant exhibit a frequency-insensitive effect at higher frequencies.
1313	<strong>INVESTIGATIONS ON STRUCTURAL AND OPTICAL PROPERTIES OF CHALCONE DENDRIMER IN Ag@TiO<sub>2</sub> CORE-SHELL NANOPARTICLES</strong>	The main focus of this research article is to observe the contributions of chalcone dendrimer in Ag@TiO<sub>2</sub> core shell nanoparticles. The samples were synthesized by Redox transmetalation method. The structure of the samples in three molar ratio viz.1:1, 1:2, 1:5 (noted as A,B,C) with Poly Vinyl Pyrolidine (PVP) as stabilizing agent were compared with the sample Ag@TiO<sub>2</sub> of 1:2 molar ratio (noted as D) using chalcone dendrimer as stabilizing agent. The prepared samples were structurally characterized by XRD and HRTEM analysis. The XRD and SAED analysis exhibited tetragonal body centered crystal structure with <em>d</em><sub>hkl </sub>= 1.6 &Aring;, 2.4 &Aring; and 3.4 &Aring;. The lattice parameters were calculated for all the samples and the variations observed were reported. The grain size and dislocation density of the synthesized nanoparticles were calculated using Debye-Scherrer formula. From Williamson &ndash; Hall plot, it was identified that the effect of lattice strain was limited in sample D in which chalcone dendrimer acted as stabilizing agent. The structural investigation showed the impact of stabilizing agent on the surface elements. Similarly, the optical characteristics were discussed based on UV-DRS and Photo luminescence studies. Using Kubelka-Munk function, the band gap energy was calculated and the difference observed in the band gap energy due to the impact of stabilizing agents on metal-metaloxide (Ag@TiO<sub>2</sub>) combination was analysed. The molar absorptivity (&epsilon;) was calculated for all the samples using Beer-Lambert&rsquo;s law and the difference in absorbance on using different capping agent was discussed.
1314	Nanoscale investigation of Si nanoribbon growth on Ag(110)	We present a nanoscale investigation by means of scanning tunneling microscopy of Si nanostructure growth on the anisotropic silver (110) surface, in the submonolayer range. Four types of Si nanostructures are studied statistically as a function of the substrate temperature in the range 300 K to 500 K: isolated single- and double nanoribbons, which differ only by a factor of two in their width, and their respective bi-dimensional counterparts in the self-assembly regime. Our observations highlight different growth regimes controlled by kinetics. Below 320 K, the Si adatoms diffuse along the easy [11 &#x0305;0] direction, forming essentially isolated single nanoribbons randomly distributed on the silver terraces. At higher temperatures, transverse diffusion along the [001] direction is activated and a competition between the growth of self-assembled single nanoribbons and isolated double nanoribbons is observed. Above 440 K, a transition from one- to two-dimensional double nanoribbons growth is evidenced. At 490 K, the Si deposition results in the formation of massively self-assembled double nanoribbons. Based on Arrhenius analyses, activation barriers are found to be (125 {plus minus} 15) meV and (210 {plus minus} 20) meV for the formation of isolated Si nanoribbons and self-assembled Si double nanoribbons, respectively. Our results allow for a better understanding of the kinetic limiting processes which determine the submonolayer morphology and illustrate the role played by the missing row reconstruction of the Ag(110) surface in the formation of extended Si nanoribbon arrays.
1315	Quadrature squeezing of the mechanical mode in a superconducting electromechanical system	We propose a scheme for realizing quadrature squeezing of the mechanical mode in a superconducting electromechanical system. The system is composed of a superconducting transmission line resonator(STLR) and a superconducting quantum interference device(SQUID). The SQUID acts as the qubit and a nanomechanical resonator(NAMR) is fabricated as one part of the SQUID. Under the large detuning condition, we use the Fr&ouml;hlich-Nakajima transformation to eliminate the qubit and obtain an effective Hamiltonian for the STLR and the NAMR. Our results show that a squeezing effect can occur in the NAMR and the squeezing degree can be adjusted by controlling the strength of the driving field and the dissipation ratio of the system. One of the most notable features of our results is the universality, i.e., the results only depend on a few scaled quantities, not on too many parameters.
1316	Magnetic tunneling with CNT-based metamaterial	Multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) fabricated by chemical vapor deposition contain magnetic nanoparticles. While increasing frequency of electromagnetic field (EMF) exposure (up to &lt;10 kHz) of MWCNTs resulted in slight induced magnetization decrease due to skin effect of the conducting carbon, higher frequencies (&gt;10 kHz) demonstrated an exponential magnetization increase. Furthermore, this magnetization increase is stronger for the EMF fields with decreasing amplitude (less than 0.5 A/m for 512 kHz). This observation reveals a possibility of magnetic tunneling in MWCNTs (change of magnetic state of blocked magnetic moments). This interpretation is supported by observation of unblocking larger magnetic remanence (MR) portion from MWCNTs with progressively smaller amplitude of oscillating magnetic field.
1317	<strong>Vibration suppression of doublewalled carbon nanotubes </strong><strong>in the terahertz range</strong>	Inspirited by locally resonant microstructure of metamaterials, the role of counter-phase intertube vibration in metamaterial-like vibration behavior of DWCNTs (doublewalled carbon nanotubes) is investigated. It is shown that unlike elastic metamaterials characterized by wavelength-independent effective mass, &ldquo;effective mass&rdquo; of a DWCNT in flexural vibration depends on wavelength. In spite of the non-existence of the &ldquo;bandgap&rdquo; (within which effective mass is negative for all wavelengths), our results indicated that forced vibration of a DWCNT driven by an applied periodic force is largely suppressed when the applied exciting frequency approaches or exceeds (but not exactly identical to) the lowest intertube resonant frequency in the terahertz range. This result suggests that the counter-phase intertube vibration (between the inner and outer tubes) stimulated at terahertz frequencies has a significant effect to suppress forced vibration of MWCNTs (multiwalled carbon nanotubes), and MWCNTs can exhibit metamaterial-like vibration behavior in the terahertz range. This conclusion may provide useful insights into vibration controlling of MWCNTs at terahertz frequencies.
1318	High-performance small- and wide-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS/WAXS) experiments on a multi-functional laboratory goniometer platform with easily exchangeable X-ray modules	Small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) is a well-established, versatile technique for the analysis of nanoscale structures and dimensions e.g. in liquid dispersions, thin solid objects or powder samples. When combined with wide-angle X-ray scattering (WAXS) complementary information about the atomic structure can be obtained. SAXS experiments traditionally require dedicated instruments to achieve the desired angular resolution, sensitivity, stability and speed of measurement. Here we demonstrate how a multi-functional laboratory goniometer platform, as widely being used for powder X-ray diffraction and for a variety of related techniques, can be configured with pre-aligned X-ray modules that enable advanced SAXS/WAXS experiments, without compromising the exceptional versatility of the instrument. Line and point collimation setups, as well as quick and easy switching between them, are readily possible. Key components are a detachable, evacuated beam path and a high-resolution, low-noise hybrid pixel area detector, in combination with a hardware interface design that allows to configure the instrument with different X-ray modules without the need for re-alignment. Software for SAXS data reduction and analysis was developed. The good SAXS/WAXS performance and the derived analytical results were verified on various test samples, such as gold nanoparticles, colloidal silica, liposomes, dilute protein solutions and solid polymer samples. It is believed that this novel approach to SAXS/WAXS instrumentation will help to make this powerful structure analysis technique more widely accessible and affordable for multi-user laboratories.
1319	<strong>Suction/injection process and thermal radiation impacts on magneto-hydrodynamic squeezing nanofluid flow and heat transfer between parallel disks considering Joule heating</strong>	In this paper, the unsteady squeezing flow and heat transfer of magneto-hydrodynamic nanofluid between two parallel disks under a suction/blowing process are studied. Thermal radiation, Joule heating and viscous dissipation impacts are considered. The researchers first converted the boundary conditions and governing momentum/energy equations into a non-dimensional form and solved them with DRA (Duan Rach Approach). Unlike ADM (Adomin Decomposition Method), this method permits us to discover an analytical solution without applying a numerical procedure to compute the missing parameters. The water based nanofluid is comprised of copper, copper oxide and alumina. The impacts of different parameters such as the suction/blowing parameter, the magnetic parameter, the solid volume fraction, the squeeze number, and the radiation parameter on flow and heat transfer attributes are investigated. Moreover, the value of the Nusselt number is calculated and illustrated in figures. The outcomes demonstrate that the fluid velocity ascends with the rise of the suction parameter while the temperature profile descends with the ascendance of the suction parameter.
1320	Letter: Molecular Diffusion Replaces Capillary Pumping in Phase-Change Driven Nanopumps	Inspired by the capillary driven heat transfer devices, we present a phase-change driven nanopump operating almost isothermally. Meticulous computational experiments on different sized nanopumps revealed efficient operation of the pump despite the reduction in system size that extinguishes capillary pumping by annihilating the liquid meniscus structures. Measuring the density distribution of liquid near evaporating and condensing liquid/vapor interfaces, we discovered that phase-change induced molecular scale mass diffusion mechanism replaces the capillary pumping in the absence of meniscus structures. Therefore, proposed pumps can serve as a part of both nanoelectromechanical (NEMS) and microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) with similar working efficiencies.
1321	<strong>Transverse Piezoresistance Behaviors </strong><strong>of N-doped 3<em>C</em>-SiC</strong> <strong>Nanobelts with Selected(1-10) </strong><strong>Top Surface</strong>	<strong>Abstract</strong> The piezoresistive effect of SiC low-dimensional nanostructures, together with their exclusive benefits of superior mechanical properties and could be integrated into the flexible devices that can withdraw large strain, promise to enable a wide range of sensing devices application possible in the harsh working conditions. In this work, we reported the transverse piezoresistance behaviors of <em>n</em>-type 3<em>C</em>-SiC nanobelts with selected  top surface and N dopants. The single-crystalline SiC nanobelts were synthesized <em>via</em> direct pyrolysis of polymeric precursors without catalysts, which had an average N doping level of ~6.02<em> at</em>.% and a typical width-to-thickness ratio of ~8. It was disclosed that the transverse piezoresistance coefficient  reached the maximum 10.29&times;10<sup>-11</sup> Pa<sup>-1</sup> at a fixed external stress of 67.03 <em>n</em>N. Correspondingly, the gauge factor (GF) was calculated to be of ~61.7, which was higher than those of <em>n</em>-type SiC materials ever reported. The results revealed that present <em>n</em>-type SiC nanobelts have the potential of becoming an outstanding contestant for building robust pressure sensors with elevated sensitivities.
1322	Evidence of Converse Magnetoelectric Interactions Observed in Sol-gel derived thin films of PLZT and CZFO using Magnetic Force Microscopy	This work focus on an investigation of the reverse magnetoelectric interactions observed using Magnetic Force Microscopy. The layered nano composite films of Pb<sub>0.93</sub>La<sub>0.07</sub>Zr<sub>0.6</sub>Ti<sub>0.4</sub>O<sub>3   </sub>(PLZT) and Co<sub>0.9</sub>Zn<sub>0.1</sub>Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> (CZFO) were obtained using sol-gel derived spin coating route. The composite structure so obtained was subjected to an external DC voltage  0V, &plusmn;2V, &plusmn; 5V and MFM topography, phase angle and intensity contrasts were recorded. MFM images show a noticeable change in the phase contrast as well as other image parameters as a function of an external DC electric field which is a signature of converse magnetoelectric interactions.
1323	Hot-carrier-mediated impact excitation of Er<sup>3+</sup> ions in SiO<sub>2</sub> sensitized by Si nanocrystals	Past research has shown that indirect excitation of Er<sup>3+</sup> ions in SiO<sub>2</sub> solid-states<p>matrix with Si nanocrystals can be achieved by different pathways. Here, we investigate the impact excitation mechanisms in detail by means of time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopy. We explicitly demonstrate that the free carrier impact excitation mechanism is activated as soon as the carriers obtain sufficient excess energy. The &ldquo;hot&rdquo; carriers with the above-threshold energy can be created upon optical pumping in two ways: either upon absorption of (i) a single photon with an energy exceeding a certain threshold hv &gt; E<sub>th</sub>, or (ii) following absorption of multiple photons of lower energy in a single nanocrystal, hv &lt; E<sub>th</sub>, followed by an Auger recombination of the generated multiple e-h pairs. In addition, we show that the impact excitation dynamics by hot carriers are similar, regardless of the mode in which they have been created.
1324	<strong>Selective electric field assisted dissolution as a technique for micro and nano structuring of metal thin films</strong>	A novel technique for patterning compact thin metal layers is presented. The technique is based on a successive application of well known, cost-effective and simple methods of glass poling and electric field assisted dissolution. A microstructure from the patterned anode, was successfully copied onto a thin silver layer on a glass substrate. It is demonstrated that electric field assisted dissolution can be used for selective dissolution of compact metal layers. Nanostructuring of compact metal layers is interesting as it can be used in the production of metamaterials, metasurfaces and optical circuits. Proposed two-step technique does not involve expensive equipment and the duration of the structuring process is independent of the size of the required structured surface.
1325	Visualization of nanocrystalline CuO in the grain boundaries of Cu<sub>2</sub>O thin films and effect on band bending and film resistivity	Direct evidence for the presence of a CuO structure in the grain boundaries of Cu<sub>2</sub>O thin films is provided by high resolution automated phase and orientation mapping (ASTAR), which was not detectable by classical transmission electron microscopy techniques. Conductive atomic force microscopy (C-AFM) revealed that the CuO causes a local loss of current rectification at the Schottky barrier between the C-AFM tip and Cu<sub>2</sub>O. The suppression of CuO formation at the Cu<sub>2</sub>O grain boundaries is identified as the key strategy for future device optimization.
1326	<SPAN style="font-size: 12.0pt; color: windowtext;">Effect of coconut shell on the performance of beta-silicon carbide reinforced conducting polymer composites</SPAN>	This study aims to investigate the effect of using the combination of coconut shell (CS) particles and beta-silicon carbide (&beta;-SiC) nanoparticles as reinforcement in the conducting polymer composites. The elemental composition, physical characterization, impact strength, water absorption and dielectric properties of the composites were studied. Chemical composition analysis reveals that the lignocellulosic CS is made up with 48.37% carbon, 6.313% hydrogen, 1.20% nitrogen, 0.306% of sulfur and 43.391% of oxygen. Presence of macroporous structure was detected on irregular CS particles size with porosity ranging from 870.9 nm &ndash; 1.6 &mu;m. The increase of the amorphization in the conducting polymer composites contributed by the CS particles increased the dielectric loss factor and electrical losses but decreased the impact strength. The incorporation of CS particles in the conducting polymer composites had a positive influence on the dielectric constant <em>&epsilon;</em>&rsquo;, dielectric loss factor <em>&epsilon;&rdquo; </em>and electrical conductivity <em>&sigma;</em>, contributed by the heterogeneous nature of the composites with overall polarizability arises from atomic, electronic and orientation polarizations.
1327	<SPAN style="margin: 0px; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; font-size: 18pt;"><strong>UV light activated NO</strong><sub><strong>2</strong></sub><strong> gas sensing based on Au nanoparticles decorated few-layer MoS</strong><sub><strong>2</strong></sub><strong> thin film at room temperature</strong></SPAN>	<SPAN style="margin: 0px; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; font-size: 14pt;">Nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>) plays a key role in environmental protection and human health. recently, molybdenum disulfide (MoS<sub>2</sub>) as a novel 2D material has been utilized to detect NO<sub>2</sub> gas, always hindered by the weak response as well as poor recovery characteristics. Herein we report an UV light-assisted, room-temperature, recoverable, sensitive and selective NO<sub>2</sub> gas sensing based on few-layer MoS<sub>2</sub> nanosheet-Au nanoparticle composites serving as the sensing layer. </SPAN><SPAN style="margin: 0px; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; font-size: 14pt;">In dark condition, the as-prepared </SPAN><SPAN style="margin: 0px; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; font-size: 14pt;">MoS<sub>2</sub>/Au sensor</SPAN><SPAN style="margin: 0px; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; font-size: 14pt;"> showed an enhanced response (10%) toward 2.5 ppm NO<sub>2</sub> more than two times larger than MoS<sub>2</sub> one although all sensors indicated an incomplete recovery. When under UV illumination, for MoS<sub>2</sub>-Au sensor, a three-time enhanced response, a full recovery as well as an improved repeatability were exhibited. Two aspects could account for the improved performance.</SPAN><SPAN style="margin: 0px; font-family: 'Times New Roman',serif; font-size: 14pt;"> On one hand, Au nanoparticle induced more light adsorption and reaction sites under illumination. The other lies in spillover effect of Au nanoparticles, contributing to effective separation of charge carrier at MoS<sub>2</sub>/Au interfaces enabling sufficient reaction with NO<sub>2</sub> molecules. MoS<sub>2</sub>-Au composites were adopted for NO<sub>2</sub> detection under UV illumination, which was firstly reported, providing a promising strategy to realize room-temperature, recoverable, and sensitive gas detection.</SPAN>
1328	Review of hydro-instability experiments with alternate capsule supports in indirect- drive implosions on the National Ignition Facility	Hydrodynamic instability growth of capsule support membranes (or "tents") has been recognized as one of the major contributors to the performance degradation in high- compression plastic capsule implosions at the National Ignition Facility (NIF) [E. M. Campbell, R. Cauble, and B. A. Remington, AIP Conf. Proc. 429, 3 (1998)]. The capsules were supported by tents because the nominal 10-um diameter fill tubes were not strong enough to support capsules by themselves in indirect-drive implosions on NIF. After it was recognized that the tents had a significant impact of implosion's stability, new alternative support methods were investigated. While some of these methods completely eliminated tent, other concepts still used tents but concentrated on mitigating their impact. The tent-less methods included "fishing pole" reinforced fill tubes, cantilevered fill tubes, and thin-wire "tetra cage" supports. In the "fishing pole" concept, a 10-um fill tube was inserted inside 30-um fill tube for extra support with the connection point located 300 um away from the capsule surface. The cantilevered fill tubes were supported by 12-um thick SiC rods, offset by up to 300 um from the capsule surfaces. In the "tetra-cage" concept, 2.5-um thick wires (carbon nanotube yarns) were used to support a capsule. Other concepts used "polar tents" and a "foam-shell" to mitigate effects of the tents. The "polar tents" had significantly reduced contact area between the tents and the capsule compared to the nominal tents. In the "foam-shell" concept, 200-um thick, a 30 mg/cc SiO2 foam layer was used to offset the tents away from the capsule surface in an attempt to mitigate their effects. These concepts were investigated in x-ray radiography experiments and compared with perturbations from standard tent support. The measured perturbations in the "fishing pole", cantilevered fill tube, and "tetra-cage" concepts compared favorably with (were smaller than) nominal tent perturbations and were recommended for further testing for feasibility in layered DT implosions. The "polar tents" were tested in layered DT implosions with a relatively- stable "high-foot" drive showing an improvement in neutron yield in one experiment compared to companion implosions with nominal tents. This article reviews and summarizes recent experiments on these alternate capsule support concepts. In addition, the concept of magnetic levitation is also discussed.
1329	Reversible nanomagnetic effects exhibited by multiscale ion-implanted platinum in silica glass recorded by an ultrafast two-wave mixing	Nanomagnetization exhibited by multiscale platinum (Pt) structures embedded by ion-implantation in silica plates was studied. An interferometrically-controlled laser irradiation was carried out in the plasmonic samples to induce periodic linear arrangements of Pt nanoparticles (PtNPs) dispersed in the surrounding of microstructures integrated by SiO<sub>2</sub> and Pt. The topographical and magnetic effects on the sample surface were analyzed by atomic force microscopy in contact-quasistatic mode, non-contact dynamic mode (AC-mode) and its respective magnetic force mode (MFM). The magnetic polarization of the multiscale Pt-based structures was further tuned with a Neodymium magnet contact procedure. MFM measurements indicated that gradient phase-shift (<em>&#x2206;</em><em>&theta;</em>) and the corresponding gradient force (<em>&part;Fz</em>/<em>&part;z</em>) were stronger at an embedded Pt-based structure magnetic shape. This process correspond to the first controlled method toward the development of multiscale plasmonic structures based on laser-induce bimodal nanoparticles distribution. Moreover, increase in compactness of the structure was further confirmed by a heightening of about 5 GPa in effective elastic modulus, <em>E</em><sub><em>eff</em></sub>, for the case of silica glass-PtNPs, against silica glass. The studied nanostructure composite behavior promises immediate applications for developing endurable high-density data storage devices. <SPAN style="color: #000000; font-family: CMR10; font-size: 9pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal;"><SPAN style="color: #000000; font-family: CMR7; font-size: 6pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal;"><SPAN style="color: #000000; font-family: CMMI10; font-size: 9pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal;"><br /></SPAN></SPAN></SPAN>
1330	Resistive switching behaviors mediated by grain boundaries in one longitudinal Al/MoS<sub>2</sub>&amp;PVP/ITO device	Nonvolatile memory devices based on 2D layered transition metal dichalcogenides have inspired tremendous amounts of research interests in recent years. In this work, resistive switching (RS) devices based on hybrid molybdenum disulphide and Polyvinylpyrrolidone (MoS<sub>2</sub>&amp;PVP) is explored. One longitudinal Al/MoS<sub>2</sub>&amp;PVP/ITO device exhibits three different modes of I-V characteristics, i.e. typical bipolar RS (TBRS), asymmetrical bipolar RS (ABRS) and threshold switching (TS), which can be explained by the formation and rupture of conducting filaments (CFs) consisting of sulfur vacancy filaments in MoS<sub>2</sub> nanoflakes and sulfur ions filaments in PVP. These CFs form from three different kinds of grain boundaries (GBs), intersecting-GB, bisecting-GB, and bridge-GB in which GBs attach one electrode, parallel to the two electrodes, and attach both electrodes, respectively, corresponding to the three modes of I-V characteristics. These three kinds of GBs coexist in one device and the CF forms randomly from one kind of them during sweeping loops. The mechanism was experimentally proved by our results of the increasing probability of TBRS in device with one layer of PVP thin film inserted into the interface of MoS<sub>2</sub>&amp;PVP and ITO and other researchers&rsquo; results in all-surface MoS<sub>2</sub> single-layer MoS<sub>2</sub> devices.
