1331	The interfacial stability and electronic properties of Ag/M (M=Ni, Cu, W and Pd) and Cu/Cr interfaces	The work of separation (<em>W</em><sub>sep</sub>), interface energy (<em>&gamma;<sub>i</sub></em><sub>nt</sub>) and electronic properties of Ag/M (M=Ni, Cu, W and Pd) and Cu/Cr interfaces are systematically studied by using first-principles calculation. Three criteria including <em>W</em><sub>sep</sub>, <em>&gamma;<sub>i</sub></em><sub>nt</sub> and<sub> </sub>quantum conductivity (<em>G</em>) have been proposed for the suitable electrical contact materials. The results indicate that Ag(111)/Ni(111), Ag(100)/W(100) and Ag(111)/W(110) interfaces have comparatively larger <em>W</em><sub>sep</sub> and lower positive <em>&gamma;<sub>i</sub></em><sub>nt</sub> among all the interfaces, which demonstrates that Ag/Ni and Ag/W interfaces are more suitable as nano-multilayer electrical contact materials than other interfaces. Moreover, Ag(111)/Ni(111) interface has the largest <em>G</em> and the best dispersing arc ability among these three interfaces, and thus it is chosen as the best candidate for the interface of nano-multilayer electrical contact material.
1332	Superconducting NanoJosephson Junctions Patterned with a Focused Helium Ion Beam	We report the fabrication of nano scale wires and Josephson junctions in 25 nm thick YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>7&minus;;&delta;</sub> thin films with wire widths as narrow as 50 nm. In this manner the film remains intact and no material is milled or removed. Transport data shows that the electrical properties: critical current and conductance scale linearly with the<br />lithographically defined width ensuring that the actual dimensions are commensurate. We observe that the critical current and voltage state resistance of the junctions is nearly temperature also demonstrate the ability<br />to fabricate hysteric underdamped junctions by using this process to create devices exhibiting high resistance and capacitance. This patterning technique allows for a broad range of electrical properties for Josephson devices that will expand potential applications.
1333	<strong>Magnetoelectric Spin-Glass Transition(s) in Pure and Disordered BiFeO<sub>3</sub></strong><sub></sub>	We present here the results of a comparative study of the spin glass (SG) transition in pure and 20% BaTiO<sub>3</sub> substituted BiFeO<sub>3</sub>. It is shown that the anomalous frequency dependence of ac susceptibility in the SG phase of BiFeO<sub>3</sub> is not linked with the spin cycloid as it is present even after its destruction in 20% BaTiO<sub>3</sub> substituted BiFeO<sub>3</sub>. Our neutron scattering studies reveal the presence of long-range ordered (LRO) antiferromagnetic (AFM) peak and decrease in the ordered magnetic moment at the SG transition temperature suggesting that some spin components are getting detached from the AFM phase. Further, the SG transition is accompanied with anomalies in unit cell volume and ferroelectric polarization around the SG transition temperature, highlighting the presence of magnetoelastic and magnetoelectric couplings, respectively. All these results suggest that the SG phase of BiFeO<sub>3</sub> is intrinsic to the system and is not due to nano-sized impurities.

1335	Photodynamics of reconfigurable two-dimensional polar wetting sheets of a dendrimer	We report an unusual reversible interfacial wetting-dewetting switching of a dendrimer incorporating azobenzene moieties. 1336	<strong>Hierarchical nanostructure of CrCoNi film underlying its remarkable mechanical strength</strong>	A CrCoNi medium entropy alloy thin film is developed using magnetron sputtering. It contains unique hierarchical nanostructures, featuring (1) a high density of planar defects (i.e., stacking faults and twin boundaries), (2) nanometre-sized dual phase (face-centred-cubic and hexagonal-close-packed) crystals, and (3) vertically aligned nano-columns, each with a width of ~ 100 nm. The hierarchical nanostructures in this study are novel and interesting, especially the dual phase structure, since the bulk CrCoNi medium entropy alloy generally presents the face-centred-cubic structure. The CrCoNi film shows a hardness quadruple that of its face-centred-cubic structured counterpart, while maintaining a considerable damage resistance. The role of the hierarchical nanostructure in producing such mechanical responses is discussed.
1337	Spectrally resolved X-ray beam induced current in a single InGaP nanowire	We demonstrate electrically detected X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS) using a 65 nm beam in single n+-i-n+ doped nanowire devices. The X-ray beam induced current (XBIC) and the X-ray fluorescence (XRF) signals were detected simultaneously as a function of the excitation energy near the Ga K absorption edge at 10.37 keV. The spectra show similar oscillations around the edge, which shows that the XBIC is limited by the primary absorption. Our results reveal the feasibility of the XBIC detection mode for the XAFS investigation in nanostructured devices.
1338	Polyaniline (C<sub>3</sub>N) nanoribbons: Magnetic metal, Semiconductor, and Half-Metal	Two-dimensional polyaniline sheet has been recently synthesized and found that it is a semiconductor with<br />indirect band gap. Polyaniline nanoribbons decomposed from two-dimensional polyaniline sheet (C<sub>3</sub>N sheet)<br />are investigated using density functional theory. The existence of nitrogen atoms in the edge of the ribbons<br />increases stability and magnetization of the ribbons and make them different from graphene nanoribbons.<br />Unsaturated nanoribbons are magnetic metals so that armchair C3N nanoribbons are gap-less spin semicon-<br />ductors in the antiferromagnetic state and half-metals in the ferromagnetic state. A transition from metal<br />to semiconductor is observed in the armchair C3N nanoribbons when the edge atoms are passivated by hy-<br />drogen. The band gap of hydrogen saturated armchair C<sub>3</sub>N nanoribbons can be controlled using an external<br />transverse electric field so that its magnitude is dependent on the direction of the electric field. Being metal<br />or semiconductor in hydrogen saturated zigzag C<sub>3</sub>N nanoribbons is strongly dependent on the edge atoms so<br />that just ribbons having nitrogen atoms in both edges are semiconductor. An external electric field cannot<br />induce any spin polarization in the zigzag nanoribbons which is in contrast with what was observed in zigzag<br />graphene nanoribbons.
1339	Ion Movement in Thin Nafion Films Under an Applied Electric Field	The electromechanical response of Nafion films with and without an ionic liquid (1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide) ([emim]Tf<sub>2</sub>N) additive were characterized under an applied electric field <em>in situ</em> using neutron reflectometry (NR) and voltage modulated atomic force microscopy (VM-AFM). NR showed that pure Nafion films exhibited no response under field strengths of ~0.5 V/&micro;m while VM-AFM measurements showed a minimal response at higher field strengths (~200 V/&micro;m), which is ascribed to residual water presence in the films. The addition of ionic liquid resulted in clear electroresponsiveness seen in both NR and VM-AFM. NR results indicated mass migration away from the cathodic interface driven by [emim]<sup>+</sup> movement in the direction of the electric field.  The lack of ionic liquid accumulation at the electrode interfaces, contrasts bulk electromechanical behavior of similar systems reported in the literature. VM-AFM measurements were able to resolve the relative contributions of the [emim]<sup>+</sup> cation and Tf<sub>2</sub>N<sup>-</sup> anion to film deformation by alternating the direction of the applied field, and support the [emim]<sup>+</sup> dominant migration seen in the NR results. The findings presented here emphasize the need for nanoscale analysis of material properties of electroresponsive thin film systems and demonstrate the potential for probing electric field effects using <em>in situ</em> techniques.
1340	Tuning and Stabilization of Optomechanical Crystal Cavities Through NEMS Integration	Nanobeam optomechanical crystals, in which localized GHz frequency mechanical modes are coupled to wavelength-scale optical modes, are being employed in a variety of experiments across different material platforms. Here, we demonstrate the electrostatic tuning and stabilization of such devices, by integrating a Si3N4 slot mode optomechanical crystal cavity with a nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS) element, which controls the displacement of an additional "tuning" beam within the optical near-field of the optomechanical cavity. Under DC operation, tuning of the optical cavity wavelength across several optical linewidths with little degradation of the optical quality factor (Q ~ 10^5) is observed. The AC response of the tuning mechanism is measured, revealing actuator resonance frequencies in the 10 MHz to 20 MHz range, consistent with the predictions from simulations. Feedback control of the optical mode resonance frequency is demonstrated, and alternative actuator geometries are presented.
1341	Low field manifestation of spiral ordering in sheet like BiFeO<sub>3</sub> nanostructures	Magnetic phase diagram of a material could be tuned through structural modification. Here we show significant lowering of magnetic field (H<sub>i</sub>) required from transition from cycloidal to canted antiferromagnetic state in sheet like nanostructures of BiFeO<sub>3</sub>, in comparison to reported bulk single crystals of BiFeO<sub>3</sub>. Structural analysis of this sheet like nanostructured BFO suggests that there is<br />more tilting in FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedra that reduces Fe-O-Fe distance in comparison to bulk BFO, leading to decrease in H<sub>i</sub> through the reduction of exchange interaction strength.
1342	Overcoming device unreliability with continuous learning in a population coding based computing system	The brain, which uses redundancy and continuous learning to overcome the unreliability of its components, provides a promising path to building computing systems that are robust to the unreliability of their constituent nanodevices. In this work, we highlight that this path can be illustrated by a computing system based on population coding with magnetic tunnel junctions that implement both neurons and synaptic weights. In particular, we show that equipping such a system with continuous learning enables it to recover from the loss of neurons and makes it possible to use unreliable synaptic weights (i.e. low energy barrier magnetic memories). There is a tradeoff between power consumption and precision because low energy barrier memories consume less energy than high barrier ones. For a given precision, there is an optimal number of neurons and an optimal energy barrier for the weights that leads to minimum power consumption.
1343	&#x00C5;-Indentation for non-destructive elastic moduli measurements of supported ultra-hard thin films and nanostructures	In this paper we report on the development of modulated nano-indentation (MoNI) to achieve sub-&#x00C5; resolution indentations while measuring applied loads and imaging materials with nanoscale resolution. MoNI was originally invented to measure the radial elasticity of multi-walled nanotubes, here we show how further progresses of MoNI allow for unprecedented high resolution indentation measurements to investigate non-destructively the elastic properties of supported two-dimensional (2D) materials and ultra-stiff ultra-thin films on substrates.
1344	Enhancement of Thermoelectric Figure of Merit by the Insertion of Multi-Walled Carbon Nanotubes in &alpha;-MgAgSb	Hybrid materials provide an efficient alternative route on improving the thermoelectric performance comparing with doping elements. Especially, the insertion of carbon nanotubes plays an effective role on modulating the electrical transport properties and phonon scattering simultaneously. We firstly fabricated multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) doped &alpha;-MgAgSb-based hybrid material and researched its thermoelectric properties in detail. The introduced MWCNTs enhanced carrier transport due to the metallic character of MWCNTs and increased phonon dispersion by the additional interfaces of insertions. The results showed that the electrical conductivity in &alpha;-MgAgSb/CNTs was remarkably enhanced especially at MgAg<sub>0.97</sub>Sb<sub>0.99</sub>/0.15 wt% CNTs boosting to 1.6 times than that of CNTs-free MgAg<sub>0.97</sub>Sb<sub>0.99</sub>. In addition, the thermal conductivity (&kappa;<sub>0.1</sub>) of MgAg<sub>0.97</sub>Sb<sub>0.99</sub>/0.1 wt% CNTs was reduced to 0.85 &kappa;<sub>0</sub>. As a result, the ZT value at room temperature was efficiently improved from 0.55 to 0.83, 1.5 times higher, and a high ZT value of 1.05 at 375 K was obtained. In addition, the dimensionless material factor B<sup>*</sup> increased from 0.98 to 1.49 at the doping level of 0.1 wt% CNTs at 300 K, which revealed that MWCNTs significantly enhanced thermoelectric performance of &alpha;-MgAgSb.
1345	<strong>Enhanced electrons extraction <strong>and superior performance of flexible perovskite solar cells using SnO<sub>2</sub>/graphene and Ag nanowires electrode</strong></strong>	The ultrafine silver (Ag) nanowires dispersed in a mixed solution of EMIMBF<sub>4 </sub>and water were spin-coated onto polyethylene terephthalate (PET) as perovskite solar cell (PVSC) flexible electrode. The graphene nanosheets (GNs) after weak oxidation were incorporated into SnO<sub>2 </sub>(SnO<sub>2</sub>/GNs) to enhance the electron mobility and flexibility of electron selective layer (ESL). The deposited C<sub>60</sub>-self-assembled monolayer(C<sub>60</sub>-SAM) between perovskite and ESL can impede carrier recombination. Herein, the improved surface photovoltage responses can be attributed to the synergistic effect of C<sub>60</sub>-SAM and SnO<sub>2</sub>/GNs ESL under zero and applied electric field. The best-performing PVSC has achieved a PCE of 13.36%, a V<sub>oc</sub> of 1.10 V, a J<sub>sc</sub> of 18.39 mA cm<sup>&minus;2</sup>, and a FF of 0.66 under a reverse voltage scan (the corresponding PCE of 12.81%, V<sub>oc</sub> of 1.10 V, J<sub>sc</sub> of 18.19 mA cm<sup>&minus;2</sup>, and FF of 0.64 under a forward scan), indicating the negligible hysteresis. The EMIMBF<sub>4 </sub>can improve the dispersivity and intrinsic contacts between Ag nanowires. The C<sub>60</sub>-SAM and SnO<sub>2</sub>/GNs can passivate surface traps in perovskite and enhance the charge dynamics. The PVSC in a low-temperature solution process is compatible with roll-to-roll manufacturing and the intrinsic charge dynamics was also explored.
1346	Magnetic edge states in bilayer zigzag graphene ribbon	The magnetic edge states in bilayer graphene nanoribbons with zigzag edges are studied by using an unrestricted self-consistent mean-field approach to a Hubbard model on the bilayer hexagonal lattice. Different from the single layer ribbon, three self-consistent solutions are found, corresponding to three different kinds of edge spin arrangements for AB-stacked bilayer zigzag ribbons. The edge state with the lowest energy is consistent with Lieb's theorem not only for the whole bilayer ribbon but also for each layer alone, where edge spins prefer ferromagnetic alignment within each layer while antiferromagnetic arrangement between the two layers.
1347	Topological charges of Skyrmions in Fe<sub>0.5</sub>Co<sub>0.5</sub>Si-Like Quasi-Two-Dimensional Ferromagnets	In a continuous system, magnetic skyrmions are characterized by an integer-valued topological index, often referred to as the topological charge. However, this topological concept is not applicable to the energetically stabilized magnetic structures of discrete lattices. In this work, we apply a quantized spin model to a Fe<sub>0.5</sub>Co<sub>0.5</sub>Si-Like quasi-two-dimensional ferromagnetic system with co-existing Dzyaloshinsky-Moriya and Heisenberg-exchange interactions. We find that, the helical texture is the spontaneous ground state; when a weak external magnetic field is applied normal to the magnetic layer, skyrmion lattice of hexagonal-closely-packed pattern is induced; our calculated periodic distances of the spin textures in weak external magnetic fields are consistent with the theoretical value; the topological charge of each skyrmion is a field-dependent non-integer value, showing strong effects of quantum physics unaccounted for by previous studies on continuous systems; each skymion is surrounded by four non-fully developed vortices, formed by the spins in the boundary area, which curl in the opposite direction; as the field is increased and temperature changes, the SkX pattern can be rotated, elongated and deformed; if the external field is continuously enhanced, a SkX plus bimeron phase appears, the spin texture evolves, and finally becomes ferromagnetic. Therefore, this quantum model, if scaled, is able to qualitatively reproduce the experimental results of SkX with long periodicity, and especially, it is expected to be more accurate than the classical ones when the skyrmion size is in the order of nanometer.
1348	<strong>Resonate and Fire Neuron with Fixed Magnetic Skyrmions</strong>	In the brain, the membrane potential of many neurons oscillates in a subthreshold damped fashion and fire when excited by an input frequency that nearly equals their eigen frequency. In this work, we investigate theoretically the artificial implementation of such &ldquo;resonate-and-fire&rdquo; neurons by utilizing the magnetization dynamics of a fixed magnetic skyrmion in the free layer of a magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ). To realize firing of this nanomagnetic implementation of an artificial neuron, we propose to employ voltage control of magnetic anisotropy or voltage generated strain as an input (spike or sinusoidal) signal, which modulates the perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (PMA). This results in continual expansion and shrinking (i.e. breathing) of a skyrmion core that mimics the subthreshold oscillation. Any subsequent input pulse having an interval close to the breathing period or a sinusoidal input close to the eigen frequency drives the magnetization dynamics of the fixed skyrmion in a resonant manner. The time varying electrical resistance of the MTJ layer due to this resonant oscillation of the skyrmion core is used to drive a Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor (CMOS) buffer circuit, which produces spike outputs. By rigorous micromagnetic simulation, we investigate the interspike timing dependence and response to different excitatory and inhibitory incoming input pulses. Finally, we show that such resonate and fire neurons have potential application in coupled nanomagnetic oscillator based associative memory arrays.
1349	The electronic structures and absorption spectra of Mn-doped GaAs nanowires in the magnetic field	The electronic structures and absorption spectra of Mn-doped GaAs nanowires in the magnetic field are calculated via eight-band k.p theory. During the calculation, the optical transitions satisfying the selection rule of nanowires at different wave vectors are considered. We find that (i) the shape of $\pi$ absorption spectra is substantially different from that of $\sigma$ absorption spectra whether the radius is 3 nm or 6 nm, and more strong peaks will appear in $\pi$ and $\sigma$ absorption spectra when the radius increases from 3 nm to 6 nm; (ii) the shape of $\pi$ absorption spectra is almost unchanged even if the magnetic field increases to 30 T, while it can be affected slightly by increasing the concentration of manganese ions; (iii) two $\sigma$ absorption spectra can be separated by the magnetic field, and the separation between $\sigma^+$ and $\sigma^-$ absorption spectra will increase as the increase of the magnetic field and the concentration of manganese ions; (iv) the intensities of the first strong peak in $\sigma^+$ absorption spectra will become larger than that of the first strong peak in $\sigma^-$ absorption spectra gradually as the increase of the magnetic field and the concentration of manganese ions.
1350	<strong>Flexible, transparent resistive switching device based on topological insulator Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>- organic composite</strong>	Two dimensional topological insulator (TIs) bismuth selenide (Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>) nanosheets embedded in Poly-methyl methacrylate (PMMA) are employed for the first time for the resistive switching (RS) application. Hexagonal 2D Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3 </sub>nanosheets (NSs) are synthesized by a simple solvothermal method and combine with PMMA at different weight percentage of 2D Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>. Field emission scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy along with other characterization such as X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS)  &amp; Raman spectroscopy were performed for the characterization of Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3 </sub>@ PMMA hybrid system. Composite was deposited on transparent, flexible PET substrate to form Ag/Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@PMMA/ITO memory cell. I-V characteristics of the device revealed stable and non-volatile memory effect. The device shows a significantly high resistance (R<sub>HRS</sub>/R<sub>LRS</sub>) ratio, more than 10<sup>3</sup>, high retention time (more than 9000 s) with high reproducibility over a large number of (10<sup>5</sup>) ac cycles. From the experimental data RS performances are explained by using a charge trapping&ndash;detrapping mechanism. Owing to the increasing interest in flexible electronics, bending tests have carried out at various bending diameters (10-30 mm) to show the mechanical robustness of the proposed device.
1351	<strong>A comparative study of polaronic transport in paramagnetic state of bulk and nanocrystalline La0.46Ca0.54MnO3 compound</strong>	In this present study, electronic transport and magneto-transport properties of bulk and nanocrystalline La0.46Ca0.54MnO3 compound is reported. The activation energies required for polaron transport in paramagnetic state for different average grain size particles were estimated from the resistivity as a function of temperature data in the absence of magnetic field. It is found that there is a strong dependency of the activation energy in paramagnetic state with the reduction of the grain sizes. Additionally, the correlation between the variation of activation energy and the crystallographic unit cell volume with the reduction of particle size is addressed.
1352	Multi-tip Scanning Tunneling Microscopy - Experimental Techniques and Data Analysis	In scanning tunneling microscopy, we witness in recent years a paradigm shift from "just imaging"sto detailed spectroscopic measurements at the nanoscale and multi-tip STM is a technique followingsthis trend. It is capable to perform nanoscale charge transport measurements like a "multimeter atsthe nanoscale". Distance-dependent four-point measurements, the acquisition of nanoscale potentialsmaps at current carrying nanostructures and surfaces, as well as the acquisition of I &#x2212; V curvessof nanoelectronic devices are examples of the capabilities of the multi-tip STM technique. In thissreview, we focus on two aspects: How to perform multi-tip STM measurements, and how to analyzesthe acquired data in order to gain insight into nanoscale charge transport processes for a varietysof samples. We further discuss specifics of the electronics for multi-tip STM, properties of tips forsmulti-tip STM, and present methods for a tip approach to nanostructures on insulating substrates.sWe introduce methods how to extract the conductivity/resistivity for mixed 2D/3D systems fromsfour-point measurements, and how to measure the conductivity of 2D sheets, and introduce scanningstunneling potentiometry (STP) measurements with a multi-tip setup. For the example of multitipsmeasurements at freestanding vapor liquid solid (VLS) grown nanowires, we discuss contactsresistances as well as the influence of the presence of the probing tips on the four point measurements.
1353	<strong>Understanding the influence of initial cluster size distribution on crystallization dynamics in phase-change materials</strong>	Phase-change materials are recognized as major technological contenders for the development of fast, low power and small non-volatile memories, and for realising the evolutionary paradigm of simultaneous data processing and storage for brain-like and neural computing.  The (re)crystallization process remains to be the limiting factor in deciding the operating speeds of phase-change devices.  It has been shown experimentally that pre-annealing amorphous phase-change materials leads to shorter crystallization times and therefore increased device switching speeds.  This has been attributed to the formation of nano-clusters embedded in the amorphous phase that reduce the incubation time for nucleation and leads to faster crystallization.  Recent work using enhanced transmission microscopy has confirmed the formation of nuclei that are few nanometres in size which enhance the crystallisation speed.  However, the correlation between the initial size distribution of nano-clusters on the crystallization dynamics is still uncertain, which is crucial for increasing the speed in phase-change memories and data processors.  This work aims to simulate the distribution of cluster sizes following pre-annealing and melt-quenching in as-deposited amorphous phase-change materials using the Master rate equation approach.  Moreover and to use this approach to systematically investigate the effects of theses simulated and theoretical Gaussian initial clusters densities in the sub-nanometre to few tens of nanometres range on the crystallization dynamics in phase-change material at different annealing rates.  This investigation revealed the enhancement of crystallization speeds with narrow initial distributions of small cluster sizes of few nanometres, for the same initial crystalline concentration, in agreement with enhanced microscopy observations.
1354	Nano-oscillator-based classification with a machine learning-compatible architecture	Pattern classification architectures leveraging the physics of coupled nano-oscillators have been demonstrated as promising alternative computing approaches, but lack effective learning algorithms. In this work, we propose a nano-oscillator based classification architecture where the natural frequencies of the oscillators are learned linear combinations of the inputs, and define an offline learning algorithm based on gradient back-propagation. Our results show significant classification improvements over a related approach with online learning. We also compare our architecture with a standard neural network on a simple machine learning case, which suggests that our approach is economical in terms of numbers of adjustable parameters. The introduced architecture is also compatible with existing nano-technologies: the architecture does not require changes in the coupling between nano-oscillators, and it is tolerant to oscillator phase noise.
1355	Spiking neuron circuits using superconducting quantum phase-slip junctions	Superconducting circuits that operate by propagation of small voltage or current pulses, corresponding to propagation of single flux or charge quantum, are naturally suited for implementing spiking neuron circuits. Quantum phase-slip junctions (QPSJs) are 1-D superconducting nanowires that have been identified as exact duals to Josephson junctions, based on charge-flux duality in Maxwell's equations. In this paper, a superconducting quantized-charge circuit element, formed using quantum phase-slip junctions, is investigated for use in high-speed, low-energy superconducting spiking neuron circuits. By means of a SPICE model developed for QPSJs, operation of this superconducting circuit to produce and transport quantized charge pulses, in the form of current pulses, is demonstrated. The resulting quantized-charge-based operation emulates spiking neuron circuits for brain-inspired neuromorphic applications. Additionally, to further demonstrate the operation of QPSJ-based neuron circuits, a QPSJ-based integrate and fire neuron circuit is introduced, along with simulation results using WRSPICE. Estimates for operating speed and power dissipation are provided and compared to Josephson junction and CMOS-based spiking neuron circuits.
1356	High-speed low-power neuromorphic systems based on magnetic Josephson junctions	Josephson junctions and single flux quantum (SFQ) circuits form a natural neuromorphic technology with SFQ pulses and superconducting transmission lines simulating action potentials and axons. Josephson junctions consist of superconducting electrodes with nanoscale barriers that modulate the coupling of the complex superconducting order parameter across the junction. When the order parameter undergoes a 2&pi; phase jump, the junction emits a voltage pulse with an integrated amplitude of a flux quantum &#x03D5;<sub>0</sub>=h/(2e<sup>2</sup> )=2.068x10<sup>-15</sup>Vs. The coupling across a junction can be controlled and modulated by incorporating nanoscale magnetic structure in the barrier. The magnetic state of embedded nanoclusters can be changed by applying small currents or field pulses, enabling both unsupervised and supervised learning. The advantage of this magnetic/superconducting technology is that it combines natural spiking behavior and plasticity in a single nanoscale device and is orders of magnitude faster and lower energy than other technologies. Maximum operating frequencies are above 100 GHz, while spiking and training energies are ~10<sup>-20</sup>J, 10<sup>-18</sup>J, respectively. This technology can operate close to the thermal limit, which at 4K, is considerably lower energy than in a human brain. The transition from deterministic to stochastic behavior can be studied with small temperature modifications. Here we present a tutorial on the spiking behavior of Josephson junctions, the use of nanoscale magnetic structure to modulate the coupling across the junction, the design and operation of magnetic Josephson junctions, device models and simulation of magnetic Josephson junction neuromorphic circuits, and potential neuromorphic architectures based on hybrid superconducting/ magnetic technology.
1357	Perspectives on Antibacterial Performance of Silver Nanoparticle-loaded Three-dimensional Polymeric Constructs	Silver nanoparticle (AgNP)-loaded polymeric constructs are widely investigated for potential applications as drug delivery systems, wound dressings, and anti-biofouling biomaterials.  Herein, we present several methods for fabricating such materials and evaluate their efficacy against Escherichia coli.  H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>(v)</sub> plasma surface modification is employed to enhance material surface wettability (explored by water contact angle goniometry) and nanoparticle incorporation.  Compositional analyses reveal that incorporation of AgNPs on the surface and bulk of the materials strongly depends on the fabrication methodology.  More importantly, the nature of AgNP incorporation into the polymer has direct implications on the biocidal performance resulting from release of Ag+.  The mate-rials fabricated herein fell significantly short of healthcare standards with respect to antimicrobial behavior, and, in comparing our results to numerous literature studies.  Notably, we identified a glaring disparity in the way such results are often described.  Thus, this work also contains a critical evaluation of the literature, highlighting select poor-performing materials to demonstrate several shortcomings in the quantitative analysis and reporting of the antibacterial efficacy of AgNP-loaded materials.  Ultimately, we provide recommendations for best practices for better evaluation of these constructs towards improved antibacterial efficacy in medical settings.
1358	<strong>Micromagnetic simulation of spin torque ferromagnetic resonance in </strong><strong>nano-ring-shape confined magnetic tunnel junctions</strong>	Spin-torque excited ferromagnetic resonance (ST-FMR) performed in nanoscale devices can be used to characterize material properties and optimize spintronic devices for application. In this paper, micromagnetic simulation is employed to study the FMR property in a nano-ring shaped magnetic tunnel junction. The simulation predictions are confirmed by experiments, revealing that two resonance states (mode-1 and mode-2) with different resonance frequency are excited by a microwave frequency current or magnetic field. The relative weak response signal of FMR at negative field can be attributed to the intrinsic asymmetric structure of MTJs, which leads to a bias-dependent asymmetric spin transfer torques. Besides, high-order harmonics with twice and three times of fundamental frequencies of the mode-1 and mode-2 are also observed.
1359	Nonlinear Plasmonics of Three-Dimensional Dirac Semimetals	The three-dimensional Dirac semimetal (3D DSM) is a new class of material with a slew of electronic and optical properties in common with graphene, while structurally having a bulk form like real metals. In particular, the Dirac bandstructure of 3D DSM conferred very high optical nonlinearities much like the case for graphene. Consequently, we found that 3D DSM has respectable nonlinear plasmonic performance in comparison with graphene, while retaining the structural benefits of bulk metals, having reduced passive plasmonic losses, and is much easier to handle in fabrication facilities. 3D DSM is expected to play a strong role in providing strong optical nonlinearities for all-optical switching, and at the same time offering a superior platform for nanophotonic device integration.
1360	Magnetic Domain Wall Neuron with Lateral Inhibition	<strong>The development of an efficient neuromorphic computing system requires the use of nanodevices that intrinsically emulate the biological behavior of neurons and synapses. While numerous artificial synapses have been shown to be analogous to biological synapses, the challenge of developing an artificial neuron is impeded by its more complex functionality. In particular, previous proposals for artificial neurons have required the use of external circuits to perform lateral inhibition, thereby decreasing the efficiency of the resulting neuromorphic computing system. This work therefore proposes a leaky integrate-and-fire neuron that intrinsically provides lateral inhibition, without requiring any additional circuitry. The proposed neuron is based on the previously proposed domain-wall magnetic tunnel junction devices, which have been proposed as artificial synapses and experimentally demonstrated for non-volatile logic. Single-neuron micromagnetic simulations are provided that demonstrate the ability of this neuron to implement the required leaking, integrating, and firing. These simulations are then extended to pairs of adjacent neurons to demonstrate, for the first time, lateral inhibition between neighboring artificial neurons. Finally, this intrinsic lateral inhibition is applied to a ten-neuron crossbar structure and trained to identify handwritten digits, and shown via direct large-scale micromagnetic simulation for 100 digits to correctly identify the proper signal for 94% of the digits.</strong>
1361	Tunable resistivity in ink-jet printed electrical structures on paper by plasma conversion of particle-free, stabilizer-free silver inks	Printable metal inks are typically composed of premade nanoparticles that require post-deposition thermal sintering to produce crystalline, electrically-conductive features.  In this paper, we show that particle-free Ag inks made from simple, water-soluble metal salts such as silver nitrate can be ink-jet printed and converted into electrical features with tunable resistivity at low temperature (&lt;100 oC) by exposure to a pure argon plasma.  X-ray diffraction confirms that the converted inks are crystalline and four-point probe electrical measurements show that the sheet resistances are a function of the pressure and power in the plasma.  From cross-sectional scanning electron microscopy analysis, we find that morphology of the converted silver layer becomes increasingly dense with increasing plasma treatment time, which explains the measured changes in sheet resistance, and that the thickness of the layer is ~1.5 &#x00B5;m, which yields a minimum resistivity of ~6&#x00D7;10-8 &#x03A9;-m, approximately 3.8X times higher than bulk resistivity of silver.  Interestingly, the resistivity can be varied over a span of 6 orders of magnitude which allows resistor-capacitor (RC) filter devices to be fabricated exhibiting varying cutoff frequencies from a single material and geometry.
1362	Development of a scanning probe microscopy integrated atomic layer deposition system for in-situ successive monitoring of thin films growth	A dual chamber system integrated with atomic layer deposition (ALD) and atomic force microscopy (AFM) was developed for the successive monitoring of nanoparticles to thin films growth process. The samples were fabricated in the ALD chamber. A magnetic transmission rod enabled sample transferring between the ALD and the AFM test chambers without breaking the vacuum condition, avoiding possible surface morphology change when frequently varying the growth condition and oxidation when exposed to air. The sample transmission also avoids deposition and contamination on the AFM tip during the successive testing process. The sample stage has machined a group of accurate location pinholes, ensuring the 10 um2 measurement consistency. As a demonstration, platinum metallic thin films were fabricated with thickness control by varying ALD cycles. The surface morphology was monitored successively during the deposition. After high temperature treatment under vacuum condition and with controlled oxygen partial pressure, the aging and sintering phenomenon of particles has been observed in the AFM testing chamber. The integrated AFM/ALD instrument is potentially a powerful tool for thin film preparation and characterization system.
1363	2D re-programmable magnonic crystal with vertical control of the spin wave dynamics: Py film decorated with array of  elliptical nanodots	We investigate magnonic band structure in thin homogeneous Py film decorated with periodic array of elliptically shaped Py dots and separated by a Pt spacer. We demonstrated experimentally formation of the magnonic band structure for Damon-Eshbach wave propagating in Py film  with the band gap opened at the Brillouin zone border and band splitting at smaller wavenumbers, due to the Bragg resonance and interaction of propagating wave with a confined magnetization oscillations in nanodots, respectively. The shape anisotropy of the Py nanodots allows to control the spin wave dynamics through the switch between two states of the magnetization with respect to the underneath film magnetization. With numerical analysis we show that predominant role in formation of the magnonic band structure is played by a vertical dynamic coupling between propagating wave in the film and magnetization oscillations in the nanodots.
1364	<strong>Synthesis and intrinsic magnetism of bilayer graphene nanoribbons</strong>	Pristine bilayer graphene nanoribbons (BLGNRs) with the average width of ca. 9 nm were obtained by longitudinal unzipping the oxalic acid-intercalated double-walled carbon nanotubes followed by annealing at 900 <sup>o</sup>C. The magnetic properties of BLGNRs were investigated. The results reveal that BLGNRs show obvious antiferromagnetic behavior with the N&eacute;el temperature of ca. 66 K. It is proposed that (i) the spin-polarized edge states are the dominant magnetic source, and (ii) the antiferromagnetism is mainly caused by the interlayer couplings.
1365	<strong>Calculation of mass </strong><strong>attenuation coefficients, effective atomic numbers and electron densities for Iron, Cobalt, Copper and Zinc nano-Hydroxyapatite</strong>	Iron, cobalt, copper and zinc substituted hydroxyapatite nanoparticles (nFeHA, nCoHA, nCuHA and nZnHA) were obtained successfully by ultrasonically assisted wet chemical method. The values of X-ray attenuation coefficients of present samples were calculated experimentally using narrow transmission geometry. The specimens were absorbed with using 59.6 photons emitted from an <sup>241</sup>Am radioisotope source with 50 mCi activity. The attenuation coefficients of the samples were compared with each other, HA and real animal bone powder experimentally and XCOm predicted values. Electron densities and effective atomic numbers were derived from the mass attenuation coefficients. The obtained results may provide information on how much radiation the samples can absorb when they are exposed to X-rays at current energy.
1366	Single, double, and triple quantum dots in Ge/Si nanowires	We report highly tunable control of holes in Ge/Si core/shell nanowires. We demonstrate the<br />ability to create single quantum dots of various sizes, with low hole occupation numbers and clearly<br />observable excited states. For the smallest dot size we observe indications of single-hole occupation.<br />Moreover, we create double and triple tunnel-coupled quantum dot arrays. In the double quantum<br />dot conguration we observe Pauli spin blockade (PSB). These results open the way to perform hole<br />spin qubit experiments in these devices.
1367	<strong>NEURONAL CELLS CONFINEMENT BY MICROPATTERNED CLUSTER-ASSEMBLED DOTS WITH MECHANOTRANSDUCTIVE NANOTOPOGRAPHY </strong>	The <em>in vitro </em>fabrication of neural networks able to simulate brain circuits and to maintain their native connectivity is of strategic importance to gain a deep understanding of neural circuit physiology and brain natural computational algorithm(s). This would also enable a wide-range of applications including the development of efficient brain-on-chip devices or brain-computer interfaces. Chemical and mechanotransductive cues cooperate to promote proper development and functioning of neural networks. Since the 80&rsquo;s, controlled growth of mammalian neuronal cells on micrometric patterned chemical cues with the development of synaptic connections and electrical activity has been reported, however the role of mechanotransductive signaling on the growth/organization of neural networks has not been investigated so far. Here we report the fabrication and characterization of patterned substrates for neuronal culture with a controlled structure both at the nano- and microscale suitable for the selective adhesion of neuronal cells. Nanostructured micrometric dots were patterned on passivated cell-repellent glass substrates by supersonic cluster beam deposition of zirconia nanoparticles through stencil masks. Cluster-assembled nanostructured zirconia surfaces are characterized by nanotopographical features that can direct the maturation of neural networks by mechanotransductive signaling. Our approach produces a controlled microscale pattern of adhesive areas with predetermined nanoscale morphology. We have validated these micropatterned substrates using a neuronal cell line (PC12 cells) and cultured hippocampal neurons. While cells have been uniformly plated on the substrates, they adhered only on the nanostructured zirconia regions, remaining effectively confined inside the nanostructured dots on which they were found to grow, move and differentiate.
1368	Thermo-Magneto Effects on Cu- Engine-Oil/Water-Nanofluids in a Porous Annulus Medium	In this attempt, we examined the thermo-magneto influences on nanofluid in a porous circular annulus region, bounded by the rotating cylinders, in the presence of the constant radial magnetic field but variable thermal conductivity. The nanofluid consists of a sample liquid (water/ engine oil) along with suspended copper-nanoparticles. We formulated this physical problem and developed the analytical solutions, by using the homotopy analysis method, in the form of the physical variables such as; the pressure, the fluid speed, the temperature, shear stress, the thermal heat transfer and the concentration of nanoparticles. Then we studied the effects of the field parameters on these physical variables. We found that the fluid-speed (pressure) increases (decreases) with the Forchheirmer coefficient, the porosity, the applied magnetic field intensity and the angular speed of an outer cylinder but it decreases with angular speed of the inner cylinder, for both the liquids. The reverse flow exists if the inner and outer cylinders are rotating in the opposite directions for both the liquids. Furthermore the thermal transfer rate in engine oil is lower than that in water. If the annulus region is squeezed then the fluid-speed decays while the pressure rises. The temperature and the thermal transfer rate decay if we march from inner cylinder to outer one. The porosity and the angular speed of the outer cylinder enhance the viscous dissipation and shear stress. The concentration is proportional to the temperature. The results are also compared with the existing literature for the clear fluid. The comparison is well.
1369	<strong>Structural phase transition, grain growth and optical properties of uncompensated Ga-V co-doped TiO<sub>2</sub></strong>	Effect of uncompensated Ga-V co-doping (0&le;<em>x</em>&le;0.046) on structural phase transition, grain growth process and optical properties of TiO<sub>2</sub> is reported here. Inhibition of phase transition due to co-doping is confirmed by X-ray diffraction measurement. Activation energy of phase transition increases from 120KJ/mol (<em>x</em>=0) to 240 KJ/mol (<em>x</em>=0.046) due to Ga-V co-doping.  In anatase phase, lattice constants increase by the effect of Ga<sup>3+</sup> interstitials.  This results in inhibition of phase transition.  Anatase phase becomes stable up to ~650 &deg;C in co-doped sample whereas for pure TiO<sub>2</sub> phase transition starts in between 450-500 &#x2070;C. In anatase phase, strain increases due to co-doping which reduces crystallite size. In rutile phase, grain growth process is enhanced due to co-doping and particles show a rod-like structure with majority {110} facets. Bandgap decreases in both phases and reduced to the visible light region. BET analysis shows that surface area increases from 4.55 m<sup>2</sup>/g (<em>x</em>=0) to 96.53 m<sup>2</sup>/g (<em>x</em>=0.046) by Ga-V incorporation which provide a large number of active site for photocatalytic activity. Hence, co-doped anatase nanoparticle can be used as a promising candidate for photocatalytic applications using visible light up to a higher temperature ~650 &deg;C.
1370	<strong>Pulsed Laser Transfer of Micro-droplets through </strong><strong>Patterned Apertures in Thin Copper Films</strong>	This paper explores a mask-based approach to control the transfer of molten droplets from a donor film to a target substrate by locally heating copper films with a nanosecond pulsed laser. The presence of apertures in the donor film facilitate the generation of micro-bumps with small protrusions that extend into micro-jets with diameters of between 1-2 mm and a height of up 5 mm above the donor film surface. The micro-jets break-up into single or multiple droplets that are deposited on the target substrate. The number of transferred droplets for a single laser shot depends on the film thickness and the laser fluence. The smallest diameter of a single droplet observed on the target substrate is below 3 mm, obtained from an 800 nm thick donor film. We explore a 2D axisymmetric heat conduction numerical model to investigate the temperature distribution in the donor film and the corresponding material phases expected for different laser fluence and film thicknesses. Furthermore, we use the results from the model to provide a qualitative explanation for the micro-bumps and micro-jets observed in the experiment, and to identify the regime where controlled melting of the donor film and transfer of molten droplets to the target substrate can be facilitated. Our results suggest that the aperture-based approach has the potential to control the minimum size of droplets transferred to the target substrate, thus allowing for controlled synthesis of micro- and nanosized metal particles, which have significant interests in sensing and catalysis applications, and microscale ballistic experiments.
1371	Designing CdS/Se heterojunction as high-performance self-powered UV-visible broadband photodetector	Se nanorod film is successfully synthesized on hydrothermally-grown CdS layer through a facile vapor phase deposition process, forming a n-CdS/p-Se heterojunction. By virtue of the narrow direct bandgap and large absorption coefficient in UV-visible range of CdS and Se, the integrated CdS/Se photodetector exhibits excellent self-powered behavior in wide spectral range. In particular, the heterojunction device shows a high photoresponse under weak light irradiation (500 nm, 1.08 &#x00B5;W/cm2) with large on-off ratio (9&#x00D7;103), high responsivity (40 mA/W) and detectivity (1.3&#x00D7;1013 Jones), as well as fast response speed (rise time 2 &#x03BC;s and decay time 22 ms).
1372	Novel optical property of PbS/ZnS nanocrystals	PbS quantum dots (QDs) were synthesized via colloidal route, and then PbS/ZnS nanocrystals (NCs) were prepared for the first time by two different routes: the epitaxial growth and cation substitution method. The structure and optical property of these NCs were characterized by XRD, EDX and vis-NIR absorption. For two kinds of PbS/ZnS NCs, the ground state exciton binding energy becomes stronger due to introducing of Zn, and there is the same blue shift of optical band gap despite their different sizes, which isn&rsquo;t in accordance with the classic <em>E<sub>g</sub></em>-R relation of nanoparticles. Two new exciton peaks appear in PbS/ZnS NCs.
1373	<strong>Study on Electrical Behavior of Copper </strong><strong>and its Alloys</strong><strong> Containing Dispersed Nanoparticles</strong>	Nanoparticles can be added to metals to tune their properties for widespread applications. Significant research has been recently conducted to understand the functional properties of the nanoparticle reinforced metals. However, few theories exist to understand how nanoparticles interact with metals to affect their electrical performance, partly due to the difficulty in producing bulk metal samples containing dispersed nanoparticles. In this work, bulk copper and copper alloy samples (Cu, Cu-40Zn, and Cu-60Ag) containing dispersed tungsten carbide (WC) nanoparticles (~100-200 nm) of more than 20 vol.% were successfully fabricated via solidification processing. The experimental results show that copper and its alloys with an increasing volume fraction of nanoparticles offer an exponentially decaying electrical conductivity. A new theoretical model compatible with the Nordheim&rsquo;s rule was established to predict the electrical behavior of metals containing dispersed nanoparticles.. The new model on the electrical behavior of the copper nanocomposite samples is experimentally validated by the low-temperature resistivity and electronic heat capacity above Debye temperature.
1374	<strong>Preparation of MoS<sub>2</sub> Quantum Dots Based on Optimized Liquid Phase Exfoliation and Its Optical Properties</strong>	MoS<sub>2</sub> quantum dots prepared by the optimized liquid phase exfoliation technique are investigated in this study. Thorough grinding of the bulk material followed by an ultrasonic reaction may facilitate the formation of quantum dots with narrow size distribution. The morphology, crystal structures and chemical properties of the quantum dots are studied using TEM, AFM, XRD, FTIR, Raman and XPS respectively. The optical properties of the nanomaterial are characterized by UV-Vis and fluorescence spectrophotometers. The results showed that the MoS<sub>2</sub> quantum dots fluoresce under 365 nm excitation and they exhibited graphene-like properties. Such characteristics of MoS<sub>2</sub> quantum dots would have great potential in optoelectronic applications.
1375	<strong>Inhibition of spontaneous emission in a leaky mode wedge nanocavity<sup></sup></strong>	In this paper, we experimentally investigate the effective role of a wedge-type leaky-mode nanocavity on the inhibition dynamics of the spontaneous emission rate of core-shell CdTe/CdS quantum dots. Three dimensional wedge cavities are fabricated inside a fused silica micro-rod by a conventional fiber-drawing technique, which allow confinement of the quantum dots by the capillary effect. It is demonstrated that both optical and geometrical design of the photonic cavity enforce the generation of leaky modes that cause an inhibition in the spontaneous emission rate monotonically, by about 50%, due to coupling of the emitted photons into continuum modes. Time-resolved experiments confirm that the spontaneous emission rate decreases as the cavity wedge angle increases from 43 to 88 degrees. The physics behind the transduction mechanism of this phenomenon is explained by the weak-coupling regime.
1376	Rheological (extensional, shear) and morphological properties of linear low density polyethylene nanocomposites in the presence of modified and unmodified silica	The objectives of this study are to investigate the effect of modification of silica nanoparticles on the rheological behavior of linear low-density polyethylene (LLDPE) in both shear and extensional flow. The silica nanoparticles surface was modified by silanization reaction and with hexadecyltrimethoxysilane as silane agent. Melt blending method was performed to prepare the nanocomposites samples. Characterization methods included Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and rheometric measurements under shear and uniaxial extensional flows. Sentmanat Extension Rheometer (SER) and parallel plate rheometer were used to investigate rheological behavior of the nanocomposites in extensional and shear flow, respectively. The shear data illustrated that for all samples, storage modulus and complex viscosity of LLDPE with the modified silica nanoparticles were higher than the samples containing unmodified silica. The extensional rheology results showed that regardless of the type of silica, the elongational viscosity becomes larger by the incorporation of silica nanoparticles. LLDPE containing 2 wt.% of the unmodified silica nanoparticles demonstrated strain hardening behavior that was disappeared by increasing loading of the unmodified silica from 2 to 8 wt.%. Another interesting result was obtained for the LLDPE nanocomposite samples containing the modified silica particles. By loading of the modified silica nanoparticles in LLDPE nanocomposite samples, a fracture took place due to gel structure formation in these samples. Finally, Kaye-Bernstein-Kearsley-Zapas (K-BKZ) model was used to correlate the extensional rheological property of the present LLDPE/ SiO2 nanocomposites.
1377	The same optical property of PbS/ZnS nanocrystals with different sizes	PbS quantum dots (QDs) were synthesized via colloidal route, and then PbS/ZnS nanocrystals (NCs) were prepared for the first time by two different routes:  the epitaxial growth and cation substitution method. The structure and optical property of these NCs were characterized by XRD, EDX and vis-NIR absorption. For two kinds of PbS/ZnS NCs, the ground state exciton binding energy becomes stronger due to introducing of Zn, and there is the same blue shift of optical band gap despite their different sizes, which isn't in accordance with the classic Eg-R relation of nanoparticles. Two new exciton peaks appear in PbS/ZnS NCs.
1378	<strong>Mixed convection characteristics in a U-shaped lid-driven cavity with a baffle in the presence of magnetic field</strong>	In the present study, mixed convection of CuO/water nanofluid in a lid-driven U-shaped enclosure filled with a baffle is studied using lattice Boltzmann method. The bottom wall is fixed at a uniform temperature and the effect of magnetic field is investigated. KKL (Koo-Kleinstreuer-Li) model is used to get the effective thermal conductivity and viscosity of nanofluid. In this model, Brownian motion of nanoparticle is considered. Effect of Hartmann number, Richardson number, Reynolds number and nanoparticle volume fraction on the fluid flow and heat transfer characteristics have been examined. The results revealed that the addition of nanoparticles has a significant positive effect on the heat transfer. However, at <em>Re</em> = 100, the nanofluid strategy has a detrimental effect on the Nusselt number when the Richardson number is high. As Reynolds number increases, the average Nusselt number increases but adverse trends can be observed when the Hartmann numbers increases. The effect of increasing Reynolds number on the heat transfer is more pronounced at higher Richardson numbers.
1379	Integrating Plasmonic Nanostructures with Natural Photonic Architectures in Pd-Modified <em>Morpho</em> Butterfly Wings for Sensitive Hydrogen Gas Sensing	This work reports a bioinspired three-dimensional (3D) heterogeneous structure for optical hydrogen gas (H<sub>2</sub>) sensing. The structure was fabricated by selective modification of the photonic architectures of <em>Morpho</em> butterfly scales with Pd nanostrips. The coupling of the plasmonic mode of the Pd nanostrips with the optical resonant mode of the <em>Morpho</em> biophotonic architectures generated a sharp reflectance peak in the spectra of Pd-modified butterfly wing, as well as enhancement of light-matter interaction in Pd nanostrips. Exposure to H<sub>2</sub> resulted in a rapid reversible increase in the reflectance of the Pd-modified butterfly wing, and the pronounced response of the reflectance was at the wavelength where the plasmonic mode strongly interplayed with the optical resonant mode. Owing to the synergetic effect of Pd nanostrips and biophotonic structures, the bioinspired sensor achieved an H<sub>2</sub> detection limit of less than 10 ppm. Besides, the Pd-modified butterfly wing also exhibited good sensing repeatability. The results suggest that this approach provides a promising optical H<sub>2</sub> sensing scheme, which may also offer the potential design of new nanoengineered structures for diverse sensing applications.
1380	Aluminum Nitride (AlN) Single Nanowire UV Photodetector	High UV light sensitivity, small size, very short response time, low power consumption, and high efficiency are the most important features of nanowire based devices for new and superior applications in photodetectors, photovoltaics, optical switches, and image sensors. Single AlN nanowire UV photodetector has been fabricated from the catalyst-free grown high quality AlN nanowires through a very practical scheme. The UV photodetector, which can operate at low voltages ({less than or equal to} 3 V), has shown a significant photocurrent response to the 254 nm UV light exposure. Moreover, the photocurrent has decayed to the dark current value rapidly, after the exposure ended suggesting the absence of defect-related traps. Furthermore, the photocurrent rise (&#x03C4;r) and decay time constants (&#x03C4;d) have been determined through modelling from the time-dependent current response curves of the photodetector. The &#x03C4;r  and &#x03C4;d were determined to be 7.7 s and 11.5 s, respectively.
1381	<strong>Exchange-interaction by the induced growth of the soft phase on the extreme hard phase </strong>	The significant change is reported in interparticle interaction for nanocomposites of &epsilon;-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and FeCo with the morphological change of the soft phase (FeCo) from amorphous to crystalline state upon annealing. It undergoes a transition from the dipolar interaction dominant regime into the exchange-interaction dominant regime, starting from the crystalline soft phase size of 9.6 nm, which is coincident with the theoretical critical dimension. The effective anisotropy increases exponentially as the ordering dimension of the soft phase increases with the ratio between hard and soft phases stays constant, causing a delay in the demagnetization process. The emerged exchange-interaction is understood by the induced growth of the soft phase on the extreme hard phase.
1382	Facile Synthesis of Ultra-Small Polydopamine-PEG Nanoparticles for Cellular Delivery	Very small polydopamine (PDA) poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) crosslinked copolymer (PDA-PEG) nanoparticles have been prepared following a convenient one-step procedure in aqueous solution. Particle sizes and colloidal stabilities have been optimized by varying PEG in view of chain length and end group functionalities. In particular, amine-terminated PEG3000 (PEG3000(NH2)2) reacted with polydopamine intermediates so that very small, crosslinked PDA-PEG nanoparticles with sizes of less than 50 nm were formed. These nanoparticles remained stable in buffer solution and no sedimentation occurred. Chemical functionalization was straight-forward as demonstrated by the attachment of fluorescent dyes. The PDA-PEG nanoparticles revealed efficient cellular uptake and high cytocompatibility thus rendering them attractive candidates for cell imaging or for drug delivery applications.
1383	Streamer corona, single filament, transient glow, dc glow, spark and their transitions in atmospheric air	By using a ballast resistor having resistance of 10 M&#x03A9;, varying the gap distance from 23 mm to 0 mm and using a fixed dc voltage at 14 kV, the streamer corona, single filament, transient glow, dc glow and spark modes and their transitions are demonstrated in positive needle-to-plate air discharge at atmospheric pressure. The electrical characteristics, the rotational temperature and vibrational temperature of N2, as well as the temporal behavior of streamer propagation in these discharge modes are investigated. First, to the best of our knowledge, the transient glow mode between the single filament mode and the dc glow mode, operated in a stable repetitive fashion, is reported for the first time in positive dc air discharges. The pulse repetition frequency ranges from 7.5 to 15 kHz. The current density and the rotational temperature are in the range of 27-105 A/mm2 and 600-850 K, respectively. Its temporal behavior reveals that, after the primary streamer arrives at the cathode, the secondary streamer initiates within several nanoseconds near the anode and then propagates at high speed of 105-106 m/s. There is no transition to spark even after the secondary streamer arrives at the cathode. Second, the transition from single filament to transient glow is characterized by the sudden decrease of the pulse repetition frequency and the abrupt increase of the current amplitude, the pulse width and the gas temperature. Third, the transition from transient glow to dc glow is identified visibly by the formation of typical glow structure (positive column, Faraday dark space and negative glow), which is accompanied by the transition of the discharge current from nanosecond pulse to dc. In addition, both the ballast resistor and the stray capacitor exert significant influence on the transition of discharge modes.
1384	<strong>Multiband Light Emission and Nanoscale Chemical Analyses of Carbonized Fumed Silica</strong>	Fumed silica with specific area of 295 m<sup>2</sup>/g were carbonized by successive phenyltrimethoxysilane treatments followed by annealing in inert atmosphere up to 650 <sup>o</sup>C. Emission, excitation, kinetics and photo-induced bleaching effects were investigated by steady state and time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopies. The local chemistry was also studied by infrared transmission spectroscopy. Strong ultraviolet and visible photoluminescence was observed in the samples after the chemical treatments/modifications and thermal annealing. It has been shown that ultraviolet photoluminescence in chemically modified fumed silica is associated with phenyl groups, while near ultraviolet and visible emission in annealed samples are originated from inorganic pyrolytic carbon precipitates dispersed in the silica host matrix. Two types of emission bands were identified as a function of the annealing temperature: one is in the near UV and the other is in the visible range. Based on the emission/excitation analysis of these two bands, as well as on correlations with the synthesis conditions, a structural-energy concept of light-emitting centers has been proposed. According to this model, the light-emitting centers are associated with sub-nanometer carbon clusters that can be bonded or adsorbed on the silica surface.  This has been validated by a detailed (S)TEM-EELS study, confirming the presence of 2-6 nm carbon nanoclusters, inhomogeneously distributed at the surface of the silica nanoparticles. These carbon nanoclusters are mostly amorphous although they possess some degree of graphitization and local order. Finally, the fraction of sp<sup>2</sup> carbon in these nanoclusters has been estimated to be close to 80 %.
1385	Electrostatic transport modulation in single crystal VO<sub>2</sub> nanowire channels and their width dependence using planar-type side gating	Investigations of electric field-induced resistance modulation in correlated electron oxides with a metal-insulator transition play a significant role in understanding the behavior of nano-domains <em>via</em> electric perturbation and in paving the way for steep slope switching applications. Here we report the dependence of the resistance switching effect on both the width of oxide nanowires and their crystallinity in VO<sub>2</sub>-based planar-type field effect transistors. A positive electric field yielded an expansion of the metallic nano-domains, while a negative one caused a depletion layer to form. Moreover, narrower VO<sub>2</sub> nanowires and single crystal VO<sub>2</sub> nanowires showed effective resistance modulation when the gate bias was varied. Our results provide an understanding of the electronic characteristics in metal-insulator nano-domains through carrier modulation and further the development of devices employing metal&ndash;insulator nano-domains.
1386	<strong>Thermal property engineering of InSe layer by a thin </strong><strong>Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> stress liner</strong>	We investigate the thermal properties of thin InSe layers with high-&kappa; oxide Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> stress liners. The temperature-dependent Raman spectroscopy demonstrated that Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> passivation layer significantly improved the thermal stability of the InSe layer by reducing the thermal coefficients of in-plane E<sub>2g</sub><sup>1</sup> phonon mode from -0.03284 cm<sup>-1</sup>/K to -0.0212 cm<sup>-1</sup>/K in comparison with the InSe sample without Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> capping layer. Combined with the power-dependent Raman spectroscopy, the in-plane thermal conductivity of InSe reaches to about 53.1W/mK, greatly larger than that without Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> capping layer 38.2 W/mK, which is owing to the large thermal conductivity of Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and the electron-phonon interactions at the interface. Generally, this work will contribute to improve the performances of the InSe-based nano-devices and extend its applications profoundly.
1387	Electrical Tunable Localized States in Sub-band of Bilayer Graphene Nanoribbon	Multiple sub-bands transport in bilayer graphene nanoribbon (GNR) with localized charge states has not been experimentally investigated, owing to the difficulty of accessing into the upper sub-band. In this letter, we utilize current annealing to heavily p-dope graphene from a capping hydrogen-silsesquioxane layer. As a result, Fermi energy can be tuned into the upper sub-valence band with reasonably small gate voltage. Owing to the localized charge states, quantum dots-like characteristics is measured in bilayer GNR, as a result of the tunnelling transport of holes in the upper sub-band through these charge puddles. In contrast to monolayer GNRs, this phenomenon appears in a considerable conductive regime, since the carrier transport in the lower sub-band is still diffusive. Moreover, by electrically tuning the Fermi energy, the localized charge puddles in upper sub-band can be resized and isolated from each other, finally leading to the single &ldquo;quantum-dot&rdquo; dominated transport.
1388	Wafer-scale fabrication of amorphous silicon nanospheres in array on 6H-SiC (0001) towards a black body wave-absorber	Amorphous silicon (a-Si) nanospheres are grown on substrate of 6H-SiC (0001) by deposition of silicon on a wafer scale. The spheres in array are uniformly dispersed, and size-controllable. The a-Si spheres on substrate have a significant absorption within the range of ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) light, resulting removal of the a-Si spheres can boost the reflectance by substrate around 15%. The special structure of silicon particles on SiC might have potential applications towards the field of optoelectronic devices.
1389	Can an Element Form a Two-Dimensional Nanosheet of Type 15 Pentagons?	Type 15 pentagon was recently discovered three decades since the 14th type of pentagon was re-ported in 1985. In contrast to such a long time span, the list of two-dimensional (2D) materials keeps growing longer on a monthly (if not daily) basis according to emerging experimental and theoretical reports. Combining these two seemingly irrelevant topics, we apply density functional theory (DFT) calculations to examine the possibility of forming a 2D nanosheet with the vertices of type 15 pentagons occupied by boron, carbon, silicon, phosphorous, sulfur, gallium, germanium, or tin atoms. We find that none of the optimized eight nanosheets remain the same initial structure filled with type 15 pentagons after the geometry optimizations by a DFT calculator. Instead, we obtain different rearranged structures for each nanosheet, most of which have not yet been reported before. For example, gallium atoms form a 2D nanosheet structure with a triangular pattern that is similar to single-layer boron sheet called borophene. These new 2D materials exhibit formation energies that are comparable to that of single-layer silicene, implying the feasibility of being grown on a substrate. The electronic structure shows that all the eight nanosheets are metallic (or semi-metallic for the carbon nanosheet), compensating for the dearth of metallic systems in existing 2D materials that are mostly semiconducting. Our work shows that linking the geometry of pentagonal tiling with DFT calculations yields both educational and scientific merits.
1390	<strong>Manufacture and analysis of nanostructured monolayer porous silicon (Psi) for silicon solar cell applications</strong>	Manufacture of PSi is produced successfully depending upon photo-electrochemical etching method. Aim of this paper is to differentiate the characterization of the PSi monolayer compared to the bulk silicon. The surface of the ordinary p-n solar cell has been refabricated on the n-type region of (100) orientation in order to get better of the conversion efficiency. The procedure relied on the variable the etching time with fixed current density and vice versa. The other procedure conditions were saved constant, the HF concentration and temperature. The role of different laser kinds and powers irradiated the n-region has been understood. In especially, the blue laser (473 nm of two powers 50 and 100 mW) appears to be the most effective wavelength to achieve the optimum efficiency and pore sizes as well as the etching rate. The samples were tested and categorized by the (I-V) Measurement and investigated by SEM, PL and AFM tests. Finally, we got solar cell efficiency was in the range of (11%) compared to the ordinary solar cell efficiency which was (3.34%).
1391	Tuning the structural and magnetic properties of MnZn nano-ferrites synthesized under a high magnetic field	An approach to improve the saturation magnetization and lower magnetic loss of nanocrystalline MnZn ferrites is given. Mn0.6Zn0.4Fe2O4 nano-particles are synthesized by a phase transformation method under dc magnetic field of 0, 2, 4, and 6 T, respectively, and their structural and magnetic properties are investigated. The saturation magnetization of the 6 T sample is ~18 % and ~16 % higher than that of the 0 T sample at 120 K and 300 K, respectively. The saturation magnetization at 120 K increases with the fabrication field up to 6 T. The lattice strain also increases with the fabrication field.
1392	A Fast Turn-on, High Intensity Plasma-induced Electron Emission Cathode Based on TiN-nanorod@carbon fiber Composite Structure	The remaining challenges confronting high-current pulsed beam sources stimulate the development of robust cold cathodes. A TiN nanorod@carbon fiber cathode was prepared by hydrothermal method and nitriding. The light emission and plasma formation on the cathode surface were compared between carbon fiber cathode and TiN nanorod@cabon fiber cathode. The uniform and large-area plasma was generated on TiN nanorod@cabon fiber cathode, owing to a higher electric field enhancement factor. Further, TiN nanorod@cabon fiber cathode turned on faster, which is inferred by theoretical derivation and evolution of beam currents. TiN nanorod@cabon fiber cathode represents a promising cold cathode with superior performance.
1393	Influence of multi-scale and curved structures on the migration of stem cells	Understanding how topographical cues can control cell behavior is a major fundamental question which is of particular interest for tissue engineering. Recent findings show that cell-scale curvature, as well as nanoscale topography can affect different aspects of cell migration. However, the correlation between specific curvature radii and cell behavior, as well as the combinatorial effect of nanoscale topography and cell-scale curvature has not yet been investigated. Herein, we employ a new femtosecond laser ablation method to generate multiscale topographical patterns directly on titanium surfaces. The process allows us to produce microgrooves of specific curvature imprinted with oriented nano-topographical features called Laser-Induced Periodic Surface Structures (LIPSS). We show that curved grooves stimulate stem cell migration speed in comparison to flat or linear grooves. The fastest velocities are observed on 75&#x00B5;m curvature radius, whereas cells migrating on 125&#x00B5;m curvatures exhibit similar speeds to the ones migrating on straight lines. Double replicas of these grooves allow us to mask the LIPSS while keeping identical the cell-scale pattern, therefore permitting to uncouple the effect of nano- and microscale topographies. We found that the presence of nanoscale topographies improves the reading of microgrooves curvature by cells. Altogether, this work shows that the combination of specific curvatures together with nano-patterning can control the velocity of migrating stem cells and promote the use of femtosecond laser ablation in the context of surface implant design.
1394	Determination of the thermal diffusivity of plasmonic nanofluids based on PVP-coated Ag nanoparticles by means of the mode-mismatched dual-beam thermal lens technique	Plasmonic nanofluids have found applications in many fields, such as for example, coolants, solar<br />collectors, and theranostics agents. For such applications, an important parameter is the thermal<br />diffusivity. In this communication, we present an experimental study concerning the dependence on<br />the concentration of the thermal diffusivity of highly diluted aqueous plasmonic nanofluids made of<br />PVP-coated silver nanoparticles. Measurements were made by employing the time resolved mode-<br />mismatched thermal lens technique and the results show an enhancement of the thermal diffusivity,<br />when compared to that of the carrier fluid, on increasing the number density of the nanoparticles,<br />and being rather constant as a function of the power of the pump beam.
1395	Artificial Kerr effect on the self-focusing of laser in a dissipative suspension of metallic nanoparticles	Self-focusing of laser beam propagating through a dissipative suspension of metallic nanoparticles is studied. Impact of imaginary part of nanoparticle polarizability on the optical force and consequently on the particles rearrangement in the presence of laser fields with an initial Gaussian profile is considered. It is shown that the absorption of laser leads to the creation of optical force along the wave propagation direction which can cause longitudinal distribution of nanoparticles. Considering fifth order nonlinearity of wave amplitude that comes from the simultaneous considering of normal Kerr effect produced by the inhomogeneity of refractive index resulted from the ponderomotive force acting on conducting electrons and artificial Kerr nonlinearity caused by the polarization optical force acting on electrically polarized particles, set of differential equations describing nonlinear steady-state evolution of laser beam is derived by using a non-paraxial method. Dynamics of laser for different frequencies is investigated and optimum frequency range for improving focusing property is determined. It is shown that the artificial Kerr effect causes localization of particles near the propagation axis that can substantially reduce the threshold power for occurring self-focusing in comparison with plasma and other rigid plasmonic systems.
1396	Characterization of dynamics and mechanism in the self-assembly of AOT reverse micelles	Reverse micelles (RMs) are recognized as a paradigm of molecular self-assembly and used in a variety of applications, such as chemical synthesis and molecular structure refinement. Nevertheless many fundamental properties including  their equilibrium size distribution, internal structure, and mechanism of self-assembly remain poorly understood. To provide an enhanced, microscopic understanding of the assembly process and resulting structural distribution, we perform multiple nonequilibrium molecular dynamics simulations of  AOT RM assembly, quantifying RM size, water core structure, and dynamics. Rapid assembly of smaller RM from a random mixture is observed to establish a constant AOT water loading within a nanosecond consistent with a diffusion-adsorption mechanism validated through Monte-Carlo simulation of a model system. The structure of RM water cores and RM molecular volume of during RM assembly is characterized during the AOT assembly process. A moment-closure equation is developed from a novel master equation model to elucidate the elementary events underlying the AOT self-assembly process. The resulting kinetic model is used to explore the role of monomer addition and dissociation, RM association and dissociation, and RM collision-induced exchange, all dependent on average RM size, which provides fundamental insight regarding the mechanisms and timescales for AOT RM self-assembly. The nascent dynamics that rapidly establish water loading, intermediate time scales of RM fusion, and longer timescale dynamics of inter-RM exchange essential in establishing equilibrium condition are quantified through these kinetic models.
