Overall, this work provides insight into AOT RM self-assembly and provides a general theoretical framework for the analysis of molecular self assembly dynamics and mechanism.
1397	<strong>Infrared tubular microcavity based on rolled-up GeSn/Ge nanomembranes<sup></sup></strong>	Germanium-Tin (GeSn) alloys have attracted great amount of attentions as these group IV semiconductors present direct band-gap behavior with high Sn content and are compatible with current complementary metal oxide semiconductor technology. In this work, three dimensional tubular GeSn/Ge micro-resonators with diameter of around 7.3 &mu;m were demonstrated by rolling up GeSn nanomembranes grown on Ge-on-insulator wafer via molecular beam epitaxy (MBE). The microstructural properties of the resonators were carefully investigated and the strain distributions of the rolled-up GeSn/Ge microcavities along the radial direction is studied by utilizing micro-Raman spectroscopy with different excitation laser wavelengths. The values of the strains calculated from Raman shifts agree well with the theoretical prediction. Coupled with fiber tapers, as-fabricated devices present high quality factor up to 800 in the transmission spectral measurements. The micro-resonators fabricated via rolled-up nanotechnology and GeSn/Ge nanomembranes in this work may have great potential in photonic micro- and nano-devices.
1398	Comprehensive numerical modeling of filamentary RRAM devices including voltage ramp-rate and cycle-to-cycle variations	The equilibrium ON and OFF states of resistive random access memory (RRAM) are due to formation and destruction of a conducting filament. The laws of thermodynamics dictate that these states correspond to the minimum of free energy. Here, we develop a numerical model that, through the minimization of free energy at a given voltage, determines the filament parameters and thus the electric current. Overall, it simulates the current-voltage (I-V) characteristics of RRAM. The model describes mutual transformations of RRAM states through SET (ON&rarr;OFF) and RESET (OFF&rarr;ON) processes. From the modeling perspectives, these states and processes constitute four programming modules constructed here in COMSOL multiphysics software tackling the electrodynamic and heat transfer equations and yielding RRAM energy and I-V. Our modeling uniquely reproduces the observed I-V varying with voltage ramp-rates. That is achieved by accounting for the ramp-rate dependent activation energy of conduction. The underlying mechanism is due to the deformation interaction caused by the double well atomic potentials universally present in amorphous materials and having exponentially broad distribution of relaxation times. As another unique feature, our modeling reproduces the observed cycle-to-cycle variations of RRAM parameters attributed to the lack of self-averaging in small ensembles of double well potentials and electronic states in geometrically small (nano-size) RRAM structures.
1399	Enhanced Raman scattering of graphene using double resonance in silicon photonic crystal nanocavities	We demonstrate enhancements of Raman scattering from graphene on two-dimensional photonic crystals using double resonances, which originate from simultaneous enhancements by a localized guided mode and a cavity mode. By adjusting the photonic crystal cavity parameters, the double resonance can be tuned to the G' Raman scattering. Excitation wavelength dependence measurements show a large Raman peak enhancement when the excitation and emission wavelengths meet the double resonance condition. Furthermore, spatial imaging measurements are performed to confirm that the enhancement is localized at the cavity, and we find that the enhanced Raman intensity is 60 times larger compared to the on-substrate Raman signal. The observed cavity enhancement of Raman scattering opens up new possibilities for the development of graphene-based light sources for silicon photonics.
1400	<strong>A facile SERS substrate based on silver deposited sandpaper</strong>	Surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) is a hot topic in recent years, which has wide application prospect and high academic value. Flexible and active SERS substrate was prepared by modification of sandpaper with silver nanoparticles. With the condition of 633 nanometer excitation wavelength, the SERS enhancement effect of the sandpaper which was treated with silver nanoparticles was evaluated by collecting Raman signals of different concentrations of silver nanoparticles and 4-MBA solution. The results demonstrate that the SERS enhancement effect of white(12000 meshes) and pink (8000 meshes) sandpaper is better under the same condition; when the concentration of probe molecule is 10<sup>-4 </sup>moL/L, white sandpaper has the best SERS enhancement; the Raman scattering spectrum has better signal when the silver sol is 15 &mu;L.
1401	<strong>Rapid Synthesis of Nano-Crystalline CZTS Ink by Microwave Assisted Method for Photo voltaic Junctions</strong>	Copper Zinc Tin Sulphide <strong>(</strong>CZTS) nano crystal (NC) ink was prepared using thiourea as sulphur source by microwave assisted process. Thin films fabricated by doctor blading/drop casting technique were then used to analyze the structure and morphology of the CZTS ink. Variation in the properties of the nanocrystals with varying Zn content in the precursor solution is studied. A Zn/Sn ratio of 1.4 with a Cu/ (Sn + Zn) ratio of 0.8 in the starting solution was identified as an optimum compositional ratio to get good opto- electronic properties. Synthesis of CZTS ink was done in ethylene glycol solvent and in a solvent which is a 1:1 mixture of isopropanol and poly ethylene glycol. The films developed from the latter ink showed better morphological and opto electronic properties. CZTS thin films show absorption coefficient of the order of 10<sup>4</sup> cm<sup>-1</sup> and optical band gap of 1.56 eV. The electrical resistivity was found to be 2.5 X 10<sup>2</sup> &Omega;cm and hole mobility 0.051 cm<sup>2</sup>/ (Vs). Glass/FTO/CdS/CZTS multilayer structures were fabricated to form P-N junctions. A knee voltage of 0.8 V from the I-V characteristics of the PN junction indicates that a good V<sub>oc</sub> can be expected from a solar cell constructed with CZTS ink as absorber layer.
1402	Magnetization reversal and emergent magnetic monopole-like state in square artificial spin ice vertex with defects	We have investigated the micro-magnetic behavior as well as magnetization reversal of dipolar coupled magnetic nanoislands with strong shape anisotropy arranged in a square artificial spin ice geometry. Our zero-temperature simulation results show that metastable two-in two-out state is stabilized at remanence of regular configurations. A complex interplay of defects and dipolar interaction leads to a predictable three-in one-out or three-out one-in higher energy state. Switching of the magnetic states is defined by the reduction of the no. of high-energy head-to-head or tail-to tail magnetic state.
1403	Spectroscopic studies of strong red emitting Sr2SiO4:Eu3+ nanophosphors with high color purity for application in WLED using Judd-Ofelt theory and TL glow curve analysis	Un-doped and Eu<sup>3+</sup> doped Sr<sub>2</sub>SiO<sub>4</sub> nanophosphors were synthesized by self-propagating solution combustion synthesis and are characterised with different material and optical characterisations. X-ray diffraction (XRD) confirmed orthorhombic phase, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) revealed the nanophosphors with irregular shape but crystalline in nature. The photoluminescence (PL) excitation, emission spectra and lifetime are thoroughly discussed. The emission spectrum due to the excitation under 260 nm showed better asymmetric ratios than the 393 nm excitation ensuring better color purity. The comparative investigations using commission international del&rsquo;Eclirage (CIE) diagram also established that the color purity of 260 nm excitation is superior with CIE co-ordinates (0.66, 0.34) and is close to NTSC standards. The Judd Ofelt (JO) intensity parameters  were obtained from PL emission spectrum and the JO parameters followed the trend  for all Eu<sup>3+</sup> concentration. The radiative properties such as branching ratios, emission cross section, optical gain and gain bandwidth of optimised concentration are calculated. Photoluminescence lifetimes exhibited bi-exponential nature. Thermoluminescence studies of the nanophosphors were carried out after exposing the samples to gamma irradiation in the dose range 20 Gy &ndash; 10KGy. The kinetic parameters are calculated using general order kinetics and are verified by computerised glow curve de-convolution (CGCD). Thermoluminescence emission spectra and contour plots were analysed that further confirms the emission centres responsible for both the process are same. The optical characterisations supported the fact that the nanophosphors excited at 260 nm have better pertinence towards display and lightning application.
1404	<strong>Observation of size dependent orbital magnetism of single Fe impuritiy in nanocrystalline Pb hosts.</strong>	Employing the time differential perturbed angular distribution (TDPAD) technique we have investigated the local magnetism of single Fe impurity in nanocrystalline Pb matrices, by measuring the local susceptibility and spin relaxtion rate of <sup>54</sup>Fe nuclei. Compared to the nonmagnetic behavior of Fe in bulk Pb host, characterized by independent local susceptibility c<sub>loc</sub>(T), the magnetic response of Fe in the nanocrystalline samples with particle size of 10 nm and below exhibit Curie-Weiss like c<sub>loc</sub>(T) with positive slope, indicating the presence of large orbital magnetic moment on the Fe impurity. The orbital moment of Fe has been estimated to be ~ 1 &micro;<sub>B</sub> for 6 nm nano-Pb. Further investigations are being carried out to understand the emergence of orbital magnetism of Fe in nano-Pb.
1405	Determination of atomic positions and polar direction in the half-Heusler Sb<sub>1-x</sub>Sn<sub>x</sub>Ti<sub>1-y-z</sub>Hf<sub>y</sub>Zr<sub>z</sub>Co using Electron channeling	The variation of the electron induced x-ray emission with crystal direction of an incoming electron beam (channeling) was used to study the crystal site preference of the different elements in a promising thermoelectric half-Heusler material with Sb, Co and Ti as the majority elements, and with lower contents of Hf, Zr and Sn. We confirm experimentally, in accordance with previous assumptions, that Sb and Sn occupy one of the octahedral sites, 4a (0, 0, 0), Ti, Zr and Hf the other octahedral site, 4b (&frac12;, &frac12;, &frac12;), and that Co-atoms occupy the tetrahedral site, 4c (&frac14;, &frac14;, &frac14;) in the cubic spacegroup F&#x02C9;43m. We furthermore observe a strong asymmetry along the polar directions as it should be in a half-Heusler when the Co atoms have a strong preference for one of the two sets of tetrahedral sites. Such asymmetries can not be observed by kinematical diffraction according to Friedel&rsquo;s law, demonstrating that the observation of element characteristic signals under channeling conditions is a unique technique for determining the sense of polar directions and distinguishing crystal symmetry alternatives in small crystal grains and nanocrystals.
1406	<strong>High quality Al<sub>x</sub>Ga<sub>(1-x)</sub>N (x~50%) nanowires with uniform Al content grown directly on sapphire substrate by PA-MBE</strong>	Al<sub>x</sub>Ga<sub>(1-x)</sub>N (x~50%) nanowires are grown directly on c-sapphire substrate by plasma assisted molecular beam epitaxy. We show that unlike the planner Al<sub>x</sub>Ga<sub>(1-x)</sub>N (x&gt;0.3) layer where a significant Al inhomogeneity has been observed , Al<sub>x</sub>Ga<sub>(1-x)</sub>N (x~0.5)  nanowires exhibit near atomic scale uniformity across the diameter and length. High resolution transmission electron microscopy analysis confirms single crystal nanowires without any detectable extended defect. We observe that the high temperature growth and the higher V/III ratio (~2.5) compared to that used during the growth of planer layers enhances the diffusion of Al adatoms thus resulting uniform composition of Ga and Al in nanowires.  Our experiments on the growth of AlGaN nanowires by PAMBE technique could pave the way for realizing nitride based deep UV light source without a use of GaN nanowire template which has been the conventional technique for growing AlGaN NWs on Si substrates.
1407	A fabrication process for self-connected horizontal SiGe nanowires	We present in this paper a low thermal budget process for self-connecting horizontal silicon-germanium nanowires. The guided nanowires on amorphous oxide layer has been elaborated by a chemical vapor deposition furnace, using vapor-liquid-solid mechanism, via a gold catalyst. The technological process for guided nanowires, is based on combining: photolithography, dry/wet etching, metal deposition and chemical-mechanical planarization techniques. First, we have optimized the growth parameters on a reference samples with pre-patterned electrodes on SiO<sub>2</sub>/Si substrate. Afterwards, the process has been modified to favor the nanowire growth inside the nanotrenches. The silicon germanium nanowire (SiGe NW) connected the predefined electrodes showed an electrical behavior of an intrinsic SiGe NW.
1408	Two-photon Absorption of Copper Indium Disulfide Quantum Dots: Interpreting the Nonlinear Spectrum	We have interpreted the two-photon absorption spectrum of water-soluble copper indium disulfide QDs with stoichiometry 0.18 (Cu), 0.42 (In), and 2 (S) and average diameter of approximately 2.6 nm. For that, we employed the wavelength-tunable femtosecond Z-scan technique and the parabolic effective-mass approximation model, in which the excitonic transition energies were phenomenologically corrected due to the stoichiometry of the nanocrystal. This model considers a conduction band and three valence sub-bands allowing excitonic transitions via centrosymmetric (&#x0394;l = {plus minus}1, where l is the angular momentum of the absorbing state) and noncentrosymmetric (&#x0394;l = 0) channels. In such case, this became relevant because the CuInS2 QDs with chalcopyrite crystal structure is a noncentrosymmetric semiconductor. Thus, our experimental results pointed out two 2PA allowed bands located at 715 nm (2hv =3.47 eV) and 625 nm (2hv =3.97 eV) with cross sections of (6.3 {plus minus} 1.0) x 102 GM and (4.5 {plus minus} 0.7) x 102 GM, respectively. According to the theoretical model, these 2PA bands can be ascribed to the 1P1/2(h3) &#x2192; 1S3/2(e) (lower energy band) and 1P1/2(hheavy) &#x2192; 1S3/2(e) (90%)/(10 %)1P1/2(hsplit-off) &#x2192; 1P3/2(e) (higher energy band) excitonic transitions. A good agreement (magnitude and spectral position) between the experimental and theoretical data were obtained. However, our experimental data suggest that the higher-energy 2PA band may have other contributions due to the mixing between the heavy- and the light-hole bands, which the effective mass model does not take into consideration.
1409	<strong>Thermal Conductance of a metallic dot Single-Electron Transistor </strong>	Dots are ideal systems to study fundamentals on heat transfer at the nanoscale and promising nanoscale heat-engines and thermal devices. Here, we report on the validation of our theoretical model on the thermal conductance of a metallic dot single-electron transistor (md-SET) by a recent experiment on the low-<em>T</em> thermal conductance. We compare with the experiment, we emphasize the physics interpretation and characteristic values and we apply the model to evaluate the operation the md-SET as heat-switch. Perfect agreement is shown between the calculated and the measured charge conductance <em>G</em>, heat conductance <em>&kappa;</em> and the ratio <em>&kappa;</em><em>/GT</em>. The experimental findings confirm the theoretical predictions on the periodicity of the Coulomb oscillations in the classical regime, the low-<em>T</em> extreme values and the high-<em>T</em> limits of <em>G</em> and <em>&kappa;</em>. The calculated conductances of the md-SET are presented in universal curves from low-T to high-<em>T</em>. It is shown that the md-SET can efficiently operate as a heat switch at temperatures , <em>E<sub>c</sub></em> being the charging energy of the dot.
1410	Nano-kirigami metasurfaces by focused-ion-beam induced close-loop transformation	Reducing fabrication difficulties while maintaining structural complexities and functionalities is one of the key challenges faced by the applications of nanophotonic devices. Here we demonstrate an exotic metasurface by using a simple close-loop nano-kirigami method. Based on the focused-ion-beam (FIB) induced continuous shape transformation of a suspended ultra-thin gold film, pinwheel-like metasurfaces with uniaxial broadband polarization conversion and handedness-sensitive phase properties are readily fabricated. By deliberately patterning the metasurfaces periodically with opposite handedness, high-contrast cross-polarized diffraction, as well as clear photonic spin Hall effect, are successfully observed. The demonstrated new types of metasurfaces, together with their suspended features for reconfiguration potentials, can open up new possibilities for the exploration of functional and reconfigurable micro-/nano-photonic and electronic devices.
1411	<strong>Quantification of free convection within a hemispherical annulus through a Copper-water nanofluid saturated porous medium</strong>	This study quantifies the natural convective exchanges occurring between a dome representing an active electronic component and an isothermal passive cupola. These hemispheres are separated by a porous medium saturated of nanofluid based on pure water and copper nanoparticles. The disc of the cavity could be inclined at an angle ranging from 0&deg; (horizontal disc with dome facing upwards) to 180&deg; (horizontal disc with dome facing downwards). The important surface heat flux generated by the dome leads to high Rayleigh number values reaching 7.29x10<sup>10</sup>. The 3D numerical solution is obtained by means of the volume control method associated to the SIMPLE algorithm. The work examines the influence of the nanofluid-saturated porous medium on heat transfer between the two hemispheres. A correlation is proposed to calculate the Nusselt number for any combination of the inclination angle, the fraction volume, the Rayleigh number and the ratio between the thermal conductivities of the porous medium and the fluid. The wide ranges corresponding to these parameters allow the thermal design of this electronic equipment for various configurations.
1412	Thickness dependence of spin wave dynamics in three-fold nano-ellipse clusters	We present the results of an experimental and theoretical study of spin wave dynamics in three-fold nano-ellipse clusters with closely approaching segments for film thickness from 7.5 nm to 40 nm. Various branches of the spectrum display soft mode behavior. Theoretical simulations involving the dynamic matrix approach are in good agreement with the measured ferromagnetic resonance spectra.
1413	<strong>The negative temperature coefficient, electrical resistivity, and surface morphology of single carbon coated silica nanosprings</strong>	A graphitic carbon, referred to as Graphite from the University of Idaho Thermolyzed Asphalt Reaction (GUITAR), is coated on silica nanosprings and silicon substrates via the pyrolysis of commercial roofing tar at 800 &deg;C in an inert atmosphere. Raman spectroscopic analysis indicates that GUITAR has a nanocrystalline structure consisting of 1 &ndash; 5 nm flakes interconnected via amorphous sp<sup>3</sup> bonded carbon. Scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy images indicate that GUITAR is an agglomeration of carbon nanospheres formed by the accretion of graphitic flakes that form an ~ 90 nm layer. The electrical resistivity of 11 single GUITAR coated nanospring devices were measured over a temperature range of 10 &ndash; 80 &deg;C. The average resistivity and conductivity of all 11 devices at 20 &deg;C was 4.30 &plusmn; 1.32 &times; 10<sup>-3</sup> &#x2126; m and 493 &plusmn; 1.05 S/m, respectively. The GUITAR coated nanospring devices exhibit an average negative temperature coefficient of resistivity at 20 &deg;C of &ndash; 0.00167 &plusmn; 0.000262 &deg;C<sup>-1</sup>, which is consistent with nanocrystalline graphite.
1414	Novel high&#xFF0D;sensitivity racetrack surface plasmon resonance sensor modified by graphene	In order to improve the existing challenges in conventional sensors, including large size, complicated preparation process, and difficulties in filling the sensing media, etc., a novel high&#xFF0D;sensitivity plasmonic resonator sensor, which is composed of two graphene&#xFF0D;modified straight waveguides, two metallic layers, and racetrack nanodisk resonator, is proposed in this study. The transmission characteristics, which are calculated by the finite&#xFF0D;element theory, can be used to further analyze the sensing properties. In addition, after quantitative analysis, the results show that the proposed plasmonic sensor generates two resonance peaks for the different incident wavelength, and both resonance peaks can be tuned by temperature. Optimizing the structural parameters of the resonator, the Q value and the sensitivity, which can reach 21.5<sup> </sup>and 1666.67 nmRIU<sup>-1</sup>, respectively, have better performance than other studies. Furthermore, the temperature sensitivity can achieve 2.33 nm/5&#x2103;, which can be easily applied in the practical detection. This study can broader the road in the field of nanometer&#xFF0D;scale biosensor and temperature sensor, ultrafast real time detection, and resistance to electromagnetic interference.
1415	Sn interspersed MoS<sub>2</sub>/C nanosheets with high capacity for Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> storage	Sn interspersed MoS<sub>2</sub>/C nanosheets are prepared by two-step hydrothermal method. The modification by Sn in MoS<sub>2</sub>/C nanosheets is designed, to improve the electrochemical performances. As anodes for sodium ion batteries (SIBs), the electrodes exhibit an initial capacity of 536 mA h g<sup>-1</sup> and maintains 431 mA h g<sup>-1</sup> after 90 cycles at 0.1 A g<sup>-1</sup>. It provides a new possible for other compound as the potential application of new rechargeable battery.
1416	The effect of pore geometry on the opening profile of DNA molecule sduring translocation	The recent years witnessed significant advances in nanopore technology and the sDNA sequencing. The DNA translocation through nanopores is one of the interesting problems. Translocation of DNA in biological processes involves many constraints, and among them, the pore through which it translocates is worthy of attention. In this manuscript, we construct a cone-shaped pore and use a statistical model to study the opening profile of DNA molecule in the thermal ensemble. How the cone angle (&#x03B8;) or the pore diameter (&#x03B4;) or the fraction of the pairs that are inside or outside the pore affect the thermal stability of the DNA molecule is the content of the current manuscript.
1417	Quantum confinement in ultra-thin gold nanowires: single-electron transport, excitation spectroscopy, and Zeeman splitting	Ultra-thin gold nanowires (AuNWs) were fabricated by wet chemical synthesis that involves a reaction of reduction. Our low-temperature transport measurements revealed the formation of coupled double dots with deformed Coulomb diamonds and quantum confinement. Single-electron transport leads to excitation spectroscopy, in particular Zeeman splitting of single-particle energy levels in AuNW quantum dots under magnetic fields. Furthermore, spin&ndash;orbit coupling strongly suppresses the estimated <em>g</em>-factor, reflecting the ballistic nature of the quantum dots. The realization of quantum confinement with large spin&ndash;orbit coupling effects in metallic wires should pave the way for application in spintronics.
1418	<strong>Temperature dependent photoluminescence of anatase and rutile TiO<sub>2</sub> single crystals: polaron and self-trapped exciton formation</strong>	This article is devoted to the understanding of photogenerated carrier dynamics in TiO2. Our article aims thus to contribute to a clarification of the scenario that governs the carrier dynamics. We base our discussion on the observations and interpretations that can be found in the literature. We complete them with temperature dependent photoluminescence experiments of both rutile and anatase titanium dioxide single crystals between 4K and 200K.Fully characterizing the nature of electronic states and the carrier recombination scenario of bulk TiO2 appears as a first fundamental and necessary step before further studying more complex nanostructured TiO2 architectures. Our work does contribute to a better understanding the nature of the electronic states involved in the carrier dynamics, by clarifying, which physical microscopic processes are dominant in the large amount of proposals that can be found in the literature. We estimate that our measurements give in this respect new and valuable information of the electronic states of these two TiO2 polymorphs.
1419	<strong>Nanofuel droplet combustion: insights into droplet burning time scale, secondary atomisation and coupling of droplet deformations and heat release</strong>	Combustion characteristics of ethanol-water (EW) droplets laden with ceria (CeO<sub>2</sub>) nanoparticles (NPs) are investigated. The present experimental study focuses on three facets of droplet combustion <strong>(i)</strong> burning time scale of droplets with and without NPs, <strong>(ii)</strong> pathways of secondary atomisation due to interface deformations and <strong>(iii)</strong> coupling of droplet shape deformations and flame heat release. A theoretical vaporization timescale is advocated which considers natural convection-based evaporation, mass loss due to daughter droplet ejections, and flow through porous media. Droplets seeded with ceria NPs, exhibit arrested surface undulations although internal ebullition is discernibly enhanced as compared to EW droplets without NPs. Deformations and formation of surface craters in EW droplets are traced to the imbalance between local vapour recoil (due to rapid ethanol vaporisation) and surface tension. Such craters collapse and form high-speed ligaments which eventually break at the tip through Rayleigh-Plateau mechanism. This pathway of secondary atomisation of EW droplets has been elucidated using a modified local weber number  . On the contrary, for nanofuels, bubble rupture is the mechanism behind the surface crater formation. Proper orthogonal decomposition (POD) technique is utilised for investigating the droplet shape and flame heat release (HR) evolution. POD analysis suggests presence of buoyant flame flickering with NP addition. Variation of modal temporal coefficients indicate the extent of droplet shape and HR coupling. EW droplet shape and HR are found to be a synced system with a phase lag arising from the flame response timescale. However, a weak coupling is detected for nanofuel droplets.
1420	Prediction of ion-induced nanopattern formation using Monte Carlo simulations and comparison to experiments	Ion induced nanopattern formation has been experimentally investigated for many different ion-target combinations and different ion irradiation conditions. Several theories and models have been developed throughout the past years to explain the observed boundary conditions for pattern formation as well as features of the patterns like wavelength, growth rates, shape and amplitudes. To compare specific experiments with the predictions of analytical theories it is necessary to calculate the linear and non-linear coefficients of the respective equation of motion of a surface profile. Monte Carlo simulations of ion solid interaction based on the binary collision approximation provide a very fast, rather universal and accurate way to calculate these coefficients. The universality expresses the broad range of ion species, ion energies and target compositions accessible by the simulations. The coefficients are obtained from the moments of calculated crater functions, describing ion erosion, mass redistribution and ion implantation. In this contribution, we describe how most linear, non-linear and higher order coefficients can be determined from crater function moments. We use the obtained data to compare the results of selected experimental studies with the predictions of theoretical models. We find good quantitative agreement e.g. for irradiation of Si with Ar and Kr ions, Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> with Ar and Xe ions, and amorphous carbon with Ne ions.
1421	Scandate Cathode Characterization: Emission Testing, Chemical Analysis and High-Resolution Imaging	This paper describes a comprehensive investigation of the surfaces of scandate cathodes that exhibited excellent performance during close-spaced diode testing. Through high-resolution imaging, it is shown that micron-sized tungsten particles constituting the cathode surface are highly faceted and are decorated with nanoscale Ba/BaO dots, along with larger Sc2O3 and BaAl2O4 particles. The facets of tungsten grains have been determined to be {100}, {110} and {112}, based on Wulff analysis of the tungsten crystal shape. Moreover, {112} facets are prevalent in the Wulff shape, which agrees with the experimentally observed facet surface areas. A model is proposed to account for the amount of metallic Ba that covers the cathode surface at operating temperatures, and which dewets during cooling of the cathode to form nanoscale hemispherical particles that are observed on the W facets after emission testing. According to this model, the coverage of Ba atoms during cathode operation corresponds to 0.5 monolayer, which represents full coverage of the available tungsten surface. Thorough investigation using a range of materials characterization techniques has provided a comprehensive picture of the structure and composition of scandate cathode surfaces. It is noted that these results do not support the existence of a Ba-Sc-O layer occupying the top 10-100 nm of tungsten grain surfaces.
1422	An optical Bragg scattering readout for simultaneous detection of all low-order mechanical modes of gallium nitride nanowires in nanowire arrays	We report the use of optical Bragg scattering and homodyne interferometry to simultaneously measure all the first order cantilever-mode mechanical resonance frequencies and quality factors (Q) of gallium nitride nanowires (GaN NWs) in 100 NW periodic selected-area growth arrays. Hexagonal 2D arrays of 100 GaN NWs with pitch spacings of 350-1100 nm were designed and prepared to allow optical Bragg scattering. The NWs studied have diameters ranging from 100-300 nm, lengths from 3-10 &mu;m, resonance frequencies between 1-10 MHz, and Q-values near 10,000 at 300 K. The system can passively detect the thermally induced Brownian mechanical motion of the NWs and can study driven NW motion, enabling the simultaneous monitoring of hundreds of mechanical resonators in a 10-100 &mu;m<sup>2</sup> area with a single optical beam. The read-out system allows large arrays of NWs to be characterized and applied as e.g. spatially resolved temperature and mass sensors.
1423	Temperature Response of Soft Ionizable Polymer Nanoparticles	Temperature response of luminescent ionizable polymers confined into far from equilibrium nanoparticles without chemical links, was studied using molecular dynamics simulations. These nanoparticles often referred to as polydots, are emerging as a promising tool for nano medicine. Incorporating ionizable groups into these polymers enable bio functionality, however they also affect the delicate balance of interactions that hold these nanoparticles together.  Here polydots formed by a model polymer dialkyl p-phenylene ethynylene (PPE), with varying number of carboxylate groups along the polymer backbone were probed.  We find that increasing temperature results in a dynamic state that allows internal rearrangements and migration of the ionizable groups towards the particle interface, while retaining the overall particle shape.  The dependence of the transition temperature on the surface to volume ratio of these polydots is much stronger than what has previously been observed in polymeric thin films.
1424	Suppression of grey state and optimization of the single photon emission of a colloidal semiconductor at room temperature	The excitation energy dependency of single colloidal CdSe-CdS core-shell nanocrystals is investigated at ambient conditions. It was demonstrated that the photoluminescence blinking effect is totally suppressed by optically exciting nanocrystals with a laser wavelength located at very low absorption spectrum range. The mechanism of this effect is theoretically attributed to excitation of only the core instead of both the core and the shell. The signal to noise ratio and the photons count are also significantly improved and better purity in terms of single photon generation is achieved.
1425	Electronic and magnetic properties of B, Al, N and P impurities in SnC nanoribbons: first-principles study	We report the structural, electronic and some magnetic behavior of the tin carbide (SnC) nanoribbons with the substitutional impurity atoms of boron, aluminum, nitrogen and phosphorus by using density functional theory (DFT) framework. The armchair and zigzag SnC nanoribbons are considered with the 7 and 4 atoms width, respectively. We realized that all of the four impurities prefer to substitute the Sn atom sites which located at the edge of nanoribbon or close to it. Also, the band structures analysis demonstrate that the impurities create extra bands in the region of nanoribbons band gap. So, the spin-down band gap value of the doped 7-ASnCNRs are reduced to 0.218, 0, 1.043 and 1.233 eV for B, Al, N and P atoms, respectively. Moreover, the half metal behavior is observed for the Al-doped 7-ASiCNR. For the 4-ZSnCNR, the impurity atoms could increase the band gap, especially in the spin-up channel. Finally, they introduce a total magnetic moment of 1&micro;<sub>B</sub> into the nonmagnetic 7-ASnCNR and they affect on the magnetic moment of the 4-ZSnCNR.
1426	On the heat transfer effects of nanofluids within rotor-stator cavities	Owing to the rapid development of a number of technological and industrial sectors, high-performance electronic devices are now ubiquitous in modern engineering and industrial applications. Effective heat management is crucial to the smooth operation of such devices and sometimes conventional methods of heat transfer fail to deliver the required performance. Recent advances in the field of nanofluids is a promising route to improving heat-transfer performance, and this is our motivation. We propose two Computational Fluid Dynamics models for a rotor-stator cavity operating at Re&omega; = 1.0 &times; 105 and filled with a fluid that consists of different volume fractions of Al2O3 nanoparticles. The first model simulates the nanofluid mixture using a single-phase transport model, and the second approach uses a two-phase transport model that allows for the relative velocity between the particle and fluid phases. All simulations are conducted using the second-order accurate solver, OpenFOAM, that is based on the Finite Volume Method (FVM) and using Large eddy simulation (LES) methods.s<p>Our results show that the higher volume fractions of Al2O3 nanoparticles can achieve higher heat transfer rates, and at the same time dilute nanoparticle concentrations have subtle effects on the momentum transport of the system. This is an advantage over micro-particle dispersion. Further, we consider the effects of particle forces in the two-phase model, such as Brownian and thermophoresis forces, and suggest that the thermophoresis forces are the dominant effect within the cavity geometry.
1427	Artificial Kerr effect on the self-focusing of laser in a dissipative suspension of metallic nanoparticles	Self-focusing of laser beam propagating through a dissipative suspension of metallic nanoparticles is studied. Impact of imaginary part of nanoparticle polarizability on the optical force and consequently on the particles rearrangement in the presence of laser fields with an initial Gaussian profile is considered. It is shown that the absorption of laser leads to the creation of optical force along the wave propagation direction which can cause longitudinal distribution of nanoparticles. Considering fifth order nonlinearity of wave amplitude that comes from the simultaneous considering of normal Kerr effect produced by the inhomogeneity of refractive index resulted from the ponderomotive force acting on conducting electrons and artificial Kerr nonlinearity caused by the polarization optical force acting on electrically polarized particles, set of differential equations describing nonlinear steady-state evolution of laser beam is derived by using a non-paraxial method. Dynamics of laser for different frequencies is investigated and optimum frequency range for improving focusing property is determined. It is shown that the artificial Kerr effect causes localization of particles near the propagation axis that can substantially reduce the threshold power for occurring self-focusing in comparison with plasma and other rigid plasmonic systems.
1428	<strong>Surface Plasmon Amplification in Refractory Transition Metal Nitrides based Nanoparticle Dimers</strong>	Aggregates of plasmonic nanoparticles (NPs) are known to show greater electromagnetic field amplification, multiple resonant peaks, and precisely controlled spectral tuning compared to their isolated counterpart. The ability of localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) mediated electromagnetic (EM) field amplification is an important criterion for a plasmonic system to act as an efficient <strong>S</strong>urface <strong>E</strong>nhanced <strong>R</strong>aman <strong>S</strong>cattering (SERS) substrate. Conventional coinage metals like gold, silver and copper are most widely used SERS substrates, mainly due to their well-established synthesis process and large Raman signal amplification. However, there is a pressing need to expand the list of plasmonic materials feasible for SERS substrates to match the exponential growth in SERS research. Identification of new plasmonic substrates will reduce the dependence on conventional plasmonic materials and SERS applications will extend into unexplored spectral regions. Moreover, one can circumvent the limitations arising due to the intrinsic nature of conventional plasmonic materials.  <strong>R</strong>efractory <strong>T</strong>ransition <strong>M</strong>etal <strong>N</strong>itrides (RTMN) such as zirconium nitride (ZrN) and titanium nitride (TiN) has emerged as viable alternatives to coinage metals due mainly to, high electron conductivity, suitability for high temperature  applications, optical response in Vis-NIR region, flexible spectral fine-tuning, and bio/CMOS compatibility. This article presents first-ever theoretical assessment of ZrN and TiN nanoparticle dimers for their suitability in enhancing EM field. Moreover, the role of nanoparticle size, embedding medium and inter-particle separation is quantified through fitting relations whose effectiveness is demonstrated by designing RTMN based substrates for selected wavelengths. The present work will provide handy tools to the designers and manufacturers.
1429	Examining tunnel current responses to acoustic excitation for STMs in gaseous environments	Scanning tunneling microscopes are used to examine surfaces and surface properties with sub-nanometer precision. However, this high precision means these microscopes are extremely sensitive to vibration. A large body of work has examined vibration isolation systems that damp any vibration mechanically transmitted from the environment to the microscope through solid material. Less work has examined the effect of acoustic vibrations transmitted from the environment to the microscope through a gaseous atmosphere. For STMs housed in gaseous environments, such as gloveboxes, an understanding of how acoustic noise manifests within the tunneling current is essential to effectively isolate the microscope. In this paper, we examine an acoustic noise signal of a single frequency in order to clearly identify the presence or absence of the peak in the FFT of the STM tunneling current. We demonstrate that during imaging, even though the acoustic noise can significantly degrade the image, the frequency peak of the acoustic noise signal does not clearly appear in the FFT of the tunneling current. Thus, the best way to identify acoustic noise and isolate scanning tunneling microscopes it is while the tips are engaged but not scanning. Further, we achieve atomic resolution on HOPG in a glovebox with the pumps running, demonstrating that acoustic noise can be mitigated using a homemade, foam-lined acoustic shell.
1430	Molecular Self-assembly Strategy for Encapsulation of an Amphipathic &#x03B1;&#x2010;Helical Antimicrobial Peptide into the Different Polymeric and Copolymeric Nanoparticles	Encapsulation of peptide and protein-based drugs in the polymeric nanoparticles is one of the fundamental fields in controlled-release drug delivery systems. The molecular mechanisms of absorption of peptides and proteins to the polymeric nanoparticles are still unknown and there is no precise molecular data on the encapsulation process of peptide and protein-based drugs. In the current study, the self-assembly of different polymers and block copolymers with combinations of the various molecular weight of blocks and the effects of resultant polymer and copolymer nano-micelles on the stability of magainin2, an amphipathic &#x03B1;&#x2010;helical antimicrobial peptide, are investigated by means of all-atom molecular dynamics (MD) simulation. The micelle forming, morphology of micellar aggregations and changes in the first hydration shell of the micelles during micelles formation were explored, as well. The results showed that the peptide binds to the polymer and copolymer micelles and never detaches during the MD simulation time.  In general, all polymers and copolymers simultaneously encapsulated the peptide during micelles formation and had the ability to maintain the helical structure of the peptide, whereas the first hydration shell of the peptide remains unchanged. Among the micelles, the PEG micelles completely encapsulated magainin2 and the native conformation of the peptide was perfectly kept during the encapsulation process. The results also indicated that the aromatic and basic residues of the peptide strongly interact with polymers/copolymers and play the important roles in the encapsulation mechanism. This research will provide a good opportunity in the design of the polymer surfaces for drug delivery applications such as controlled-release peptide delivery systems.
1431	An X-band Saturation Recovery EPR Spectrometer Based on an Arbitrary Waveform Generator	An X-band (ca. 9-10 GHz) saturation recovery spectrometer to measure electron spin-lattice relaxation (T1) was designed around an arbitrary waveform generator (AWG). The AWG is the microwave source and is used for timing of microwave pulses, generation of control signals, and digitizer triggering. Use of the AWG substantially simplifies the hardware in the bridge relative to that in conventional spectrometers. The bridge includes selectable paths with differing power amplification to permit experiments requiring hundreds of milliwatts to fractions of nanowatts for the pump and observe channels. The signal is detected with either a double balanced or quadrature mixer. Resonator tuning is performed by outputting chirp signals and monitoring the signal from the resonator, with options for either reflection or transmission modes. Two limitations of current AWGs as sources for EPR spectrometers are the low output power and high source noise. The low output power was increased by using low noise microwave amplifiers. The source noise was decreased by addition of a Wenzel high-stability clock. The spectrometer was tested with samples that have T1 between a few hundred ns and hundreds of &#x00B5;s. Signal-to-noise performance is similar to that of a conventional saturation recovery spectrometer with a solid-state source. The bridge design minimizes the number of discrete components, which decreases the footprint. With replacement of frequency-sensitive components, this spectrometer can be used to perform saturation recovery measurements at any frequency within the range of the AWG.
1432	<strong>Modified dielectric and magnetic properties of Fe and Co substituted TbMnO<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles</strong>	Structural, dielectric, conductive and magnetic properties of TbMn<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Co<em><sub>x</sub></em>O<sub>3</sub> and TbMn<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Fe<em><sub>x</sub></em>O<sub>3</sub> (<em>x</em> = 0.1 and 0.2) nanoparticles (NPs) prepared by the sol-gel method have been studied. Room temperature x-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns reveal formation of the pure crystalline orthorhombic phase. Transmission electron microscopic images of doped samples show particles with average size of 30 nm. Temperature dependent dielectric curves of all samples exhibit an increment of dielectric constant and loss with increase in doping concentration. Frequency dependent conductivity curves exhibit two different dispersive regions due to grain boundary and grain relaxations along with a frequency independent part all obeying the Jonscher&rsquo;s power law. Frequency dependent impedance spectra and Cole-Cole plots of all samples corroborate the presence of grain and grain boundary relaxations and their temperature dependence follow the Arrhenius relation. Temperature dependent magnetization curve of each sample exhibits antiferromagnetic ordering of both Tb and Mn moments along with a ferromagnetic interaction in the Co-doped sample with <em>x</em> = 0.2. Magnetic hysteresis loops (at 5 K) of all samples show reduction in magnetization value in the doped samples. Conversely, coercivity is found to increase after Co and Fe doping.
1433	Surface plasmon-enhanced UV-emission from ZnO by aluminum bowtie nanoantenna arrays	Aluminum bowtie nanoantenna arrays fabricated by colloid lithography followed by oxygen plasma processing were used to demonstrate the localized-surface-plasmon enhancement of UV light emission from ZnO grown by atomic layer deposition. 4-fold photoluminescence enhancement in the peak of the near band edge emissions was obtained by introducing Al nanotriangles with the gap distance of 31nm by accurate control of the time of oxygen plasma treatment. Extinction spectra and theoretical simulations showed that this improvement benefited from the resonance coupling between the surface plasmons and the excitons of ZnO and the tremendously elevated local electromagnetic fields across the gaps. This cost-effective and facile approach paves an attractive way for high performance optoelectronic devices.
1434	Strain driven magnetic and electronic properties of Zn doped Fe3O4 nano-hollow spheres	We synthesized ZnxFe3-xO4 nano-holllow spheres (NHSs), a promising functional material for spintronic devices. Temperature dependent magnetic studies indicate increase in saturation magnetization Ms with Zn doping, attaining a maximum at x=0.2. The strain developed due to Yafet-Kittel angle reduced Ms with further increase in doping. Dynamic magnetic property studied analyzing ac susceptibility data revealed spin cluster interaction in our systems. Investigation of dielectric property as a function of temperature over a frequency range of 10 KHz-100 MHz by analyzing dielectric spectroscopy, dielectric loss and ac electrical conductivity indicates that the dielectric permittivity and electrical conductivity decrease with increasing Zn content.
1435	Functional inkjet-printed silver top electrodes on Pb(Zr<sub>0.53</sub>Ti<sub>0.47</sub>)O<sub>3</sub> thin films	Herein, we describe direct patterning of silver top electrodes on polycrystalline Pb(Zr<sub>0.53</sub>Ti<sub>0.47</sub>)O<sub>3</sub> (PZT) thin films via inkjet printing. The films were deposited on platinized silicon via chemical solution deposition. Individual nanosilver ink droplets were then printed on the PZT surface to create round top electrodes with tunable diameter from 75 to 93 &#x00B5;m. Printing parameters were optimized for deposition of homogeneous electrodes. High-quality of the electrodes sintered at 350 {degree sign}C is confirmed via measurements of the direct piezoelectric response and polarization loops of PZT thin films, whose results are comparable to the ones obtained for sputtered platinum top electrodes.
1436	Carbon NanoDots: Opportunities and limitations of carbon nanodots to study their biodistribution at the human lung epithelial tissue barrier	Inhalation of combustion-derived ultrafine particles ({less than or equal to}0.1 &#x03BC;m) has been found to be associated with pulmonary and cardiovascular diseases. Correlation of carbon-based particle physico-chemical properties such as surface charge and agglomeration state with adverse health effects are, however, not yet elucidated, mainly due to limitations related to detection of carbon particles in biological environments. We have therefore applied model particles, i.e. carbon nanodots, mimicking simplified particles derived from incomplete combustions with different surface modifications and fluorescent properties to assess their biodistribution in a three dimensional (3D) lung epithelial tissue model. sThree different carbon nanodots (CNDs) namely nitrogen, sulphur co-doped CNDs (N,S-CNDs) and nitrogen doped CNDs (N-CNDs-1 and N-CNDs-2) were prepared by microwave-assisted hydrothermal carbonization using different precursors or different microwave systems. These CNDs possessed different chemical and photophysical properties. N-CNDs-1 and N-CNDs-2 surfaces were positively charged or neutral, respectively, arguably due to the presence of amine and amide groups while N,S-CNDs surface were negatively charged possessing, in addition to amine / amide groups, also carboxylic groups. Photophysical measurements showed that these three types of CNDs displayed a strong photon absorption in the UV range. Both N-CNDs-1 and N,S-CNDs emitted low fluorescence emission whereas N-CNDs-2 showed high emission.sThe 3D human lung model composed of epithelial cells (A549 cell line) and two primary immune cells, i.e. macrophages and dendritic cells, was exposed to CNDs via pseudo-air liquid interface (ALI) at a concentration of 100 &#x00B5;g/mL. Exposure of these particles did not induce any harmful effect to the cells 24 h after exposure as assessed by cell morphology, cytotoxicity and pro-inflammatory cytokine (tumour necrosis factor-&#x03B1;) release. Distribution of the CNDs in the lung model was estimated by measuring the fluorescent intensity in three different fractions, e.g. apical, intracellular and basal, after 1, 4 and 24 h of incubation, whereas reliable results could be obtained for N-CNDs-2 only. It was shown that N-CNDs-2 were found to translocate rapidly, i.e. &gt; 40% in the basal fraction within 1 h and almost 100% after 4 h, while N-CNDs-1 and N,S-CNDs were still located on the apical surface of the lung cells, i.e. about 80% after 1 h. This could be attributed to agglomeration behaviour of N-CNDs-1 or N,S-CNDs. Surface properties of N-CNDs exhibiting amino and amide groups induce more uptake as N-CNDs could be detected intracellularly. This was less evident for N,S-CNDs with carboxylic acid groups on the surface. In conclusion, CNDs have been designed as a model system for carbon-based particles, however, their small size and agglomeration behavior made fluorescent measurement as a method for quantification challenging. Nevertheless it could be demonstrated that surface properties and agglomeration affected the biodistribution at the lung epithelial barrier in vitro.
1437	Osmosis through a Semi-permeable Membrane: a Consistent Approach to Interactions	The movement of ionic solutions is an essential part of biology and technology. Fluidics, from nano- to micro- to microfluidics, is a burgeoning area of technology which is all about the movement of ionic solutions, on various scales. Many cells, tissues, and organs of animals and plants depend on osmosis, as the movement of fluids is called in biology. Indeed, the movement of fluids through channel proteins (that have a hole down their middle) is fluidics on an atomic scale. Ionic fluids are complex fluids, with energy stored in many ways. Ionic fluids flow driven by gradients of concentration, chemical and electrical potential, and hydrostatic pressure. Each flow is classically described by its own field theory, independent of the others, but of course, in reality every gradient drives every kind of flow to a varying extent. Combining field equations is tricky and so the theory of complex fluids derives the equations, rather than assumes their interactions. When field equations are derived, rather than assumed, their variables are consistent. That is to say all variables satisfy all equations under all conditions with one set of parameters. Here we treat a classical osmotic cell in this spirit, using a sharp interface method to derive interface boundary conditions consistent with all flows and fields. We allow volume to change with concentration, since changes of volume are a property of ionic solutions known to all who make them in the laboratory. We consider flexible and inflexible membranes. We show how to combine the energetics of the membrane with the energetics of the surrounding complex fluids. The results seem general but need application to specific situations of technological, biological and experimental importance before the consequences of consistency can be understood.
1438	<strong><strong>Angle dependent localized surface plasmon resonance from silver nanoparticles embedded in SiO<sub>2</sub> thin film</strong></strong>	<SPAN style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 150%;">Near surface silver nanoparticles embedded in silicon oxide were obtained by 40 keV silver negative ion implantation without the requirement of an annealing step. Ion beam induced local heating within the film leads to an exo-diffusion of the silver ions towards the film surface resulting in the protrusion of larger nanoparticles. Cross-sectional transmission electron microscopy (XTEM) reveals the presence of poly-disperse nanoparticles (NPs), ranging between 2 nm-20 nm, at different depths of the SiO<sub>2</sub> film. The normal incidence reflectance spectrum shows a double kink feature in the vicinity of 400nm, indicating a strong localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) from the embedded NPs. However, due to overlap of the bilayer interference and LSPR, the related features are difficult to separate. The ambiguity in associating the correct kink with the LSPR related absorption is cleared with the use of transfer matrix simulations in combination with an effective medium approximation. The simulations are further verified with angle dependent reflectance measurements. Additionally, transfer matrix simulation is also used to calculate the electric field intensity profile through the depth of the film, wherein an enhanced electric field intensity is predicted at the surface of the implanted films.</SPAN>
1439	<strong>Coercivity enhancement in heavy rare earth-free NdFeB magnets by grain boundary diffusion process</strong>	Grain boundary diffusion of a Pr<sub>3</sub>(Co,Cu) eutectic alloy has been performed for coercivity enhancement on Nd-lean Nd<sub>10</sub>Fe<sub>84</sub>B<sub>6</sub> nanocrystalline ribbons. The coercivity increases from 0.5 T to 2.5 T after 6 hours of infiltration at 600 &ordm;C. High resolution electron microscopy and EDX show that the excess a-Fe present in the initial samples diminishes during infiltration, giving rise to the formation of a RE-rich RE-Fe inter-boundary phase and a layer of (Nd,Pr)<sub>2</sub>Fe<sub>14</sub>B close to the surface of the hard magnetic grains. Such microstructure favours the coercivity by increasing the nucleation field for reversal magnetization and providing magnetically isolated/decoupled hard grains.
1440	<strong>Fermi level De-pinning for Dopant-free Silicon Solar Cells</strong>	Fermi level (E<sub>F</sub>) depinning is shown to be critical for the design of selective asymmetric electrode photovoltaic cells, and to be clearly much less than the electron affinity rule estimate. The degree of Fermi level pinning is calculated by density function calculations for the cases of 0, 1 and 2 layers of a representative oxide HfO<sub>2</sub> inserted between a metal layer and a Si substrate. It is found that two layers of HfO<sub>2</sub> is enough to depin E<sub>F</sub> sufficiently to allow typical electrodes of MoO<sub>3</sub> and nanostructured ZnO/silicate to give a potential difference as large as the Si band gap.
1441	Influence of Solvent Quality on Conformations of Crowded Polymers	The structure and function of polymers in confined environments, e.g., biopolymers in the cytoplasm of a cell, are strongly affected by macromolecular crowding. To explore the influence of solvent quality on conformations of crowded polymers, we model polymers as penetrable ellipsoids, whose shape fluctuations are governed by the statistics of self-avoiding walks, appropriate for a polymer in a good solvent. Within this coarse-grained model, we perform Monte Carlo simulations of mixtures of polymers and hard-nanosphere crowders, including trial changes in polymer size and shape. Penetration of polymers by crowders is incorporated via a free energy cost predicted by polymer field theory. To analyze the impact of crowding on polymer conformations in different solvents, we compute average polymer shape distributions, radius of gyration, volume, and asphericity over ranges of polymer-to-crowder size ratio and crowder volume fraction. The simulation results are accurately predicted by a free-volume theory of polymer crowding. Comparison of results for polymers in good and theta solvents indicates that excluded-volume interactions between polymer segments significantly affect crowding, especially in the protein limit of small crowders. Our approach may help to motivate future experimental studies of polymers in crowded environments, with possible relevance for drug delivery and gene therapy.
1442	<strong>Simultaneous Arrayed Formation of Single-Electron Transistors Using Electromigration in Series-Connected Nanogaps</strong>	A field-emission-induced electromigration method (activation) is reported for integrating single-electron transistors operating at T = 298 K. The field emission currents between the two opposite electrodes of each series-connected nanogap are tuned to accumulate Ni atoms within the gaps. For ten series-connected nanogaps, the resistance (<em>V</em><sub>D</sub>/<em>I</em><sub>D</sub>), obtained using the current-voltage (<em>I</em><sub>D</sub>-<em>V</em><sub>D</sub>) properties of these nanogaps during the activation procedure, is observed to decrease on activation. As a result, island structures are formed within the gaps, and the nanogap-based single-electron transistors can be integrated, when atom migration occurs at the tip of each nanogap electrode. After activating the ten series-connected nanogaps with a preset current, <em>I</em><sub>S</sub> = 1 nA, current suppression (representative of coulomb blockade) is not observed in the fabricated devices. On the other hand, coulomb blockade, which depicts the charging and discharging of the nanoislands, can be observed at room temperature, after activation with a preset current, <em>I</em><sub>S</sub> = 150 nA. Furthermore, the modulation properties of the coulomb blockade voltage by the gate voltage are also determined at room temperature. These results experimentally demonstrate the arrayed formation of ten single-electron transistors operating at room temperature, constituting a significant step toward the practical realization of single-electron-transistor-based systems.
1443	<strong>TiN-nanorod/carbon fiber composite structure cathode for plasma-induced field emission</strong>	The remaining challenges confronting high-current pulsed beam sources stimulate the development of robust plasma cold cathodes. A TiN nanorod/carbon fiber cathode was prepared by hydrothermal method and nitriding. The light emission and plasma formation on the cathode surface were compared between carbon fiber cathode and TiN nanorod/cabon fiber cathode. The uniform and large-area plasma was generated on TiN nanorod/cabon fiber cathode, owing to a higher electric field enhancement factor. Further, TiN nanorod/cabon fiber cathode turned on faster, which is inferred by theoretical derivation and temporary evolution of beam currents. TiN nanorod/cabon fiber cathode represents a promising cold cathode with superior performance.
1444	Realization of laser frequency stabilization in sub-nanowatt level using nanofibers	We propose a novel scheme which combines conventional Doppler dichroic atomic vapor laser lock (DAVLL) and nanofiber techniques for realizing frequency stabilization with sub-nanowatt laser power. The dependences of DAVLL signal on the total incident power of probe light and the quantification magnetic field amplitude indicate that the power for frequency stabilization could be minimized to only 15 pW. To evaluate the frequency stability of the locked laser, we calculate the Allan standard deviation,which shows that the relative frequency stability could reach 10<sup>-10</sup> level at 10 seconds. This frequency stabilization scheme paves the road for future quantum optical device integration.
1445	<strong>Local magnetostriction measurement in a cobalt thin film using scanning probe microscopy</strong>	The local magnetostriction measurement has become an emerging issue because strain-mediated nanocomposites have received considerable attention due to their potential applications for high sensitivity sensors and high density energy harvesters. Compared to many instruments capable of measuring nanometric magnetic domains, techniques for measuring local magnetostriction have been rarely reported. Here, we introduce a local magnetostriction measurement method by modifying an atomic force microscope (AFM) by combing a solenoid to apply an external <em>ac</em> magnetic field and induce magnetostrictive excitation. The distribution of magnetostrictive response is mapped by contact mode AFM and lock-in detection techniques with a few nanometer lateral resolution. We have found that a few micrometer-size domains of a cobalt film showing different amplitude and phase signals of the magnetostrictive response are observed by the second-harmonic response of the <em>ac</em> magnetic field frequency, which is not detected in a linear response signal. We suggest that the phase and amplitude signals observed in each domain are related to magnetic-easy-axis directions. Our findings provide a unique pathway to understand the local magnetostrictive response based on scanning probe microscopy.
1446	<strong>Generation of UV-induced radiation defects in calcite</strong>	The effect of UV light on the most common mineral on Earth &ndash; calcite (CaCO<sub>3</sub>), has been little investigated, despite its significant implications for many areas of research, such as photodegradation of CaCO<sub>3</sub>-containing materials, conservation of historical objects, dosimetry and dating. In this study, conducted on nano- and micro-grained calcite samples using Electron Paramagnetic Resonance spectroscopy, we provide a detailed analysis of the radiation defects (paramagnetic centers) generated by UV radiation, including their identification, location (surface- or bulk-related) and stability during the period up to 4 years after irradiation. The observed paramagnetic centers, such as isotropic and anisotropic CO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup>, CO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>, SO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup>, SO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>, NO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup> and NO<sub>2</sub><sup>2-</sup> ions, are analogous to gamma-induced species, which contradicts a widely-held belief that low-energy radiation cannot create radiation defects in wide band-gap materials, such as calcite. We present a mechanism of UV-induced generation of carbonate paramagnetic species in calcite based on retrapping the &lsquo;secondary electrons&rsquo;, i.e. the electrons released from non-carbonate traps by UV light. The efficiency of this process is strongly connected with the size and morphology of calcite grains, which can be especially relevant, considering the variety of CaCO<sub>3</sub> particles used in the industry and available in nature.
1447	Wafer-scale Photolithography of Scanning Nanocantilevers	The detection of small forces using singly-clamped cantilevers is a fundamental feature of scanning probe force microscopy in all its variant forms. In these technologies, silicon-based nanomechanical devices continue to be the most widespread high-performance nanomechanical sensors for their availability, ease of fabrication, an inherently low mechanical dissipation, and well-controlled surface mechanical dissipation. Here, we develop a robust method to batch fabricate extreme-aspect-ratio (10^3), singly-clamped scanning nanowire mechanical resonators from plain bulk silicon wafers using standard photolithography. We discuss the superior performance and additional versatility of the approach beyond what can be achieved using the established silicon-on-oxide (SOI) technology.
1448	<strong>Coupled plasmon in the rounded Ag Hexagonal Nanoplate Dimer</strong>	The subtle changes in the edges and corners of nanoparticles are the common occurrence during the manufacturing process of them which it affects on the nanoparticle's sensing properties. In this work, We studied rounding effect on sensing properties by numerical simulation of silver hexagonal nanoplate dimer. In these nanoplates three main plasmonic bands arise (dipole, octupole and anti-bonding modes). Both dipole and octupole modes are strongly affected by changes in the refractive index of the medium and blue shift under the influence of the edges rounding. Our results show that hexagonal dimers with the least gap distance (<em>g </em>= 1nm) have the largest extinction cross section and the maximum hybridization of plasmon peak. Furthermore, our results show that octupole mode has the highest FOM in both types of perfect and rounded hexagonal nanoplates dimer, and the FOM of the rounded hexagonal dimer is less than the perfect hexagonal nanoplate dimers. This study may be used to build more advanced sensing devices based on metallic nanoparticles.
1449	Contrastive analysis of Hydrothermal and Co-precipitation synthesized CeO2 NPs for various biomedical applications	The foolproof work has been analyzed for the synthesis of Cerium oxide (CeO2) nanoparticles (NPs) via hydrothermal and co-precipitation methods. We emphasize the highly adequate hydrothermal method in synthesizing CeO2 NPs for biomedical applications against Gram strain bacteria. Absorption spectral investigation at 283 nm and 274 nm confirms the formation of CeO2 NPs for hydrothermal (HYNPs) and co-precipitation (CONPs) methods respectively. Functional group analysis firmly reveals the akin conjugation of the presence of organic and inorganic species in the synthesized CeO2 NPs. Cubic structure and average crystallite size of synthesized NPs are estimated using Sherrer's and W-H methods. Obtained average particles size is compared with HR-TEM to be 10 nm and 5 nm using hydrothermal and co-precipitation methods respectively. Consequently, synthesized CeO2 NPs shows excellent antimicrobial activities. Moreover, HYNPs gave promising antioxidant activity with lowest IC50 as compared with CONPs. Owing to the biological active nature of CeO2 NPs, HYNPs acts as a best therapeutic agent in biomedical applications as important antibiotics.
1450	The generation and evolution of a diffuse nanosecond pulsed dielectric barrier discharge in airflows	Atmospheric-pressure dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) with airflow participation has been widely used in recent years. In this experimental study, diffuse DBD excited by repetitive nanosecond pulses is achieved in airflow. On the introduction of airflow to the gas gap, the discharge state transforms from a filamentary one into a diffuse one at first, followed by the generation of a thin filamentary discharge at a high airflow rate. It is observed that the diffuse discharge and the thin filamentary discharge are ignited from the electrode boundary, subsequently move towards the downstream region with a velocity below the corresponding airflow rate. Subsequent to hundreds of pulse cycles, a stationary discharge state is formed with the thin filamentary discharge in the upstream region and the diffuse discharge in the downstream region. The length of the thin filamentary discharge region is associated with the airflow rate, pulse repetition frequency, and applied voltage. The observations presented above are ascribed to the transverse electric field at the electrode boundary and the redistribution of charges under the action of airflow.
1451	<strong>In-situ water-assisted structural-manipulation of C1s sp<sup>3</sup>-characteristics in ferromagnetically-filled carbon onions: the case of high pressure Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> Bbmm</strong>	Carbon nano-onions (CNOs) are quasi-spherical fullerene-like structures with 60N<sup>2</sup> carbon atoms (N being the number of carbon layers) self-arranged in carbon shells. Reversible controlled transformations of these nanostructures into nanodiamonds (CNDs) have been recently demonstrated by using a laser wavelength of 532 nm for timescales of 40 min (CNOs to CNDs transformation). However, no studies have yet reported the dynamics of such transitions in metal/carbide filled CNOs (Me-C@CNOs). In this work we have investigated such structural transitions in the case of Fe-C@CNOs with controlled curvature. We find that no CNOs to CNDs conversion is present under prolonged laser-beam irradiation at the temperature of 673 K. Instead a novel re-crystallization effect which leads to progressive increase in the intensities of the D, G and 2D bands is present. This observation is supported by controlled temperature dependent X-ray diffraction measurements in vacuum. In the attempt to control the sp<sup>3</sup> characteristics of the CNOs-shells we have then developed an advanced fabrication method where the controlled addition of water to ferrocene allows to profoundly enhance the sp<sup>3 </sup>carbon-characteristics of the CNOs by progressive oxidation of the encapsulated particles into a high pressure Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> phase.
1452	Saturation Scattering Competition for Non-fluorescence Single-wavelength Super-resolution Imaging	Stimulated emission depletion nanoscopy and its derivatives based on saturation induced competition effects have become an indispensable tool for studying cellular events and their dynamics in living conditions. However, the successful implementation of these techniques heavily relies on the saturation and competition nature of excited fluorescent dyes exerted by two laser beams of the different wavelength, which perplexes the optical system and inevitably suffers from photobleaching effects. Harnessing the emerging saturation scattering of plasmonic nanoparticles, here, we demonstrate a novel fluorescence-free single-wavelength super-resolution imaging technique using gold nanoparticles. A lateral resolution of 101.2 nm (&lt;&#x03BB;/5) is achieved through introducing saturation scattering competition (SSC) of 60 nm gold nanospheres between dual beams at the same wavelength. In addition, the SSC drastically reduces the saturation intensity by three orders of magnitude than conventional STED process at comparable resolutions. As a proof of concept, we realized robust single-wavelength super-resolved imaging in MG-63 cells with a simplified system. The current technique provides a new modality of biosample-friendly technology for optical super-resolution imaging.
1453	Quantitative phase imaging of cells in flow	Quantitative phase imaging (QPI) offers high optical path length sensitivity, probing nanoscale features of live cells, but it is typically limited to imaging just a few static cells at a time.  To enable utility as a biomedical diagnostic modality, higher throughput is needed.  To meet this need, we have developed methods for imaging cells in flow using QPI.  Here we present our digital holography approach for imaging cells with an emphasis on the issues required for imaging moving cells.  In particular, the issue of choosing a quantitative criterion for digitally refocusing cell images will be examined.  Examples of holographic images of flowing red blood cells are presented and analyzed.
1454	Energy filtering in silicon nanowires with a geometric superlattice for steep-slope transistors	This paper investigates energy filtering in silicon nanowires by resonant electron tunneling through a geometric superlattice. A geometric superlattice is any kind of periodic geometric feature along the transport direction of the nanowire. Multivalley quantum-transport simulations are used to demonstrate the manifestation of minibands and minibandgaps in the transmission spectra of such a superlattice. We find that the presence of different valleys in the conduction band of silicon favors a nanowire with a rectangular cross-section for effective energy filtering. The obtained energy filter can consequently be used in the source extension of a nanowire field-effect transistor to prevent high-energy electrons from contributing to the leakage current. Self-consistent Schr&ouml;dinger-Poisson simulations in the ballistic limit show a sub-60 mV/decade inverse subthreshold slope for a nanowire with side-indentations. The adaptation of the quantum transmitting boundary method (QTBM) to the finite-element simulation of 3D structures with anisotropic effective mass is presented in the appendix. Our results bare relevance in the search for steep-slope transistor alternatives which are compatible with the silicon industry and can overcome the power-consumption bottleneck inherent to standard CMOS technologies.
1455	<strong>Optoelectronic Properties of Calcium Cobalt Oxide Misfit Nanotubes</strong>	We report on the optoelectronic properties of a recently discovered nanotubular phase of misfit-layered calcium cobalt oxide, CaCO<sub>2</sub>&ndash;CoO<sub>2</sub>. Individual nanotubes are investigated by spatially resolved electron energy-loss spectroscopy experiments performed in a transmission electron microscope and complementary first-principles, time-dependent hybrid density-functional theory calculations are performed to elucidate the electronic structure and optical spectra. We find that the band gap is independent of the geometry of the nanotubes, and experimental and calculated results independently confirm an optical gap of 1.9&ndash;2.1 eV for the CaCO<sub>2</sub>&ndash;CoO<sub>2</sub> nanotubes. The time-dependent hybrid density-functional theory calculations also suggest the existence of strongly bound intralayer excitons (up to 0.5 eV binding energy), which could allow for optoelectronic applications of these nanotubes at near-infrared to visible (~1.5&ndash;2 eV) wavelengths.
1456	Enhanced Thermoelectric Properties of Flexible Aerosol-Jet Printed Carbon Nanotube-based Nanocomposites	Aerosol-jet printing allows functional materials to be printed from inks with a wide range of viscosities and constituent particle sizes onto various substrates, including the printing of organic thermoelectric materials on flexible substrates for low-grade thermal energy harvesting. However, these materials typically suffer from relatively poor thermoelectric performance, due to their low Seebeck coefficient, S, and electrical conductivity, &#x03C3;. Here, we demonstrate a modified aerosol-jet printing technique that simultaneously incorporates well dispersed high S Sb2Te3 nanoflakes, and high-&#x03C3; multi-walled carbon nanotubes providing good inter-particle connectivity, to significantly enhance the thermoelectric performance of poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) polystyrene sulfonate structures on flexible polyimide substrates.
1457	<strong>Controlled hydrothermal temperature brings tunable permittivity and electromagnetic absorption performance of reduced graphene oxide</strong>	Hydrothermal reduction method has been chosen to prepare reduced graphene oxide (RGO), the results reveal that controlled reaction temperature brings tunable permittivity and ideal electromagnetic absorption (EA) performance of pure RGO. A composite loaded with 5 wt% of RGO can possess an effective EA bandwidth of 7.56 GHz from 2.9 to 3.2 mm, when graphene oxide (GO) was reduced under 160 <sup>&deg;</sup>C for 6 h. Meanwhile, as-prepared RGO can effectively dissipate incident electromagnetic energy in the whole X (8-12 GHz) and Ku (12-18 GHz) bands. This study shows that RGO can achieve ideal EA performance without any other decorated nanomaterials.
1458	Effect of nanoparticles on streamer and breakdown of vegetable oil impregnated pressboard in non-uniform electric field	Electrical equipment is always subjected to various of operating conductions and voltage waves which cause insulation failure on the surface of pressboard (PB). In this paper, pre-breakdown streamers of surface discharge on the interface of PB in vegetable oil based Fe3O4 nanofluids (NF) were observed by the shadowgraph method under lightning impulse voltage. The images indicate that streamers of NF impregnated PB show more branches than that of pure oil impregnated PB. The stopping length of streamers propagation is calculated by shadowgraph images for NF and pure oil. Results suggest that the stopping length of NF impregnated PB is shorter under the same extra voltage. Secondary reverse streamer is generated at the dissipation process by the reverse electric field, which is caused by residual space charge imparted by primary streamer. Results indicate that the Fe3O4 nanoparticles have reduced the length of secondary reverse streamer. The positive and negative lightning breakdown voltage of Fe3O4 NF impregnated PB is increased by 24% and 12% at 50mm gap, respectively. In addition, nanoparticles effectively have changed the electric field distribution resulting in the alleviation of streamer concentrated along the parallel direction of PB, and increased the lightning impulse breakdown voltage.
1459	<strong>Deformation Behavior at Sliding Interface for Nanoscratch of Aluminum in Dry, Water and Aqueous H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> Conditions</strong>	Nanoscale deformation behavior of aluminum at sliding interface was investigated by nanoscratch experiment and X-ray photoelectron spec-troscopy (XPS) in variable conditions involving dry, water and aqueous H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>.
