It was found that deformation of aluminum in the nanoscratch process could be divided into two regimes relying on the evolution of frictional coefficient. Similar results have been observed in dry and water conditions. However, the stick-slip behavior is integrated into deformation process with aqueous H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> compared with the results of that in dry and water conditions, resulting from the formation and breaking of chemical bonds interaction of OH and Al atom. In addition, this deformation behavior is described in the framework of a mathematical model based on Mo&rsquo;s theory using the atomic contact concept instead of asperity contact, which relates the transition of friction from sub-linear to linear and deformation changing from elastic to changing elastic-plastic. Finally, a parameter of critical energy barrier is employed to reveal the atomic material removal mechanism in Al chemical mechanical planarization (CMP) process with the consideration of chemical actions and elastic deformation.
1460	Density and viscosity profiles governing nanochannel flow	The density and viscosity profiles across the nanochannel height were respectively compared between the flow factor approach model and molecular dynamics simulation for the Poiseuille flow in a nanochannel, when the agreements between these two approaches were good in calculating both the flow velocity profile across the channel height and the volume flow rate through the channel. It was found that except close to the confining wall, the comparisons in the two regards showed satisfactory agreements; Because of the solidification of the thin layer close to the wall, the errors of the flow factor approach model in calculating both the local density and local viscosity close to the wall can not considerably affect its calculation accuracy of both the flow velocity profile across the channel height and the volume flow rate through the channel, both of which were actually governed by the density and viscosity profiles of the flowing media in the middle section of the channel height.
1461	Nonlinear Constitutive Models for Nano-scale Heat Conduction	We present a rigorous approach that leads, from a many-particle description, to a nonlinear, stochastic constitutive relation for the modeling of transient heat conduction processes at nanoscale. By enforcing statistical consistency, in that the statistics of the local energy is consistent<br />with that from an all-atom description, we identify the driving force as well as the model parameters in these generalized constitutive models.
1462	Giant enhancement of stimulated Raman amplification in metasurfaces made of silicon photonic crystal nanocavities	We demonstrate that stimulated Raman amplification can be enhanced by more than four orders of magnitude in a silicon metasurface consisting of a periodic distribution of specially engineered photonic crystal cavities in a silicon photonic crystal slab waveguide. In particular, by designing the photonic crystal cavities so as they possess two optical modes separated by the Raman frequency of silicon, one can achieve large optical field enhancement at both the pump and Stokes frequencies. As a consequence, the effective Raman susceptibility of the nonlinear metasurface, calculated using a novel homogenization technique, is significantly larger than the intrinsic Raman susceptibility of silicon. Implications to technological applications of our theoretical study are discussed, too.
1463	Nanometer scale thermal response of polymers to fast thermal perturbations	The non-equilibrium dynamics of polymers at nanosecond and nanometer scales is described by linear integro-differential equations with dynamic heat capacity. The exact analytical solution for the non-equilibrium thermal response of polymers in plane and spherical geometry is obtained. It is found that even fast components of dynamic heat capacity significantly affect the thermal response to local thermal perturbations. A non-equilibrium local overheating in polymers under pulse heating is determined. This local overheating is greatly enhanced by fast components (ca. 1 ns) of dynamic heat capacity. The non-equilibrium and non-linear thermal response of typical polymers with relaxation parameters corresponding to polystyrene and poly(methyl methacrylate) is analyzed. The obtained results can be used for the analysis of the heat transfer process at the early stages of crystallization with fast formation of nanometer scale crystals.
1464	Effective surface tension of liquid marbles using controllable nanoparticle monolayers	A liquid marble&rsquo;s effective surface tension (&gamma;<sub>eff</sub>) is a frequently used but perplexing concept and clarifying this tension has been challenging, mainly due to difficulties in controlling affecting factors from marble surface particles. In this study, we addressed this issue using water marbles covered by nanoparticle monolayers, which substantially removed the control obstacle and resulted in simple physical models. Comparative results reveal that the surface solidity caused by local or overall particle jamming, which is a common phenomenon that has been lightly considered, limits the &gamma;<sub>eff</sub>&rsquo; implication only to macroscopic properties, rather than including interparticle forces as in previous assumptions. Similarly, &gamma;<sub>eff</sub> depends on very specific conditions including the measurement method and all liquid marble parameters; hence, its value can vary significantly even when the particle coverage is similar. The equivalence quality is proposed here that could be an important concept when addressing liquid marbles&rsquo; &gamma;<sub>eff</sub>.
1465	A Transport Isolation by Orbital Hybridization Transformation toward Graphene Nanoribbon-based Nanostructure Integration	Among feature-rich graphene-related materials, graphene nanoribbon-based nanostructures are particularly attractive since they can provide tunable and excellent electronic properties. However, the integration of high quality graphene nanoribbon-based nanostructures on large scale is still an open area. In this paper, a novel idea as transport isolation is proposed. By a construction of different orbital hybridizations of the carbon atoms in graphene, the graphene nanoribbon (GNR) regions and functionalized graphene regions are integrated. In the hybrid system, the functionalized graphene regions play the role of isolation barrier. Based on the first principle calculation, it is demonstrated that about 0.6 nm wide hydrogenated graphene is enough to reliably isolate the GNR regions. Besides, it is revealed that once the armchair GNRs (AGNRs) are fully isolated by functionalized graphene, their band gaps are basically maintained and are weakly dependent on the width of functionalized graphene regions. In addition, the transport characteristics of those isolated AGNRs are verified to be similar to the pristine AGNRs on device level. The above virtues infer our method can effectively produce a reliable isolation, verified by a simulation of device integration demo. We hope it can provide an intriguing option for the integration of graphene nanoribbon-based nanostructures.
1466	<strong><strong>Athermal coalesc</strong><strong><strong>ence of two </strong></strong><strong><strong>parallel and </strong></strong><strong><strong>contacting a</strong></strong><strong><strong>morphous SiO</strong></strong><strong><sub><strong>x</strong></sub></strong><strong><strong> nanowires</strong></strong><strong><strong> as induced by uniform </strong></strong><strong><strong>e</strong></strong><strong><strong>-beam irradiation</strong></strong></strong>	The coalescence of two parallel and contacting amorphous SiO<sub>x</sub> nanowires as induced by uniform electron beam irradiation was <em>in-situ</em> studied at room temperature in a transmission electron microscope. It was observed that the two parallel and contacting nanowires demonstrated a quick athermal coalescence at the contacting surface and nearby, and finally evolved into a single nanowire of a bigger diameter. It was also observed that there is not any detectable atom loss during the coalescence. Based on the observation, a new mechanism of athermal &ldquo;diffusion&rdquo; and plastic flow as driven by the effects of the nanocurature of the amorphous SiO<sub>x</sub> nanowires and the electron beam-induced athermal activation, which were different from the existing knock-on mechanism and e-beam heating effect, was proposed to elucidate the observed phenomena. It is expected that such a study has important implications for the nanoprocessing and nanostability of future nanowire-based structures or devices.
1467	<strong>Hole and electron trapping in HfO<sub>2</sub>/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanolaminated stacks</strong>	HfO<sub>2</sub>/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanolaminated stacks prepared by atomic layer deposition have been investigated in terms of their charge storage characteristics for possible application in charge trapping memories. Memory window, electron and hole trapping and leakage current mechanisms have been studied in dependence on Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> thickness and post-deposition oxygen annealing. It is shown that in as-deposited stacks hole trapping dominates and it is stronger in stacks with thicker Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>. O<sub>2</sub> annealing increases electron trapping thus giving rise to a larger memory window and enhanced charge storage characteristics, i.e. 65 % of charge is retained after ten years and the memory window decreases by 6 % after 2.5x10<sup>4</sup> program/erase cycles. Consideration of leakage current mechanism reveals domination of space charge limited current through deep traps. O<sub>2</sub> annealing increases the density of these traps without changing their energy position.
1468	<strong>Identification and separation of local and nonlocal nonlinear optical effects: Theory and experiment</strong>	Understanding the nonlinear optical effect of novel materials will play a crucial role in the fields of photonics and optoelectronics. Herein, we theoretically and experimentally investigate the concurrence of third-order locally refractive nonlinearity and thermally induced nonlocal nonlinearity saturation. We present the analytical expressions of the Z-scan trace and the number of spatial self-phase modulation (SSPM) rings, which allow one to unambiguously yet conveniently separate the contributions of local and nonlocal nonlinearities in the case that both effects occur simultaneously. As a test, we study both the local and thermally induced nonlocal nonlinearities in fullerene/toluene solution by performing continuous-wave (CW) Z-scan and SSPM measurements at two different wavelengths. This work enriches the physical mechanism of nonlinear optical effect in solution dispersions of nanomaterials which can be exploited for nonlinear photonic devices.
1469	Magnetodynamic and spin-transfer properties of Ni$_{\text{100-x}}$Fe$_{\text{x}}$/Pt nanoconstrictions	We study the magnetodynamic and spin-transfer torque properties of Ni$_{\text{100-x}}$Fe$_{\text{x}}$/Pt ($x$ = 0 to 40) microstrips and nanoconstrictions using spin-torque ferromagnetic resonance (ST-FMR) measurements. We extracted the spin Hall efficiency by analyzing the lineshape and the linewidth of the ST-FMR signals. We found that the spin Hall efficiency increases as the Fe content increases. The enhancement in  the spin Hall efficiency is correlated with an increase in the spin-mixing conductance and is attributed to the transparency of the FM--Pt interface to the spin current. Our results suggest that the spin current generated via the spin Hall effect can be maximized by engineering the interfaces with higher transparency between the FM-Pt layer which is important for applications such as magnetic nano-oscillators.
1470	Performance analysis of nanostructured Peltier coolers	Employing non-equilibrium quantum transport models, we investigate the details and operating conditions of nano-structured Peltier coolers embedded with an energy filtering barrier. Our investigations point out non-trivial aspects of Peltier cooling which include an inevitable trade-off between the cooling power and the coefficient of performance, the coefficient of performance being high at a low voltage bias and subsequently deteriorating with increasing voltage bias. We point out that there is an optimum energy barrier height for nanowire Peltier coolers at which the cooling performance is optimized. However, for bulk Peltier coolers, the cooling performance is enhanced with the height of the energy filtering barrier. Exploring further, we point out that a degradation in cooling performance with respect to bulk is inevitable as a single moded nanowire transitions to a multi-moded one. The results discussed here can provide theoretical insights for optimal design of nano Peltier coolers.
1471	<strong>Structural, optical and Raman investigation of KFeO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles: A novel material as photo-anode for dye sensitized solar cell</strong>	The present power crisis all around the world urgently demands highly efficient solar cells. More importantly these sources of energy should be environment friendly. In this direction, dye sensitized solar cells (DSSC) have been fabricated using KFeO<sub>2 </sub>nanoparticles as photo-anode material. KFeO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles have been synthesized by sol-gel methods. The structural, morphological, optical and photovoltaic properties of synthesised nanoparticles have been investigated. The transmission electron microscope (TEM) study reveals that the size of nanoparticles is 12 nm. Reitveld refined X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns reflects the orthorhombic phase of the synthesized nanoparticles with <em>Pbca</em> space group. The optical study reveals that the band gap of the KFeO<sub>2 </sub>nanoparticle is 1.88 eV. The Raman study discloses that there are three Raman active internal modes viz., A<sub>1g</sub>+E<sub>g</sub>+T<sub>2g</sub> and eleven Raman peaks corresponding to these modes. The CIE (International Commission on Illumination or Commission Internationale de l'&eacute;clairage) diagram and photoluminescence spectra of these nanoparticles have been studied. DSSC have been fabricated using these nanoparticles and photocurrent versus applied voltage study of this suggests that the open-circuit voltage (V<sub>OC</sub>), short circuit current&ndash;density (J<sub>SC</sub>) and fill factor (FF) % of the fabricated DSSC is 0.84 V, 4.72 mA/cm<sup>2</sup> and 64, respectively.
1472	<strong>Tunable specific-loss power of magnetic nano-spheres in vortex state for high-efficiency hyperthermia bio-applications</strong>	We explored the reliable control of high-efficiency specific-loss power (SLP) using magnetic nanoparticles in the vortex state, the value of which power is one order of magnitude higher than those of the conventional mechanisms of SLP reported thus far. The underlying mechanism is based on the precession of a single vortex core and subsequent dissipation due to the intrinsic damping when the vortex-state spheres are resonantly excited. Owing to the dynamic characteristics of vortex-state nanoparticles, the resonant excitation of vortex-core precession is variable with particle size as well as tunable by the size-specific resonant frequency and strength of ac magnetic fields applied to the particles. The ac magnetic-field energy absorbed by the particles can be converted very efficiently to other energy forms such as heat. We derived, semi-analytically and by micromagnetic simulations, the quantitative relationships of the SLP quantity with the particle size and intrinsic damping constant of nanoparticles, and with externally controllable parameters including the frequency and strength of ac magnetic fields and dc magnetic-field strength. This work provides a reliable means of control as well as an optimal design of high-value SLP for high-efficiency hyperthermia bio-applications.
1473	Writing Skyrmions with a Magnetic Dipole	We demonstrate numerically on large spin lattices that one can writes<p>skyrmions in a thin magnetic film with a magnetic dipole of a few</p>s<p>tens of nanometer in size. Nucleation of non-chiral skyrmions as well</p>s<p>as chiral skyrmions formed by the Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction</p>s<p>has been investigated. Analytical model is developed that agrees with</p>s<p>numerical results. It is shown that skyrmions can be written though</p>s<p>a number of scenarios that depend on the experimental technique and</p>s<p>parameters of the system. In one scenario, that branches into subscenarios</p>s<p>of different topology, the magnetic dipole on approaching the film</p>s<p>creates a skyrmion-antiskyrmion pair. As the dipole moves closer to</p>s<p>the film it induces collapse of the antiskyrmion and creation of a</p>s<p>non-zero topological charge due to the remaining skyrmion. In a different</p>s<p>scenario the dipole moving parallel to the film nucleates a skyrmion</p>s<p>at the boundary and then drags it inside the film. Possible implementations</p>s<p>of these methods for writing topologically protected information in</p>s<p>a magnetic film are discussed.
1474	Investigation of nano scale additives on performance characteristics of biodiesel in a CI engine	There is a rapid decrease in the sources of fossil fuels due to increased demand in energy. Researchers are focusing on alternative resources of fuels. Inedible vegetable oils are emerging as promising alternative for diesel fuel. But due to several problems, they have to be blended with diesel for their use in engine. In present work two different blends of Thumba biodiesel are prepared and investigated. One blend consists of 20% oil in biodiesel and is termed as B20. The other blend, termed as B19MCE1, consists of low concentration of mesoporous carbon. The results indicate that B19MCE1 blend has lowest brake specific fuel consumption and highest brake thermal efficiency at full load. Also the emissions and exhaust gas temperature are reduced in case of B19MCE1 blend.
1475	Silicon-based polarization analyzer by polarization-frequency mapping	Measuring states of polarizations (SOPs) is a fundamental requirement in high capacity optical communications, optical imaging and materials characterizations. However, most of the existing methods focused on the assembly of spatial optical elements, making the system bulky and complex. Alternatively, the integrated methods were mainly presented by plasmonic nanostructures or metasurfaces, difficult to integrate with commonly used silicon photonic devices. For large-scale inter-chip optical interconnections, the silicon-based polarization analyzers are in demand and in its infancy. Here, a silicon-based polarization analyzer by polarization-frequency mapping is put forward. The basis vectors of polarization are mapped to two frequencies by thermally-tuned phase shifters. The SOPs are retrieved from the frequency domain. The proposed polarization analyzer is demonstrated experimentally and can measure SOPs in entire C-band. The scheme is compatible with CMOS fabrication process, making it possible to be integrated with other silicon-based devices monolithically.
1476	The role of ligand design on nanoparticle and biomolecule interactions	Ligand functionalized inorganic nanoparticles offer great potential as vehicles for in vivo delivery of drugs, genes, and other therapeutics. These nanoparticles offer highly customizable chemistries independent of the size, shape, and functionality imparted by the inorganic core. Their success as drug delivery agents depends on their interaction with three classes of biomolecules: nucleic acids, membranes, and proteins. Experiments have demonstrated the importance of charge and hydrophobicity for biocompability and cell internalization. Ligand length, flexibility, branchedness, and other properties may also influence the delivery efficacy of nanoparticles. However, comprehensive understanding of ligand design principles lies in the cost associated with synthesizing and characterizing diverse ligand chemistries and ability to carefully assess the structural integrity of biomolecules upon interactions with NPs. Here, we discuss recent advances and open questions in the field of nanoparticle ligand design, with a focus on atomic scale interactions with biomolecules.
1477	High-efficiency AlGaN-based multiple quantum wells grown on low dislocation density AlN realized on small-coalescence-area nano-patterned sapphire substrate	Targeting to clarify the control principle of AlN growth on nano-patterned sapphire substrate (NPSS), the growth behaviors of AlN on hexagonal configuration hole-type and truncated-cone-pillar-type NPSS with the same period and mesa width have been investigated. It is found that threading dislocation density (TDD) of AlN grown on the hole-type NPSS reaches 4.87&times;10<sup>8 </sup>cm<sup>-2</sup>,<sup> </sup>that is over one order of magnitude lower than the value 6.63&times;10<sup>9 </sup>cm<sup>-2 </sup>on the pillar-type one. It is verified that the TDD of AlN grown on NPSS is largely dominated by the area ratio of the coalescence zones and thus the NPSS pattern with small coalescence area (SCA) ratio, such as the hexagonal configuration hole-type NPSS, is the preferred choice for high-quality AlN epitaxy. Benefiting from the low-TDD AlN grown on the hole-type NPSS with SCA, the internal quantum efficiency of the 281-nm AlGaN-based multiple quantum wells has reached 73.9% at 300K.
1478	High-density and vertically-aligned GaN nanocolumns grown on graphene using a thin AlN buffer layer	The growth of high-density, vertically-aligned GaN nanocolumns on graphene/silica glass by RF-PAMBE is feasible using a thin AlN buffer layer. AlN serves both as nucleation sites for the nanocolumns and protects the graphene from the N2 plasma and in-plane strain generated by GaN nucleation. The nanocolumns are grown in the c-axis direction with wurtzite structure and exhibit an acceptable verticality. Furthermore, the columnar structure of GaN provides higher photoluminescence intensity than that of a reference HVPE-GaN bulk substrate. These findings are therefore very encouraging for further establishing graphene as an alternative substrate to enhance the performance of III-N-based semiconductor devices.
1479	Rodlike counterions at heterogeneously charged surfaces	We study the spatial and orientational distribution of rodlike counterions (such as mobile nanorods) as well as the effective interaction mediated by them between two plane-parallel surfaces that carry fixed (quenched) heterogeneous charge distributions. The rodlike counterions are assumed to have an internal charge distribution, specified by a multivalent monopolar moment and a finite quadrupolar moment, and the quenched surface charge is assumed to be randomly distributed with equal mean and variance on the two surfaces. While equally charged surfaces are known to repel within the traditional mean-field theories, the presence of multivalent counterions has been shown to cause attractive interactions between uniformly charged surfaces due to the prevalence of strong electrostatic couplings that grow rapidly with the counterion valency. We show that the combined effects due to electrostatic correlations (caused by the coupling between the mean surface field and the multivalent, monopolar, charge valency of counterions) as well as the disorder-induced interactions (caused by the coupling between the surface disorder field and the quadrupolar moment of counterions) lead to much stronger attractive interactions between two randomly charged surfaces. The interaction profile turns out to be a nonmonotonic function of the intersurface separation, displaying an attractive minimum at relatively small separations, where the ensuing attraction can exceed the maximum strong-coupling attraction (produced by multivalent monopolar counterions between uniformly charged surfaces) by more than an order of magnitude.
1480	<strong>Charge transfer induced tunable bandgap and enhanced saturable absorption behaviour in rGO/WO<sub>3</sub> nanorod composites.</strong>	We report the charge transfer from Tungsten trioxide (WO<sub>3</sub>) to reduced graphene oxide (rGO) through steady state fluorescence quenching with fitting. Also we report ns nonlinear optical (NLO) properties of GO, WO<sub>3</sub>, and rGO/WO&shy;<sub>3 </sub>at 532 nm employing the open aperture Z-Scan technique. The samples exhibit typical third-order NLO behavior including saturable absorption (SA) and Reverse saturable absorption (RSA). The rGO/WO<sub>3</sub> nanohybrids shows the low saturation intensity I<sub>s </sub>and 0.5x10<sup>11</sup> W/m<sup>2 </sup>compared to the pristine WO<sub>3</sub> saturation intensity I<sub>s</sub> ~1x10<sup>13</sup> W/m<sup>2</sup>. The results display that the effective functionalization and the reduction of GO enhances the SA performance of the nanohybrids. Results show that these nanohybrids are potentially useful for mode locking, optical switching and as a saturable absorber. Moreover the structural property was confirmed by X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), UV spectroscopy reveals the bandgap variation due to rGO incorporation. HRTEM supports the nanohybrids as nanorods and the vibrational properties were analyzed by Fourier transformed Infrared Spectroscopy technique.
1481	A Self-Consistent First Order Analytical Model of Plasma Jets: A Two Fluids Approach	Laser ablation processes have applications from thin film deposition to isotope separation, through plasma plume generation, which suggests mass and charge separation of species as the plume evolves. However, it does not have a theoretical model for, that takes into account equilibrium configurations. The present work is dedicated to build a simplified two fluids non-neutral plasma equilibrium self-consistent model, based on few parameters for first and fast analysis of morphological and statistical features for typical experimental plasma plumes. The velocities field, density profiles, and normalized histograms for the velocities module associated with the species were determined. The electrostatic potential field was also depicted. The model was validated for laser-ablated plasma plume and compared in good agreement with experimental molybdenum plasma jet generated by interaction of Nd:YAG nanosecond pulsed laser with solid target at atmospheric pressure.
1482	<strong>Au-Nanoparticles Strip-Loaded Channel Waveguide </strong>	A strip-loaded channel waveguide was fabricated by deposition of Au nanoparticles (AuNPs) in a thin strip via organometallic chemical vapor deposition (OMCVD) on top of a polystyrene slab waveguide. The beam confinement is demonstrated experimentally, despite the absence of a classical closed layer for strip-loading. The successful AuNP density conditions for plasmonic waveguide hybrid transmission devices are discussed, typically for plasmonic sensing applications.
1483	<em></em>Ultra-fast wide band spectrum analyzer based on a rapidly tuned spin-torque nano-oscillator	A spintronic method of ultra-fast broadband microwave spectrum analysis is proposed. It uses a rapidly tuned spin torque nano-oscillator (STNO), and does not require injection locking. This method treats an STNO generating a microwave signal as an element with an oscillating resistance. When an external signal is applied to this "resistor" for analysis, it is mixed with the signal generated by the STNO. The resulting mixed voltage contains the "sum" and "difference" frequencies, and the latter produces a DC component when the external frequency matches the frequency generated by the STNO. The mixed voltage is processed using a low pass filter to exclude the "sum" frequency components, and a matched filter to exclude the dependence of the resultant DC voltage on the phase difference between the two signals. It is found analytically and by numerical simulation, that the proposed spectrum analyzer has a frequency resolution at a theoretical limit in a real-time scanning bandwidth of 10 GHz, and a frequency scanning rate above 1 GHz/ns, while remaining sensitive to signal power as low as the Johnson-Nyquist thermal noise floor.
1484	Plasmonic enhancement of figure of merit on magneto-optical Kerr effect in Au/Co/Au nanostructure	Enhancement of the longitudinal magneto-optical Kerr effect in Au/Co/Au plasmonic nanostructures was experimentally investigated. We fabricated Au/Co/Au rectangular patch arrays with different short axis lengths varied from 125 to 245 nm. When linearly polarized light with wavelength of 785 nm was illuminated to the structures, local-mode surface plasmons were resonantly excited only in the structure with 200 nm in length. Under this condition, significant enhancement of the magnitude of the complex Kerr rotation was observed. We also evaluated the figure of merit (FOM) in both Au/Co/Au and Co nanostructure and compared them. Our results demonstrated that the introduction of plasmonic Au structure to magnetic layer is effective not only to enhance the longitudinal magneto-optical Kerr rotation but also to improve the FOM parameter through the highly reflectance of Au itself.
1485	Particle size effect of Ag catalyst for oxygen reduction reaction: Activity and stability	Based on DFT calculations, we investigated the activity and stability of three octahedral Ag nanoparticles (Ag19, Ag85, and Ag146) on catalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and further compared their ORR performance to an outspread flat Ag(111) surface and Pt(111) surface. The results indicate that Ag19 cannot be used as an effective ORR catalyst mainly due to its poor stability under the electrochemical environment. In contrast, both Ag85 and Ag146 possess higher surface cohesive energies and cluster cohesive energies, indicating they have relatively lower thermodynamic tendency to electrochemical dissolution. In addition, both of these two nanoparticles also have high catalytic activities, as suggested by the calculated highest potentials of 0.80 and 0.76 eV. Therefore, our current study indicates that an octahedral Ag nanoparticle with the diameter of ~2 nm should has good catalytic activity and stability for ORR.
1486	Numerical simulation on nanosecond laser ablation oftitanium considering plasma shield andevaporation-effected surface thermocapillaryconvection	Nanosecond laser ablation of metal is a complicated process which contains many strongly coupled physic phenomena: material heating, melting, evaporation, vapor dynamic and plasma shield. Here, to investigate the nanosecond laser ablation process of titanium at 1064 nm wavelength in atmospheric air, a multi-physics axisymmetric two dimensional (2D) model is presented. The temperature evolution and distribution of titanium target was solved by governing equations and the vapor dynamic was determined by the Knudsen layer relations. Further, the plasma shield effect was calculated to correct the energy distribution of incident laser.As the laser fluence increases, the energy efficiency becomes lower. Therefore, we analyzed the surface morphology profiles after laser ablation on different laser fluence between 2 and 12 J/cm<sup>2</sup>. The result shows that the increment of laser fluence seems to lead a slower non-linear increment of the ablation depth and diameter of melt zone.  The calculated results are in good agreement with the experimental results, which provides useful information for nanosecond laser precision fabrication.
1487	Combined STM and AFM show that atomically-resolved scanning "tunneling" microscopy with contaminated tips involves large forces	Graphite is a common substrate for both scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and atomic force microscopy (AFM) studies. It is inert and can be easily prepared. However, there are open questions regarding the interaction of tip and sample. Most notably, the giant corrugation that was observed in STM data has been postulated as an effect due to strong attractive and repulsive forces acting on the tip. We perform STM and AFM at room temperature in ultra-high vacuum to clarify the forces at play during imaging. We observed giant corrugation and, simultaneously, background repulsive forces greater than 200 nanonewtons. After tip conditioning, we were able to conduct STM in the non-contact regime and simultaneously observe short-range attractive forces.
1488	<strong>Oriented growth of metastable Co<sub>5</sub>Zr phase: Rare earth free permanent magnetic thin films<sup></sup></strong>	This letter reports the results of <em>rf</em>-magnetron sputtering grown [110] oriented 50 nm Co<sub>5</sub>Zr (CZ5) thin-films on MgO (100) single-crystal substrate. RF power, substrate temperature and film thicknesses were optimized to obtain maximum energy product for a film, calculated along the easy axis [110], as (BH)<sub>max</sub>~0.95 MGOe and H<sub>c</sub>~ 647 Oe. In light of the literature values obtained by Saito [Appl. Phys. Lett. <strong>82</strong>, 2305 (2003), Mater. Trans. <strong>44</strong>, 1713 (2003)] as BH<sub>max</sub>~1.3MGOe, with H<sub>C</sub>~2.2KOe for metastable CZ5 phase in Co<sub>80</sub>Zr<sub>20</sub> melt-spun ribbons, our results for thin film samples are significant. X ray diffraction studies along with the rocking curve analysis confirm the [110] oriented growth of the films. Evolution of hard magnetic phase (domain size ~ few tens of nanometers) at the cost of nonmagnetic matrix is clearly observed in the films grown at 600<sup>0 </sup>C in the magnetic force microscopy images taken at room temperature. Polar plots of the coercivity as a function of angle between the applied magnetic field and the film, highlight the fact that [110] oriented CZ5 film has same value of H<sub>c</sub> along set of all &lt;110&gt; directions and shows four-fold symmetry due to the cubic symmetry of the CZ5 phase.
1489	<strong>Barium-hexagonal-ferrite</strong><strong> functionalized</strong> <strong>poly(vinylidene fluoride)</strong><strong> composite film: A unique metamaterial towards enhanced microwave absorption</strong>	Barium-hexaferrite (BaH) loaded poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) composite films with different nano-filler ratio were prepared by solution casting method for electromagnetic interference shielding applications. These BaH-PVDF composite films have been evolved as the potential one for absorbing microwave radiations and the corresponding shielding effectiveness (SE) of ~ -110 dB at 8.55 GHz for one such composite film with a thickness of ~ 0.234 mm is achieved. In comparison to the other publications on ferrite/hexaferrite-polymer systems this BaH-PVDF composite films are the most effective one for the enhancement of the microwave absorption due to the following factors (i) the improvement of the b-phase of PVDF due to the incorporation of the BaH nano-fillers inside the structure of PVDF and (ii) the presence of large number of BaH-PVDF interfaces that act as the active centres during wave matter interaction. The superior control over wave matter interaction by the modulations of the above factors and thereby the enhanced microwave absorption is the aim of this work. Also, in this work the simultaneous contributions of both BaH and PVDF have been established and these all together make this particular metamaterial a unique microwave absorber.
1490	Revealing silicon crystal defects by conductive atomic force microscope	The machining and polishing can result in damages on silicon surface. It is of paramount importance to investigate electric performance of processed surface for understanding and improving the employment of silicon components with nanoscale crystal defects. In this study, the conductivity of nanoscratches on silicon surface was investigated using a conductive atomic force microscope. Compared to the original silicon surface, electric breakover can be detected on mechanically scratched area at low bias voltage, and the current increases with the voltage. In contrast, no obvious current was found on defect-free scratch created by tribochemical removal. The conductivity can also be found on a friction-induced protrusive hillock created at high speed, nor on a hillock created at low speed that is constructed by amorphous silicon. Further analysis shows that lattice distortions can facilitate easily electron flow and contribute greatly to the conductivity of a mechanical scratch on silicon, but amorphous layer contributes hardly to the conductivity, which is supported by high resolution transmission electron microscope. As a result, the relation between the electrical performance and microstructures was experimentally established. These findings shed new light on subtle mechanism of defect-dependent conductivity, and also provides a rapid and nondestructive method for detecting surface defects.
1491	Two-Dimensional Monolayer FETs with PN Junction or Heterojunction Channels	The major challenges in the scaling of metal-oxide-semiconductor field effect transistor (MOSFET) include large source-to-drain leakage and small on/off current ratio, especially when the channel length is below 10nm. To address these challenges, we designed and investigated a new type of short-channel FETs based on two-dimensional (2D) transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) with a PN junction or heterojunction at the middle of the channel. In this comprehensive first-principle computational study, different gate length and channel materials have been investigated and compared, with a focus on the analysis of ballistic transport and energy band alignment. The results indicate that the off-state leakage current and on/off current ratio are significantly improved in the FETs with a junction channel, in comparison with the FETs with homogeneous channel. This new junction-channel approach, leveraged with the intrinsic advantages offered by 2D TMDC monolayers, suggests a new and very attractive strategy to construct future nanoelectronic transistors.
1492	Response Increase of Antenna-Coupled Nanothermocouples by Thermal Insulation	We present a 2.5-fold increase in the open-circuit voltage response of antenna-coupled nanothermocouples (ACNTCs) by thermally insulating them from the SiO2/Si substrate using an oxide membrane suspended over a cavity formed from the Si substrate. Polarization-dependent measurements are presented and compared to simulation results. The thermal response of the ACNTCs increases 2.5-fold when they are thermally insulated from the substrate by the cavity. We also show that the polarization-dependent response, and hence the polarization ratio, depends on the depth of the cavity.
1493	Purcell enhancement of the photon parametric decay in two-dimensional nonlinear materials	Ultracompact nonlinear optical devices utilizing two-dimensional (2D) materials and nanostructures are emerging as important elements of photonic circuits. Integration of the nonlinear material into a subwavelength cavity or waveguide leads to a strong Purcell enhancement of the nonlinear processes and compensates for a small interaction volume. The generic feature of such devices which makes them especially challenging for analysis is strong dissipation of both the nonlinear polarization and highly confined modes of a subwavelength cavity. Here we solve a  quantum-electrodynamic problem of the spontaneous and stimulated parametric decay in a nonlinear quasi-2D waveguide or cavity. We develop a rigorous Heisenberg-Langevin approach which includes dissipation and fluctuations in the electron ensemble and in the electromagnetic field of a cavity on equal footing. Within a relatively simple model, we take into account the nonlinear coupling of the quantized cavity modes, their interaction with a dissipative reservoir and the outside world, amplification of thermal noise and zero-point fluctuations of the electromagnetic field, and other relevant effects. We derive closed-form analytic results for relevant quantities such as the spontaneous parametric signal power and the threshold for parametric instability. We find a strong reduction in the parametric instability threshold for 2D nonlinear materials in a subwavelength cavity and provide a comparison with conventional nonlinear photonic devices.
1494	Electrical and optical characterization of extended SWIR detectors based on thin films of nano-columnar PbSe	There is an increasing demand for detectors with extended Short Wavelength Infrared (SWIR) absorption at wavelengths between 1.6mm and 2.8mm.  Towards that end, PbSe absorber layers were grown by the Chemical-Bath-Deposition (CBD) technique in a columnar morphology on n-type (100) oriented GaAs substrate, where the columns are densely packed perpendicular to the substrate. The spectral absorption edge and photoluminescence (PL) peak of these layers were blue shifted from the bulk bandgap of 4.7mm to 2.2mm, i.e., within the extended SWIR range, due to quantum confinement effect.  Current voltage (I-V) measurements were carried out in a vertical geometry of different circular mesa sizes (250-2000&mu;m in diameter). The area dependent current&ndash;voltage measurements indicate a densely packed layer with no apparent pinholes. On the other hand, surface leakage currents on the mesa perimeters are the dominant mechanism of the dark current. A photo-response to SWIR illumination was evident, confirming the feasibility of using such structures as extended SWIR photodetectors upon minimizing leakage currents using surface treatments
1495	<strong>Resistivity switching in activated carbon fibers</strong>	This work presents an effect of switching of resistivity of activated carbon fibers, obtained with a combination of adsorption of specific molecules and application of external electric field. Observed jumps of resistivity were due to the ordering of dipolar guest molecules which acted as a gating factor for hopping transport of charge carriers within the granular fiber structure. The presented research shows that the control of electrical transport in porous carbon systems is possible by means of structure, host-guest interactions, temperature and external stimulation. As such it is important for fundamental understanding of electronic properties of graphene-based systems, as well as for their adsorption-related applications, for example energy generation and storage. Resistivity switching might prove useful for tuning of the carrier transport in nanoelectronic units (single electron transistors, spin valves) or for increasing the sensitivity and selectivity of molecular sensors.
1496	Ni(OH)2 Nanoplates Decorated on Graphene Nanosheets for Alkaline Secondary Batteries	The &#x03B2;-nickel hydroxide/reduced graphene oxide (&#x03B2;-Ni(OH)2/RGO) nanocomposites were successfully synthesized by microwave-assisted method. The as-obtianed samples are composed of the &#x03B2;-Ni(OH)2 nanoplates deposited homogeneously on the surfaces of RGO layer. The discharge capacity of &#x03B2;-Ni(OH)2/RGO composite fell from 316.3 to 259.9 mAh/g at the discharge rate from 0.2 to 10 C, the capacity decrease slightly by 17.8%. The excellent capacity and rate capability are assigned to the well-defined nanocrystallinity of the disorder hexagnoal &#x03B2;-Ni(OH)2 nanoplates growing and anchoring on the surface of the RGO layer with most numerous of available active sites, which provide more comfort space  for protons and ions. By virtue of the superior capacity of pseudocapacitive &#x03B2;-Ni(OH)2 and pleasurable conductivity of RGO make the &#x03B2;-Ni(OH)2/RGO) composites a promising battery-type material for high-performance alkaline rechargeable batteries.
1497	Influence of the Dzyaloshinskii&ndash;Moriya Interaction on the topological Hall effect in crossed nanowires	We used micromagnetic simulations to investigate the influence of the Dzyaloshinskii&ndash;Moriya interaction (DMI) on the topological Hall effect (THE) in crossed nanowires with two characteristic magnetic structures, including radiated-shape and antivortex states. Early in our study, we found that the occurrence of the THE strongly depends on the polarity and vorticity, and topological Hall resistivities separate into four values in an external magnetic field, depending on the polarity and vorticity. In this report, we show that even in the absence of an external magnetic field the topological Hall resistivities also separate into four values in crossed nanowires under the influence of the DMI. Therefore, by measuring the THE, we can detect both the polarity and the vorticity simultaneously, even in the absence of a magnetic field. This result might be useful as a basic technique for studying and developing next-generation multi-value memory.
1498	Impact of Pulmonary Alveolar Epithelial Cells of Human Lung on Microfluidic Chips	The investigation of the human physiology and pathophysiology requires models that resemble living tissues and organs as precisely as possible. Animal models and static cell cultures lack human tissue-specific (or organ-specific) functions, which are available in dynamic cell cultures using microfluidic systems. Air pollution is a serious problem currently affecting society, and it primarily has adverse effects on the lung. Pollutants are found in particulate matter, including silica, which is a component of sand dust. Here, we demonstrate the differences in static and dynamic cell culture responses and the effect of air pollution on the lung. Human pulmonary alveolar epithelial cells were cultured in a silica-nanoparticle-treated medium on plates and single-channel microfluidic chips. The dynamic cell culture gave more plausible qualitative and quantitative cell viability staining results than the static cell culture. We successfully managed to achieve a healthy cell culture of human lung cells in a microfluidic chip. The analysis methods revealed various kinds of differences between the static and dynamic cell cultures; these differences are crucial for designing a model that represents a human in vivo environment as closely as possible.
1499	Density and viscosity profiles governing nanochannel flow	The density and viscosity profiles across the nanochannel height were respectively compared between the flow factor approach model and molecular dynamics simulation for the Poiseuille flow in a nanochannel, when the agreements between these two approaches were good in calculating both the flow velocity profile across the channel height and the volume flow rate through the channel. It was found that except close to the confining wall, the comparisons in the two regards showed satisfactory agreements; Because of the solidification of the thin layer close to the wall, the errors of the flow factor approach model in calculating both the local density and local viscosity close to the wall can not considerably affect its calculation accuracy of both the flow velocity profile across the channel height and the volume flow rate through the channel, both of which were actually governed by the density and viscosity profiles of the flowing media in the middle section of the channel height.
1500	<strong>Effect of inhomogeneous mesoporosity and defects on the luminescent properties of slanted silicon nanowires prepared by facile metal-assisted chemical etching</strong>	Slanted silicon nanowires show an improved optical absorption and better electrical contact than the vertical silicon nanowires. High aspect ratio mesoporous slanted silicon nanowires oriented along &lt;100&gt; direction are fabricated by a facile two-step metal-assisted chemical etching process. Inhomogeneous porosity with pore diameter of 2-10 nm is identified by the analysis of transmission electron microscopy, angle dependent Raman spectroscopy and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller measurements. Slanted silicon nanowires possess a core/shell structure and the porosity varies from top to bottom of the slanted silicon nanowires. The presence of neutral oxygen defects, self-trapped excitons and surface defects is identified by photoluminescence spectroscopy, and the results are correlated with Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy data. In addition to mesoporosity, defects such as self-trapped excitons, oxygen vacancies and surface defects on Si/SiO<sub>x</sub> interface contribute to the luminescence of slanted silicon nanowires. Red shift in the photoluminescence with increasing etching time is explained using Quantum Confinement Luminescent Center model. Understanding the role of defects and porosity in slanted silicon nanowires is highly desirable to increase the efficiency of silicon nanowires based optoelectronic devices.
1501	Ultrafine ErC<sub>2</sub>@C Core-Shell Structural Nanocomposite with Significant Magnetocaloric Effect and Microwave Absorption Properties	<strong>Traditional techniques for synthesizing ultrafine rare carbide particles involving high-temperature annealing processes are lack of effectiveness, resulting in an extreme limitation to fully explore their properties and potential applications. We herein demonstrate a modified arc-discharging approach to synthesize the core/shell structural ErC<sub>2</sub>@C nanoparticles, in which ultrafine ErC<sub>2</sub> clusters with a mean diameter of 7.5&plusmn;0.5 nm can be uniformly dispersed in carbon matrix ascribed to the non-equilibrium evaporation-condensation process. It is found that the ErC<sub>2</sub>@C nanoparticles present significant magnetocaloric and microwave absorption performances, corresponding to the magnetic entropy change of 8.7 J/kg K at 4 K with the magnetic field variation of 0-5 T, and the maximum reflection loss of -49 dB at 15 GHz for a 2.44 mm thick absorber. The present work thus provides an effective strategy for the synthesis of rare earth carbides and explores their potential applications in diverse fields.</strong>
1502	A novel method to increase the productivity of nanoparticles by double wire electrical explosion	Low production efficiency is the key factor that restricting the application of the electrical exploding wire technology used in metal nanoparticles preparation field. This paper presents a novel and simple double wire electrical explosion (WEE) method to increase the nanoparticles productivity. The overvoltage generated by the first WEE process is used to breakdown the designed transfer spark gap and induced the second WEE process, leading to a double electrical explosion process in one circle of the capacitor discharge. The principle of the double electrical explosion process is expounded and parameters are optimized by experiments. The effects of the second metal wire length on the value of the deposited energy in metal wire were analyzed and optimized according to the coefficient of the metal wire overheating. The results showed that the optimal proportion of the first and the second metal wires was 1: 0.836, and the production efficiency can increase by 83.6 percent, which was significant for the metal nanoparticles large-scale preparation science the metal wire electrical explosion process operated in repetition mode.
1503	Be3N2 monolayer: a graphene-like two-dimensional material and its derivative nanoribbons	Using first-principles calculations, we computationally designed a new two-dimensional (2D) inorganic material, Be3N2 monolayer with a flat hexagonal structure similar to graphene . Good stability of the Be3N2 monolayer is demonstrated by its moderate cohesive energy, the absence of imaginary modes in its phonon spectrum, and the high melting point predicted by molecular dynamics (MD) simulations.The Be3N2 monolayer is a direct band gap semiconductor with a band gap of 3.831 eV that can be effectively tuned by employing an external strain.The wide band gap and outstanding strain-engineered properties make Be3N2 monolayer a highly versatile and promising 2D material for innovative applications in microelectromechanical and nanoelectronic devices. Additionally, the one-dimensional Be3N2 nanoribbons which divided by Be3N2 monolayer, are computed to have quite rich characteristics such as direct band gaps with various values, depending on the direction of the division and the width of nanoribbons.
1504	<strong>Ultrafast Plasmon Charge Transfer Dynamics in Au-ZnO Nanocomposite Thin Films</strong>	Here, we present ultrafast charge transfer dynamics in Au-ZnO nanocomposite systems by exciting them in inter- and intra -band levels of Au with pump energies higher (2.48 eV) and lower (1.96 eV) than the threshold energy for inter-band transition (2.4 eV), using femtosecond time-resolved pump-probe technique. The spectral responses for both the excitations exhibit different behaviors and these variations are quantitatively interpreted in terms of pump induced changes in the dielectric constant of Au. It is found from the temporal dynamics that the electron-phonon component in Au-ZnO system decays much faster (~3 ps in multilayer Au-ZnO for 2.48 eV excitation) than that observed in Au sample (~7 ps in Au) for both the pump energies. The transfer of highly energetic electrons from Au nanoparticles to ZnO across the Schottky barrier results in an accessible optical response for wide band gap ZnO in the visible to infrared range via plasmon charge collection. The calculated charge transfer rate in Au-ZnO system is found to be (&gt;10<sup>11</sup> s<sup>-1</sup>). Our work demonstrates a study to understand the ultrafast charge transfer processes in metal-semiconductor hybrid structures for various photonic devices.
1505	Dielectric properties of condensed systems composed of fragments	The dielectric properties of molecules or nanostructures are usually modified in a complex manner, when assembled into a condensed phase. We propose a first-principles method to compute polarizabilities of sub-entities of solids and liquids, which accounts for multipolar interactions at all orders, and is applicable to any semiconductor or insulator.  The method only requires the evaluation of induced fields in the condensed phase, with no need of multiple calculations for each constituent. As an example, we present results for the molecular polarizabilities of liquid water in a wide pressure and temperature range. We found that at ambient conditions, the dipole-induced-dipole approximation is sufficiently accurate and the Clausius-Mossotti relation may be used, e.g. to obtain molecular polarizabilities from experimental refractive indexes. However with increasing pressure this approximation becomes unreliable and in the case of ice X the Clausius-Mossotti relation is not valid.
1506	Metastable &#xF064;-Fe during reduction of Ferric Oxide and its magnetic properties	Ferric oxide (Fe2O3) was reduced to metallic Fe using the carbon source from the nut shells of pistachio or walnuts at temperatures above 1400 &#x00BA;C in argon gas atmospheres.  X-ray diffraction analysis shows the presence of &#xF061;-, &#xF067;-, and &#xF064;- phases of Fe in addition to the presence of graphite phases as carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and amorphous carbon.  By selecting the appropriate ratios of each nut shell powder to Fe2O3, it is demonstrated that pure Fe is produced without any residual ferric oxide.  The amount of each of the three Fe phases was dependent on the temperature and the duration of processing at high temperature. Transmission electron microcopy results showed copious quantities of CNTs.  Magnetic data suggested the average magnetic moment was consistent with &#xF061;-Fe but reduced moment for both the &#xF067;-Fe and &#xF064;-Fe. This simple method of producing &#xF064;-Fe along with CNTs has potential industrial applications as composites.
1507	Thermoelectric efficiency in three-terminal Graphene nano-junctions	The thermoelectric efficiency of a thermal machine consisting of a triangular graphene nano-junctions connected to three electrodes in the linear response regime is studied. Using the Onsager formalism and a combination of semi-empirical tight-binding calculations as well as Green's function theory, the efficiency at maximum output power which can be written in terms of generalized figures of merit is investigated. Results for a set of temperature and  chemical potential parameters shown that adding a third terminal will improve the efficiency at maximum output power with respect to the two-terminal setup.
1508	Dual-band Dielectric Light-harvesting Nanoantennae Made by Nature	We show that the dual-band maxima in the absorption spectrum of bacterial light harvestors not only are due to the bacteriochlorophylls involved but also come from the geometry of the light harvestor.sBeing able to manipulate these two band arbitrarily enable us to fabricate the nanoparticles to separate sunlight into photovotalic useful range and thermally useful range to increase the efficiency of solar light harvesting. Such antennae are also useful for remote power charging at flexible configuration.
1509	<strong>Half-metallic surfaces in thin-film Ti<sub>2</sub>MnAl<sub>0.5</sub>Sn<sub>0.5</sub></strong>	Materials exhibiting a high degree of spin polarization in electron transport are in demand for applications in spintronics &ndash; an emerging technology utilizing a spin degree of freedom in electronic devices. Room-temperature half-metals are considered ideal candidates, as they behave as an insulator for one spin channel and as a conductor for the other spin channel. In addition, for nano-size devices, one has to take into account possible modification of electronic structure in thin-film geometry, due to the potential presence of surface/interface states. It has been shown that typically these states have a detrimental impact on half-metallicity. Here, we employ density functional calculations to explore an inverse Heusler compound, Ti<sub>2</sub>MnAl<sub>0.5</sub>Sn<sub>0.5</sub>, which exhibits half-metallic electronic structure in bulk. In particular, this material behaves as a regular metal for majority-spin, and as a semiconductor for minority-spin states. We show that in thin-film geometry, the type of termination surface has a decisive effect on half-metallicity of this material. In particular, we analyze six possible termination configurations, and show that for four of them, energy states emerge in the minority-spin band gap, reducing the spin polarization of Ti<sub>2</sub>MnAl<sub>0.5</sub>Sn<sub>0.5</sub>. At the same time, our calculations indicate that two termination surfaces <em>preserve</em> half-metallic properties of this material. This result is somewhat unexpected, as most of the available literature reports reduction of the spin-polarization due to the presence of surface states. Thus, our results show that a judicious choice of the termination surface may be a crucial factor in nano-device applications, where highly spin-polarized current is needed.
1510	Occupied Free-Space Superatom States in an Encapsulated Ca2N Nanotube	Inspired by the success of the periodic law of elements, superatom states have been widely used to understand complex chemical systems. Besides those states delocalized on multiple atoms, the concept of superatom states has also been extended to states distributed in free space surround or confined by multiple atoms. Such free-space superatom states are expected to provide a useful conceptual framework to understand chemical properties of their associated nanosystems. Unfortunately, all free-space superatom states reported to date are unoccupied states, which strongly limits their applications. In this study, we predict that both occupied and unoccupied free-space superatom states exist in an encapsulated Ca2N nanotube. In this composite system, the inner Ca2N nanotube provides anionic electrons in free space inside the tube which form occupied s-, p-, and d-like superatom states. The outer carbon nanotube layer provides a protection for these free-space superatom states from ambient environment. Such protected superatom states are expected to have a great potential in various application fields such as catalysis and electronics.
1511	<strong>Tailoring nanostructured surfaces with plasmonic/magnetic </strong><strong>multifunctional response</strong>	In this work we present an innovative way to functionalize large surfaces combining both plasmonic and ferromagnetic nanoparticles on a substrate, by growth of bilayers and a subsequent single annealing. In particular, we show here the formation of Au and &gamma;-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles using this route. Thermal treatments promote the nanostructuration of the film plus a partial oxidation of Fe to form ferrimagnetic oxides. For this purpose, annealing conditions and the structure of the bilayer must be selected to achieve an optimal nanostructuration, avoiding the full oxidation of Fe to form antiferromagnetic hematite.
1512	Hollow-cathode glow discharge in a trigger unit of pseudospark switch	This paper deals with the investigation of the sealed-off hold-cathode thyratron (pseudospark switch) with a trigger unit that uses a low-current auxiliary glow discharge. As distinct from the commercially produced thyratron TPI1-10k/50, the trigger system of the device under investigation is modernized so that it is able to operate in absence of the so-called high-emissivity tablet. The data on the principal features of the discharge sustainment in the novel trigger system are obtained. The interpretation of the data is carried out based on the model of the discharge with hollow cathode, which has been developed as applied to the conditions of the low current densities. It is shown that the regimes of the auxiliary discharge have an impact on the trigger characteristics of the switch. The ability of the switch operation with nanosecond stability with respect to a trigger pulse at high anode voltages is demonstrated.
1513	Single-shot near edge X-ray fine structure (NEXAFS) spectroscopy using a laboratory laser-plasma light source	We present a proof of principle experiment on single-shot near edge soft X-ray fine structure (NEXAFS) spectroscopy with the use of a laboratory laser-plasma light source. The source is based on a plasma created as a result of the interaction of a nanosecond laser pulse with a double stream gas puff target. The laser-plasma source was optimized for efficient soft X-ray (SXR) emission from the krypton/helium target in the wavelength range from 2 nm to 5 nm. This emission was used to acquire simultaneously emission and absorption spectra of soft X-ray light from the source and from the investigated sample using a grazing incidence grating spectrometer. NEXAFS measurements in a transmission mode revealed the spectral features near the carbon K-&#x03B1; absorption edge of thin PET film and L-ascorbic acid in a single-shot. From these features, the composition of the PET sample was successfully obtained. The NEXAFS spectrum of the L-ascorbic acid obtained in a single-shot exposure was also compared to the spectrum obtained a multi-shot exposure and to numerical simulations showing good agreement. In the paper, the detailed information about the source, the spectroscopy system,  the absorption spectra measurements and the results of the studies are presented and discussed.
1514	Ultrafast dynamics of hexaferrite colloidal particles	Here we report an experimental study on the rotational dynamics of hard magnetic hexaferrite nanoparticles in water. Stable aqueous colloid of SrFe<sub>12</sub>O<sub>19</sub> was synthesized by borate glass-ceramic dissolution technique and studied by TEM, small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), magnetometry and optical transmission methods in applied DC and AC magnetic fields. The particles represent nanoplates with a mean diameter of 50 nm and a mean thickness of 5 nm having a coercive force of 4700 Oe and a saturation magnetization of 51.5 emu/g. According to magnetic field dependent SAXS data, a probability orientation function was suggested considering the colloidal particles rotation in the applied field as an activation-free process. The magnetization dynamics of the colloidal rotators was described by an interplay of magnetic torque and drag force in the frame of non-interacting particles model. At frequencies below 100 Hz, the particles are able to fully rotate after the magnetic field. At higher frequencies, the complete following becomes impossible due to the energy dissipation and the particles movement changes to oscillations around randomly oriented axes. These vibrational axes can be aligned by strong external permanent magnetic field, causing the coherent particles oscillations and correspondingly the rise of the high-frequency response of the colloid optical transmission. As a result, the efficient magneto-optical light modulation has been achieved at frequencies exceeding 5 kHz, revealing the fastest response rates among known colloidal magneto-optical media.
1515	<strong>High Curie Temperature CoSi nanowires by Mn-doping.</strong>	We report the synthesis of high Curie temperature (Tc &gt;800K) Mn-doped CoSi nanowires. CoSi and Co<sub>1-x</sub>Mn<sub>x</sub>Si nanowires were synthesized by Chemical Vapor Deposition. Transmission electron microscopy was used to identify a crystalline B20 cubical structure. Zero-field cooling and field cooling measurements confirm a spin disorder behaviour at low temperatures. The magnetic properties of doped samples were explained by means of the Ruderman-Kittel-Kasuya-Yosida (RKKY) interaction where the localized Mn atoms interact with the conduction electrons in CoSi providing a net ferromagnetic moment and explaining spin disorder at low temperatures. An individual CoSi nanowire was experimentally analysed by performing off-axis electron holography, providing information about its local magnetization. DFT calculations were performed to understand the effects of Mn doping, Si-vacancies and surface atoms in the magnetic properties at the surface of the nanowire. An estimation of the Curie temperature was made using the mean field approximation (MFA).
1516	Nanoscale transitions in glass-forming melts	Glass-forming melts frequently undergo a liquid-liquid transition (LLT). Unraveling the nature of LLTs is therefore seen as an important stage in identifying valid theories of the glass transition itself. In this work, we find evidence for two LLTs being no true phase transitions in the thermodynamic sense but nanoscale transformations. We base this conclusion on simulations of two distinct, albeit generic glass formers: the ternary alloy Zr<sub>0.606</sub>Cu<sub>0.29</sub>Al<sub>0.104</sub> and silica (SiO<sub>_2</sub>): although various thermodynamic, structural, and dynamical properties or their temperature derivatives appear to change quasi-discontinuously at the LLT, no computed quantity shows any size-dependence reminiscent of a thermodynamic phase transition once the system size exceeds a few hundred atoms.
1517	Determination of the Quantum Well Carrier Capture Time by Transport Factors in Light Emitting Transistor	We carry out the physical modeling of the light emitting transistor (LET) operation with the focus on the carrier lifetime in the base, which is a key factor in the device speed performances. Our model is based on the observation of the degradation of the base transport factor caused by the LET heavy base doping, and its variation with the base current. We revise the conventional charge control model of the bipolar junction transistor (BJT) to account for these new features and assess the concentration of the base minority carriers captured in the quantum well (QW). Our approach based on the Zhang and Leburton&rsquo;s (Z-L) rate equation model enables us to obtain the device microscopic parameters, such as the capture time, base recombination lifetime and base transit time in terms of the LET emitter current and base current, as well as the design parameters such as doping concentration, base width, QW width or QW location.  Whereas the base recombination lifetime can be estimated to be of the order of a fraction of a nanosecond, the QW capture time is found to be of the order of a picosecond or less. Our simulation successfully reproduces the optical frequency response diagram of the LET obtained from the experiment.
1518	Growth and mechanical properties of 111-oriented V0.5Mo0.5Nx/Al2O3(0001) thin films	Pseudobinary V0.5Mo0.5Nx(111) alloys with the B1-NaCl crystal structure are grown on Al2O3(0001) substrates in an ultra-high-vacuum system by reactive magnetron sputter deposition in mixed Ar/N2 atmospheres at temperatures Ts between 100 and 900 {degree sign}C. Nitrogen-to-metal, N/(V+Mo), fractions x vary monotonically from 0.9{plus minus}0.1 with Ts = 100 {degree sign}C to 0.4{plus minus}0.1 at Ts = 900 {degree sign}C. Nitrogen loss at higher growth temperatures leads to a corresponding decrease in the relaxed lattice parameter ao from 4.21{plus minus}0.01 &#x00C5; at Ts = 300 {degree sign}C to 4.125{plus minus}0.005 &#x00C5; with Ts = 900 {degree sign}C. Scanning electron micrographs of cube-corner nanoindents extending into the substrate show that the films are relatively ductile, exhibiting material pile-up (plastic flow) around the indent edges. Nanoindentation hardnesses H and elastic moduli E, obtained using a calibrated Berkovich tip, of V0.5Mo0.5Nx(111) layers increase with increasing Ts (decreasing x) from 15{plus minus}1 and 198{plus minus}5 GPa at 100 {degree sign}C to 23{plus minus}2 and 381{plus minus}11 GPa at 900 {degree sign}C. These values are lower than corresponding results obtained for 001-oriented V0.5Mo0.5Nx films. In addition, film wear resistance increases with increasing Ts, while the coefficient of friction, under 1000 &#x00B5;N loads, is 0.09{plus minus}0.01 for all layers.
1519	<strong>Surprisingly high magneto-electric coupling in cubic Co<sub>0.7</sub>Fe<sub>2.3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>-SrTiO<sub>3</sub> nano-composites</strong>	Magnetoelectric (ME) coupling of (x)SrTiO<sub>3</sub>-(1-x)Co<sub>0.7</sub>Fe<sub>2.3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> synthesized by the sol-gel method is presented in this study. The presence of constituent phases of Co<sub>0.7</sub>Fe<sub>2.3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>  (CFO) and SrTiO<sub>3</sub>(STO) in the composites were confirmed by x-ray diffraction studies. The field emission scanning electron micrographs show well-distributed CFO and STO phases in the composites. The dielectric constant (e&cent;) and loss tangent (tand) of the composites were studied as a function of frequency. CFO and all the composites exhibit typical ferromagnetic hysteresis loops whereas their ferroelectric hysteresis loops show leaky behavior. Surprisingly high value of magnetoelectric voltage coefficient, a<sub>ME</sub> = 9.1 mV/cm Oe is obtained for the composite having 50% STO and 50% CFO content. These results demonstrate that the lead free STO-CFO could be effective as magnetoelectric composite and may provide an alternative for environmental friendly ME device application.
1520	<strong>Refined model for plasmon ruler based on catenary shaped optical fields</strong><sup></sup>	The catenary, in addition to be structure of mechanics and optics, expresses the rule of evanescent field coupling between metallic nanoparticle pairs. In the present paper, the catenary shaped optical field distributions within the gap of nanoparticle pairs as well as the distance dependence of scattering spectrum shift are investigated. A novel model defined by power attenuation functions is established to describe the scaling behavior of local field enhancement and plasmon wavelength shift of metallic nanoparticle pairs. Compared to traditional model, the proposed model here can more accurately describe the scaling behavior of scattering spectrum shift, which help to refine the existing plasmon rulers. Our findings can serve as a guideline for designing and optimizing catenary field based plasmon rulers.
1521	<strong>Nanoindentation and bending fracture behavior of flexible inorganic thin films grown at near room temperature with <em>in situ</em> tensile/compressive stress </strong>	Residual stress is known to affect significantly the mechanical fracture behavior of flexible thin films. Here we suggest an <em>in situ </em>chemical deposition process that allows for control of extra compressive or tensile stress in inorganic thin films. This process uses the fixed convex or concave surface of a flexible substrate to impart compressive or tensile stress, respectively, after the releasing step to the flat mode. Using two technical evaluations of mechanical fracture behavior, the existence of extra stress was verified with expected enhancements of the fracture resistance only in the case of compressive stress. For example, a ~45% improvement of the elastic modulus was confirmed by nanoindentation testing for a compressively stressed sample compared to the reference sample. The bending fracture resistance was also enhanced for the compressively stressed sample, as evidenced by a ~18.5% improvement in the crack-initiating critical strain under the bending motion.
1522	Electronic transport induced by edge modification of graphene electrodes in single molecular device	The electronic transport properties of salicylidene aniline based molecular devices with the graphene electrodes are investigated using the density functional theory and the non-equilibrium Green&rsquo;s functions. The calculated results suggest a clear switching behavior. In addtion, the modification of -OH on the edge of graphene nanoribbons causes the increase of currents, but the reduction of switching ratio. The modification of F on the edge of graphene nanoribbons improves the switching ratio. Also the negative differential resistance effect found in the device is discussed by the transmission spectra and local density of states. The results show the effects of different modifications of the edge of graphene nanoribbons on the electron transport. This method can become a candidate to improve the performance of device in future molecular circuits.
1523	Conductance recovery in graphene nano-ribbons systems using pseudo-spin filters	In this work we study some applications for the pseudo-spin filters. The filters are potential barriers with hyperboloid sub-band contributions that are locally applied over the graphene nano-ribbons. These filters modulate the pseudo-spin and the quirality of the wave-function allowing the recovery of the conductance loss due to imperfection, bends, or constrictions found in the system. The filters can be used as patches for damaged regions within the ribbon in order to increase the transmission, even when it is zero. The recovery of the conductance is fulfilled by a direct manipulation of the pseudo-spin polarization at both sides of the scattering region, which allows the recovery of the wave-function symmetry between the entrance and the exit of the <br />system.
1524	X-ray Ptychography on low dimensional hard condensed matter materials	Understanding the structure of low-dimensional hard-condensed matter systems is critical for manipulation and optimization of next-generation nano-scale semiconductor and spintronic devices. Synchrotron X-ray based imaging techniques, have been under intensive development in the last two decades.  They are complementary to traditional electron-based imaging methods while adding advantages of elemental and bulk sensitivities. X-ray ptychography is a reciprocal-space based imaging technique, with strong phase-contrast with potentially diffraction-limited spatial resolution. Further, using resonant X-ray, the technique can be made to be element, electronic and magnetic sensitive. In this review article, the far-field diffraction-based ptychography techniques are discussed, and examples of their scientific importance in low dimensional materials sciences are presented. Near field or Fourier ptychography will not be discussed in this review. Future developments in this emerging field are proposed for nanotechnology and materials sciences in general.
1525	Femtosecond time-resolved photoemission electron microscopy for imaging the spatially heterogeneous carrier relaxation dynamics of semiconductors	Femtosecond time-resolved photoemission electron microscopy (TR-PEEM) simultaneously furnishes high spatial- and temporal resolution and is therefore well suited to the study of ultrafast phenomena of spatially heterogeneous materials. Until recently, however, the majority of the TR-PEEM investigations to date are confined to plasmonic phenomena in metal nanostructures. Here, we report a TR-PEEM instrument based on interfacing the hollow-core fiber-compressed output from a fiber laser to a PEEM microscope. The instrument is used to generate lifetime maps that report on the spatially heterogeneous carrier relaxation dynamics of semiconductor materials. Starting from a Yb fiber laser with 1030-nm center wavelength (1.20-eV photon energy), 50-&#x00B5;J pulse energy, and 320-fs pulse duration, 55-fs pulses are produced after spectral broadening in xenon gas followed by dispersion compensation by chirped mirrors and a pair of fused silica wedges. The harmonics 2&#xF077; - 5&#xF077; are produced by second harmonic generation and/or sum-frequency generation in BBO crystals, yielding pulse widths of 46 fs, 40 fs and 28 fs for the 2&#x03C9; (2.41 eV), 3&#x03C9; (3.61 eV), and 4&#x03C9; (4.81 eV) pulses, respectively. Given the high, 0.6-MHz repetition rate of the fiber laser, an exposure time of 10 s yields static PEEM images with spatial resolutions of 77 nm and 58 nm when the sample is illuminated by 3&#x03C9; and 4&#x03C9; light, respectively. Finally, we show that the apparatus can be used to investigate the sub-100-fs electronic relaxation dynamics of single-layer platinum diselenide (PtSe2) at the &#x0393; valley following photoexcitation with 2.41-eV light. By using a home-built MATLAB code, we produce an image of the spatial distribution of electronic relaxation time constants, whose statistical analysis not only recovers the ensemble-averaged electronic relaxation time constant, but also directly yields the extent of spatial heterogeneity of the observed dynamics.
1526	<strong>Controlling the charge transport mode in permalloy films using oblique angle deposition </strong>	We have systematically studied the effect of oblique angle deposition on the transport properties of permalloy thin films. Films deposited at angles larger than 50<sup>0</sup> exhibit a metal-insulator transition that can be further manipulated by changing the deposition angle. This transition is manifested as a deviation from the usual phonon-scattering behavior in the temperature dependence of the resistivity. Furthermore, a change in the magnetic anisotropy in the films is clearly demonstrated in their magnetoresistance that shifts from negative to positive with increasing deposition angle. Oblique angle deposition results in the formation of nano-pillars that modify the fundamental electron scattering process in the films. The modifications in the scattering process produce a metal-insulator transition in the films grown at high angels. The possible mechanisms responsible for the observed behavior are discussed.
1527	<strong>Mechanical Properties of Tungsten-Rhenium, Lanthanum and Copper doped Tungsten-Rhenium nanostructures &ndash; a DFT study</strong>	The mechanical properties of Tungsten(W), Re doped W (W-Re), La doped W-Re and Cu doped W-Re nanostructures were explored using density functional theory (DFT).
