For exploring the mechanical properties, elastic constants, Young&rsquo;s modulus, Bulk modulus and Shear modulus were observed. The ductility and hardness of the nanostructures have also been studied at the atomistic level. Furthermore, the density of states spectrum (DOS) was analyzed for these nanostructures. The findings reveal that W<sub>0.81</sub>Re<sub>0.14</sub>Cu<sub>0.05 </sub>nanostructures show the best combination when compared to factors like ductility and Young&rsquo;s modulus.
1528	Simple and Facile One Pot Hydrothermal Synthesis for Nanopetallike Thermochromic VO<sub>2</sub>	This paper reports successful synthesis of different phase of nanopetallike thermochromic VO<sub>2 </sub>via hydrothermal method by varying molar ratio of reducing agent, citric acid monohydrate to vanadium source, vanadium (V) oxide and by keeping temperature 230<sup>o</sup>C for 24hr. Five samples are synthesized with molar ratio V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> to citric acid monohydrate 1:1, 1:1.5, 1:2, 1:3 and 1:4. The synthesized nanoparticles are characterized by XRD for phase identification, FTIR for confirmation of chemical composition. To confirm about optical properties, UV VIS is done. Electrical conductivity is also confirmed with conductivity meter. Morphology and uniform size distribution of the materials is found with SEM and size of the particles is confirmed with TEM. Thermal properties are confirmed with STA. Synthesized materials VO<sub>2 </sub>(B) and VO<sub>2</sub> (M) are useful for electrochemical and energy saving window coating if its transition temperature is controlled.
1529	Study on large-area silicon nanopillars with broadband low reflectance	Broadband low-reflectance silicon has a variety of potential applications and low-cost, large-scale preparation is beneficial to industrial applications. In this work, we fabricate and investigate large-area silicon nanostructures with low reflectance in a wide wavelength range by using a low-cost metal assisted chemical etching method. It is found that the silicon nanostructure consists of vertical nanopillars in a random distribution and the pillar heights are lower than 3 um. The weighted average reflectivity shows low reflectivity of 2.3% in a wide wavelength range of 300 to 1100 nm. The model is constructed and the reflectivity simulations are conducted by using the finite-difference time-domain method. The simulation result shows a good consistency with the measurement result in the wavelength range of 300 to 1030 nm. The present results can be used to investigate and understand large-area silicon nanostructures with broadband low reflectivity.
1530	High Curie Temperature CoSi nanowires by Mn-doping	We report the synthesis of high Curie temperature (T<sub>C</sub> &gt;800K) Mn-doped CoSi nanowires. CoSi and Co<sub>1-x</sub>Mn<sub>x</sub>Si nanowires were synthesized by Chemical Vapor Deposition. Transmission electron microscopy was used to identify a crystalline B20 cubical structure. Zero-field cooling and field cooling measurements confirm a spin disorder behaviour at low temperatures. The magnetic properties of doped samples were explained by means of the Ruderman-Kittel-Kasuya-Yosida (RKKY) interaction where the localized Mn atoms interact with the conduction electrons in CoSi providing a net ferromagnetic moment and explaining spin disorder at low temperatures. An individual CoSi nanowire was experimentally analysed by performing off-axis electron holography, providing information about its local magnetization. DFT calculations were performed to understand the effects of Mn doping, Si-vacancies and surface atoms in the magnetic properties at the surface of the nanowire. An estimation of the Curie temperature was made using the mean field approximation (MFA).
1531	Design and performance of nanoXPS, a new setup for spatially resolved x-ray photoelectron spectromicroscopy at the Swiss Light Source	We report here on the successful design, installation and operation of a high spatial resolution x-ray photoelectron spectrometer, called nanoXPS, at the Swiss Light Source. The new setup works in transmission, and is capable of extracting valuable chemical information with nanoscale resolution on samples deposited on x-ray transparent substrates. A Fresnel zonesplate is used to focus the incoming photon beam and create a nanoprobe beam that crosses the sample. Photoelectrons, generated from the backside of the silicon nitride membranescoated with the sample, are collected by a Specs Phoibos 150 electron analyzer positioned at 45 degrees with respect to the incoming beam direction. By raster scanning the sample acrosssthe x-ray spot, an element specific photoemission image is obtained. The estimated spatial resolution of the chemical imaging was less than 500 nm for present set of measurements, and it can be improved up to a few tens of nanometer. This kind of photoelectron spectromicroscope will allow in-situ measurements with high spatial resolution. Element-specific x-ray photoemission maps can be obtained before and while exposing the sample to gas/gas mixtures to show morphological and chemical changes of the surface.
1532	Nonlinear optical rectification and optical bistability in a coupled asymmetric quantum dot-metal nanoparticle hybrid	We study the optical response of a coupled asymmetric semiconductor quantum dot - spherical metal nanoparticle structure. The asymmetric quantum dot has permanent electric dipole moments that also interact with light. We derive the density matrix equations for the system including the modification of the electric field and the exciton-plasmon coupling. We give emphasis to the effects of the nonlinear optical rectification and controlled optical bistability and analyze these phenomena for different values of the light intensity and different distances between the quantum dot and the metal nanoparticle. We show that when the system is set in a situation where<br />optical bistability can be produced the optical rectification of the hybrid system is bivaluated. We also analyze the slow down to reach the steady state<br />when the system is driven close and far from the turning points.
1533	Collective Density and Energy evolution during Diffusion of Nanoparticles in Polymer Solutions	The diffusion of nanoparticle in polymer solutions has been studied using the dynamic density functional theory. By considering the collective density and free-energy evolution of nanoparticle, we show four different diffusion modes depending mainly on particle size and polymer concentration. Under the condition of low polymer concentration, the diffusion dynamics is controlled by particle free motion. As the concentration increases, if the particle size is comparable to the correlation function of polymer chain, nanoparticle needs to penetrate through a cage and overcome an energy barrier, such that the local diffusion inevitably slows down. Further increase of polymer concentration could result in another caging regime and additional energy barrier. In contrast, large particle can be easily restricted by the surrounding polymer segments, and the local diffusion becomes extremely difficult. In this case, nanoparticle diffusion is controlled by the Rouse dynamics of polymer chains.
1534	Magnetic Domain and Domain Wall Analyses of MnAs Nanodisks Selectively-Grown on Si (111) Substrates	We report on the experimental and analytic results on magnetic domain and domain wall structures of MnAs nanodisks on AlGaAs buffer layers selectively grown on Si (111) substrates partially covered with dielectric SiO<sub>2</sub> thin film mask patterns for the selective-area metal-organic vapor phase epitaxy. The results on the size dependence of magnetic domain structures in MnAs nanodisks observed by magnetic force microscopy show that a single domain is predominant in the MnAs nanodisks with an area of approximately 3 x 10<sup>4</sup> nm<sup>2</sup> or less. It is also indicated that multiple domains, in particular, two magnetic domain structures with a 180<sup>o</sup> domain wall are predominant in the nanodisks with an area of approximately 6 x 10<sup>4</sup> nm<sup>2</sup> or more. In addition, in the case of nanodisks with multiple domains, the nanodisks not only with N&eacute;el wall but also with Bloch wall are possibly formed, judging from the detailed analyses of the magnetic force microscope images obtained. These results suggest that the magnetic domains and domain walls are possibly tuned by the control in the MnAs nanodisk size.
1535	<strong>High Speed</strong><strong> Efficient Ultraviolet Photodetector based on Multiple WO<sub>3 </sub>Nanowires</strong>	This work presents the fabrication of multiple WO<sub>3</sub> nanowires photodetector for ultra-violet detection. This photodetector exhibits a photo to the dark current ratio of the order of 4 with a high relative change in conductance around 8100 upon 340 nm illumination at 0.87 mW/cm<sup>2</sup>. The photodetector exhibits high responsivity of 47.3 A/W and high 340 nm to 450 nm rejection ratio of ~8800 with excellent stability. Low noise equivalent power (NEP) with 0.37 fW/&radic;Hz and high Detectivity ~10<sup>12</sup> Jones is observed.  We obtained a fast response with rise time (t<sub>r</sub>) of 112 &micro;s and fall time (t<sub>f</sub>) of 84 &micro;s. These promising results demonstrate the applicability of the photodetector for high speed ultra-violet detection.
1536	Distinctive defect states in GaN at low and high Mg concentrations	We demonstrated a wide range of magnesium (Mg) doping control (10<sup>16</sup> &ndash;10<sup>20</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup>) in a GaN layer grown by metalorganic vapor phase epitaxy (MOVPE) on a freestanding GaN substrate and investigated the distinctive defect states at low and high Mg concentrations ([Mg]). Hydrogen concentrations ([H]) in as-grown GaN samples showed a one-to-one<br />relationship with [Mg] over the wide Mg doping range of 6 &times; 10<sup>16</sup> &ndash; 3 &times; 10<sup>19</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup> due to the formation of the Mg-H complex, but exhibited gaps between [Mg] and [H] at the low and the high ends of the doping range. At low [Mg], we found that [H] was in good agreement with the sum of [Mg] and carbon (C) concentrations, indicating the formation of the C-H complex. For heavily Mg-doped samples with lower [H], transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning TEM analyses showed that nano-scale defects are formed in the doped layers, and that these defects are pyramidal inversion domains (ID) with Mg segregation at the top (0001) boundary. We estimated the amount of segregated Mg atoms on the basis of our TEM-STEM analyses and concluded that most part of the Mg atoms not forming Mg-H complexes are segregated at the ID boundaries.
1537	Branched InAs nanowire growth by droplet confinement	Anisotropy in crystal growth of III-V semiconductor nanowires can be enhanced by the assistance of a liquid particle. During the past decades, selected scientific works have reported a controlled change of nanowire growth direction by manipulation of the assisting droplet. Although these results are interesting from an engineering point of view, a detailed understanding of the process is necessary in order to rationally design complex nanostructures. In this letter, we utilize our understanding of the growth-assisting droplet to control the morphology and direction of gold-assisted wurtzite-phase InAs nanowires, using controlled droplet displacement followed by resumed growth. By confining the droplet to the nanowire sidewall using zincblende inclusions as barriers, epitaxial growth of horizontal branches from existing nanowires is demonstrated. This is done by tailoring droplet wetting of the nanowire and using identical conditions for nanowire 'stem' and branch growth. This work demonstrates the importance of the droplet dynamics and wetting stability, along with the benefits of crystallographic control, for understanding growth along different directions. Controlled branched growth is one way to achieve designed nanowire networks.
1538	<strong>Amorphous aluminum-oxide supercapacitors</strong>	An amorphous aluminum-oxide supercapacitor can store a large amount of electric charge on its blackish, uneven Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3-x</sub> surface, which have a convexity of 21 nm, AlO<sub>6</sub> clusters, and a resistivity of 16.5 G&Omega;cm. The electric storage can be elucidated by extreme enhanced electron trapping resulting from both the quantum-size effect and the offset effect from positive charges at oxygen-vacancy sites. Here, a supercapacitor, which is characterised by high surface area of ~2,400 m<sup>2</sup>/g and formation of large numbers of electric double layers, demonstrates a vertical line in the Nyquist diagram and rapidly increased the imaginary impedance and phase angle was deduced to &minus;90&deg; with decreasing frequency in the Bode diagram using a distributed constant-electric circuit with a parallel assembly of nanometer-sized capacitors on a highly insulating amorphous aluminum surface. The supercapacitor indicates a switching effect for both positive (~+66 V) and negative (~&minus;11 V) potential.
1539	High spatial coherence in multiphoton-photoemitted electron beams	Nanometer-sharp metallic tips are known to be excellent electron emitters. They are used in highest-resolution electron microscopes in cold field emission mode to generate the most coherent electron beam in continuous-wave operation. For time-resolved operation, sharp metal needle tips have recently been triggered with femtosecond laser pulses. We show here that electrons emitted with near-infrared femtosecond laser pulses at laser oscillator repetition rates show the same spatial coherence properties as electrons in cold field emission mode in cw operation. From electron interference fringes, obtained with the help of a carbon nanotube biprism beam splitter, we deduce a virtual source size of less than 0.65&plusmn;0.06 nm for both operation modes, a factor of ten smaller than the geometrical source size. These results bear promise for ultrafast electron diffraction, ultrafast electron microscopy and other techniques relying on highly coherent and ultrafast electron beams.
1540	<strong>Harnessing the light confinement effect of Si nanowire arrays developed on different crystallographic planes: Insight to light polarization and omnidirectional properties</strong>	In this paper, fabrication of vertical Si nanowire arrays (SiNWAs) by a facile metal assisted electroless etching approach on different crystallographic planes of Si has been reported. A very low specular reflectance (R<em><sub>spec</sub></em>) of 0.04% and 0.03% has been achieved in the whole visible range for SiNWAs grown on Si(100) and Si(111) oriented substrates, respectively. High broadband enhancement has been detected for vertical SiNWAs due to multiple scattering paths inside the nanowire arrays. On the other hand, inclined nanowires showed a fascinating behavior at the longer wavelength regime, where light gets the longer path to reflect back-forth and ease to reflect back outward at normal incidence. Moreover, for [100] SiNWAs, transverse electric (<em>TE</em>) field component demonstrates the strong polarization insensitive properties at the expense of transverse magnetic (<em>TM</em>) field component with a minimum reflectance of &lt; 2% up to 1200 nm. The [100] SiNWAs demonstrates extra-ordinary omnidirectional properties at &theta;<sub>B</sub> &ge; 58&ordm;. COMSOL simulations reveal the effective dipole coupling and the presence of strong harmonic modes for vertical SiNWs at a typical wavelength regime. The highly bound states of the particle tunneling through the classical forbidden region shows a strong dependence on the gradual increment in the refractive index (m<sub>i</sub>) from 1 to 3.4. The strong and intense first order Raman signal located at ~520 cm<sup>-1</sup> demonstrates the asymmetric confinement effect for directional nanowires. This novel finding of describing the light localization properties for SiNWAs with different orientation gives a new route to support various photonic applications.
1541	Modern highly sensitive magnetometry: principles, limits of detection, and pitfalls	In the field of nanomagnetism and spintronics integral magnetometry is nowadays challenged by samples with low magnetic moments and/or low coercive fields. Commercial superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometers are versatile experimental tools to magnetically characterize samples with ultimate sensitivity as well as with a high degree of automation. For realistic experimental conditions the as-recorded magnetic signal contains several artifacts especially if small signals are measured on top of a large magnetic background or low magnetic fields are required. In this tutorial we will present a representative discussion of artifacts which can occur in studying samples like soft magnetic materials as well as low moment samples. It turns out that special attention is needed to quantify and correct the residual fields of the superconducting magnet to derive useful information from integral magnetometry and to avoid erroneous conclusions.
1542	<strong>A novel effective thermal conductivity model of polymer composites with sheet-like nanoparticles</strong>	In this study, we present a novel theoretical model for effective thermal conductivity aiming to the sheet-like nanoparticle polymer composites and analyse the model by comparing with other relevant models as well as experimental data. We obtain the effective thermal conductivity of a sheet-like nanoparticle with an interphase layer by analysing the different differential equations in both in-plane and out-of-plane directions in a cylindrical coordinate system. Then the present model is established based on the Nan&rsquo;s model and the solutions of these differential equations. The influences of interphase thickness, detailed sheet-like shape, anisotropic thermal conductivity of nanoparticle and volume fraction on the effective thermal conductivity of polymer composites are discussed.
1543	<SPAN style="color: #000000;">Luminescence study of stressed Si nanoclusters formed by dual metal ion implantation</SPAN>	<SPAN style="color: #000000;">Stressed Si nanoclusters (NCs) are synthesized using two-stage metal ion implantation technique. 1544	Improving the read-out of the resonance frequency of nanotube mechanical resonators	We report on a new electrical detection method of ultrasensitive carbon nanotube mechanical resonators. The noise floor of the detection method is reduced using a RLC resonator and an amplifier based on a high electron mobility transistor cooled at 4.2 K. This allows us to resolve the resonance frequency of nanotube resonators with an unprecedented quality. We show that the noise of the resonance frequency measured at 4.2 K is limited by the resonator itself, and not by the imprecision of the measurement. The Allan deviation reaches ~10<sup>-5</sup> at 125 ms integration time. When comparing the integration time dependence of the Allan deviation to a power law, the exponent approaches ~ 1/4. The Allan deviation might be limited by the diffusion of particles over the surface of the nanotube. Our work holds promise for mass spectrometry and surface science experiments based on mechanical nano-resonators.
1545	Molecular dynamics study of the thermal conductivity in nanofluids	In this work, the thermal conductivity of a model nanofluid at various volume fractions of nanoparticlessis computed thanks to equilibrium molecular dynamics (EMD) and non-equilibrium molecular dynamicss(NEMD) simulations. The Green-Kubo formalism is used for the EMD simulations while a net heat flux issimposed on the system with a change of the boundary conditions for the NEMD simulations. The interactionssinside the nanoparticles, between the fluid atoms, and between nanoparticles and fluid atoms are all takensas a Lennard-Jones potential. An empirical parameter, &#x03B6;, is added to the attractive part of the potential toscontrol the hydrophilicity of the nanoparticles, hence controlling how well dispersed are the nanoparticles insthe base fluid. The results show that the aggregation of the nanoparticles does not have a measurable effectson the thermal conductivity of the nanofluid. Nanofluids with volume fractions of 2% and 3% showed ansenhanced thermal conductivity with respect to the bulk fluid. Surprisingly, nanofluids with higher volumesfractions did not show any enhancement of the thermal conductivity.
1546	Electrochemical Methods for Fabrication of Polymers/Calcium Phosphates Nanocomposites as Hard Tissue Implants	Developing and manipulating new biomaterials is an ongoing topic for their needs in medical uses. The evolution and development of new biomaterials, both in the academic and industrial sectors, have been encouraged due to the dramatic improvement in medicine and medical-related technologies. Due to the drawbacks associated with natural biomaterials, using of synthetic biomaterials are preferential due to basic and applied aspects. Various techniques are involved to fabricate biomaterials. Among them are the electrochemical-based methods which include electrodeposition and electrophoretic methods. Although electrospinning and electrospraying are not typical electrochemical methods they are also reviewed in this articles due to their importance. There are many remarkable features that can be acquired from this technique. Electrodeposition and electrophoretic are exceptional and valuable processes for creating a thin or thick coating films on a surface of metallic implants. Electrodeposition and electrophoretic have some common positive features. They can be used at low temperatures, do not affect the structure of the implant and can be applied to complex shapes and they can produce superior properties, such as quick and uniform coating. Furthermore, they can possibly control the thickness and chemical composition of the coatings.  Electrospinning is a potentially emerging and efficient process for producing materials with nanofibrous structures which have exceptional characteristics such as mechanical, pore size and superior surface area. These specialized characteristic induce these nanostructured materials to be used in different technology. This review will focus on the discussion of the electrochemical methods for manipulating biomaterials produced from natural and synthetic polymers.
1547	<strong>In-situ water-assisted structural-manipulation of C1s sp<sup>3</sup>-characteristics in ferromagnetically-filled carbon onions: the case of high pressure Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> Bbmm</strong>	Carbon nano-onions (CNOs) are quasi-spherical fullerene-like structures with 60N<sup>2</sup> carbon atoms (N being the number of carbon layers) self-arranged in carbon shells. Reversible controlled transformations of these nanostructures into nanodiamonds (CNDs) have been recently demonstrated by using a laser wavelength of 532 nm for timescales of 40 min (CNOs to CNDs transformation). However, no studies have yet reported the dynamics of such transitions in metal/carbide filled CNOs (Me-C@CNOs). In this work we have investigated such structural transitions in the case of Fe-C@CNOs with controlled curvature. This observation is supported by controlled temperature dependent X-ray diffraction measurements in vacuum. In the attempt to control the sp<sup>3</sup> characteristics of the CNOs-shells we have then developed an advanced fabrication method where the controlled addition of water to ferrocene allows to profoundly enhance the sp<sup>3 </sup>carbon-characteristics of the CNOs by progressive oxidation of the encapsulated particles into a high pressure Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> phase.s<p><strong> </strong>
1548	<strong>The Ultrafast Carrier Dynamics of Bi2TexSe3-x Nanosheets </strong>	<strong>The ultrafast dynamics properties of Bi2TexSe3-x Nanosheets are investigated by time-resolved photoluminescence (PL) and pump-probe techniques in visible wavelength and near-infrared wavelength separately. The steady state PL peaks of three nanosheets are asymmetric, because of strong spin-orbit coupling. All the PL lifetimes in 400 nm are around 0.2 ns, dominanted by the charge separation</strong><strong>&#xFF1B;</strong><strong>all the PL lifetimes in 500~550 nm are around 1.2 ns, which are associated with the thermal effects. But in 450nm, with the increase of Se atoms, the ratio of these two effects changes from 2:8 to 6:4, meaning an obvious reverse of dominant mechanism. The electron-phonon relaxation lifetime, measured by pump-probe in near-infrared wavelength (1550 nm), is changed from 1.49 ps to 0.85 ps with the value of X from 3 to 0. It proves indirectly the previous conclusion that the increase of Se atoms could enhanced the thermal effects. 1549	The diode characteristic and prefect spin-filtering effect of zigzag SiC nanoribbon heterojuction with Boron and Nitrogen impurities	Based on a Zigzag Silicon Carbon nanoribbon with width 4 (4ZSiCNR), we construct a heterojunction through different substitutional impurities. The left part of junction is Boron-doped at the Si-edge of 4ZSiCNR (B-4ZSiCNR), and the right part is Nitrogen-doped at the C-edge of 4ZSiCNR (N-4ZSiCNR). Our results show that B-4ZSiCNR and N-4ZSiCNR exhibit half-metallic features at ferromagnetic state, which provides the possibility to design spin nanodevices. By performing first-principle quantum transport calculations, spin-dependent transport properties in different magnetic configurations are studied. Current-voltage curves show prefect spin-filtering and negative differential resistance effects when the two electrodes are polarized with different spin orientations. When the two electrodes are polarized with up spin orientations, the heterojunction can be used as a diode. Through detailed analysis of two electrodes&rsquo; band structures along with the transmission spectra, the interesting transport behaviors can be understood. Besides, the Bloch states of spin-polarized bands crossing the Fermi level can help us to understand the appearance of the negative differential resistance effect.
1550	<strong>High-quality AlN film achieved by growth-mode modification using sputtered AlN buffer</strong>	We proposed a strategy to obtain high-quality AlN film by combining growth-mode modification with sputtered AlN buffer using metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD). Compared with the AlN film grown on the island-like MOCVD AlN buffer, that grown on the flatter sputtered AlN buffer demonstrates a weaker three-dimensional (3D) growth and an earlier growth-mode transition from 3D to two-dimensional (2D), facilitating the faster coalescence of the surface. As a result, a 5.6-&mu;m-thick crack-free AlN film is achieved with a root-mean-square of 0.14 nm over 3 &times; 3 &mu;m<sup>2</sup>. It is found dislocations in the AlN film grown on the sputtered AlN buffer can be significantly suppressed through two new channels: high-density nanoscale voids and 90&deg; dislocation bending. Plan-view scanning tunnel electron microscope shows the threading dislocation density is dramatically reduced to 4.7 &times; 10<sup>7</sup> cm<sup>-2</sup>, which is extremely low for AlN film grown on sapphire. This very simple yet effective technique demonstrates great potential for the mass-fabrication of low-cost and high-performance deep-ultraviolet devices.
1551	A spatially smoothed device model for meso-structured perovskite solar cells	Meso-structured perovskite solar cell (PSC), utilizing a mesoporous absorber layer consisting of mesoporous metal oxide and perovskite material inside, is still delivering the highest solar cell efficiency for perovskite-based type solar cells up to date. Its outstanding performance critically depends on the nanoscopic morphology formed inside the mesoporous absorber layer. This, however, is not accounted in most perovskite device models, as they are based on an effective-medium formulation for the mesoporous absorber layer and the details of its underlying morphology are ignored. The mesoporous absorber layer is treated as a two-phase model that describes intrinsic solar cell physics such as free charge carrier generation, carrier transport, and recombination within the two phases, as well as at the interface between the two phases. We derive a spatially smoothed device model for meso-structured PSCs based on volume-averaging of electric potential, electron and hole concentrations of the two-phase model and this spatially smoothed formulation captures two essential morphological descriptors that are not found in existing effective-medium formulations for meso-structured PSCs, namely surface-to-volume ratio and porosity inside the mesoporous layer. Furthermore, we determine the explicit functional forms of the effective parameters in the spatially smoothed model for the case of an ideal &ldquo;Spaghetti&rdquo; blend morphology.
1552	Electrically controllable spin-polarized transport in bilayer graphene with Rashba spin-orbit interaction	We study spin-polarized transport in bilayer graphene nanoribbons (BGNs) in the presence of Rashba spin-orbit interaction (SOI) and external gate voltages. It is found that Rashba SOI alone in BGNs can only generate current with spin polarization along the in-plane y direction. The spin polarization can be significantly enhanced by the interlayer asymmetry or longitudinal mirror asymmetry produced by external gate voltages, and the polarization components can be found along the x, y and z directions. Spin current with high spin polarization and high flexibility in the orientation can be obtained in the proposed device. Our findings shed new light on the generation of highly spin-polarized current in BGNs without external magnetic fields, which could have useful applications in spintronics device design.
1553	<strong>Effects of modal phonon local non-equilibrium in thermal reservoirs on thermal conductivity prediction using molecular dynamics</strong>	Non-equilibrium molecular dynamics, which is widely adopted to study heat conduction in bulk materials and nanostructures, uses thermal reservoirs to prescribe temperatures. A basic requirement for thermal reservoir is that different phonon modes are at thermal equilibrium. In this work, based on spectral phonon temperature analysis, the modal phonon temperatures are extracted from the overall temperature in graphene using the Berendsen, Nos&eacute;-Hoover and Langevin thermostats. It is found that although all the modes are at equilibrium in the Langevin reservoir, the phonon modes are in local non-equilibrium in the Berendsen and Nos&eacute;-Hoover thermostats, with optical phonons overheated in the hot reservoir and overcooled in the cold reservoir. This local non-equilibrium significantly affects the thermal conductivity calculation. Taking graphene as an example, we find that the Berendsen and Nos&eacute;-Hoover reservoirs predict lower thermal conductivity compared to the Langevin thermostat, owing to the over-excitation of optical phonons. Our work also helps explain some measured apparent thermal conductivities where the heating or cooling are inherently non-equilibrium.
1554	Piezoelectric modulation of nonlinear optical response in BaTiO<sub>3</sub> thin film	We study the nonlinear optical response in a strained thin film ferroelectric oxide BaTiO3 using piezoelectric Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-PbTiO3 (PMN-PT) (001) as a variable strain substrate and La-doped SrTiO3 as a conductive buffer layer. The rotation-anisotropic second harmonic intensity profile shows hysteretic modulation corresponding to strain variation from the inverse piezoelectric response of the substrate. An enhancement of 15% is observed at 1.2 kV/cm, while a control sample shows negligible change as a function of piezovoltage. Reflection high-energy electron diffraction, x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and high-resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy reveal the epitaxial interface. X-ray diffraction and piezoresponse force microscopy confirm tetragonal distortion and ferroelectricity of the BTO overlayer. Our results suggest a promising route to enhance the performance of nonlinear optical oxides for the development of novel nano-opto-mechanical devices.
1555	<strong>Phonon scattering by antiphase boundaries in the Fe<sub>2</sub>VAl Heusler alloy</strong>	The Fe<sub>2</sub>VAl Heusler alloy, which crystallizes in the L2<sub>1</sub> structure at 300 K, undergoes two order-disorder phase transitions to the B2 and A2 structures at high temperature. Quenching this alloy from temperatures where the disordered B2 or A2 structure are stable, allows stabilizing a nanostructured variant of Fe<sub>2</sub>VAl containing L2<sub>1</sub> antiphase domains (APDs) separated by antiphase boundaries (APBs). The size of these APDs can be controlled by the quenching rate and ranges from ca. 280 mm to 95 nm. An analysis of the lattice thermal conductivity (<em>l</em><em><sub>L</sub></em>) by a modified Callaway model shows that the APBs can scatter the phonons, leading to a significant reduction of up to 20 % at 300 K for this quantity. Hence, phonon scattering by APBs provides a new method towards lower thermal conductivity in Fe<sub>2</sub>VAl.
1556	Transport properties and thermoelectric effects in gated silicene superlattices	Low-dimensional thermoelectricity opens the possibility of improving the performance and the efficiency of thermoelectric devices by redistributing the electron density of states through the reduction of dimensionality. In this work, we explore this possibility in silicene by reducing its dimensionality through the periodic arrangement of gated electrodes, the so-called gated silicene superlattices. Silicene electrons were described quantum relativistically. The transmission, conductance and thermoelectric properties were obtained with the transfer matrix method, the Landauer-B&uuml;ttiker formalism and the Cutler-Mott formula, respectively. We find that the redistribution of the density of states together with the intrinsic characteristics of silicene, the local band gap and the large spin-orbit coupling, confabulate to the enhancement of the thermoelectric properties. In particular, the Seebeck coefficient and the power factor reach values two and three orders of magnitude higher than those found in gated graphene superlattices. These findings in conjunction with the low thermal conductivity of silicene indicate that silicene-based nanostructures could be the basis to more efficient thermoelectric devices.
1557	A 3-mirror Surface Force Balance for the investigation of liquids confined to nanoscale films between two ultra-smooth polarizable electrodes	We present a new technique, based on the Surface Force Balance (SFB), for the direct measurement of surface forces between two ultra-smooth and polarizable gold electrode surfaces across thin fluid films. Combining the direct interferometric measurement of surface separation and contact geometry with smooth electrode surfaces has proved challenging in the past, and for this reason previous measurements with the SFB typically involved two insulating mica surfaces, or one mica surface and one electrode surface, or an alternative less direct measure of the surface separation. Here, we demonstrate that a 3-mirror interferometer can overcome these difficulties:  the setup involves two ultra-smooth electrode/mirror surfaces between which the fluid is confined,  and a third mirror to allow for interferometric detection of the liquid thickness with nanometer resolution and at thicknesses much smaller than the diffraction limit of the light. We conclude with a proof-of-concept measurement across dry nitrogen gas. The technique should prove useful for studying the properties of fluids confined at the nanoscale inside a slit-pore of controlled electrical potential or subject to applied electric fields.
1558	Performance Enhanced Flexible Terahertz Modulators Based on Graphene FET with Organic High-K Dielectric Coating Layer	Fabricating a graphene field-effect-transistor (GFET) on a Polyethylene- Terephthalate (PET) substrate gives rise to a flexible THz modulator with a unfulfilling modulation depth (MD) of 15~20%. In this work, we proposed a robust graphene modulating layer where the graphene monolayer is coated with a high-K dimethyl sulfoxide layer (DMSO). With this organic nano-coating the intrinsic MD of the GFET based THz modulator is significantly enhanced to ~40% while maintaining a low insert loss (IL) of 1.3dB. Adouble modulating-layers modulator with a MD of 70% and a multilevel modulator with 4 levels amplitude shift keying (ASK) modulation are also successfully realized. The large intrinsic MD, low IL, as well as its flexibility, render this enhanced modulator extremely versatile in fabrication of novel devices for nonplanar THz applications.
1559	<strong>Electrical properties of boron-incorporated ultrananocrystalline diamond/hydrogenated amorphous carbon composite films</strong>	Boron-incorporated ultrananocrystalline diamond/hydrogenated amorphous carbon composite (UNCD/a-C:H) films were deposited by coaxial arc plasma deposition with boron-blended graphite targets. The effects of boron incorporation on the electrical properties of the films were investigated by hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Their electrical conductivity increased from 10<sup>&minus;7</sup> to 10<sup>&minus;1</sup> &Omega;<sup>&minus;1</sup>&middot;cm<sup>&minus;1</sup> with increasing boron content up to 5 at.%. From the temperature dependence of electrical conductivity, hopping conduction due to localized states produced by boron atoms is predominant in carrier transport. X-ray photoelectron spectra showed the shifts of Fermi levels toward the top of valence band with increasing boron content. It implies that boron atoms in the films leads to form localized states, which results in enhanced electrical conductivity.
1560	An atomistic model for the charge distribution in layered MoS2	We present an atomistic model for predicting the distribution of doping electric charges in layered molybdenum disulfide (MoS2). This model mimics the charge around each ion as a net Gaussian-spatially-distributed charge plus an induced dipole, and is able to predict the distribution of doping charges in layered MoS2 in a self-consistent scheme. The profiles of doping charges in monolayer MoS2 flakes computed by this charge-dipole model are in good agreement with those obtained by density-functional-theory calculations. Using this model, we quantitatively predict the charge enhancement effect in MoS2 monolayer nanoribbons, with which strong ionic charge-localization effects are shown.
1561	Enhanced four-wave mixing in waveguides integrated with graphene oxide	We demonstrate enhanced four-wave mixing (FWM) in doped silica waveguides integrated with graphene oxide (GO). Owing to strong mode overlap between the integrated waveguides and GO films that have a high Kerr nonlinearity and low loss, the FWM efficiency of the hybrid integrated waveguides can be significantly improved. We perform FWM measurements for different pump powers, wavelength detuning, GO coating lengths, and number of GO layers. Our experimental results show good agreement with theory, achieving up to ~9.5-dB enhancement in the FWM conversion efficiency for a 1.5-cm-long waveguide integrated with 2 layers of GO. We show theoretically that for different waveguide geometries an even higher enhancement in FWM efficiency of ~20 dB can be obtained. Finally, we theoretically show that FWM in silicon waveguides (both thin nanowire and slot waveguides) incorporating GO films can be enhanced by more than 35 dB. This demonstrates the effectiveness of introducing GO films into integrated photonic devices in order to enhance the performance of nonlinear optical processes.
1562	Effects of Curing Temperature and Nanofillers on Mechanical and Piezoresistive Properties of PDMS/MWCNT Hybrid Films	In this study, the conductive polymer nanocomposites (CPNCs) of PDMS/MWCNT hybrid films were prepared using the layer-by-layer (LBL) production method. The sandwich-structured films containing an ultrathin layer of piezoresistive nanocomposite were manufactured by means of the vacuum filtration method. In order to apply this technique, a suspension of CNT particles was prepared and the piezoresistive nanocomposite was manufactured. In the following, the mechanical properties of both pure PDMS and PDMS/MWCNT nanocomposite were investigated using a tensile test and Dynamic-Mechanical Thermal Analysis (DMTA), and the results were discussed. Finally, the piezoresistive properties of the hybrid film, which contains an ultrathin layer of PDMS/MWCNT nanocomposite, were measured and the piezoresistive defects such as creep and hysteresis effects were investigated.
1563	<strong>Microstructural, vibrational, dielectric and ferroelectric properties correlation in hot-pressed PbMg<sub>1/3</sub>Nb<sub>2/3</sub>O<sub>3</sub> ceramics</strong>	Microstrctural, vibrational, ferroelectric and dielectric properties investigation reveals non-stoichiometric chemical ordered regions (CORs) and relaxor like dielectric characteristics in lead magnesium niobate (PMN) ceramics uniaxially hot pressed (HP) at 800 <sup>o</sup>C to 1200 <sup>o</sup>C. Occurance of (&frac12;&frac12;&frac12;) superlattice reflections along &lt;111&gt; in &lt;110&gt; zone axis SAED pattern as well as the presence of bright nano-meter regions in corresponding dark-field images in 800 <sup>o</sup>C hot pressed PMN demonstrates formation of the CORs as soon as perovskite phase is formed during calcination and remains unaffected with HP sintering tempreature. Lattice constant is observed to be invarint with HP sintering temperature. Separation between two broad peaks of Nb-O-Nb stretching mode is found to increase from 76.7 to 86.2 cm<sup>-1</sup> and the red-shift of O-B-O bending modes near 265 cm<sup>-1</sup> suggest an increase in the polar nano-size regions. Dielectric constant maximum (&epsilon;<sub>m</sub>) is increased from 8800 to 25000 and temperature of &epsilon;<sub>m</sub> (T<sub>m</sub>) is shifted from 278 K to 263 K with increasing average grain size from ~ 1.1 &mu;m to 2.8 &mu;m. Grain size dependence of the &epsilon;<sub>m</sub> and shifting of the T<sub>m</sub> towards lower temperature is correlated with core: shell thickness ratio calculated from the core-shell model. Increase in Grain and grain boundary resistances calculated from impedance spectroscopy and maximum polarization (P<sub>max</sub>) obtained from field induced polarization switching are consistent with the grain size analysis.
1564	The effect of Ti<sup>+</sup> ion implantation on the Anatase- Rutile Phase Transformation and Resistive Switching properties of TiO<sub>2</sub> thin films	We investigate here the structural phase transformation and electrical Resistive Switching (RS)<br />properties of TiO2 thin films (80 nm) after their self ion implantation with 50 keV Ti<sup>+</sup> ions at several<br />fluences. UV-Raman, GIXRD, TEM, XPS and AFM techniques have been utilized to investigate<br />the modifications in thin films. Both, the as-grown and ion implanted, films display mixed phases<br />of rutile (R) and anatase (A). Surprisingly, however, a phase transition from A to R is observed<br />at a critical fluence, where some anatase content transforms into rutile. Such ion beam induced<br />structural phase transformation has not been explored earlier in TiO2 thin films. This A to R<br />transformation increases with additional fluence. The critical fluence found by GIXRD is slightly<br />smaller (1&times;10<sup>13</sup> ions/cm<sup>2</sup>) than from UV-Raman (1&times;10<sup>14</sup> ions/cm<sup>2</sup>), indicating the first initiation<br />of phase transformation probably in bulk. All the films contain anatase in nanocrystalline form<br />also and the phase transformation seems to take place via aggregation of anatase nanoparticles.<br />Thin films also show the presence of oxygen vacancies (OV) Ti<sup>3+</sup>, whose number grow with fluence.<br />These OVs as well as thermal spikes created during Ti<sup>+</sup> ion implantation are also crucial for the<br />A-R transition. After implantation at the highest fluence, TiO<sub>2</sub> thin films show bipolar resistive<br />switching behavior. Development of conducting filament, formed by the migration of many oxygen<br />vacancies generated during ion implantation, can be responsible for this behavior.
1565	<strong>Perspective: Nanomaterials Design with High Pressure</strong>	The high pressure and high temperature phase diagrams of nanomaterials often differ significantly from their bulk parents offering novel approaches for the engineering of original materials. The importance or even the dominance of surface atoms in the nanoworld enhance the effects of the environment, geometry or even of intercalation if relevant. We explore the present knowledge and future opportunities of such effects on the high pressure phase diagrams of nanomaterials as nanocrystals, carbon nanotubes, fullerites, graphene and other 2D systems as well as nanoporous structures like clathrates or zeolites. Recent advances and future challenges in the use of extreme thermodynamic conditions to develop new functional nanomaterials, composites or devices will be reviewed together with the specificities of the experimental environment required for these investigations.
1566	Ion-implanted Silver Nanoparticles for Metal-Enhanced Fluorescence	Metal Enhanced Fluorescence (MEF) has promising applications in the field of optical displays, bio-sensing and photodynamic therapy. In this work, we exploit the plasmons of embedded silver nanoparticles (Ag NPs) fabricated by ion implantation to enhance the fluorescence of Coumarin515 dye (C515) via MEF. Ion Implantation of 70 keV Ag ions in quartz matrix at different fluences was carried out to synthesize Ag nanoparticles inside quartz matrix. The formation of Ag NPs is characterized by the optical absorption measurements and approximate sizes of Ag NPs was obtained from the fitting of the optical absorption spectra with Mie theory calculations. Rutherford Backscattering Spectrometry (RBS) measurement was used to obtain the depth profile and concentration Ag within the substrate. From the RBS results, it was determined that front edge of the layer containing Ag was formed at an average depth of 16 nm below the surface, which closely agreed with Stopping and Range of Ions in Matter (SRIM) calculations. Increase in the size of the NPs is observed as the fluence of the Ag within the substrate is increased. The MEF of drop casted C515 dye was studied using steady-state emission and excitation spectra measurements. Fluorescence enhancement factor ranging from 1.0 to 2.1 with a maximum enhancement for the largest size NP was obtained. The observed MEF was ascribed to a combination of plasmon enhancement with larger nanoparticles and to increased plasmonic hot spots.
1567	Multiphysics rectification of light and heat using liquid crystal	The detection and treatment of signals, as optical and thermal ones, are crucial for many relevant applications. Employing nanostructured metamaterials to design broken spatial inversion symmetry devices it were created interesting rectifiers, as  optical and thermal diodes.  However, such devices are monophysics, rectifying only one kind of energy. Here we show a multiphysics diode that rectifies simultaneously light and heat. It consists of a capillary tube keeping a nematic liquid crystal that holds an escaped radial disclination: an axial asymmetric defect the spontaneously arises in cylindrical cavities. Using the properties of the 5CB liquid crystal, we numerically measured thermal and optical rectifications of, respectively, 3.5\% and 120\%, comparable to carbon nanotube thermal diodes and  photonic-crystal-based optical diodes. From thermal, shape and molecular studies developed in this work, we concluded low working heat flux eases both optical and thermal rectifications, miniaturizing the multiphysics diodes favors thermal and disfavors optical rectifications, and both rectifications has different optimal molecular configurations. We believe the presented multiphysics diode can contribute to save materials,  increase information processed,   miniaturize complex systems and develop new structured devices.
1568	Multi-scale study of the deformation mechanisms of thermoelectric p-type half-Heusler Hf<sub>0.44</sub>Zr<sub>0.44</sub>Ti<sub>0.12</sub>CoSb<sub>0.8</sub>Sn<sub>0.2</sub>	Increasing the figure of merit ZT of thermoelectric (TE) alloys is a challenge that is currently attempted through various metallurgy methods, including nanostructuring and dislocation engineering. Microstructures with such level of complexity raises questions about the mechanical reliability of these new materials. Indeed, despite the values of hardness and elastic modulus known for the clear majority of TE materials, the data on deformation mechanisms are still rare. Focusing on the nanostructured p-type half-Heusler Hf<sub>0.44</sub>Zr<sub>0.44</sub>Ti<sub>0.12</sub>CoSb<sub>0.8</sub>Sn<sub>0.2</sub>, our multi-scale study aims to analyze the deformation mechanisms. Experiments conducted at macro-, meso- and micro-scale are designed to trigger and assess plasticity mechanisms. Compression testing on bulk samples subject to a confining pressure environment and temperature leads to an exclusive brittle failure. The mixed-mode failure mechanisms involve switching between intra- and inter-granular crack propagation, depending on the grain size met by the crack tip. Indentation toughness at meso-scale generates cracks, while TEM analysis of the crack tip area confirms no dislocation activity and 3D-EBSD technique confirms the mixed crack propagation behavior. At micro-scale, micro-pillar compression stress-strain curves and failure mechanisms are comparable with bulk samples testing analysis. These results can be used to provide design guidelines for more crack-resistant TE alloys.
1569	<strong>Hydrophobic Magnetorheological Suspension</strong>	We developed hydrophobic magnetorheological suspensions with improved stability against gravity. The space-spanning particle network arising from hydrophobic aggregation is responsible for this enhancement. The hydrophobic effect in the presence of field is overcome by decreasing amount of hydrophobic particles or the addition of magnetic nanoparticle leaving magnetorheological suspension a considerable magnetorheological response. This work emphasizes the advantage of hydrophobic force in control of sedimentation stability without the need for any anti-setting additive.
1570	<strong>Plasmonic&ndash;magnetic dual-functional graded nanoparticles with oxide shell passivation designed for bioapplications</strong>	Plasmonic&ndash;magnetic dual-functional nanoparticles with a graded structure in which plasmonic silver (Ag) and ferromagnetic iron-cobalt-platinum alloy (FeCoPt) components were mixed at the atomic level with a composition gradient were chemically synthesized. The surfaces of the nanoparticles were uniformly covered with iron oxide (Fe<em><sub>x</sub></em>O<em><sub>y</sub></em>). The resulting nanoparticles possessed a graded core/oxide shell structure and unique physical properties. In addition, the surfaces of the nanoparticles were biotinylated to enhance their versatility for use in various bioapplications such as bioimaging, biosensing, immunodiagnosis, and hyperthermia<em>.</em>
1571	Crucial role of electron correlation for conductance of &#xF070;-conjugated wires: a generalized tight-binding model	We propose to use the quasi-correlated tight-binding (QCTB) pi-approximation for treating single molecule electronics problems and demonstrate its advantages. Previously, this generalized tight-binding (TB) method has been elaborated for describing effectively unpaired electrons and other properties of large-scale bipartite (alternant) networks. Here, we construct a one-electron Green's function matrix (Greenian) at the QCTB level, and present analytic solutions for finite-size polyene chains and other conjugated molecules. The simplified wide band limit model is assumed in most formal and numerical computations. We give an efficient computational scheme which incorporates the bipartite symmetry of effective pi-electron Hamiltonians we construct. The known selection rule for electric conductance in bipartites is extended to take into account the imaginary part of Greenians. It is shown that even a very simple inclusion of pi-electron correlation effects removes specific quantum interference nodes (antiresonances) which occur within the standard tight-binding (TB) model. Systematic computations of the Greenian matrices at the full configuration interaction (FCI) level confirm this prediction about instability of the TB Greenian nodes with respect to more advanced theories. We find that QCTB results are frequently not numerically accurate compared to FCI. Nevertheless, in qualitative and quantitative terms QCTB, performed with the same ease as TB, provides an essential advance over TB. As an example of using QCTB for large systems we analyze conductance spectra in graphene nanoflakes. In particular, we show that 'zigzag' connections can afford significantly higher electron transmission than 'armchair' connections.
1572	Selective Activation of an Isolated Magnetic Skyrmion in the Ferromagnetic Background with Microwave Electric Fields	We theoretically reveal that pure eigenmodes of an isolated magnetic skyrmion in the ferromagnetic background can be selectively activated using microwave electric fields, without exciting gigantic ferromagnetic resonances, in contrast to conventional methods using microwave magnetic fields. We also demonstrate that this selective activation of a skyrmion can drive its translational motion in the ferromagnetic nanotrack efficiently under an external magnetic field inclined from the normal direction. It is found that a mode with combined breathing and rotational oscillations induces much faster propagation than the breathing mode studied previously by Wang $et$ $al.$ [Phys. Rev. B {\bf 92}, 020403(R) (2015)].
1573	Optically Modulated Electric Synapses Realized with Memristors Based on ZnO Nanorods	Artificial synapses based on compact nanodevices are indispensable building blocks for implementing artificial neural networks in hardware. In this work, we demonstrate optically modulated artificial synapses realized with ZnO nanorods. These artificial synapses advance preceding memristive synapses with regard to the ability of response to not only electric but also optical modulation. The high surface state densities of the ZnO nanorods endow the present device with high photoresponse, resulting in the optical encryption effect, while the subsequent decryption can be realized by applying electric pulses. The optical encryption and electrical decryption functions provide a novel concept to process massive data for artificial neural networks. Moreover, with the aid of the optical modulation, new methods are opened up for future optically-tuned synaptic devices for secured communications.
1574	Glass Fracture by Focusing of Laser-Generated Nanosecond Surface Acoustic Waves	Dynamic fracture of borosilicate glass through focusing of high-amplitude nanosecond surface acoustic waves (SAWs) at the micron scale is investigated in an all-optical experiment. SAWs are generated by an intense picosecond laser excitation pulse focused into a ring-shaped spot on the sample surface. Interferometric imaging of the sample surface with a femtosecond probe pulse allows quantitative measurement of the vertical surface displacements. Images taken at different pump-probe delays capture the SAW as it converges towards the center, focuses, and subsequently diverges. The amplitude of the SAW is varied by changing the laser excitation energy. Above a certain laser excitation energy threshold, a damage at the acoustic focal point is observed. A post-mortem investigation reveals a crater formed by the ejection of a piece of material. Numerical calculations matching the measured surface displacement profiles help us determine the time evolution of the stress distribution in the sample and at the acoustic focus. We find that the glass withstands a nanosecond local tensile stress of at least 6 GPa without visible fracture, which is well above the tensile limit observed in conventional shock spallation experiments.
1575	PROBING ELASTIC PROPERTIES OF NANOWIRE-BASED STRUCTURES	We report the analysis of elastic properties of a composite medium consisting of GaN nanowires embedded into a dielectric matrix, which constitutes the active material of nanowire-based piezogenerators. A non-invasive technique, Transient Grating Method, is used to generate and analyse the propagation of acoustic waves in the frequency range from a few tens of MHz to several GHz. Effective elastic moduli of the composite anisotropic material are restored then via the minimization of the discrepancy between the measured and calculated wave characteristics. The latter are simulated using the time-efficient computer model based on the explicit integral and asymptotic representations of laser-generated surface acoustic waves in layered anisotropic waveguides. The method adapts the Green's matrix formalism to the laminated composite medium under consideration. A comparison with a reference composed of a dielectric matrix without nanowires shows that the mechanical behavior is strongly influenced by the presence of the nanostructures.
1576	<strong>Exploration of the adsorption behaviors of group-IV tin nanotubes from DFT computations: A search for superior SO<sub>2</sub> gas sensors</strong>	The structural and electronic properties of the pristine and SO<sub>2</sub> adsorbed buckled tin nanotubes were investigated using the density functional theory calculations. The effects of SO<sub>2</sub> gas adsorption on the electronic structure of the nanotubes were analyzed in detail. SO<sub>2</sub> molecule was initially positioned on the armchair and zigzag stanene based nanotubes with orientations through both interacting sulfur and oxygen sites. The results suggest that the considered armchair nanotubes have direct band gaps at the K point, which indicate the semiconductor characteristics of these nanotubes, making them efficient candidates for gas sensing applications. Moreover, the considered (9, 0) and (10, 0) zigzag nanotubes exhibit also semiconductor behavior. Among the armchair nanotubes, the adsorption energy of SO<sub>2</sub> molecule on the (8, 8) armchair nanotube is the highest (most negative) of all, representing that SO<sub>2</sub> interaction with (8, 8) nanotube is energetically most favorable. The adsorption energy slightly increases with increasing the nanotube diameter. Besides, the adsorption of SO<sub>2</sub> molecule on the nanotube surface through its oxygen atoms is more favorable in energy than the adsorption by its central sulfur atom. The projected density of states of the interacting Sn and oxygen atoms show the formation of chemical bonds between these atoms, as evidenced by the increment of electronic density at the middle of the newly formed bonds predicted by charge density difference (CDD) calculations. Based on CDD calculations, we found the charge accumulation on the adsorbed SO<sub>2</sub> molecule, which indicates that SO<sub>2</sub> acts as a charge acceptor.
1577	In an Ionic Liquid, High Local Friction is Determined by the Proximity to the Charge Network	Structural heterogeneity in ionic liquids is to a large extent defined by nanoscale apolar pockets that act as spacers between strings of positive and negative charges that alternate. In contrast to this, recent work from our group and that of others appear to indicate that dynamic, energetic and mechanical heterogeneities are governed by the charged part of the liquid. In this article we study the dynamics of methane, a small apolar solute in the family of Ionic Liquids (ILs) s1-Alkyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide (Im1,n/NTf2-), with n=2, 4, 8 at temperatures that make the viscosity for each liquid similar and around 8 cP. We do this in an attempt to equalize the effect of the solvent on the dynamics of the solute. In all cases, we find that solute proximity to charge-enhanced regions coincides with translationally caged regimes (high local friction) whereas the opposite is true in charge-depleted regions. In a way, these ILs behave like a liquid within a liquid where the charge network is the high friction component.
1578	<strong>Flexible Graphene Composites with High Thermal Conductivity for Heat Dissipation in High Power LEDs</strong>	Multifunctional flexible graphene composites (FGCs) have been fabricated by using a mold-casting method. The acrylic co-polymers matrix of FGCs has an elastic modulus in the range of 18-68 MPa and high mechanical strength suitable for heat dissipation for lighting applications. Scanning electron microscopy images show that the graphene nanoplatelets in the FGCs coalesce in the through-plane direction, enhance their thermal conductivity by increasing the inter-sheet contacts among graphene nanoplatelets, and reduce the defects and grain boundaries. The heat dissipation properties of the FGCs were compared with these for aluminum heat sinks. For this, the operating temperature in the emitting area of a high-power UV-LED was measured as a function of the weight for each type of heat sink. Experiments on LEDs demonstrated that the FGCs with masses of 4.9 g and 5.5 g cooled down the hottest points on the LEDs at similar temperatures observed when the LED is operating on an aluminum heat sink with mass of 565 g. The heat dissipation results demonstrated that the FGCs could be used as compact and lightweight heat sinks for high power LEDs employed as lighting sources.
1579	Structural dynamics of LaVO3 on the nanosecond time scale	Due to the strong dependence of electronic properties on the local bonding environment, a full characterization of the structural dynamics in ultrafast experiments is a critical. Here we report the dynamics and complete structural refinement at nanosecond time scales of a perovskite thin film by combining optical excitation with time-resolved X-ray diffraction. This is achieved by monitoring the temporal response of both integer and half-integer diffraction peaks of LaVO3 in response to an above-band-gap 800 nm pump pulse. We find that the lattice expands by 0.1% out of plane, and the relaxation is characterized by a biexponential decay with 2 ns and 12 ns time scales. We analyze the relative intensity change of half-integer peaks and show that the distortions to the substructure are small: the oxygen octahedral rotation angles decrease by &#xF07E;0.3&#x00BA; and La displacements decrease by ~0.2 pm, which directly corresponds to a ~0.8{degree sign} increase in the V-O-V bond-angles, an in-plane V-O bond length reduction of ~0.3 pm, and an unchanged out-of-plane bond length. This provides experimentally accessible values for structural and electronic tunability in this class of materials.
1580	<strong>     Thermoelectric properties of nanostructured bismuth telluride (Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub>) with annealing time and its composite with reduced graphene oxide (RGO)</strong>	In the present work, thermoelectric performance of EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) assisted bismuth telluride (Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub>), prepared by hydrothermal technique has been investigated. The samples after preparation are annealed in vacuum chamber at 100<sup>0</sup> C for 6 hours and 10 hours to compare its properties with sample without annealing. The results show that the materials are nanocrystalline in nature, having rhombohedral lattice structure with preferred orientation along (015) direction. Lattice parameters from Rietveld refinement shows that &lsquo;a&rsquo; decreases while &lsquo;c&rsquo; increases with annealing time for Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub>. Thermoelectric performance of the samples improve significantly with annealing time by one order of magnitude. These observations are in tune with the presence of antisite defects where Bi lattice sites are occupied by excess Te. Composites of Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> with reduced graphene oxide (RGO) (1 &amp; 3 wt%) (10 h) have been prepared and characterized to investigate thermoelectric performance. For Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub>- RGO (1 wt%) composite, a maximum value of ZT (0.29), higher than Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3,</sub> at room temperature is obtained due to increase in electrical conductivity of the composites.
1581	Y-doping TiO2 compact layer for efficient perovskite solar cells	To improve the electron transporting and suppress the charge recombination between the interface of TiO2/perovskite, a smooth and compact Y-doping TiO2 compact layer was successfully prepared by hydrolysis-pyrolysis method using an acidic titanium isopropoxide solution in isopropanol and yttrium chloride hexahydrate (YCl3&#x2022;6H2O) was used as the yttrium source. The influence of Y-doping on the microstructure, crystal phase, chemical composition, optical absorption of the TiO2 compact layer was investigated. And the electron transporting and charge recombination in the TiO2/perovskite interface of the corresponding solar cells were systemically analyzed. The planar perovskite solar cells based on the Y-doping TiO2 compact layer with a Y/Ti molar ratio of 5% obtained a photoelectric conversion efficieny (PCE) of 15.22%, while the undoped perovskite solar cells gave a PCE of 14.05%. When the 200-nm length TiO2 nanorod array was introduced between the 5% Y-doping TiO2 electron transporting layer and the perovskite thin film, the corresponding perovskite solar cells achieved a PCE of 18.32% under illumination of simulated AM 1.5 sunlight (100 mA&#x2022;cm-2).
1582	<strong>Conductive tail-to-tail domain walls in epitaxial BiFeO<sub>3</sub> films</strong>	The complex conductive behavior of ferroelectric domain walls is attracting more and more attention for its potential application as an independent nanoelectronic component. For the (001) epitaxial BiFeO<sub>3</sub> films, we find that the domain wall conductivity is various among 71&deg; domain walls, with tail-to-tail (T-T) domain walls more conductive than head-to-head (H-H) and head-to-tail (H-T) ones. Furthermore, it is observed that most of the conductive areas are composed by two parallel lines around the T-T domain walls. These experimental results can be well simulated by our newly-developed theoretical model based on the polarization configuration and a tunneling mechanism. Our work will help to understand the mechanism of domain wall conductance in materials and further promote the usage of domain walls in advanced nano-devices.
1583	A Hierarchical Approach to Chemical and Aggregate Equilibria	A new paradigm is presented to describe and quantify chemical equilibria.  The approach is especially useful for reactions yielding a quasi-continuous size distribution such as aggregation or polymerization.  The mean aggregation number &lt;N&gt;i is the central quantifying parameter where i is an index for the structural level in a hierarchical model. The change in Gibbs free energy for aggregation (or polymerization) is given by &#x2206;G2=-RT ln&#x2061;&#x3016;(1/&lt;N&gt;2)&#x3017;. Rather than postulating the equilibrium of chemical potentials as the starting point, the ansatz relies on a differential equation expressing the balance between subunit dissociation/association and the concentration of free particles. From this consideration a series of relations are derived, among others, the underlying thermodynamic pseudo-potential/chemical potential of the association/dissociation process. The compatibility of the approach with previous results like the law of mass action or the Clausius-Clapeyron equation is demonstrated. Discrete distributions in the degree of aggregation as well as quasi-continuous distributions can be elegantly derived and can be connected to the respective free energies. The work concludes with example calculations for a micellar and a colloidal pigment nano-particle system.
1584	Raman analysis of strain in p-type doped silicon nanostructures	In this work, 100 nm-thick boron-doped silicon beams with doping levels between 1&middot;10<sup>16</sup> and 1&middot;10<sup>20</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup> undergoing uniaxial tensile strain are investigated by Raman spectroscopy. The structures exhibit a noticeable reduction in Young&rsquo;s modulus (~20%) compared with the value reported for bulk. The traditional Raman shift coefficients used to determine stress and strain in bulk structures are revised and appropriate corrections are implemented to account for the observed changes in Young&rsquo;s modulus. Interestingly, the Raman shift-strain relation in silicon nanostructures with strain along the [110] direction is found to be independent of size effects and doping. In contrast, the Raman shift-stress relation is found to be highly dependent on size effects. The dependency of the Fano line-shape parameters, used to fit the Raman first order peak in structures with high levels of doping, with strain is also reported. The results are shown to be crucial to accurately determine stress and strain from Raman measurements in doped silicon nanostructures and devices with size effects.
1585	Scanning Frequency Comb Microscopy--A new method in Scanning Probe Microscopy	We generate a microwave frequency comb having hundreds of measurable harmonics by focusing a mode-locked ultrafast laser on the tunneling junction of a scanning tunneling microscope having a metal sample. These harmonics, which are at integer multiples of the laser pulse-repetition frequency, are generated by optical rectification due to the nonlinear current-voltage characteristics of the tunneling junction. With resistive samples the harmonics are attenuated due to loading by the addition of the spreading resistance. At each value of the sample resistivity the microwave power is maximum at a different value of the tip-sample distance. This distance may be obtained by using different pairs of values for the applied DC bias and the DC tunneling current. Furthermore, with no applied DC bias, the same microwave power is obtained at the same tip-sample distance when this distance is determined by maximizing the microwave power as the criterion for feedback control. Using this criterion, in place of maintaining a specified set-point tunneling current as in scanning tunneling microscopy, offers the possibility of obtaining finer resolution in the tip-sample distance and greater stability with resistive samples. This new procedure may enable nondestructive measurement of the carrier profile of semiconductors with true sub-nanometer resolution, which is required as the semiconductor industry progresses to the sub-nanometer lithography nodes. It may also enable measurements with fragile 2-D materials such as graphene.
1586	<strong>Nuclear and magnetic small-angle neutron scattering in self-organizing nanostructured Fe<sub>1&#x2012;<em>x</em></sub>Cr<em><sub>x</sub></em> alloys</strong>	Small-angle neutron scattering (SANS) in self-organizing nanostructured Fe<sub>1&#x2012;<em>x</em></sub>Cr<em><sub>x</sub></em> (<em>x</em>=0.21, 0.43 and 0.53) alloys has been studied. The relation between the nuclear (<em>I<sub>N</sub></em>(<em>Q</em>)) and the magnetic (<em>I<sub>M</sub></em>(<em>Q</em>)) contributions depends on the alloy composition and the extent of self-organizing due to phase separation (PS). When PS is pronounced with a large concentration fluctuation amplitude, the two scattering contributions are identical, whereas when the concentration fluctuation amplitude is very small, <em>I<sub>M</sub></em>(<em>Q</em>) is negligible compared to <em>I<sub>N</sub></em>(<em>Q</em>). The relation between the scattering signals is critical when assessing PS in Fe<sub>1&#x2012;<em>x</em></sub>Cr<em><sub>x</sub></em> alloys by SANS, which has been mostly ignored in prior works in the literature.
1587	Highly sensitive detection of photo-thermal transient stress by a sub-nanosecond pump probe with surface plasmon resonance	Photoacoustic microscopy (PAM) has attracted increasing attention for non-invasive functional imaging in biomedicine and biomedical studies. The surface plasmon resonance (SPR) sensor is a potential acoustical detector with high sensitivity and wide bandwidth for use in high-resolution 3D PAM. In this study, we investigated a simple Kretschmann SPR sensor, demonstrating highly sensitive stress detection in the sub-nanosecond timescale by directly inducing photo-thermal transient stress. To do this, we designed and used a sub-nanosecond pump probe system. The SPR sensor clearly detected the transient response from the thermal elastic effect, while a simple pump-probe sensor without SPR did not detect it. Our experimental results demonstrate a simple SPR sensor that can detect stress with high sensitivity and sub-nanosecond time resolution. This technique could be used in high-resolution 3D PAM by mounting a small biomedical sample on the sensor.
1588	<strong>Graphene-based &lsquo;hybrid&rsquo; aerogels with carbon nanotubes: </strong><strong>Mesoporous network</strong><strong>-</strong><strong>functionality promoted defect density and </strong><strong>electrochemical activity correlations </strong>	Electrochemical activity of graphene and graphene-based &lsquo;hybrid&rsquo; nanomaterials is crucial for energy and water sustainability applications, which requires delicate control over its geometric and electronic structures. We demonstrate that precise control of the density of defects, hierarchical porosity, and topological interconnectedness, invoked in hydrothermally synthesized graphene aerogel integrated with multi-walled carbon nanotubes that can finely tune morphology, structure, defect density and enhance the electrochemical heterogeneous electron transfer rate (k<sub>ET</sub>). We prepared a range of three-dimensional graphene-based &lsquo;hybrid&rsquo; scaffolds (or aerogels) and their nitrogenated equivalents with varying graphene-carbon nanotube compositions using two schemes (approach 1 and 2). This study allows us to correlate quantitatively between number defect density (<em>via</em> Raman spectroscopy; RS) and heterogeneous electron transfer rate (<em>via</em> scanning electrochemical microscopy; SECM). RS provided microscale structural characterization revealing localized vibrations. The first- and second-order Raman bands are analyzed in terms of band position, intensity ratio and integrated intensity determining structural disorder, inter defect distance, number defect density. The role of oxygenated (carbonyl; C=O, carboxyl; -COOH) and nitrogenated (pryridinic-N and graphitic/pyrrolic-N) surface functionalities and bonding configurations besides hierarchical mesoporosity are emphasized for understanding the improved physicochemical properties. The defect-induced increase in finite electronic density of states (DOS) near Fermi level calculated using density functional theory (DFT) helped in establishing moderate defect density for enhanced heterogeneous rate as a critical state such that the whole system becomes electronically activated while maintained structural integrity (sp<sup>2</sup> network). Moreover, it enlarges the overlap between DOS for graphene-based aerogels and redox probe, which signifies experimental correlation establishments.
1589	<strong>Dynamic behavior of droplets under interfacial jamming of nanoparticles</strong>	Interfacial particle jamming is known for locking a droplet in a non-spherical shape; however, the effects of jamming on the dynamic behaviors of droplets are not well known. In this paper, droplet impact dynamics are studied on a mechanically weak superhydrophobic surface whose outer nanoparticles (NPs) were detached by the impinging droplet and jammed at the droplet surface during retraction. The jamming degree was enhanced by increasing the impinging velocity, and unusual parachute-like droplet shapes manifested increasingly clearly at the rebounding moments. Likewise, oscillation prohibition, bounce damping, and final deformation were each enhanced with an increase in velocity. The critical impinging velocity for final deformation was much smaller than that required to generate complete droplet coverage, indicating that considerable local jamming was sufficient to generate droplet deformation.
1590	KdV Acoustic Structure with Exchange-Correlation Potential in Plasmas	The effects of exchange-correlation potential(ECP) on the profile of dust acoustic solitary waves (DASWs) in degenerate dusty plasmas has been investigated. The plasmassystem is consisting upon three species such as degenerate ions and electrons, andsclassical dust grains. This study is comprising upon the linear and nonlinear analysissof long wavelength dust acoustic waves in non-relativistic plasmas. The linear acoustic wave have been analyzed by using the multi-fluid model whereas to study smallsamplitude DASWs, modified Korteweg de Vries (KdV) equation has been derived bysusing the reductive perturbation theory. The effects of dust concentration (Havenesssparameter h) in the plasma, and exchange correlation potential have been highlighted.sThe dust concentration and exchange correlation potential affect the solitary wavesamplitude and its width remarkably. Our results can be used to understand the characteristics of nonlinear electrostatic waves exciting in a dense degenerate Fermi gas,spresent in metallic nano structures or presumably in near-supernova environments,sin the presence of massive charged defects.
1591	Predicting Stability of Nano-Fin Arrays Against Collapse by Phase Field Modeling	Silicon nano-fin arrays serve as fundamental components of modern field-effect transistor devices. However, during the fabrication process of the fin patterns, collapse is often observed, but a full understanding on it has not been achieved yet. Here, we study the mechanisms of this pattern collapse phenomenon by phase field simulations coupled with elasticity. Along one given deformation path of the nano-beam, we are able to track the free energy change, recognize the saddle configuration, and estimate the associated energy barrier for failure. Our simulation results capture the fin arrays transiting from being stable, to meta-stable, to unstable against collapse, with increasing aspect ratio. The model predicts that the structure is more stabilized when reducing the liquid wettability. In addition, from the free energy landscape, we identify the minimum energy path (MEP) for pattern collapse taking place in the presence of liquid evaporation. These findings improve our knowledge on pattern collapse and provide useful guidelines for designing synthesis pathways of stable fin structures.
1592	Powder consolidation of nanocomposite Nd-Fe-B magnets by cold deformation process	High-pressure torsion (HPT) was applied to nanocomposite Nd-Fe-B magnet for the following two purposes. The first is to obtain anisotropic nanocomposite magnets by development of deformation texture, and the second is to consolidate bulk magnets directly from powder compacts without sintering process.
