Although no texturing occurred in this set of experiments, the consolidation was successful and increased the relative density up to 90% of a nanocomposite magnet having the coercivity <em>H</em><sub>c</sub> = 4.4 kOe and the remanence/saturation magnetization <em>&sigma;</em><sub>r</sub>/<em>&sigma;</em><sub>sat</sub> =100/165 emu/g. The shear strain gradient generated in a disc after HPT allowed us to discuss a relationship between shear strain and porosity, as well as the significance of shear in densification process.
1593	<strong>A molecular dynamics simulation of thermal bubble nucleation confined in graphene nanochannels</strong>	Molecular dynamics (MD) simulationsare carried out to simulate thermal bubble nucleation processes in homogeneous and heterogeneous systems, respectively. It is found that the nucleation temperature of water confined in a graphene nanochanneldepends strongly on the channel height in a nanoscale heterogeneous system. Once a channel height is reduced below 3nm, the nucleation temperature in the heterogeneous system is higher than that in the corresponding homogeneous systems, which violates the classical nucleation theory that homogeneous thermal bubble nucleation sets an upper limit for nucleation temperature under a given pressure. The abnormal phenomenon is attributed to the formation of solid-like structure for the water confined in a nanochannel, in which the whole water system has a lower potential energy than that in the corresponding homogenous system. Decreasing or increasing the solid liquid interaction strength may reduce or increase the nucleation temperature, which can explain the nucleation temperature dependent on surface properties in various heterogeneous systems.
1594	Explosion of the thick metallic surface during ultrafast rise of a multimegagauss magnetic field	The technique of producing a multimegagauss magnetic field on the surface of a cylindrical conductor with a rise time of less than one nanosecond has been proposed and examined experimentally on a high-current generator with a peak current of about 2 MA. In experiments in the conductor region, a plasma with a density of 10^16-10^17 cm^-3 is preliminarily injected. The fast increase of the magnetic field on the conductor surface is realized, as the J&#x00D7;B force sweeps up the injected plasma in the axial and radial directions. It has been observed that such a high-rise rate of the field is accompanied by an explosion of the current skin layer with the formation of a surface layer of a dense high-temperature plasma and a powerful pulse of soft x-ray radiation.
1595	<strong>Scalability and wide temperature range operation of spin-orbit torque switching devices using Co/Pt multilayer nanowires<sup></sup></strong>	Spin-orbit torque (SOT) switching and retention properties in Co/Pt multilayer nanowire structures with various widths <em>w</em> down to 20 nm and the temperature dependences of the performance in the nanowire device with <em>w</em> = 20 nm are studied. Switching current <em>I</em><sub>sw</sub> scales down as <em>w</em> is reduced. The nanowire devices show high thermal stability factor <em>&Delta;</em> &gt; 100 for all the widths at room temperature. In the 20-nm-wide device, while a magnetization can be switched by current from -50 to 125&deg;C with a marginal increase in <em>I</em><sub>sw</sub> as the temperature decreases, <em>&Delta;</em> of more than 100 is kept up to 125&deg;C. These results indicate that SOT-switching devices using Co/Pt multilayers are scalable in nanoscale dimensions and can operate over a wide range of temperatures, offering high potential for a wide variety of applications including automobile and aerospace.
1596	Magneto-Maxwell nanofluid in von K&#x00E1;rm&#x00E1;n swirling flow with nonlinear radiative heat flux and chemical reaction	We study the impact of Arrhenius chemical reaction with activation energy and nonlinear thermal radiations in von K&#x00E1;rm&#x00E1;n swirling flow of Maxwell nanofluid over a rotating stretchable disk. The influence of magnetic field is studied by applying it perpendicular to the disk rotation. Brownian motion and thermophoresis features are incorporated due to nanoparticles utilizing Buongiorno model. Further, the characteristics of non-linear thermal radiations on heat transfer mechanism are studied in view of Rosseland approximation model. The mass transfer analysis is inspected by employing the binary chemical reaction with activation energy. Similarity hypotheses is performed to facilitate the solution of governing momentum, energy and concentration equations. The transformed non-linear equations are attempted numerically by using bvp midrich scheme in Maple software for visualizing the influence of governing parameters graphically and numerically. The major outcomes of present analysis reveal that fluid temperature is enhanced with growing radiation parameter. Solute concentration is an increasing function of activation energy parameter. Moreover, the reaction rate diminishes the solute concentration.
1597	Engineering of the Resistive Switching Properties in V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> Thin Film by Atomic Structural Transition: Experiment and Theory	Bipolar resistive switching has been reported in ITO/V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>/ITO structures. Synthesized from sol-gel process, the nanostructured V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>&middot;<em>n</em>H<sub>2</sub>O xerogel thin film endures significant structural transition during the post annealing step. The impact of structural transition of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> film on the resistive switching properties is studied in this work. The switching voltage decreases from 6.5 V to 3.0 V when the annealing temperature increases from 220&#x02DA;C to 280&#x02DA;C, and then increases up to 5.0 V at 350&#x02DA;C. Above annealing temperature of 350&#x02DA;C, the reversible switching characteristics disappears. Thermogravimetric measurement show that intercalated H<sub>2</sub>O molecules fully evaporate above 350&#x02DA;C. X-ray diffraction shows that the xerogel phase gradually vanishes as the annealing temperature increases, and only &#x237A;-V<sub>2</sub>O&shy;<sub>5</sub> and &szlig;-V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> exist at high annealing temperatures. Ab initio simulations are performed to evaluate the formation energies of oxygen vacancy in xerogel, &#x237A;-V<sub>2</sub>O&shy;<sub>5</sub> and &szlig;-V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> phases. The results are in good agreement with the experiments: the formation energy of oxygen vacancy is significantly lower in xerogel than in &#x237A;-V<sub>2</sub>O&shy;<sub>5</sub> and &szlig;-V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub>, enabling the occurrence of reversible switching when xerogel phase exists in the sandwich structure.
1598	A versatile apparatus for fermionic lithium quantum gases based on ansinterference-filter laser system	We report on the design and construction of a versatile setup for experiments with ultracold lithium (Li) gases. We discuss our methods to prepare an atomic beam and laser cool it in a Zeeman slower and subsequent magneto-optical trap, which rely on established methods. We focus on our laser system based on a stable interference-filter-stabilized, linear-extended-cavity diode laser, so far unreported for lithium wavelengths. Moreover, we describe our optical setup to combine various laser frequencies for cooling, manipulation and detetction of Li atoms. We characterize the performance of our system preparing degnerate samples of Li atoms via forced evaporation in a hybrid crossed-beam optical-dipole trap plus confining magnetic trap. Our apparatus allows to produce quantum gases of N &#x2248; 10<sup>5</sup>...10<sup>6</sup> fermionic lithium-6 atoms at nanokelvin temperatures in cycle times below 10 seconds. Our optical system is particularly suited to study the dynamics of fermionic superfluids in engineered optical potentials.
1599	Irreversibility analysis of the three dimensional flow of carbon nanotubes due to nonlinear thermal radiation and quartic chemical reactions	In this work, three dimensional flow of a fluctuating nanofluid is examined in moving (rotating) coordinates. Carbon nanotubes (MWCNT / SWCNT) are taken as nanoparticles whereas water is considered as the base fluid. Xue's model for effective thermal conductivity (carbon nanotube-based composite) is utilized. Entropy generation is analyzed in the presence of both homogeneous and heterogeneous mass concentrations. The dimensionless variables are introduced to obtain the dimensionless form of the boundary layer equations along with the entropy augmentation equation. Equations are then solved using an explicit scheme based on the finite differences, and the behavior of the entropy augmentation, Bejan number and temperature is elaborated. The effects of various dimensionless parameters such as Reynolds number, Brinkman number and radiation parameter on the entropy augmentation rate, and Bejan number are presented graphically for MWCNTs and SWCNTs. Variation in the engineering coefficients ( Nusselt number, skin friction, Sherwood number) are shown with various emerging parameters for MWCNTs and SWCNTs. It is found that the entropy augmentation rate can be controlled by minimizing the action of the Brinkman and Reynolds numbers. The results also reveal that the heat transfer (rate) is bigger for SWCNTs in relation to MWCNTs.
1600	Frequency temporal variation of electromagnetic pulse radiation produced in a high intensity laser-solid interaction	In this paper we present a time-frequency analysis approach for electromagnetic pulses (EMP) generated by a high power laser interaction. To resolve not only the frequency components of the signal but also how they vary temporally, a scanning time window moving across the signal is used within which a fast Fourier transform is performed. The optimum period of this scanning window varies with frequency and we describe how this can be varied for signals containing frequency components ranging from the megahertz to gigahertz. This approach is then applied to experimental data and shows the megahertz components arise tens of nanoseconds after the laser interaction compared to the prompt gigahertz frequencies.
1601	Synthesis,structural characterization and electrochemical performance of x%Li<sub>4</sub>Ti<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> / (1-x)%TiO2 Nano composites for lithium ion batteries<strong></strong>	<strong>Abstract:</strong>In-situ dual phase x%Li<sub>4</sub>Ti<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub>/(1-x)%TiO<sub>2</sub> (with x=30,40,60,70) Nano-composites were synthesized by sol-gel using molar ratio Li:Ti=4.5:6 by varying heating temperature. TGA/DSC studies of dried uncalcined gel with Li:Ti=4.5:6 indicated the formation of LTO/TO phases around 600&ordm;C to 800&ordm;C. TGA/DSC of calcined powder at 600&ordm;C/5h exhibited structural stability of the LTO/TO phase at heat treatment of up to 800&ordm;C. XRDs exhibited varying wt%. of LTO:TO due to varying heat treatments of the same dried gel with Li:Ti=4.5:6. Composites of LTO with TiO<sub>2</sub> showed reduced band gaps and predicted increased electronic conductivity of the samples for enhanced electrochemical performance as anodes of Li-ion batteries. XPS showed that in both LTO and LTO/TO nanocomposites, Ti cations are in the oxidation state of 4+, indicating the charge neutrality and suitability for oxidation/reduction reactions during Li-ion intercalation/de-intercalation.
1602	Estimation of Magnetic Particle Size Distribution for Ferrofluids Based on Nonlinear Programming Optimization and Improved Bayesian Methods	Ferrofluid or magnetic fluid is a new type of functional material made up of nanoscale ferromagnetic particles. It is a colloidal liquid that becomes strongly magnetized in the presence of a magnetic field. For its fundamental research and industrial application, the particle size distribution (PSD) of its magnetic particles is crucial to characterize its material property like flow behavior. This work aims to develop efficient and robust PSD estimation methods for ferrofluids under two cases, known and unknown distribution types. The main task of the first case is to estimate the distribution parameters for a given PSD. For this purpose, Lp norm method is employed to convert the PSD estimation matrix equation into a constrained nonlinear programming problem. Then nonlinear programming method (NPM) is presented to estimate the PSD parameters based on the magnetization data. The main tasks of the second case are to reconstruct the PSD curve and estimate the distribution type and parameters. To achieve these goals, an improved Bayesian method is proposed by using the estimation obtained from NPM as its prior information. Then a non-parameter hypothesis test method, Shapiro-Wilk test method is introduced to determine the distribution type of the PSD. To illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed methods, theoretical analysis and Monte Carlo simulation are conducted based on the material parameters and experimental results of two ferrofluid samples. Through the comparison, it is found that the NPM is less sensitive to the noise like measurement error and it can provide more accurate estimations than conventional inversion methods, such as least square and Bayesian methods. Moreover, the proposed improved Bayesian method is efficient and robust to the noise, which can be used to reconstruct the PSD curves of ferrofluids without using the conventional time-consuming experimental methods like transmission electron microscopy.
1603	Electrical and Thermal Conductivities of Few-layer Armchair Graphene Nanoribbons	The tight-binding Hamiltonian model and the Green's function formalism have been employed to<br />calculate the temperature dependent electrical and electronic thermal conductivities of metal<br />and few-layer armchair graphene nanoribbon semiconductors and the results were compared with<br />the mono-layer system. It was observed that due to the overlapping of the nonhybridized $p_z$<br />orbital perpendicular to the sheets, increasing the layers of the systems causes the conductivities<br />of the layers to decrease. Also, these quantities are calculated for three different values of interlayer<br />hopping of the nonhybridized $p_z$ orbitals. The results show that in low temperatures, the electrical<br />and thermal conductivities of the system increase when the interlayer hopping term is increased.<br />However, by increasing the temperature, the curves representing electrical conductivities converge<br />to the same value while thermal conductivity decreases.
1604	<strong><strong>Lead-free Epitaxial Ferroelectric Heterostructures for Energy Storage Applications</strong></strong>	With the development of electronic devices toward miniaturization, light weight and integration, dielectric film-capacitors for recoverable energy storage have attracted ever-growing interests owing to their fast charging and discharging rate. In continuation to our investigations for achieving high energy density, we have grown lead free BaZr<sub>0.2</sub>Ti<sub>0.8</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (BZT)/ Ba<sub>0.7</sub>Ca<sub>0.3</sub>TiO<sub>3</sub> (BCT) heterostructures and studied the structural, dielectric, ferroelectric and energy density characteristics.  The BZT/BCT bilayer epitaxial heterostructures were grown on LSMO buffered LAO single crystal substrate by optimized pulsed laser deposition technique. The ferroelectric phase transitions have been probed above room temperature with relaxor behavior. These nanostructures show high discharge and charge energy density 9.74 and 26.55 J/cm<sup>3</sup>,<sup> </sup>respectively. These heterostructures show high dielectric permittivity, large polarization and high energy density characteristics well above the room temperature which may be useful for both high power and energy density applications.
1605	<strong>Feasibility of 3D-printed precision scanners</strong>	A flexure-hinge-based nanoscanner, which can be manufactured at home at a low cost is proposed. A prototype of the said scanner, fabricated using a three-dimensional (3D) printer, exhibited a single degree-of-freedom motion. Limitations with regard to material, fabrication precision, and actuator force were overcome, and crosstalk was reduced by designing holes onto the side face of the flexure hinge. Fabrication of such holes could only be facilitated by use of 3D printing technology. Experiments performed in this study demonstrate that the proposed scanner can perform linear motion over a 10-&micro;m distance over a voltage range of 30 V.
1606	Focus Article: Solid-State Nanopore Hydrodynamics and Transport	The resistive pulse method based on measuring the ion current trace as a biomolecule passes through a nanopore has become an important tool in biotechnology for characterizing molecules. A detailed physical understanding of the translocation process is essential if one is to extract the relevant molecular properties from the current signal. In this focus article we review some recent progress in our understanding of hydrodynamic flow and transport through nanometer sized pores. We assume that the problems of interest can be addressed through the use of the continuum version of the equations of hydrodynamic and ion transport. Thus, our discussion is restricted to pores of diameter greater than about ten nanometers: such pores are usually synthetic. We address the fundamental nanopore hydrodynamics and ion transport mechanisms and review the wealth of observed phenomena due to these mechanisms.  We also suggest future ionic circuits that can be synthesized from different ionic modules based on these phenomena and their applications.
1607	Effect of surface residual shear stress on bending stiffness of rectangular micro/nanobeam structures	Surface residual stress and surface elasticity have a strong influence on the bending stiffness of micro/nanofabricated cantilever structures. This study presents a sandwich beam model with two surfaces and a bulk layer to describe the distribution of the surface residual shear stress. By considering the compatibility condition of displacement across the surfaces, we obtain a specific equation of the curvature varied with the surface parameters of prestressed sandwich beam. The solution of the equation of the curvature shows that micro/nanobeam structures undergo axial and bending deformations. The effective modulus of micro/nanobeams can be either positive or negative. The bending stiffness of micro/nanobeam structures can be either larger or smaller than that of bulk beam, which is determined by surface parameters.
1608	<strong>Improvement of response time on hetero-core optical fiber hydrogen sensor utilizing Pd nanoparticles</strong>	A hetero-core optical fiber hydrogen sensor that employs the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) phenomenon has been developed. It utilized spherical Pd nanoparticles, which were able to absorb and release hydrogen more quickly owing to their large surface areaper unit volume compared to that with a Pd thin film.The Pd nanoparticles were immobilized on the surface of the fiber sensor portion bythe electrostatic interaction. The Pd nanoparticle fiber sensor succeeded in detecting hydrogen by observing the difference between the light intensity spectra with and without 4% H<sub>2</sub>in atmospheric N<sub>2</sub>. A change in the optical loss response of 0.32 dB at a fixed 850 nm wavelength, and rise and recovery times of 1.1 s and 2.5 s, respectively, were observed upon exposure to 4% H<sub>2</sub>in atmospheric N<sub>2</sub>, which may be one of the fastest response times among optical fiber hydrogen sensors.
1609	High performance 33.7 GHz surface acoustic wave nanotransducers based on AlScN/diamond/Si substrate	Surface acoustic wave (SAW) devices usually work below 20 GHz, due to constraints of material&rsquo;s performance and fabrication ability. This work breaks through the resonant frequency limit and the highest resonant frequency of excited SAW modes up to 33.7 GHz at Ka-band is reported. To achieve this, a AlScN/diamond layered structure was presented to obtain high electromagnetic coupling coefficient K<sup>2</sup> for SAW, which shows more than 200% higher compared to that of traditional AlN/diamond-based SAW devices. In addition, an improved and robust electron-beam lithography based nanofabrication process termed &ldquo;SELSP&rdquo; was proposed to realize high-resolution IDTs and 30 nm scale IDTs were demonstrated. The performance metrics of the fabricated SAW devices, such as resonant frequency and K<sup>2</sup>, are presented and discussed. This work promotes the development of SAW IDTs for super high frequency applications.
1610	<strong>Property-Structure Relationship in Lead-Free Relaxors</strong><strong> Ba<sub>5</sub>RSn<sub>3</sub>Nb<sub>7</sub>O<sub>30</sub></strong><strong> with Tungsten Bronze Structure</strong>	Lead-free relaxors Ba<sub>5</sub>RSn<sub>3</sub>Nb<sub>7</sub>O<sub>30</sub>(R=La, Nd, Sm) with tetragonal tungsten bronze (TTB) structure were prepared by a standard solid-state reaction process, and the dielectric and ferroelectric properties were systematically determined together with the structures and microstructures. Rietveld refinement result suggested that a single-phase tungsten bronze structure in space group <em>P</em>4/<em>mbm</em> was obtained for all the compositions. Both the dielectric constant (<em>&epsilon;</em>&rsquo;) and dielectric loss (tan<em>&delta;</em>) exhibited a broad maximum with evident frequency dispersion far below room temperature, which indicated the typical relaxor nature. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns revealed that the relaxor behavior in the present system originated from the incommensurate modulation. The dark-field transmission electron microscope (TEM) images confirmed the presence of polar nano regions (PNRs) in the areas generating the satellite reflections of incommensurate modulation, which implied a possible correlation between the incommensurate modulation and polar nano regions in tungsten bronze relaxors.
1611	Interaction between indium tin oxide nanoparticles and ferricytochrome c: conformation, redox state, and adsorption scheme	The conformations and redox states of ferricytochrome c, before and after adsorption onto or collision with the surface of indium tin oxide (ITO) nanoparticle, are studied to understand the interaction between the cytochrome c species and the conducting metal oxide surface. The resonance Raman scattering and the optical absorption spectroscopy reveal that the change of pH at moderate ionic strength induces conformational transitions and redox-state transitions which suggest intramolecular electron transfer associated with the conformation. The conformations of the cytochrome c species are maintained after adsorption onto or collision with the ITO surface, but the redox states are significantly changed and the change depends on the surface structure of the ITO nanoparticles. The adsorption or collision processes are governed by the pH-dependent electrostatic interaction between the proteins and the buffer anions on the ITO surface. This adsorption scheme differs from the traditional one.
1612	Rheological (extensional, shear) and morphological properties of linear low-density polyethylene nanocomposites in the presence of modified and unmodified silica	The objectives of this study are to investigate the effect of modification of silica nanoparticles on the rheological behavior of linear low-density polyethylene (LLDPE) in both shear and extensional flow. The silica nanoparticles surface was modified by silanization reaction and with hexadecyltrimethoxysilane as silane agent. Melt blending method was performed to prepare the nanocomposites samples. Characterization methods included Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and rheometric measurements under shear and uniaxial extensional flows. Sentmanat Extension Rheometer (SER) and parallel plate rheometer were used to investigate rheological behavior of the nanocomposites in extensional and shear flow, respectively. The shear data illustrated that for all samples, storage modulus and complex viscosity of LLDPE with the modified silica nanoparticles were higher than the samples containing unmodified silica. The extensional rheology results showed that regardless of the type of silica, the elongational viscosity becomes larger by the incorporation of silica nanoparticles. LLDPE containing 2 wt.% of the unmodified silica nanoparticles demonstrated strain hardening behavior that was disappeared by increasing loading of the unmodified silica from 2 to 8 wt.%. Another interesting result was obtained for the LLDPE nanocomposite samples containing the modified silica particles. By loading of the modified silica nanoparticles in LLDPE nanocomposite samples, a fracture took place due to gel structure formation in these samples. Finally, Kaye-Bernstein-Kearsley-Zapas (K-BKZ) model was used to correlate the extensional rheological property of the present LLDPE/ SiO2 nanocomposites.
1613	Modulating the semiconducting properties of buckled tin nanotubes by metal/nonmetal codoping: Band gap tunability from DFT computations	By using the density functional theory calculations, the structural and electronic properties of substitutionally doped buckled tin nanotubes were investigated in detail. The dopants (B, N, Al, P) were substituted at two patterns into the structure of armchair and zigzag nanotubes. The results of formation energies indicate that the doped stanene based nanotubes are thermodynamically stable. The band structure calculations indicate that both pristine armchair (8, 8) and zigzag (8, 0) nanotubes act as semiconductors because of their band gap opening around the Fermi level. For the B, Al doped nanotubes, the Fermi level shifts to the valence band edge, whereas in the N, P doped systems, the Fermi level shifts towards the conduction band edge. Thus, the mono-doped systems exhibit metallic characteristics. However, there is a direct band gap between the valence band maximum and conduction band minimum for BN-codoped and AlP-codoped structures, suggesting the semiconductor property of these systems. Therefore, B/N and Al/P pair doping improves the electronic properties of stanene based nanotubes by opening the band gap at the Fermi energy. Total charge density distribution plots show that there is non-zero charge density between the dopants and Sn atoms, representing the formation of covalent bonds between them.
1614	Multi-scale simulations of polymeric nanoparticle aggregation during rapid solventsexchange	Using a multi-scale approach which combines both molecular dynamics (MD) andskinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) simulations, we study a simple and scalable methodsfor fabricating charge-stabilized nanoparticles through a rapid solvent exchange,si.e., Flash NanoPrecipitation (FNP). This multi-scale approach is based on microscopic information from MD simulations, and is able to access macroscopic length- and time-scales using a KMC algorithm, which allows direct comparison with experiments and quantitative predictions. We find good agreement of our simulation results with the experiments. In addition, the model allows us to understand the aggregation mechanism on both microscopic and macroscopic levels, and determine dependence of nanoparticle size on processing parameters such as the mixing rate and the polymer feed concentration. It also provides an estimate for the characteristic growth time of nanoparticles in the FNP process. Our results thus give useful insights for tailoring the FNP technique for fabricating nanoparticles with a specific set of desirable properties for various applications.
1615	<strong>Uniformity Analysis of NbN Nanowires Based on Element Mapping</strong>	Superconducting nanowires with a super-large ratio of length to width are the core components of superconducting nanowire single-photon detectors (SNSPDs).The uniformity of these nanowires directly affects the key parameters of an SNSPD, including the detection efficiency, dark count, and time jitter. Uniformity is also crucial to the response consistency and the product yield of the manufactured devices. In this study, we performed Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) mapping and statistical analysis of NbN nanowires with different widths. Based on this, we established a method to evaluate the homogeneity of superconducting nanowires from the perspective of the element distribution. With the help of AES element imaging, we drew the distribution images of C, N, Nb, Si, and O in the nanowires. Based on graphical analysis, the uniformities of the element distributions in both the transverse and vertical dimensions were discussed, providing an intuitive criterion for optimizing the processing procedure of SNSPDs to improve consistency and product yield.
1616	<strong>Superhydrophobicity resemblance of rebound dynamics of colloidal droplet on miscible colloidal films </strong>	The present article reports a hitherto unexplored phenomenon of colloidal droplet impact dynamics. Colloidal droplets impacting on a thin film of the same colloid exhibits bouncing and rebound dynamics typically observed on superhydrophobic surfaces. Colloids of multiwalled carbon nanotubes, graphene, silica and Poly (3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)-poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) are used to experimentally study the droplet dynamics on respective fluid surfaces upon impact with different initial kinetic energies. The droplets show unique behaviour of complete rebound twice on impact, followed by hovering and complete coalescence. The rebound is an elastic process with dominant energy dissipation due to bouncing induced oscillations and is similar to bounce observed on generic superhydrophobic surfaces. The bouncing behaviour has been explained by appealing to the concepts of surface pressure and elastic component of the interfacial tension in complex     fluids. The restitution coefficient and retraction velocity of the rebound is independent of the viscosity and weakly dependent on the range of impact velocities, which is a signature of superhydrophobicity induced bouncing. Mathematically, the contact time of the colloidal droplets is observed to abide by the scaling law &tau;<sub>c</sub> ~ (&rho;R<sup>3</sup>/&gamma;)<sup>1/2</sup>, which is associated in literature<sup> </sup>to bouncing dynamics on superhydrophobic surfaces. Additionally, the carbon nanotube based colloidal droplets display a unique phenomenon of partial coalescence following rebound and continues multiple steps of cascade and coalesce events. It is proposed that the upward capillary wave mobility and downward fluid drainage compete and govern the possibility of partial or complete coalescence.
1617	&beta;-Ga<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> MOSFET Self Heating and Thermal Management	&beta;-Ga<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3 </sub>is in attractive material for high voltage applications and has the potential for monolithic integration with RF devices. However, the limitation of &beta;-Ga<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>&rsquo;s low thermal conductivity will need to be overcome to achieve high power dissipation devices. A combination of Raman nano-particle thermometry measurement and thermal simulation has been used to investigate self-heating and thermal dissipation in &beta;-Ga<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> MOSFETs. The peak channel temperature is close to the drain edge of the gate, with a measured thermal resistance of 88 mm&middot;K/W. Experimentally validated thermal simulations have been used to investigate different thermal management approaches: Enhanced lateral heat spreading, flip chip, and wafer bonding. Substrate thinning and wafer bonding to a high thermal conductivity carrier is predicted to be the most beneficial, potentially removing most of the heat transport bottleneck associated with the &beta;-Ga<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> substrate.
1618	<strong>Predictive modeling of misfit dislocation induced strain relaxation effect on self-rolling of strain-engineered nanomembranes</strong>	Combining atomistic simulations and continuum modeling, the effects of misfit dislocations on strain relaxation and subsequently self-rolling of strain-engineered nanomembranes have been investigated. Two representative material systems including (GaN/In<sub>0.5</sub>Ga<sub>0.5</sub>N) of wurtzite lattice, and II-VI materials (CdTe/CdTe<sub>0.5</sub>S<sub>0.5</sub>) of zinc-blend lattice were considered. The atomistic characteristics of dislocation and the resulting lattice distorting were first determined by generalized-stacking-fault energy (GSFE) profile and disregistry function obtained through Peierls-Nabarro (PN) model. Those properties were then used to calculate the accurate mismatch strain of those nanomembranes with the presence of dislocations, and as inputs into von-Karman shell theory to quantitatively evaluate the effects on self-rolling curvature and anisotropy. The theoretical results were further confirmed by atomistic simulations of different crystal geometries and dislocation configurations. Our results provide essential theoretical insights towards prediction and design of rollup configurations for strain-engineered nanomembranes containing crystalline defects.
1619	<strong><em>Terahertz Time-Domain Study of Cu Nanoparticles:</em></strong><strong><em>Investigation into The Negative Time Shift Observed for Cu Nanoparticles</em></strong><sup></sup>	<em>We report the investigation of Copper(Cu) nanoparticle colloids(NPs) by using Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy (THz-TDS) technique. THz-TDS measurements are performed on various volumetric concentrations of Cu-NPs. We have observed a different behavior for the Cu NPs when compared with the Silver(Ag) NPs</em><em>. Most interestingly, Cu NPs have shown a gradually increasing  negative time shift and increase in amplitude corresponding  with the increase in the concentration with respect to the reference signal(the host media) instead of the positive time shift and decrease  in the intensity of the THz signal observed for the Ag NPs. We have modeled the observed THz signal peak profiles for the different volumetric concentrations of NPs colloids and determined the phase shifts with high precision. The negative time shifts measured were explained to be caused by the advanced phase shift observed through a dielectric-conductor interface as the electromagnetic field transmits into the absorbing media in the presence of a thin layer formation at the quartz and the colloid interface. We have repeated the measurements(both for Ag NPs and Cu NPs) for aggregation and sedimentation control up to 1 week. The control measurements shown consistent results both for the Ag and Cu NPs. Furthermore we have evidenced the presumed thin film formation at the quartz boundaries by using UV-Visible Spectroscopy technique. For the Cu NPs we have observed a thin film formation on the quartz boundaries but not for the Ag NPs, proving our hypothesis on the different behavior in between the Ag NPs and the Cu NPs. </em>
1620	Modeling of the in-situ nitrogen (N) doping of graphene-carbon nanotube (CNT) hybrids in a plasma medium and their field emission properties	A numerical formalism for investigating the effect of in-situ nitrogen doping (N-doping) on the plasma-assisted growth of graphene-carbon nanotube (CNT) hybrids is established. The growth rate equations for the CNT, graphene and graphene-CNT hybrids are set up considering the energy balance on the catalyst particle and the kinetics of plasma species such as electrons, ions, neutrals of hydrocarbon, hydrogen, and ammonia gas that aid in N-doping. With N-doping, the hydrogen ionic species density initially increases and then falls, promoting the growth of higher order hydrocarbons in plasma. The electron density also rises with N-doping such that the electron-mediated ionization and dissociation processes, increase eventually affecting the availability of growth precursors. The cumulative effect of the variation in the plasma species density with N-doping leads to the growth of nanostructures with high aspect ratio. In the present work, the field enhancement factor ( ) of the graphene-CNT hybrids is approximated as the ratio of its dimension along the y-axis to that along the z-axis. The   of graphene-CNT hybrids is found to be larger than that of the undoped and N-doped CNT and graphene. Moreover, N-doping further enhances the   of graphene-CNT hybrids.
1621	<strong>Bipolar electrocaloric effect in Pb<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Gd<em><sub>x</sub></em>(Mg<sub>1+<em>x</em>/3</sub>Nb<sub>2-<em>x</em>/3</sub>)O<sub>3</sub> ceramic:</strong><strong>relaxor with super-dipolar glass state</strong>	The finding of large electrocaloric (EC) effect in ferroelectric and relaxor materials in the past decade opens a practical way of refrigeration in upcoming era. In this study, the indirect method is employed to investigate the electrocaloric (EC) effect in Pb<sub>1-<em>x</em></sub>Gd<em><sub>x</sub></em>(Mg<sub>1+<em>x</em>/3</sub>Nb<sub>2-<em>x</em>/3</sub>)O<sub>3</sub> relaxors; <em>x</em> = 0 to 0.1 ceramics, synthesized by the Columbite precursor method. Electrocaloric temperature change (<em>&Delta;T<sub>EC</sub></em>) is calculated from temperature dependent heat capacity and <em>P</em>-<em>E</em> hysteresis loop measurements, using a thermodynamic Maxwell equation. Temperature dependence of the <em>P</em>-<em>E</em> hysteresis loop reveals an anomalous behaviour around the glass transition temperature <em>T<sub>g</sub></em> ~ 204 K, at 5 kV/cm applied field for <em>x</em> &ge; 0.05 specimen, which is in the vicinity of a crossover from high-temperature positive to low-temperature negative EC effect. This anomaly has been explained evoking the critical slowing-down upon cooling, of the polar nano-domains&rsquo; dynamics to that of the super-dipolar glass state. The maximum negative EC coefficient <em>&xi;<sub>max</sub></em> is observed to decrease from ~ 0.4 K-mm/kV at 164 K to ~ 0.1 K-mm/kV with increasing Gd-content, where polar nano-domains&rsquo; response to the external electric field is believed to be sluggish.
1622	<strong>Decoupling Thermal and Electronic Transports in Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> Nanowires by Porphyrin Adsorption</strong>	Decoupling the electronic thermal and electrical conductivities is one of the limitations hindering a breakthrough in thermoelectric efficiency. After a conformal surface coating of bismuth telluride nanowires (Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> NWs) by porphyrins, the thermal conductivity increases from 0.8 to 1.0 Wm<sup>-1</sup>K<sup>-1</sup> at 300 K without any obvious change in electrical conductivity. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations assisted by Boltzmann Transport Equation (BTE) simulations of electronic transport properties indicate that the electronic thermal transport is enhanced by the depletion of surface charge carriers, which results by the transition from metallic to semiconducting behavior. Thus, the adsorption of porphyrin onto the Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> NWs layer suppresses the surface electronic conduction, resulting in thermal electronic conduction dictated by the bulk of the NW. The results mean that electronic thermal transport can be decoupled from the electrical conductivity by changing the density of surface states on Bi<sub>2</sub>Te<sub>3</sub> NWs
1623	<em>Loss mechanism and microwave absorption properties of rGO/CIP/PVA composites</em>	In this manuscript, the new type of Micro-nano structure rGO/CIP/PVA composites were fabricated by disperse graphene oxide in the core shell structure of CIP/PVA, aiming to improve the dielectric loss of the composite material not changing the magnetic loss and thus improve the microwave absorption capability.When the electromagnetic wave first reaches the rGO, a part of the wave is absorbed by its dielectric loss, and the other part is through rGO or refraction, which is consumed by the CIP through the magnetic loss.When the thickness was 2.5 mm, the effective absorbing width (reflection loss lower than &minus;10 dB) of composite materials with GO and the prepared CIP/PVA composite at 1 mg/g was about 8.4 GHz.
1624	Molecular screening effects on exciton-carrier interactions in suspend carbon nanotubes	Photoluminescence spectroscopy measurements are performed on suspended carbon nanotubes in a field-effect configuration, and the gate voltage dependence of photoluminescence spectra are compared for the pristine and the molecularly adsorbed states of the nanotubes. We quantify the molecular screening effect on the trion binding energies by determining the energy separation between the bright exciton and the trion emission energies for the two states. The voltage dependence shows narrower voltage regions of constant photoluminescence intensity for the adsorbed states, consistent with a reduction in the electronic bandgap due to screening effects. The charge neutrality points are found to shift after molecular adsorption, which suggests changes in the nanotube chemical potential or the contact metal work function.
1625	Feasibility of 3D-printed precision scanners	A flexure-hinge-based nanoscanner, which can be manufactured at home at a low cost is proposed. A prototype of the said scanner, fabricated using a three-dimensional (3D) printer, exhibited a single degree-of-freedom motion. Limitations with regard to material, fabrication precision, and actuator force were overcome, and crosstalk was reduced by designing holes onto the side face of the flexure hinge. Fabrication of such holes could only be facilitated by use of 3D printing technology. Experiments performed in this study demonstrate that the proposed scanner can perform linear motion over a 10-&#x00B5;m distance over a voltage range of 30 V.
1626	Plasmon-enhanced harmonic generation in hybrid architectures based on nonlinear dielectrics and metal nanostructures	NA
1627	<strong>Ab initio studies on the Sn/Cu interfacial properties during lithiation of Sn anodes </strong>	The high capacities of Sn anodes are accompanied by large volume deformation and diffusion-induced stress, which result in fracture and pulverization of electrodes and electrical disconnection with current collectors. In this paper, by using <em>ab initio</em> simulations, we investigate the influence of lithiation on the Sn/Cu interfacial mechanical properties, such as interfacial strength, fracture location, and debonding. The results show that interfacial strength weakens severely upon lithiation. For most lithiated Sn/Cu interfaces, fracture appears within the Li<em><sub>x</sub></em>Sn slabs. However, at high Li contents, fracture is favorable at the interface regions due to the strong anisotropy of Li<em><sub>x</sub></em>Sn alloys. In addition, Cu<em><sub>x</sub></em>Sn alloys formed at the interface regions could increase the interface strength and enhance the deformation resistance. Based on the simulation results and a linear elastic fracture theory, we construct a diagram that can determine the optimal dimension range of Sn&#x2012;Cu core-shell electrodes. These findings highlight the interfacial failure mechanism of Sn anodes and provide a valuable guide for the design of heterogeneous nanostructure electrodes.
1628	<strong>Structural and Electrical characterization of NaNbO</strong><sub><strong>3</strong></sub><strong>-PVDF Nanocomposites fabricated using Cold Sintering Synthesis Route</strong>	Nanopowders and nanowires of sodium niobate (NaNbO<sub>3</sub>) were synthesized and subsequently used for preparing composites with PVDF using cold sintering technique in the weight ratio of 80:20 (Ceramic: Polymer). Phase purity of ceramic powders and nanowires was confirmed by X- ray diffraction analysis. Different phases of PVDF formed under various process parameters were also identified. TGA analysis was performed in order to check the thermal stability of the composite. SEM was used to study surface morphology of the samples and EDAX analysis also was carried out in order to see the distribution of polymer in the composite. Dielectric constant and loss tangent were measured and compared with theoretically calculated values. Theoretical breakdown strength and energy density were calculated and found to be as high as 1345 kV/cm and 6.1 J/cm<sup>3</sup> respectively at room temperature. Discharge efficiency of 64% was obtained for annealed nanocomposites.
1629	<SPAN style="font-size: 14.0pt; font-family: 'Arial','sans-serif';">Morphology dependent resonance modes in highly porous TiO<sub>2</sub> microsphere</SPAN>	Micro and nano structures of Titanium Dioxide (TiO<sub>2</sub>) are well-known for their photocatalytic application. High surface area and high light scattering efficiency in such structures enhance their photocatalytic activity. The present work explores the possibility of enhancing photocatalytic activity through mesoporous TiO<sub>2</sub> spheres by exploiting the coexistence of high porosity and morphology dependent resonance (MDR) modes. A controlled synthesis of TiO<sub>2</sub> spheres with nano-crystalline grains of anatase phase and high surface area of about 96m<sup>2</sup>/g has been successfully accomplished leading to mesoporous particles with uniformly distributed pores of small diameters much less than wavelength of incident light. Despite the high porosity, MDR modes are observed in photoluminescence (PL) spectrum of a single sphere. As inclusion of pores may produce significant changes in the refractive index (RI) of the resonator, and as the quality and density of the modes depend on the RI of the resonator, it is important to have a procedure to determine the RI of the resonator as well as to characterize the MDR modes. An iterative procedure that is quite general is presented for mode identification and for the determination of the porosity-induced reduction in the RI and for ascertaining the presence of chromatic dispersion. Presence of high surface area as well as of MDR modes of reasonably high Q-factor makes these particles promising for photo electrochemical applications.
1630	Influence of TiO2 Nanoparticle size on creeping flashover property of  Transformer Oil-Impregnated Pressboards	Nanoparticles have exhibited great potential in improving insulating property of liquid and solid dielectrics. To explore their modification mechanism on transformer oil-impregnated pressboards, TiO2 nanoparticles with different diameters of 5nm, 10nm, and 15nm were synthesized and used to prepare transformer oil-based nanofluids. The creeping flashover characteristics of both pure oil-impregnated paperboards (OPs) and nanofluid-impregnated pressboards (NPs) were examined under lightning impulse and AC voltages. It was found that the creeping flashover property of NPs is significantly improved with the decreasing of nanoparticle size. Especially, it is enhanced by 2.44 times under positive lighting impulse as nanoparticle size reduced from 15 nm to 5 nm. The results of space charge decay and trap characteristics reveal the decrease of nanoparticle size can lower trap depth and greatly enhance the space charge dissipation rate, leading to more uniform electric field distribution at the interface between nanofluid and pressboards and higher creeping flashover property.
